I bought it excited to play this and the Co-op and was let down. Before buying just know the co-op does not feel like co-op, more so feels like you went to a friends house and you shared a controller. Have fun watching your one friend fish and you have to sit and wait until he is done. If people could go and check out something while someone is doing something else it would be much more enjoyable, but as is you are forced into doing things you do want if your friend gets curious.

Also have fun fighting if you guys are expecting turn based, speed is not a factor in this game and you all fight for who goes 1st or 2nd and in my 1 hour of playtime it has already made the team crumble. I enjoy games where the faster you are the faster you can go sometimes even overlapping slow characters, not in this game though lmao. 

Overall the game has an amazing idea and I wish my first hour was more enjoyable but it is missing key features most "Turn Based" RPG games have and I was very letdown. Refunded as of now, might try again if the game gets tweaked for the better.

TLDR: An excellent roguelike featuring turn-based tactical combat in the style of XCOM that mixes in elements from Darkest Dungeon (Eg. Camping Skills). I would recommend Shardpunk: Verminfall to anyone that enjoys or is looking to get into this particular genre of games - especially at this price point. 

Having just finished my first successful run on normal, which I binged over the course of 9 hours, I have to say that it's quite the compact yet fairly polished experience. The core combat loop is extremely enjoyable and is fairly similar to XCOM in this regards, where good positioning and target priority is highly rewarded. This is complimented by an excellent soundscape and a banger OST, which creates a wonderful atmosphere of perpetual tension ‚Äî which really comes to forefront in the lulls between combat encounters. 

The game, much to my surprise, also has an excellent tutorial stage. To someone who is new to the genre, it does a good job of bringing the player up to speed on the key game systems and guiding them on how they actually work in practice by introducing important complexities - such as how Weapon Heat interacts with Overwatch. As such, the tutorial is quite useful for veterans of the genre as well, as it clearly explains and demonstrates mechanics which either iterate on the X-COM formula or a simply brand new (Ohhh Looting Spree my beloved)

Whilst I could go on at length about how I enjoyed all these iterations/additions to the X-COM formula, the sheer excitement and/or panic that I experienced when I interacted with them for the first-time is something I highly recommend that you experience yourself. 

Just wanted to close out this review by thanking Splattercatgaming for featuring this game on their channel, as I would have never have stumbled across this game myself.
Fantastic gameplay and amazing racing mechanics!

I'm impressed with the beautifully rendered backgrounds and thoroughly enjoying the story so far. However, to enhance the immersion of being in the environments, I believe some movement would be beneficial. The interactive dialogue with the characters is a standout feature, making it feel like you're truly there with them.

To further improve the experience, it would be helpful if there were an autodialogue option on a timer, based on the conversations. The current left-click interaction is limiting. Additionally, implementing more colour on the UI and adding keyboard shortcuts such as 1, 2, 3 to select tone options would be a helpful addition.

Overall, the character building is great due to the good writing and dialog options the decision-making yields satisfying results. The game is fun and engaging.

Definitely not as bad as people make it out to be, yes, your starting cards are trash, and your starting tribe might not be for you, but it's really not that difficult to grind out a couple runs to unlock some good cards. Now the RNG and difficult fights, the #1 complaint of this game, they are heavily RNG dependent with your starting cards, but do a few runs and get better starting cards, I assure you, you'll get past the first fight no problem. Next up is synergies, and just because one card does something with health in it's description, doesn't mean that another card with health in it's description will synergize well.

All that being said, you have to play it to get good at it, and you have to play it to see the interesting cards and conditions. You can't just boot it up and be good at it, that's not the point of a roguelike-deckbuilder, let alone a roguelike.

In interest of full disclosure, I was predisposed to disliking this game knowing this was the reason Undergrad Steve handed off writing duties on CK to a couple of hacks. That being said, I really like CK so I knew he could make a decent game and that was enough to convince me to spend the money to give the game a chance. And now, having given the game a chance, my review:

1) Technically the game is fine with the notable exception of the sex scene that wasn't because when I clicked on Yes for manual control, it went by so quickly (and I don't mean the scene was short. I mean it was like somebody hit fast forward and the pages zipped by) that it was basically over before it started. A bit like losing your virginity. 

2) The graphics are fine. Nothing much to say one way or the other. 

3) The writing. This game tries to be serious and funny and doesn't succeed at either one. The MC is whiny and inept, but can suddenly transform into super smooth once you figure out the secret formula (and you will because it's a trope, and a bad one at that).  Your friends seem to exist for no reason other than to further highlight said ineptitude. Most AVNs, or at least the ones I've played, are mindless lighthearted sex romps. Some actually have a little bit of a plot that works in between sex scenes. Some have the potential for a good plot depending on how it develops. Unscripted is none of these. It aims for clever and winds up at contrived. 

Final word: It might be your cup of tea, but for me, Unscripted is Refunded.

Great things the game does:

When you beat the game your team that beat the game becomes the new end boss for the next run. Amazing because you have to plan your new run on countering your old broken team. Very strategic.

Random starting hero card. So cool rolling the dice and getting a new hero every time.

Bad stuff is RNG can end runs early because you die on like the first boss. Even many runs in this still sometimes happens for me. 

Some enemies are too strong, I hope to get some easy encounters and dread getting others. And a bug for developers to fix, rng ended a run just now where an enemy card had a teeth modifier charm, but the text didnt show up on the card because it already had a full card of text.

All my guys attacked the teeth charm card and died, and I obviously wasnt given a warning in text only the small little charm in the bottom left. Text needs to be scaleable so if it runs off the card it will just put the front smaller to show up on the card.

This review will cover both volumes of the collection. I am reviewing as a newcomer to the series.

I'm going to start by going over the part that isn't the games themselves: The main menu stuff. Right off the bat you're introduced to a fully voice acted Mega Man.exe who will greet you. There does not appear to be any sort of subtitles option in the release version of the collections, so if you switch the language to one you don't understand you might not get the full benefit of the change in voice actor. Mega Man will greet you every time you boot up the game, and from what I have heard he will even sometimes have different things to say based on the time of day. There's an interact button if you want to make him talk, although the pool of things he has to say doesn't appear to be very large. I so far cannot confirm whether he gains more things to say as you progress in the games. He's overall nothing too complex, but he's a harmless inclusion. If you want him to be quiet, you can also just simply mute him. Pre-orders received cosmetic skins for him, they do nothing other than change his appearance slightly and give him some minor new dialogue. They do not apply to the in-game look, only the main menu.

In regards to other main menu features, it's comparable to the Zero/ZX collection released in 2020. Unlike collections prior to Zero/ZX, there doesn't appear to be any merchandise you can look at or trailers to watch. There's an option to download battle chips, which appears to only work once per save file per game. Volume 2 seems to have a lot more right off the bat. Depending on which volume you're playing at the moment you can listen to the various music from each game and even set one to play as the main menu music, and you have a gallery of artwork based on the games in the volume you're currently in.

As for the games themselves, a noteworthy change compared to previous collections is that entering the collection settings menu doesn't pause the in-game music. I don't really know anything about the content compared to the original releases, but I do know that there's a new font being used for text. There's a filter you can toggle on and off, though the CRT filter of previous collections is missing. It's not really missed in my opinion. With the filter on, there appears to still be stray elements here and there that remain unfiltered, and with the filter off there's still some things that are smoothed out such as certain text elements. It's generally not a big deal, though if you prefer the filter on for some reason you might be annoyed by how many pixels are still visible.

Like previous collections you can choose a border to occupy the space outside of the original aspect ratio. Noteworthy however is the apparent lack of an option to disable borders entirely. If you like having black borders surrounding your retro games instead of stylized artwork, that sadly doesn't seem to be possible here as far as I can tell. You can also choose what size to display the game at on screen. There's small, medium, large, and largest. Largest is as close to full screen as you can get. Testing at 1080p appears to preserve pixel scaling regardless of in-game screen size settings, so you don't have to worry about any misshapen pixels. However, I have heard reports of alternative monitor resolutions not producing perfect pixel scaling. This issue does generally seem to be easier to solve than previous collections however.

A noteworthy inclusion is the new Buster Max mode. This can be toggled both while you are on the main menu and in the collection settings menu in-game at any time. It changes your standard buster attack to do 100 points of damage, trivializing encounters. You can use this as a sort of easy mode, as a way to speed up grinding, or just generally as you see fit. The collection does not punish you for using this in any way, even in regards to achievement collection. It's up to you to decide whether you want to use it or not.

Unfortunately as a newcomer to the series, I don't have much to comment on regarding content inclusions for each game. My understanding is that almost all of the content for each game is here including previously Japanese exclusive content, however my knowledge is limited to the pre-release marketing as I have never played these games before now. I am aware of a new online component regarding trading/battling with other players, but I have not used this feature yet personally.

Overall, the collection doesn't seem to disappoint. It's exactly what it seems to be, and has pretty much everything you could want from such a collection. I'd recommend saving up for the bundle with both volumes and/or waiting for a sale. While I do feel as though the content offered here is worth the release price, I also understand that many people might not be able to afford it at that price. That's okay, don't feel pressured to impulse buy here if it's looking like a bit much for you.
Whazzat? You want summa DIS whiskey?

Besides the stupid Denuvo DRM, the game runs pretty smooth with no issues. 

Here you have a collection of battle network games from 1-3, and it seems like the trophys are linked for all 3 games instead of it separately... I'm personally going for a 100% completion which means I have to play it more than once. 

The menus are clean and simple as you are greeted with a Modren 3D model of Megan.exe with the original voice actor from the anime... There is different language options and changing your language does change the logos of the games which is cool but it's still the same game don't be confused that it's some "different version" or anything just because of the logo change for another language. 

In terms of gameplay there isn't anything new, it's basically the same gameplay from the GBA games.

Was is new however is buster MAX mode that allows you to do 100x the damage of your normal buster shot, which is EXTREMELY helpful especially for the first game that doesn't have an escape button.... I don't think I have to remind everyone here how much of a labyrinth structure MESS the first game's internet areas are... And because they are a mess you keep running into enemies that without the escape chip your forced to fight, every, single, TIME... But thanks to Buster MAX mode you can make quick work of this mess. It also doesn't effect trophys, so go ahead and use it if you get stuck, it makes grinding for chips and zennys easier too. 

Extra features include the exclusive battle network Japanese only chips that you can immediately download and use at the start of the game.... they are very overpowered in the early game but if you think you feel guilty about using them early don't..... these games spike up in difficulty. There is also the Japanese only 499 patch cards they added but those are separate from these battle chips and you won't be able to use those until Mega Man Battle Network 4 which is in collection 2. 

Capcom also added online fighting and online trading to all the games, I haven't tested these features yet as it's still pretty early for people to be using it. 

There is a HD filter that makes it less pixelated, in my opinion it looks fine and does make it easier on the eyes but that's just me. 

You can also have different custom borders, which is a neat little addition. 

And then you have the usual MegaMan Collection stuff with the art galleries and music players.... You can actually run as specific music piece to play as your main menu theme though so that's nice. 

Overall your getting a lot of bang for your buck here, definitely recommend getting it.

Great port, one my favorite gba/megaman games ever made. Steep price, but it is well implemented and offers lots of features that were previously hard to obtain + online play.

Super fun rouge-like! I just finished playing hades and was looking for something to scratch that itch. bonus that it‚Äôs more of a bite-sized (pun intended version) rouge lite that I can squeeze in a few plays during a break or a lunch). Love the retro 2D look and it plays smoothly.
I will admit, it is way different than what i was expecting, but! it's not a total L. have great potential, awesome weapons, and it's free. Can't really complain. i'll give it a solid 7.5/10.

Game feels great but being a slow paced TPS game, this is a game of "peekaboo", which means everyone and their moms are hiding behind cover and using Third Person view to check for enemies.

Another problem is classes' weapons, in other shooter games, all "classes" have weapons that doesn't make them useless, here some operators just have bad weapons and you can't do a thing with it, there is a reason why Medics and Marksman are never used while in other shooters they're always filled first, their weapons SUCKS, marksman in special, they have no option to change to another main weapon so your best bet is either the VSS or a DMR with high fire rate because most "snipers" don't kill on headshot and because of that, you're always looking for at least 2 shots to kill people.

Some small problems would be progression, like, you need to play a lot with your operator to "level him up" and then unlock passive/talents to bulk him up, you pay an in-game currency for that, I reckon that it should take quite some time (maybe 8~20 hours?) of playtime with an operator to fully unlock him...and then unlock other operators to use their passive on other operators too...in any case, I don't feel like this one is a major problem because it adds progression to the game.

In any case, this game is a hard pass, specially if you're not into TPS shooters, if it were an FPS game then the slow paced combat and the need of awareness would definetely make this a good game, as of now, I can't recommend it to anyone.

- 5v5 matches

- Character classes

- You start out with basic weapons and iron sights. All other weapons and attachments are locked behind scoring dozens or hundreds of kills.

- Movement is a bit slow. This isn't going to scratch the Titanfall or Tribes itch. 

- Seems mechanically sound aside from some issues like roll being slow. 

- MTX, Battle passes, fortnite style funny skins, like the tiger mascot space suit that early backers unlock

- Mechanics are easy to learn if you've done any 6DOF movement game. It took me all of ten minutes and half of that was re-binding keys. If you haven't played 6DOF games before it might be harder to learn, but you shouldn't let it intimidate you. Remember that the enemy gate is down and you'll be fine. 

I wish their was a "meh" option instead of yes or no. If you're looking for something different from Fortnite and CoD and CS:GO, and you don't mind grinding for hours to unlock red dot sights, I'd say it's worth checking out, but it's not a strong endorsement. I'm put off by the small teams, the small maps, the inclusion of sniper rifles (in a 6DOF game snipers can go anywhere in the play volume, making them much more frustrating to deal with than in flat games), and the requirement to grind for weapons and equipment in a small team competitive game.

The settings has no FOV slider and you cannot edit or customize your in game UI like the mini-map's position. Another issue I saw was that your username doesn't show and instead shows the in game names that are random to a degree. Gun customize is very good but feels as tho in certain areas its lacking in the parts and guns. Tilting is slow and needs to be tweaked just a little bit faster in my opinion but others may think otherwise. With all this I still suggest the game and give it a positive review. The reason being is because compare to many other early access, this game is pretty spot on even when I played it in alpha. Gun plays good, movement is good, concept is good, and it gives the itch and customization I'm looking for. I think with a little more time over this year until its full release it can upgrade and add more things as its open to the devs to listen to community and try there best to keep it going. It will need content if they want this game to survive. Eventually they will have ranked but they don't as of currently. I think this game is worth a try and just needs support and feedback as it grows during early access.

Its exactly what it claims to be: Its a legacy collection of the MMBN games. Its not a remaster, its not a remake, its all of the games in two packages. They give you extra goodies like artwork, music player, and other things, but please don't go into this assuming its going to be some upgraded reboot with crazy HD features. They never promised that. If you enjoyed MMBN (I definitely did), you'll enjoy this. If you didn't like the MMBN games, you wont enjoy this, Also, its best to play this game with controller. Some people complained about the lack of remappable controls, but I maybe I'm too much of a causal to care. I play most games with controller anyways, especially 2D games. 

The ONLY thing that I don't like about this collection is the Buster Max mode. Its too OP of a option and I hate having the option to take an easy route in games. Id rather the temptation not be there, But considering that its an optional option (Im using that word "option" as if I have no other word options), I'm going to keep it turned off. Buster Max will take away the fun of the game for me, but its good for if you revisit areas that you already beat and want to look for any loot you missed without dealing with battles. You also don't want to use Buster Max if you plan on playing online unless you are already a master at the game, otherwise, you wont understand the mechanics of the game and all of the cards and your skills are going to atrophy. You will get deleted like an "I'm sorry" text to your ex. 

Overall: Get it! Its really fun! But try not to use Buster Max except for grinding. Play the game the way it was originally meant to be played and you'll have a blasty blast. :)

I'm not gonna recommend this game. I'm sure people will enjoy it, but for a fully released game, I don't believe there is enough content here to justify its $10 pre-sale price tag. As much as I like the concept, I believe it is held back by a few factors: 
1. The weapon variety isn't fleshed out enough. I think that 4 weapons is good, but the weapons themselves (besides the rocket launcher) didn't bring me to try different playstyles. The minigun is essentially a faster firing pistol, and the shotgun is typically the best gun for most situations.
2. Level design. Aside from a few levels, they mostly play the same. All trucks are the same size, all cars are cars, It would've been cool to use bits of the environment more as a way to navigate. The enemy placement is another thing, and is noticed towards the end especially. They tend to be spread out or condensed, but the AI doesn't like the latter so they tend to trickle towards you unless you rush in.
3. Movement. The movement is fine, and I don't want to compare this to ultrakill too much, but for a game that is all about fast paced movement, it is really difficult to keep up momentum. The only truly fast way of moving is the grapplehook, which stops you at its point. Dashing out of it still loses that momentum. It would have been nice if movement focused on that momentum that surges you forward, since the game forces you to move ahead.
4. Enemies. There is little enemy variety. When combined with weird placement, it feels as though there are no challenges. In my game, the #1 reason I died was the tunnel level, where signs and pipes instakill you. They also kill all of the enemies, so it just becomes "run forward and dodge." It would have been nice to see enemies have to be taken out in different ways. Melee enemies are always killed in a kick, but what if they could block it or counter? I never really felt endangered in my time to just run into a group of melee guys and kick them. 
5. Time. It took me 39 minutes to beat the "main game." And while yes, there is infinite mode, that is just not for me. I kept expecting as I played through the game that there would be some big moment, something that would test my skills toward the end. Instead, it tests whether you remember to use your grappling hook. It left a sour taste in my mouth. 

To Conclude, it's not a bad game, but because of the factors I mentioned above, I cannot recommend it in its current state. As much as I dislike early access, this game should be labeled it. It doesn't feel like a fully released game, with nominative amount of content for its price. This game ends with a cliffhanger stating that it will be continued, but that isn't enough for me to recommend it. Just because I do not recommend it does not mean it is a bad game, there is probably something there for people, but not for me. 

P.S. for the devs
If you want to improve this game, please prove that it is not a unity asset flip by continuing development. Go beyond being a copy of the clustertruck formula. There's a lot more I could say, but I'll just leave as this: prove me wrong.

Also, I wish there were more camp events, certain companions would form rivalries etc. as they do in Wildermyth but that isn't really in this, you have relationship +1/-1 and thats it, doesnt do much in terms of group dynamic or anything. Or like in XCOM or rimworld where if a character dies in combat it negatively impacts the other people, if they liked the person or positively impacts if they hated the guy or something like that. Needs more flavour events

Also people dying isnt end of the world so I would recommend not save scumming, if somebody dies they die. Sad event but you move on and hire new people, great stuff. Rest in peace Sibric

Awesome little game! Can't believe it's only $10. I think it's worth more than that. Takes inspiration from a lot of great games, from XCOM, to Vermintide (obviously) to Darkest Dungeon, but also doing it's own thing too! Graphics are perfect for this kind of game/setting imo. The game is tough but fair if you're smart. Characters are awesome, I'm a huge fan of the sniper and katana lady you can start with. Pew pew! Slash Slash!

Mission variety is decent too and your automaton is fun to pilot. Only thing I didn't quite expect is that this is a roguelike also. You get permanent unlocks and just start a new game when you fail. Not my favorite thing, but makes sense for a small game like this. I didn't quite reach the end of the first section, so not sure how many more there are. but I'm curious to find out.

Spoiler warning

This game is about half as long as Chapter One was, even if you do every optional case. That by itself is disappointing, but the story is also really lackluster.

A Lovecraftian story needs to have unexplainable cosmic horror. A Sherlock Holmes story, meanwhile, need to have every mystery explained in impressive detail. So a Lovecraft story where Holmes is the protagonist can't have both; it has to pick one. Either Cthulhu is real, or Sherlock figures out that it was just a squid-shaped hot air balloon that was part of some plan to steal the crown jewels and murder the butler. Frogwares, bizarrely, chose the option of "neither". Nothing truly unexplainable happens, and Sherlock never wraps up the mystery.

Three times in the game Sherlock has hallucinations of some alien landscape where he has to solve some (trivially easy) puzzle to get out. Despite there being multiple obvious explanations for the visions, namely that he was drugged and envisioned landscapes that were implanted into him subliminally by all the bizarre paintings hung around the bad guys' lairs. Sherlock suggests that the visions are caused by drugs a few times, but inexplicably dismisses the idea as if it weren't less ridiculous than many of his other deductions in the games (and books). But for some reason, this causes Holmes' sanity to completely unravel. It's like Frogwares wanted to go full-Lovecraft with the story, but didn't have the guts to pull the trigger and have an actual eldritch abomination show up. I know they were somewhat tied to the plot of the original game, but why stick with the original plot when they rebuilt everything else?

Thankfully, there's multiple murder mysteries you get to solve along the way. Unfortunately, they don't get the attention they deserve. The worst example is in the insane asylum when you find the director dead after discovering all the horrible things she was doing to inmates. You examine the body, and then without even determining the killer he's like "we got what we need, let's get out of here". It's implied that it was Gerda who killed the director, but since when has a Sherlock Holmes murder been so straightforward? It was such a wasted opportunity for a murder case in an insane asylum. And the game's short length could have used the help.

And on top of all that, the mystery-solving segments are all pretty easy. The most challenging part of them is figuring out what you can interact with (I played on the hard setting where they can't be highlighted). Everything basically falls into place after you find everything to interact with, and the mind palace portions can be easily cheesed by just spamming all your evidence into the equation until something sticks. It's a LOT less challenging than Chapter One was.

In short, if you liked Chapter One, you might like this, but will feel disappointed. If you didn't like Chapter One, you won't like this at all. I'm more disappointed than anything.

This review is coming from someone who has no history with Pinball or Pinball FX3!

I'm happy to see this finally make its debut on Steam (after a year of Epic Games exclusivity)! As a newbie to the Pinball scene, I'd say this is a nice entry. You get a few free tables to start with and then can purchase more tables as DLC; this business model of free game + DLCs makes sense as I doubt they could encase every licensed DLC within a single (reasonable) price, and still make it profitable.

The big elephant in the room is that previously, players could transfer their DLCs from Pinball FX2 to Pinball FX3 for free, as those two games ran on the same engine, and thus, there was basically no labour involved to move assets from one entry to another. The problem here is that this title makes the jump to the Unreal Engine, and thus, porting the older tables to this newer game required the devs to do manual work. As such, they're now charging again for these tables, whereas loyal fans are conditioned to expect to be able to transfer their previously purchased tables for free, as they have been able to before. This isn't a problem for new players, but again, fans who have purchased tables before are disappointed.

As an outsider looking in, I can understand the frustration; it can be debated whether the graphics were even improved, and thus, whether it worth jumping to a new engine or not in the first place. People don't want to pay for what's essentially same thing twice. On the other hand, I've seen multiple players act as though they MUST purchase the new DLCs. It's not like you're losing access to the tables you purchased 5+ years ago, those are still accessible in the phenomenal Pinball FX3, thankfully. I think expecting DLCs to be transferable isn't necessarily the norm in the gaming industry, so it's unfortunate that Zen Studios have put themselves in this situation where it's expected of them now. The DLC bundles that offer a discount for those who already own the tables from older games are a nice middle-ground, but not one everyone is satisfied with. I'm not sure what an alternative could be.

I also think the optimization / performance of this game is a bit questionable. I have to play on lowest settings at 720p to reach 60 FPS on my Steam Deck, which is a bit of a bummer. Perhaps this can be ironed out down the line via updates.

As for the game itself, it's Pinball! Lots of tables to checkout, with flashy effects and addictive sound design. I think if you're a newcomer, you'll really enjoy this game (provided you're willing to purchase / rent tables), but if you're a long-time fan, you may only have interest in this game's exclusive tables, and otherwise, you'll likely want to stick to FX3. If previous DLCs were transferable, I'm sure this game would have a much better review score. That's the biggest contention point.

Plantera 2: Golden Acorn is a sequel to the popular farming and idle game, Plantera. It is a relaxing and engaging game where you grow and manage your own garden. The game has colorful and detailed graphics, pleasant music, and simple controls, making it easy to pick up and play.

In this game, your main objective is to collect Golden Acorns that come from the oak tree. These acorns can be used to unlock new features and upgrades. You start with a small garden and gradually expand it by planting various crops and trees and placing decorations. As you progress, you'll encounter different types of crops and animals, each with their own unique characteristics and requirements.

The game also features unwelcome guests like moles, crows, rabbits, and even a UFO, which can eat your crops or dig up your garden, causing damage and reducing your Golden Acorn production. However, you can protect your garden by clicking on them, hiring guard dogs, bees, and scarecrows to chase them away.

Plantera 2: Golden Acorn is a well-designed and enjoyable idle game that provides a relaxing experience. With its fun and engaging gameplay, the ability to expand your garden, and protect it from unwelcome guests, the game is definitely worth playing. Whether you're a fan of idle games or just looking for a fun and relaxing game to play, Plantera 2: Golden Acorn is a great choice.

This review was written by someone who is somewhat into many game genres, though not very relevant to this genre. I would like to list the important parts that I see in the game without any distinction between positives and negatives. (So ‚Äã‚Äãyou can decide for yourself <3)

- I want to start with the gameplay time. I'm playing the game incredibly slow in a really chill mode. That's why I haven't seen every card and event in the game even though it's been over 8 hours. Therefore, based on the comments made to see all the cards, we can say that it has a gameplay of 8-10 hours. (For the early access version. And this period will be extended with new cards and events to come as long as it stays in early access.)

- Our goal in the game is to create a city based on random cards from our deck. And while doing so, it's important to keep your citizens happy. At this point, we come to the importance of balance. A difficult objective card (the red ones) at the beginning of the game can make your game really difficult as the cards come randomly. But since we depend on a few conditions to lose the game, we can say that the structure is balanced at this point. (At the beginning level of the game, the objective cards can be very difficult. But as you continue playing in a short time, the bonuses gained make this difficulty more bearable.)

- There are troubles, disasters and festivals as random events in the game. Since these are subject to a certain condition, we can slow down or speed up their arrival. I think these random events are enough for the early access phase and add excitement to the game. For example, we can lose our important buildings in case of an earthquake, or we can turn all the cards we draw into road cards with a new feature. (Come on, who likes a leader who doesn't make some road?)

- The map size did not satisfy me. In fact, the game needs to have a more appropriately sized map than it currently has. A map that is too small will not be large enough to accommodate game content. On the other hand, a very large map may show less content than it actually is. I think this needs improvement.

- I think that the small cosmetics on the table other than our game board are enough for now. Definitely an in-game currency and store should come. Or, if additional packages are to be made for the game, such cosmetics should be added to them. (But these will definitely be reserved for the full version of the game and will have no effect on gameplay.)

- Thank you for taking time to read my review. I hope this helped you to get a little idea about the game. Have fun in your Cardboard Town¬†my¬†friend¬†<3

This review is going to be in 3 parts. The first will be directed at people new to the series, the second at everyone, and third at existing MMBN fans. 

Before getting to that though, I'm just going to start with my opinion: yes I recommend it, but I'm a MMBN fan so of course I would say that, I want people to get this game so that Capcom could see this be popular and make a new game, so the rest of this review is just trying to be informative. 

Part 1: For New People

The Mega Man Battle Network games were a collection of action RPGs (mostly) for the GBA games. This collection and the simultaneously released Vol 2 contain all of the 6 numbered entries (all except the first two entries were split into 2 versions like Pokemon, hence the "10 games" in marketing). This collection contains the first 3, and vol. 2 contains 4-6.

The gameplay is a little difficult to describe. Combat takes place on a 6x3 grid, where the left 3x3 is where you can move around, and the right 3x3 is where your enemies can move. 5 battle chips are drawn from your deck of 30, which you select based on shared letter (think "suit" of card) and shared chip type. You battle for 9 seconds, where you can move on the grid, use your chips, and/or your (relatively weak) megabuster.  after which you can choose to return to chip selection, and repeat until the enemy is defeated.  This system is expanded upon as the game goes on and becomes increasingly nuanced and complex (the final entry supports a robust PvP meta, for example), but these basics are upheld. 

This system would later go on to inspire One Step from Eden. Unlike One Step from Eden, however, this game isn't a rougelike. There is a set story, involving Lan Hikari in the real world, who operates Mega Man.exe, his Net Navi, in the cyberworld, in their fight against viruses and a (game-dependent) terrorist organization. Generally Lan moves in the real world, finds a place for Mega Man to "jack-in" and enter either a local network or the internet. On the internet, battles come from in the form of random encounters.

The game's stories aren't really their strong point. It is mostly typical shounen fare, often hindered by awkward localization with numerous typos (particularly in BN 4). Most of the fun is derived from improving your chip folder and skills as you fight ever stronger navis. The games have a lot of mechanical depth, particularly the later entries, which lets players spend a lot time tinkering with folder set-up.

In general, 1 and 4 are considered to be the weakest games. 1 is janky in the way that first entries often are, and 4 suffers from a series of poor design decisions and a particularly atrocious translation effort. 3 and 6 are generally considered the highlights. 3 for its post-game and varied settings, and 6 for its gameplay and PvP. Playing the games in order is recommended, but if you aren't enjoying 1, you can try skipping to 6 to see if the series is for you at all. Or 3 if you only have this collection. Speaking of which, this bundle is $40 for the first 3 games, and the other is also $40, but you can get both for $60 if you get the bundle, which you probably should if you think you'll like these games.

Some tips:
1) Buster Max mode is basically a "cheat" mode that puts your base buster power to 100 and can let you breeze through the games. Keep this in mind if this is something you are interested in, even if just for speeding up grinding.
2) If you are struggling and don't want to resort to the above, try reducing the number of letter codes in your folder. Putting a bunch of powerful chips is great and all, butt if you are only getting one chip each turn, you are going to be much less effective.
3) The Rockman Exe Zone has a very helpful wiki that is well organized if you ever want to consult a resource.

Part 2: For Everyone

This collection has added online support with a (simplistic) ranked system for battling other players. Not all of the games are balanced, but 6 in particular is balanced in a way which has lead a competitive scene existing for it (and has had decent-sized following for several years now). I expect that to continue in this collection once people have gotten themselves solid collections of chips to participate in it.

Also new to the collection are the ability to gain "download chips" which were Japanese only event chips at a press of a button. Similarly, one can use "patch cards" which were Japanese-only E-reader cards which were used for a variety of things. Mega Man is also voiced in the title screen, and will have a variety of things to say depending on the circumstances when playing the game. You can look at a variety of artwork and promotion material for the games, and listen to music from the games (and see achievements linked to the Steam achievements).

Part 3: For Existing MMBN Fans

The in game changes are relatively minor. Ever game has a "buster-max" mode which lets you put your base megabuster damage to 100 if you want to just skip through some tedious parts of the games. The text has been replaced from the pixelated ones with new high resolution ones. The games are all based on the JP versions, so there isn't any cut content (well, except Botkai Crossover battles in 6 and Beast Gate content), so there is more content than the GBA Western release. You can change languages in the option menu on the same save, which can be nice for those learning Japanese and/or Chinese. There is a filter option which starts as on by default, but you can turn it off (I personally do). There are also borders you can select around the game, but there is no "no border" option for those of you who do not like it. Some bugs were patched out, and some were kept in single-player but patched out of PvP battles. Enumerating which were are beyond the scope of this review, but you can check out fan communities for detailed info if you are interested, like Rockman exe corner and Team Battle Network.

Some bugs have been introduced, however. A minor visual one involving sprites looking like they are standing on the player character is somewhat common. More seriously, the MMBN6 Virus Battler rewards currently are set to the ones from the western GBA release which is problematic, so you should change your language to Japanese when doing it until that is fixed.

Another minor annoyance is with the soundtrack currently being a mono version of it, rather than Stereo which was in the GBA games. I imagine there will be a fan patch for this in the near future. Another is that the game used Denuvo. However, Capcom usually removes it a year or two after release, if previous releases are anything to go by, so it probably won't be permanent.
Hehe

Tried EA version and was very excited for the full release but the game actually got worse. Spent the first 30 minutes just slowly moving to a nearby settlement. By the time I got there party was half tired. It also seems like they slowed down pretty much everything just to make it appear that the game is longer than it actually is and they also added some very frustrating grind elements. Combat is punishing and not in a good way. You can lower the difficulty but that makes the game extremely boring. Also party management, unlocks and professions is very poorly implemented. There are some nice elements hidden somewhere under all this bs but I dont have the time or patience to figure all of that out. Might be worth revisiting when it is on a deep sale.

Thought that this would be a meme game, but a lot of it stood on its own.  Some parts were pretty janky, like walking animations playing during dialogue sometimes, but it'll probably be patched out. The first level was short, while some are long and could even be made as their own game.  The detective world was pretty unique, would have liked it if it was expanded on, and the pokemon-esque world was the best one IMO.

Overall, it was enjoyable to play, worth a buy despite it only being around 3 hours.  Would like DLC in the future of some more worlds, hopefully a bit longer in length.

An interesting looking Vampire Survival Clone held back by lacking information, mechanics and QoL options.

[list]There is none of the following:
    [*]Achievements
    [*]Controller Support
    [*]Descriptions with detailed information in Shops, Upgrade Selection or When unlocking new "Talents"
    [*]No Display of when an Attack is going to go off or what level it is at.
    [*]No Weapon Fusions, or fun modifications. (Everything is Just +1 Projectile or -0.025 Cooldown)
    [*]No Dashing, Shielding, blocking, countering or any means to avoid the bullet hell from coming to end you.
    [*]DPS Chart of what weapon has done how much damage, most damage, etc.
    [*]No way to check the current level or total upgrades you have on a Weapon during a run.
[/list]

The character Select Page doesn't show your unlocked Bonuses as a + amount. You have to enter a mission and hit ESC just to see how much you've gained.

Snickerdoodle is a worthless Weapon. It does like 3 DMG a hit and takes ages to hit anything. It also only strikes very close enemies. Even if you move while the animation is going off or an enemy is standing near the "cookie" looking attack circle, it doesn't do damage to them.

Other worthless Weapons include:
the Bubble one where it shoots 4 shots on angles. Dmg is too low.
the stupid gems that float around you. Doesn't knockback enemies and dmg is too low.
The bouncing book only bounces once then explodes into nothingness. At least the dmg isn't low.

The "Fork" weapon while hits hard and crits hard, does not pierce multiple enemies or at least attacks fast enough to make it worthwhile.

Upgrading "Power" does not make me FEEL powerful. Sure, it has increased my damage EVER SO SLIGHTLY... I got from doing 6 DMG to 8 DMG. Wow, gee thanks.

When unlocking new Talents or Weapons, it actually only unlocks them for purchase in the shop. Which it does not tell you this. EVEN THE NEW STAGE HAS TO BE PURCHASED FROM THE SHOP AFTER UNLOCKING IT. Piss right off with that nonsense. Sure, it's cheap but this is stupid.
Nice game, great aesthetics.

Where do I start with [i]EIGTBOK[/i]?

I first played the game on Itch several years ago-- it's been long enough now that I truly can't remember how I originally found it. I could've just been looking for new and unique indie games. Boy, did I get my wish.

A little context here, since people read reviews to see if they'll like something or not: [i]EIGTBOK[/i] is a fantastic collection of bizarre and engaging little minigames and hidden secrets on the world's weirdest desktop, but it's also what many would weightily appellate an "Art Game‚Ñ¢", so if you get cold feet about an author being frank and open about their life or your adventures through multicolor cyberspace occasionally being interrupted by grim reminders of the real world, go now or forever hold your peace.

There, that's your tl;dr.

Still here? Good. I like you.

[i]Everything is going to be OK[/i] is not just a game about the Internet, or trauma, or the stress of being an artist. It is a stupendous crescendo to the author's previous works in the vein of web art, spanning everywhere from [i]BlueSuburbia[/i] (waiting with baited breath for that remake...) to [i]Tetrageddon[/i], and far predating pale imitators like Hypnospace Outlaw and the endless parade of other Weird Desktop Simulators we've seen in more recent years. It is the work of someone who is truly in love with their medium of choice. Nothing included is there to snag a merch deal with Hot Topic or turn into a popular Twitter meme, it's all painfully genuine, even and especially the silliest bits. 

It almost feels a little too intimate at times-- wading through the cheerfully suicidal bunnies and whimsically creaking cyberbones, it feels a bit like peaking into someone's very old and very weathered diary, new sheaves of paper shoved in every few years or so to extend its life, and consequentially expand your view of the feelings and events described within. It's fitting that so much of the more hidden content in the game is literal poetry.

Every playthrough I try to go through the little ritual of wading through the numbered programs in "order" (Numbered 'Pages', then 'missing' pages), but it's inevitable that anyone would get lost on the labyrinth somewhere along the way. This is what I would consider a feature, not a bug. Further down the line, several applications you find seem to be re-purposed or reinvigorated Alienmelon projects from days of yore, frankensteined back to life here for your enjoyment. Contest entries, desktop pets, other programs of obscure origin and even vaguer purpose. It is, and I mean this as high praise, a shockingly dense text for a solo project.

Replaying it for this review, I even found new things I somehow hadn't stumbled across before-- I'm STILL not sure how many sound effects are in the duckmonkey music minigame, for example. I can't imagine how long that must've taken to record and program. And towards the end I discovered an entire essay, hiding away in one small button. (No, I won't tell you where. That's for YOU to figure out!)

Everything Is Going To Be OK has made me cackle like a madman. It has made me contemplate my own life and the choices I've made. It has made me cry like a child. But, most pertinently to the point I am trying to make, again and again it restores my faith in video games as an art and storytelling medium. Maybe everything really [i]is[/i] going to be okay.

...Also, like, it's been in the MoMA. If that sweetens the pot for you at all.



(P.S.: My personal favorite is page 10. Little wormy was SO right about everything.)

Rewind or Die" is a thrilling and gruesome horror game that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. As a fan of Puppet Combo's previous works, I was excited to try out their latest creation and I wasn't disappointed.

The game's retro aesthetic and VHS-style visuals create a truly immersive and nostalgic experience, reminiscent of classic horror films from the 80s and 90s. The gameplay is challenging, but never feels unfair or frustrating, as you navigate through eerie environments and encounter terrifying enemies.

One of the standout features of "Rewind or Die" is its unique "rewind" mechanic, which allows players to go back in time and try again if they meet a gruesome end. This adds an interesting layer of strategy to the game, as you must plan your movements and actions carefully in order to avoid being killed.

The sound design in "Rewind or Die" is also worth mentioning, as it adds to the game's overall atmosphere and sense of dread. The music and sound effects are expertly crafted to create an unsettling and immersive experience.

Overall, "Rewind or Die" is a fantastic horror game that I would highly recommend to fans of the genre, especially those who appreciate Puppet Combo's unique and creative approach to horror gaming. With its retro style, challenging gameplay, and innovative mechanics, "Rewind or Die" is sure to keep you entertained and terrified for hours on end.

Dang, I was excited for this one. The atmosphere and setting is there, but there's a lot that brings it down. I'll do a pros and cons list:

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The setting - Like I said earlier, the level design and visuals are fantastic, definitely up there with the rest of the Torture Star/Puppet Combo games. If anything, it might even take the #1 spot.
    [*]The villain - Not too much to say here as most villains in these games don't get much development past their looks and actions. The pig look is freaky and cool looking, and his sprint animation is pretty scary too.
    [*]The scares - If you're not into random and unnecessary jump scares, this game might annoy you. But they got me good and I enjoyed them, so it's a pro for me.
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The music - There is not a lot of music in this game. Not a huge deal, but my biggest issue is with the chase music, which you're going to hear a lot. The heavy metal song itself sounds cool, but it really takes me out of the experience. It's not scary at all, it's only startling because that means you're about to be chased.
    [*]The puzzles - You can turn your brain off for the entire game basically. The most engaging parts of the game were the sudden jump scares and chases. 
    [*]No sense of urgency - I never felt on edge except for one chapter of the game, where the killer is actually roaming around the level. Take Murderhouse or Stay Out Of The House for example, you have to complete puzzles WHILE the killer is actively looking for you, I always felt extremely anxious entering new rooms in those games. The killer, aside from scripted sequences, is no where near you for the majority of this game.

The game felt like it was about to get really good the entire time, and then it just ended. Unfortunate, because I did enjoy my time for a little bit; it just fell super flat.

This game is great with headphones and in the dark if you want to build even more immersion. I was playing this with the light on with my Wife beside me we jumped so hard way too many times. I give this game 4 Meat Hooks out of 5.

For you not interested in my rant that will follow. I am in love with wildfrost allready. I have watched streamers for many more hours playing it, besides my own experience with the game. It does not deserve the mixed reviews. Personally I put it up there after Monster Train and Vault of the Void. Two of the best card games in my opinion.

The first runs, on the starting difficulty are easy. And I have died 15+ times before beating the boss the first time. Wildfrost expects you to pay attention to the board, plan your moves. Your dmg output and your HP pool. The action economy instead of mana is implemented in a genious way, but in the end, it is a game you have to learn to play as if it was your first card game. And that is what I believe makes everyone think it is unballanced. Your skills from other card games come into this one, but you have to adapt them.

I would highly suggest catching a stream of Celerity or Esty8nine on twitch if you are not sure if Wildfrost is for you. The communities there are awesome, and can help you decide.

Every run is so interesting, the cards interact in so many ways depending on the board and the modifiers on them (charms).  It is crazy how polished the game is mechanically. The run variety is amazing. The unlocks add to the complexity of the game gradually. There are 3 factions that play quite differently. And overall feels so fresh in a game genre where the majority of games are more of the same formula, or not so good attempts to innovate.

An amazing card game!

I love this game! It has a really cute art style and tons of charm. There are plenty of fun and workable synergies, and a lot of neat unlocks. I'm writing this review because I really enjoy this game and I'm deeply saddened to see so many negative reviews, especially when I disagree with their theses.

A lot of the negative reviews focus on game balance, and RNG.
To preface, I've played both demo cycles of this game, and have currently won two runs. (9 hrs of playtime)
I think it would definitely be good if some cards got re-balance love, but most cards are very obviously good, or not so good. This is very normal for rogue-like deckbuilders! Some tools are bad, unless you're already severely lacking in them.
This game isn't necessarily easy, despite the art style, and you should not necessarily win every run!

I believe a lot of players are either not thinking through their turns properly, or are not used to the style of gameplay this game revolves around (Each unit has a turn timer until it triggers). The rng in this game is sometimes punishing (as is the nature of rogue-likes), but it never feels unfair. If your deck is based around abusing a single mechanic, prepare to lose if you find yourself against a horde of enemies built to counter it! Building decks with tools to counter your counters is essential.

I think the game could benefit from some ui quality of life changes, (hovering over enemy charms and being able to see their effects, undoing held cards is sometimes finicky), but overall this game is amazing. I highly recommend it.
Game is good, polished fully complete fun rogue like being released. Difficulty can be patched if it is a legitimate issue. It is a good game.

Art style, music, and gameplay is phenomenal. The difficulty feels it needs to be balanced but I might also just be bad at games. Only quality of life thing as I'm writing this is I feel can be fixed is when you fail a run there is a button that exits to desktop and if playing with controller that's the default option selected. Because of this its way too easy to accidentally close out of the game. It'd be better if the button was for exiting to main menu.

Criticism noted can all be attributed to the game launching two days ago and needs to be minorly balanced. Otherwise it's a fantastic game with amazing gameplay that I cannot recommend enough

I love Pinball FX3 and 2 and have played about 530 hours in both games. I didn't like Zen's move to be Epic-inclusive for some time (a year or so), but understand that they had to do it because of financial reasons.

Now that FX is finally available on Steam I was excited and had my wallet ready to buy all tables at launch, something I had done in all those years of FX2 and FX3. But the wait was not worth it.

Table physics are better and more realistic now, not just on real-life machines (Williams tables etc.), but on all of them. As I haven't really played the real machines, the physics of FX3 were ok to me...but I guess, they are better now...so it's a point for Zen.

However, there's not more to like at the moment...

+/good:
1) Physics
2) New tables available

~/average:
You have to buy all tables you own in FX3 again. It's understandable though as nobody works for free.

-/bad:

1) The whole idea to launch FX instead of keeping FX3 and releasing new tables for it

2) UI and menus: I prefer FX3. In the German localization a lot of menus have shortened text that looks odd. Filtering tables and tournaments is tedious and fiddly.

3) Option menu: You cannot even assign buttons freely, but have to use presets. A to shoot, B to change camera like I'm used to from FX3 is not possible.

4) The graphics are a bit better, but at first glance, the remastered FX3 tables just look like there was a cheap filter or effect added. I am used to the old look and graphics...they were good enough.

5) "Modern" full-color DMD: I'm 43 and used to the charm of retro displays. I know some new real-life machines such as The Hobbit have full-color DMDs with actual film footage, but I don't like them either. I prefer the old look.

To sum up, the physics are better than in FX3, you get some new tables, but that's it. I really don't like the decision to develop a whole new engine instead of keeping FX3 and releasing tables for it! Everything was good enough there or even better.

Well i'm not going to bash the pricing cause I know it takes money to acquire more licenses and we can always play fx3 tables if we don't want to re buy.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
[list]
    [*][b]Pixel art[/b]: The pixel art, as evident from the screenshots, is gorgeous. There's lots of little details, like the grass being pushed down under your feet as you walk over it, that are easy to overlook but definitely add up to something beautiful.
    [*][b]Grappling, in theory[/b]: The grappling, when it works, is great. Slingshotting yourself over hazards is satisfying.
[/list]

[h1]The Not-As-Good[/h1]
[list]
    [*][b]Grappling, in practice[/b]: There is basically no tutorial section or guidance on how to utilize the grappling system to its greatest potential. Many times during boss fights I would think, [i]how the hell am I supposed to avoid that attack?[/i] because I couldn't find a way to grapple that allowed me to...you know...avoid the attack. This made some fights feel like marathon slogs because of one seemingly impossible-to-dodge attack. (Yes, I'm sure there's been no-hit runs of this game. No, I'm not capable of such a feat.) Many jumping puzzles look possible to do with your current ability set, but are actually meant for later in the game once you have new abilities -- however, no obvious indication is given that you're wasting your time. Many jumps are [i]just[/i] out of reach, and when you don't make them, it creates a moment of "Am I just messing up grappling hook physics, or is this legitimately not possible to do at this point?"
    [*][b]Player guns[/b]: I found that I basically always had to have the trinket that extends the range of my bullets attached because, otherwise, it seemed like I had to basically be kissing the bosses in order to hit them. And when every boss is capable of killing you in 2-3 hits, being so close simply is not a feasible strategy at times unless you've managed to memorize every attack of every phase. With the paltry coinage that enemies dropped, I found myself wanting to avoid fighting enemies because the gunplay is so mediocre at the best of times that I didn't want to risk losing health (or worse, dying and losing a chunk of progress) because I had to be on top of the enemies in order to hit them. I mean, the first gun that the game gives you is basically a rapid-fire charge gun. Why do I have to be four feet away from the target to effectively use it?
    [*][b]Difficulty[/b]: I was prepared for a challenge. I wasn't prepared for an amazingly un-fun challenge. Don't know how to use the grapple effectively because the game didn't teach you the basics? Have fun trying one puzzle jump dozens of times until, somehow, you manage to make it across...only to be faced with [i]another[/i] puzzle jump that requires multiple attempts. And don't you dare die at this point, because death sends you back to your last save and undoes all of your progress -- say goodbye to completed rooms and acquired items, and have fun going to get them again.
    [*][b]Protagonist, or lack thereof[/b]: I read the dialogue. I found bits of lore. And I'm still REALLY confused on who I'm supposed to root for in this game. You'd think the player character, right? Well, no, she blew up a lab full of innocents to kickstart the game, and she thinks a story where everyone in a village drowns for no reason is "humorous." Maybe the characters we fight are the ones to support- ah, no, apparently they kill kids and torture the fae. I played up through three or four major bosses and about a dozen map regions, and I didn't find a single character that I liked and/or wanted to support. EVERYONE seems like a terrible, terrible person.
    [*][b]One grapple per boots-on-the-ground[/b]: Maybe this is fixed by a later ability, but with a grappling hook, doesn't it make sense to want to chain together grapples through difficult areas in order to create a satisfying series of jumps? Locking the grapple ability to once per use until you land on the ground again made every jumping section a case of "How do I get to that patch of ground. Okay, how do I get to THAT patch of ground. Okay, now how about THAT patch of ground." Really feels like a missed opportunity to create some interesting and challenging platforming sections.
    [*][b]Discerning important objects from each other[/b]: Many boss fights were made more difficult for me simply because I couldn't tell what was my bullet, what was an enemy bullet/sword/whatever, what part of the boss (if any) caused contact damage and when, and what was a background element. For instance, with the boss fight with all the swords (for those who played to that part, you know the one), I found that, in phase 2, the swords that locked onto your position were colored like they were in the background right up until they fly directly at you from eight feet away.
    [*][b]Healing, grenades, and One Bar to Charge Them All[/b]: the devs took a page from Hollow Knight's book and tied both your heal and your ranged attack to a chargeable meter. But whereas Hollow Knight made that an obvious and integral part of the game, I found myself chipping away at enemies trying to slowly charge the bar just so I could get another weak heal out of it. I never used the ranged attack other than to open doors that required it because, well, why would I waste my mana on a ranged attack that is VERY easy to miss when I could instead save it for another heal that could potentially save me from having to restart a platforming section or a challenging boss?
[/list]

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
If you're hard up for a "Metroidvania" (I use that term loosely here, since new movement/traversal abilites seem very sparse at least in the early game) and want to try a game with interesting-but-confusing movement mechanics, consider Rusted Moss. If you just want another Metroidvania, grab...literally anything else in the genre, honestly.

EDIT: I just checked, and seriously? Achievements tied to speedrunning with certain completion requirements? Oh, **** off.

Games pretty fun. It's very open after the tutorial boss with lots of places to explore and items to find though some areas are much more difficult to do earlier. I generally haven't liked grapple systems in the games I've played but this one worked for some reason. Combat is pretty eh, it's not really bad but I don't think there is much to write home about. It's mostly trivial with a few exceptions that require a fairly high degree of precision(It's mostly contained to 1 area). A few times they make you do combat in weird scenarios which I like but there are also quite a lot of boring battle rooms where you just fight 3-5 generic enemies in a boring battle arena. Death is fairly punishing though outside of one area save points are pretty abundant. The mediocre combat is made up for by the platforming segments being extremely fun and reward creativity with most of them having multiple ways of going about them depending on your skill with the games physics engine. There is also a ton of speed tech you can learn if you want to go fast. There are few bugs but none of them were very disruptive and it seems like they'll be patched out soon.

Took me about 17 hours to 100% but others may spend much longer. Pick it up if you like very open metroidvanias with lots of fun movement tech.

Right. I have a lot positive to say, and very little negative. Like, no negatives at all. And for reference, I did 2 playthroughs for testing on both the Steam Deck and standard Windows PC, and I can safely say this is one of the most enjoyable games I have played in a while. It absolutely doesn't waste your time, and absolutely rewards replays. I will cover what I enjoyed, cause there's nothing I disliked, and then talk about some wee bugs I encountered, which weren't game breaking or anything, so they weren't bad... at all, really. And also in the case of Steam Deck, it could be down to the preset Proton it uses causing issues.

So what are the positives?
-Amazing music
-Fun characters. I am british, and the game is british, so it's a no brainer that I enjoyed the humour that comes from the characters. I absolutely appreciated the design of the killer too
-Amazing artstyle and colour scheme
-The easter egg(s) and references to pop culture were enjoyable to find and understand
-The game is only about 4 hours long per playthrough, which is short and sweet, and something I appreciate alot more as I grow older
-Just play the game, you'll understand more fully. It's absolutely worth every playthrough.

You mentioned issues with the game?!?!!??!?
Barely, but yes, which is absolutely why I did two playthroughs, just to see what the difference between Steam Deck and my laptop were.....but there still weren't alot of issues, either. Pretty much all it comes down to is:
-Steam Deck had some flickering textures, some minor performance stutters, but only really affected my experience for a few seconds everytime it happened. I played on Handheld at 60hz, but didn't test docked because I'm too lazy to plug it in again. But if you only have a Steam Deck, you won't have any real issues with it on there, and the trackpads will also be very helpful in your adventure, and you have to be absolutely mindful of Proton, especially when the game is unsupported, there is no real telling what exactly will happen with the game, so do keep that in mind
-Game specific...... I found a way to glitch deeper beside a locker with the door in the security room by just walking into it while it was opening up, and moving the camera around a bit to get yourself fully lodged in there. But literally all you have to do to get out is close the door and it'll send you flying to the other side of the room. I don't even see it as an issue, it's quite entertaining to do. I couldn't find any issues the Steam Deck didn't have already, so both experiences are absolutely amazing from the getgo.

So overall?
I've never been so hooked on a game in my life, and I really do mean that. Especially because of the length of the game, I couldn't help but just continue playing till the end, and even to 100% every achievement. The environment is so pretty to look at, you can pet the dog and enjoy a nifty 4 hour tale about a pig killer doing killer things. Not much else to say, apart from what was already in the bullet points..... ALTHOUGH, do not play with the VHS filter off. The flickering becomes much more of a problem with it off, and even shows off unique flickering to the filter being off, which I suppose the VHS filter is able to hide. It definitely ruins the vibe of the game, but I totally get why such a feature is implemented, and I'm not gonna put that as a negative for it. It's helpful for those that need it, but at least currently, it's quite hard to look at. But otherwise, the game is amazing, and you should absolutely play it now.

I really like the controls, they are simple and work really well but I dislike almost everything else.
The style of the game and the musics are pretty good too.

There is 28 arenas but they all feel the same and are very small.
You have a random powerup spawner in the middle, some walls around it and environmental hazards like lasers and fires that can damage the cars most of the time located in the edges of the map.
There is no reward for exploration since the spawner is alway in the middle, there isn't several of them and there is no destructible walls or anything like that.

The powerups aren't very satisfying to use.
One give you extra speed but you don't care because the arenas are super cramped anyway.
There is one that give you youre special but the way it work is meh.
You press right mouse button then you see youre character appear in youre screen and every opponent on the map instantly die from what I understand.
Would've been cool if every character had a different specials and also if you would have to aim with it instead of just killing everybody on the spot.
Apart from that there is the health and invincibility ones that are self explanatory.

The story is badly made but it's because the developper is clearly a kid.
I'm not an english speaker but the way the characters speak is very rudimentary.
The story present itself on the form of very slow powerpoints between each battles you do but you can't skip these and you can't click to make the pages pass faster.
Imo the story us pretty cringy but since the developper is a kid I'll cut him some slack, I don't care about the story anyway, I was here for the gameplay.

The way you fight is very meh.
Imagine you are playing Twisted Metal so you have the base machinegun that you can alway shoot with because it has infinite ammo, but you have no other weapons apart from the special that spawn from time to time for you or a bot to pick up and again, you don't have to aim with it, it just kill everybody on the map.
That's honestly boring.
Also there isn't really physics in this game, so you can't push the bots into the hazards to kill them and there is also no collision damage from what I've seen.
The only creative thing you can do is wait for them to get stuck into a hazard or a wall and stay on their ass to prevent them from backing out or turning while shooting them for extra damage.

There is 4 different characters but apart from them having different storys and endings, there isn't much point to having several of them because they all play the same, their cars aren't very different apart from their colours and the special is the same for each of them.

If you are reading this dev please don't take this review personally because you have a lot of potential.
Imo making a game like that as a kid is pretty impressive.
The controls are so f*cking good, I like the idea of steering with the mouse and having the possibility to freelook with it by pressing the middle mouse button.
The game look cool, I love it's Tron style and the electronic music.
I feel what hurt it the most is that there isn't enough variety in gameplay like in old games like Twisted Metal or Vigilante 8 apart from the characters having each their storys and endings.
Legit as a base concept this game is very solid, the bones are really good.

Ignore the bad reviews talking about bad connection or the game being boring.

A: You can select the regions you want to connect to on the matchmaking tab, it'll take a bit of time before everyone sees this and goes to their respective regions. (side note I want the game to remember what regions I have selected when I reboot it)

B: The game just came out in EARLY ACCESS of course it is not going to have a major amount of content because that takes time. (I would very much like to see a competitive game mode and also some modes with more than 5v5)

Since you're in space, where there is no air, you have have 2 health bars, One is your suit, the more you get hit, the more it will go down but sometimes it will become punctured in which you need to patch it up, which doesn't take long but the more you wait, the more it will drain your second health bar, oxygen, if it runs out then you pass out and die, pretty simple, the only time you have to worry about running out is if your suit is punctured. 

This game is a dream to play, the gun play is pretty cool due to there being nothing quite like it on the market. The zero gravity really flips how you think about recoil and range. Also the physics are very interesting, with your gun's recoil pushing you back certain distances depending on the type of ammo fired. As well as on certain maps you can pressurize rooms which eliminates your oxygen bar while you are in the room, you can also open a door which will launch you out into the map (think of the gravity launchers in Apex Legends).

You can also customize your astronaut which is cool but I wish there were more cosmetics (probably will come with time; side note I really, really want country flags as patches).

Overall its a super unique game and I'm very excited to see what else the developers have in the future.

I'd say buy this if you have money to spare.

I loved the Demo! But the full release game is crippling in difficulty. The first boss you'll face is relatively easy. To give you an idea, you'll have 1 mini boss fight. After that you'll get 2-3 random bonuses you can collect. It may be an extra hero card or it can be a charm to boost a single cards damage. Then you fight the second mini boss. This one is a bit tougher and whatever you've set yourself up for will decide whether you get destroyed quickly. If the 1st fight is a 2/10 for difficulty, I'd say the second one is a 4/10.

After you beat the second boss you'll get another 2-3 bonuses including an option to visit a shop to buy charms or cards with the money you earned on the last 2 fights. What you do at this point is extremely important and if you feel like you've barely made it through the second fight then you might as well just start over because the 3rd fight is easily a 10/10 for difficulty and it's brutal. It's the "main boss" fight for this chapter of the game. The mechanics and how quickly the enemies advances is nearly impossible if you don't look up a card meta which just always seems silly to me in video games. Like why look up a meta so that I can auto pilot an adventure game just to say I beat it. You might as well hire a robot to beat the game for you. Anyway, I digress.

The issue here is that you've literally only fought 2 battles at this point. Now the 3rd being the main boss fight and only 6 chances to gear up seems pretty crazy considering the boss mechanics. You will fight 1 of 2 main bosses here but they both have a similar second phase mechanic where they either split into 2 smaller version of themselves or they gain 1 attack every single time they hit you. One of the bosses comes out with a hero card with a turn cooldown of 1. So it has a turn every round. Oh yeah, that same card gains 1 attack each turn. So it just snowballs damage. So while you have 3-4 cards on the field, the enemy has all 5. 2 of which are snowballing damage, 1 gives you a debuff that doubles your damage received, and the other does equal damage to its health every 3rd turn which is 6 damage. Most hero cards only have 5-8 health lol.

It's an absolute shit show of a fight and at first I was like "I enjoy a challenge. I'll start building a deck and creating a cool build to do this fight" and in 5 hours, 25 runs later, I beat it once only to die right after on the second chapter on the first fight.

The boss fights really need nerfed. I think the damages are fine and add a challenging component to deck building but 3 fights? dude. I cant even get out of the first chapter. I'm tired of seeing the snow. Devs. PLEASE. HOW DID THIS EVEN GET BETA TESTED LIKE THIS.

Remake > Original

Yep, you read that right. The remake of the classic SH game The Awakened is fantastic and the expanded storyline alongside the the side cases (which are quite a lot compared to what I expected) make it so much better than the original. I am a proud backer of the kickstarter campaign for this project. I have no regrets. It was worth it.

The story is almost the same, some minor changes here and there. It was rewritten to fit in the new timeline. There are some references to Chapter One but if you're a new player, don't worry. You can play it as a standalone game. You are in for a real treat !

The characters, what can I say ? The chemistry between the new friends-to-be Holmes and Watson is on point. This journey tests their relationship to the maximum.

The music is splendid. It makes the experience even more immersive. The dark atmoshpere of the game is *chef's kiss*.

The gameplay mechanics are the same as Chapter One's with some little differences. There is the mind palace (which is different from the previous games), deductions, pin an evidence to search for more clues, interact with people, you can change Holmes and Watson's clother.

The graphics are great, the game ran very smoothly. The team did a great job in optimizing it.

Frogwares deserves all the praise and our respect for what they've done. Delivering a game in such tough times and in so little time...it's incredible. The game was announced in July 2022 and now in April 2023 we are playing it. Frogwares, I take my hat off before you ! Well done !
