Actual gameplay: endless loop of defending villages and raiding outposts.

A wonderful survival game with a unique and interesting story and setting. Features a wide array of beautiful (and terrifying) animals and other creatures. This review is based on the demo which I played and enjoyed extensively!

A single player survival game that focuses on story and survival in equal measure. 

You must find the fabled fountain of youth.  All the while balancing food, hydration, and energy.  This balancing game is all the more important because when you die, you die for good.  Any time you run out of health you will faint.  Fainting causes you to lose maximum health.  When that maximum health runs out you give up the ghost.  Death can however be delayed by drinking the water of life from jugs hidden around ancient ruins.

Crafting allows you to take from the resources of the Island of Hope and make things to further increase your chance of survival.  Craft medicines to deal with the multiple types of illness or injury looking to put you in the ground.  Make better armor and weapons to deal with the animals of this island.  Build yourself rafts and other bigger vessels to explore the local area and find new islands to explore and plunder for your new beach side base.

The devs have so far completed 2 of the 5 total zones in the game allowing for much exploration and adventuring.  They are very open to the feedback of the players so make sure to leave your ideas on the Survival FOY discord.  If the devs can keep up with the work they have done so far this will be one of the best survival games on steam.

Before I played Desktop Dungeons i had a small wee wee, no friends, no girlfriend, depression and absolutely no will to live. None of these things have changed, but the game is pretty good.

Desktop Dungeons is a fun puzzle RPG played over small grid-based dungeons with trips back to town in between to refresh and plan the next adventure - think Darkest Dungeon. But instead of a consistent roster of characters making progress over many dungeon runs, each run begins with a Level 1 newb of a chosen Kin/Class combination.

The map starts out mostly hidden, with a mix of walls, monsters, and loot scattered throughout. Using your chosen character's unique skill combination, your goal is to navigate the semi-open floor plan dungeon in search of the boss monster. Monsters are static in nature - they stand in one spot and don't attack you unless you attack them, so you get to pick and choose the timing of your combats to maximize your experience. And maximize you will, as enemies are not bags of loot, but bags of precious experience needed to level up and reach a high enough level to face the boss monster in combat.

Sounds like a pretty standard RPG, so why is it a puzzle RPG? 

To start with there's basically never enough monsters in the map to attain maximum level just fighting fair. Monsters are worth more XP if they're above your level when you kill them, so you're incentivized to fight them early. But then you're also taking more damage as you go and there's limited healing items, so you're planning to hit those precious full-heal level ups as you go. 

Fortunately, every new map space you uncover grants you health and mana back. So you could punch the monster, then uncover some map to gain back health and mana ... but they'll get a chance to heal up too, so your attacks were less useful. Oh wait, but you could hit them a couple times, kill a really weak monster that pushes you over into a new level, get the full-heal, and THEN come back for round 2 with the big monster! Assuming you remembered to leave some weak monsters around - you did start planning which monsters you would prioritize killing first, right? Oh, and of course there's all this great treasure lying on the floor to make you stronger - but that means exploring into the fog, which will burn your precious chances to heal up later.

Ooo, wait, this spell I found turns a monster to stone so I don't get XP for it, but then it makes the next monster worth 50% more exp. So if I turn a Level 1 monster to stone and kill something big, I'll get more bonus exp for killing the big monster than I would get for killing them separately. And it'll also create a barrier that I can throw this other monster into for damage. And ...

Now you're really playing Desktop Dungeons.

Also - as a long-time owner of the original Desktop Dungeons, they sent this to me free of charge!

It took a few hours for me to actually fall a decision:"Should I buy it, should I buy the Deluxe Edition or should I not buy it at all?"
I've purchased the Deluxe Edition. Some may call me crazy, some people are calling me crazy anyways, but that's a story for another day, anyways, where did I stop? Oh, right: Some people may call me crazy for spending 49,99‚Ç¨ for this game, and I totally understand why. As someone who started playing minecraft since Beta 1.5, who's still playing "The Settlers 2: The Next Generation", who played with castles as a child and joined a medival RP-PVE-PVP factions Minecraft Server in 2012, I can find joy in this game.

Of course, the game is young, has a few bugs that can make walls fly in the air for example and features the can let your place building on nether territory (destory the buildings (I forgot what they're called) that are meant to make the air more breathable for piglins and less for overworld inhabitants -> some blocks underneath it will change back into grass blocks where you can place towers for example), but exactly because it's young the game has still a lot of bugfix and content update potential.

I personally wished this game, and games in general were less expensive, because for many people that much money is a lot, some of use don't have jobs (yet), don't earn much money or have a lot of expenses. The current price is not really one a lot of people are willing to pay, especially with the option option of the "Deluxe Edition" is like 25% more expensive than its normal version and its main feature is to add one more character and a few more mount skins(?) to the game.

This leads to another for me controversial topic -> Skins and Microtransactions:
A really important, at least for me really important, feature of minecraft is the creation, upload and wearing of player skins. Skins help you to individualize your ingame representation, fuel creativity, make you feel more one with a game.
Sadly Minecraft Legends took a path of a list of player-skin-models you can select with not much liberty to customize your character. It has its reasons, like facial expressions of the characters and earning more money through minecoins and some of the characters are wearing pretty outfits (my fav. outfit is the green-brown one, since it reminds me about one of my main minecraft skins I've pixeled over seven years ago), but giving players to dress a character differently, combine, individualize even more, is something that would make the game more worth playing. This could be through a 3D-skin-upload, or even if just a character designer.

[Some text I wanted to write, but I forgot what I planned to write. Here some more things I've remembered in a list format:]
- It would be nice if we could give our game saves names.

I enjoy the game, but I wished there were more features, bug fixes, maybe even a feature to play as the piglins in multiplayer and that the game wouldn't cost that much.

I gave it a thumbs up and hope that price, etc. will change in the future.

PS: I've set all of my settings I found ingame to english, but still the characters are talking in german to me, how do I change it to english?

I haven't been so disappointed in a while. The demo for Gun Jam was a highlight of 2022 for me, but the full release just falls completely flat and its a shame.

The linear "checkpoint"-style levels with bespoke tracks tuned to the level timings (or so it felt anyways) got basically replaced by 3 arena-style levels that last way too long and just become boring. There is one checkpoint-style level left, but due to any song being playable on any level it doesnt have the tight feel of the demo anymore.

Another big thing is that it feels like the main tracks arent manually beatmapped anymore, the shots are way more sparse and they do not feel like they align with tracks too well, as if it is just auto-mapped the same way you can auto map your own tracks now (which is appreciated).

Its just such a letdown overall. The demo felt pretty tight in terms of rhythm, and the checkpoint style was the highlight, mixing fast navigation while shooting enemies to fit into every section on time, together with more open arenas that would come around during very fitting parts of the song.

The worst part is that you can see how it was in the 3rd steam trailer and judge for yourself.

The UI also somehow got a downgrade? While it can be treated as less intrusive - with everything glowing on screen - its harder to see  now that numbers dont have a backdrop, and instead are just floating white text on the screen.

There are also bugs, or what feels like bugs anyways. You can clear arenas without killing all the enemies somehow? The boss healthbars do not update, enemies get stuck on things and you can't find them sometimes. Also the gun sounds feel way undertuned and hard to hear. And the icons for beat types (single hit vs hold) arent clear or explained. There is also no tutorial whatsoever, even tho the demo at least showed controls on screen and provided basic objectives to get you started.

TL;DR This release of gunjam feels very undercooked, and just plain worse than the beta. I don't think I'm going to be refunding because i played the beta so much I feel like I got my fun out of it, but I dont think I'm going to be playing the main game until major changes are made

I can see where this is going but there's more to be done to make this "fun". Some points of frustration that ruined the fun for me

- Only paint brush size is very small, which means the painting takes a long time to complete
- Hold to select which part to assembly is quite a lengthy amount of time (3-4 seconds ish, this doesn't sound a lot individual until you realise the level of detail this goes to, i.e. each string, tuning knob, pick up, dial etc) 
- Having to select which variant of a part for each instance of that part ( combined with the above means adding all 6 strings means, long press down to select the string, picking the only correct one from the menu, selecting assembly complete, threading the string) repeat 6 times. 
- The spiral stairs are narrow and very bumpy, climbing them is quite tricky without falling off and is motion sickness inducing (in someone who doesn't get motion sick! )

This all said, the game was bug-free quite detailed and had a lot of features. Just needs some quality-of-life fixes to make this recommendable

my only criticism would be to make camera shake off by default as it makes the screen vibrate a lot and i think it subtracts from the already amazing experience that this is.

TLDR if you play games for fun, have a taste for small details and love pixel graphics, try this out and support one of the most passionate indie devs out there!

Really deep and interesting combat, amazing bossfights (particularly champion bossfights), fun quests, great enemy variety, great story, fantastic music, and a unique and consistent artstyle.
Some dialogue, particularly Sylas's dialogue can be jarring given previous incarnations of Sylas in lore, but this makes Sylas seem like more of a three-dimensional character and make him more relatable and fleshed out. 
Also there is little to no voice acting in the game and they reuse voice lines (mostly grunts, yells, and champion catchphrases) from League of Legends which is a little disappointing given how much voice acting there was in Ruined King, but the reused voice lines are well placed and serve to make champions more recognizable.
However i do not think it was a good decision to lock some spells behind a paywall, and while the spells are absolutely not necessary to complete the game nor are they overpowered and it personally doesn't bother me much, it is still very dumb to do in the first place.
Overall, this is probably the best Riot Forge game so far and this has made me even more excited for future Riot Forge games.

I was really excited for the game to come out. I was a huge fan of Minecraft Dungeons and I grew up with Minecraft. I've been checking off the days in my calendar for this game. When it released I downloaded the game and today I started to play it.
I didn't get very far however because I couldn't even beat the tutorial. One of the first things you learn in this game is the gathering zone. You need to hold right click to select a zone and then while you're right clicking, click left click to confirm. I am playing on laptop so I can not hold right click and then left click while doing that. If I left click I attack and if I hold right click I highlight a zone. 
I can not gather anything and I am stuck in the tutorial. I searched the web and couldn't find any solutions. I spent 27 minutes playing this game with the majority being sitting there puzzled.
Is it possible to play on laptop?

Great base of a game to build off of. Needs some work to understand how to make things work and operate cleanly, at the risk of making the UI more complex needs more information feeding in. Best with the big story set pieces, and you need to really think about the game around these.

Minecraft Legends is a game that looks good on paper, and has promising ideas, but is lackluster when it comes to actual gameplay. For right now, I can't recommend it. They added in-app purchases for skins before they even added modding, or player-made skins, which is an insult to the creativity of the Minecraft universe. I would spend no more then $25 on it, and even then you'd be much better off purchasing Minecraft Dungeons.

I think the reviews would be more positive if it wasn't so expensive; you shot yourselves in the foot with the expectations that come with a 40 dollar game.

Things they should do to improve the game:
1) Make it so only you can control your troops not every person.
2) Add some leveling system for pvp so its not just okay we won awesome go again for no reason.
3) Add more units to the game. There are so many mobs that could be added and make the game amazing.
4) Allow us to play online with our friends against other random people not just randomize teams every game.

[h1] What were they thinking?? [/h1]

It's one of THOSE remasters. You know the one. The head-scratcher. The unnecessary one. The "What were they thinking??".

Desktop Dungeons is a magnificent game. A puzzle roguelike for coffee breaks with simple yet smart game rules paired with clear visual design. Brilliant. The original game that is. 

This remaster on the other hand is a mystery. How can a team that created the original forgo charming and CLEAR visuals for a Hearthstone like cookie-cutter graphic style and an anti player UI? The monsters and items are small, the camera angled for some reason and all crucial information is scattered all over the screen seemingly at will. For a game that needs CLEAR information this re-imagining gets everything wrong. Just skim over a few other reviews (positive or negative) and you will see a common theme of UI issues. Fast and fun play sessions are turned into slow grinds against the interface.

And the developer knew about the game's quality and still went through with it. They even gave away this game for free to people that owned the original in an attempt to fish for positive reviews. Don't be fooled.

Rewind turned a beautiful game into an awful mess. Thankfully you can still play the original (for free!) instead of paying 20$ (lol!?) for this inferior "remaster".

Enjoying the remaster so far. The original hadn't clicked too much with me but this one is way more immersive and does a great job onboarding at the start along with a few smart design and balance changes.

Loving the game but it has some noticeable flaws:

- dying and retrying wont automatically refresh your flasks
- if you die you have to play trough the animations every time, there's no skip button, just a fast dialogue button
- the difficulty scaling is a disaster, on hard against bosses 1 hit equals losing half if not more of your hp

For the rest the game is excellent.

I love this game a lot, but if you're reading this, know that there is a whole lot that needs to change if this game is going to last.  First of all, the game was released half-complete.  Many buttons in the ui have no functionality or have functionality that doesn't lead to anything.  Second, in typical Microsoft fashion, the game is quite buggy.  It doesn't mess with gameplay much, but it is definitely noticible.  Finally, and what I feel was extremely neglected, is your typical pvp benchmarks: Stuff like team comms, a useful ping system, or the ability to report other players.  This game leaves the door wide open for trolls to hop in and ruin a game, and from what I can see, there is no way for you to effectively counter this in-game or prevent this out-of-game.

I do love the concept and will continue to keep playing, but these are things that other players as well as Microsoft need to be made aware of.  A healthy game cannot be this broken for very long.

I can't believe i got hyped for a year just to end up hating this game. All I do in my regular life is: blast techno/synth music, and shoot guns in destiny and cod. I thought this game would be perfect for me, hell my NAME is even JAM. But what we have here is heartbreaking.

 The demo that came out several months before release was amazing! The music was somehow curated to line up perfectly with the timing of shooting enemies, as well as the traversal of the levels. You were able to feel yourself get faster and better as you improved and got further each time. The high beats when you were swarmed with enemies, the small lulls that allowed you to dash to the next area, it felt like it all made sense. Like when you first start out, you get slapped around a bit, you dont reach the time gates fast enough, and you need to learn. And as you learn, you started to feel how the timing of each area lined up perfectly with the songs, the amount of enemies in a given space, and how far you needed to traverse at any given time; when you practiced and improved, the flow just clicked in your mind and felt so good, even if it could be too challenging sometimes. All of that seems to be gone now.

So what happened with the full release? Why does it feel so bad?? 
To start, lets just get this out of the way; the music is phenomenal. Truly the crown achievement is the soundtrack. Unfortunately thats where it ends though. The graphics are not impressive, but we already knew thats not why we're here, so we can ignore that. The level design from the demo seems to have gone out the window. No more corridors or mazes to navigate, now its just 1 big room. This creates a new problem where you don't know where enemies are coming from anymore. Previously as long as you kept marching onward, you knew that enemies would come face you head-on. But now that you're just playing in a big room, you can get swarmed from all directions. This simply does not work for Gun Jam. There's no radar. There's no minimap. There isnt actually anything to allow you to gather info to fight back. Hell for a game all about audio, the 3D sound design is atrocious. You can't hear enemies around you at all, they barely make a sound, which is why changing the game from gauntlet-style corridors to just 1 big arena is so frustrating to me.

The other major issue I have with this game is the auto-mapping of the song beats; basically those colorful cues for when youre allowed to fire your gun. Yes "allowed to" because you literally cant deal damage off the beat of the song. And the flow of the beat? Completely random. No idea how the hell it ended up SO different than in the demo, but the timing of when youre allowed to shoot feels so wrong. For a few seconds you'll be firing to the beat of the backing drums, then maybe it will switch tempo to like the bass or lead vocals or something and just completely throws you off. Like come on, I'm still clicking to the beat of the drums back there, they didn't go anywhere, so why did you have to change it up on me? Why is it that in the demo it was able to seamlessly flow from slow to quick and back to slow shooting and it all made sense with the phrases of each song, but now it feels so random?? It just feels so bad when you are swarmed on all sides by enemies, but the game said you need to wait 2 seconds until the next note where we will allow you to shoot gun. bro i am not jamming.

Besides that, the weapons themselves are kinda bland. No visuals or sounds or effects that really stand out. Kinda sucks not having any control over your arsenal at all, apparently only the song may decided for you which gun youre allowed to shoot when. Oh are you surrounded by a hoard of small guys? shotgun or aoe blast sure would be nice, but we're just gonna give you this zapper you can tap once every second. Maybe this doesnt even matter at all since there is hardly any enemy variety. nothing but 'big guy who walks at you for melee' or 'small guy that walks at you for melee'. I remember the demo also had a couple flying guys and a large robo boss type but thats about it.

man it doesnt feel good at all to crap all over this game that i was so excited to play. i seriously considered refunding this, but because i love the music so much i just cant do that. this game showed so much potential in the demo that seems to be all  gone now. no more levels, no progression, no story even. its literally just 'insert coin to play arcade game for a few minutes'. if they were to just manually adjust the firing of the weapons to the specific beats of each song, and then make those flow into actual maps, this game would be amazing. it would make it feel like an actual curated, tight, lovingly crafted experience. but as it stands now, cannot recommend this game. I hope i need to come back and edit this review in the future.

I was not a fan of the GUI / UX in this game. Everything felt very artificial - e.g. collecting palm leaves by pressing E when staring at the trunk to pop-up a container-like view, selecting the leaves I wanted, and then pressing "collect". I didn't feel immersed in the environment at all. I also didn't love the awkwardness of pressing RMB to start throwing a spear, then RMB to put it away, but LMB to actually throw it.

I want to address the badger combat that a few other reviewers have complained about.
I think the problem with the combat is two-fold.

1. It seems like the player's block is very slow, like pressing RMB has a delayed reaction / the actual block occurs a non-negligible amount of time afterwards. This applies also to the attack.
2. It didn't seem like the badger had any telegraphing before the attack, so as a player it felt like I was just pressing RMB at an arbitrary moment in time in order to block the attack that would come later.

The combination of those two factors made the combat feel clunky and non-responsive. That could be addressed by tightening up player animations (make them much more responsive) and making sure enemies have a clear "pause" period before their actual attack so that the player can recognize and block at that exact moment.

Survival mechanics with crafting, exploration, discovery and adventure!

Beautiful and smooth so far!

Puerto Rico 1513 in search of the fabled fountain of youth you shipwreck on some islands.  Can you survive long enough to find any surviving crew-mates?  Will you live to find the fountain of youth?

Early Access launched today and this game downloaded, installed and booted without issue.  Plays great and feels polished up to the end of the "tutorial" story driven quest line.  Excited to see what's next!

Overall:

Devs seem to have already put in plenty of work for an Early Access game so I imagine they will continue their efforts while polishing and support this game through to it's full release!  Looking forward to playing more and hearing others opinions as we all await the fabled "perfect survival sim game" - good buy at a great price to support a hard working team. Thanks devs!

Ive played quite a few survival crafters and feel i have a good base line to compare to.

Thus far, this one needs some work. 

The harvesting is quite bland with no animations, just a pop up screen.
The crafting UI is pretty terrible and un-intuitive.
The durability on items is ridiculously low, almost 1 shot use.
The progression of crafting tech doesnt seem particularly streamlined.
Item quantity requirements feel really high in comparison to low harvested items. 
Map shows icons where "resources" are - loses a bit of immersion.
Resources have recharge times listed meaning static spawns which is just meh.

I was hoping for a mix of green hell / icarus but at the moment this game is way off. Great concept just not particularly well implemented.

Everything seems laborious, from killing to crafting to harvesting - and not in a fun way.
General gameplay wise, it got boring quite quickly - plugged away to try and do more but its just...dull.

Worst part: You cant harvest whilst being hunted by an animal. (The hunted animal was a snake 10 metres away just looking at me....just meh)

4 hours on record otherwise i would request a refund. 

May try it again in the future once some work has been done.

Moons of Darsalon looks like a long-lost Commodore Amiga game, but plays like an action/adventure/platformer/puzzle hybrid with Lemmings (the Darsonauts). You have to rescue the Darsonauts on each level, which are surprisingly intelligent (they defo feel like they have minds of their own) and are mostly-not terrible at keeping themselves alive and obeying your commands. The game plays well with plenty of polish and fun (and rockin' chiptunes). Most of my time with this game is hours spent playing the Demo, but I can't wait to sink more hours into the full game finally! This game has a lot of heart and really reminds me of the games I grew up on from the late 80's/early 90's, but manages to pack in so many little touches and systems to keep it feeling fresh. One of those "just one more level" kind of games that are fun and engaging. It introduces you to the systems gradually so that you won't feel overwhelmed which is also nice.

One thing of note, the full game (not the demo) takes 25-30 seconds to load on the Dr. Kucho! splash screen (with no indication that the game was still loading). After that, the game works fine, but it threw me off at first.
A throwback to Lemmings and Clonk with a lot of humor and soul.

Fire and Maneuver" is a unique take on strategy from an indie development studio. I have put quite a few hours into the game at this point and find the combat system refreshing, as it is unlike any other game with its turn-based combat-focused gameplay. The game is getting some flak for going from free-to-play to a price of $15 right now. The developers, when they set out to make the game, had no clue how expensive it would be. In order to continue development, they had two choices: sell out to a scummy microtransaction-filled model or admit their mistake and transition to a paid model, while letting all the players who played during early access keep their copy. Most developers would just quit when things get tough, but Armchair History Interactive has come through to make a unique and compelling indie game.

The game is early access, but it doesn't even have working critical features. One critical feature you will run into is infinite loading screens. Ways to access this wonderful hell include but are not limited to: ending your turn in a battle, turning the game on, trying to access a manual or autosave, ending your turn in campaign, trying exit a battle after winning, and so many more.

Frankly, this is just game breaking. If you get stuck, the only exit is hard closing the game. Want to return back to your game even with an autosave? Too bad start over. This has not really improved, and I might check back in a couple years. Either way I don't think I can sadly recommend this game.

3 hours on the first day of release and I can say? Very good first impression. 

Notable +

* Simultanious turn based games feel strategic like a turn based game without reactionary - as you need to predice your opponents moves in real time - but you don't wait for your opponent to make their turn, as you fill out your orders for the first time.

* Free? More than capable of being a ¬£10-¬£15 steam game given its current form and status. Again, still under development too.

* Nation diversity is a A* for me, at least from a eurocentric perspective. With plans to release nations from elsewhere, however, I dont feel confident criticising this just yet. But for now, you have plenty of EUROPEAN nations to play - mostly great powers. 

* Regiment uniquness. Want to play an Austria with only Hungarian regiments? Go for it. Germany with only bavarian regiments? GO FOR IT. Great Britain with only Scottish troops? We got you. Also Highlanders are just awesome to use 10/10 love firing twice.

* Perks?  Simple and easy to understand, along with the combat. +1 range, +1 attack order, +1 manuever order. Simple, thank god.

I feel bad putting anything here, seeing as it is expected given it's a free, unfinished (still in development) game.

[b] –°ompact and enjoyable roguelike [/b]

Bosorka is a new roguelike, which can give you fun, but with some nuances.

- First, the witch is flying on a broom, and controlling it feels smooth and pleasant. You can both dash and sprint, and the impact gives a nice addition to the control.
- Secondly, the overall battle system is dynamic and decent. Enemies' patterns are not unique, but battles require using your mobility and spells as much as possible. It was also a good discovery that the dash can be used to stun enemies, making it a part of your usual tactics. As a roguelike, the game provides you with different spells and amulets (even different types of brooms) that could be unlocked during the walkthrough.
- Thirdly, levels have their unique visual themes and have a variety of transition principles. E.g. one level will require you to fly over the water (while the stamina level for movement reduces over time), and another will make you use the wind streams to fly into the air to reach the distant islands. 

Meanwhile, you have to keep in mind some issues before start playing: 
 - There's not a big variety of all content - bosses, levels, spells, amulets, and so on. As a result, you can unlock most of the closed content in 4-5 hours, and that's all that the game can offer you. Moreover, more variety in build creation would be great. Some spells and amulets are stronger than others.
- It also would be great to have a more unique style, as some enemies are not visually memorable.

However, if you'd like to play not a long roguelike, which not requires to have a wiki guide on the other page, Bosorka could be a nice choice for some hours of catchy gameplay!

A Griefer's Paradise

I was freely giving bug reports and helping the devs improve their game when I noticed the "griefing" PvP community were being praised and given a dissent-free platform from the devs to brag about their open desires to grief others.

This was an immediate turn-off and I quickly realized that this company had actually designed the game around the ability to grief others.  It is their game and they can do what they desire, but I warn you not to pay for a game that is still dealing in the business of encouraging PvP griefing.

[b]  Pets Hotel was featured on my youtube channel[/b]


https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2964594848


and now onto the short review

[h1]TL;DR Review[/h1]




//intro//

Welcome back comrades, this is MF Kraven & you are watching less than 10 mins reviews. The Youtube series where I take a look at games i think seem cool & give my thoughts on them in less than 10 mins.


Today I take a look at Pet's Hotel, a business sim game about running a hotel for Pets. But can the formula of owning and running a hotel for pets be a viable business plan or will it be doomed to fail? Let's find out.



//Graphics, Sound & Artstyle//

Starting off with graphics, I can say I appreciate what they're going for, and some of the animals look absolutely adorable- and maybe it's because I don't like the look of certains breeds.. but some are straight out of uncanny valley.That being said, for what this game is- it is aesthetically pleasing. Only real gripe i have with sound is that it's not memorble and what is, (the ringtones, is annoying) 


//Gameplay//

There are three game modes to choose from, while only two are shown- sandbox mode to me should be a thing of it's own. You start by entering your Pet Hotel & answering phone calls to see if customers can make reservations for their trusty companions. If room is available you register their pet's name, the amount of days they will be staying and if they choose any extra services like nail clipping. You then wait for the next day to check that pet in and take em to their room- the animal in question will have certain bars that you can check to see what their needs are. Food, Water, attention, potty time, etc. Some animals will have preferences to what food they like or dont like as well as allergies so be wary of that as well.

Challenge mode pits you into a scenario where times a ticking, you have a certain amount of days before you close down. So try and complete the objectives given to you to save the resort! A few of em dont have any holding rooms for pets so it's up to you what goes where.


Free Mode, sets you up in a building with a few rooms and tosses you right into the fire. a few holding rooms for your customers, and ready to be booked and cared for.

Sandbox mode puts you into a freemode map but allows you to construct at your hearts desire with no penalty on cash, of course achievements are also locked during this game mode, just in case for those who like that sort of thing. aka people like me


//Price//

 17.99 USD


//How many hours estimated//

Well over 20 hours of fun can be had in this. My estimation.


//Final Thoughts//


Rejoice owners of Nintendogs because this to me is a spiritual successor to that formula. Yes it's part business sim but also part playing with pets. Having to feed them, play with them, pet them. It actually works amazingly with the SteamDeck touchpad. You'll be rubbing good boy's bellies in no time, and damn the people who made me feel ashamed of playing with a Nintendogs, sure I was 14 and ccouldve been playing other games but i digress.

Pets Hotel is a cutesy management game, with no real objective other than to have a good time with your guests. But that novelty seems to run out pretty quick, as in the day to day tasks, when you have a few pets- time seems to go real slow, so when you speed a day up, well you're met with pets with depleted bars in the morning. But if you have too many pets in your hotel, you cant possibly reach em all. WHERE another gameplay mechanic comes into play, hiring employees to both run the front desk and help with pets can be available but the addition of this feature makes me wish this was multiplayer. How awesome would it be to run a Pet Hotel with a friend? Expand your resort, start charging a little more but keep giving the same mediocre attention to pets cause, how are they gonna tell?

I am having a good amount of fun, I just wish there was more happening or time went by a bit faster. There's no real penalty for letting a dog go poop in their room so there's no real incentive on taking em out to the backyard to let em make their business. Cant force the cat being picked up in an hour to drink some water even though his meter is low and I understand this may be by design, but in challenge mode- sometimes good reviews matter, and after having Stryker in my care for 7 days, always in the green to go home in an Orange meter because of that, sucks.


I hate how slow the NPC's move too. And that damn, phone, nonstop ringing. FORTUNATELY you can mute the phone, but i find that just going to your management computer and setting certain availability off is the best. And that's kind of why I hate hiring people, let's say that (25 mins in) Aero is being picked up so we have an availabilty- however because technically the room is being taken up, the day prior i couldn't take anymore dogs, but I still did it anyways- see I figured okay Aero will be picked up, as soon as i give him back I can quickly register from my notes Hank the dog, then take him in. That way I have my room booked up for the day, because for whatever reason people make a reservation for their pets a day ahead of time and always come the following day. Instead of a "hey im gonna drop my dog off today for 6 days, do you have any spots?" 



Little bits and details that I'm sure the devs might iron out in the future. In any case, with all these little gripes i have, I can still say whole heartdly you will have a great time if either pet care or business sims are your thing. Don't expect a deep game, just expect a cozy little sim game where you rub good boys bellies.

I was disappointed when GL announced his "free" game was going to be paid for the 1st year, that is a cheap shot considering they always said this was going to be F2P at release. But after giving it some thought and playing the beta back in June 2022, I realized this is money well spent, since I highly enjoy this title and I know as a fact that this will give me hours and hours of fun. So I got this just as a thank you for the developers.

Also, I'll make it clear, you can get all characters, car parts and crews FOR FREE in-game. Everything in-game is free, except for the premium season tiers (you get 2 seasons for free in the standard pack), but even those tiers you can get for free by farming loot boxes which can be purchased FOR FREE with in-game currency.

If you're an old school racing fan and loved F-Zero and games like that, you'll love this one, regardless if you like disney characters or not, the game is fun regardless of its franchise.

So there is a bug going on. If you return to your rebell camp during a Mission you loose every Resource you got, including Recruits (that part is probably intended). BUT The real Problem is here: For the game you already oponend all the chests and recruited all the Rebels, so you can't do it anymore. So after you returned to rebell camp you can enter an emptyed mission, where you cannot get resources from chests or recruit rebels. So which means with this Option alone you can brick your game totaly. 
This Game is so much fun. I have two ideas for a Solution:
* return to base camp actually lets you keep everything from chests and your Rebels but resets everything you got from fights. This would be the easiest solution and would turn a bug into a feature. Also the Feature would make sense that way in the first Place because for my Second Idea this Feature just feels senseless:
* return to base camp resets everything to before you actually started the mission (this is probably how this is supposed to work). -> As I said I think this would just make the whole option useless since you got no new resources to spend on anything just ending up restarting from new which no Player ever wants.

Upon starting up Minecraft Legends, I was immediately struck by the enjoyable and engaging gameplay of this real-time strategy game set in the beloved world of Minecraft. The introductory cinematic pulls you right into the action, as the player must take on the role of a hero tasked with stopping a piglin invasion in worlds lacking their own protectors. With the aid of golems and various mobs, players are able to mount a defense against the invading piglins. However, I did find myself struggling with the controls - particularly when using a mouse and keyboard - which felt disorienting and difficult to manage at times. Even when utilizing banner commands, I found it challenging to control the individual units effectively.

Despite these issues, the true strength of Minecraft Legends lies in its engaging storyline and immersive setting. The game effortlessly transports players into a rich and detailed world, filled with exploration and discovery. The addition of mounts adds an extra layer of excitement to the gameplay, making it all the more disappointing that some cosmetic features are locked behind a pay wall. It feels somewhat at odds with the game's promotion of creativity and exploration, and may leave some players feeling frustrated. However, if you're willing to overlook these drawbacks, Minecraft Legends has a lot to offer for fans of the Minecraft universe.

Moons Of Darsalon is probably one of the most vibrant homage ever made to games on old computers from the 80/90s (damn this CPC464-like loading screen is just AMAZING and brought back tons of memories). You ll immediately remember games such as Lemmings while playing it.

Trying to rescue your colleagues moving them to the closest base station using the many tools (weapons, flashlight, jetpack, plateform builder, vehicles, etc) and voice commands offered to the player ll prove challenging but never unfair. This thanks to Moons of Darsalon smart level design that ll challenge you while not turning frustrating because of poor controls or badly tuned puzzles.

Also the game has an external level creator tool available on the game Discord server to make your very own stages and share them to challenge other Moons of Darsalon players. This single feature should offer the game a virtualy infinite lifespan for as long as people ll release their very own creations.

Visualy speaking this is one of the most accurate retro looking game that i have ever seen when it comes to mimiccing games from the Amiga/Atari ST or early PC era. Its screen filter offers both the CRT and VHS-like vibe. Also all filters are individualy activable, good job!

Last but not least Moons of Darsalan chiptune soundtrack is just INCREDIBLE. The game catches absolutely everything from musics and sound Fx of old computers. Needless to say that the soundtrack is a MUST BUY even if you don't plan to play the game for as long as you enjoy chiptune music!

[h2]So all in all Moons of Darsalan is an incredible suprise to me and probably one of the best if not the best homage to computer games of the 80/90s ever released. So don't hesitate a single second, this game is a gem![/h2]

Desktop Dungeons is a great and unique game. I'm less sure whether this version is worth playing over the original. This version has a few notable improvements - like dungeons aspect ratios being much better for contemporary screen resolutions; and better combat predictions so there's less (or no?) risk of dying in combat for a reason you don't necessarily understand, which happened occasionally in the original (e.g. maybe some status effect was applied mid-combat). There's also been some very slight rebalancing; the number of such changes can be counted with one hand, which is fine in what's essentially a remastered game.

I also appreciated that I was able to port my save files from the original over to the remastered version.

The overall new presentation and UI is more of a mixed bag. Top-down is just a better perspective for a turn-based puzzle game than this isometric perspective, where one must occasionally scroll to see all enemies. And I just don't understand why the health UI has player stats in the top left and enemy stats in the top right: the single most important thing in the game is to be able to tell at a glance whether you can kill a monster or not, and this is not possible here; instead you must constantly glance into either corner to compare what will happen to both you and the monster.

A remaster is the perfect opportunity for genuine UI innovation, and the actual UI falls far short of its potential. Here it sometimes feels more like you're fighting the UI, rather than benefiting from it.

With all that being said, the game is still Desktop Dungeons, so it's still fun.

Overall a great game with extremely fun combat. Weaving in and out and how the game incentivizes you to use stolen magic by having it cost 0 mana is really cool. The game actually feels like how Sylas would play in League of Legends if he was playing urf. 

I would consider it a bit pricey considering 100%ing the game should take no more than 15 hours but it was still really fun overall.

With that said, the game REALLY could have used voice acting. It felt kind of dry with just text showing up on your screen that you have to read. The Ruined King felt so much more alive because of the fact that it implemented voice acting.

Also the cutscene skipping is fraudulent and barely speeds it up at all so if you die in a boss fight and start it up again, you have to watch the entire thing before you can get on with the action.

Also while not something that ruined the experience, the progression tracker is a straight up lie. It said i was 25% done with the game within the first hour and had me thinking "Oh wow this game is REALLY short" but that ended up not being the case as the tracker went very slowly outside of the first 25%. Don't be fooled into thinking this game is 4 hours long. Mageseeker is ~15 hours in length or ~10 if you're really good at the game.

Overall a solid 8.5 out of 10.

A pretty neat re-imagining of the original Desktop Dungeon game. I'm glad they ditched the old artstyle for a little something more cartoony and whimsical, and the new features and balance changes are a welcome sight.

Overall a pretty neat rework of an older title, with a little extra to justify the purchase.

There are a few bugs, as of now I've run into crashes at random points, sound recursion when taking the elite lightning mageseeker ability, enemy AI getting stuck in corners, and the revive mechanic not working. Aside from that, the game is very fun and cool for those invested in the LoL/Runeterra lore. The story is not super complex, but the arc of sylas is realistic if not a little annoying at times considering some of the purely revenge driven choices he makes through the first 50% of the game. The side characters help to flesh him out more and are all useful to the story.

Overall, the game is a firm 8/10, best fight by far the Garen rematch. One of the best fights I've had in any game hands down.

I have finished the game in its entirety on Kingslayer Difficulty (Hardest Difficulty), only missing 3 achievements that i will end up getting eventually. Here's My Review.

As for the game generally:

This game is amazing. From start to finish, the game keeps you intrigued and invested in the characters of Sylas, Garen, Lux and any others you meet down the line, as they all have a place in the story, as well as a job that they all do extremely well. This game takes place just after the events of Lux stopping Sylas' live execution (known info) and fills in a part of Demacia's lore that has been left out for quite some time now, so everything in this game is such a joy and wonder to discover as you play through. The writing and direction with the game is also really good, depicting characters really well in every situation they're in. The game is also surprisingly smooth, fast, and looks incredible, and the Combat only makes the game smoother, faster, greater. 

Combat, Controls, etc:
The game at the start is rather simple. Introductions of a light and heavy attack as every game does. Although, some people may find that there are an overwhelming amount of controls (at least on controller, nearly every button has a use). However,  there is no such scenario where you HAVE to use ALL buttons. I went through the game using only 3-5 buttons anyway. The game also allows you to make your own combat style through the Outlaws, who are practically Assists that give you 1 special move u can use anytime through the use of a couple inputs such as Light, Light, Heavy as an example. Once you get a grasp of the buttons and mechanics, the game only gets Faster and more enjoyable with each kill on an enemy, as you start chaining from enemy to enemy with speed, dealing massive damage along the way. And even combining your moveset with the ability to steal Magic Abilities and use your own ones allows for even more creativity in the way you play. 

Lore-wise:
Yes, the game has a lot of good little callbacks, mentions and even new stuff. For you lore nerds out there, there is A LOT to discover here i feel. Some stuff about Noxus and Freljord, not in the main story but stuff that you can find if you look around, be prepared to read though.

Now, I will say that the game does have a couple underlying bugs at the moment, only 1 of them affecting my gameplay:
Firstly, as rare as this one is, occasionally an enemy just won't die. You still progress as normal, as the next area will open upon depleting it's health bar, but it will just refuse to die. Just continue on and ignore it.

Secondly, this one is rather common i think, as it happened to me on all my attempts with a specific boss, but the bosses health bar would be depleted and the level wouldn't progress for another 15-20 seconds at least. It does end up progressing normally, but ur kinda forced to wait for the game to realise that u actually won the fight. 
Thats really the only 2 main bugs I ran into. Other ones are slight UI bugs that are just not an issue.

Unlock system:
You are able to spend the same currency on Everything here. The game doesn't throw a bunch of different currencies at you like Gems or Crystals, rare separate currencies, none of that. This currency is able to be used for new Spells and Upgrades for Sylas, being stuff like Damage or Health upgrades for example. Very simple system here, and it works just fine. 

Campaign Content and Replayability:
Aside from having the usual Campaign missions, there are also Secondary missions you can complete for extra rewards and extra fun. You can do these secondary ones at basically any time you see fit. 
There is a character that provides the ability to replay every mission you've done.
The Replayability here is really just to get stuff you haven't gotten or found in previous missions (which there will likely be a good handful of stuff you miss), but outside of that, unless u just feel like playing the game again, there isn't much. 


If you took the time to read this, Thank you. You're a chad. And I do very much recommend this game to anyone a fan of this genre, or anyone willing to try something new.

I clicked that I recommend this game [AT FIRST, READ EDIT BELOW], but only if you have a niche. 

I have been looking for a fast-paced shooter a-la Ultrakill that felt unique and challenging with a high skill ceiling. This is absolutely it. Self-paced challenges combined with the structure of a rhythm game in the FPS genre feels like an M rated Rhythm Heaven Fever. 

The music feels awesome, and massive plus there's an option for custom songs. I haven't tried it yet, but I'm excited to see if the dev allows for public mods or a workshop to share custom levels or tracks like Beat Saber did. 

While there aren't levels, the fact an update was released mere hours after launch indicates that there is hope for more content on the way. 

Right now it feels barebones, but the premise is fantastic and I will play the game far beyond my "$1=1 hour" rule.

SUGGESTIONS: 
1. More distinctive graphics. Everything looks bright and it can be hard to focus on what I just shot or who I killed.
2. Workshop support: Probably a long-time project and there are better things to work on right now, but it would be awesome.
3. Campaign. Don't need a story, but some pre-built levels would add an astounding amount of content.



EDIT

After playing for a bit more I can tell that the songs are not lined up to the beats, or maybe the beats aren't aligned consistently to the song. Either way it just seems like I'm playing a timing game with only visual cues. That definitely needs fixing.

Also the algorithm for inserted music could use some work. I'm willing to supply my song copies as base but they seem too quiet. Not to mention the same beat alignment issue is here, but it's excusable in this instance since it's trying to place beats according to what seems like waveform spikes alone.


Okay, finally refunding the game. The beats being off, timing screwy, did anything from the demo make it to the final product? Will they?

Owning the original DD netted me this game for free.

I liked the original; it's basically more of that here with different or better GFX.
Desktop Dungeons: Rewind, like its predecessor, is like a puzzle game in a way. You have to throw yourself, gear, and your glyphs (magic) at the right enemies for your level in the right order to kill without dying, regen by exploring fog of war squares, then do the same to the next enemy until you !SPROING! level up and auto-fill hp/mp making yourself stronger and able to more easily tackle enemies.

Each run is a procedurally generated map and, if you win or escape with your life, you gain some money. You use that to upgrade your village which gets you new classes like Fighter, Wizard, etc, or species/races like Human, Elf, Dwarf, etc. and a couple other things.

There's also a selection of premade puzzle maps to tackle.
I have no reason to believe the rest of the game won't be more of the same, so I'll drop a casual positive review, keeping in mind it was free to me so price is not part of this review.

The game play itself is the same  puzzle RPG mechanics from the original game presented in 3D. It feels pretty good & seems to be mostly bug free. The update to graphics, such as the 3D & wide screen support & general supporting of a modern Windows system is done well.

The main thing that makes the game play a bit annoying is the forced tutorial type stuff that keeps popping up.
Maybe it's because it's been some time since I started a new game in the original product but Rewind feels like it has more of the tutorial/forced moves & that said mechanics take more clicking to get through.

Over all it's a small thing to the game play & is eventually over leading to the ability to play nice short dungeons almost infinitely.

However what drags the game down is its lack of accessibility & 'quality of life' options. For instance there's no colour blind settings, no key binding options or even a key list, no pausing the game on focus loss,  no GUI/UX options, etc.
For instance... 'E' does something but I'm not sure what yet.. I suspect it's the last spell used but I randomly hit 'E" while playing to  get my only spell's 'spell ready' prompt.
It's sure be nice to see what keys the game accepts instead of randomly hitting something & have the game act on it.
Another example is inability to to change how the camera is operating; I prefer to have the PC in the upper right hand corner & will initiate actions while already 'scouting ahead' on the map... only for the camera to put the PC centre screen & no option to change this behaviour.

Over all I don't feel the game deserves a 'great' or a 'horrible'; I feel the game is 'alright' but Steam's review system is either a 'yes' or a 'no' thumbs up or down system. And then there's the 'owners of the original game get Rewind for free'.
That's a good move by the developers/publishers & a rare 'players matter' move... but it also feels very much like they're trying to 'buy votes'.
Now... do I need to mark my review as 'received for free' as I own the original game? I don't know & am unclear on Valve's rules on such things.

So I'm going for what I hope is the more reasonable road... I'm down voting the game despite thinking it's alright because I'm intending it as an attempt to even out all the positive votes to make the [u]overall rating[/u] a more neutral rating.
I'm also not marking my review as 'received for free' as I did, at one time, spend $ on the game... I bought the original at full price several years ago.

Important note: This game is not $30 material, but for what it tried to accomplish it succeeds. 

Pros:
[list]
    [*] Amazing visuals being constrained to pixelart.
    [*] Bosses are well designed and challenging; every scenario feels unique and offers new challenges.
    [*] Stealing spells is pretty fun, but choosing combos is a welcomed addition I was not expecting. It's a perfect mix of bullet hell and beat-em-up games.
    [*] Fun ways of interacting with the environment to find secrets without it feeling too random. 
    [*] Music is incredible and the sound effects really add to the immersion.
    [*] Good story... Though it's also a con with he enemies you fight. 
    [*] Garen kicks butt.
[/list]
Cons:
[list]
    [*] Demacia is anti-mage... but you steal spells from mages that are fighting for Demacia.... WHAT?
    [*] Game is extremely short. Like, insultingly short. 
    [*] The spells available are underwhelming and few, yet they have the nerve to have interesting spells that you need to PAY for. for $30 bucks you deserve to have full access to cool stuff in a short experience like this at LEAST. 
    [*] Slow-mo is a little repetitive when getting hit, and there is no options to skip cutscenes. So when you fail a bossfight, you get to re-watch a long animation just to fight again. I guess it's motivation to not mess up?
    [*] There's no skipping into-splash? I would prefer to just get into the game and not spend two minutes waiting every time i boot it up. 
    [*] The buffer is a little extreme for my taste, don't miss-click or fat finger. You will be punished. 
    [*] Seriously wait for this game to go on sale. It's good, but nothing incredible and shorter compared to most games in the genre. 
[/list]

A lousy cash grab Microsoft forced upon their employees, immediately upon starting the game the controls feel dreadful and the concepts feel downright insulting- it's watered-down Minecraft while stuck to a horse. Instead of collecting these resources and building structures yourself, have allays do it for you! Meanwhile, the only engaging aspect is the combat, which is remarkably shallow. Real time strategy without the strategy, essentially. I just spammed towers and sat still, and the spawners I could build felt really awkward because I could just spam allies out of them (allies that struggle with path finding it seemed lol), which clumsily assisted in mowing down the equally clumsy and mindless enemies while I attempt to assist by spamming the one attack button they give me. I finally gave up when I was sent to take care of the night beacon- required to progress- and the game had the fucking audacity to spawn the fortress in the MIDDLE OF A LAKE. I could not build a bridge- it was too far. I had to get lucky with one skeleton destroying two polluters and barely having grass to make a cobblestone golem generator on the main island, so I did. I had to leave and return multiple times for resources to tank through the endless piglins. I couldn't bring any mobs over from the outside because they refused to move through the lava surrounding the fortress, which was awkwardly coexisting with water just fine. Once I finally thought I was getting somewhere, I realized I couldn't destroy the walls protecting the portal. I was clever enough to jump over it, but the player character cannot destroy structures so there was no amount of tenacity I could have had to actually complete this mission. I couldn't bring creepers past the lava moat and I needed them to destroy the wall to bring the other units in to destroy the portal- it was impossible and the world was softlocked.

The artstyle I personally hate, the half-and-half of the classic sharp edges and ugly cut corners feels very bothersome, and the cel shading job they did looks awful. I feel like it just really badly wanted to look unique from the vanilla game like Dungeons did (Dungeons' artstyle I thought was very cool) but they couldn't think of any ideas. This last visual point feels awkward to talk about, but the playable characters they present at the beginning provoked an interesting response from me when I started. They were all effeminate save for maybe one design that could maybe go either way and another design that was totally ambiguous because of the mask they were wearing. Considering Mojang's recent focus on representation and inclusivity, I was surprised because I didn't feel represented at all as a man.

I've seen the story before the game launched on Youtube through an "All Cutscenes" type of video. The story's dog water- especially the literal Mark of Cain plot point they've got going for the origin of the Illagers. The god characters turn a group of villagers that choose to fight for their world grey and violent and that's just supposed to make sense. They fight the battle but now they're evil after the game's story closes- doesn't bear any relevance to the actual plot. Even Dungeons' story was better, and it was also a kids' story with a simplistic plot. I even think Story Mode's story was better, and that's hilariously low.

Lastly, my personal problem with these spin-off games. While I actually simp for Dungeons both in gameplay and style, I do think these spin-off games throttle and bottleneck the creativity and potential for vanilla Minecraft. Microsoft would rather allocate a small team to each version of Minecraft vanilla, the one game that consistently makes them millions, causing the game to suffer in events like the 1.17-1.19 updates because they simply don't have enough corporate manpower to fulfill their promises. The "Modders can do x y and z in like 2 weeks" narrative hardly applies to these people because there's so many more layers to their development process due to their corporate environment. Regardless, there's so much creativity and mind blowing ideas put into Dungeons, and I'll even admit into some of Legends (like the hand-painted terrain)! And because these ideas which would arguably be even more powerful in vanilla are in a spin-off game, instead, we can only hope to get something like it in vanilla. Thankfully we've gotten pillagers and piglins.

Oh, and can I ask what Deluxe edition was supposed to do? Did I just pay 10 extra dollars for fun or something? To top it off, there's SERIOUSLY minecoins in this fucking game? I get it in vanilla because the game is continually being supported for free, but they actually expect me to use minecoins in Legends? This just sucks. I'll probably be editing this as I experience more shit during gameplay or if I find certain aspects I perhaps judged too harshly. Overall, I do not recommend this game, especially at the price it stands at now. Go play Dungeons or vanilla.

It was one of the games of all time. I recommend playing it, and then never thinking about it again.

The gameplay is great, and while the ranked multiplayer mode is probably pay-to-win, the regulated multiplayer mode thankfully isn't. Sadly, the confusing menus, microtransactions, multiple in-game currencies and grind really bog down the overall experience.

A Kart Racer feels like one of the easiest games to monetize via cosmetics alone. There could have been stickers, kart bodies, trails, boost effects and character skins. Instead they decided to muddy it up with a super convoluted character progression system where you need 20 toilet seats, 5 screws and 10 12-sided die to upgrade Goofy's top speed by 15 points. Unfortunate because the actual core game is incredibly fun. The driving feels great, I love the addition of a really big jump to traverse the tracks, and giving every character a unique kit + character specific specials makes races feel chaotic in all the right ways. I've played a ton of it already in the short time it's been out and I'm having blast! But I unfortunately can't recommend it in good faith to people without a gigantic asterisk about the grinding mechanics. If you can tolerate some really awful grinding systems, this is an incredibly fun kart racer. Otherwise, stay away.

Rad game

Dear reader, hang tight, as this will be a long one.

Desktop Dungeons and I go way back, and I have many fond memories of this gem, being familiar with it since the early Alphas,  dating way back from circa 2010. Ever since then, the seeds of its genre bending, non-conforming, innovative gameplay were already planted,
becoming fully realized in 2013, refining many of the systems and mechanics seen in said Alpha.

Now, in brilliant fashion, we see yet another polished iteration of the game, Desktop Dungeons Rewind, a prety clever addition to the title that I'll explain further down the review.

Now, enough with the reverie. What even is this thing!?

As I mentioned, Desktop Dungeons Rewind (henceforth simply DDR, for brevity) doesn't conform to a set genre, but rather, the interplay between many aspects of established genres is what makes the game tick. 

You have top down dungeons with random layouts (with set rules to
ensure it is beatable) from roguelikes, playable classes and fantasy races from most RPGs (each with unique traits), as well as equipment, inventories and other such staples, but in a very unique way of going about it.

Another layer that makes the weird and wonderful DDR sandwich is resource management, but not in the way you might be used to - you are not building a base to survive relentless waves of monsters; resource management is key to be able to outlast and beat enemies.
Health, Magic, Experience, Spells, Equipment and even the exploration of the dungeon itself are resources.

Each "dungeon" can roughly fit in one screen (though there are multiple floors, in many cases) and the overall objective is winning by beating the boss (or, in some cases, bosses) and exiting the dungeon triumphant. Monsters are distributed in such a way that their levels range from 1 all the way to 10 (the bosses). 

This aspect of the game could be considered something of a puzzle game; different dungeons have different denizes with their own innate abilities and statistics that need to be taken into account with each engagement.

Combat is entirely tactical and deterministic, with the combat predictor being a large part of how enemies are approached, and utilizing everything at one's disposal (and even knowing when to let go of such things) ends up "clicking" and leads to an 
incredible feeling of clarity. 

There are so many options, synergies, and individual equipment pieces with varied effects 
that the ever elusive elation of emergent play happens here naturally.

When defeated, the player is given the option to try the run again, "rewinding" time to roughly the halfway point, restoring the state of play and allowing the player to redo mistakes.

Besides dungeon spelunking, the player has some light management aspects to contend with, mostly allowing for meta progression unlocks that range from items, classes, races and more, allow allowing for a more customizable, front loaded approach to future expeditions, as
well as practical puzzles for the struggling player (I wholeheartly recommend any newcomer to try them).

All in all, the game is a one of a kind experience that cannot be contained or defined in simple terms,  a kind of beautiful genre chimera that one can't help but love once its ingenuity and heart become clear to the player.

[h2]Recommended for fans of puzzlers with a fantasy roguelike spin.[/h2]

Going to go ahead and give devs a thumbs up here. It's a great game and the devs are some real standup folks. As am sure most know by now, they gave this game out free to owners of their first game which was insanely generous and just goes to show the level of respect they have for their fanbase. (Thanks devs)

In a nutshell, this game is identical to the OG Desktop Dungeons save a few things like some much needed balance changes and supporting newer GPU's/monitors. Game is so much easier on the eyes if you own a large monitor compared to the old game and now we can even zoom in very close to our little heroes which just helps this aspect further. It really looks and plays well on newer hardware without losing the original charm of the first game. 

Overall the game is a solid remaster and am very happy with it. I do have a couple minor complaints however. The biggest offender here is the lack of a Codex. The Codex carried all sorts of valuable information and stats to keep track of your playtime, what you've unlocked, information on monsters and all sorts of great stuff. All of which is absent in this game and that really kills the enjoyment I could have with this game as I love pouring over stats. I would call myself a stats junky and so not having any is pretty painful. Devs did say if things turn out well, they will devote a bunch of time to adding the Codex for this game too. So I really hope this game gets the attention it deserves so they can do just that because it's a good game and I'd love to see some more content/updates! 

The only other issue I have aside from the missing Codex is some bugs. I've encountered a couple in my short time, one was a 'infinite' saving bug where it just was 'saving' forever preventing me from closing the game and another was a main quest bug that had me redo the same quest multiple times. 

Other than those issues, this game is truly awesome. I love the new look and feel and being able to see everything on my monitor without straining my eyes. It feels a lot more fluid too and just dungeon crawling is a lot more fun this time around in general. All the silly humor and unique art direction from the original is here, just with a modernized look and feel. The only things missing are like I said, a Codex and maybe some touchpad/controller support so we can play this on TV's/tablets. 

Definitely a keeper if you enjoy puzzle roguelikes with lots of replay value and unlocks. For $20 full price (currently on sale) it's a steal considering how much playtime you can get out of it. Easy thumbs up. Great devs and even better game.

Right to the point review:
Mageseeker is a really enjoyable game, i truly enjoyed it all the way through and i rate it a 8/10.
Pros; 
-Story is very strong and Sylas Arc is neat. If it's canon then it makes me enjoy it a lot more
-The gameplay and controls (Mouse and Keyboard) feel very fluid and nice. 
-The animation on all the spells and characters are super clean and well animated
-Major bosses are super cool fights and have lots of awesome combos (Lets be honest, you will spam light and heavy attack without bothering with the combos)
-The characters exclusive to the game such as Yops and Leilana are super well written and I enjoyed them
-Good variety of enemies and compelling main villain 
Cons;
-As much as I liked it. It is not worth 30 dollars. i beat the game in 10.5 hours. (And almost all achievements and all side quests) Short Story
-No voice acting outside of cut scenes was pretty disappointing, (and there are voice lines but they are ripped directly from league of legends for characters such as Shyvana, Sylas, Lux, Garen, Morgana, and Jarvan IV) characters other than the cast from League have no voice lines at all.
-The combat is becomes repetitive after a while. 
-Every villain but the main one, (not including Jarvan or Shyvana) are very lifeless and they have nothing compelling about them. 
Overall i enjoyed it and i 100% recommend it on a sale but i think you should save your money until then. Thank you for reading.

If you're looking for a new RTS experience and are already an RTS fan, this isn't it.  It's very shallow.

Given that you're only able to give orders from your character's location and the game is optimized to be played with a controller, all you can do is tell units to attack in a direction.  You issue attack move commands, leave to go spawn more units, and return to issue more attack move commands.  You can issue attack move commands by unit type, but you can't queue up multiple targets or rapidly issue orders at different points in a battle.

Battles turn into visual noise.  Piglin enemies blend into the piglin environments.
I think this game is really fun, if you like open world games. The building mechanic is really interesting and its satisfying to watch everything you make get built in front of you.

The game is very shallow strategically, but there is a lot of fun to be had. If you're purely looking for an RTS, this is not the game for you.

I will only be talking about campaign/coop content, as I have not done PvP (it is atrocious, there is no chat).

The campaign gameplay consists of attacking Piglin bases and defending villages, the gameplay is fairly simple but the gameplay loop feels fun once you get into it. The way you'll have the most fun is to unfortunately not engage with the RTS part of the game for the most part, commanding your units is a chore because banner view (a mode which allows you to command specific units in your army) is horrendous to use, gathering all your units after sending them somewhere is tedious, and there is no strategy to choosing which units you bring with you (bring a few healers and bring whatever other unit you prefer). Not only that, but units will get stuck on terrain and kill themselves in lava, among other things, it really doesn't help that the AI is severely lacking in the staying alive department.

The best way we found to have fun is to engage in ridiculous concepts, that is to say; cure netherrack to be able to build in enemy bases, build cannons/arrow towers or whatever else, and go to town, it's fun to launch TNT at enemy structures while being bombarded with crates containing enemies, or getting shot with exploding spikes.

There isn't much else to say about gameplay, experimenting is a good way to enjoy the game, but it still becomes incredibly repetitive after a while, so unless you enjoy repetitive gameplay loops, I recommend you do not play this game.

You do technically get stronger in the game, so there is progression:
You earn Prismarine for defending villages/destroying bases, which you can then use to unlock resources and improve the maximum amount of those resources you can hold, therefore increasing  your fighting options and power.

Atmosphere is spot on, especially in combat, the combat music especially fits the sheer chaos that ensues while taking on enemy bases, the sound design has a ton of personality, and I've never seen something like it. In terms of atmosphere, the game truly is its own universe.

There is a clear lack of polish when doing certain things, notably building. Whenever you build a wall in this game, you designate a length of wall for your Allays to build, this is fine, it works well, it's intuitive. However, in order to destroy that wall, you are required to remove each pillar making up the wall ONE BY ONE, it is ridiculous, this should not be allowed, you could almost call it being taken hostage. This might be fine with you, but it doesn't stop there, because just interacting with the bits of walls is an endless nightmare, it's insanely clunky, high chance you'll destroy that gate you placed instead of the wall.

Multiplayer can be unplayable at times, it's fine when you're just building or exploring, but there are constant disconnections while attacking bases (especially large ones). Resources are shared between every player, so unless you're playing with friends, it's possible you'll have someone draining all the resources for themselves without giving a damn about you, and as mentioned previously, there is no way to coordinate because there is no way to communicate with other players except by pinging stuff, and even that doesn't work well because there are no specific pings, no "enemy spotted" ping, you just ping with no indication as to what it means. The maximum amount of units you can summon is also shared between players, so have fun wrestling with other people in order to have your own army.

Be warned;
There are microtransactions in the game (you might have noticed the "Minecoin" currency below the "add to card" buttons), and it appears to me that some new gameplay content will be locked behind the marketplace, because for the first Lost Legends chapter (basically additional content, it's base game but with different gameplay mechanics, the first Lost Legends chapter is free and is a wave defense gamemode), you are sent to the marketplace in order to pay zero Minecoins, it is free, but it doesn't bode well for new Lost Legends content.
If you don't like the sound of that, I recommend you wait a while and see what happens before buying.

Overall, fun game, but it's not much of an RTS and there are considerable issues that [i]will[/i] turn players off.

I recently played Life Changer and I think it's impressive. The game allows me to create my own destiny and shape my own life. I particularly loved the fact that I could compete with my friends or go on a personal journey of self-improvement against computer. It's not common to find a good life simulation game that offers both competitive and solo options, not even the SIMS, so it was a pleasant surprise.

Another feature of Life Changer that I am fond of was its RPG elements, such as map exploration and character development with the ability to advance your virtual character's education and career. You start the game in middle school and have the opportunity to work your way up to a bachelor's degree and beyond, even completing a doctorate! It's exciting to see my character's educational journey unfold and the impact it has on their career prospects.

Speaking of careers, I was impressed by the level of detail in the game's career system. You can start off your career from a humble janitorial position, and work your way up the ranks and potentially become the CEO of a large company. The game provides a sense of satisfaction as you climb the career ladder and achieve financial stability, all while making strategic decisions along the way.

One of my favorite features in the game was the investment simulation, which not only allowed me to invest in various assets like businesses and properties but also gave me the ability to upgrade and improve my virtual businesses. Through strategic investment decisions, I was able to grow my wealth and attain financial stability in the game, which added an extra level of excitement to the gameplay.

I was pleasantly surprised as well by the educational value of Life Changer. Through playing the game, I learned valuable life skills and financial literacy, which I can apply to my real-life situations. It was a great way to learn while having fun.

Overall, Life Changer is a good life simulation game that is both enjoyable and empowering. It has what I need to achieve my personal growth and success goals, from education and career advancement to financial stability and happiness.
