Chicken Fall is more than a little strange.  It's missing pieces and no small amount of polish, and boy is it janky.  It's hard to make sense of, and not even because of the clunky English or occasionally missing translation.  It does [i]not[/i] work on controller without some Steam Input retooling--and tolerance.  If it released like this, I'd probably have to give it a thumb down, because it's not [i]ready[/i].

But, in early access and at $6, I feel it's more important that within its weirdness is a neat little twin-stick shooter platformer bristling with an amalgam of oddball ideas and quirky play.  It's procedural levels are pretty sizeable and full of odd situations that lead you to consider your approach, and the dev's kitchen-sink policy has thrown in a weirdly varied pool of tools and toys.  It's definitely engaging.

There's two key downsides in that seemingly everything both costs and has deliberately limited uses, and that your inventory is just absurdly small despite needing to individually store anything you use (except, for some reason, your truckload of ammo) and [i]all your mission rewards[/i].  Want that alloy drop to pay a fraction of the next weapon unlock or that single gem stone?  Well, better drop your armor, because you've already got NINE THINGS.

I hope this dev can make this game as much as they dream for it to be, because their dreams seem worth seeing.

15 minutes in and I'm already in the headspace of "waiting for it to get good." This game doesn't offer anything that other games in this genre don't and it doesn't seem to do anything better either. Parrying is mandatory meaning the only way to face a challenge is with parry, which ignores player agency of choosing how to fight an enemy right off the bat. You only get to choose which equipment, stats and cool parry effect you're forced into.

I'm not opposed to having one mechanic be the ideal way to play the game, where compared to all other strategies it's the most effective. But forcing a single strategy on a player and hoping they know how it works? Calling yourself a metroidvania and souls-like while only having one way to face a challenging encounter is just... why? Those games give you tools which you can use in a number of ways in different situations (combat, platforming, exploring, environmental effects like a light from a torch). There's so many flaws from only the beginning that I'm not give this game more of my time. Maybe I'm missing out on something great, but if you give me two bosses back to back that are wars of attrition with a single mechanic (parry or run out of block) I'm out. 3/10

Let me preface this by saying that this isn't a terrible game by any stretch. It's competent and does what it says it'll do which is for the most part just fine. You create a character and set out on a linear(ish) adventure through some interconnected stages from start to finish and fight some bosses along the way. The game's difficulty is middle-to-high and it has no qualms in punishing you heavily for screwing up repeatedly. Par for the course for souls-likes which would be well and good were it not for a few critical flaws that stop me from really recommending the game and instead slapping it in the "no thank you" pile.

What I didn't dig :
For the starters, the game DEMANDS that you parry. Not parrying is a death sentence from the very early start to the very end -- some encounters downright impossible without it. The bulk of your damage will come from counter-attacking posture-broken enemies. This is fine, I can get behind it -- i love some high-parry gameplay that rewards good reading, however i find myself utterly frustrated by how janky the parry feels in the game. Let me explain -- parry windows are usually fairly strict in these games, but they make up for it by giving you legible telegraphs with few unnecessary "held" attacks (basically a still windup animation). Parry gameplay revolves around fluidity and legibility, and will usually at least give you some leeway in case you miss that parry window. This game however does not give you these amenities; your parry window is wide and very generous, but enemy attacks consist of elden-ring type windups that are borderline unending (some enemies will legit hold for almost a full second after their windup animation, while your parry window falls to about 500ms). Because these holds are fairly still you have to memorize rather than react for parries. This isn't my cup of tea in the slightest and I much prefer having parries be a result of a good read, not counting down how long an enemy will hold before they release a very clearly designated attack. 

Secondly, this game features some precision platforming segments. While some platforming is expected, certain areas are literally dotted with spikes along floors, walls barring one small crease for you to dash through, failue will have you take damage and respawn on your last safe ledge. Compound this with enemy placement designed to make you fight in those tight quarters, and a long recovery animation if you touch spikes and you can find yourself getting infinitely comboed by enemies who will hit you off a platform -- where you hit spikes and respawn without being able to move -- only to be knocked back down again and for this to repeat until your death. Not cool. At least give me control once I respawn so i can keep fighting.

Lastly, blocking is flat out broken. I don't mean this in the sense that you can't block -- you can. Be releasing the block button leaves you locked in place for the length of your parry window but without your block active - despite your character still clearly being in a blocking stance. This feels TERRIBLE when fighting with weapons that require any sort of windup (like axe or staff) since a missed parry leaves you almost no room to at least do a bit of chip damage in. 

The stuff I did enjoy:
The level design, color palettes and art are all really good. Visually this game looks great and really gives you a lot to look at. The palette choices for every area feels unique and the level design mixed in with it gives you a generally clear way ahead (barring the mercy colossus fight, which has a hint hidden on a signpost by the arena telling you how to progress). The enemy design is a little bare (a few recolors here and there) but each enemy feels unique in its presentation and gives you a clear indication that it's different.

The music and sound effects are nice and somber, and while not outstanding, are more than above average. This is no ender lillies, but it's got a vibe that's easy to settle into.

The weapon variety is more than enough -- each weapon type feels very distinct in its approach and playstyle and the game gives you a lot of room to experiment with builds and isn't terrible about giving you the option to respec fairly early on using dark fire seeds. Armors are quite unique in that each set will give you a set bonus -- however this does mean you wont be mixing sets like you would in some games. You can, but why would you ?

Stuff im neutral on:
The punishment for death in stripping you from your armor until you use a consumable at a specific NPC is ... interesting. I have no problems with it, it fits the lore and adds a bit of a layer of tedium to deal with if you get stonewalled in a particular place. Having to stop what you're doing to go get your armor back feels unnecesary -- the resources to do it are abundant (i had well over 30 of them by the time i stopped about 5 hours in) and are easily farmable. 

The story is servicable, it isn't bad nor particularly amazing. I haven't found myself terriby attached to it, but I wasn't skipping over dialogue either.


Overall this game's a fairly mid "neutral" for me. I'm sure i'll eventually shrug and finish off the last hour or two I seem to have left on it, but the frustration with the forced parrying and bad telegraphs has ultimately left me feeling fairly apathetic towards the game. Your mileage may vary if that's your thing though.

[h1]Opening/ Information[/h1]

Reading a review is not enough? Want to see some footage? Check the link and watch some game footage for yourself and decide if this game is worth your time:

https://youtu.be/KLJMQ1SeC5E

Deepening Fire is a Souls like, horizontal, early access game with cartoonish graphics a lovely story and a lot to do and explore.


This is the first game created byVeryBigDog who entered the rough world of Indie souls like games on Steam. I wish the best for them, and I am still confused how this game can be still in Early Access with all the content in it.


[h1]Gameplay / Story[/h1]

Complete confusion. This game is a complete confusion for me. When it popped up and our beloved Klaus tried to force me to play it like a mother force-feeds a 6-month year old, I was not amused. First red flag, its Early Access 2D side scrolling game. Second red flag, it's 2D souls like. Third Red flag, it's a one-man developer team. Fourth Red Flag: It looks like an Armor Games developed Flash game on the Videos and Screenshots. What happened then? I barely eat for 2 days and made a 7 Hours long Video and beat the game. Forgot the second amulet to have the true ending, and maybe I will play it again.


This game is a typical souls like, you got a dash function to dodge, a great parry function that activates a skill, in abused the "healing skill". You start as a guy who has no clue what happened in a calamity wasted world engulfed in fire and hate. There is no narration as it's a typical in this dark games. People tell you the story, letters tell you about the uncomfortable world and how everything gone from bad to worse to Nestle owns all our fresh water in the world. You get great stages that are unique, you have companions that tell their story. You have a Ninja Samurai who helps you find new people for your Garden. Your Garden is mostly the point you can talk, take haircuts and teleport to new worlds. This game has really hard boss fights but is extremely fair on save points and items in case your skin burns, and you can't carry armor anymore. Yes, he had to implement that. The only stupid thing is, range is by far powerful, not due to the damage but due to the constant damage you can provide since you do not have to dodge in range, and you can "pew pew" out of rage. And you know what you fight at the end? A Planet and super nova eating entity who can instantly kill you by eating you like the black void.


[h1]Pro[/h1]

+ a lot of different enemies
+ Stages are unique with easy but nice puzzles
+ unique Bosses with unique skill sets
+ NPC's you will learn to love
+ devastating story with great Dark Souls storytelling
+ a lot of Armor with unique set Bonus
+ RPG function to level up your character
+ Weapons, Staffs, Swords, Lance, Axe, Daggers it's great
+ the effects are great
+ the sound is amazing
+the controls are smooth and responsive


[h1]Contra[/h1]


- The Last Boss is really hard
- Some stages are confusing, one end boss is only accessible when letting an enemy destroy the floor.


[h1]What can the Dev do to improve the game?[/h1]

Oh hello there, since it's early access it might be good to give some advice right? Well, there isn't much I can say but:

+ More Swords please, I found like 3 through the game and a lot of other weapons, but I'm the kinda Sword guy in video games.

+ Some Book to see which items are currently missing and need to be found would be great.

[h1]Conclusion/ Who will enjoy the game?[/h1]

Deepening Fire offers an addictive game with unique Bosses and a really great effort for the souls like games. This game was such a surprise. All Red Flags were actually Green Flags. I cannot understand why this game is still marked as Early access? It's a bit pricey for the 7 hours of content, but it's a full game without any real issue. I have seen AAA Titles more unfinished at full release than this piece of art.


Who will enjoy this game? Do you like Dark Souls? Shovel Knight? Want to feel a satisfying feeling when doing a parry? Look, I can't give this game enough justice, just do yourself a favor and fast-forward the gameplay video I did and see for yourself how awesome everything fits together.

I am really liking this game, but I have some constructive feedback....

Pro's
- Visually great looking
- Challenging in terms of keeping healthy
- Large maps/ areas to explore
- lots to construct and things to build (work stations etc)
- Small elements of good things from other games (Crafting, exploring, sailing).

Con's / constructive

1) Basic things like sticks/stones can take 20 mins to go find (not in abundance) like the Forest
- When you need 4 sticks and need to run 15 mins to a tree on the other side of the island
- When you need a stone, the minimal 2-3 formations are empty and you need to find a random round stone
- Running past trees/bushes which can't be farmed (no animation) like on Raft is grindy

2) Away from the story, the game can feel bland like "Raft"
- Lots of random small islands with nothing on them
- It's great building kilns etc, but clay is very rare in most areas - which defeats wanting to build a base/items.
- Same animals all over, dog, snake, and scorpion placed near resources makes it a bit "MMO" feeling

3) Resources are spread far too wide, with 3 or 4 stone piles on a large island (when running past millions of rock 
  formations)
- Large Island - Great! Lots of trees and rocks - Awesome! Can you mine most of it - NO?
- Throw stuff like random big sticks, branches, and more sticks around, let us build and be creative once the story/ initial survival element is getting stale.
- No animations/time consumption for crafting - often contradicts the survival system

When you first spawn in, getting sunburned, thirsty, and naked...feels like the movie "Cast Away" which is AWESOME!

After a while, it starts feeling like the game "Raft" where it's nice and pretty, but so much missing and there could be so much more to do...please add this whilst it's in early access! :)

I beat what's currently available in this game in 6.4 hours: level 3 of the 3 maps, ending with Lunar Colony.  It was a challenge and absolutely packed with fun.  I have a lot of praise to give for the game, and a list of minor gripes.  Note that these are very minor gripes, and I still recommend the game overall.

Gripe number 1: Even though I'm using a gamepad with analog directional control, the movement seems to lock in to the 8 directions.  There are rotations between and I can fiddle back and forth to stay between, but if I'm not constantly moving the analog stick away from my intended direction, it doesn't follow the exact direction I'm using with the analog control.  I think the game would be better with this fixed, since I see no reason to lock into cardinal directions.  This is my main gripe with the game.

Gripe number 2: There are only 3 or 4 good upgrades on each weapon in the end of the game.  I want to get the cooldown reduction, damage, and crit on all my weapons.  If I get them, I clear everything with no problem.  If I happen to miss them on any of my weapons, the swarm becomes overwhelming and I can't beat the curve.

Gripe number 3: Each weapon is limited to 3 upgrades.  There is a ton of synergy between upgrades and I would have loved to focus on 1 weapon and get a ton of upgrades for it, which would limit the upgrades I can get for other weapons.  That would be very cool.  Unfortunately, you are forced to upgrade weapons you don't like instead of being able to pile onto 1 awesome weapon.  In combination with gripe number 2, all the weapons feel samey in the end if you want to win every battle.

Gripe number 4: Getting to the intended strafe angle wastes your movement significantly.  If I want to face a swarm and mow it down, I have to first get far away from them, then turn around and run toward them fairly significantly, such that it's very wasteful.  In the end-game, it's almost never a good idea to try that unless you have plenty of space.  It's better to get lucky with your enemy positions in the early game and run toward them.  This kind of defeats the coolness factor of learning to use the strafing system.  I would prefer if you could turn independently of your movement, even if that required some kind of upgrade.  If that happened, it would be also nice to have more than 1 decent weapon that takes advantage of your facing direction.  The laser is good but encourages never strafing, and the diagonal shot is just garbage in my experience.

Gripe number 5: Only the first mech that's unlocked by default is any good, and only the second pilot that's unlocked is good.  Choosing the other mechs than the one that has good handling or pilots than the one that increases attack speed is a sure way to lose in the highest difficulties.  It would be nice if later mechs and pilots that are unlocked had advantages, but they seem to be worse.  The mech that provides speed has such terrible handling that it's unusable, and the mech that adds max hp is useless because its other stats are worse and the max hp doesn't come back any faster if you're damaged.

Gripe number 6: The number of non-weapon upgrades you can get are artificially limited in such a way that you can break your whole run if you get the wrong ones.  If you don't get the healing upgrade, you are pretty much guaranteed to lose in the end-game.  Movement speed and handling are good together, but you're bound to take a hit or two whenever you get surrounded, and the healing upgrade is so significant that it's almost mandatory to succeed.  I tried a few runs without it and I only won without it once.

Gripe number 7: Leveling to max level is guaranteed on every full run, so you end up running out of ways to upgrade around the 10-to-12-minute mark, which leaves 8 to 9 minutes of no upgrading and just shooting and dodging.  It would be nice to be able to get further upgrades.  Maybe something like that is coming with meta-progression, but currently with the max level of 60, it feels a bit less fun after 12 minutes.

Gripe number 8: While I'm only half-way through the meta-progression after having beaten the last available mission, all the future meta-progression upgrades available are almost worthless.  I have the ones that boost damage, and the ones that boost handling and healing, but the rest do things that don't really matter, so I'm left wondering how I'll be able to increase my power for any harder missions.

Gripe number 9: The bosses at the end of each run are essentially jokes.  By the time I reached the third boss in each run (the last boss), I was so powerful that it would die in under 3 seconds if I just faced it and punched it.  I would have liked to see something like all the other enemies going away when the boss spawns and the boss being a serious threat on its own, at least in threat level 3 runs.  It'd be really cool to see the gameplay shift that would come with something like that.

Despite all these minor gripes, the game kicks ass.  Here are some praises off the top of my head, and I'm not sure I can recall everything I liked:

- I played on Linux, and the game ran perfectly, and my gamepad worked immediately.
- There were absolutely 0 performance dips below 60 fps, which is my monitor's native refresh rate.  I'm using an Nvidia GTX 1080 Ti.
- I encountered only 1 bug in the entire time I played, it was in the menu and caused a button to be disabled when it should be enabled, and it resolved itself with some simple re-navigation which enabled the buggy button.
- The music and sounds are amazing, and I never felt the need to turn the sound off and replace it with a background video or my own music.
- There is legitimate challenge which doesn't feel too frustrating.  There are definitely moments when it felt impossible to succeed just because of unlucky upgrade options, but buying some meta-progression and restarting the mission to try again a few times always resulted in a sense of progress and never just hopelessness.
- The limitations of the current version of the game are clearly exhibited with "Coming soon" buttons for future maps, mechs, and pilots, so I feel like even though I beat the game, I have more fun ahead.  I'm hoping the devs follow through because I'm excited to see any changes.
- The price is fair for the game; just about the upper limit for a game I'd purchase individually without a bundle, considering I already have almost 1000 games and haven't played more than half of them.
- This game is the best mech game I've ever played, and really makes me feel like I'm piloting a monstrous mech that has superior technology compared to vast armies of traditional units.
- The enemies and graphics are very clear as to what will hurt you and what is good, while maintaining that unique feeling that comes from being in a huge mech.

I was addicted to the original Desktop Dungeons, and this is essentially a remastered+ version. Desktop Dungeons is a brilliant puzzler with RPG elements.

Research

Money

Star Map

Invasion / Combat Mechanics

Nice refreshing single-player take on the base building survival genre. Instead of constantly hitting trees and rocks, it's an instant action but you trade off your in-game hours.

I strongly urge anyone who enjoys survival games to pick this game up and give it a try, AND BE PATIENT! When I bought this game I found myself not enjoying it for the 1st 2 hours of gameplay. I took a step back and actually played another game for a couple of hours, and once I was relaxed and ready to try this game again I went for a straight 12hr binge. What I didnt like at first impression was how stiff and slow everything is, coupled with the "Long Dark" style of time passing during certain actions you make. But I now very much appreciate how the physics of the player work in the game, as it feels more grounded in realism, and really isn't that bad at all. The time passing mechanic kinda grew on me as it actually keeps the pace of the game going from decision to decision and I have absolutely no complaints.

What keeps me hooked on playing the game is the immersion I feel in the world. The graphics are great , but not fascinating and they remain consistently polished to the point where every asset on the island and it's surrounding waters feels like it belongs. The map itself is very well made and I find myself keen on discovering everything if I have the stamina to do so. There are so many things to learn and build in this game that I can foresee myself putting hundreds of hours into this game, which brings me back around to my first point.

If you are a fan of Survival games, you don't want to miss out on this game!

How to start... Perhaps first to shortly describe two runs, then to write my observations and suggestions.
     First run (Easy difficulty): Was very short. Melee attacks seemed to be very weak and very quickly I was low on health. Also, in first few houses was nothing of use, just a bit of pistol ammo but no weapons or pickups whatsoever. Then went to a metal factory marked with a green exclamation mark and I've found a first and only weapon - Tokarev rifle. Had only 6 bullets, managed to eliminate two zombies but all of a sudden a horde of 6-7 zombies just spawned from the room behind (which was cleared) and that was the first death. I've respawned in the safe house but literally in the second room there was a horde of zombies waiting and that was second death. Next respawn zombies were there in the very exact room where I've had spawned and that was the third death, only within first few seconds of being respawned. Total first run was less that 10 minutes.
     Second run (Easy difficulty again): Spawned in a safe house, nothing there, moved to a next house and oh boy...a jackpot (both in good and not so good way). Few items were there at once - Welrod pistol, M32 Grease Gun, some ammo.. But once I've picked up those, almost immediately other items started to spawn. And was like that for good 15-20 minutes - whenever i picked up something, something else respawned within several second. Total, had over 200 pistol ammo, almost 150 rifle ammo, around 70 sniper ammo, perhaps 40 shotgun ammo, lots of candy bars, cough syrup, energy drinks, two or three of each Welrod, Grease Guns and M1 carbines, as well as a knife and a wooden bat. With all that, managed to survive quite long, perhaps over 50 minutes. Reason for the first death in this run was automatic increase in difficulty (I guess it was), as, the scale reached pink / purple-ish color saying "Insane". Zombies started to spawn all over, a lot of them, behavior changed completely - they were detecting me from very far away (even though it was night time), they were jumping over the walls, going into houses.. Even when I reached the safe house, they were not only going inside but were respawning inside cleared rooms as well, glitching through the walls and closed doors too. Second and third death were very quick, as, difficulty meter was on Insane, managed to reach two more houses but since all rooms over there were completely empty, I've died twice empty handed, as there were too many zombies.
       Impressions and suggestions:
     - Very nice concept, lots of room for expanding the core gameplay with open-world maps, random generation, scripted maps,..
     - Lots of potential for different types of maps and game modes. Can be fully- or semi-random generated maps, scenario maps with linear or branching objectives / paths. (Heroes of Might & Magic 3 flashbacks kicking in :) )
     - Huge modding potential. Hope that game developers will include modding tools and work on having active and friendly modding community. Really enormous potential for that to happen, as the basic game concepts offer a lot of room for modding.
     Suggestions and personal opinions about game mechanics so far:
    - Starting unarmed only. Okay, but needs to be more impactfull. Damage with both "1" weapon slot and "F" key attack are too weak. Even if you have, for example, a rifle equipped, hits with weapon buttstock seemed weaker than hits with fists. Knife and wooden bat too, haven't noticed any difference in the amount of the damage dealt. Also, when wielding a melee weapon, perhaps a right mouse button could serve as a block, as zooming with a melee weapon has no purpose.
     - Firearms. So far, okay variety for open alpha. Even though, hits with a firearm don't feel that much impactful, even when you hit a zombie in the head. Very little noticeable difference in weapon damage - whether it's a Welrod pistol, M1 carbine or Tokarev rifle. Zombies just keep running towards you, start jumping, moving really fast.. Here, feel that game developers could have to choose between arcade or a bit more realistic approach in firearms and weapon combat. Or, perhaps both to be available, as in-game options when creating a world map / lobby.
     - Weapon slots. Personally, feel it's very restrictive and maybe it would be better just to leave the slots open for any kind of weapons a player desire. That could allow for more flexibility, adapting to weapon pickups (as drops are random) and more enjoyment in multiplayer matches, where players could specialize and customize loadouts, exchange weapons in-game as they see it fit to their strategies and playstyle.
     - Item drops. Way too little. Item drops are very scarce, often there is absolutely nothing to pickup. Health and support items too. Aside from that spawning bug in second run, almost all of the houses were completely empty. In my opinion, balancing difficulties, giving an enjoyable or challenging gameplay stems from giving items and pickups to players while balancing environment, enemies, meaningful challenges etc.. and not from denying the basic items and leaving the players completely empty handed.
     - Environment. So far, completely empty. Would be great to be able to scrounge through the cupboards, shelves, refrigerators, ovens, etc.. to give players more incentive for exploration and immersion. Perhaps a rare drop chance in wardrobe closets to find new clothes, avatar accessories,.. Lots of the world objects - such as fire extinguishers, boxes, dishes, ventilators chairs, etc.. - perhaps could be used as pick-and-throw objects that can deal damage and stun zombies. Also, plates with food, baskets of fruits that are often found in kitchen tables..perhaps could be a one-time health or stamina consumables. Maybe to introduce wending machines scattered throughout the map too.
     - Health and stamina mechanics. Health seems okay so far, even though healing items are almost non-existent. Aside (again) that spawning bug when I got lost of cough syrup (which instantly fills the health bar by some amount) and a candy bar (which seems bugged, as description says it regenerates health when hunger icon is full but it doesn't do that, no health regeneration effect). Perhaps healing items should be more present, in different varieties and healing mechanics.
About stamina.. Seems fair that it's used for active actions such as jumping, sprinting, dodging.. But huge problem is that every action decreases your maximum stamina bar so eventually you come to a situation where you have very little max stamina available, which disables a player from actively dodging in succession, jumping over the fences or windows.. (which is a cool mechanic, being able to just jump though the window but needs a bit of polish as often avatar just jumps in a spot instead of through the window, even though you're standing correctly).
     - Day / Night cycle. Nice addition and immersion mechanic. Perhaps it could be more meaningful later in the future, with specific types of enemies appearing in different times of a day. Or, perhaps an in-fight mechanics (similar like in classic Doom, where different types of monsters attack each other).
     - Enemy variety. Noticed only a regular type of zombies. But, really don't like that enemy behavior is changing on the fly - they are either standing or rushing and jumping towards you. It breaks the zombie immersion for me. Also, magically spawning from nowhere or behind a player from a room that was cleared just don't feel fair.
     - Difficulty scaling. Should stay as declared, not raise automatically every 10 minutes or so. Perhaps "aggro / notoriety" system around a small area, similar like in GTA.
     - Perk / skills system. Adding an additional reason to have skills, character progression / specialization.
Hope this can be a constructive feedback to developers and I'm looking forward to see this game as a new indie hit, like Ravenfield.

Mario Kart 8 Deluxe is one of my all-time favorite games. Whatever you imagine when you hear "Disney Kart Racing Game": Disney Speedstorm is most certainly not that! This game is suprisingly unique, and not just another "Mario Kart Clone". It has a great sense of speed. The tracks may not be as creative as in Nintendo's game, but the core gameplay here is also much less about "get around curves fast", and more about "combo various types of speed boosts for max speed". And it's also unexpected how much STYLE this game has, from it's graphical presentation and especially it's electronic music soundtrack, that has some killer hits!
Technically I also had no issues so far, and it runs great on the Steam Deck. Online Multiplayer is fun, but a suprisingly huge chunk of the content is for singleplayer races. Characters do level up and get better stats. They do have individual powers that are noticably imbalanced. So if you are looking for an arcade racer for balanced and skill-focused competiton, this is not the game for you. Play this for it's breakneck feeling of speed and the insane action moments it puts on your screen!

The elephant in the room is the games monetization. Well, you can't gloss over it: outside of its races the games looks exactly a free2play mobile game, and if you hate every aspect of free2play games, this will be your nightmare. It has it all: paid season pass, various currencies, cosmetics, lootboxes, content on cooldown,...
This IS a free2play game, that is scheduled for release in late 2023 or 2024. Right now, you're not buying a game, you're literally paying to get EARLY ACCESS to this new, FREE game, in it's current state. So please do your research and make sure you know what you get yourself into, to avoid frustrations.

I, personally, am having a blast so far with this suprisingly stylish and fast arcade action racer, that gives me something to play everyday. Since the content is broken up into seasons, I will make my personal verdict on this after the end of the first season, when I know how far I progressed, how much time the game demanded to experience and unlock its seasonal content and, most important, how much fun I had during these weeks. Then I will see if I'll keep playing, or leave the game for good.

So right know, though I'm having a lot of fun, I can't actually recommend this to anyone, unless you are very aware about what you are getting, when you purchase a Founder's Pack.

Thanks for the free game. The original DD is one of my most-played Steam games.

You guys messed this one up, though. Here's what needs to change to have a chance at a positive review:

- Allow me to see the entire map on one screen. I don't like zooming and panning around for my "coffee-break game," I want to see everything at once so I can make quick, informed strategic decisions.

- Allow me to turn off the animations. I don't need to see the characters and enemies fight each other, I want to watch numbers subtract from each other so I can move on to the next set of numbers as quickly as possible.

- Fix the GOD AWFUL UI. It takes double the time to make out anything in this mess of information, including the frigging character select screen. Labels would be nice -- I don't want to mouse over a dwarf to see that it's a dwarf. Why are all their heads brown with no distinguishing characteristics? WTF? Why do I have to click the challenge flags to see what they are? The information on the game map all blends in to the background. You should have DD non-veterans playtest this UI. The only reason I got through was that I had most of this stuff memorized.

- There's nothing wrong with the word "race," why did you do this? I'm more put off by the gore and violence you added -- the opening title has a monster keeling over and spilling blood across the screen. One of your trailers shows an adventurer's bloody, dismembered head falling to the ground. Yes, there were little blood pools in the original, but that's nothing compared to this. Guess I won't be playing this game with my kids -- the word "race" is far less objectionable.

This remaster focuses on all the wrong things. I won't be playing again until I see an update addressing this.

Solid 8/10 game, finished with around 13 hours of actual playtime with all achievements, so perhaps not worth the full 30 dollar price tag but I personally don't regret buying it.

Pros are good combat, great writing, good music, good visuals.
Cons are aiming system feels a little clunky, and spell variety/choice could be better in my opinion, healing towers and nature enemies with homing magic can feel a little annoying on some maps, and it's short for the price tag. 

Pros heavily outweigh the cons, if you're interested in Mageseeker and unsure, Riot's earned my recommendation this time.

as an ADHD-haver and Minecraft enjoyer with no real experience with RTS games or things like Pikmin, I sat down and binged the story (and only the story) in two days. I'm just going to share my thoughts with that perspective in mind, so please consider that!

I want to open by agreeing with the fact that, as the game is on launch, it's not worth a $40-50 USD price tag. while the game is beautiful and I somehow ran into minimal issues performance-wise, I agree that the story is fairly bare bones as it is and is actually quite short in comparison to most games these days (roughly 10 hours, could be shorter if you decided not to explore much)
that being said, this is a children's game! it's a game made for children targeted as children, I wasn't expecting a story with depth or any real length to it, and as someone who has never played an RTS, I found the gameplay fairly challenging without the aspects of co-op or PVP involved

I did play about an hour or two in story co-op, but didn't get any connectivity issues or anything. what I [i]did[/i] find out was that one person skipping cutscenes skipped them for [i]EVERYBODY[/i]. I had already seen them 3 times at the point that I was skipping, but it was my boyfriend's first time seeing them, so I unknowingly skipped the majority of the earliest cutscenes for him until he brought up that they weren't playing all the way and I told him I'd been skipping mine. after I stopped skipping cutscenes, his played properly, so the issue was just me skipping

bridges were difficult to place; world gen was very strange and hard to work with; and no matter how many corners of the map I [i]did[/i] explore, a lot of things either never appeared or I simply never found them, which was quite a bit frustrating since I was trying to unlock everything I could to actually have a strategy other than "rush to the portal, make everything hit it" (which worked anyway, I broke most portals doing only that!)

also, at the moment there is no postgame save for the single free-LC thing and PVP. I'd prefer an infinite free play mode that encourages exploration and base building that maybe even incentivized cleaning up the nether everywhere, but instead my postgame was...a notification that never went away and whatever pop-up bases I didn't clear (and maybe a bunch of the Random Event village raids)
[spoiler]also the three spirits? aspects? whatever that summoned us to the world just completely disappeared from the Overworld in postgame, leaving me behind in the starting area scarred with nether so badly that all the flowers and animals were gone too, generally making me feel very awkward and lonely. is this supposed to feel rewarding? I feel punished...[/spoiler]

as someone who does not enjoy PVP and likes games I can dump thousands of hours into doing literally nothing, I would've liked a reason to do just that. but as it stands, this game has a very brief shelf life, and once you finish the story and free-LC, you likely won't have a reason to come back for a really long time if you also don't like PVP

there's no issue with a game being short or a game that's only meant to be played once, but Minecraft's spinoffs like Dungeons tend to have a lot of content and felt like they could be played infinitely. with that standard in mind, this game is lacking a lot

I also agree that there could be more units &ct added in the future. I understand why you used golems/humanoid mobs, but I'd like to see something like bats or goats get used too! the closest equivalent were llamas that you could rally for ranged shots, but you can't summon those on demand (which is also disappointing!)

[u]in conclusion/TL;DR:[/u] children's game meant for kids doesn't have a lot going on; story is simple. game could use more content/an extra game mode, but the game is enjoyable. the ending needs work [b]very[/b] badly

The completely random level construction method leads to a complete loss of control over the difficulty of the game.
Simply put, this game has a spell where after petrifying a small monster (without gaining experience), the next kill experience gains+50%. Monsters are classified into different levels, with lower level monsters having less experience and higher level monsters having more experience. So far, it is still normal.
However, first of all, the experience card of this game is very dead. You must use this spell multiple times to be at the same level as the boss, otherwise you will find yourself two or even three levels lower than the boss. Secondly, this game upgrade has a huge improvement in attributes. That is to say, if you are lower than the boss level, you will not be able to fight at all. If you cannot fight, you will have to run away. This cost benefit is equal to 0, and you will also lose the money you spent on buying things.
Then there is also a very treacherous situation. The initial map of this game is covered by the fog of war, and the character's health and mana are restored by exploring the map. If you don't hit the discovered monster, you will lose blood and mana. That means you can't plan your route at all, you can only rely on luck. Often, it's difficult to kill monsters in front of you, and a bunch of level 1 small monsters emerge from behind. Then, the remaining big monsters are generally one or two levels higher than you, and you can't beat them at all.
Having said so much, even the game's spell drops are random. Sometimes (a lot) you don't even have the experienced spell in the entire map, and you don't even have to gamble on luck. This map will definitely not pass, even if you open the entire map at the beginning and plan to pass, because you don't have enough level, you just can't win.
Sure enough, there is a reason why this game is free. Steam has never given me any fun games for free.

Ravendock is a fun mix of Raft and Colony Sim. When you start the game, you're given the bare minimum - a dock and some planks - and are given the freedom to create what you'd like. It has a lot of depth. You can get to the point where everything is automated. There are areas to explore. NPCs to meet. Some colonists even come with specific passive that match their clothing. For example, one can show up wearing vegetables on her head which means she eats less.

You quickly get lost in this game. What was supposed to be a quick 20 to 30 minute session turned into nearly 4 hours quickly, and not a single moment full dull. Getting struck by lightning, fires, having to deal with the happiness of colonists, etc. There's always something that can be improved.

I'm excited for the future of Havendock.

More of a meh than a recommend or not. 

I was excited for this game to come out and the first couple hours I was feeling goooooooood. Game play was smooth and chaining around to different enemies while blasting off spells felt good. 

However this game somehow manages to overstay it's welcome, despite being only about 10-15 hours long. 

-The areas are cool at first but eventually just devolve into rooms of bad dudes that you gotta punch for too many rooms.
-The spell upgrade system is fun until you realize most spells are kinda useless and, while they look cool, are too mana inefficient and you're better off just blasting folks with the base spells until closer to end game. 
-There were several times where the game soft locked on me either due to a bug or because I was out of mana and a specific enemy type can only be damaged with spells, so with no way to kill the last enemy in a room and progress I had to quit out and start the level completely over again. 
-The mouse and keyboard controls are just bad. Playing with a controller feels much better. 
-Combat is almost smooth; a lot of times trying to launch cool combos then dash away like the magically badass you feel like doesn't always work. I found myself spamming the same quick combo all game and never really needing to move away from it since no enemy was able to adequately punish or force me to change tactics, even bosses. 
-Speaking of bosses, they're probably the best part of combat. They usually offer fun tests of game knowledge and reflexes. However, most of the later bosses have several stages, fine, but there's no indication of this so if you pop all your best spells and unchained mode early, you might end up wailing on them in a useless effort since they go invulnerable. That's fine, test the player, punish them sure. This is an issue because there's no skip cutscene button. So if you die on a boss, you have to sit through the entire dialog with them and then through all the stages, which usually aren't hard once you know their attack patterns. So instead of a fun challenge they sometimes just feel like their wasting your time as you slowly crawl towards progression. 
-The story is kinda, all over the place. Characters are cool but need some more room to breathe and develop. Due to the length of the game things happen one after the other and there's no sense of any story beats being earned. 
-The hideout growing as you recruit mages is super cool, to see it go from a rundown ruin to a bustling little town is super satisfying. There should be more perks attached to this system though, usually you just get upgrade materials, which are nice, but it feels like there should be more there. 

All that said, I don't think this is a bad game, just kind of a mediocre one. The core gameplay loop here it great, but unfortunately that's kind of it. For fans of the League universe like me, the lore and world building are the main draw. For non fans there's not much for you. 

The biggest issue and the reason for the negative review is the DLC. As a fan I thought I'd support the company by going for the deluxe edition since the Ruined King Deluxe offered some cool weapons that were references to League proper. For $10 this game locks a few spells (not even particularly good or impressive ones), a couple PNGs for your "room" (literally just set dressing, no interaction or anything), 3 palette swaps, and some bonus upgrade materials after each main story mission (which as I've said are kinda pointless since the game gives you more than enough to max out your character). So to increase the price 1/3 for literally nothing is gross. It reeks of Riot's money grubby meddling and it's a shame.

I rarely play games of the same saga one after the other, because I've found that they put me off a bit and I usually end up leaving the second title half finished, or I force myself to complete it. However, when I finished Coffee Talk and received the opportunity to play its sequel, I immersed myself once again, fully and without hesitation, to this fantastic universe so relaxed and jovial. I must say, being a narrative and enjoyable experience, I didn't feel that usual overwhelming feeling, and I'm very glad since both titles have been truly magnificent. 

Coffee Talk Episode 2: Hibiscus & Butterfly, is the second installment of this very special game that has touched many people since its release. It is a title that presents itself as a visual novel with simulation elements, putting us in the role of Barista (the main character whom we can name, and whom I will refer to as him for simplicity), owner of a very peculiar coffee shop that only operates at night, and which is frequented by creatures and people of all kinds. I will try not to repeat myself too much with respect to my previous review (from Coffee Talk 1), [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Sieghiro/recommended/914800/]and I invite you to read it first just in case and to avoid any confusion![/url]

The [b]story[/b] follows the same pattern as in the first installment, being told as a set of stories that involve the various characters who visit the Coffee Talk caf√©. On this occasion, we‚Äôll be able to glimpse a little more about characters that previously did not have so much prominence, such as Jorji, the neighborhood policeman and proud father, who escapes from time to time to have a hot drink between his nightly patrol days. This gentleman will follow the trail of acts of vandalism against cars, and little by little will be involved in a couple of somewhat paranormal events that will make for a strange case.

On the other hand, new and curious individuals will make an appearance in our establishment, such as Lucas, a ‚Äòsatire‚Äô influencer who focuses on trends, or Riona, a ‚Äòbanshee‚Äô whose dream is to become an opera soprano. This particular duo is quite prevalent in the 'story', and among the new characters they are certainly my two favorites. Lucas is very charismatic, but has moments that filled me with tenderness, and Riona is somewhat shy and pessimistic, but will open up with us little by little. Among other new characters, there is also Neil's (an alien from the first game) sister who has come in search of her brother and to learn more about our race.

Other of our dear old customers will also have their moments, such as Lua and Bailey, the couple that against all odds has finally reached the path of planning their wedding; or Hyde, the vampire model who is already a bit bored with his job and is looking to broaden his horizons. These and many more stories are woven thanks to the atmosphere of our coffee shop, a special corner where people can feel at home, and we as Barista will be in charge of welcoming them and giving them warmth. We'll also be able to unveil some secrets and uncertainties that we were left with in the first installment, such as the origin of the Barista himself, which kept me in suspense on more than one occasion. It is, as in the first installment, a story full of interesting, comical and emotional situations, a tangle of very nice tales and that although they are set in fantasy, they feel very real. A narrative that captivated me yet again.

The [b]gameplay[/b] does not change much with respect to the previous title, we can continue reading and interacting with our customers by preparing them drinks in an enjoyable mini-game. However, we‚Äôll have some variety that will keep things interesting, since we‚Äôll have a new mechanic where we'll be presented with objects, whether by their owners' own will or not, and we'll have to return them or pass them on to those who need them. This must be done at the time of serving the drink, and on more than one occasion I have lost the opportunity to serve the coffee with the corresponding item next to it; I recommend not to follow my steps, and pay attention! Otherwise it will happen to you as it did to me, that at the end of the game I was told the following: "you may have completed the story, but you have not appreciated all its nuances".

Another thing that stands out a lot this time is the new repertoire of ingredients that we'll have at our disposal when creating new mixtures. In particular, we'll have hibiscus and anchan tea, spices that provide a very colorful aspect to the drinks we can prepare. Hibiscus gives a very lively reddish tinge, and anchan, on the other hand, creates a bluish coloration that conveys tranquility, and these details will be important when it comes to fulfilling orders; after all, these two herbs will be very popular among our clientele, so it is worth taking note of the drinks we create with these ingredients.

A detail that I didn't mention in my previous review, more out of absent-mindedness than anything else, is that depending on whether or not we get the drinks we are asked for, will be how the 'stories' of the characters end, in a good or bad ending, so to speak. It is something that curiously did not give me "problems" in the first game, but that is much more noticeable in this second installment, as it has more variety with respect to the arcs of each of them. Customers play more with your memory, asking you for drinks like "the one you served me that day", and sometimes... they even reference requests from the first installment, so evil!

In addition to coffee and recipes, we'll have a new function in our app "Tomodachil", in which we'll be able to see the 'stories' of our customers and leave them a 'like' if we want; it‚Äôs a simple detail I appreciate it, as it is entertaining to see what kind of interactions there are between the characters in this social network. Just as in real life, they disappear the next day, so you have to be attentive in case you don't want to miss one of them. Apart from that, we still have the recipe book, the music player app and the diary, although Freya no longer writes in it. It is not that there is a great revolution in gameplay, but I have been entertained as I was entertained in the first game, and that's what I find most important.

The [b]graphics[/b] are just like the previous one, a detailed and very beautiful pixel style. Some of the characters will have new aspects, such as hairstyles or clothing, and the environment is still that cozy coffee shop we are used to. I remember mentioning that I regretted not being able to glimpse those creatures passing by on the sidewalk, through the shop windows, and I am grateful that this time we could meet Lucas and Riona, these two new races and individuals who have a phenomenal style. The [b]soundtrack[/b] returns with a vengeance, boasting delightful songs of various rhythms; I noticed the occasional livelier one, such as a very fierce piano tune, but they still don't leave out the melodies that convey tranquility and relaxation. There is little I can say about this section, since I would be repeating myself too much in respect to my previous review, but I want to make it clear that it is still an excellent soundtrack.

In [b]conclusion[/b], Coffee Talk 2 ~ Hibiscus & Butterfly  is a second episode that, with a stronger than strong story, once again brings us all kinds of emotions between conversations and endearing characters. The strong point has always been its storytelling and the interactions between its clientele, and it's beautiful to be able to see the relationships that have formed between the characters that started as cafe acquaintances, to the point of calling each other family; and these moments touched me to the core. The gameplay did not lose its touch and added some other entertaining mechanics, and the audiovisual aspect maintains the impeccability of the first title. Totally recommended!

[h1]Desktop Dungeons Review[/h1]

Desktop Dungeons is an addictive and challenging puzzle roguelike that offers a unique and rewarding experience for players who enjoy dungeon crawling, resource management, and strategy. From the moment you start playing, you'll find yourself drawn into a world of randomly generated dungeons filled with traps, monsters, and loot. Your goal is to defeat each dungeon's boss and bring back as much treasure as possible, while also upgrading your kingdom to unlock new classes, races, and items.

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]

One of the most impressive things about Desktop Dungeons is its gameplay mechanics. The game is turn-based, and each turn you make decisions that will impact your success or failure. You have to manage your resources carefully, including your health, mana, and inventory, as you explore each dungeon. Every step you take, every monster you fight, and every trap you trigger could mean the difference between victory and defeat.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The game is also incredibly challenging. Each dungeon is randomly generated, which means that you never know what to expect. Some dungeons are easier than others, but even the easiest ones can be tough if you're not careful. You have to think strategically and plan your moves carefully to survive.

[h1]Classes[/h1]

One of the great things about Desktop Dungeons is the way it rewards experimentation. There are dozens of classes and races to choose from, each with its own unique strengths and weaknesses. Some classes are better suited for certain dungeons than others, and some races have special abilities that can help you in specific situations. You'll need to experiment with different combinations of classes and races to find the best strategy for each dungeon.

[h1]Graphics & Sound Design[/h1]

The graphics and sound design in Desktop Dungeons are simple but effective. The game has a charming, retro-style aesthetic that is both nostalgic and modern. The music and sound effects are also well done, adding to the overall atmosphere of the game.

[h1]Overall Experience[/h1]

Overall, Desktop Dungeons is a fantastic game that is well worth your time and money and for this week when I am writing this review you can even get it for free. The gameplay is addictive and challenging, the mechanics are well thought out and balanced, and the graphics and sound design are top-notch. Whether you're a fan of roguelikes or just looking for a fun and engaging puzzle game, Desktop Dungeons is definitely worth checking out.

I didn't find the few mechanics in this game satisfying.

It's a bit weird to be told you've lost the game on the first click, and [i]then[/i] be sent into a tutorial, which has overblown music like the world was about to end. The gameplay is like learning an awkward version of chess, as you have to consider each move carefully even if you're not near an enemy. Simply walking around the dungeon can mean you lose, even if nothing attacks you. As far as I've seen, the enemies are unable to attack you first, so the fighting is a bit flat.

I didn't like how the difficulty revolved around recycling all your items and trying to remember which tiles you already stepped on, because you only regenerate health (and recharge ranged attacks) by stepping on tiles that you've never stepped on before, so the healing potential is wasted if you step on them at full health. You need their healing potential to recover after fighting low level enemies so that you can level up to beat the dungeon boss. Part of the problem is that you can only see the tiles immediately around you (or ones you've already stepped on), so you can't even plan ahead - essentially soft-locking you if you don't end up strong enough to defeat the boss. You're more or less forced to buy "preparations" just to slightly increase your chance of winning, and get punished for experimenting with different strategies because the meta is narrow, and restarting costs you the preparations again.

As the meta involves pacing around the dungeon while counting the tiles like a mentalist, I didn't feel any immersion - the game breaks the fourth wall constantly which doesn't help, and fights just involve a mouse click or two. I thought there must be something fun about this game, but I don't get it. When exploring a dungeon I feel like I'm messing up an awkwardly made puzzle, and that's the entire game. I'd rather trade the intensity of picking your steps so carefully for the animating flow of a real-time strategy game. Why wouldn't I play something more fleshed out like Age of Empires 2? Even Celtic Kings had an RPG mode that felt more natural. For ¬£11.99 it doesn't offer much in the way of mechanics, and seems game-breakingly difficult.
Got Rewind for free as I bought the original back when. TotalBiscuit recommended the original Desktop Dungeons and this one plays the same on the mechanical side. I love it.

This is basically a modernized reboot of the original Desktop Dungeons with a few small changes. Which is fine, because the original game was already an incredible gane.

Desktop Dungeons is basically a dungeon crawl themed puzzle game where a fresh level 1 character is dropped into a dungeon and you have to carefully manage your resources to fight enemies and defeat the bosses at the end of the level. For instance, regeneration occurs when you uncover new parts of the map, so it's important to explore at a measured pace to avoid running out of health. You'll also need to keep track of items, glyphs and the whims of the various Gods within the game.

Lots of varied dungeons together with many different class and kin combinations leads to a lot of replayability. There are also a lot of puzzles and challenges that can really test your knowledge of the game systems, and a daily dungeon with a leaderboard.

One thing I'm not crazy about is that the new graphics make it a little harder to see what's going on with everything at a glance. However there are some interesting balance changes and some quality of life improvements that I can appreciate.

Anyway, it's a great game and you should play it, or at least check out the original Desktop Dungeons.

Extremely disappointed.

Let‚Äôs address it straight away. The art style is without a doubt the biggest selling point to this game and rightly so. I mean it worked on me too. Using the classic Japanese ink painting aesthetic can‚Äôt help but stand out. And while I did have my concerns about how well this would translate on a more 3D plane, as soon as I took my first few steps, my concerns washed away. The disturbing monster designs, fog and mist elements bringing along all those weird and wonderful Silent Hill vibes are a more than welcome addition.

Put simply, gameplay wise it‚Äôs an old school D&D or Wizardry based dungeon crawler. You move your party around a map, jump into battle and use your limited options to best your foes. So those of you coming out of your 1990‚Äôs cryo chamber, you‚Äôll be a little underwhelmed on the gameplay front. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, Labyrinth of Zangetsu does the basics incredibly well but most battles play out the same.

Also being an old school style game, the difficulty is right up there with the toughest of them. But only until after the second level. You‚Äôll have crits a plenty go against you, wiping out your party members. You‚Äôll then have to head back to the temple to resurrect them‚Ä¶ well if you‚Äôre lucky. It costs a heavy chunk of change to do this in the early game so you‚Äôll create new warriors to replace the higher level ones you lost to grind for cash‚Ä¶ not in that way. But what is likely to happen, you get impatient and they die too. 

It‚Äôs incredibly tedious doing this but like I mentioned it doesn‚Äôt last long until you start tripping over weapons worth 1000‚Äôs of yen and amassing a small fortune. Also by this time, you‚Äôll find you are becoming something of a small army, wasting the lesser cronies for fun. Fortunately the bosses and hidden enemies will put you back in your place if you decide to turn your brain off.

The story is another minimal aspect to the game. It‚Äôs essentially a go here, do this type of plot. I never really felt I had input in the story at any point, which is a shame. Oh and is it really to much to ask for an auto move feature? But enough of my moaning. I like to nitpick and some of these issues I spotted will irk other people too. 

Labyrinth of Zangetsu is a lot of fun. So much so that when I started playing it, I didn‚Äôt want to play anything else. Yes the loop of die, grind for cash, fail resurrection and grind for more cash again tedious at the start, the rest of the game is a highly enjoyable dungeon crawler. Easily worth picking up if you want to play something that looks and feels different to the standard JRPG.

For my Full Review of Labyrinth of Zangetsu check out my video here: https://youtu.be/VGNx6SMvAd8

Do I recommend OTXO? That's a nobrainer, because fugg yeah I do! Don't confuse OTXO with Hotline Miami, because I can see how you could. But this is an entirely different beast. OTXO dares you to be quick on your feet, down a glass of your favorite spirit and bust down the doors guns blazing. And like Drago once said: "if he dies, he dies". Just get up and try again, and again... and again. Just don't get too comfortable with the idea that you'll figure out how each run works. Randomly generated rooms will throw you for a loop.

Is that an issue? Fugg no. You'll have no issues with dying over and over as OTXO knows how to sink its teeth into you. Is it the stellar action? Could it be the banger OST? Call it a combination of both.

OTXO: don't even hesitate. Just buy the game. You won't regret it if you've been having good times with Hotline Miami in the past. Just don't expect OTXO to be Hotline Miami 3 and you'll be golden.

This game was honestly more fun than I anticipated it would be. The characters are mostly lovable, managing your schedule to be able to do the most with the most people is fun, and the overall gameplay loop kept me interested. There are a few things to note however. Firstly, if you're not a fan of having to redo things until you get a good ending, you might get stuck in the game at a few points. Save scum is the way to go. Make sure you save frequently. Also I would like to mention that it feels like a lot of the character sprites could use some touching up. The game has amazing CG art, but once you see a good CG and then go back to seeing the character sprites, they feel a little... unfinished. I mostly got this feeling with Elle, as my first thought upon seeing her was "dang her eyes are half of her head." If you could model the sprites in a similar proportion to the CG pictures, I think it would work very well for the game in the long run. It's not all the characters though. I thought characters like Cassie, Iro, Eli, Fumi, Dorian, and even Iro's dad looked fine. But most others are just a bit funny looking. A few that come to mind are Elle, Quill, Bonnibel, and even Mio to an extent. Other than that though, I personally didn't have any other problems with the game. I can't wait for the next/another one.

While I've only played the game for a couple of hours at the time of writing this review, there's a lot i have to say about it from just the first week alone. I will have this be a spoiler free review for those who care about the story. 

Firstly, this game requires a lot of saving, with only 60 save slots that will probably all be used immediately with all the overwhelming options at the start. Then with having 60 save slots, unless you're following a guide then you will save at least 10 times a day, there are 30 days in this game I believe, and then you find out you did something slightly wrong when it comes to setting up your character? You'll have to fully restart because at that point you've already saved over the file of that choice.

While the dates are nice and fun the save scumming kinda ruins them for players trying to end the date positively, with saving at a choice, picking every choice at that save to see the best one, and then picking the best one, it just gets repetitive and annoying. 

I've focused on enough of the negatives so let's discuss the positives.
The characters are some of the best I've seen in a western dating sim game although that could just be the 50+ hours I've spent playing Crush Crush talking.

I think the art is some of the best I've seen from Sad Panda Studios other than maybe the recent Phone Flings we've gotten on Crush Crush. 

All of the characters are fully voice acted, and personally I was fine with every performance in the game, with a few stand outs like any other game.

Overall I still liked the game even with the flaw of me saving 70 times in my first few hours of gameplay. I'd say if you just wanna have fun with it play it like you would any dating sim just with saving a little more regularly, and if you wanna get every achievement and such follow a guide.

Overall Review: 8.5/10

Please remember that this game is Early Access and all the flaws I've mentioned may be fixed by the time you are reading this so I'd say just give it a chance if you liked Crush Crush, wait a little bit if you've never played it.

[hr][/hr] 
[b]In a nutshell, here is my gaming experience[/b]
I always play it for a while and then drop it - its mechanics are made black box, either intentionally or unintentionally, and there are always situations where it can be frustrating. In some cases, you even have to ask the developers directly to get an answer. 
[hr][/hr] 
[b]More detailed review[/b]
The game was bumped up from the original 40 bucks to 60 bucks, and I was expecting it to be a full upgrade from the previous generation, and that's not the case - its current state can only be described as a little bit of a fix.
[b]About WEGO turn-based system in FCSS[/b]
The WEGO turn-based system is not really a "novelty", it's just a freak patch - in fact, the so-called RTS has a minimum time granularity, the traditional turn-based system has a time granularity, and even our reality The world also has a minimal unit of time like Planck time. What modern computers have done is to reduce the time granularity of "turns" to what we consider "real time", and strictly speaking even the miniature personal computers we use are not a real time system! 
Some people find this very realistic, but I always felt that OnTarget Sims screwed it up when I thought about it more deeply. The length of the command cycle sometimes starts at tens of minutes, and you're telling me that my scout will do nothing but report to his superiors over the radio when he sees an entire Soviet regiment running towards it? But even if I set the standoff rule for it, it could only relocate when the enemy was at a certain distance, not to mention the risk of exposure due to close range movement.
I really hope Ontarget Sims would reconsider the way the Wego mechanic is Implemented in their next title. But also not like Armored brigade - a unit should be evading artillery fire out of its instincts, not having me, the commander, tell it where to hide!

[b]So here comes our next point, the realism of the game. [/b]
[u]
‚ÄúIn real life, commanders maneuver forces 2-levels down. That means a Battalion commander focuses on maneuvering platoons while a brigade commander is focused on maneuvering companies. There's a reason why this idea exists.‚Äù 
[/u]
This is a comment from a U.S. Army officer about FCSS. The same comment applies to Combat Mission, where we players play not as any commander, but as all the units on the battlefield! I have to refute one of FCSS's slogans - The player is definitely not playing as a brigade/battalion commander.
[u]Artillery: There is a lack of functionality. [/u]
the lack of "suppression" effect of artillery attacks means that they do not behave in the right way to kill soft parameters, when your artillery does not directly kill enemy units, the soft parameters of enemy units will not be affected in any way. For example, when my mechanized infantry and tanks launched an attack on the enemy in a town area at the same ti me I dumped hundreds of rounds of 122mm howitzers into the town. I believed they had been overwhelmed by my artillery barrage, but in fact they had not. They completely ignored my artillery barrage and wiped out my attacking forces with precision!
[u]Nasty stubborn design, especially for WP side. [/u]
Artillery and CAS lack illumination ammunition - this is important to the Warsaw Pact. Warsaw Pact knows that their NVG level is not as good as NATO, and therefore they intend to use a lot of artillery to turn the night into day. But not in the game, so in the current version, any night battle scenario is "unfair" for WP players
Most of the scenarios in the game have too many concentrated WP units and the game refuses to provide the option to split units, which may be explained by the theory in FM100-2-1, but again, FM100-2-1 does not state that a WP company must only expand within 500m! It also mentions that a WP company will spread out to 1000m or more in the following situations, such as defense. It would be foolish to refuse to allow a Warsaw Pact unit to deploy in a more suitable method.
[u]Too careless in some details[/u]
I know the developers have done a lot of research in some very detailed areas, such as the effect of the inverse temperature phenomenon on TI devices. But I find it hard to believe that FCSS has made these things "reasonable". For example, standoff relocate is supposed to be designed to allow units to maneuver to avoid threats, but why would they maneuver in the direction of the enemy? When it comes to SOP as a "selling point", the situation is even worse. For example, the default SOP for units in some scenarios is to relocate as soon as losses occur, which is designed to preserve a unit as much as possible, but why would a Soviet infantry company start fleeing in panic because they lost an infantry squad and left trenches they had dug in advance? And the AI doesn't change SOPs, which means that in these scenarios their units start fleeing as soon as they are lost, and I can't imagine how this can explained. these  absurd aspects of FCSS make it hard for me to say that FCSS is a rigorous wargame.

[b]UI/UX design is still terrible. [/b]
Although the UI art is much improved(I have to say this was a big factor in motivating me to buy FCSS on day one), the actual experience is not as good as I thought it would be. The first is the annoying map zoom, which is very sluggish and the shortcut keys are very counter-intuitive. The mouse wheel up zooms in instead of out, which can be changed in the settings, but I still find it very ridiculous, you guys haven't used the touchpad on your laptop? The direction of the mouse wheel can be changed, but other shortcuts do not offer the option to change it. For example, the new SOP menu shortcut is ctrl+k and the Los tool is ctrl+L, which is very inconvenient because I need two hands to press it! 
Another thing, Esc doesn't always close pop-up windows quickly, some windows can be closed quickly with Esc but some can't, which also annoys me a lot. 

[b]Bad AI design[/b]
Bad news for single player. FCSS‚Äôs AI is subpar, because it's almost indistinguishable from the AI of any other games that was probably designed over a decade ago - all it does is march towards the objectives set by the script designer and the only tactic used is to send all troops, both combat and support, through different paths to get within range of my tanks. And it seems to have no concept of long range engagement and tactical retreat, when the target area is blocked by my position, it will not stop, never. It will ignore casualties. Does this look like competent AI design? I can't tell any different from those old wargames. Where is the elaborate and cunning AI they promised?


Too many FKing DIALOGS
Having dialogs in wargame is not a problem, but there are TONS of them that I can't see the FKing map and have to get them out of the FKing way. Maybe I shouldn't have called FCSS an Excel simulator, because there aren't that many dialog boxes in Excel either.
Move unit? Have a dialog.
How fast you want? Have a dialog.
What to do in the end of the path? Have a dialog.
Want to resupply? Have a dialog. 
Plan a CAS strike? Have a dialog.
Game paused? Have a dialog.



[hr][/hr] 
[h1]Conclusion [/h1]
After writing all this, I've pretty much written out all the negative feelings I've had while playing FCSS. I'm tired and upset, because six months ago I wasn't expecting such a mired-in development hell‚Ä¶man I don't want to buy the same game for the third time already‚Ä¶
Just stop.

A light and fun game that requires thinking and creativity. The game features an intricate crafting system that requires you to scavenge for different materials and combine them in unique ways to create tools, weapons, and even fortifications. This aspect of the game is incredibly satisfying as you feel like you are truly surviving in a world where an incredibly suspenseful and game that will keep you hooked from start to finish.

Every day a horde of people will invade your base and you must fight them to survive. These hordes are incredibly challenging and will test your skills as a player. The sound of the people approaching, the frantic gunshots and explosions, and the constant fear of death make these days a real experience.

I would like to see the full game, keep it up!

Buy this when it's on 50% sale. Been playing on single player campaign only. It's fun, and if you prefer to fortify your defenses first before taking actions, even at default difficulty, game becomes quite hard. 12 hours in I finally met my first boss. I had 4 layers of Stone Walls and 2 layers of basic towers. He came through them like hot knife through butter. The piglins that prefer to fortify their bases got to lvl 3 - the final stage - and I'm excited to how to destroy them. The game becomes very enjoyable once open world kicks in. 

But, I don't see this becoming something like the "Next" Minecraft. The gameplay style is very limited, and I can't see how you can improve this even with help of the modders. The game could become another level if building on top of existing structure was allowed, like Fortnite, but at this point, not much customization.  

I also played Multiplayer once, it was toxic. They disabled in-game chat and voice chat, but you can still feel it being toxic. No communication between teammates. Game started even before I hit ready (in fact, there's no way to be "Ready." Once you join you are up to host's decision to launch the game or not). The game I joined was already in progress and enemies were bombarding us from mountain. And I believe many other issues have been addressed by other players as well (such as friends in specific team or teammates destroying your building or teammates stealing your army, etc). If devs were trying to follow other games that don't have in-game chat allowed, please do more research that some of those games had system similar to sign language. (*cough* *cough* Meadow)

Certain vtubers said this game feels like "Diablo for Kids." Feels exactly same. If you are trying to decide whether to buy this game to play with your friends, or host your own server (again) to play different mod for Minecraft, go with later option. Even if they fix multiple things in next few patches, with 8 player max in multiplayer (4 of them being your enemies), you are not going far with this game. 

TL;DR: they tried to simplify things. They have overdone it.
