Bought this game for $17.49 cdn just recently, so I'm playing the latest patch (Dec 2022).  Never played the physical game before, but I like dice games so I gave this a go.  Good game.  Played for 17 hours according to the tracker and I think I'm done.  I'll see how the game's DLC are in 2023 if I get back into it.  Here's my view playing solo.

- Overall a good simple game.  Dont think it's worth that given I've had more fun in other games for half the price, but it is early access.  So cant expect 50% off sales anytime soon

- Well polished.  Didn't have one crash, everyone moves swiftly.  Everything works

- Graphics are simple flash/mobile quality.  Clean, but dont expect miracles

- Sound is repetitive and the Music slider works oddly.  Unless you make it 10%, it always seems loud and barely goes down in volume.  Go from 90% to 40% and the sound barely changes

- UI works smooth, but the button placement is bad.  You got green button prompts which are relatively small and put in different corners of the screen at different times.  A waste of space and unneeded mouse moving.  There's also 1-2 too many mouse clicks needed to get through a round.  The profile button on the home page (a white silhouette) is way out there too.  You wont even notice it at first, but that's where your stats and leaderboards are

- The game has a slew of race and classes which have different bonuses, minuses and stat thresholds to meet.  It is flawed as some are way better than others.  Monk and Druid and Warrior seem the best IMO by a lot.  Unless I'm doing something wrong, some race/class combos cant even reach the threshold.  So if a Monk needs minimum 18 strength (6, 6, 6) for that row to score pts, and a faerie girl starts with Strength -2, her max is really 16.  So you can't reach it unless I'm messing up

- It's based on a card game.  The game itself is fine.  Nothing spectacular.  It's basically rolling dice trying to score pts on fulfilling objectives and picking and paying for cards to help your goal.  The RPG character creation setting fits perfectly

- It's a nice swift moving game.  If you're having a crap game or want to start over, there's an Abort Game option.  Starting a fresh game is fast.  You can pick your race (or randomized choice), but the class and attribute and alignment cards are random

- Not a hard game to understand.  Hitting 38 pts or more (best rated achievement) is pretty tough to do but I did it before my 10th game.  You'll probably get a lot of 28-35 scores.  I hit 40 pts once and I maxed out everything with a good assortment of item bonuses to boot.  I don't know what the max score is, but it's probably no more than 50?  At this point, once you hit 38 pts top tier, your goal is trying to beat it and get as high as possible

- The stats leaderboard in the profile button is good.  It shows your top scores, avg scores, race/class usage etc...  A handful of good charts for numbers geeks

Zoeti is a Roguelite/Deckbuilding game.

You know this games of deckbuilding with lack of a good smooth gameplay like slay the spire has? Well, this one has better smooth gameplay than slay the spire and I love it.

First of all you don't need know the rules of poker for understand this game.

They apply the rules of poker as 8 diferent ways for attacks, for example one pair (1 card) = A and B type of atacks or defend which each  one you can level up for do more dmg/shield; two pair (2 cards) = C and B type of atacks.

Very easy to understand, the tutorial helps a lot.

The game also focus on a good narrative story but you can skip the dialogues if you only want this game for the gameplay.

There is also a roguelite part where there are unlocks and lvl up of your character, but nothing that you didn't see in another games of the same genre.

Lets play Walkthrough - https://youtu.be/2zLZMQfEfI0


The Story Plot is very solid and it will keep you going 
It's like a beautiful Visual Novel
3 Unique characters, at first the other 2 are locked so you can unlock them by finishing game 
Each time during a mission, you get to choose several paths each one with unique encounters and rewards 
If You Die its game over , no save game option 
Lots of unique weapon skills 
There is also a meditative mode where you can upgrade your skills and cards 

Rating - 8/10
( Great Game ) 
GO FOR IT !!

Buy it, love it, play it forever. A beautiful game that rides on a well-polished track of game mechanics that I could play for just one more run... forever.

The core gameplay of Zoeti is drawing from a deck of cards and using card combinations to activate abilities and fight your enemies. As you progress each run, you'll learn new skills and upgrade previous ones, collect artifacts that boost your abilities when certain conditions are met, acquire character skills that drastically affect your gameplay choices, and gain consumable items to compliment your ever-expanding kit. Mechanically the game is incredibly solid, and the fundamentals build with each new chapter and each difficulty, increasing your options but also increasing the complexity of how you can play most effectively.

Pass or fail, each run rewards you with experience points that unlock new abilities, relics, and items to find in your next playthroughs, as well as two unlockable characters with different card pools. Passing a chapter means you can try again on the next highest difficulty, leading from Normal to Hard, Horrific, Nightmare, and finally Inferno.

While I found the story and world-building to be inconsequential, the art style and production make the game undeniably attractive. All of the characters are beautifully drawn and are presented with distinct characteristics, even if their situations can be a little bland. The character design (humans and animalkin) as well as the basic monsters provide a more than substantial backdrop to the game, but never once did it impede or overshadow the smooth beauty of the card mechanics and ability combinations.

I would buy this game for a friend if they seemed even the slightest, little bit interested, knowing full well they'd get pleasantly sucked in just like I did.

Rabelle please call me.

Hey everyone this is just the Pros and Cons for this game that played on my Steam deck using a PS5 controller game given to me by Publisher @akuparagames

Developer @DusklightGames

Release UK 20/4/2023

Price UK ¬£16.75

Played entirely on Steam Deck using a PS5 controller.

Full review on my blog and all my pictures and fan art on www.garylodgegamesreview.game.blog

Check my YouTube for videos https://www.youtube.com/c/GRIMREAPERSAGE

PROS

* Characters you meet all have their own look and all have their own personality.
* Playable characters all have their own look and all have their own feel and all unique moves with their own playstyle.
* Items you can use are cool as loads and help a lot on your journey.
* Accessories are super important as help during runs and can provide temporary buffs for so many fights such as more damage or health regen at end of every fight.
* Skills are impressive as tons of them all are unique to the characters and can be upgraded as well. 
* Choices are important as multiple paths containing  fights, random encounters that can be good or bad and even rest points and shops.
* World is interesting and new each run.
* Monsters are cool as they have a lot of variety to them and all have their own look and all have their own attacks to learn in order to defeat them.

CONS

* Super difficult and easy to fail runs can be frustrating.
* Sometimes RNG gives you naff hands and makes it feel like you're just gonna fail that fight.

OVERALL SUMMARY

Overall for ¬£16.75, has cool characters, heroes, accessories, items, and a pretty art style. However it can be frustrating as super difficulty makes it easy to fail runs and sometimes RNG gives you naff hand causing you to take damage or fail the run.

This is an accurate and faithful implementation of the solo and local multiplayer (no AI) dice game by the same dame.  It plays well and is frankly very enjoyable.  It removes the fiddly bits of the real world version (I will admit there is a degree of joy of chucking dice in a dice tower and hearing them tumble), but this also means that the game can be played many times in the same space of time.

This is a must get for people who enjoy the real world game or enjoy solo board gaming.

Nice little horror walking simulator well worth the money. The atmoshpere is very intense, really putting you on the edge of your seat with some well-timed jump scares.. My only complaint is the lighting, which is a bit too bright. You can see it for yourself in the screenshots. The only way to turn it down is by lowering the general brightness, making the scene almost pitch black so you can't see anything. But hey, that makes it even scarier which may or may not be what you want.

I enjoyed this game, I just finished my first run at about 8 hours in which isn't too bad.

The gameplay is enjoyable, with a solid gameplay loop. It could use some more interesting upgrades because a lot of them are just different iterations of the same one. But overall it's still fun.

One thing I would change though, especially with the amount of backtracking that is required during a run, is that traps should deactivate after a room is completed. Also some of the puzzles as you progress in the run start to get more unintuitive, which is pretty annoying because it can feel like a waste of time.

Honestly only bought the collector's edition for the bonus items like the statue and books, I had NO expectations for the game to be good but I just keep going back to it so something was done right I guess. Overall the game is pretty alright.

Sadly there are far too many issues to make this the fun/entertaining game it could be.  There is the mentioned problem with planets only being visited once. Making it hard(especially if you lose a whole team to a 10% chance of injury and they all die?). Theres the issue with guards walking off when needed. The invasions being a problem as it takes 2 guards to take down one invader. Meaning you lose generators and the guards either die before getting to a bed or spend a month or more being constantly treated.

The planets you visit seem to rarely have any specimens on them. Meaning you cannot write any new patents for income.
Doctors walk off somewhere else rather than heal people. Also I have 3 people on hospital beds that have been treat 40+ time and over three months ingame. And they still have mental damage/insanity. Thats my best engineers unable to mine.

Sadly getting uninstalled and maybe I will come back later and see if it has improved. Then I will change the review.
The multiplayer system absolutely sucks. You cant even get into a lobby to play with other people. The game feels rushed and dull. I love RTS games, and minecraft, but this game is okay at best.

When this game was announced, I brushed it off... but upon watching some of the pre-launch promotion, I decided to give it a try. I was pleasantly surprised.

This game blends elements from RTS's like Age of Empires and MOBAs like League of Legends and DOTA. While it leans a little heavier into the RTS side, it's a really interesting spin on the genre. While like any RTS, it's a bit overwhelming to learn all the units, upgrades and buildings at first, it is much more approachable than most games of its genre. 

I've most enjoyed the versus mode (PvP). Forming private lobbies with friends works great and the game is remarkably balanced. It feels like everything has a counterplay despite the relatively small unit variety. Public PvP DOES have a critical bug preventing you from forming premade teams with your friends, but they've acknowledged that they're working on fixing that ASAP. 

As for the price tag... I'll admit, it's a LITTLE high. If they'd knocked $10-$20 off of it I would be more accepting, but $40 ($50 Canadian) is a lot for what the game currently has to offer... that said, I AM enjoying it a lot and will continue to play the versus mode. 

TL;DR: Great game with friends. Not for you if you if you're looking for a chill game and just want it for the campaign, but great for RTS and MOBA vets who enjoy team play and theory-crafting strategies.

Fountain of Youth is a great survival game. the game has a distinct take on survival being in the 1600s (1500s?) and not having access modern tech what so ever. the game is similar to Stranded Deep in a lot of ways but there is more to do in the game and its less janky.

The devs also seem like they are going to continue working on the game and adding to it. And nowadays i think we need to support devs like that as much as possible

[b]+ Survive the Harsh Realities of the 16th Century Caribbean in Survival: Fountain of Youth - A Thrilling Open-World Adventure!„ÉΩ(¬¥‚Ä¢ œâ ‚Ä¢`)„ÄÅ[/b]

[h1][b][1] Intro [/b][/h1]
Survival: Fountain of Youth is an early access open-world survival game that takes you on a thrilling adventure to the Caribbean islands in the 16th century. You are a shipwrecked explorer on a quest to find the legendary Fountain of Youth, a historical event that adds a realistic element to the game.

[h1][b][2] Game Experience[/b][/h1]

The game's core gameplay revolves around crafting tools, building shelters, hunting for food, and fighting off predators to survive on deserted lands. With over 30 different animal species, each with its own habitat and behavior, you must be careful not to become the prey. The game's environment is full of hazards, including dangerous weather conditions, poisonous plants, malaria-infested swamps, and hunger and thirst. You will need to improve your skills, explore the islands in search of resources, and build sea vessels to travel between islands.

Survival: Fountain of Youth has a vast crafting system that allows you to create hundreds of items, from simple tools made of sticks and rocks to advanced muskets, metal armor, and tools. Each action you perform improves your skills, making you a hardcore survivor. The game features 15+ unique islands, each with its own landscape, climate, weather, flora, fauna, and resources. You must adapt to each island's conditions, solve the mysteries they keep, and seek unique treasures.

The game's story is intriguing, as you uncover the remnants of an ancient civilization that perished for an unknown reason. Search ruins and temples, decipher centuries-old puzzles, and unveil the mystery behind the legendary Fountain of Youth. Survival: Fountain of Youth is an early access game that still has room for improvement. The developers plan to add three additional regions with new biomes, animals, resources, puzzles, and points of interest. They also intend to expand the crafting system with more blueprints and machines and allow players to finish the story of finding the Fountain of Youth.

[h1][b][3] Verdict [/b][/h1]
In conclusion, Survival: Fountain of Youth is a thrilling open-world survival game that immerses you in the 16th century Caribbean islands. It has a vast crafting system, challenging gameplay, and an intriguing storyline that will keep you engaged for hours. If you are a fan of survival games, then you should definitely give this game a try.

This game is a retro-modern gem, one that values player responsibility and creative thinking while immersing you in a solid world:

+The music and sound are tuned to perfection

+The pixelart is beautiful and surprisingly impressive

+The physics are clear and consistent 

+The platforming and general movement feels adequately heavy (and dangerous when going fast!)

+The humor is fun and goofy

TIP: If some levels seem a bit hard at first, try treating it not like any other game that you'd mindlessly scroll through but as a realistic pixelart simulation.

Tip 2: Crew members can seem dumb at times but that's to be expected from someone in distress, have patience and treat them like realistic humans (which are a bit slow too sometimes)

Labyrinth of Zangetsu is a celebration of traditionalism. It‚Äôs art, it‚Äôs story, and its gameplay all harken back to a mythologized Japan of old; both with its ink-infused hand brush style and its ‚Äòdudes in a line‚Äô first person dungeon crawling RPG gameplay. And that‚Äôs also why it‚Äôs not exactly a surprising game. 

It‚Äôs rigid adherence to its yesteryear throwback style ensures that what you see is what you get; and it‚Äôs the same intense difficulty that had me pulling my hair out when I overplayed my hand and got wiped in the labyrinth is also the source of the profound relief I experienced when I leveled up and got a new tier of cleric spells.

It‚Äôs not going to convert anyone that doesn‚Äôt already have a fondness for the genre, but its clean and simple execution of its classic tenants are reminder of why they're classic in the first place.

Candidly this is probably a little closer to a first impression than it is a review; I‚Äôm about 7 hours and 4 dungeons deep, which the UI suggests is maybe about halfway through the game. If you‚Äôre looking for an end game analysis that‚Äôs something I can‚Äôt give, yet I enjoyed what I played and wanted to spotlight the game regardless.

Because Labyrinth of Zangetsu is as dungeon RPG-y as it gets, and it manages to do so much with so little. Simple alternations between stocking up in town and going back out for another expedition serve as your traditional flow; but what wasn‚Äôt there was any sort of risk reward mechanic to disincentivize flipping back and forth between them at whim.

When you get stuck in Labyrinth of Zangetsu, one of the best plays you can make is just to stay near the dungeons entrance, farm some early mobs then go back to town and heal up for free. That‚Äôs the kind of old school we‚Äôre working with and it‚Äôs also something that will morph from a cheesy tactic to an integral strategy because of the challenging enemy mobs and the high stakes that come with dying to them.

A team death in the labyrinth is effectively permanent with the caveat that corpses and items can be retrieved by a future party; but good luck getting there again without everything you‚Äôve lost‚Ä¶ You‚Äôll have to resort to going back to base and recruiting a whole new party, one you‚Äôll create with stat rolls, race and class selection, and even picking from a small list of portraits that hopefully looks like whatever fighter you‚Äôve envisioned for yourself.

Even if this plucky young group of novice warriors are able to grab the corpses: the resurrect mechanic is as last century as it gets. You pay a ton of gold and roll some invisible dice so that half the time the game just laughs in your face, takes your money, and leaves the corpse lifeless anyway.

It‚Äôs why Zangetsu is a game of incremental advantages and slow, grindy gains‚Ä¶ but there are some obvious modernizations that poke through some of its old school trappings.

Smart UI elements like icons that display when you have equippable gear being unused and an ‚Äòauto-redo-last-turn-button‚Äô help reduce some of the input quantity you might expect traditionally. Which is also why its so weird that some other parts of the game don‚Äôt have improvements like that: the chests that enemies drop on death need to be inspected, disarmed, and opened with multiple different inputs governing each. That goes double for the later chests that have multiple traps on them; a test to ensure you‚Äôve got your parties stat distribution correct for sure, but maybe a little too frequent for how time consuming they are to open.

You may also be surprised how non-labarynthine Labyrinth of Zangetsu is; because despite the name, exploration is a component but not the primary focus. Both a mini-and macro map that auto-fill out details as you move around make most of the pathfinding trivial compared to some of its genre contemporaries.

Instead, the lion's share of your time will be spent engaging with and taking down the various enemies. A front and backline party formation will have you hiding your mages behind as beefy a wall you can make and letting them blast away, and limited spell usage per run will have you fleeing back to town when you‚Äôre exhausted.

Labyrinth of Zangetsu knows this and embraces it. The small list of conventionally ‚Äòmodern‚Äô features the game boasts are largely UI concessions to help it be more playable with a controller, and it manages to introduce them without declawing the game entirely.

For better or worse this old-school romp is unconcerned with broad appeal; and that uncompromising attitude was as much a source of frustration as it was fun. But its no-nonsense approach to the dungeon RPG formula was simple if not easy, and make it a great pick up-n-play steam deck or switch experience rather than the longer term commitment that some of its peers are.

It wears its heart on its parchment; so much so that any one idle screenshot almost entirely conveys everything that this game is about. But just like its traditional-ink focused art style, Zangetsu finds beauty in what‚Äôs old‚Ä¶ just don‚Äôt forget that sometimes that means clicking a dozen prompts to open one chest.

Thumbs up if you are ok playing EA games.

Pretty solid so far for single player. The MP has issues, but there's plenty of warning to that effect.

If you're interested in survival management games this is a solid entry so far. There's a less automation than in games like Factorio - you're still going to be doing plenty on your own.  The world is charming, it has decent sound/music design, and the gameplay loops have been fun in my first few hours. There's also a fairly long tech tree to work through and plenty of implied complexity.

My current wishlist (beyond MP fixes) would be more charts. I want to be able to better see if I'm producing enough food, etc, for my inhabitants.

A great little title for fans of aircraft. The models are clear and detailed, the setting is clean and easy to navigate. The amount of time you spend here is dictated entirely by how long you want to spend peering at all the details on each aircraft. There's no interactivity or gimmicks with this museum, you just teleport to the spot you want to go to and then you have a good look around from your chosen spot. I couldn't find any in game options during my first ten minutes of use (I would have preferred to mute the music or at least turn the volume down) but for a free piece of software you can't really complain. If you're a fan of aircraft, got some time to kill and want to see the scale of five early famous machines, you can't go wrong with this free VR museum.

Stray Blade is an adventure game with souls-like elements. But that description doesnt describe the way the game is. I will go into a few of the main aspects of the game and give the good and the ugly about it.

 Combat:
-The game has a parry, a dodge and with certain weapons a block. Perfect parries stagger an enemy for a second, deal poise damage and give back stamina. Parrying at just the wrong time blocks the damage, but doesnt stagger the enemy and leaves you open to a second attack. Just like parrying, perfect dodging recovers you some stamina but doesnt stagger enemies. And blocking is well... blocking. 
-The combat can feel clunky at times due to its unforgiving damage and stagger when you dont perfect dodge or parry and the stamina economy also requires you to do perfect parries and dodges. Some weapons have slow attack combos and dont have enough hyper armor, nor can you increase your poise like in a Fromsoft game. It takes some getting used to but eventually the flow of combat will become more of a dance then a battle. If you can find the patience for it that is.
-The abilities you unlock troughout the game (Intium, Manninite and Xhinnon) have their own uses in combat, Intium is fun, Manninite seems fun but doesnt do enough to make it worth it and Xhinnon turns on easy-mode.

Story:
-The story is pretty good if you read all the extra lorestones you can find around the game and talk to Boji whenever you can. Without the lorestones and Boji the story does become confusing, and the ending becomes very confusing and a bit weird.
-The valley of Acrea is very rich in its culture and history, and you can find out quite a bit about how the society was before their fall. Many areas have interesting tid bits of lore regarding them. The valley also looks very pretty.

Exploration:
-The exploration is this game is quite fun and reminds me of metroidvanias. You go trough an area, see some stuff you dont have the ability to get and come back later to find some nice customizations or other secrets. 
-The world as noted before looks great and each new area is great to look at and run around in. 

Performance:
-I ran the game on high settings on a 3070, Intel I-7 10700k with 16GB ram. I only noticed minor performance issues in certain areas. (Have to go back and check the areas again to give acurate and recent statistics on this since my info on this is outdated)

Final Thoughts:
Stray Blade is a good game that I am going to be replaying a handful of times with some fun challenges for myself. There are aspects that could be better or design choices that couldve been made differently but looking at the game as a whole its 100% been a blast and I cant wait to see what the future brings to this game.

Exciting, Different, Fun.  Worth spending your time on.  I played the Beta and I have felt a lot of games have been formulaic or repetitive, but this doesnt fit that negativity.  Its a fresh breath into adventures, but it will test you at times to your skills
Pretty good so far. Much more of a relaxed / chill to play these type of games. Combat is tricky to get used to, but is highly rewarding when you get used to it.

keybinds suck on both controller and keyboard. bindings menu wont let more than one action share a key and it has too many actions to bind. theres more keys to bind than there are buttons on a controller. how? 

make your keybinds simpler or make them bindable to more than one thing.

A big collection of marketplace assets with extremely DUMB AI and a game that adds nothing new to the table.  While this game is better than I expected, it's just not worth the price at this point in my opinion.

For me, the determining factor will be if this dev or devs actually continue updating this game and making the AI better and also doing things like improving the absolutely terrible AI that we see here at launch today.  ..Most indie devs of games just like this over the years quickly give up and abandon their survival games as we've seen at least a thousand times before.  I have and see NO reason to believe that the dev(s) of this heavily asset reliant survival game will do any better.  ..Time will tell, but this is a "NOT RECOMMEND" for me until I see proof that this game is going to actually be supported by the dev(s) are are quick to try making $$ on it with the early access launch today.

NOT RECOMMENDED... because the AI is terrible and the game is NOT optimized at all and this game really adds nothing new to the already over-saturated survival game genre here on Steam.  If these devs (or dev) shows this game is cared for and quality updates keep coming in over the coming months, then my opinion just might change.. but that is a BIG "if"..  We shall see.

(Reviewed on Index with RTX 3080)

As a person who quite recently finished the original game, I was looking forward for this port. That being said, I was ALSO VERY, [b] VERY [/b]  afraid. Usually VR ports are.... mediocre at best. However, I was very pleasantly surprised.

I am absolutely digging the control scheme, it's awesome! It feels great, you are really inside the game, it isn't annoying or a chore to play, the flow feels very natural and I can see that they must've put a lot of effort in tweaking it all. The art direction feels "different" (in a good way) when you're actually inside the game, you have to compare it yourself. You can feel the damage of the weapons, the recoil, the swings, the enemies look great and overall the game feels really nice. Had some issues at first with the game being laggy and dropping frames, but I just clicked the video settings a bunch and it's completely ok now (Epic settings 120Hz). Usually, I am very critical of VR games (mainly because I am already spoiled by the good ones out there) but god damn, for 20‚Ç¨ this game is a steal.

Of course, there are minor issues, like me clipping through a wall, teary animations on enemies, not being able to throw the axe on Index (or it's veeeeeeeeeeery finicky) or unpickable mana from time to time... yea they are the annoying thorn in the eye, but man! This game absolutely rocks! If you have played the first one, definitely get this. If you haven't, buy both! they feel VERY different and they are both a unique experience.

Worth every cent, penny, pound, whatever your currency is, it. is. worth. it.

Perfect. Exactly what I have expected it to be. 

Thank you for giving me a chance to experience magnificent universe of AE in VR.

... that's true when an unusual quest! Although this is an indie game, it looks very interesting and impressive. I liked the soundtrack. The plot is really strange and atmospheric. I haven't looked all over here yet, but I've already found a lot of easter eggs. At the end of the chapter there is a form for voting and writing ideas. As I understand it, the developers will take the best ideas and implement them in chapter 2. But there is also a DAO, so I hope my idea gets into the game.
I liked the riddles - they are kind of abstract. They hint at something, have a deep meaning, but the developers will apparently keep the intrigue until the next episodes. Laughed since the bug in the jar. In general, an unusual game, even just to walk around this apartment. There's something about it. I will buy a copy for my parents. they even lived in a similar apartment once upon a time. 8/10 - keeps intrigue and is very unusual. I wish the first chapter was longer, but in general I was carried away and I was lost in time)

Stargate strategy basebuilding game, like it alot.

After 14.9 hrs of playing the game without any glaring bugs... the game gave my PC the blue screen of death. Yikes! 

This is a Early Access Game and there are balancing issues along with bugs. It is not in a horrible condition, but it is a little rough at the moment. I will check back when the game is officially launched.

Fun game but still requires a lot of polishing and balancing.  

I really had hoped that it would feel more like Stargate but instead I feel like the guy stuck behind watching the gate room.  This is still early access so I have hopes that more interaction with the gate teams will be added to give it more of that Stargate feel.

The game runs fairly smooth except for a static sounding glitch that happens.  Has not caused my game to crash yet but is very annoying when it happens.  Easily fixed by restarting the game.  While I love not having to micro manage all the residents of the base, they tend to be pretty mindless with medics choosing to go workout & such instead of healing the room full of injured people in the med bay.  The biggest issue I ran into was a balance issue where my income from patents seemed to slowly expire faster than I could get the material to create new ones leaving me slowly going broke.

Overall I love the Stargate feel, being able to build a base and create teams to send out on missions.  I think the price is fantastic for this game but at present, would not purchase it because of the income balance issues and the AI needing work.  With a little more work put into the game, I can easily see it becoming one that I play frequently and eagerly await that patch.

Cute game, could definitely have a good size player base if the current issues are fixed and if the dev realizes that they should add workshop. Currently you will sometimes have trouble entering people's maps and also it seems like you cannot save a map you create at the moment because it seems to all depend on their servers with no local saves whatsoever.

It's kinda like minecraft, terraria and bunch of other stuff in one. You can actually import assets and your own skins and there seems to be some sort of power system with pressure plates, wires and lights etc. Glass panes are actually seamless and there are a lot of small quality of life features that are nice.

I wish people wouldn't just crap on their keyboard and call it a review after 0.2 hours of gameplay when it is just day 1. It would be better if they went to the community tab to actually leave some good feedback so new games can stop dying and improve.

This game WILL be the next big speedrunning game, mark my words. I've just completed it and I had a blast! My speedrun world record any% will be uploaded later. The art was awesome, the hiding mechanics were interesting. I thought the character design of the enemies was great, and I had a great time playing. I did find a couple bugs during my play through (though as a speed runner i am not complaining. the WR will be mine!), that I've listed below for you. 

1. the book ramp towards the beginning makes you slide down, or halts movement if you get in between them. 
2. If you are moving on multiple planes of movement, Ie. holding W and A or D at the same time, while pointing your camera at a 45 degree from where you want to move, you can move significantly faster. This makes many impossible jumps  possible, and I dont think it was intended. I also quite enjoy seeing the silly rat go very very quick. 
3. After you beat the game, you can still press continue from the main menu. This spawns you in near the final cauldron with all of the ingredients respawned. It doesn't seem like the cauldron final scene has a check for if you have collected the ingredients already in this state. This allows you to instantly run to the end and watch the final cut scene again. Which is awesome, cause its a great cut scene (not so good for my speedrunnin times tho!!) 

overall, 6/7. What a silly little rat.

One hour in and it is great! Got to the third level and wanted to share a bit.

A few quick and easy recommendations for the DEVS:
Have the shadows set lower on first boot.  They are way too demanding to be defaulted to Epic.
Option to rotate health bars 90 degrees.  I feel it is more natural to do a "check the time" motion rather than a "I come in peace"
I find that activating the soul power always triggers when I don't want it to.  For example, when shooting enemies up on a ledge, I have my hand raised to aim and it activates.  Perhaps add an option to raise both hands to activate.
The shadows on the torches with a floor stand on the first stage have a broken shadow issue.  No adjustment of the settings helped.
I also noticed I was dropping weapon with the Index.  Needs some adjustment.
The angular velocity is fine but the distance required to activate the green sword needs to be increased way more.  I was constantly setting it off just moving around.

Then an issue I had while adjusting the Effects in settings.  The menu pointer disappeared and then maybe also aim as detached from hand and got set to my HMD look.  I don't know if the second issue was caused at the same time.

Otherwise, they did a FANTASTIC job porting this.  I am going to enjoy this very much.
I will easily support all the New Blood titles getting the same VR treatment.

For the last few days I have been working really hard on a review for this game because frankly, it's great and it deserves a very detailed thought-out review. Thanks to some audio issues though I will have to start from scratch (issue from my headset, not the game) so I figured the least I could do until then is post a quick review here.

The first time I hopped into Amid Evil Vr I wasn't sure what to think but I quickly realized this was one of my new favorite games. The thing about VR is games is they are always trying to imitate real life but when that real life isn't imitated, the immersion is broken. Amid Evil Vr on the other-hand, is not imitating real life but instead what it would be like to live inside of a retro video game as a warrior and at that, it does an incredible job. I felt as if I were Wreck-It Ralph, but infinitely more badass.

I rarely just flat-out recommend a game, I will always say something like "if you like this genre or style of game-play then this game might be for you" but Amid Evil Vr I stand behind 100%.

EDIT: Shadow quality does indeed seem to tank performance. Turned it to low and game now runs smooth as butter.

It's New Blood's best game in VR and it's pretty darn fun!

Just hope those enemy animations get tweaked to work in higher framerates.

Finally a real nativ retro FPS in VR. Amid Evil already was an amazing game and I ask waaaay back for VR as it would be a great fit. But they said "This wouldn't work, weapons are sprites." I said I don't care this needs to be in VR. And look where we are now. :)

If you want the "real deal" of a retro shooter in VR, a native one that is (we got plenty old goodness via VR mods like Doom, Quake, etc.), you need to buy Amid Evil VR.

Please New Blood give us DUSK next! :)

This is a really interesting space-based roguelike where you control a single craft out to find a MacGuffin that can stop a star collapsing. You get 1000 turns to do this.

Most of the traditional roguelike trappings are here -turn-based gameplay, high difficulty, permadeath, procedural generation etc., but what really sets this game apart is the combat.

All the combat entities are effected by what is basically Newtonian physics. This means that you can't turn on a dime because spaceships have inertia they need to overcome before they can turn. Depending on how fast you are going it may take several turns to stop and turn around. This means that you have to carefully plan out your encounters, not just out-gunning and out-thinking your opponents, but out maneuvering them as well. Your ship has multiple mount points, facing forwards, and facing port and starboard. All this coalesces into an experience that is more than the sum of it's parts. In an carefully upgraded craft you can feasibly fight several opponents at once if you are smart about it, and pulling it off is extremely satisfying (and hard as nails).

Depending on how you have upgraded your ship in a given run the game can play out in vastly different ways. You really have to get a feel of what your current ship is capable of if you are going to win fights. Are you a heavy cruiser with tons of shields and armour that moves one tile at a time lighting the fuck up out of everyone in your wake, or are you a nimble fighter craft - darting in and out of the fray before the enemy has a chance to respond? 

It's all valid, all comes with tradeoffs, and is also out there for you to fight.

The game takes place on a 5x5 galaxy map, where each sector on the grid is a procedurally generated star system, with planets, anomalies, enemies, stations you can trade with and repair at, and even black holes. You can jump between these systems at will (assumming your hyperdrive is charged) gathering intel, earning credits, and getting into fights.

The game is a little content light at present. I haven't had a successful run yet, but I feel like I'm close. But it's fun - the combat is really unique, has excellent emergent elements to it, and is far deeper than it first seems. It's one of those systems where small additions can open up incredibly wide new possibility spaces, so I hope the devs add more stuff.

I find this a unique and enjoyable game, and I don't play many fighting games. However, I have three problems with the game: 
1) There's no epilepsy warning of any kind on startup.
2) There's no accessibility options, or any way to turn off the flashy effects, as low effects still make me nauseous. 
3) I can't seem to do a local match, one person on keyboard and the other on controller? I tried this last night and it registered the controller and keyboard as player one.
So I can only play this game in very very short spurts because of my photosensitive epilepsy. However, I do respect the game and what it's trying to do, and I hope they make a patch so I can properly play this soon.

WARNING: do not buy this game you cannot refund even if you play under 2 hours because they set it up in a way they bypass Steams refund policies.

This game is kind of a dud.

There is a fuckton of pop up menus and microtransaction currencies that they hit you over the head with every time you are not in a race.

The battle pass items and stats boosts are obnoxious, it takes away from the gameplay. Often times I would just be wondering if my opponents just had better raw stats cause they bought the battle pass or some MTX that gave them an advantage. I am not saying they did but I am saying that the fact that it exists means I cannot eliminate from possibility or my mind and that partly ruins the enjoyment of the gameplay for me. 

All of the music has these weird nobody asked for remixes. Some are alright but the majority stand out in a bad way.

The gameplay is the best thing this game has to offer but I don't feel like its good enough to look past most of the junk. Kinda felt souless but a higher quality souless as if a lot of money was spend on testing and making this game based on trends and market research but not heart, passion or originality.

If you absolutely love Disney and Kart Racers you will probably look past most of this games faults. If you just love Kart Racers then you may be better off waiting until this game is free-to-play.

The game offers pretty solid experience, it is clearly driven by Evil Genius mechanic with added Stargate concepts. In current state there are quite some issues which will likely prevent you from reaching late game content (which I've personally reached only after finding and abusing bug that yielded millions of credits (pretty much infinite) and were able to exclude botched mechanic of patents from my game experience.
What went well:
Game concept and idea
Overall game experience
Stories behind the gates are pretty fun and diverse
Base building mechanics are pretty solid as is
Tutorials are mostly sufficient

Things  that was bad:
> Financial system is a total mess (patent mechanic needs full review - as from game design perspective it is using finite resource to give temporary gains, and these gains are highly random which results in inevitable collapse
> Increasingly complex waves of intruders require constant staffing with soldiers, medics don't have enough time to heal them between waves some times
> Doors doesn't block the intruders eliminating the possibility of creating kill-boxes in Evil Genius style
> Final monthly report hits twice sometimes (patent expire quicker, if you are negative on profits you go downward quicker, popular topics/positions to hire made useless in this case)
Patent mechanic as a main and almost single source of profit
> Selling material (and you can sell only one of them) is not a viable long term solution as of its randomness and it doesn't even cover up the salaries for the team of engineers - solution: allow selling all materials or increase costs greatly, or remove salaries at all - pivoting the concept of profit making into since expedition is a point for brainstorming
> According to time pace, it takes around 6-12 hours for a person to traverse the base, 4 hours to eat etc. The time pace and movement needs to be reviewed prior to release
> Pause doesn't pause, yes you've read it right - some people randomly continue walking and doing their job during game pause
>  Mechanic of influence is useless, it just doesn't add anything to the game, capturing sentient sectors only yield interesting series of missions, ultimately - nothing else
> RPG mechanic of the people you hire make very painful the case of their death or flee due to missed salary
as opposed to Evil Genius where each person is dispensable, making them less eager to flee due to salary is a possible solution
> Salaries (which are useless from my standpoint) are capped on the moment of hire, and there is no reason of looking for more expensive people as they are progressing their stats pretty quickly
> There should be some additional way to level soldiers on base and scholars as they progress way slower then Scientists (through patents and missions), Engineers (through repetitive missions)

Recommendations for developers:
> Introduce sustainable way to utilize scientists for new hypothesis (starting from lvl1 as later in game low level scientists are nearly useless)
> Remove expiry dates from patents, initiative should be developing over time, you can add diminishing effects on individual categories, this way you will be able to softly limit the income and for example update its condition after reaching certain story milestones, for example: first aliens met, foundry built (and engineers available) - new way of gaining profit introduced, invasions started(quick growth required to survive) - this will fix most issues with financial system
> Reduce salaries or increase profits from patents (leaving common as is, but gradually buffing usage of uncommon+ hypothesis will solve another financial problem - there is not much financial difference between using Legendary or Common (2-4x) while obtaining them is much much harder(15-20x) including all the random factors reducing the difference between complexity and profit will solve the issue. Consider leaving legendary hypothesis for some scenario based decisions (correct team set up or proper rolls success during missions)
> Reduce the time that squad is entering the gate, this is main bottleneck in a late game experience and frequently resulting in a deadlocking order queue and people infinitely waiting to enter the gate
> Reduce the price of zones as it pushes player to only cover the room with a proper zone under the facilities and ignoring the walking space, which make the room look much uglier (consider utilizing same mechanic as in EG - room can be removed as whole) and selling facilities less punishing (for example 0.8 of price instead of 0.5)
> Simplify the Training room research tree to two milestones instead of first major and adding all the other facilities through individual researches
> Reduce the price for research of autonomous intensive care unit
> Add warnings for upcoming removal of initial funding(50k per month), I've only noticed the number of remaining months in a second playthrough after first one got ruined the moment it happened
> Consider adding some loans and make the financial bankruptcy less punishing, the game ultimately shouldn't be about the money. From my perspective it should revolve around discovery, stories and scenarios behind the gates, alien relations, base management, fight for survival (recall the original Stargate) - the finances should be a background thing and have much less impact on game mechanics and story - in real life science is mostly non profitable except rare cases when individual discoveries yield billions and change the humanity life forever - exogate should be one of this kind of discoveries, as well as all the discoveries made behind the gates, the patent for these shouldn't individually be barely covering the salary of a single person.

Lower priority recommendations to consider:
> Tweak combat mechanics, it is way too clumsy now, but it is not a major factor for the game experience so may be left as is
> Add some wall of honor for fallen people
> Add decorations
> Add incidents (fire/flooding/toxic gas etc.) and cope mechanisms to improve on base management mechanics

While I did not play the Demo as it appears a lot of those who dislike the full release have, with very little knowledge of the game I came in and found the release to be an enjoyable experience. The gameplay is rather fun despite my lack of knowledge in the genre and feels extremely replayable due to the different playstyles of combat versus movement. The auto mapper took a little getting used to initially but the "gaps" and "lulls" that people may be describing (IMO) are there to give notable windows where ur options for combat/movement are limited, thus forcing u into decisions and giving the game some skill expression that I enjoyed. On the other hand there are moments (from custom imported songs) where I tested the song with AutoDetect and then again with the precise BPM added and the auto mapper wasn't too horribly different, giving this game a credit to the amount of different experiences one can have with a practically unlimited library. 

I am very excited to see how this game's lifespan goes as with more maps and characters to play as the sky is pretty much the limit. To touch on the different types of maps for a moment, the difficulties associated seem to follow the difficulty of the terrain itself of the map and the Enemy / Boss types. The song itself doesn't define difficulty which I feel works because the way the maps and enemies are designed and vary, it seems skill expression will be more about rhythmic knowledge and  enemy management, not just whether or not u can hit the notes on beat. This makes grinding high scores or learning new songs pretty fresh and will continue to keep the game fresh as maps and characters are released. 

Definitely give this game a shot if you love music and/or shooters because it is a largely polished, with crisp and fast paced gameplay and lots of potential to grow.

Although I only did two runs, both of which ended relatively quickly as can be seen by how little I've played, the game didn't really succeed in making me want to play more of it as the pace of the gameplay just feels a bit...off? I suppose?

Calling it fast-paced just feels like a complete and utter underestimate of how fast things really are considering that the game's core even revolves around managing a focus meter to slow the game down and make it more manageable. You're rewarded for going fast and killing enemies in "interesting ways" to get more coins, which are then used on buying drinks at the bar, this games perk/item system, or unlocking new drinks for it to offer you.

As focus has to regenerate, you only have so much to play with if you want to go fast. Due to that you'll want to mostly toggle it on and off quickly, just enough to get the drop on the enemies. This constant fast-slow-fast-slow made me feel more disoriented than anything else and after I failed my 2nd run, I moved to refund it as the game wants me to play faster than I find enjoyable while also just making me feel borderline nauseous.

Another issue is that there were no options to change the resolution or to swap between fullscreen and windowed. Furthermore, when I tried to change the keyboard bindings for the focus button, shift is uncomfortable for me to use as my pinky is somewhat numb, most of my alternate binds came up as "undefined". Alt, Ctrl and all of the numpad keys weren't being accepted.

On a plus side, the soundtrack, what I heard of it, sounded great and the guns themselves also felt satisfying to use.

I'm sure the game is plenty enjoyable if you enjoy games that move at the pace of an enthusiastic tourist during their first time on a German Autobahn, but if you're like me, the one who'd be in the passenger seat clawing at the upholstery, legs straight and pushing against the two break pedals they wish were there with all the might they can muster in a vain attempt to stop the madness they're being subjected to, I'd say give this one a pass.

Part Hong Kong Massacre, part Hotline Miami.  Adds unlockables, hence roguelike, as you progress.  These come in the form of drinks, which are sort of like power ups.  Unlike the two aforementioned games, you have HP here, so you can take quite a few hits/shots.  You can slow time, a la HKM and melee like HM.  If you need a fix for either two, this is an easy recommended.

*sound settings do not seem to be honored when starting up again.  It's ear bleeding loud.

Stray Blade is a fun RPG that reminds me a bit of Fable in the art style. Combat is easy to pick up but tricky to master. Plenty to explore and collectibles to find. Character customization is narrowed down to the armor and weapons you use but with that you can customize in many different ways. If you're looking for a solid adventure RPG Stray Blade is worth a look.

The game is entertaining, however, thier controller support is lacking hard. Theu don't support PS controllers, you can't even remap controller buttons. Also in game play character actions are visible slower than if you use a mouse and keyboard. These causes a higher death rate if using a controller.

I definitely enjoyed my time with the game. I'm not much for story driven titles, but even trying to skip the story, I found myself stopping to listen from time to time. I also find the price to be right on point. Just casually playing the story with a little bit of exploration on the side, you'll easily get at least 30 hrs out of the game. To me $1:1hr is a good price point.

I also had a lot of fun around the end trying to one-shot bosses with a certain rune+weapon combo =).
Although mainly an action-adventure game with elements from other sub-genres, it's a very nice addition to the Souls-Like sub-genre.

Remember the Fable series? This has a wonderful feeling of "What if we redid fable with a ton more weapons, combat variety and places to explore?"

In short, it's fun as heck, wonderful, and the combat's just a joy. Easy recommendation, and one I had no trouble playing to completion and enjoying the whole way through, especially when I got lost and just wandered off to see what goodies could be found in a given directoin. Spoiler: There's a ton of things hidden freaking everywhere.
This game is fun for the most part!

Stray Blade is here, I have been waiting for this game, Like ever since it was announced, 

Story: Learning of the Valley of legend, you see Farren journey to the land of acrea, But due to something happening, Farren meets boji, a wolf turned human, he is your companion,and guide.

Combat: When you first get into Stray blade the combat feels clunky, Until you get some skills unlocked some movement,and additional attacks, and also when you get more weapons, and armors, yes armors, as in more than one outfit, which are found in chest and etc.

Music: The amazing soundtrack sounds so good from the rise of the strings to the brass coming in, i love the music,

Sound Design: Ngl some of the sounds like someone beating a metal drum with a heavy hammer, but the sounds of the bows being fired, the fire crackling, to the sound of the forge and the hammer and tongs.

Enemy design: I love the variety of the enemy's, but man some of there parry windows are rough. But once you learn, the elites are tough, and they can tank the damage.

The three rulers of Acrea in your quest to beat them, you find new weapons, and abiltys to aid you in your quest,

overall i would give this a 10/10

In the end it still needs a few patches to be what it wants to be especialy when it comes to the fighting system but overall i like it.I¬¥d recommend for all which r not sure to buy it to wait a bit till the first patches r out and give it a try then.

I've been hyped for the game for a long time but after playing, it does have a few issues. 

The performance is unexpectedly poor despite the retro graphics, the 5 seconds here and there where it's smooth is lovely. Another issue is with Quest2 on PC there's a few inches of offset between the in-game hands and the controllers irl. There really should be a HIDE WRISTS setting since they don't follow the irl wrists at all, it breaks the immersion every time I point a weapon. A gr8 example of VR wrists is RE4VR, it has wrists that bent similar to how they bend irl.

The Axe throw mechanic feels like it needs work. It'll function for maybe 10 seconds until an enemy is onscreen, then the axe just drops like a weight. The axe dropping issue also applies to whatever weapon I switch to so the sword, staff, etc. feels unfinished. The axe could also benefit from having a bit of weight added like many other vr games with weighty weapons like Walking Dead S&S etc. and perhaps a collision sound and particle effect when thumping a wall with it. Besides that it does feel good to chop foes but again the axe spinning special attack feels so wrong when pointing it forward due to the ugly wrist pointing up to the sky.

If there's an update fixing the performance and axe throw mechanic I'll switch my review to positive cuz I still really love Amid Evil. I'll probably fight through the weirdness for another couple levels still, it's so close to excellent! Still hyped for it

Eresys is an incredibly well-crafted co-op horror game that truly captures the essence of H.P. Lovecraft's work. Really liked the fact that the game's emphasis on teamwork which creates an immersive experience, The creatures where hard enough but Eresys is an absolute must-play for horror fans and anyone looking for a thrilling gaming experience.

After playing an hour I'm really liking it.
At its core it's a stealth game, you sneak around on a large island, avoiding monsters and collecting torn pages for your grimoire and blood to summon eldritch beings. There are also relics to find which are then displayed at your hub area.
Absolutely chilling, the foggy atmosphere with the unsettling music sets the mood perfectly.
Only played solo, might be harder than multiplayer but seems viable.
Very stable, didn't encounter any major bugs, some weird animations here and there. The only negative I can think of is that you don't seem to be able to pause the game even when playing solo, although there are safe zones.

At 30 bucks this game does not deliver. Not to undermine the hard work from the developers because I can tell there's care behind some of the aspects of this game. But if this wasn't attached to League's IP this game would be generic and boring.

I'm not being entirely objective and I won't pretend so either. I'm a fan of the genre, but not a hardcore one. I find the art-style to be blander than I expected. At the beginning I was stunned but quickly that faded and I was a bit underwhelmed. Some of the areas like the hub look very nice and the animations are definitely great to look at. But some of the other areas and backgrounds left me a little disappointed. Sometimes the perspective can be a little confusing too and I feel like the pixel work could have been better, but maybe it's because I have played other games with an aesthetic that attracted me more. 

Then there's almost no voice lines, and the game loop is repetitive as hell. You're gonna find yourself spamming the same moves and not using the spell mechanic so much expect for some of the big enemies because the mana is very limited. And if you do it's probably because it's your 9th side quest where you gotta beat 12 waves of the same 4 enemies and you just kind of want it to be over with. 

There's some great ideas here that I really appreciate like how you grow stronger with the followers you recruit, it gives the game an appropriate feeling. But then there's other things like the fact that you can waste all your potions while at full health. I found this to be pretty frustrating. The hardest difficulty is, in my opinion, challenging enough without having to worry about spending all of my potions by mistake while I was at full health and throwing away a change at winning.

Which leads me also to the fact that for some reason there's no shortcut to the battles. Yes there's a sort of fast forward that skips dialogue but sometimes there's plenty of animations before a battle starts and you have to sit through them every time...

In my opinion this game would have been fine at 15 bucks, maybe 20. But as it is.. I wouldn't recommend it unless you are crazy for the League universe or the game genre
Love the game, combat feels great. Only issue is (if you're bad like me and playing on king slayer) you are unable to skip cut scenes before fights which make boss fights feel tedious sometimes.

If you go to the discussion boards right now the game has serious balance and gameplay issues.  I feel like the developers were so impressed with the various mechanics they were able to create that they never considered the feedback loop of the gameplay.  Right now you can only send one mission to any planet, and unless you send multiple scientists there is a high chance that you don't get theories.  Without theories you can't generate patents, which are the only way to boost your monthly income.  Worse patents only last for 12 months once created so you need a continuous supply of theories, which have a definite finite limit.

Worse the AI for the medical room is trash.  Its not just poor, but actively works to hinder the player by not having medics prioritize healing the sick and injured.  Someone who gets hurt is liable to spend months lying in a medical bed because the medic prioritizes training and socializing over healing.

This is an early access game and there is plenty of room for major improvements, but unless I see some I cannot recommend this game.  Right now in the state its in the game has a "you are losing and it will keep getting worse until you quit" gameplay loop.  there is rarely a feeling that you are moving forward and most of your play is defensive to try to prevent the inevitable collapse and bankruptcy.  Unless the developers make adjustments to the game play this will always be a frustrating game for a very niche audience.

I would recommend the game after some adjustments. Money seems to be a game killer for me, you keep needing more people more research and constantly building more rooms which is the fun part but the game doesn't seem to give enough money to get very far that I seen. You write patents to make money but they only seem to pay around $10,000 for a limited time. That is enough to pay maybe 2 people. You will need to pay teams of people from scientists, medics, soldiers etc and the money runs out fast. I don't see how this is sustainable on the amount of money you can make at least from the beginning.

Summary: Fun game potential but some really bad balance and RNG issues as the quests progress make it not fun. Save often so you can fix bugs with reloads. Also some dialogs have weird religious phrases that feel completely out of place, really don't know what is going on with that.

- Way way to easy to over build at the beginning, should have better into quest series that limits what you can buy/do. 
- RNG especially in your first several missions can end your game. First couple planets should have better/guaranteed drop rate of research items.
- You get a single 10 day warning of invasion, nothing else. It's not enough time to research, build, and recruit the needed defenses. This ended my latest game as I was unable to recover from the attack.
- Very unforgiving play, as in you need to know what is going to happen from previous playthrough to plan your base correctly and know when to do things.
- No feedback on what some icons and status effects mean. Had no idea that there is a mission leader which most all of the RNG is based off of. Can't get gaters to drop things in the base and it permanently locks them out from do anything else. Have to reload to fix.
- Gaters can get stuck inside objects or between objects and walls easily. Have to reload to fix.
- Gaters can also get stuck doing a task, never take care of themselves, and quit. Have to reload to fix.
- Trivially, the mission returned screen pops up and triggers or interrupts what you're doing. Would like it to pop up like the mission progress.

Great concept but hope they address the balance, RNG, and bugs as those just make things super frustrating.

coffee talk extends beyond being just a game. i first picked up coffee talk in the summer of 2020 and i never knew that it would leave such a lasting impact, almost 3 years later.

i work as a barista part time and i actually had what i described as my first "coffee talk" experience in real life only a couple days ago with this woman that ordered a chai. i like to think that was incredibly divine timing, considering this sequels release.

she asked me something along these lines, "what do i do when i am vulnerable with someone and they mistreat me for being emotional?" of course i was taken back by this question as i have never been asked such an introspective and openly vulnerable question by a customer before. we have a beautiful conversation, and for a couple hours i am stuck in my head wondering how i may have given off an energy that she could feel that she could confide personal feelings with a barista, a stranger she's never met before.

in the same day, she comes back. she thanks me for listening and giving her advice and explains that there was a situation where she was refused accommodation for an unseen disability she has. 
i tell her that it wasn't her fault and that when someone has the ability to be accommodating & kind and chooses not to be, it isn't a fault or something that she did and this leads into what i want to say about coffee talk. 

coffee talk is just a game really. but its a bit more than that, at least for me personally. you might know a person, you see them all the time walking around, doing typical human person things but there are stories and so many memories attached to each person you see. i don't think i will forget the conversation i had with her, she reminded me that we are complex & to comfortably express being vulnerable, something i need to practice myself sometimes. why not listen to our friends and provide a safe space for them when we can, rather than refusing outright when we have capability to be warm & loving people. we can absolutely practice being more vulnerable & more accommodating to someone being vulnerable. which includes writing this sappy review of one of my favourite games i have ever played. thanks coffee talk for being such a comforting game & that teaching me that humans were made to connect <3

This game sneaked upon me from nowhere, and without a friend's recommendation, I'd have never even found out about it. So far, it pretty much feels like a souls-inspired take on Fable/Kingdoms of Amalur, with easy to grasp yet somewhat difficult to master stamina-based combat with parries, dodges and poise break. The world is visually attractive, and there's tons of stuff to discover while hunting for the next boss.

Overall a fun experience. I think with a few more patches and fixes the game may end up being a lot of fun for the right audience.  The story is average but the world has a fun art style.  The combat is where I has some issues.  The combat can be quite difficult, which is not an issue on its own. The issue is more that the game seems to be overly reliant on the parry mechanics.  As someone who prefers sneaking or dodging even when I play a souls like, it felt a bit frustrating. I also found that a lot of enemies can be cheesed pretty easily with certain weapons.  Overall a fun experience and the devs are definitely listening to feedback and making improvements.

Stray Blade is a great rogue-lite game. Combat takes a little getting used to, as it doesn't operate like a typical hack 'n' slash. Some skill and timing is required to be successful and it can take a little time to develop. 

Overall, the game is graphically interesting with a wonderful artistic style. Enemies feel threatening (and definitely are), but the environment isn't overly dark and heavy as with some games in this genre. Leveling your characters skills, upgrading/enhancing weapons, etc. all have natural and understandable progressions and add to the game play experience. 

I am enjoying the game a great deal and definitely recommend it!

I am having so much fun playing Stray Blade. The world is beautifully designed and does a great job of keeping me immersed. The combat system is really satisfying although it can be a bit rough in the beginning. I love the lore that is scattered about the world, waiting to be found.

A friend and I had been absolutely HOOKED on the demo lately, so scooping this up when it released was a no-brainer. It's chaotic but tons of fun. I can't recommend it enough as a multiplayer experience. Because of how fast and easy it is for things to go horribly wrong, it really helps build clear communication.
It's a stealth-focused rogue-lite platformer with base building and colony sim mechanics. Each of your agents has positive and negative quirks that greatly effect the mission. If you succeed, you gain XP and the agents can level out of those negative perks. If you don't succeed, that agent is gone forever. However, you can kidnap enemy agents on missions and then brainwash them into becoming playable agents. It gets more and more complex from there.
I love it. It's definitely a mainstay in my multiplayer games collection and I'll be trying to talk more and more people into getting it to join the insanity.

The best parts of this game are the environments, voice acting, and cut scene choreography. These components are at a stark mismatch with the lower effort low-poly graphics, but at least they filled the environment out with decent effects and lighting.

I was expecting a puzzle game with some light platforming and exploration. Unfortunately the puzzles are kid-tier and the platforming isn't great. Tedium as a difficulty. 

It seems like a decent portion of the game is stealth sequences with invisible enemies - which is again at a massively stark contrast with the childlike components of the rest of the game. What an unpleasant experience to have to constantly ping the invisible enemies with your flashlight, but don't shine them for more than a millisecond or they will stagger and stop their patrol, making you wait even longer for that opening. Also these enemies are not repelled by the light sources that eradicate the other black slime patches. Not intuitive at all.

The controls are very frustrating. Sometimes you don't clamber on a ledge when you should, and some ledges just can't be clambered, but there is nothing indicating that. You cannot rebind the controls and they set Q to interact instead of the industry standard E. Also set SHIFT to crouch instead of the industry standard C or CRTL. Weird choices that are annoying to get used to - unless this is the only game you've ever played...I guess. 

You can't aim your weapon, only use it in the flat direction your character is facing. You can't aim up or down. So if you want to drop into an area with invisible enemies patrolling, then you can't shine down to see where they are in advance. Just hope for the best. I really don't see a reason for the enemies to be invisible, it doesn't add any extra challenge or fun, just work.

Possible the worst thing about this game, and something that I've never seen done in 30 years of gaming, is extremely poor saving/advancing. You can collect hidden gems, but if you don't complete a puzzle after that, then you'll have to do it again when you play next. Sometimes you will advance to an area and a cutscene will pull you to the next without any confirmation, meaning you can no longer get the hidden gems in that area. And these trigger points are not telegraphed at all. Not like you open a door to advance, you're just walking along and a guy starts talking to you and pulls you to the next area. I saw another review say they were annoyed about not getting to explore after collecting an item, and I thought to myself "surely it was obvious that would happen", but nope - it happened to me too.

[h2]I Did Not Expect This Famished Inquisition[/h2]

If you came here seeking magic, you'll catch a whiff of it in the art direction and narrative, but you'll find much of this title starved in terms of gameplay.

[h3]GG:[/h3]
- Incredible, expressive pixels and animations that breathe life into characters and the setting.
- A diverse and scrappy cast.
- Strong elements of narrative presentation via writing and the aforementioned art style.

[h3]No RE:[/h3]
- Combat gets stale quickly.
- Uninspired progression.
- A lot of overlap in the spells.

[h3]You Might Still Like It If:[/h3]
- You believed gaming graphics peaked in the early/mid 90s.

- You love the lore of League of Legends so laviciously you'll laud a little scrap like this labor of ludology. Legit.

- DEMACIA! If you need more explanation than that, then you're not in this category.

[h3]But I Think You'd Probably Rather Play:[/h3]
- [b]Hades:[/b] Maybe you've heard of it? A masterpiece of the type of combat experience Mageseekers attempts to provide, on top of its own compelling narrative and rich cast of characters.

-[b]Ruined King: A League of Legends Story:[/b] An immersive dive into the world of Runeterra via its incredible presentation. It's also not bad to play, provided you are into crunchy turn basesd RPGs and can stomach a gromps-worth of mechanical bloat.

I do plan to finish Mageseeker to find where the narrative takes me, but the $30 launch price is a lot to ask for a game that's most engaging when you're not playing it. Consider my alternatives first if you haven't gotten around to them yet. They are slightly more expensive at full price but are considerably more rewarding.

While the game itself is rather interesting, I can't recommend it at it's current state for a few reasons:

a) There are bugs that prevent you from fighting battles with reinforcements, which is a serious issue.

b) The UI of the game is exceptionally bad, and half the time the tooltips don't work or display incorrect text.

c) The game has this weird micro-transaction thing going on in it. You can purchase gold with real world money, and you apparently need to unlock the nations within the game with it or something? I'm not entirely sure how it works, but at least for custom battles you have to buy them with in-game gold(that you acquire with real money, or super slowly by playing the game). When I pay a bunch of money for a game, I expect to be able to play all the contents in it without having to pay MORE due to in-game microtransactions. If this was a free-to-play game then perhaps such things(along with the numerous bugs) could be overlooked, but as is, it's a definite no from me.

All in all a huge shame, the game has great promise, and especially the era it's set on is monstrously underexplored in the wargame genre(or any games or fiction for that matter), so it's really disappointing that it ends up being a hastily slapped together cash-grab from the looks of it. Even if that's not the intent, the lack of polish is too much for me to recommend it until all issues are fixed. 

Also, there's no free campaign mode at all like I expected, only a few campaigns based on historical stuff, which means you can't freely play, say, Italy and conquer Europe, They exist in only one scenario as a minor role.

A seemingly trustworthy, and not-at-all-suspicious robed guy inside an orb of darkness wants you to catch him some fish. What could go wrong? 
[spoiler]It's not like it'll be the end of the world![/spoiler]

There are 4 regular fish, and 1 special one:
1 A fat fish.
2 A long fish.
3 An eel thing.
4 A manta ray.
5 A BIG octopus thing.

1 and 2 share an area, as do 3 and 4.
You have limited inventory, so you'll need to go back to robe-guy occasionally to drop 'em off.
After you've caught four of each, you have to fish up a gamecube floating under a noisy cloud, which lets you talk to the star giant, who summons the special 5th fish for you.
After catching fish 5 and dropping it off, I guess the world is saved?...
[spoiler]Either that, or everyone on the planet dies, and are reborn as space-birds? Who can say?[/spoiler]

It's not a horror game, but it has a great ominous and tense atmosphere, and just looks really cool!

I should also probably mention, that my PC is well-below the recommended specs, but ran the game perfectly.

My only gripes are two slight lacks of clarity:

1 It took a bit to figure out how to actually reel fish in, finding/hooking is easy, but when I hooked 'em I couldn't figure out how to move the white bar, which you have to keep inside the yellow one...after many failed attempts I finally realized you move it by moving the mouse horizontally...I had been mashing/clicking everything, but didn't think to do that...Then again, I don't play a lot of fishing games, so maybe this is normal? It did SHOW an example of catching, but didn't actually say "move the mouse, dum-dum"

2 I rowed around for quite a bit in Astra looking for fish 5, but didn't think to look straight down under my boat, and when I failed to catch it, I rowed around again for a while without finding it...tho after talking to the giant again, it respawned.

^ Then again, these gripes can also be summarized as "I may just be an idiot".

Even with my rough start and long search for fish 5, I still won the game in about an hour, so maybe it can be done in 30-40 min if you know what you're doing?
