I'm a big fan of all of Erik's games, Factory Town include, and playtested this game, so I'm a bit biased, but I think it's something truly interesting!

"Idle" games have always been a weird concept. From the early days of something like Cookie Clicker, they were made as experimental or joke games originally. Then, mobile games happened... And the design of low-effort, high-feedback "addictive" games fit the usual over-abundant genre of games that exist solely to try to suck your wallet through your phone to feed your endless treadmill. There were a few standouts among them that tried to do something extra, things like Realm Grinder or Clicker Heroes, that added a bit more sense of progression, and maybe just a hint of strategy and management.

Which brings up another huge positive. At least at the time of writing this, there is NO way to progress in the game via microtransactions. I actually can't think of another idle game that does this, and the pace of Factory Town is designed around it, instead of playing slow to tempt you into an additional purchase.

All that said, Factory Town Idle is something different, to the point that it is far more "management" than "idle". Though it follows the same exponential progression of an idle game, it's easy to spend hours staring at production lines, tweaking numbers, unlocking improvements, and constantly growing. You'll soon unlock the ability to make multiple towns (which are basically new game sessions) and trade between them, which means the likelihood of running out of things to do is extremely low. The only thing that's truly "idle" about the game is that you can (optionally) continue running things while the game is closed.

This does, however, mean that the game isn't for everyone, and, confusingly, it might not be right for the average idle game player; someone who wants short bursts of a thing they can check on now and then and play casually. It's designed more for number-crunching optimizers, who don't mind clicking through endless (yet entertaining) spreadsheets. It also seems like it could be a bit overwhelming at first for someone not familiar with Factory Town, since it's an abstraction of the same things you would do in that game: use workers to make goods, sell goods to houses, use coins to make upgrades, grow, plan, automate, repeat.

For me, though, this feels like the evolution of a genre, and I'd really like to see more small devs take on ideas like this; taking engaging concepts that have been abused in mobile games and making them back into properly enjoyable, lovingly designed games.

Very much recommended for anyone who looks at the screenshots and thinks it might be for them!

They said it couldn't be done. They said a VN about maid [strike] femboys [/strike] girls in a cafe wouldn't be done. But god damn it, my the bulge in my pants says otherwise.

Disclaimer: I have never played a VN before and probably will not play another one again (unless Myosuki releases another one), so this review is about as ignorant to the genre as it possibly can be.

The game has surprisingly good writing. I was honestly surprised when perhaps my all time favorite word (dubious) was used within the first like 5 minutes of the game. In addition to that, the conversations feel like they could actually happen between two people. I'm sure we all know games or anime or whatever that just makes us think "The writer has never interacted with another human ever". This game (at least at the point of me writing this review) does not give off this feeling :). It's also very "meta" which I wasn't expecting. I was very amused when there was a long conversation about the struggles of developing a video game and how bad it is to pirate them.  

The game isn't porn. I always have this kind of stereotype where anime inspired visual novels are usually just a medium for viewing porn, but this really isn't the case. There is the flashing scene in the first like isk 15-30- minutes, but that is more of the Shakespearean concept of roping in viewers than a glimpse at how the entire game will play out. Over 2 hours in and that's the only (arguably) NSFW moment present. Don't worry horn dogs, there is a DLC "adult patch" available, though not on steam.

With all of that aside, there are some problems. The player character is relatively annoying, though not as annoying as I somewhat expected him to be (forced male). There are some particularly good dialogue options sprinkled in, so it's not as bad as it could be.

Another problem that is present is the load times. Between some scenes the game will load for probably like 2-5 seconds. That might not seem like a lot, but it is a little jarring considering just how well everything else in the game runs. It's not something that particularly hurts my experience, but I imagine it is something potential buyers might wonder about.

TL:DR Buy the game, the writing is surprisingly good and it doesn't have a lot of the problems that I assumed would exist in a VN. It's made by an indie group and the director of the group is super active on their discord server in a way that makes me root for their success :)

In this adventure game, you are dropped upon a mysterious island where you must seek for objects, solve riddles, and simply explore.

Because the island is open, you can explore and perform tasks in any order you like. In the event that you select that option before the start of the game, important items will be highlighted once you get near. This makes the game less frustrating because some items can be hidden behind or underneath other items. Additionally, if you change your mind throughout the game, you can turn it off. Just beware that going in blind can make things more difficult for you.

Everything in the game is done using gestures, which makes the game a bit more special. When you use the mouse, you raise a hand that creates a vivid trail. The fact that there is no guesswork involved is a plus. As soon as you move your mouse over a significant item, the gestures appear in the lower right corner.

Puzzles are pretty interesting and don‚Äôt force the overused problems such as memorization, color manipulation or block pushing down your throat. There is some classic keycards and codes searching, but there's also stuff you don't see in any similar game.

The diary is the most vital tool you have. It includes notes on each particular task as well as the precise actions that must be completed. Without immediately giving you the answer, it's done really nicely. Additionally, tasks and actions that have been finished are marked off so you can clearly see what has to be done.

The diary contains a lot more information. You can view the map, which highlights significant locations, count the bones that have been found‚Äîthe game's collectible‚Äîread notes and letters that provide details about the underlying plot, and manage your inventory. 

You'll be picking up a lot of seemingly pointless or worthless stuff because this is an adventure game. You can arrange eight of them in the taskbar, allowing easy selection with keys ranging from 1 to 8. With various orbs that have particular abilities, like turning day into night or guiding you to bones, this is quite helpful.

Particularly with regard to text that has not been translated, there is some apparent lack of polish. The most obvious is the loading screen in Cyrillic, although there are other instances as well.

I have enjoyed just about all of the "100 Hidden" series in the past, so I opened up this game with a certain expectation.  I started playing at first and was disappointed - although the 3D art is interesting, it didn't live up to the old 2D art that I've loved in the previous entries, and the frogs were shockingly easy to find.  I got all the way to the bottom and only had 53 found, though, and that's when I discovered you can also rotate this puzzle.  Suddenly, the 3D made sense, and I actually had to search a little bit.

I still don't like this as much as the 2D entries, but it was a fun little offshoot of the series.

With the addition of the third dimension, the gameplay has become very sophisticated. This game has definitely become one of my favorite games, if not most favorite game ever made. The careful placement of each frog, the addition of the collectible fruit, shells, and fish, and the amazing level design, this game should most definitely be bought by everyone. I cannot recommend this game enough.

And now, a haiku.

Very superb game
But there is one big mistake
Forgot the last frog

Thank you Anatoliy Loginovskikh, my favorite dev of all time.
THIS GAME IS AWESOME< REALLY FUN AND REALLY GOOD PUZZLES

I recently embarked on a delightful adventure with "100 Hidden Frogs 2," and it was an experience that filled my heart with joy and wonder. This captivating puzzle game, which showcases the beauty of nature and the magic of discovery, left me entranced from start to finish.

The game's visual design is nothing short of breathtaking. The lush, vibrant scenes depicting serene ponds, lush forests, and tranquil meadows are a feast for the eyes. The attention to detail is awe-inspiring, with each frog meticulously hidden in plain sight, blending seamlessly into the natural surroundings. As I explored each scene, I found myself marveling at the intricacies of the artwork and the skillful craftsmanship that went into creating such an immersive world.

The gameplay is both challenging and satisfying. Searching for the elusive frogs requires keen observation and sharp problem-solving skills. Each level presents a new set of puzzles and obstacles to overcome, keeping me engaged and motivated to uncover all the hidden treasures. The sense of accomplishment I felt with each discovery was truly rewarding, and it kept me coming back for more.

One of the aspects that touched me the most was the game's sense of connection with nature. "100 Hidden Frogs 2" serves as a gentle reminder of the beauty and wonder that surrounds us in the natural world. It encourages players to slow down, observe their surroundings, and appreciate the little miracles that often go unnoticed. It rekindled my love for nature and left me with a renewed appreciation for the simple joys that nature provides.

The game also boasts a soothing, ambient soundtrack that perfectly complements the serene atmosphere of the game. The gentle melodies and nature-inspired soundscape added an extra layer of immersion to my experience, making it all the more captivating and enchanting.

Lastly, I must mention the heartfelt message that resonates throughout the game. "100 Hidden Frogs 2" conveys a profound love and respect for nature, reminding us of the importance of preserving our planet's biodiversity and the need to protect our natural habitats. It's a timely and poignant reminder of our responsibility to care for the environment and the precious creatures that call it home.

In conclusion, "100 Hidden Frogs 2" is a heartwarming and enchanting puzzle game that touched my soul in ways I didn't expect. Its breathtaking visuals, challenging gameplay, connection with nature, soothing soundtrack, and heartfelt message make it a truly memorable and captivating experience. I highly recommend it to anyone who appreciates the wonders of nature and seeks a wholesome and uplifting gaming experience. It's a treasure trove of joy, discovery, and inspiration that will stay with me long after the game is over.

Cannot recommend. Short answer is the developer says you need to build right to not have bosses that are bullet sponges.  But there is no way to make a build since you just open chests and a random thing drops out. Aka extremely bad version of Risk of Rain style buffs.

Longer and more detailed part. They stole stuff from Risk of Rain but even in that game you can choose certain things. Risk of Rain has so many good things and mods helped it be even better since you knew what the items were.  This is a downgrade of that system.

The bosses are 800 Hp and you usually are doing around 1.5 damage per hit.  This means you are having to attack some stupid boss for 500 plus times.  Now you are doing around maybe 2 hits per minute which means that it will take at least 4 minutes to kill him.  Did I mention that your shooting takes stamina?  So you will not be shooting all the time and since not every hit will hit you are around 6 MINUTES for one stupid boss.  This also means you are just watching the same stupid boss go through the same sequence of steps again and again.  Oh and hitboxes are bad since you will take damage from the bosses for no reason. Bosses will do hitscan type attacks offscreen so you will take damage since you could not see their windup.  Bosses can multi-hit you since there seems to be barely any invulnerable frames after taking damage.

Enemies are just simple things and take no thought process to fight.

So how are you supposed to "Build right".... There is no way since everything you get up till the first boss is random.  You can pick some stuff after the first boss but again you have at least a 6 minute boring meat shield you have to kill first. That is why this is a failure of the developer not designing the game right since no game should just have stupid bullet sponge bosses.

Again cannot recommend and probably will ask for a refund since this game is not good but will decide in the next week since I still have at least a week before I would be above the thresholds..  The developer needs to "git gud."

Actually decided not worth my time since it seems that it maybe has at most 4 hours of gameplay.  For a  roguelite that is extremely low.

Edit Just watched the developer play and within 2 minutes they died to the first boss.  Only getting him to half health.  It was due to one ability that you get only on one broom.  There is a high change you would not even get the ability if you played other brooms.

[b]To all the negative reviews out there. Minecraft Legends is an RTS. Please set your expectations right.[/b]

An RTS is about commanding; telling your troops/builders what to do. In an RTS, troops do stand still and do nothing because you didn't tell them what to attack next. (Not the AI bugging out)

[hr][/hr]

Okay with that out of the way...

Minecraft Legends simplifies the usual real-time strategy gameplay loop hardcore RTS players might be used to. Say goodbye to your teleporting camera, drag select, and clicks per second, because you're no longer an armchair general. Now you lead your troops into battle and this concept strongly restricts the range of micro-management you have over the battlefield. This restriction actually makes Minecraft Legends a very good entry RTS.

I fully recommend this game for the types of players listed below. Consider buying the game if you fall in any of these categories.
1. new to RTS and interested in trying it out
2. played RTS in the past casually
3. has a group of friends you want to mess around with (in PVP & PVE)
4. loves Minecraft/Mojang a lot

I haven't tried out the PVP yet (will be finishing the PVE first) so I will not comment on it.

From the get go I had in mind that this game is built to be PvP focused. However gameplay is slow, and in a multiplayer match players will be leaving and joining as the 4v4 match takes a very long time to complete. 30 minutes ish if the players know what they're doing or an hour plus if they don't. There is no visible MMR system or ranks, the PvP portion of swinging your swords at each other on your mounts is very wonky. Most of the time it felt like I should have hit my opponent or that I was far enough after disengaging that I shouldn't have been getting hit.

I hope in the future they change PvP for the sake of the game, standardize the map instead of having it randomly generate everytime. I can only see them adopting a sort of League of Legends style arena with piglin bases to the side and resource generators you can upgrade through the prismarine. The PvP aspect needs to be standardized imo for briefer matchs and an MMR system implimented to keep matches balanced. Maybe even a smaller arena until you reach a high enough rank.

As for the PvE portion of the game, for me it was more enjoyable but rather tedious. I find myself either waiting for a building to fall or running around trying not to die from getting spammed by ranged enemies. The piglins have massive bases but you only need to attack a small portion of it to defeat them. I have just started so perhaps I just haven't experienced the entirety it has to offer but I suspect its just more of the same save for tougher ai enemies yet to be encountered, even bigger piglin bases that I only need to attack a small portion of but wait around for 20 minutes to take out defensive towers and piglin spawners that are in my way towards the portal.

All in all its a promising shell of a game that fails to deliver the impressive rts punch. Perhaps I'm just too old (I'm 27) and shouldn't be so worried about a game aimed more towards children. (Which I might add is an even bigger argument for them to revamp PvP. What kid is going to invest that much time into a match in the first place!)

[h1] Not worth it. (At least now?) [/h1]

I was one of many who wait release of that game with a big hopes and great hype. But now it's there and... huh.

First of all, [b]pros:[/b]
[b]+Music[/b] is great and I love it. Most of shooter-rhythm games just stick with rock or metal and hear something like that it's breath of fresh air.
[b]+Movement[/b] is fluid and have momentum. It's fun to move around and play with acceleration.
[b]+Shooting[/b] is not that impactful as it must be but it's not bad.

And, sad to say, [b]cons:[/b]
[b]-Content[/b] for now it's barely have any. It's sure is gonna be not issue later but for now if you buy a game you get almost no content at all.
[b]-Weapon Balance[/b] is debatable thing but Rocket Launcher almost oneshot everything while shotgun require sometimes absurd amount of shots.
[b]-Level Structure Ideology[/b] is bland. Checkpoint system level feels fun enough but there's only one.
Arenas is good addition to game content but for now [u]they are[/u] main content.
There was very little interactables and clever design in those levels, they are mostly empty room with enemies, jumppads and explosives.
There is no clever use of verticality, not enough hazards or in general no interesting places to play around.
It's really sad when the best levels in gameplay design sense is corridor with empty rooms and round arena with abyss around.
[b]-Game Structure[/b] there is no progression at all. You can choose whatever song you want, any level you want but can't choose character on it, there is no track of your runs, there is no unlocks (if theres any, all my win runs unlock nothing).
You feel like you just aimlessly play the songs and don't have even reward of what grade you get from complete it outside your final screen on current run.
[b]-Enemy Attacks Variety[/b] is lacking. There was only projectiles or contact damage. It's hard task to balance a bunch of variety in games like that, but it need more of it.
Some enemies have shields and that's already good path to spice things up but it need more.
[b]-Custom Songs Rhythm[/b] ... it's works in 5-10% of songs. Auto-BPM also can't properly detect bpm if song is not super flat.
[b]-Original Songs Rhythm[/b] in general it's fine but it really hit or miss sometimes.
[b]-Weapon Auto-Fire[/b] is weird. You can just hold button and auto-shoot. I don't even notice if that impact score at all but it must be toggleable feature. It kill all purpose of having rhythm.

[hr][/hr]

I wish later I can return and change that review, but for now the game is a mess. It's not horrible in any case it's just a really weak game with no hooks or depth.

So if you wanna buy it now, go on, why not, but don't expect a good experience. It's really mid and weak.

[h1] That section is for Devs (If they bother to get feedback) [/h1]

I'm just a lil guy who don't even publish my games and don't even finish them most of the time, so my words is can be irrelevant, but I really hope this game is get changes and I only wish best for devs.

[b]Progression:[/b] that game need one. Even if it's simple like unlock levels not from start or some songs. Just show closed levels/songs to player and way to unlock it even if it's simple like finish one or couple another songs. No need to lock everything but for now it's feels totally aimless.
[b]Progression Tracking:[/b] the menu currently is full sandbox. It's okay if you aim on that but hope you consider to add grades and run statistics. Even simplified one. The levels or songs don't even shown any completion on them and you don't feel engaged to beat it on high score because of that.
[b]Progression/Freeplay:[/b] if you gonna consider adding any progression but aim mostly on free player experience, the good way to do it, simply separate current game selection mechanics into 'Freeplay' mode.
[b]Character Selection:[/b] weird to feel when characters is mostly generate difficulty but they attached to levels. If you want so much allow player choose whatever they want, allow them to choose characters also. Cause thet's a good wat to squeze more from few selection of levels.

[b]Level Design:[/b] if your main aim is arena style gameplay I can't complain but I was sure most of players get hyped because linear style of levels. If you already work on some, then it's great but I hope arenas gonna be additional type of levels, instead of main one.
[b]Score System:[/b] games like this is score oreintated and curently game feed is lacking. There was no clear indecation of why and how to get better scor except obvious ways. There was no wat to compete agains another player or the game currently. If there was changes to give moore feedback to players and have any leaderboard on at least main songs of the game it's can be way more engaging to replay songs better and better.
[b]Level Interactions:[/b] jump pads, abyss, explosives it's a good starting point, but there was a very little way's to expirement with that. There was almost no elevation in linear levels also. It's all make the level design bland and most of the time not engaging to play levels in different ways.
[b]Enemy Projectiles:[/b] Theres very few of them. Almost all attack is - 'contact damage, contact damage from charging at you, direct bullet projectile, homing bullet projectile, prediction bullet projectile and ground zone bullet projectile.'
It's good start but bad variety in long terms. There is many games what already show how do more from little. If you consider adding more 'wave', 'direct lasor'  or 'AOE' projectiles with good indication of them coming it can spice up gameplay a lot.
[b]Characters and their Difficulty:[/b] the only difference now as I notice it's amount of health and 'ability'. That means if you already use ability the difference for current gameplay between characters is simply none. That's not a good way to build character based gameplay.
If they have different speed, amount of jumps, some other ways to change their movements, that's already a great way to differentiate them from each other.
In perfect world the differenct sets of weapons is way to go, but that's a too much work.
[b]Weapon Difference and Balance:[/b] As I said before, Rocket Launcher way to powerful while using shotgun to blast some big enemies is invalid especially while there is a bunch of projectiles around.
But thing is, idea around you have different range wepon is clash hard with unability to select weapons manually. If you stick with idea of weapon scrolling that way maybe that's a good idea to give them alternative fire? Like more aoe attack for rifle weapon or more distant attack for shotgun.
I get the idea of timing your movement to upcoming weapon for change distance between you and enemy but in practice most valid strategy is maintain same distance and wait for better weapon, cause the speed of weapon appearance is way fast than your ability to plan and execute that.
[b]Run Modifiers:[/b] another way to make more from few selection of levels is while having a good track of your score in menu have modifiers for current run. You get the idea. Also Auto-shoot can be one of them, instead being constant cheeze-card.

[b]Custom Songs and their Mapper:[/b] first of all it barely works. It's automaticly give 400 bpm to Elden Ring ost (I test a lot of weird songs to watch if mapper can handle anything) and that's the most fun expirience.
sadly, out of beat stuff it's not that fun expiriense at all.
Two things must be done or that feature is gonna be as useles as most of automappers in other rhythm games:
[b]Custom Songs Mapper Editor:[/b] instead of automate process allow players to put map handly and shift bpm on the fly. It's gonna lead to really good maps as well as funny shenanigans especially when players can set manually what weapon used in what part of the song. Honestly, any editor (like a FNF for example) can be a real game changer for stuff like that.

This is not an objective review. I've already played the entire Blood Moon demo when it was available and loved it. From the wolf pack to fighting vampires to the large amount of romance options, Blood Moon delivers on all of it. You make important decisions every step of the way - do you save the stray, kick her out of the city or kill her? Do you ally with the vampires, hunters, witches or no one? Do you protect your new home or abandon it? It all leads to different outcomes. Barb's writing is engaging and the pack truly squabbles, jokes, and cares about each other. [spoiler]You CAN DIE. But even that leads to a beautifully sad ending. This is gonna sound weird, but I recommend dying at least once.[/spoiler]
Not objective at all: I hope Blood Moon is a huge success, I hope it makes the proposed sequel Thicker Than a reality.

P.S. People comparing this to Project Zomboid are missing the point the only thing Dead Unending really has in common with PZ is the isometric viewpoint. PZ is a survival sim and this is more of an arcade tower defence. survival aspects in this game are almost completely inconsequential as one of the first things you unlock is the ability to spawn unlimited amounts of food.

It has some good aspects. Killing enemies and creating combos feels great. But the game has some mechanics that really work against itself. The focus slows things down when I'm trying to enjoy the past pace of the game so I end up rarely using it. 
Enemy bullets are so fast its impossible to try and dodge them unless you happen to perfectly use your focus. But enemies also have no signalling as to when they will shoot so its hard to tell when a good time to even use focus is.

Then there is the readability. Everything kinda blends together with the black and white. Its hard to tell when something is an obstacles like a table or a wall. So I ended up getting stuck behind obstacles rather often trying to dodge enemy fire. 
The game also doesnt give a lot of feedback to the player when it comes to getting hit. So its hard to learn from your own mistakes.

Lastly is the roguelike aspect. You can unlock new power ups by spending in-run currency. Not something I would recommend for any game. Choosing between trying to maximize a runs potential or unlock new stuff for other runs is never a fun decision and dying with a lot of cash on hand feels extra agonazing because of this. From what I saw the upgrades themselves also didnt seem all that impactfull.

Rougelite Hotline Miami with some small yet smart changes from the admittedly very easy comparison.
 
When only a few enemies remain, they are highlighted in the room to make finding the last stragglers far easier, making the search for those few guys you missed a lot less painful. 

All of the guns (I've seen so far) can be reloaded, allowing you to hold on to a favorite gun a bit longer at the cost of slowing your momentum by having to wait for the reload animation.

The dodge roll can be used to traverse small pieces of furniture, making awkward room structure less of a hassle to traverse while allowing you to still avoid damage.

You have a health bar, but the game feels like it's balanced around it accordingly. Enemies are more alert and can also take more than one shot before dying.

If you're a HM purist then this all probably sounds like blasphemy, but for everyone else this is loads of fun. Oh, and the soundtrack absolutely slaps.

I love Amid Evil and have played thru it a few times so i was excited for this. I immediately found EVIL difficulty and made my way thru the first 2 levels. Its everything i was hoping for. No issues with motion sickness with this game even with a ton of jumping around and smooth turn turned up high. Amazing job with this version of the game, its a ton of fun.

Dave personally asked me to post a review so even though I never do that I will here.

If you've played Amid Evil you'll feel right at home here - it's not an FPS awkwardly ported into VR. Each weapon has its own level of interactivity and immersion and no cuts were made to the level design in the transition. Every secret and room is presented in full. That being said, this is quite literally just Amid Evil, but in VR. There's no new levels or doohickeys exclusive to this version, which you can take either positively or negatively.

My only nitpick with the game right now is there is not an option to disable the underwater filter that overlays the screen. I'm not super prone to VR sickness, however I found myself wanting to stay out of the water as long as possible because it was pretty nauseating for me.

Overall though I'm super satisfied with this version of Amid Evil so far; congrats to Dave and Indefatigable on the successful launch!

This is fantastic! A port so well made you could be fooled into thinking it started as a vr title.

Amid Evil is a doom-like old school shooter with fast paced movement, lots of guns and a ton of secrets.
It has everything you could expect from a vr title in terms of settings (smooth/teleport movement, smooth/snap turning, standing/seated mode).

The only small nitpick i have is that the aiming crosshair for the green blade is too high for where my eyes are looking, if i could adjust the height of it in the settings, that would be fantastic.

The Endless wave mode from the flat version looks to be coming soon in a future update aswell! 

Highly recommend!

What did you expect? It's Amid Evil, but in VR. Which means, it's still awesome with a bit of extra immersion. Would highly recommend!

PS. Tell your friends. Tell your friend's friends. If this game does well, there's a good chance NB may deem it worthwhile to go through the trouble of making VR ports of their other games. I'm not sure the human brain could survive Ultrakill VR, but Dusk VR would be really sweet!

I do worry about the potential for monetization, as others have said, but I want to focus this review on the other aspects of the game for those who want to know about the gameplay itself.

I'm not the biggest racing or cart racer fan, but I've played a good amount of Mario Kart in my time, as well as some Kart Rider Drift and others. And, all of that in mind, I genuinely think Disney Speedstorm might actually be my favorite of them (monetization not withstanding.) 

The tracks are all beautiful and detailed, taking you through a number of worlds and scenes from various Disney movies and parks, all with plenty of shortcut, alternate routes, mirror courses, alternate starts, and more - plenty to keep it fresh and develop your own way through a course, plan tactically, and speed past opponents.

The characters are tons of fun, at least if you're a Disney fan. Many of them use classic lines from their respective movies, but but with a racing twist. And there's Figment representation! Disney parks fans rejoice.

The best part of all, so far, is the music. Each course has a number of different remixed tunes to go along with it - Make a Man Out Of You for the Mulan one, some of the Muses' gospel-sounding tracks for Hercules, etc. And these go harder than they have any right to. Absolute jams that will tickle your nostalgia while also putting you in the racing mood.

There's a couple different online race modes, as well as a ton of "story quests" that take the form of various challenge races - standard races, time trials, elimination modes, ones where you need to play as a certain character, ones with missions to perform x amount of stuns or use a number of items, etc. There's a lot of variety, and they seem like a great way to learn the mechanics, as well as start unlocking some characters and leveling them up!

All of the above makes this, for me, probably the best cart racer on PC, and a definite favorite overall personally.

Going into some of the progression mechanics - I'm 50/50 on them. First, there's the issue of monetization. Everything here is setup to support battlepasses for years to come which, on its own, isn't the worst thing... But there's also loot boxes (currently only purchasable with battle pass and other in-game currencies) and gacha shards to collect. For that reason, I am worried as others are.

That being said, if there wasn't monetizaiton to all of this (or if the monetization could stay purely cosmetic) I personally find the progression and gameplay loop appealing. I'm goal oriented, I like seeing numbers go up, so acquiring unlocks and things to fine tune stats and unlock new skills would be a nice mechanic if it wasn't a red flag here. At the same time, I can see why this might be a turn off for some folks who just want a "pure" cart racing experience, but there's plenty of room for private lobbies and alternate game modes (the former seems to already exist) that I hope the devs can consider in the future!

The one saving grace for now is that there doesn't appear to be any option to spend money beyond buying the game itself (or a Founder's Pack,) or a battle pass, meaning the only P2W present is a few exclusive skins for the early access packs and a bit of quicker progression for those with the premium battlepass unlocked. On top of that, in addition to your standard daily and weekly rotation of battle pass challenges to complete for progress, there seems to be a system in place for a seasonal story mode with challenges similar to the base game's story quest with tons and tons of time trials and objectives to complete to earn experience on the pass even as a solo player, or someone still learning and gearing up. 

Overall, I definitely do recommend the game. It's great fun, and the core game is clearly made with passion for the movies and characters with many levels of detail and effort put in that it doesn't feel like *just* a cash grab. I just hope that the monetization stays tame enough to keep people engaged and not scared away by credit card swipers.

The original Desktop Dungeons was one of my all time favorite quasi-roguelikes. The art, the humor, the surprising amount of depth really made it my go-to solution for coffee break games for a long time. DD had a slight problem, though, one that I think long time players were not impacted greatly by but was certainly preventing the game from drawing in new players or offering the devs much breathing room for future work on a wonderful game: the UI, as gorgeous as it was, was pretty limiting and showing its age pretty severely. 

Rewind at first seems like all it does is bring the original DD forward in terms of presentation -- a fresh new visual look with art just as charming as the original, maps that actually fit most monitors these days, new writing, and an admittedly (currently, as of the week of its release) somewhat divisive new UI that ultimately allows for more flexibility in builds and I imagine future development -- but look a little deeper and you'll find that they've also made some changes to some classes and kin to help bring less-used combinations into the spotlight as well as the new Rewind mechanic allowing you a chance to save an otherwise botched run with ~neat time travel animations~ 

It really feels like more than a fresh coat of paint, it feels like DD for the modern era and I hope it draws in new people and leads to even more stuff for a game I honestly never imagined would be given this kind of chance. 

If you've never played DD before, absolutely give it a chance, you'll love it. It's a bit like a roguelike and it's a bit like a puzzle game. It's got permadeath, but it's really quick and death isn't very painful. There are permanent upgrades to your kingdom in between runs which include things like new kin and classes to play as as well as new items and other goodies to bring into runs with you. Individual runs all take place on a single dungeon level of your choosing prior to departure where you'll start at level 1 and climb as high as level 10 or so by strategically taking down enemies and being clever. Enemies, in contrast with most other roguelikes or roguelites, do not move around or follow you. They exist only on the tile you discover them on, so you get FULL control over how you interact with them but that means you have to really think about how you go about fighting them so that you can best leverage your abilities to gain the most experience and waste the fewest amount of resources to eventually take on the level boss. 

In addition to a whole bunch of kin and classes to choose from, there are a ton of items you'll progressively unlock and see showing up in your dungeons as well as a pantheon of gods a la Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup who really make runs go in wild directions sometimes. 

Overall, tldr: Get this wonderful game and change your LIFE (as far as your coffee/smoke/siesta breaks are concerned)

To 100% the game requires roughly 15 hours, which is far less than I expected for a 40$ game. HOWEVER, I am a sucker for lore and they did deliver on that front, reaching a (personally speaking) satisfying conclusion/milestone for the Demacian civil war. Numerous texts in the game reference other entities in the league of legends universe such as evelynn and fiddlesticks. I thoroughly enjoyed it despite the ending requiring some imagination to tie it into the other Universe stories.

The combat is somewhat clunky save for a few specific movesets which can be animation-cancelled, resulting in me defaulting to only two combos outside of spell usage. The Kingslayer difficulty is designed so that you will be punished heavily if you attack recklessly. As a result, mana generation from basic attacks is low and this, in combination with low max mana capacity, discourages usage of non-copied spell except the two which provide shielding and healing. Most of your variety in spell usage will come from stealing enemy spells. Certain side quests introduce rogue-like elements that are not carried over to other missions. This gameplay system was fun but also felt bad afterwards as there is a significant difference in power between main quest Sylas and side quest Sylas. I wish the game fully embraced the rogue-like system for every single mission (with respective balancing of course as there are some perks that are absurdly broken resulting in you one or two-shotting regular mobs.)

I encountered roughly 6 bugs throughout the entire games, most of which are minor, one of which bugged a boss fight for me, forcing me to restart the fight. 

Overall, it's clear there is a lot of love from the devs put into this game. An upvote from me.

Fun game so far. Plays kind of like a Vampire Survivor style of game where it auto attacks but in this you can manually aim attacks as well. The title is more on the arcade style of gameplay. Has a few different scenarios you can play through and several selectable characters with different starting weapons and special attacks.

Pros:
- Has 20 minute gameplay loops so can play in small burst
- Stages have missions/quests you can take on which sometimes add to the lore of the scenario or have some funny or weird things that happen. Fun way to break up the gameplay.
- All characters seem to have different specials I am still experimenting with.
- The art style is neat and every scenario feels like a call back to some 70/80‚Äôs horror movie.
- Co-op is rad.

Cons:
- Found some parts of the game confusing or not explained too well.
  - Didn‚Äôt realize for a couple of playthroughs that the hand looking icons on the upgrades are tied to how many things you 
    can hold. You can only hold up to 8 arm logos things and some items take one arm while others take 2
  - The coins you collect while playing are for an upgrade shop on the main menu
- The boundary of the stages is represented by mist but the player can take damage if they get to a certain point near the colored barrier and not in it. This was confusing the first couple of times I died near the edge of a map but didn‚Äôt touch the colored area.
- Explosions pulse the screen with a red effect that looks like you got hurt even if you haven‚Äôt got hurt.

Some stuff I think would be cool in future updates:
- Would be cool to have a mode that chains the scenarios together since they seem like they may be linked to each other story wise.
- Might be a bug but doesn‚Äôt seem to save options settings. I personally like turning off the CRT filter, in my opinion makes the game look much better.
- Seems odd these days to not have Steam cards or Achievements. Not a deal breaker for me but I feel like others would want this. 


Will try to update as I play more and see more of the game.

I love this game! I had no idea that I'd be playing the full version for 10 hours as soon as I installed it. I bought Raft a few months ago, wanting it to be more like this without even knowing about Havendock at the time. No zombies, battles, military shooting, child wizards, or aliens. So rare, yet so awesome when found.
The ways I can customize the game to my liking are awesome. I like to focus on the mechanics of a new game with as little distractions as possible, so being able to turn off things like weather, death, and disasters was a very welcome feature. I'm able to progress through the game at my own pace and focusing on different parts of the game in the order I choose. 
Judging from the research tree and workshop items not yet built, I could have everything unlocked (researched) and built in another 3/4 hours if not rushing.
I would highly recommend this game! 8/10

Stray Blade feels like an homage to older adventure games with a souls-lite combat system and I really enjoy it. The combat does have a slight learning curve but once you get into it everything flows very smoothly. The visuals and worldbuilding are beautiful, especially coupled with the dynamic environments. Definitely worth the price if you miss old adventure games, but want a little bit more of a challenge.

Faulty re-location rules, e.g. when three full cavalry platoons are facing only one (1) T-64 with back from friendly tank platoons, the only reasonable choice is to remain in the dig-in and destroy the only tank instead of turning around and withdraw and hence ruin the entire battle plan.

Excellent work and looking forward to more RAT GAME!

Very badly optimised. 5800X + 3070 gets about 5 FPS in the opening tutorial section. I heard that you should be able to change the settings down so its playable once you make it past the tutorial. The problem is that the FPS is so low that the physics breaks so you will never be able to get past the tutorial. 

I went to the INI files and edited the settings just to be able to play the game, then I noticed that the in-game settings can only be changed by notching it up one step at a time. So when you click on it for the first time and it resets the quality to epic, congrats! your game just froze.

I am the boomiest of boomers and I grew up on the shootiest of shooters, and this brilliant boomer shooter blew off my damn bloomers.

You really NEED a controller for this, and mine was registering left and right as up and down and it just wasn't gonna cut it for what this is. It's a precise platformer and it really needs a a more precise control scheme.

Definitely the best of the "100 hidden" series thus far, with this game being in 3D: In addition to moving up and down like in the previous games, you can also rotate sideways around the tower like level! It really turned this into a brand new and much improved experience!

Another great addition was the three "fetch quests", where you first locate one NPC, and then find ten of the object they show you. Getting all ten and returning to the NPC gives you a key that you can use to open one of three chests, each with a frog inside.

My only critique is that the game is very poorly optimized, so if you've got a lower end system, it's gonna get laggy! My computer can run stuff like the Resident Evil 2 remake without any trouble, but not this. I really hope the developer fixes this in a future update, as I do imagine a lot of people playing these types of games probably aren't running on high end gaming computers.

In any case, I'd love to see more games in the "100 hidden" series in this style!

100% in 60 laggy minutes. :P
Amazing game, beautiful depictions of frogs, and stunning scenery.

Like all the other '100 hidden nouns' games, this one was a cute little game finding a bunch of frog tucked away and peeking around all sorts of corners and shapes. The idea of rotating the 3D image is a great one, though it is not indicated in the game anywhere, so I had to learn about that through watching a gameplay trailer on the store page. Much like all the others of this series, there is no real UI beyond 'number of [noun] left' and a Start/Exit menu. There is also a considerable performance issue as it is incredibly slow and a bit choppy, and when I get the the lowest area, the game told me my video memory was exhausted, and to expect poor performance, which it did indeed get worse. However, the game is also $2, so it's not a huge deal to me how the performance is with how cheap it is. Altogether, another solid addition to the '100 hidden nouns' series.

Leaving this here for now as a like, but want potential buyers to know a couple of the drawbacks as of EA.

There is no controller support (I'm not sure why it says partial in the description, but KB+M is the only option in game). This game will be MUCH better with controller support, playing it KBM with WASD and I,H,J,K,L feels very unnatural and I do not like it.

1440p is currently the maximum resolution. As someone who exclusively plays on a 4K OLED, I do not like looking at the lower resolution.

The English VA is obviously done by Chinese VA speaking English, and the translations are pretty poor for the time being. I'd gladly volunteer myself for some male VA as I feel I could do a better job (not trying to be rude). 

All that being said, this game is very fun and has a unique aesthetic and some new ideas in the roguelite genre. I think it has a lot of potential, but I'm hesitant with a small Chinese developer in terms of how long it will take to get much needed QOL from what I have mentioned above, and what responses will be like.

Never have I bought a game not even 10 minutes after it was up available for purchase. This game is just aesthetically pleasing in so many ways. The characters. Illustrations. Menu. Upgrades. Skills. Loading screen. Everything. One thing off is that Lilya has two different colored eyes but her model are both one color so that could use a fix.

Lets talk about the game.
It is fully voiced though I'm sure they are just chinese native speakers that know English so it can be a little broken or certain words are pronounce how you look at them such as Mecha being pronounced as Meh cha instead of Meh ka. Some subtitles don't match what they say but it still means the same just used a synonym. During story character models actually move and make face expressions though they're chibi models but cute.
Combat goes from Basic attack combos that can be aimed up but dont change too much. You can down smash. Use skill but there are 4 visible beats and if you do it on the 4th beat the skill will be a much powerful one compared to beat 1, 2 and 3. You can perfect dodge turning it to an attack that telegraphs you right towards the enemy. Another skill lets you attack as you dodge until the meter empties out. Then you have an Ult that has multiple button pressing sequences.
Upgrades. Every now and then you'll get an upgrade. Like hades style. Basic attack will be Lightning, Fire poison etc. Or skills. Whatever you choose BUT if you get two different upgrades on the same attack for instance. Fire/poison on down smash you get BOTH so down smashes will do poison AND fire as long as you picked it both up. I haven't tried more since I haven't played enough. There's more different ways to upgrade yourself which I won't go too much detail into since I haven't gotten a grasp of it yet in memory.
Upon completion of rooms and runs you'll get a type of currency or item that lets you unlock outfits or recolors of your characters that you choose as long as you have the respective amount which I really like and hoping for actual different outfits instead of just different colors. There isn't really any interactions with the environment just killing mobs for now completing rooms and picking rooms. Healing isn't too rare to get so that's good and it isn't too tough only when you get greedy is when you find yourself getting hit a lot. Beautiful game. Love the music and the characters.
Thats all I really have to say. I really enjoy this a lot and it's worth a try for it's price.
Game is very cute and fun so far.

Riot Forge does not miss. From the story, through the music, the characters, to the gameplay, it was straight 10/10. I would recommend that, and many other of their games to anyone, League Fans or not. it might not be long, but damn is it satisfying. It builds the world in a great way for people who doesn't know any backstory of Demacia or Valoran in general, and yet still leaves a lot of teases for older fans. The characters are memorable and to some may be relatable, the score is my new go to ost, and the quite unpopular spell-thief hack and slash gameplay is a cherry on top. Hats off to the dev team, did not expect to have so much fun in such a short time.

[h1] Decent and enjoyable Disney themed kart racing game. [/h1]

Disney Speedstorm is a decent kart racing arcade genre that seems to have taken some ideas involving Mario Kart and turning it into its own theme. I was looking forward to the early access release when it was first announced a few months ago. The characters and the animations for each are well-done and each seem to have their own distinct personality while your racing or selecting them in the main menu. I especially love and adore Donald Duck. 

Unlocking parts and suits and paint jobs and customizing your kart is not that difficult but everything I feel is limited and bare in this area right now. The tracks are also wonderfully done and each has its own theme song from the various Disney films that I and most people probably know and used to watch. However, while there are only 8 tracks so far and its limited here as well, more and more additions and features I‚Äôm sure will be coming. The chapters/stories are good as well, there‚Äôs just some levels like the elimination races that are quite challenging. The AI/computer racers are programmed well to be challenging enough even on medium settings where I have it at.

As far as pay-to-play is concerned like some reviews mentioned, I really have not had that much of an issue with that. It is a bit annoying though how the game tries to force you to do this and that in order to move on, but in my perspective it‚Äôs not all that bad. Cross-platform is also a nice feature as well so if I play this on another platform it will smoothly sync between both platforms. I have tested this already and it works well. Overall, if you enjoy Disney films and the iconic characters or like and want something a bit different than Mario Kart, I recommend giving it a chance and picking this up. I do really enjoy it thus far.

This game is pretty great! The art is different and stands out. The game play is pretty damn smooth and feels good. If you're looking for a different take on somewhat souls-like combat mechanics with a twist and an absolutely lovely story-line, Stray Blade is definitely a damn good place to get it. 
Yes, my copy was provided for me, but that holds no power over this review or my feelings of the game. I genuinely enjoyed myself 95% of the time. I am very excited for this full release and fully intend to go through the game again as a completed title. It's just that good!!

After playing so many Team Beef ports, I am unequivocally ready for Amid Evil in VR. This game has a great aesthetic and gameplay loop. Motion controls are simple but well integrated. The speed is not for newcomers, but after years of playing in VR, it is exactly my pace. 

A definite recommend. I hope we get other New Blood titles with the same treatment.

A few notes, text on walls needs to appear sooner for ease of reading - the menu also needs to be easier to access from in-game. Those are my only gripes. I'd like to see eye-tracking as a future update on the one weapon with look-aim.

[h1]Experienced on the Meta Quest 2[/h1]

You can view my initial impressions review & gameplay here: https://youtu.be/zHhWTHce44w

I do recommend this game. It's pretty much a 1:1 translation of the original non-VR version. What's new is obviously they added 3D visuals to go along with motion controller support. Everything you would pretty much expect is here. Caution however: I did come across a bug where my weapon didn't show up or I could no longer select a weapon. However, the bug was only for a few seconds and did not otherwise effect gameplay.

As far as the visuals, I think they look cool in VR, but I'm not sure this type of art-style really pops in VR. Also, because you're using motion controllers for aiming, the aiming is much easier than the pancake version where you're using KBM. Therefore, I do think the VR version is easier than the non-VR version. However, the good news is that the game has not been nerfed at all for the VR experience. It is all here just like pancake, although some of the levels will come later.

Game is running on the Unreal Engine. On my RTX 3080, on mostly high graphical settings, I was getting mostly 90 fps, with some frame rate drops here and there, usually at the start of levels. You do have full locomotion available, along with smooth or snap turning. You have button crouch or button jump as well. You can play comfortably seated.

Because I already owned Amid Evil, I got a very generous loyalty discount. Thank you devs for that! Make this game quite a deal. I hope more boomer shooters come to VR, especially Dusk!

9/10, great Game.

Pros:
+Really Really Good story based on Oppression and Revolution.
+Fantastic Gameplay, the Spell thief aspect is wonderfully executed and crafted
+Wonderful Pixel Art, most likely one of the best currently on the Market. 
+Very Interesting Setting, Same with their Previous Game(Riot Forge) named Ruined King, the World of Runeterra really intrigues.
+Gorgeous Animations
+Great Soundtrack

Cons:
-Day 1 DLC, Really shouldn't be here, it really feels like what was put in the DLC and Pre-Order Bonus should just be in the base Game.
-Short. The game takes around 15-20 Hours to beat with Side Content. If this is short for you for the 30 Buck Price Point, then I would wait until it gets on Sale.
-Slow Beginning, It takes around an Hour of Game Progression for the Game to open up to a level that feels like you are not still in the Tutorial.
-Minor Bugs. Should be patched out soon, and they are thankfully not gamebreaking

Overall, I loved the game, if you are interested in the Lore of League of Legends/Arcane/Runeterra. Then this is def a must, otherwise, if you just want a good action game with a good story attached, this will also fulfill that itch.
very unique game, worth trying

Minecraft Legends isn't the best game in existence, but despite the current reviews I would never consider it bad by any means as many people want you to believe. It certainly is a bit janky at times, feels ever-so-slightly underpolished, and will definitely kick you to the curb and spit in your face a few times, but there is an incredible amount of quality put into this game. The dynamic between slapping down structures on the fly as you breach into an enemy fortress, collecting resources and special units to temporarily aid you in battles, and summoning infinite amounts of general units to feed the engine of war as you try to order the clusterfuck of different units in the right direction is incredibly fun. 

Each unit has a clear cut purpose for destroying structures, dealing damage from afar or up close, stunning enemies, and healing allies. Different structures have to be used very accordingly to hold the line against the opposition and continue pushing through their defenses. There was clearly lots of thought put into this game, and if it truly were badly designed the reviews would be alot more negative. Its a delicate balance the developers have sewn together. Confusing and janky as it may be, it is a very interesting and fun game that I'd definitely recommend [i]...maybe not at the current price though,[/i] it doesn't have THAT much going for it to justify a $40 price tag. Wait for a sale.

Also I'd like to add that typically I'll play a game to general completion or when I've seen most of the game before reviewing it, but the amount of people reviewing this game that have brains that classify as cantaloupes rather than organs is insane. I cannot comprehend how idiotic someone has to be to think [b]THE FIRST TWO HOURS OF THE GAME THAT TEACH YOU THE BASICS AND ONLY BARELY INTRODUCE NEW UNITS IS THE ENTIRE CAMPAIGN.[/b] God, this platform is just pathetic sometimes. The negative reviews for this game are absolutely retarded.
Game is alright but definitely is too expensive, more worthwhile buying gamepass or waiting for an eventual sale.

Received the game for free as part of a launch day livestream event - you can see my name (as well as the names of my friends from C.H.A.O.S.) in the credits stage.

That being said, I highly recommend this little indie game if you're looking for a friendly challenge with your friends on the game's Global Steam Leaderboard - it can easily get really addicting to "just do 10 more levels" to catch up with your friends, and before you know it you're in the triple digits.

Just be careful when playing on mouse and keyboard - hitting Escape closes the game instantly!

A cute little roguelite platformer about a quest to recover a lost hat. You build up a base to do things like heal your crew and convert captures to your crew, with a pretty standard roguelite like research system to start accruing those permanent upgrades. A nice assortment of hats and weapons, all with various effects to discover and collect multiple copies of that you'll need for research. Some of the traits a person can get can be frustrating especially when stacked together and leveling up only has a chance to remove a bad trait (though maybe research can help with this regard). Had a few times where I've died and wasn't really sure why, and weapons have very low durability, so if you have someone who can't snap necks or knock people out by landing on them and burn very fast through the durability/ammo you bring with you, it can be quite difficult to go forward. All in all though I'm enjoying the game so far! I would like to try co-op with a friend sometime. :)

If you like VR and Amid Evil it's a no brainer.  I'm so glad they made this version...Now let's all hope for Dusk next?!

Biggest Take Away/Final Thoughts:

At first I thought this game was going to be one of those games that I would deem "The Jump-scare Simulator" examples: Emily Wants to Play, FNAF, Hello Neighbor,etc... I totally think there is a place for these type of games. But After fully completing the game I walked away with an experience akin to The Evil Within, Resident Evil, Silent Hill etc... Not saying that the quality is the same, but devs made a solid attempt at building this world where it's only a PC and floppy disc away. I say "attempt", but honestly I really liked the world creating I thought it was creepy, interesting, fun and most important surprising. Surprising in the sense that this game kinda subverts you into thinking you are going to get one experience, but instead getting in my opinion a more well rounded experience that was a joy to explore, to get the collectibles and hear the experiences of the ones that came before.

The combat is fun but not a fan of the game mode.
What I mean is that we need to find the enenry sources... but the map is quite big.
And the problem with survivor type games is that you are in a race against time to level up faster that enemies can scale, and if we are constantly on the move, that means we are not either not killing enough enemies or not picking up the exp orbs. Either way, it means we are losing on levels while we look for the energy sources.
There are several ways to fix this: 
1. Just give us the exp for killing the enemies without needing to pick them up. We don't have to pick them up, there's no rule saying that ALL VS clone games have to have pick up exp.
2. Show us the map so we can move to the objectives as fast as possible. But even with this method we are still losing out on the level gains, but it makes the problem a bit more tolerable.
3. Slow down the enemy scaling or spawn rate, or both. In that case we have more time to search.

Anyway, if you ONLY care about combat, this game is good. But if you care about beating levels... I personally can't enjoy this.
Nailed the game play but gacha-like progression might become a problem. Otherwise, amazing soundtrack and great map design.

A compelling story with deep game play and so many different combos, although the game doesn't have enough content to justify $30 unless you're really into the story. If you're into the story for this game it's worth the price, although if you're going to skip past all the cut scenes and are looking purely for game play the game is too short for the current price point in my opinion. It took me only 20 hours to 100% complete the game including all side missions. I highly recommend playing on the highest difficulty gives the game a souls like feel and made boss fights exhilarating. Secondary missions are also not that important, there is a cool story line for one of them where you get to fight a league champion which you would have missed if you only did the main quests. Secondary missions are primarily just for money so you can get upgrades although they are fun, they give a rogue-like feel since during some of the secondary missions you can choose between different spells which give you unique buffs. Overall great story, great gameplay, gorgeous artwork, short campaign, little replayability. 8.5/10

Blood Moon is a lovely story about protecting the family who chose you, when everything goes bottoms-up. The writing is fun, relatable, and punchy, and the characters feel like they have life to them. There are many outcomes to the challenges you face, and replayability is high. Each love interest is very different to the others, and each possesses their own kind of sweet and spice. If you want a story about werewolves on the wolfier side, who are messy and loud and fiercely loyal and protective, this one's for you. Also, this is one of the few Interactive Fiction stories with older!Love Interests, which I personally adore (more than a little fond of Sergi myself tbh). Some good 'n' dirty fight-to-protect-your-family wholesomeness, I love it.

Getting the comparison out of the way, I've held Hotline Miami (and Wrong Number) as some of my favorite indie games of all time for years. Naturally, with the retro-pixel top view gun-switching ultraviolent fast paced shooter action going here, this game had enormous shoes to fill. So my first few runs made me think "this is just fresh enough. Some good ideas, nice visuals... Yeah, this is good".

And then I got into a boss battle with a giant mecha snake with machineguns. In my 4th run. And that was awesome. "Hotline Miami, this is not".

So yeah, for anyone like me that might have been worried that this is "just bringing some decade old game with more modern considerations", I'm pleased to see that it differentiates itself positively and extremely early. With "bullet time" to slow down the massive amount of bullets on the screen, a fresh variety of enemies and bosses early on, and a generous healthbar that will likely deplete after strings of poor decisions and bad planning, each floor has a lot of adrenaline that doesn't reward "trial and error", but instead, planning how to approach each room.

Yeah, planning is rewarded... but so is keeping a high combo multiplier to get more money to make your run better. So there's a lot of high-risk high-reward decisions at every moment. Play too safe and you won't be able to afford upgrades, yet play too reckless and you'll end up surrounded with no "bullet time" to even the odds.

It's very good action, extremely fast paced, and while it can feel a bit clunky early on due to the unusual controls, waltzing in and painting this black and white mansion red is very gratifying.

So yeah, recommended if you like fast paced action, punishing but fair gameplay, are okay with its violent themes, and if you like roguelikes in general.

It is a great honor to participate in the beta-test of Flashpoint campaigns Southern Storm. I have been played the previous title  "Flashpoint Campaigns: Red Storm" since 2014. I was deeply impressed by the game's unique asymmetric turn-based system and command-oriented mechanism. I also made some battle reports and materials about the game in Chinese community.
I started relearning the game about two years ago when I got the beta test for the Flashpoint campaigns Southern Storm. Compared with the previous game, Southern Storm has made many changes in the game mechanism, such as the introduction of standard combat procedures (SOPs), which enriches the details of combat operations and allows players to intervene in combat from more dimensions. In addition, the UI and art of the game has also made great changes, the interface information is detailed and beautiful, and the readability and visibility are very good.
The game supports the PBEM+ system, and players can play against each other. During the test, I also learned a lot about the organization and command of modern warfare from other friends with professional experience, which changed my understanding of modern warfare.
Whether you are a tabletop wargame player or have played other types of digital wargames, Southern Storm is worth a try.
more like aMID evil!!!!!!

Initially, I wrote a very detailed and lengthy review, but then I freaking lost it. So here's the basic gist of it. The game is fun, engaging, and worth whatever you pay. It reminds me of Quake, but despite that, I find the gameplay unique. It's nothing as I've ever played before, and I bet it'll be like that for you too. I haven't played enough of the game's original version to make a direct comparison, but I can talk about the mechanics featured within the VR version. Your non-dominant hand has your health, ammo, and souls featured on it, and your dominant hand holds the weapon of your choice. By clicking the grab button, you can switch out which hand is dominant. You can hold weapons with two hands, but not like you're used to doing in VR. Instead of grabbing the weapon with both hands, you simply move your non-dominant hand to the weapon, and the game grabs it for you. You can throw your weapons by holding the trigger and grab buttons and making a throwing motion, you can do this with every weapon, but the only effective one is the axe. To get your weapon back, you need to click the trigger or grab button, and it teleports to your hand instantly. I like how soul mode is activated in this version, instead of the click of a button. All you have to do is raise your non-dominant hand over your head, which is very easy and quick to do and hard to accidentally do since you don't really need to move your non-dominant hand outside of looking at it to see your health, ammo, and souls. Soul mode gives every weapon an alternate fire which is much more powerful and effective. Even though getting the timing right was initially confusing, you can parry red projectiles with the axe, which hits them back to the enemy and immediately kills them. You could also just cancel out the red projectile with the axe at the cost of ammo and not looking as cool. I've only run into one bug so far, and that was my axe turning invisible and not doing damage which forced me to get killed by an enemy so I could load a save which luckily fixed the issue, and it never showed up again. I beat the first episode, and it was great overall. The pacing is pretty good. Unless I haven't run into any hitscanners yet, you can dodge pretty much everything thrown at you. In conclusion, Amid Evil VR is a great game, and everyone should play it.

The game is fantastic. It is heart pumping, visually appealing, and has a killer soundtrack. Oh, and its in VR, what is not to love? I do have to say though, I use virtual desktop with a quest 2 and smooth turning is not working. Snap turning works, but when I enable smooth it just stops reading my joystick all together leaving me to turn my head IRL, which actually made me have MORE fun playing the game due to feeling a bit more immersed as a result. I would still like to have it looked into of course, but other than that and some frame drops here and there at max settings, i have no complaints. Thank you!
A very thoughtful conversion of a great base game to VR. It would be great to see the rest of New Blood's titles make it over as well!

Legit fun and well made game that will be absolutely ruined with micro-transactions unless something changes. 

The menu and the unlock system are that of a Mobile Game where they want you to spend tons of credits to unlocks "shards" to then eventually get enough to upgrade a character. 
Unless you can race lots and race well and get 1st place often, you will never unlock these shards very often.
So you'll be forced to pay for credits to buy shards. If you don't get shards, you'll be under leveled and can not progress.
There are 3 or 4 different types of in game currency that is not only confusing, is not needed.

I can already see how this game is setting itself up for a absolute money grab forcing people into buying shards.

As for the game it self, it runs real well. Looks great. Fun maps. Overall is legit fun and a honestly well made game.

So while its a good game and legit fun to play. WAIT FOR IT TO BE FREE TO TRY IT. Or at a min. only get the base version!

Hi fellow gaming Gents,
We have got good promise of a game, I like it, but it is very unbalanced, RNG  based resource income and few bugs makes playthroughs a chore just even to learn mechanics of the game.

Cute pretty fun game.  More like a 2d beatemup than a platformer from what I've seen so far.

-- some quick notes I wanted to know before buying
Separate text and speech language settings: YES
Separate volume for voices: YES
Controller support: YES (all my playtime is on my standard xbox 360 controller, and I've had zero issues)
Controller button remapping: Mostly (at least one in-combat move seems to be attached to the button you map to interact, and there's no remapping for the menu controls)
English translation: Understandable as far as gameplay but a bit janky.  Some weird language use to get used to, both theme/stylistic and odd word choices.

-- combat
Combat inputs are: jump, dodge, normal attack, special attack (timed cooldown, enhanced on specific music timing), ultimate attack (charged slowly by hits), and trigger temporary power-up mode.  There's also a jump slam attack and teleport-counterattack you get by dodging through an enemy attack (which is pretty strong and generous on timing), and the counterattack and ultimate each trigger a small boost mode which can trigger some special upgrades.  You can duck too, but aside from an upgrade that was triggered by "squatting" I'm not sure if it's relevant.  The cooldown on the special feels overly long given the very few actions at your disposal, especially since you'll often need to wait for the beat if you want the better version (I think it does cooldown on the beat, but you have to be ready to hit it exactly off-cooldown or wait a fullbeat cycle).

So far, the rhythm element seems to be limited to activating your special attack on a specific fixed beat every few seconds (instructions say "on downbeat", but it's more like every fourth downbeat).  Timing is reasonably generous there.  I'd have liked to see a lot more music linkage.

-- characters
You start with the sword girl and have to unlock the other two through "story progress".  I haven't seen the first boss, but I've had several runs and have not unlocked another character yet.

-- upgrades
Uses a Hades-style themed attack upgrade choice (including rarities and bonus rewards for having tried everything in a set, but here you can stack upgrades instead of only having one), select your next stage reward, gifting and keepsakes (seems like keepsakes are empowered by further gifts to that character, not by fighting with them equipped).  Upgrades feel very Hades on a basic level, but there seem to be some nice/cute variations.

There is also a weird run-upgrade grid you slot items into at the shop.  It's 3x3 and random each run.  Slot items come in different shapes to restrict where you can slot them.  Each slot has a bonus (which can easily be useless to you), and each row and column has an additional bonus if you have all three slots filled.

And then you have "drinks" which add some varying upgrade effects, and a larger overarching upgrade that can be a game-changer (one notable one I saw reset the special attack's cooldown as long as you hit the on-beat bonus, which was really nice).

In short, there are a lot of avenues to upgrade during a run.  They're all pretty random.

Metaprogression has three fairly shallow trees.  Unlock nodes to see adjacent nodes, each node has levels it can be upgraded.  Early meta-upgrades look fairly normal, but currency costs seem pretty huge.  There are several meta-currencies to gain and spend.  You look to have up to four keepsake slots, but I've no idea how those are unlocked past the first slot, or whether the keepsakes make for interesting upgrades.

-- level generation and enemies
As far as the first boss's zone, each level seems like a fairly fixed simple platformer style series of rooms, without much of any platforming opportunity, and relatively few enemies arranged in simple groups.  Short series of rooms, take level-end reward, choose next level reward, repeat.  Enemies seem to have very few types and they do only one thing each, so pretty low interest/engagement on the enemy side of the game equation.

There are some kind of trap-based levels, but have not seen one yet to compare its design.

All-in-all, cute game and seems quite polished for what's there.

a wonderful way to expand on demacia's story and the aftermath of the lux comic. 8/10. it took me around 14 hours to complete which might not be worth $30 but i enjoyed it nonetheless.

pros:
- interesting characters/companions that make you care about the rebellion and the cause!
- story is well written - shows that things are more gray than black/white which i was hoping they would, especially in regards to sylas
- beautifully done animations, inside and outside of combat
- progression is pretty neat to experience with the outlaws and the improvements to the camp
- well designed combat/gameplay with the use of sylas's actual kit in league
- a lot of easter eggs to league of legends 

cons:
- no voice acting which would have been a great addition
- the scrollbar on the letters is a bit clunky/awkward
- dashing and fast forwarding are on the same button (spacebar). towards the end of some quests i would dash forward into a cutscene unknowingly and it would start skipping the dialogue insanely fast
- the combat as well as the sidequests do get a bit repetitive
- some of the environments are repetitive as well but i guess demacia's aesthetic just be like that
The advertisements made it out like the single player experience was going to be great, but it's just repetitive and seems mostly designed for PVP and microtransactions

The discord group is helpful and through there I feel like the devs will take notice and work on fixes if you have any issues.  I'd highly recommend, especially if you are able to catch it at the current discounted price.  It is worth every penny.  Also it is not a short game which I'd hate to spend more than $20 on a game I can finish in 5 hours. It is open worldish and I managed to get lost a few times but if you like open world then this game is for you.
