Under all the p2w trash is a fun game at times. This game WILL be ruined by monetization, because you actually get a gameplay benefit from dropping cash on upgrade items and shards. The worst thing is that you can't even finish the Starter Course if you don't buy the more expensive Founder's Pack, because you need the characters that come with those to play those.

The absolute worst thing that's close to ruining the experience for me is the insanely aggressive rubberbanding. It doesn't matter how high your level is, how perfect you race, the AI will catch up until the last few meters of the lap. I've also encountered AI opponents teleporting right next to you before crossing the finish line. I'm not sure if it's relevant, but that only happens to me when I play a race with a racer that has a lower level than the recommended level for that race. It's unfair and needs fixing.

The good: The soundtrack is great, the graphics look quite pleasing, runs fantastic on Deck and, despite the monetization and rubberbanding, it can be fun to play. I'll definitely put some more hours into this, but I sincerely hope they tweak the monetization and rubberbanding before official release. For now, I don't think I can recommend paying for this game.

Micro transaction is absolutely present, I am not sure that is because of the Disney characters? With that in mind, the graphics in Disney Speedstorm are absolutely stunning, with bright, vivid colors and intricate designs that really bring each track to life. The attention to detail is impressive, with everything from the background scenery to the character animations looking top-notch.

Gameplay-wise, Disney Speedstorm is a blast to play. The racing mechanics are intuitive and easy to pick up, but there's enough depth there to keep players engaged over the long term. Each character has their own unique special abilities that can be used strategically to gain an edge on the competition, and the tracks themselves are filled with all sorts of hazards and obstacles that will keep you on your toes.

One of the things I really appreciate about Disney Speedstorm is how accessible it is. While there's definitely a learning curve to mastering the game's more advanced mechanics, it's easy enough for anyone to pick up and start playing right away. Plus, with a variety of different modes to choose from, including single-player races and multiplayer matches, there's always something new to try.

All in all, Disney Speedstorm is a fantastic racing game that's sure to appeal to fans of all ages. Whether you're a die-hard Disney fan or just someone looking for a fun, fast-paced racing experience, this game is definitely worth checking out.

I wish I could give a "meh" instead of a yes or no. A strategy action game without much of either with jank controls to boot. The game seemed to be advertised for a singleplayer or co-op experience but the campaign is very shallow and short, but the PVP is awful and simply just not fun. The PVE can be very fun, hectic and intense, and will be fun for the few hours of playtime it has to offer. It seems like the idea was there but the execution is just not that great. I did greatly enjoy my time with what was on offer but it simply did not feel as a complete experience. Rain Games has Released another gem among their catalog of games.

For those of you playing a Rain game for the 1st time, Don't worry about missing out on lore.  
The game does a fantastic job of guiding you thru the lore even if you haven't played Teslagrad or World to The West via collectibles and on scream prompters.

If you'd REALLY like to know the story, I recommend playing Teslagrad 1 and WttW.  Mesmer as well for the additional world building but it's not essential.

BACK TO THE GAME!

Oh boy! You're in for a puzzle Metroidvania Collectible and it's an electrifying time!  This game takes place Alongside Mesmer, RIGHT after World to the West.
You've crash landed from being pursued and must make your way. TO THE TOWER!!!
You'll puzzle solve, use sweet fluid magnetic controls, platform, have boss fights, EPIC BANGER MUSIC SLAYIN IT, and collectibles with lore pieces scattered thru out the world map. The game doesn't hold your hand BUT, it is VERY intuitive. 

The game clocks at about 3-6 hours depending on how skilled you are at platforming metroidvanias. 
It is an absolute spark of a gem and well worth the 20$ dollars + some if you play the original Teslagrad.

The artwork and 3d models is fantastic, the BGMS slay again, and the.... in game nordic language? all bow wrap this present with a resounding boom and thunderous delivery.

10/10 I hope more people see how wonderful these Game Devs are and give their other games a shot!

the only technical flaw is that the forced vsync of the game doesn't work under linux, i have to use goverlay to force it, on steamdeck you won't have any problem with the fps limiter.

I wish I could give this a neutral rating. It doesn't deserve a negative review, but it's not revolutionary. I played with one other person initially, and after an hour and a half, we had almost collected all 30 PAGES. We unfortunately died around 23, then brought in two more friends. The map is HUGE, and that is it's greatest downfall. I can't imagine trying to complete this solo because of it's size. Also, this does NOT have to be played as a stealth game. You're given a lantern that lets you immobilize enemies and allows you to get away. I cannot imagine sneaking around this map, I spent most of it running around. 

If there's a smaller map that accommodates solos/duos, I'd LOVE this game. I played aggressively so the fear of the monsters wore off quickly. Either decrease the map size or decrease the page amount, because trudging through a large map searching for 30 pages was tedious. Play it with friends and do not take it seriously, maybe you'll enjoy it. PS: Would smash Cthulhu.

On its most basic level, this game is just a really solid 2D side scrolling platformer hack and slash. Moving your character feels great, combat is very reactive, and there are a decent variety to enemies and builds you can get with your roguelite elements. The randomization helps keep things fresh and varied, since you can't just optimize your way to your ultimate builds, at least not right away, and the very act of slaying enemies in the core gameplay loop is very fun and fluid.

Where this game REALLY shines, though, is taking the "multi" in "multimedia experience" VERY seriously.

The art is gorgeous. The electronic music is great. The voice acting, while cringey at times and clearly made by ESL VAs, has heart and the writing is fairly decent if nothing too special. The world feels alive, it's stylish as hell, and though there are some quirky and strange decisions, like random statistics that mean nothing to the player and too much "this is what we call X, but we never explain it", it's still entertaining to me.

This game seems to be something rather special. Hopefully it grows better from here, but so far in EA, I think it's worth the price.

This game is amazing so far after 3 hours of playing.

It's Princess Maker 2 but bigger, better, with more activites, the world feels massive and it seems you have a degree of freedom that all "rise simulators" should aim for.

I remember when I played PM2 that you were kind of "forced" into warrior builds in order to go to the dungeon and it made seeking arts, literature paths boring and empty. This my friends is completely fixed in Volcano Princess.

Seems you can even romance girls and you are not locked into marrying your daugther to male (haven't reached the end game yet of course but the option seems to be there and the girls don't shy away of being "flirtious" with your daugther)

Also, the game has a loit of mini games, you are into dice gambling you have it, you are more into rhetorical debates you got it too, "mini" farming sim... it's there, cooking game... you got it, random "loot" grind... yup you guessed it it's there too.

9/10 If you ever played Princess Maker series or Romanesque Witch or any other "rising sim" it's a MUST BUY. 

The only thing I would like to be changed is that the achievements menu is kind of a HUGE spoiler, I would preffer it to be hidden with " ??????? " naming.

This game is wonderful, just as good as the first one, if not better in terms of writing. Having the foundation of the first game to use as a stepping stone really helped elevate the writing and expansion of returning characters. Here is my review after my first play-through of the game. 

I normally review games looking at both negatives (the bad) and the positives (the goods) and honestly I only have one negative about this game and it has nothing to do with game play. It is the title.

I have seen many wonder if this is a dlc to the first game rather than a stand alone game due to how they titled it. The "episode 2" part needs to go. Just Coffee Talk 2: Hibiscus & Butterfly" would have been better. The episode part just throws people off. 

And on the other end there's really so much positive to say about the game. The writing in this one is outstanding. The artwork, even though in the style of the first, looks just as wonderful if not better too! I love making drinks and guessing the drink combo's that the character orders. Also like the first game you input your name at the start of the game and the characters throughout the game refer to you by your name. A nice little touch to keep you immersed. You never see yourself in the game, it is always from your perspective. However this game had a few comments about our character that made it very interesting about who WE are. 

In the second game you can influence the story more than the first game. By doing certain actions, like getting their drinks wrong or right, or forgetting to give them certain items,  you will have some different outcomes in how the story progresses for good or bad for some of the characters. You may even stop seeing customers if you mess up their drinks too often! Or if you give them the right drink or the right item you will see extra story content for some of the customers.  

I had no crashes and the game supports widescreen. All you really need is your mouse to play. There is some light comedy, some heartfelt moments and some serious undertones to some of the characters' stories. A great game told through the stories of your customers as you, the ever present, caring barista listens on. 

A hug of appreciation for Mohammad Fahmi (may he rest in peace) and his entire team for forging ahead to bring the world of Coffee Talk to the fans again. It was well worth the wait and I think he would be so proud of the final game and the entire team.  I recommend both games, and honestly encourage everyone to start with playing the first one. For those who are returning to the world of Coffee Talk, enjoy your adventure! ‚òï

"Wild Dogs" is a cool retro styled platformer in the vein of the classic Contra games. 
 
The game follows the typical run-and-gun platformer format, but occasionally the game-play changes into a fixed-screen shooter or precision platformer.

Expect hordes of alien and robotic enemies and lots of mini-bosses (I'm currently in the middle of stage 2 and I've already encountered 6). 

The game's difficulty is on the higher side, so you'll likely need to replay each level a few times to practice and get the hang of things. 

Visually, this game features lovely monochrome pixel art, with color palettes that are reminiscent of the classic Gameboy. The tilesets and character sprites are beautiful and add to the overall nostalgic feel of the game.

If you enjoy a challenge or have fond memories of classics like Contra, then you'll definitely enjoy "Wild Dogs"!

If you sat Tarantino and Lovecraft in a room and said "I need a game idea or else I'll delimb you." This might be what they came up with. 

The Good: 
 Grimy but well designed graphics.
 Bizarre quests (Yes, there are quests and interactions in a autosurvivor game.)
 The music and sounds are well put together for the genre.
 You can change from auto fire/aim to manual fire/aim  for a more direct approach on larger enemies.

The Bad:
 Limited weapon selection as of writing this.
 Some of the weapons feel rather useless until they are almost fully upgraded.
 
The Ugly:
 As of writing this, there are a few progression breaking bugs around menuing and interacting.

Summary. Altogether for the price this is an interesting take on a fairly new genre, and a love letter to the grindhouse horror scene.

I'm not gonna lie - I'm pretty impressed. I wasn't expecting to be, since I generally do not enjoy 'Idle' games.  The developer of the original 'Factory Town' game (a VERY casual but enjoyable 3D city builder) has taken his game, and distilled many of the great aspects of the core game loop down to the most essential elements - which also removes the 3D building aspect - leaving only the 'town management' aspect of the game remaining.

A town management simulator. It's enjoyable. It's minimalist. It hits all the right areas of the brain while playing, like a good 'Skinner Box' type game should. And since it's an 'Idle' game, you can play for awhile, log off to go have a life, then come back to additional progress that has been made while you were away.

Thankfully, the Dev does not (nor will he ever) use/abuse those mechanics to force players into micro-transactions like many other games do.  You get the whole game, immediately, with nothing else to purchase, ever.  A good game from a good Dev, with a good track record of quality and attention to the development process.

It's graphically charming the game functions for the most part, but it feels very hollow. 

It feels like an RTS in name only. The outposts you build are usually just going to be for fast travel purposes. The villages already make resources for you. Due to how enemy mobilizes (or rather, how they don't mobilize) their armies in this game, you don't have to really think about building outposts to hold off the enemy from occupying a space or to cut them off from resources. Besides the attack and occasional new base every night, the piglin army are just sitting there waiting for you.

In terms of action and combat tactics the game also feels very limited. Defensively, the upgrades you can get to your building feel like they're just an afterthought when just spamming walls and arrow towers already suffices. Offensively, it's just a cycle of leading a bunch of stone golems to rush a few buildings in the enemy base, retreating to make more, and then bringing out your creepers to nuke the nether portal when the enemy's defenses are down. 

Where I think the game could've salvaged itself was to have a lot of interesting side content in the world and a good campaign. Sadly, I found that the game failed on both these fronts too. Besides some admittedly helpful mounts, you just find some resources laying around + some golems and towers that I really never got much use out of. The story feels like it's aimed strictly at an extremely young audience. Nearly all the cutscenes featuring the horde being the exact same joke of a commander Piglin bullying the smaller ones. Your allies has scripts written on wooden that hasn't been turned to paper yet, with only one of them even attempting to say even slightly amusing things and still fumbling at that.

Honestly, for being an indie fighting game, what this game manages to achieve is MORE than impressive. While issues I'll get into later have kept me from experiencing all it has to offer, I can say that from the perspective of a fighting game fan I was very surprised by how much care went into it. 

First off, the roster. There are seven characters, which is a really big roster for an indie fighter. The best indie fighting game, them's fighting herds, only launched with six. I was also really happy with how much life went into the animations. Despite basing the characters on simple colors, the devs went out of their way to make each character filled with expressive and fun animations that really help the game feel polished. Each character is fun to control, helped by smooth universal movement. The archetypes cover your standard shotos, zoners, grapplers, and rushdowns, but also have some weird ones. Of particular note is Violet. While there have been characters who clone themselves in past fighting games, I don't think I've ever seen a character like Violet, who freely switches between her clones and has multiple ways to use them. It's obvious the developers knew what they were doing, and managed to fit as much depth as possible within these small movesets.

The overall system mechanics are quite fun too. While it seems quite simple at first, there is a lot of polish on display here. The combo system is pretty intuitive, with a lot of depth under the surface (helped by a roman cancel system like guilty gear). I am a bit worried that there isn't enough defensive mechanics, given how fast crossups can be in this game, but it is too early in the game's meta to make any conclusive statements about that. 

I've praised the animations, but I have some problems with the overall graphics. Im very happy the devs do give an epilepsy warning on the steam page, as this game can be kind of intense to look at, however there is another problem. The big problem is the lifebars. They're stylish, but I think they're so stylish they start to hurt gameplay. Their shape and inconsistent colors can make checking how much health you have left more frustrating than it should be. A small issue, yes, but in a genre as fast paced as fighting games, this can cause issues. There's a reason most fighting games have simpler looking lifebars. The super meter isn't as big a deal because they give you a number on the side to easily check how much meter you have. As for the soundtrack, unfortunately due to technical issues on my end I couldn't listen to it. (this is definitely not this game's fault, my computer just has some issues, but it does mean I couldn't hear the ost sadly.)

There is one last issue, the online. It's laggy and buggy and doesn't work very well. I'd love to play the game more, but I just find the online annoying to deal with. Im sure the devs know about this and are working on it, but for now, that is a major issue.

Overall, if I had to describe this title in one word, it would be polish... except for the online. The animations? Great. The movesets? Fun. The mechanics? Interesting. The online? Bad. It's a shame, because for a free game, this is quite a great deal. The game is still worth your time, but perhaps stick to local matches until the bugs are ironed out.

Rave is a gripping and intense puzzle game set in a grim, dark fantasy world. The game features detailed 3D graphics and haunting sound effects that will immerse you in a world of horror and suffering. The storyline is engaging, with a plot that will keep you hooked until the very end. The puzzles are challenging and require creative thinking and logical skills to solve. As you progress, the game becomes increasingly difficult, and you will need to use all your ingenuity and cunning to survive. The game's enemies are scary and will require you to fight them to reach your goal. Overall, Rave is a must-play for fans of horror and puzzle games.

Great mix of idle game and automation/optimization sandbox!

Not as "dumb" as something like cookie clicker or clicker heroes, and not requiring you to start from scratch tens/hundreds of times to progress. You can "start over" with other towns but the really awesome thing is your current town still exists/can still grow and you can trade resources to your newer towns to tech them up much faster. The game encourages this by having towns in unique biomes with unique resources in those, to encourage trading between your settlements, and optimizing those for specific purposes.

[b]Pros:[/b][list]
[*] Fun and fluid combat
[*] Easy to get into
[*] Tutorial isn't a huge wall of text and gives you time to learn a mechanic before introducing another one
[*] Controller-Support (mostly)
Tested with Xbox One, Xbox Series and Dualsense. All worked flawlessly. A nice quality of life change would be the addition of Playstation button prompts as of now you'll always have the Xbox layout.
[*] Multiple playable character with different playstyles
[*] Fully voice acted
Considering the English voice actors are Chinese, some characters have a rather strong accent and the pronunciation isn't always on point. However, since voice acting isn't necessarily a given, I don't really mind it.
[*] Soundtrack is fire
[/list]
[b]Neutrals:[/b][list]
[*] Rhythm game elements
One of your skills gets powered-up or changed depending on when you press it. You can either listen to the music (it's mostly easily recognizable when you'll have to press to enhance it) or use the visual indicator next to the skill icon. 
Personally I really like it but I can also see some people disliking it.
[/list]
[b]Cons:[/b][list]
Aside from some minor deviations between dialogue box and voice acting (mostly single, interchangeable words), I couldn't really find anything faulty with the game.
[/list]
[b]Conclusion:[/b]
If you like Hades and Dead Cells and don't mind the anime aesthetics, Neon Echo is a great mix of both games and easily recommendable for the current price.

This game is amazing. I would likely recommend for anyone that likes roguelike or metroidvania games.
Before getting into a few nitpicky things that I think could greatly improve this game when the game is completed, I would like to start off by saying the music, art, and combat are all amazing. I have played AAA games that didn't come close to being as good as this.

For things I would like to see improve as the devs continue to work on it:
- The English dub. There is one, voices are fine but several words are pronounced incorrectly ("mecha" being pronounced "meh-cha" being the most noticeable)
- No PS4 controller prompts
- The skill that activates with Y or triangle. You have to time it's usage perfectly to get max out of it. I would love to see it filling in sync with the music, opposed to increasing and decreasing over time and having to monitor it.

For anyone interested, this game is 100% worth the price. If you are fine with a Chinese dub I would recommend using that over the English. I have seen some people say that controllers do not work; they do. I have played with a PS4 controller with no issues.

It's a fun game, but the structure of "free game with DLCs to unlock it" means that it is fully non refundable. You can not pay, test to see if you like it, and return it like you can almost any other game on steam. The core racing is pretty fantastic, but having drivers who level so there are objective "best" choices, having the game so reliant on replaying the same tracks with only marginally different circumstances, and having so many mobile style currencies to keep track of is frustrating. 

It does run and play great on Steam Deck, and the theming, music, and mechanics are all pretty top notch.

Disney Speedstorm at its core is a fast paced, action packed racer with very catchy music and visually nice boards, beyond that there are some good points and bad points.

The bad points are there are too many currencies. Currently there are blue tokens from various sources, yellow tokens from the battle pass, and light purple tokens from multiplayer, plus other one off tokens for free boxes. If they want to avoid problems going forward they need to combine systems for ease of access

As mentioned this game as loot boxes, of a sort. Some boxes offer purely cosmetic items for your character or car, the main box though which you buy with battle pass currency gives you a chance at getting crew for your car (which increases your racing stats in the wake of not being able to change kart)  or racer tokens which is how your character levels up, but it not their racing level, more on that in a second

Character leveling and racing levels is where I think this game is going to make or break itself. Your character has a star rating, better star rating better stats and abilities. They also have a racing level which dictates what level difficulty you are capable of doing, but sadly it also affects stats, meaning that if you are a level 5 racer and queue for ranked, you may very well race off against people who are level 10 and able to go MUCH faster than you. Some may view the system as an incentive to keep playing to get more items and subsequently and get better, others may not.

The good points are the game actually feels very good to drive, it‚Äôs got very tight steering, nice manual boosting and character specific battle items that make the game fit to your style of racing, personally I prefer ramming people off the board so I play Donald üòä. Compared to Nickelodeons kart racers, this feels much better and in some ways feels better than Mario Kart

The tracks, while few in number for early access, in my opinion do feel varied based on the fact there are 4 different version of each track to where each race you‚Äôll have a moment of ‚Äúwhich version is this?‚Äù And I personally enjoy that.

The music which is a mix of new songs and remixes from their corresponding franchises (Mulan features a remix of Ill make a man out of you for example) fits well. Personally I think the music is great and really pumps you up for a good time..

Realistically, if you look at the game as a whole with all its pluses and minuses and have the sense it is early access, I think it ranks more of a 7, 7.5/10

If you are looking for a Mario kart clone, go play Mario kart. This game isn‚Äôt trying to be Mario kart, it‚Äôs trying to be its own racing game and calling every racing game that comes out a Mario kart clone seems unfair bias

But that‚Äôs me.

[h1]"Remaster"[/h1]
[b]First off I would like to thank the creators for the free game.[/b]
[i](I got Rewind for free for owning the original Desktop Dungeons)[/i] 

I would not recommend buying this game how ever unless you are on a [u]4K monitor[/u].
[i](The original does not look good at all on 4K unless in a window.)[/i]

If you do intend to buy/play I recommend reading the guide Eable wrote first. The main plus is that the DLC is included.
[list]
[*]It seems to be the same as the old game just with a new look and camera angle. The old game had a better UI and it was easier to read the information you needed because it was all in one place and not all over the screen. The new camera angle makes it rough to plan unless you zoom all the way out anyways. (Kind of like you can zoom in and look at units in Starcraft but no one plays like that.)
[*]The tutorial seems to be more puzzle like then the actual game and does not really teach you much you would not already know by the point you get to it. [i](It is hidden away in the Explorers Guild under the Puzzle Challenges.)[/i] The starter pack challenges teaches you a bit but also teach some bad habits like attacking enemies your level most of the time.
[*]The gameplay is the same unrewarding struggle of limited resources and hitting large enemies just so you can back off and kill a small one to regain hp and mana from leveling. [i](Wonder how many people make it past the bankers?)[/i]
[/list]
In the end I am not sure who this is for. They gave it to the original owners free so not us. New owners will most likely get tired and leave or refund it after finding out it does not have features like remapping keys or real graphic settings.

The only downside to this game is the bugs, they aren't that sever tbh, you can just restart from your checkpoint which fixes it.

At first I was having a great time with the game. The stealing your opponent's abilities is a cool concept. But I kept going back to doing light-heavy attack combos way more since it's more reliable on groups of enemies. Then when there's boss combat, I kept doing the same thing, until I realize, wait, I could steal the boss' magic and deal more damage! Basically, stealing enemy attack is fun, but it takes a lot of preparation, not to mention aiming at that one fire mage in a clump of ice mages clumped together is hard. It could've done better. There's a lot of interesting mechanics, and I respect the experimentation of these mechanics.

Voicelines, I was expecting voicelines at the least with how much I paid for.
The Art, It's amazing at the start until some missions just repeat the same boring maps unlike at the start of the game and the main hub.. I need more environmental detail and better character art.

Raining Rocks: what the heck is up with the rocks falling on the boss arena while the boss is doing an AOE attack as I sit in a tiny platform??? And I could barely see them coming since they are random yet fast. I feel like that's illegal. It's just annoying.

Simplistic Level Design. Sylas hooking to a rod is just to get funky outside of combat is what it feels like.

The skip button, why can't you just make it instant? Or at least an option to? I have to sit there and watch the animation on fast forward every time, there's no point to it.

In my opinion, this is worth half the price. It's either voicelines or better art to give the price justice. Better gameplay-loop wouldn't be bad as well. But the main problem I have is that there's no voicelines..

Very good Sylas Simulator ! 

10/10

Game is an intense and immersive dark fantasy puzzle game that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The game's storyline is engaging, with a lost soul wandering through the endless corridors of hell, trying to find salvation. The graphics are carefully crafted to create a world of darkness and horror, with haunting sound effects that will give you chills.

The game offers challenging puzzles that will require creative thinking and logical skills to solve. As you progress, the game becomes increasingly difficult, and you will have to use all your skills to overcome obstacles and scary enemies. The game also offers hidden secrets and clues that add to the intrigue and depth of the plot.

It is an exciting game that offers an immersive and intense gaming experience. With its engaging storyline, challenging puzzles, and scary enemies, the game will keep you entertained for hours on end.

Dead Unending is a simpler version of Project Zomboid.

There are several hours worth of gameplay, however there is not much replay value after everything is unlocked.

Simple looting style can be frustrating and losing weapons by accidentally discarding them can happen frequently. 

Three resources to build and craft make for easy dynamics. 

Shelter becomes irrelevant when defenses are built up enough, i have found myself with more resource farming items than anything else. 

Game is worth it for those who found Project Zomboid too intense. For those who like zombie games, i would buy on a discount/sale.

Will update for patches

It's a bit slower paced than I was expecting compared to what I saw in trailers but that's not necessarily bad - could also just be early-game.  Excited to continue to dive in here.

Adventure Puss is a thrilling retro platformer that takes players on a wild adventure as a heroic cat battling against cunning rats. The unique storyline and colorful pixel graphics create an immersive retro atmosphere that instantly captures the player's attention. The game features multiple locations to explore, each with its own unique challenges and obstacles. The combat system is engaging and satisfying, as players must use their dagger and other methods to defeat the hostile rats. The game's engaging gameplay and challenging enemies keep players hooked for hours on end, making it a must-play for platformer fans. Overall, Adventure Puss is a fun and exciting game that combines a unique storyline, engaging gameplay, and retro visuals to create a memorable gaming experience.

Gemcrusty is a free psychological horror video game about an explorer who descends into madness, both literally and figuratively, as his greed and lust drive him to explore an endless mine located right underneath his opulent mansion. The protagonists's struggle with mental illness results in him envisioning various bizarre hallucinations over the course of his descent such as twerking moles and canine butlers. 

The sheer loneliness and brutality of the explorer's spelunking escapades cause the poor man to imagine precious gemstones as cute anime waifus. His mind assigns these imaginary women various personalities that resemble common anime tropes. Such apparitions even speak in confusing, broken sentences, no doubt a clever reference from the developers to the protagonist's failing mental state.

Have had an overall great experience with the game so far. The game has a great sense of humor that feels rather unique and despite being early access, most features feel fleshed out and balanced. It's great to see a game that understands what early access actually means by releasing a truly engaging and well put together title for the community to play and discover minor issues and give feedback for new ideas.

A Grand Slam game, a complete refresher to the tower defense genre, absolutely hit all the marks for me. A little sarcasm and comedy, an interesting twist on human fate, and gameplay that is immediately engaging and ramps up quickly.¬† Some of the best parts for me include "No Hopes" where you can greatly modify the gameplay by enabling difficulty modifiers and, in various combinations, create a completely different experience. I was super fortunate and got access to the beta for a bit as well as the playtest weekend. I saw some discussion in the game's official Discord during the playtest weekend, and the developers seemed very engaged and willing to make the game the best experience for players possible. I came away from that chomping at the bit for a chance to own uninterrupted access to the game and with excitement for the possible future of the game, as the roadmap shows some pretty awesome potential that I cannot wait to see come to fruition.¬†¬†

Now, not to take away from my overall glowing review, the store page said there would be Steam Leaderboards, but I don't see that feature anywhere in the game currently, and while I don't think it is critical to the game play at all, as I can still go into discord and dunk on my friends manually, it would be cool to have something to show off what I can do passively.

Even though I have posted have a positive review, I don't recommend the game as of now.

It is still in EA and for the time being, you don't get too much content. At best, you can maybe squeeze 3-4 hours of fun out of the game, before it gets repetitive, and you start to find out the limitations of it. The campaigns get pretty repetitive, it's just the location that's changing, the AI is sometimes struggling and the whole restaurant management gimmick is kind of basic as of now (the only thing you're really in charge of, is how much food you want to buy and how much the food costs).

You can place a toilet in the middle of your restaurant and nobody will seem to care, they'll just go to it without a care. You can serve everyone food from the ground, and they'll still give you 5 stars (but rats might steal some of it, so there's that I guess?)... You can do a lot of stuff that seems illogical, and the game doesn't care. As I said, still basic.

Now though, why did I leave a positive review anyway?
Because the developer seems to read the forum a bit and tries to fix the game and make it better. As of now, they're also still working hard on the game, so it wasn't abandoned still (who knows what the future might bring though). If you're looking for a *basic* restaurant tycoon, this might be worth your money (on a sale), and it has the potential to grow bigger in the future.

If you read the review in a few months from now, and you still see that the game is getting updated, and nice content is being implemented, buy it (I think 2 more campaigns were added since the game was released, not even a year ago).
If you check and there were no new updates for a long time... I would recommend you to stay away from it. The current price tag isn't worth the content you'll be getting right now, and your money is most likely better spent elsewhere.

A cute little restaurant sim. It's pretty basic right now (in early access) and once you hit your stride it turns into a bit of a resource management game, but otherwise it's pretty fun.

Pros:
- Nice art style
- Straight-forward gameplay
- Resource management is fun‚Äîmanaging repeat ingredient orders, menu prices, etc
- Has decent replayability
- The scenarios are fun/challenging

Cons:
- Things sometimes get buggy (stairs aren't movable or staff can't navigate out of a room, even though there's a door or space to move, staff won't do their prioritized job, etc)
- No music to play along to, which makes things... quiet
- It IS early access, but the features are quite limited in terms of how closely you can manage things (could include staff pay/skill management, specialty training for certain foods/ingredients)
- Building tools and decor are very limited

Overall a fun game. I'd recommend it in early access, but I'll definitely be keen to see what release features and updates they come up with.

A really nice concept. If updates are consistent, I can see this being a wonderful, relaxing game.

A few recommendations to the developer:

I recommend adding female staff models and names, and perhaps some non-binary models and names. 

I would really like to be able to move an item on the first floor to the top floor! I have to delete the item and buy a new one, which is a bit frustrating. 

It would be helpful to have an information panel that tracks which staff feel overloaded and in what area (do I need more cleaners? More waitstaff? More cooks?). 

I wish there were more ways to increase the flow of customers. Lowering prices works somewhat, but not really enough when you get a big operation going. Maybe add an advertisement feature to drum up extra business (to your benefit or detriment!). Maybe you could also add a random chance for a food critic to enter the building, and based on that pawn's experience it could give you a popularity boost or stifle business. 

Other recommendations are mostly to add additional content, but that is already in the works! 

I hope this helps :)

honestly, with how fun this game is in early access I'm really excited to see where it goes. I bought it after Northernlion uploaded a couple videos on it and am really impressed with the content. It is well worth the 12$ I paid for it, If you like simulation games and building games then Im pretty sure you'll love this game and think its worth the buy. As I'm sure it will only improve with time

After playing this game for 2 hours I felt as if I had experienced pretty much everything this game has to offer, at least in its current state. It was fun for the first 1.5 hour but then I realised I had done everything there is to do and there was no more fun to be had.

I would also like to point out the lack of diversity in this game. I know it's just a game, but I find it odd that there are exclusively male workers in the game, especially since they already have female characters in the game (I also noticed male guests would have naked legs when using the toilet, but females would keep their pants on and cross their legs - not a big issue and may be an oversight but I found it odd). Add on to that that there are only white characters - I don't imagine it can be too difficult to apply a small variety of skintones? I really hope the game will improve on that as it continues to develop, it would be nice to see more diversity. 

Anyway, I wouldn't recommend the game in its current state. However, I will be keeping and eye on this game to see if it improves to the point that I might be interested again, because the first 1.5 hours of playing was fun.

I would be ecstatic if poker, black jack, and roulette were added this would truly make this game fantastic.

I think its a neat little restaurant sim that has potential. The scenarios are fun and challenging but feel fair, after about 7 hours i 3 Star'd all the ones available. The ingredients, cooking, worker, money, stock, delivery strategy & gameplay is fun and feels balanced. The biggest issue that plagues this game is lack of information and lack of more indepth content. Its hard to get a good balance of what i need more or less of when all i can really do is eyeball it, no graphs or UI information on how much of X im using, workers claim to be busy but idk if thats my waiters, cooks, janitors, or bus boys. A graph or two could EASILY fix this issue and i hope to see the dev implement this. For indepth content... Currently the game is a 1 trick pony, its a really good trick but its still one trick. I would like to see mechanics that occur in games like Rimworld or Prison Architecht where maybe professional reviewers visit the restaurant and can really harm or boost customers based on their review.

TLDR: Early access REEEE, Dev on good path. Approve of content for price. 

P.S. Music kicks on when you place the Gramophone decoration and it is perfect for the Pizza & Mafia scenario, would buy original soundtrack of ingame soundtrack. 10/10 there

Looking for a thrilling dungeon-crawler game that will keep you engaged for hours? Check out "Kiro." This text-controlled game offers a robust leveling system that lets you unlock new abilities and increase your stats as you progress. Plus, the multiplayer feature allows you to team up with up to six players for even more fun.

One of the most exciting aspects of "Kiro" is the treasure trove of loot you can collect throughout the game. With a wide variety of weapons, armor, and magical items, there's always something new to discover. And the spellcasting system is intuitive and fun, giving you the power to unleash magical attacks on your enemies.

What sets "Kiro" apart from other dungeon crawlers is its attention to classic RPG themes and lore. Fans of the genre will love the nods to classic tropes and themes found throughout the game.

In short, if you're looking for an addictive dungeon crawler with a deep leveling system, multiplayer support, and a wealth of loot and magic, "Kiro" is the perfect game for you. Get ready to embark on a thrilling adventure and explore a magical world filled with danger and treasures

Charming roguelike that changes each run, but has a selection of handcrafted rooms, so you can get a feel for where traps, secrets, puzzle solutions and enemies will be located on repeat playthroughs

Pros
+Chill music
+Nice pixel art and animation (even the grass is dancing)
+Characters are likeable and remarkably zen seeing as their whole world and existence ends each day
+You can have unique builds quite quickly and get given a new super power at the start of each run
+Enemies can set off traps and harm each other. Sometime it's fun to sit back and enjoy the chaos
+Achieve stuff even on short runs as unique stories unfold and new items get unlocked

Meh
~A lot of roguelikes have a fast travel option, but the schtick of this game is the rooms gradually get filled up with fire as you explore forcing you to push forward. So tactical exploring is a necessity and teleporting around would make this unique level destruction idea redundant. Personally I quite like it, but does mean backtracking a fair bit. At least the slain enemies stay dead.
~It's pretty difficult. There are some bees in the first area that seem OP and snipe you with an undodgeable bullet so you always need to be aware of where they are.
~The game does actually save your run as you quit (which I love), but the game doesn't say "save and quit". This might lead people to thinking they are having to throw a run when they have to leave the game.

Cons
-Some power ups are straight up bad. There's one where you become a bomb and blow up, losing a heart each time. I just reset my run when I get this.

Tips
+Try and get the ghost bullet upgrade (my fave). You can hide behind walls and kill enemies without facing them and also cheese some of the switch puzzles.
+Activate "highlight enemies" in the options. It certainly helps (especially with the aforementioned bees!
+Try to head towards the question marks on the map. They are always rooms that will improve your run.
[spoiler] +You can blow up some walls with bombs. The wall to the left of Guitarboy at the start always has a secret [/spoiler]
[spoiler] +You can cheese some of the more challenging switch activated doors by dropping a bomb on the switch and activating when you get to the door [/spoiler]
[spoiler] +There is a character that can permanently add certain info to your map, so you can strategise where to head to each run [/spoiler]
[spoiler] Try to save up 1000 coins for the cow man. (You only need to do this once). Then when you find a missing cow you can heal yourself for one heart and get a free item [/spoiler]

You honestly cant get through the first few parts unless you have unlocked certain characters and that is if your lucky to get the shards to unlock them (Which in most cases you need 10 shards and only get one or two in the boxes). The reward systems for the daily/seasonal activities feel underwhelming and honestly not worth it at times. You will find yourself grinding for countless hours trying to get one specific upgrade, only to get locked right back out for not having another item. I would love to give this game a great review for the game play, music and overall presentation of the worlds and characters, but the many menus, stores and gacha systems included in the game really kills the joy of playing it.

This game is fantastic, currently in the top 100 of all players on Ranked Multiplayer. I highly recommend this game if you are a racing game fan. The gameplay is solid, tracks are fun and unique, not a single track blends together with another one, unless you're counting variants, but each variant sections off certain portions of the track. The game is easy to pick up and play. I thought it was going to take me a while to understand how it works, but I was getting top 3 positions without issue shortly after my first few races. The soundtrack is godlike, and I wish more people were willing to try it out now. 

My only issue is latency online, but I think it's because the game isn't overly popular in the United States quite yet, because I've been matching with a lot of people from Europe and Asia, so some latency is to be expected. 

Overall, I'd give this game right now where it stands at a 9.5/10.

Coming from someone who is very invested in the world of League of Legends this game is a dream come true, not only is the gameplay amazing but the story is the best story in this world yet, Sylas is an incredibly compelling protagonist and the side characters, be they new ones introduced in this game or ones from Riot projects in the past, are so well realised.

While 'mixed' seems fair right now, I think this could be something special.

Truth be told, a mix of Evil Genius and Stargate SG-1 is right up my alley. So, yes, rose tinted glasses. But the fundamentals seem fine, as they say. You build a base around your gateway, recruit a team of gaters (I will always read this as 'gators'), explore new worlds and research the things you bring back for fun and profit. It works and it's fun! Up to a point.

For it to go from 'interesting and fun' to 'great!', I think these areas need some tweaking or reworking:
- Medical: it's a weird, obtuse system that locks in both the patient and the medic, with the medic walking endlessly from the medicine cabinet to the patient, who seems to not recover one iota unless being fed drugs. Medicine that delivers it's effect over a longer period, and thus needs to be applied less frequently, would already be a huge step up. It would also open the door for different kinds of medicines, which could generate interesting choices.
- Missions: the narrative focus can use a lot of tightening and some more visuals. I discovered a friendly alien civilization and all I got were these three lines of dialogue. Something like that. But also: some indications as to what could be expected (perhaps a drone you send through on a much shorter mission?) would be invaluable. As would still getting basic rewards from missions that turn out to be story missions.
- Menemies: this is in part the medical problem, as your downed soldier stay downed for what feels like eons. But also: doors are purely aesthetic right now; why do all the other gaters train on the shooting range, but refuse to pick up a rifle; I would like to prioritize targets (so it's not just three one on one fights that I will lose); I would also like an iris to close the gate, perhaps delaying the invasions?

In general the game could also use more information on pretty much everything, and some tweaking to the interface, so that it's possible to view and edit the teams on the galaxy map, for example.

But all this criticism comes from a place of love. I really hope this one can deliver on its promise.

I think it does a good job of incorporating a rhythm dynamic into an fps and the core gameplay elements of Gun Jam are quite addictive!

The compact and minimal UI is sleek and uninhibited on the action frame while the general graphic design, with pulsing and vibrant colours on all levels, is fantastic and gives the game a certain charm. The most defining aspect however, has to be the soundtrack which, whilst spanning multiple genres, sounds massive and explosive and delivers a great beat-driven shooting session. The option to be able to add your own music to the game is a nice touch too!

On the other hand, there's not a lot of content to play with at this time and the possibilities for customisation of characters and level design seems yet to be fully explored. Also, if the game had a story mode which possibly gave more depth and background to the main characters I think this could enhance the game's replay value even further.

Overall though, playing this game was a great experience of beat-blasting to a great variety of awesome music!

I played during the English Beta-testing and this game scratched the itch I was looking for in an Asian-inspired city builder. 

You manage a population as it grows over time. They have different needs and you occasionally get raided by enemy soldiers. There's a lot of subtle nuances within the mechanics that make for interesting gameplay. 

The game has a story mode which also acts like a tutorial. The game also has free-play which allows you to create cities without a mission in mind. I definitely think this game has a lot of replayability. 

If you like city-builders, I definitely do suggest giving this one a try!

I got this game for the sake of owning a game with a bear in it, and I can confidently say that it delivers on that part. You play as a bear who delivers food to other animals (with orders being shown through the UBear Eats, accessible by pressing C), but the food's essentially scattered around the campsite by humans. It's your job to sneak through the campsite in order to retrieve said food for your customers. I like the stealth part, but having to throw items is a bit more complicated than I thought it would be. Your M1 button *is* working, you just need to hold M2 to aim before you can throw. As an avid ragdoll enjoyer from my time in Source Engine games, I can also say that the ragdolls here are pretty alright. They collide with the ground as one would expect, though limbs feel a bit too loose, particularly the bear's arms. One other note, having him pull out two tree branches as a disguise is so stupid, but the fact that it actually somehow works is just the icing on the cake.

[b]My review to Your Average Bear[/b]

I only played for an hour but I really like this game already. It runs smoothly, it has great graphics, great voice actors, a compelling story and it immerses you into the game. You actually tend to the plants and move leaves around to look for fruit to harvest. You use your spells in every aspect. I feel like they've improved a bit on the witch life sim. This is totally worth the original price, I was honestly surprised it was only $20 with as much effort it seems has been put into the story. 

The only cons I see so far is a bug I've encountered when having played for an hour and tending to all the plants I did, it stopped letting my view change around the plant as my character moves around it to see the leaves and fruits better. The view stayed in one spot and it was a bit hard to harvest at times. The bug does go away if you close the game out and reopen the save.

There is heart and care in this game but some of the execution in my opinion falls short. Stealing enemy spells is fun. Your own spells later on also become strong. However, there is the limiting resource that is mana to cast your own spells and not the stolen ones (stolen ones are free to cast and on cooldown how often you can steal from an enemy). You gain mana with your physical attacks aka punching stuff. Problem being is that some of the bigger tankier enemies require more than one cast of spell element they're weak too. They're also aggresive with their attacks. This leads to a situation where you're doing short combos at times to build up your mana for one more spell cast just to take a small chunk of their health bar.

This problem is further compounded in some boss fights where the boss can have long attack combos, animations or damage effects on the ground that linger. This leads to you having enough time to land 2-3 hits unless you wanna take damage. Another problem is the perspective or camera angle. There has been numerous times where an enemy would be hidden completely behind an object and you have no idea they are preparing an attack. Also sometimes enemies will just shoot at you from off the screen.

Then there are the bugs. Sometimes you will just be unable to attack but can still move. Other times the reverse can happen where you can not move but can still attack. Enemies can clip into walls or objects and thus become untargetable (at least you can still hit them attacks if you aim directly and run up to them).

Finally a small design gripe with one of the bosses from me. Minor spoilers but you eventually unlock Ultimate Spells. There is a boss in this game where none of your Ultimate Spells work on it. As in the game won't even let you cast them. My guess is that it is because this boss can not be targeted.

This is an amazing game already, my favourite survival game now! I'm not that far in this EA version yet, but I had played the demo for about 90 hours last year (several playthroughs). I think that alone says a lot.

It's a pretty realistic survival game (no weird monsters or fantasy elements), which presents you with a lot of the challenges you'd also face in reality. From the obvious unfriendly animals, over weather effects like sun, wind, rain and related illnesses, injuries e.g. when crafting in the dark, and of course your own needs for food and water etc.
There's a day/night-cycle and crafting actually costs time (it's fast in realtime, but could represent an hour or 2 in the game for example), which I like very much.
There are 4 different difficulties you can choose from, but I think if you're looking for a truly relaxing experience, you should look elsewhere. Although compared to the demo, they definitly made "normal" (the 2nd of 4 diffs) easier, especially those killer birds :D
There are a lot of things to craft and build, including boats to explore other islands. You can also explore the underwater world.
In addition to that, there's a story. I can't say much about the story yet, as there wasn't too much of it in the demo and I'm not far into this EA version, but the survival part alone is fun and challenging enough for me to recommend this game already.
It looks good, the atmosphere is awesome, and I haven't encountered any bugs yet (there were also not many in the demo and rarely, if ever, game-breaking). I feel like there's some optimization still needed though.
You can also rebind your keys.

The devs are amazing, very involved with their community and receptive to feedback, which was already very visible during the time the demo was available and got new/tweaked features and fixes. It's also apparent that they already included some more of the demo feedback into this EA version of the game.
There's an EA roadmap, which looks very promising to me. Even more crafting. building, areas to explore, longer story, etc.
challenging and beautiful

Honestly, I was not sure what to expect in this game. I was expecting something new and something familiar since I have already played the first game a while back. At the same time, I did not hold high hopes to see all our favorite faces from the first game. This game, however, exceeded my expectations by bringing back basically EVERYONE from the first game and introducing new patrons to our mysterious barista.

How this game differs from the first one is that emotion expressions seem a little more explicit and fun this time. Old characters have all grown a little and it is nice to see them again, sharing their new conflicts in life. I simply adore how the new characters interact with some of our old faces, which is what brings the two games together cohesively.

The game has also introduced some new features, which can drastically alter the endings for some characters, and I love it. It gives you more reasons to deviate from trying to reach the perfect ending unlike the last game, of course with the help of achievements.

Overall, lovely game that makes me want to look forward to another episode in the future, though the endings in both games are satisfying enough to call it a day. In fact, I would say the second game (this one) did even better than the last one.

A Unique Combination of Grand Strategy, RTS, and FPS

If you've ever wished for a game that combines the best elements of Hearts of Iron, Men of War, and Hell Let Loose, then this game is definitely worth checking out. It's a modern Grand Strategy game that seamlessly integrates Realpolitiks II's diplomatic, economic, and military gameplay with the Real Time Strategy of Call to Arms and the First Person Shooter mechanics of Insurgency: Sandstorm and WW3.

The game features a Quick-battle mode that allows players to quickly jump into the action and experience the different gameplay mechanics. The graphics and sound are also impressive, with realistic military units, weapons, and landscapes, and fitting soundtrack.

One of the best things about this game is its unique combination of gameplay elements. The Grand Strategy aspect allows players to control and manage their nation's economy, diplomacy, and military, while the Real Time Strategy mode lets players command their troops in battles and skirmishes. The First Person Shooter mode adds an immersive layer to the gameplay, allowing players to experience the action up close and personal.

The game is not without its flaws, however. Some players may find the learning curve steep, especially if they're not familiar with the different gameplay elements. The AI could also use some improvement, particularly in the FPS mode.

Overall, this game is a must-play for fans of Grand Strategy, Real Time Strategy, and First Person Shooter games. Its unique combination of gameplay elements makes it a refreshing and exciting addition to the genre. With the promise of multiplayer and coop modes in the future, this game is definitely one to watch.

If you're a fan of the Ace Attorney games, then I would highly recommend giving this game a shot.

The cases here are akin to Ace Attorney where not everything is as simple as it seems, which kept my interests throughout the whole game with its twists and turns.

The gameplay is very similar to Ace Attorney, with you examining scenes and gathering evidence, then having a rebuttal with suspects and witnesses. 

Key Differences :
- There is no 'Press' mechanic for testimonies. What you hear is what you have to work with.
   This can be a plus or a down for some depending on your stance on pressing testimonies in other games.

- Presenting Evidence is easier in Normal difficulty. Instead of choosing from a hoard of evidence, the game chooses a few (1-4) evidence that could or could not be relevant to the testimony at hand. All you need to do is figure out which evidence is the right one and to present it on which statement.
[Note : I played the game on Normal, I'm unsure of how it is on 'Enjoy the Story' and 'Challenge' difficulty]

I don't understand Chinese too well, so I played the game in English. The translation is pretty good, but there are some word breaking ( exa- *next line* -mple) that makes reading a bit tedious. I can't really say anything
about the voice acting since I don't understand them, but I do enjoy them! The voices fit the characters.

Overall, I really enjoyed the game! As a fan of Ace Attorney games, this game hit a lot of right spots with the
story, characters, and mysteries.

The Mageseeker is a good little game for those who want to know more about the rising of mages within Demacia although, that's about it.

The gameplay is solid, if not a little stagnant. You can mostly get through the entire game with a few repeatable button combinations. I felt the shop items were added as unlocks but very linear in nature. It's almost the illusion of being a non linear game.

I never felt the battles were truly big until the last third of the game. I played the game on a balanced difficulty and had to repeat a few bosses before I found a way to breeze the game through. 

It really needs voice acting. The conversations were a little dry and would be a lot more interesting if they had voices to accompany them.

I enjoyed seeing the progression of the story and it didn't feel too repetitive. It is what it is, a little lore enrichment while not being the premium AAA game. Good to play if your a league of legends lore fan.

Otherwise, i'd maybe give this a skip.

Absolutely loved the campaign. Took just under 10 hours and 13 in-game days on 'storied' (easy) and it's been nothing but fun and thinking about the next move in a fairly large world. 
It's not quite an RTS, which makes this game a lot easier to pick up due to simple and intuitive controls, but it also has a high enough ceiling to keep things interesting. 
Units can be commanded in a single groups, class or type and each has their own use.
Building is really easy to do on the fly (note that my sensitivity was very high, 80%) but it is also great to take some time to get a perfect setup. 
The resource gathering is simple and can be done while running through the world or while building, so it doesn't become boring at all.
A few minor bugs here and there but nothing game breaking or terrible (the fact that legendary units stopped working was annoying but the final boss being finished in about 20 seconds means it's not too horrible).
Would absolutely recommend this game for the campaign alone!

one of my favorite shooters!

Great game, if you like fast-paced actions do yourself a favor and try it. The Hotline Miami influence is obvious but it also reminds me of Enter the Gungeon. The top-down shooter and roguelite genres blend together really nicely. The shooting feels crisp and all of the weapons feel unique and fun to use. The perks system has some interesting modifiers that can really change up your run, along with some boring stat increases. I like the combo system, which forces you to play aggressively and barrel through doors without knowing what's on the other side. 

My one complaint is that the sparse color palate can affect how legible the action is. One enemy shoots acid pools that can be hard to differentiate from regular floor in a firefight.

I never write reviews, but this one is so atrocious it begs for it.
As with all games that attempt to clone Hotline Miami, it lacks all the glory, beauty, fluidity, and fun present in the original. The main factor that makes this one particularly abominable is that the developer forces you to restart the ENTIRE campaign every time you die to mask the fact that the game has a quite low number of levels. Yes, repeat all of the very easy first levels, all over again, and again, and again.
Not to mention the fact that the music is rendered in such a way that it loses all its sound quality, and that the entire game is in black and white for no apparent reason, and enemies are unable to open doors but can quick-peek you from across the map.
Do yourself a favor and skip this one. It's that bad.
I was expecting smexy times but got hit with the feels instead 10/10 will play again.
Beautiful, great voice acting, definitely unsure how to feel about the parry/blocking system though, the timing never quite feels right.

Stray Blade is a fun action RPG with relatively simple but surprisingly satisfying combat. The counter and dodge system takes a bit to get used to at first but once you get the hang of it it's very fun and engaging. I'm personally a big fan of the aesthetics and the level design is fun and interconnected. The weapons are pretty unique with their own play styles, featuring a special ability, and feel good to use. Your companion adds to both the combat and the story and unlike many other games isn't annoying or grating. There are still some issues that should be worked out, targeting can be wonky and there are some performance problems but I think the game is well worth the asking price. If you are looking for a cool action RPG with relatively simple but engaging combat and a cool aesthetic, I would recommend Stray Blade.
Fun, beautiful, and not easy =)

Stylistically Stray Blade reminds me a little of Kingdoms of Amalur, but it plays a "little" (I stress a little) like a From Software game.

To succeed, you'll need to master the dodge and parry system
Not enough control of the camera with auto repositioning
Jumping feels janky
There is no visual indication of fall damage or low health - though there is the obligatory heartbeat
Graphically, it's OK.  Which I like better than something like Thymesia
Definitely a game you want running at 60 FPS or more.  Turning down shadows gives you a massive boost in FPS.  I was dropping into the 50s with a 7800x3d and 7900 xtx at 1440p using ultra.  Lowered it to high and get at least 45-90% back.

I kinda like it, but to say it's 'one of the most anticipated action-adventure titles of 2023' would be an overstatement.  Considering I just heard about it today.  Anyway, it's got some jank in the combat.  Though I would say it's more nuanced than anything.  I'd recommend it at it's launch 20% off.

This game has a ton of potential and you can see that the devs tried making a good game, but it just falls short. The combat is clunky to say the least. The enemy AI is bonkers and has issues with path-finding. The attack animations are very inconsistent (some look great some are terrible). The game also suffers from a very  large amount of bugs, the biggest one being that the camera is constantly re-centering itself making normal gameplay almost impossible. The world building is pretty good, but the main character is unlikable.

My biggest gripe with the game is the combat! There are no 'normal' attacks - all opponents either attack you with a blue attack that you MUST parry or a red attack that you MUST dodge making the combat feel like a big QTE instead of giving you tactical options and the choice of when do you wish to simply block or now risk for a parry but potentially get a bigger reward. And since this game tries to be a souls-like, the combat makes or breaks it...

Had the game launched without some of these terrible bugs and had the devs made some adjustments to the combat itself, this game could have easily been a 7/10, especially for its asking price...

Sky Survivors is an addictive roguelike arena shooter that offers players multiple game modes and a variety of skills, characters, and unique weapons to choose from. The "Stairway to Heaven" feature adds a twist to the gameplay and allows for unique bonuses on each floor. However, the game lacks the depth and variety found in more popular games of the genre. Overall, Sky Survivors is an interesting choice for those who enjoy arena shooters with RPG elements and are willing to overcome challenges to enjoy the game.
An interesting 2D crime story about how to become a mafia boss. I liked that in addition to shooting and robbery, the game has a facility management simulator. Recommend!

A technically well-thought-out time management in which we begin our journey from a restaurateur to the head of the mafia. Take care of your restaurant by improving and taking care of it like your own child. Climb up the financial ladder, do not forget about the roof, what to protect from bandits and hide your fabulous income from the watchful eyes of the police, hungry jackals.

Oh my gosh, Don Duality is such a fun game! You get to manage your own restaurant and make it super successful by buying more tables and advertising. But that's not all, you also get to lead a mafia organization and do all sorts of shady activities like robbing banks and intimidating law enforcement. Plus, there are random events that keep things exciting and you even have to launder your money to avoid getting caught by the police. It's like being in a real-life mob movie!
Don Duality: Run a restaurant, expand your business, and lead a mafia faction. Beware of random events and launder money to avoid problems.
America has many dirty secrets. At one time, the mafia had unthinkable influence. Your task is to lead a mafia group and bring it to prosperity.
A pixel adventure where we rob banks, launder money in the criminal world, but the main thing is not to get too carried away because with success, unnecessary attention may come

TL:DR game needs some balance fixes, other than that, good roguelite title to occupy your interest

I got this game for free as I had the original version.

The new graphics and the UI is a completely downgrade to the game, removing critical information from the player as now the map is not completely displayed on screen and the player needs to pan around the camera constantly and making some items very hard to spot. 

The original is way better than this, and hey, at least it is free now! Go grab that one.

I really resented the idea of a graphic update, but once I gave it a chance I can see why they did it. The zoomable camera is one aesthetic upside, making the run feel a tiny bit more personal like a traditional RPG. And the visuals are generally 

The writing is as verbose as ever, and while the humor is generally all right it frequently feels like you're watching a comedian run out of material onstage. Like they had a rule for their writer, you have to have a joke in every single dialog. Sometimes there's just nothing there, and it's hard to watch someone try.

Definitely not worth the pricetag and Sylas desevered better than this.

SKADER is when Tron meets Gorilla Tag! Easy to start moving but hard to master, the arena is perfect shiny ice and you can skate over it.

- LOCOMOTION: No joystick to move around, you need to work hard with your body to gain at least some speed, jump, brake, and even do a 360 in the air for an achievement! 
- MULTIPLAYER: It's a multiplayer game but the option to play with bots only is available and they can be hard to beat
- GAMEPLAY: the goal is to get hold of the cat and run with it until someone stuns you and gets the cat, then everybody starts to skate after the new player. You leave a trail behind you, pick up some powerups and use your Glaive to stun other skaders
- VR: you do need to stay and turn 360 in place, no need to have a room-scale setup but playing in a chair won't fly

Very Very Good for what it is. Is it the next hotline miami? No. Is it worth the $15? In my opinion, yes. If you like the action of hotline miami and the game design of roguelites this is PERFECT.

There are a lot of things to break down about the game design but overall I'd say many of the choices the designers made are clearly well-thoughtout and manage to take Hotline Miami's frantic combat while still making it playable as a Roguelite. The player has a proper healthbar, and its pretty generous, too. You can't really have a roguelite if you had Hotline Miami's "dying every 5 seconds" mechanic. It still manages to be extremely frantic as the Combo Meter directly increases the coins you get, which then helps the Roguelite aspect. Honestly it's impressive how the designer has broken fundamental staples of Hotline Miami and Roguelites and still managed to get the best of both worlds.

Pro-tip: I don't know if the tutorial explained this, but you can Kick with both the Left Mouse Button AND the Middle Mouse Button. You can even middle click while holding a gun and you can kick without having to drop the weapon.
2 runs and instant refund, not my thing.

Don Duality is a business management card strategy game in which player embodies a mafia boss who is determined to expand his/her influence in the criminal world.

You‚Äôll be manage a restaurant and dealing in nefarious acts of all kinds. Use your connections, influence, and intimidation and become the biggest, baddest boss. 

To do so, player will have to recruit gangsters who will robbing banks, collecting debts, and intimidating law enforcement. 

This game is a lot of fun and super easy to play!

A pixel parody of Mafia affairs. Where we do economics, launder money, improve the restaurant, have a showdown, and other little things. All in all, the idea is not bad, but...
But man, pixels, I hate pixels! 
Well, make a normal picture without those horrible squares, the 21st century, why make this mess?

There is a chance to be the leader of the pixel mafia. Send bbandits to rob people and launder the loot in your restaurant. Although the restaurant turns out to be such a successful enterprise that I don‚Äôt even know why to rob at all.

It's funny how the police don't care if you rob people. She is offended only by the fact that you are laundering the stolen money. And the more successful you are at laundering money, the more angry the police are with you. So you will have to artificially reduce the efficiency of your restaurant so that it does not have time to launder all the loot.

The game is card-based, so your choice of actions will most often be completely terrible and inappropriate. True, some cards can be discarded. But usually it doesn't help much.

Ok. Immediate thoughts for this game....are very very positive. It's....really difficult. I have done a lot of runs over 4 hours of playing it. Enemy designs are great. The sound effects are great. The music is awesome...it sounds like... you are in the depths of hell. It is..... really really hard. I have done... nearly 30 runs..... I have Giant Grapes. I usually use Abe because of the +1 projectiles. Now....it being difficult is not insomuch the issue.... however....there is this meta progression.... and herein lies the issue... in my 30 runs.... I don't feel.... all parts of the meta progression... I see the healing sure.... and SOME.... of the damage...and I can clearly see... that I have more health. If I were to rate this game now? I would give it.... an 8.7 out of 10.... you KIND of feel like you feel stronger when you put points into strength.... and you KIND of feel like.... I took a few points less damage when you put them into Armor. Armor.... seems nearly useless.... at max it mitigates 5.5 hp of damage. However, to me...armor is not the issue. For one thing... Ice Orb and Radioactive Skull....are supposed to slow enemies down yes? Or possibly freeze them. For Ice Orb. I find that Ice Orb rarely freezes...very rarely. This issue I am finding is.... those eagles? that start coming in? are... just too tanky... I know they are meant to be hard... but that second wave of them.... is a little bit skewed. They are insane. I would like to see them have....idk... maybe 10% less health? I have tried a ton of different combos... and none of them seem to work...I get swarmed. The best way to deal with them? Stand between obstacles. The ONE time I did make it to The Mortician? I have no idea how I made it there. Luck. And then he killed me after about 45 seconds. I would like to see... either a redoing of Armor.... because you really can't tell when you have it.... I have Armor maxed out on my game.... but still I get hit for 4 points of damage after a few minutes from them? I really really like this game.... and I will eventually beat this first level.... but it's super hard. I can't feel too much meta progression. It may turn people away. I would still recommend this game because... yeah... it's a blast. Thank you for your feedback if you wish to share it with me.

Great idea but poor (I hope yet) implementation.
Many problems have already been pointed out in other reviews but I still remind of it.

[list]
[*] Unbalanced and unforgiving economics. You virtually can't get past the midgame without using F9 console with money cheat code.

[*] Broken gaters priorities. Medics can do anything but treat patients. Soldiers can go sleep or eat right before the invasion.

[*] Almost absent defensive capabilities. No turrets. Doors are totally senseless and useless. Soldiers level doesn‚Äôt affect their fighting abilities.

[*] Dubious UI decisions. For example, you have to manually assign exosuit for one and every gater who goes on a misson. And if you reassign exosuit rack to another gater while exosuit is still on, the former owner of exosuit doesn‚Äôt return it to rack. Well, yes, you can use this bug as a feature, making gaters always wear exosuits, but come on, there‚Äôre better ways to manage equipment, right?

[*] Bugs, bugs and more bugs. Gaters freeze in middle of action. Enemies freeze in the midst of a fight. Absent data research options. Yeah, I understand this is Early Access. But still.
[/list]

Well, I definitely will keep an eye on the game patch notes and my opinion may change if majority of the problems will be solved.
