This game is tough. I really want to like it, but it's entering the market when so many other games in the genre are just flat out better.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
1) Great concept with the comic book style scenarios.
2) Adding quests to this style of game is a good concept.
3) The body horror is a welcome change to the standard fantasy skin these games tend to have.
4) 10 playable characters to start is great.
5) Excellent graphics, especially with scanlines enabled. Really gives that 90s feel.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
1) No Deck support. Tried using multiple versions of Proton/GE, no success.
2) In under 2 hours of gameplay, I soft locked twice losing two different 6000+ kill runs. 
3) Cutscenes are awkward and skipping them goes line by line, despite the text never changing. 
4)Weapon balance is non-existent, every run that I've taken all single-handed weapons has been far, far easier. Two handed weapons seem to be much worse. This might be character specific, but I wouldn't know, because:
5) No explanation of weapons, characters, skills, etc. Maybe I overlooked how you can check these things, but in game there did not seem to be a way to check damage, health, skills, even the items only show a one-time pop-up as to what they do.
6) Some runs, weapons would not be able to be improved. It seemed to happen with melee weapons more frequently, but some weapons would just get stuck at level 1. If you chose to upgrade them, it would stay at the same level and you would be offered the same upgrade choices next time. Is this intentional?
7) Meta progression is t e r r i b l e. You collect money at an agonizingly slow pace. In 1.5 hours of gameplay, I was roughly 1/4 of the way to purchasing my FIRST upgrade. There are also very few, uninteresting choices for spending money. They need to add character specific progression, or change the way money is gained. Maybe this picks up as sessions go longer, but I don't feel compelled to find out.
8) Damage is not indicated properly. When a car explodes off screen, I get a big scary red screen flash. When an enemy is crawling on my skin, no screen change aside from health bar rapidly dropping.

As it stands, I'm not sure how this game can justify 2x the cost of Vampire Survivors for a small percentage of the content, less polish, and no real defining features outside of the theme. I really want to love this game. I'm going to hold out hope that the devs address the issues and polish this up, because I think it has a solid base that can be built on.

It's fun! There is a lot of work to be done, though. This is a good base for a very chill restaurant tycoon game, though! The variety of dishes and drinks you can serve is good. The decor, whilst limited at the moment, looks nice. There's options for income outside of the food and drink such as gambling and various games, however they don't offer much profit. There's also an unreasonable amount of dirt, so much so to the point where it becomes unmanageable, and the employees seem to love ignoring dirty plates on tables. This is a very good base, but it does very much feel like it's in its early stages. Will be keeping my eyes on future updates, though, and I'm interested in seeing where this goes!

Really a half-baked game that shouldn't be out of early access. To be a management game, it's really at the bare minimum. A super limited, inconsistent, and unbalanced choice of furniture and decorations. Virtually no upgrades (if you need more capacity, you just place more of the same kitchen equipment). No research. No staff training or learning with time. No ad campaigns or similar to control affluence.

There are some very rough mechanics for a restaurant management game. For example, chairs and tables don't connect to form a single block, so you must leave one layer of free tiles all around the chairs to ensure customers can still pass (seriously?). This is ridiculous and a big lack of gameplay optimisation.

There are also some other major gameplay issues. Your establishment doesn't follow some opening times, your place is always open in an eternal daylight with constantly incoming patrons, to a point where a queue forms outside. If you want to rebuild the restaurant, you have to: close it down, wait for everyone to be served (including people in the queue outside!), wait for them to leave, modify the place, and reopen. This makes no sense. Virtually every single tycoon game manages this better. It would've been way smarter and more interesting to have a building phase at night, a staff/ingredients management phase before opening, and a running phase. Instead, we have this. Trying to modify the restaurant with customers inside, with the ensuing mess, was very frustrating.

Also, no campaign mode and no progression whatsoever. Just 6 plain scenarios and a sandbox that offers limited incentives given that everything is immediately available, so money is your only limiting factors. The most you can do is unlock dishes with money, which in turn unlocks any new ingredent required. But this is not stimulating and once more an underdeveloped feature. There is only a bunch of dishes, and it seems you have to start from fries in every case. For the first two months, I run a place that only served fries because I really had no alternatives. The game offers no real choice to, say, build a coffee shop vs a fast food vs an upscale restaurant. Again, a half-baked product.

I could go on, but you get the idea. If you really have to, buy it with a heavy discount. Or just avoid it altogether. If you're lucky enough to get your hands on that old gem that is Restaurant Empire, you will see what a restaurant tycoon game can really be about. Make yourself a favour and avoid Tastemaker.

Lovely exploration centric game. Keeping healthy is a real challenge and I have yet to feel like I've stockpiled anything. 
Everything has a use and aside from a small bottleneck in tendons, I didn't feel like I was grinding too much.

Combat is a little lack luster, but that's ok to me. I vastly prefer exploration and story, but I know this bothers some people. Highest complaint is the "something is hunting you" when you try to harvest something. For the first island, this isn't bad. You'll hear a growl or hiss and can dispatch it.
The problem goes when you go to the next island and the eagle that's miles away in the air is hunting you and you can do nothing until it decides to come get you. Not sure what the solution is, but game is polished. Haven't had any terrible things happen like getting stuck on a rock or falling through the world. Fun times.

The game was so close to being great but the never ending menus completely ruin the immersion. If you want to cut down a tree it is a menu, harvesting an animal is a menu, picking a flower menu, sleeping menu, eating menu, lighting a fire menu, cooking menu. 

I felt like I was playing Survival: DMV/IRS edition.

The only action that doesn't require a menu is the combat, which I found clunky and unintuitive. 

For these reasons I cannot recommend this game to most people. Unless you are a fan of surviving bureaucracy, then have fun you glorious weirdos.

As a musician I'm having a lot of fun playing the game. It felt very strange at first compared to traditional shooters but once you start getting the groove it's a lot of fun. It's great that the OST has different styles of music and the fact that you can add your own music gives it a lot of replayability. 
Most other rhythm shooters so far have a very heavy metal blood and demons kind of aesthetic (not my jam...pun intended). I much prefer this style of colorful scifi cartoony look. I like the style and feel of the 4 arenas and really look forward to seeing what other content they have planned for the future.

Instead of a roguelike deckbuilder, it is more like a puzzle story game. The deck building part is barely there, and game difficulty is quite easy. Battles and events quickly become repetitive and boring, some settings are just counter intuitive. There are plenty of characters for different play style. However,  around 20 characters, there are about only about 3 styles of playing. Overall, this game feels like a RTE battle with puzzle story.

I like this game. It has a very retro, playing-an 80s-video-game-on-your-Commodore 64 feel to it.  The sound, the graphics, and the quirky humor all gel together to give that sort of vibe. The gameplay is pretty satisfying as well. I like flying around in my jetpack while battling aliens in flying saucers, leading my fellows to safety. This game was not on my radar, but I spotted a post about it on Reddit on release day,  and that got me to check out the demo. It didn't take me long to decide to buy it and I am glad I did.

To be honest, I was expecting more from the second game. It should have had 5 times more content and be better polished to be a 10/10 in my book. Still a good game on it's own, though.
Pros: unique and satisfying movement, good music, great art.
Cons: short, easy, a bit clunky.

Worthy successor to the original Teslagrad. Overall I enjoyed this game, its new mechanics and I definitely can recommend it, especially if you liked first game. Can't wait for Teslagrad 3 xD

I really loved the original Teslagrad, but this game does not feel nearly as well put together. I haven't given it a ton of time, but the physics of picking up and throwing blocks is so terrible that I quit the game after failing at the first boss (miniboss?) several times. I have since learned that the beginning of the boss encounter was the end of the demo content, and I find it incredibly concerning that the last thing the devs had the players do in the demo was climb a frustrating block stack that out-of-bounded me once and threatened to do so several more times. Reading some reviews of the latter parts of the game, it seems like the physics continues to be an important mechanic, so my motivation to progress any further in the game is entirely shot. I don't think there's room for janky physics like this in 2023.

An excellent metroid-like with a wonderful visual style, stunning animation and very satisfying controls and movement. 

The first game was charming, but proved quite frustrating to play because of how floaty the platforming could feel despite how demanding the game got. Teslagrad 2 thankfully has none of that. It can still be a challenging game, but moving around, jumping, climbing, zipping, all feels and looks fantastic. 

It also does a thing I love, but not enough metroid-likes do correctly: you get new abilities, but they are not just to open an arbitrary door and then nothing else. All the moves you acquire add to your movement and attack options, making navigating the environment quicker and more enjoyable each time. It's wonderful stuff, and I had a great time zooming around back and forth, finding everything on my own. 

It's not a very long game, I would imagine a normal playthrough will take you about 3-4 hours, and then a few more depending on if you try to find all the scrolls and secrets. I recommend it, as there is a ton of world building and environmental storytelling to discover through this. It took me 8 hours in total and I thoroughly enjoyed my time.

The 100% secret final boss is REALLY tough, but it was very satisfying completing the game. Gorgeous artstyle and wonderful animation, fantastic soundtrack, great world building and wordless narrative. I'm excited to see what the developers will do next in this world, as this is stellar work and an excellent metroid-like well worth playing.

9/10

Great game, has more replay value than soulsgames.
If you wanna experience everything, you have to die, mostly due to gravity.
Games enemies are basically simulating an ecosystem, if you clear an area of enemies, and if you die, then those areas mostly will be later on devoid of those enemies or switched out with the other type of enemy, basically fiends vs humans, humans build new stairs, platforms, chests, forges, also sometimes block some pathways, while fiends will destroy said stuff.
You also have some metroidvania stuff too, when you get new powers to get access to old areas.
Speaking of old areas, loads of shortcuts that you can unlock, on the fiend side you grow down vines, and on the human side you open mid sized gates from the other side.

Combat is also okay, mostly the game wants you either to dodge or parry enemy attacks, but you can try to interrupt the enemy, before getting hit yourself. Timing is still essential, just that you can't rely on 1 defensive strategy. You can also disable the color coding for what type of an attack is incoming, but then it just becomes a trial and error mechanic where you have to remember every attack and if you have can dodge it or parry it.
Lock on mechanic is needed here if you want to see the enemies health/stun bar, but it's not needed for doing parries or dodges.
You start out the game with fists, you get a your old rusty sword back which also hints how much time passed after your first cutscene death, you can also find another starting weapon, these two don't have any masteries for them. Later on you'll only find blueprints for weapons and armor, so you have to use the enemy forges to craft yourself new gear. All the weapon that are crafted come with an unlockable passive skill for the character while not using the weapon. Each weapon also has a special attack.
You can also craft rune that act as temporary buffs for the weapon you have in your hand at the moment, or the hand slot (haven't tested yet, if it's weapon bound or slot bound), the buff itself so far doesn't seem time based, but more about how many times it activates.

Nicest part of the game are the finishing animations, which can be done forcefully after stunning an enemy or automatically sometimes when killing an enemy. You also have your backstabs, which are pretty brutal, but seem to be same for all weapons.

Oh and also some weapons come with a shield, and only with those weapons you can block attacks, the rest of them will only do a parry with the block button, though there is a separate parry button.

First off I REALLY don't like the trend of making two games, one flat and one VR. I would not have bought the pancake version at all if I knew I would just be buying it again to get the game I wanted. 

Second of all I am not enjoying the axe. Attacking with it feels so weak, the small SHLING sound effect gets drowned out by the 20 other noises at any minute. Hitting back projectiles seems to be a complete gamble if you will just wiff or not. I cannot for the life of me figure out the timing, go too early and get hit, go a little later and get hit, go the exact same time and angle and position, get hit 50% of the time, holding the axe completely still and letting the projectile hit it worked once. Throwing the axe has worked a grand single time for me so far. I know throwing in VR is kinda lame generally, or that the knuckles can be a little over sensitive or slow to release. If the trigger acted as a release and ignored the grip it would work every time. 

My last gripe is the screen flash every time anything happens. I axe an enemy and pick up its drop in the same moment it dies, screen flashes, did I get hurt? who knows. The screen flash was annoying in the pancake version but it is so much worse when its your entire world flashing bright white. I dont know if I can turn this off in settings because I could not access any settings when i was in game(also annoying).

ps if a free quake mod can have finger support, so can this. 

So I have nothing but negatives to say about this game, why do I recommend it?  Well, its fun. Game had me engaged like a lot of VR doesnt. I just hope the dev continues to work on this and polish it into the game it deserves to be.

It's a great game port from mobile! Do not let the term "mobile" put you off, this is actually a pretty nice game especially when compared to Activision's greedy COD titles. The graphics, even for a mobile game port are not bad either (there are still PC games that have worse graphics being released).

Combat Master is not run by a really greedy company. They do have bundles, but they are all under $10 each and they give you a variety of matching skinned guns, knives, etc (what you see, is what you get). They also have a battle pass, which only cost $5. Keep in mind that this is a free game, so some microtransactions are necessary (devs need to eat lol) but at least they are not expensive and are not gambling mechanics.

The game is pretty small in storage requirements, which makes it perfect for people who have bad internet or low end PCs. Being a game ported from mobile, you may also be able to play this on a older/weaker PC without major issues.

You can play the game both online and offline, and you can also access the stuff you earned/bought offline too. Offline playability ensures that you can still play the game even if the servers shut down (of if your internet is down, or if you're somewhere without internet, ect.), which is great! Offline modes allow you learn the game mechanics, experiment with various loadouts, as well as avoid cheaters and toxic players too. The offline modes also have adjustable difficulty and progression works offline too, so the game is not P2W (new players can play offline until they unlock better gear and are ready to play online) and veteran players can still get a challenge from the bots by cranking up the difficulty.

Additionally, this game has optional crossplay (play with players on a different platform) and shared progression (you can play the game with your account on both PC and mobile). This also means that your purchases on mobile or PC carry over to other platforms! Of course if you want, you could create a separate account on PC or mobile. 


Overall, this game is very much worth playing. If you like COD, but hate Activision's greed and hate EOMM (Engagement Optimized Matchmaking)... this game is for you!

Jesus where do I start.

I am gonna be pretty critical of everything here despite it being day 1 launch.

The game is not marked as early access, therefore I should expect a good release. This game isn't even serviceable as a fun game, let alone the good part.

The art style is simple and I do like that, a mix of risk of rain 2 and genshin impact type style. But it has a hard time picking. The models themselves have blaring issues that make them overall ugly to look at and the amount of uv mapping errors creating texture stretch or normal map issues are very apparent. The sound engine is. Unity teir, lets leave it at that. (before that triggers someone who swears by unity, I also use unity daily. It's pretty lackluster.) The sounds are just overwhelmingly loud and underwhelmingly quiet. The balancing of the audio is just messy is what I mean.

The animation is. Yeah. It's really, really stiff and lazy since they don't have any sort of tilt or ik systems to it. It all looks hand animated by new developers and very rushed. For instance the walking animation is just the running animation slowed down by however much percentage it takes to line the feet up with the speed. 

Voice acting is nice, I do like that part. Hate the writing. Why does cucklefuck the cat need to treat new players like an expert despite the game not even having a tutorial. They just kind of throw you in and say. "Ok, now do this!" They dont even go over basic ui elements like opening the inventory.. (its "I" by the way, worst fucking choice. Use b for bags or tab or literally anything that doesn't require me to lift a hand away from the movement controls)

As far as story goes. "yeah world used to be a bustling place and now this thing is killing it. it died, you have to rebuild" trope as always.

As for gameplay. Ooooohf, cant jump, cant go over ledges because of invisible walls, terrible, unresponsive ui and buggy pathfinding on cucklefuck. I do like that you can pick up the plants and inspect them, very polished feeling feature. Maybe its not, it just feels like the only thing they put more time into.

I've played several card-based roguelike games lately, and often there's more to the game than just how the cards themselves work. While some other games focus on external systems for getting cards for the main usage of those cards, Arcana instead focuses on very simple cards with an interesting depth of use for individual cards inside and outside of combat. 

Most of time time this results in a puzzle, where certain cards solve a problem presented to you. Don't have a light? Use a Torch, or if you're using magic, Fireball. A lot of cards do this, which is honestly pretty amazing. I think this is one of the more interesting games I've seen that does more with the concept than "here is a card game you can't play in paper" and does some really interesting stuff with it. 

Absolutely a good game if you want to explore how the system works, not too difficult either! Highly recommend.
Game is bugged. Reinstalled a few times, not worth fighting with it. Decent concept, though.

Teslagrad is a fun and cute game, family friendly and any age enjoyable. I remember playing the original wanting there to be more, and was happily surprised with the remaster and Teslagrad released today.

The game play is fun and best with a controller, but you can play just fine on a keyboard. All controls can be easily remapped for desired style.

The story is fantastic and the artwork cute and well done. This was a fun and enjoyable experience from start to finish.

I remember the boss fights being very frustrating, but also rewarding upon victory. I look forward to doing it again and then taking on Teslagrad 2.

I recommend Teslagrad for the gamer who enjoys good story games and non-stressful platforming and progression. Just do not let a boss fight get you frustrated. Once you figure it out, it is rewarding and easy to replicate that success.

I had played Teslagrad a while ago and really wasn't expecting a followup to that first opus; so I was pretty glad seeing a second one was being released, and quite curious about it,

My fist impressions are that, it doesn't disappoint: the graphical art is a bit similar in some points to the first one, while being a tad more colorful, and I was surprised to see that some elements, as well visual as musical, were reminiscent of Ori and the Blind Forest (the visual resemblance at some point, concerning some nature elements, such as trees, waterfalls as well as some foes, is rather staggering). The music is very beautiful too imo, and corresponds well to the sceneries of a slavic / nordic folklore. So artistically, it's a continuation of the first which doesn't break off too much from it, while presenting a certain evolution.

As for the gameplay, simply said, the controls are easy to learn while hard to master, given the situations you will be put into - I died a lot for the time I started to play the game, but the automatic save points were placed in a *very* fair way, made apparently to not frustrate the player - otherwise, there are many passages and sections that are rather tricky, and if you fail it's only a chance to do it again, to better handle the lightning based character's actions.

....I need to play more of this, have just started it but felt compelled to write a review anyway - it's with no doubt a game which quality stays faithful to the first one's,and once again glad this game came out. Just a tiny bit puzzled this game doesn't have more reviews - but it might be logical, as another metroidvania of the same sort (Rusted Moss) was released just one week before, and Teslagrad 2's release might have been a bit overshadowed by Rusted Moss' one; I hope in any case that Teslagrad 2 meets some good success because it would be frankly deserved. A followup worthy of praise, beautiful.

A game never learn from their mistakes a decade ago...

The good side first: great art, lovely character, intrigue world-building, and speechless storytelling!

But that's not what make (any) game become a good game. No. Games need "gameplay" in order to make it memorable/enjoyable!

And that's what lack from this title.

Admittedly, the core idea of the game that explore "electromagnetic" mechanic is charming. Build a platforming world with north/south magnetic field here and there, while let the player to switch on/off their character became a psudo-magnetic object in order to solve the puzzle. Sound fun and challenging and have a lot of potential interesting levels. Implementing it right and the game might join the greatest puzzles of all time club (notable members: Fez, Portal, Baba is You, Patrick's Parabox, etc).

However, this game ruin the opportunity. Even with the second chance.

The magnetic mechanic itself is so clunky! Yes, the physics was implemented realistically, e.g., jumping is projectile. But does the game [i]really[/i] need that realistic aspect, like putting realistic first and player intention later (not to mention that the control is not tight at all)? Combined with the continuously coordination and curved platforming everywhere, now each jump is crucial since a slightly different initial angle/position result in huge different outcome momentum. Which the game take a sadistic path that require you to make perfect jump and maintain correct momentum multiple times in a row.

Furthermore, a room in this game is too large with too less checkpoints. A misjump at the last part of the platforming section will cost you a minute, because now you need to redo everything from start of the room, again.

The annoying platforming is one thing. But boss fights take the frustration to another level.

Basically, you have 1 HP.

Really? In 2023??? When other games in the industry concern about accessibility and have option to subdued these frustration, let player enjoy the game the way they like. (And, maybe, after they beat the game once, they might comeback for the intentional experience later!)

Duck, even Dark Souls allows mistakes!!!

Honestly, whose the target audience of this amazing world-building but punishing gameplay?
[list]
[*] You like platforming? Then Celeste will teach you what is tight control.
[*] You like mind-blowing puzzle? Baba is You, Patrick's Parabox, Stephen's Sausage Roll!
[*] You like sit-back-and-relax metroidvania? Try Toki Tori 2+.
[*] You like epic-boss-fight metroidvania? Metroid, Castlevania, Hollow Knight.
[*] You like a combination of all above? Definitely Tunic!
[/list]

I don't understand why the developer [i]must[/i] develop a game this [i]frustrating[/i] (in a bad way). I don't wanna even use the word "hard" or "challenging", because the game is unforgivably difficult to the point that it is not fair to play the game anymore.

So, if you enjoy torturing yourself, like playing Getting Over It (by yourself, not just watching YouTuber screaming in pain). Then this game might be perfect for you.

I'm not much for mobile-style games, so I wasn't already experienced in this type of game. 
I got the demo a few days before release, and I was genuinely impressed by this game even before acquiring the full version.
It takes Bejeweled and does a good job, in my opinion, of "rogue-liking" it.

In specific, gameplay requires that you master the manipulation of the board, because every enemy has a different way of being killed,
and builds can be coherent (i.e. have particular strengths and weaknesses depending on your spell loadout and relic quantities).

In general, it has the Slay the Spire-esque magic recipe of relying on experience and memorization, while also requiring on-the-spot thinking, making every run unique.
And there's still a great deal of development potential and refining to be done, so this is an affordable and worthwhile pick for people who pop into early access games and play them whenever they're updated.

9/10 for me 

._.

Bear in mind, this review is coming from the perspective of a Sylas main, so this game basically had to butcher the personality of the characters in order to lose me. That being said, this game is very fun. The game feels well paced story wise, as I never felt like I needed to take a break or was "grinding". 

THE COMBAT
I played this game on the hard difficulty. The gameplay reminded me a lot of HADES, but with less customization, not a roguelike, and the unique twist of stealing magic. It's very fast, with enough mobility that I could totally see somebody beating this game with no damage taken. That being said, the game is very aware of this, and often forces you to use your mobility to survive attacks, either from grappling to far away enemies/landmarks, or spam dashing to escape a chasing projectile. 
I said there was less customization compared to HADES, but really, it's just different. You aren't in a roguelike, so your loadout is exactly what you make it. You can customize up to four spells you have equipped at all times, varying from AOE damage, healing, simple projectiles, or even utility such as invisibility. About mid-way you also get an empowered state, which comes with your choice of an ultimate. There are 6 ultimates, and each of them have atleast SOME advantage over the others. I only ever used 4, but I do feel the other 2 had their purpose, and someone else would probably find a use for them. You can also spend your currency on base increases to defense, health, physical damage, and magic damage, so there is some variance you can put on your playstyle, though I would be surprised if anyone focused on physical damage, given the game's nature. 
The enemies varied from interesting to mildly annoying. There is one enemy that you have to bring to the ground just to hit them, and with my upgrades at the time I had to do this twice in order to bring one down, leading to me just never targeting them first and accepting the damage they cause. There's also a couple of enemies that have weird damage hitboxes, and I still don't know how one of them works. With all of that out of the way, the rest of the enemies were generally intriguing. A lot of the enemies had attack variants that were fun to interact with, such as the early game wind mages buffing allies, and using their magic to kill their allies was just beyond satisfying.

THE STORY
Avoiding spoilers, the story was good. None of the league characters were butchered or ruined really, and a lot of them were actually made much better in my eyes. The original characters were also mostly delightful, with only a couple that I didn't like, but they weren't overbearing by any means, so it wasn't a problem. 
The story also didn't feel meaningless, as, despite being at a previous point in the Runeterra universe compared to now, it added a lot of lore, and one of the revelations was very exciting to me. It does make the warriors cinematic/freljordian raid on demacia feel a little confusing, but it's not like they made it impossible, and I wouldn't be surprised if it made more sense to somebody who is more of a lore buff than I.

THE ART
This game's artwork is phenomenal. I don't think I've seen this beautiful of pixel art in a game PERIOD. Every spell looks cool as hell, and the game's contrasting colors meant that I almost always could tell what was going on in a fight, with the exception of maybe one enemy. The sound design was also impressive, even if they re-used a lot of sounds from league. I am very picky with sound design, and have often left games just because of it being badly done, but this game knocked it out of the park.

CONCLUSION
Overall, I'd give this game a 9/10 for anyone who is interested in Sylas/playing Sylas as a character, a 8/10 for anyone interested in the league universe, and a 6/10 for anyone who just wants an action RPG. The game's biggest drawback is it's length vs price, but I don't regret my money spent whatsoever, since I was enjoying every minute of it. That being said, if you aren't interested in the league universe, and just want it as a beautiful action rpg, then I'd wait for a sale, maybe 30% off or so.

I am immediately in love with Moons of Darsalon! This is probably the first modern game I've played in a long time that really packs a retro feel.  It has probably the most perfect 90's arcade vibe of anything I have played in years and years, like spot-on.  A 30-minute session of this, and suddenly it's Summer, 1992, and we're killing time pumping quarters into Strike Force at Darien Lake while we wait for the laser light show to start...  The visual and audio theming is spot-on, it's absolutely terrific. Dev, I see how you even added little music-sync'd pauses into the post-level screen dancer's routines, that's absolutely charming.

As far as gameplay, I've spent a few hours jet-packing and leaping around and learning not to bonk my head on things.  I appreciate that so far the levels have been fairly short time-wise, which fits well with my limited gaming time.  The levels are timed, but I can take as long as I like and be as methodical or idiotic as I like.   The terrain destruction/creation, and the ability to issue simple commands to your evacuees add an interesting element to things.  There are even vehicles to drive!  This was a bought-it-as-soon-as-I-saw-it game, and I don't regret it one bit, I can't wait to see what fresh mayhem awaits next!

As much as it pains me to say, since I think this VN has a lot of heart so far, I cannot recommend this in good faith, at least in its current state.

You see, while the main selling point of this game is the fact that it is about otokonoko, as in, crossdressing men, it really just isn't. The characters are exclusively referred to as "she", "her", "girls", etc., only going "Haha but they're boys though" in one single passing line every couple hours to remind you since you'll inevitably forget. This is, 99.9% of of the time, just a hetero maid cafe visual novel about women, which is not what they advertise themselves as.

You might be thinking "Maybe it's supposed to be about trans girls", but one look at any of the promotional material will probably dispel that. Even in-game, they use the terms "crossdresser", "otokonoko", and "boy" *just* enough to where it would be pretty uncomfortable if that was the intent.

It kills me, because I was looking forward to this game for over a year. I was really hoping this would be an oasis in the barren wasteland of English otokonoko themed games, but it was just a mirage. I'll probably see it through to the end, and should the devs end up patching this issue, I'd be more than happy to give this the glowing review I wish I could be typing, but as it stands this game is, frankly, not at all what it's selling itself as, and degenerate homosexuals like me, it'll just be a disappointment.

This game makes hotline miami feel like a puzzle game. Fantastic game! If you liked hotline miami, but really wanted to go on more of a rampage, this is the game for you.

One of the most immediately captivating and extraordinarily slick roguelites I've encountered in some time. The premise is simple: kick down door, mow down enemies, rinse and repeat. And really, what more do you need?

The core gameplay feel is much like Hotline Miami: equal parts tactical planning and twitchy clutch maneuver, plus the occasional spray-and-pray. A time-slowing mechanic present in the game makes pulling off those hairpin strategies a bit easier, but you can pretty much ignore it if you'd rather rely solely on your guns to do the talking. And, speaking of guns, they all feel absolutely FANTASTIC, which great haptic feedback from vibration (I've been playing with a controller). Also notable is that they SOUND incredibly satisfying (no puny Enter the Gungeon pea shooters here), with meaty sound design to enhance the sense of power. This is all backed up by a pulse-pounding soundtrack. Seriously, the music is sick -- you'll get absolutely amped as the beat pulses beneath the hail of gunfire and occasional explosion.

Of course, the roguelite structure means some key changes from the Hotline Miami base. For one, you don't die in a single hit; you have a much more forgiving health bar that refills after clearing each room (more akin to a floor), and you can boost your health and get some sustain through items as well. It's a necessary change to support the run-based (rather than mission-based) formula. And, of course, there are those aforementioned items (called liquors in-game): you start each run with a free item from a randomized choice of three, and every two or so rooms, you'll encounter the shop, where you can buy pretty much as many as you can afford. Needless to say, you can rack up quite a handful of items relatively quickly, and fast, stylish gameplay rewards you with more money via a combo multiplier. It's worth noting that the items themselves are well-designed, too: exploding corpses, reflecting bullets, health leeching attacks, get-out-of-death-free iframes, and more good stuff like that. Roguelite fans who love to accrue a ton of cool passive upgrades (myself included) will be very happy with this dynamic, and, to sweeten the pot, there are plenty of unlockable liquors as well.

In short: you simply must check out this game. Even in my short playtime, I can tell this is something special. Blazing-fast pacing, incredible gunplay, stellar sound design, and meaningful progression make this an incredibly easy game to recommend.

I will begin this review by stating upon the removal of the accidental (fucking hopefully) this review will become a recommend with a few asterisks, but still a very high recommend. Now for the actual review which was sent previously in the suggestions channel of the game discord.

First, incredibly fun game. I really enjoy it. I do however think it has a pretty extreme identity problem. While initially everything seemed to work well, some jank and weirdness I will comment on shortly, I really enjoyed it. But then I died. I expected to be sent back to the main menu, or to a replay screen, or some sort of rogue-light element regarding boosts in between games. To be honest I thought the game was a rogue like. However, to my surprise, I spawned back in! This came as a shock, but I kept playing, and it all just felt empty. 

The limited world generation has been commented on previously, however the fact that when you die you have to  go through all of it a second, and even third time, makes the situation even worse. I knew what the, admittedly limited, buildings were like already, and so any reason to return to any of them instead of either running  straight to a marked point or to my death locale is removed by that fact. That then leads to two other issues I have with the game currently: first, that the marking of locations of useful items on the map is not a great system just at a foundational level (I can try to explain this is you'd like however I feel it is kinda self explanatory. Chore list instead of exploration kinda vibes) and second, the stamina system. As I've only played about three hours of the game this night at this point I may be missing what previous versions of the stamina system looked like, however as it is right now the stamina system, while it works perfectly in combat (IMO), only slows down the entire game outside of combat.

I think it's worth going into the stamina bar a bit more as, considering the design choices you've made with the bosses, the dodge roll, and everything else, you are going for a dark souls type vibe. This is wonderful and makes me super excited to see what the boss battles look like in the future! However, let's take a look at these games you're (this is an assumption so correct me if I'm wrong) referencing. Elden Ring, incredible system for physical combat, but when traversing the map you can ride Torrent! Dark Souls III/Sekiro, the campfire/sculptor systems act as portals across the large worlds. Now, obviously, that sort of fast travel would go against the entire ethos of this game, however I bring them up because each example is showing a way to differentiate out of combat, and in combat, movement. And currently, the out of combat movement options are extremely limited. What doesn't help this is the fact that stamina is used extremely fast while running, and the only way, to my current understanding, to recharge it is soda or water which if you run out of, you're basically just done!

So, combining the lack of engaging aspects to stamina, and the multiple lives. Taking into account the (current) lack of interesting locations, and the (assumed) goal for a repeatable game loop. I believe that the multi-life aspect is currently very negative for the game. Every time you respawn you are either running from marked '?' to marked '?' hoping you get a strong enough weapon to just grab your old gear, and on the way if you don't pick up enough soda or water you're just fucked! So, you replay from your Home to wherever you died, possibly on the other side of the island, running through already picked and labyrinthian houses. To be honest, at this point, I just start a new world each time I die. I of course have neglected to mention the respawning of loot till now, however I feel if anything it's requirement as a system is only a symptom of the respawn system. I don't believe it actually adds anything to the game's experience.

This is all not to say that the almost arcade-like approach cannot work or be fun. It's just the current build of the game does not support it. Maybe you add a hardcore mode in the future making the whole above section optional. Maybe (and hopefully) the world is continually added to and expanded, adding more interesting things to explore on the way, the houses more clearly built, zombies more interesting to fight, and likely more stuff you have planned I don't even know about! This also applies to stamina, I'm sure all the numbers are currently subject to change and maybe something like natural stamina regen will be added in the future. However I think currently the fact you don't restart after each death is highly damaging to the entire game loop and honestly enjoyment killing for me at least (note again, I've just been restarting fresh after each death).

Okay, I think that's all I can say when it comes to the respawn factor. Now, other stuff:
**The zombies** overall are fine, nothing bad nothing great, hitboxes can be kinda weird in CQC but I'd assume that's on purpose for melee to be needed (which while we're on the topic I feel melee could use a bit of a damage buff, but maybe I'm not actually hitting my attacks).

**The bosses** are fine, the ones I've currently beaten (the cop and the queen) are both wonderful! The main issue is just the fact that both of them (in initial stages especially) rely super heavily on movement, which is a great thing, if only the movement wasn't so buggy they got caught on each and every little corner. The Queen gets stuck easily in the stairwell for instance, and I don't think I even need to give examples for the cop.

**The guns** are all wonderful, I love using them all. I think the variety is fine and the ammo spread is good too. If I could critique here I would just comment on spawning again. The '?' ping system is bad. Maybe have more recognizable spawning locations like in gun lockers or something, just don't mark them on the map. Again, something that could be fixed by removing respawns. Ammo wise I think the rates are all a bit low rn (or maybe I'm just unlucky). There's been a couple runs now where I just kept searching for ammo, but would end up just running to question marks to unload the guns there for 
measly handfuls of ammo (which was admittedly pretty fun, just not for long)

**The world** is a work in progress. I like the ideas behind it all, I just have one comment. When using imagery to bring across topics such as fascism, while fictional or made up characters or people are fine, using a picture of a nazi officer taken straight off of google is not a great idea. Especially when there is (currently) no real method to my knowledge of learning the plot you are trying to put across. I get what you're going for, but that's just not the way. If anything lean more into the already created police station building, expand police imagery, add some more proper fasho-1984-police combinations. Now that would be unique in the world of video games we exist in. (Just to expand on this point, I did not recognize the picture, multiple people on the steam community page did and then uninstalled the game. I see the use of this  imagery negatively, however ignoring my perspective this is actively harming the player-base)

**Multiplayer** god I'm sure it's gonna be so fun when it's easier to play with my friends. Very excited.
**Graphics** fine, nothing to write home about.
**Sound** Guns all sound great, otherwise no comments.

I think I got all my ideas out there, I want to finish by stating that again I recognize that this is an alpha build. Obviously everything is subject to change, I just hope my suggestions may assist in making you (especially you as an individual developer) have to make less changes total to reach a quality product. I really really really enjoy the game already, and I hope that's evident because I just spent over an hour writing an extremely long discord "essay" on my suggestions and thoughts.

This game has really good moment to moment gameplay. Mechanics like charging powerups, dash slamming enemies, grinding on rails, and using unique character abilities is fun, and the game very much feels like a combat racer. And, the music in the levels ranges from okay to amazing. BUT, the monetization in this game is complete and total garbage. The game has basically a billion different upgrade currencies, racers have levels that effect their stats, racers are unlocked through a shard system, with you also needing to collect more shards to increase a character's power and rarity (the base version of every character doesn't even have their unique ability), and the game has loot boxes (which I thought we have gotten past as a medium but apparently not). The later sections of the starter circuits in the game don't even give you the character that you need to start them, you just have to hope that you'll get enough shards for the necessary character through loot boxes. On top of that, levels and rarity levels can be important, and competitive races can be dominated by people with high level, high rarity characters (ranked also has a meta, as Mike Wazowski is way overpowered, which is a sentence I never thought I'd write). The game does have a 'regulated' ranked mode where all racers have the same level, but the rewards for that mode are heavily limited. If you want to unlock anything, you have to play in a basically pay to win ranked mode. What's even funnier and dumber is that in the game's current 'early access' (or just normal release for suckers like me who paid) you can't even spend money so your progression is just arbitrarily locked. This game can be really fun, but in its current state it feels like a parody of every crappy free-to-play system designed to annoy people into spending money. And if the developers don't fix that, I don't think this game has a future, which is sad, because again, I really do like some things about this game.

If I had to title this review, I would call it "Too Bad Playing Through The First Route Took Me More Than 2 Hours So I Couldn't Get A Refund."

I agree with the other negative review that talks about this not feeling like the type of game it is advertised as - this feels like playing a heterosexual visual novel through and through. There's barely any of the "Girls!?" part in this game, it almost never comes up that these are boys cross-dressing in a maid cafe - they're always referred to as "she" and "girls" and by the end I was just bored, waiting for anything interesting to happen. Not to mention, the fact that this game is already so expensive and any "exciting" (adult) parts are gated behind an off-site paywall is ridiculous. 
It took me 3 hours to play one route - and that's me taking it slow, saving at the seemingly-important questions because I am a save-scummer in these type of games, going back to see what the other options were, hoping that I was maybe just missing the interesting options the first time around and I'd eventually find something worth continuing to play this game for - and I got more bored and more disappointed the longer I played.
And what's more - the "girls" barely have personalities to speak of, all whiny/abrasive and not very endearing, and the character you play as is pretty pathetic. (Not that that's especially rare in these types of games, I know no one plays these games for the MC, but it just makes for a more annoying experience on top of everything else). The plot is also VERY melodramatic, maybe if I cared about any of the characters I would care about what happened to them, but again, I really did not expect to sit down with this game and get nagged about the complexities of keeping a cafe open, I just wanted to have fun and see cute guys in cute outfits... like was advertised in all the marketing.
I realize maybe I over-hyped this game in my mind, but with so little of these types of games to choose from, so much advertising from the developer, and such a long time of seeing it sitting on my Wish List and looking forward to it, I can't help but feel let down by the final product. And I feel like I'm pretty lenient with my judgement because I WANT more games like this to exist - just fun, silly, lascivious romps for people who like cute guys to sit down and enjoy for a few hours. But at this price point, for what you get v.s. what is advertised, I say save your money. Or if you really just like to look at characters in maid outfits and pretend they're boys even though every line of dialogue in the game practically tells you otherwise, then go for it.

I went into this game expecting to really like it. After playing it for about 20 minutes, I had a pretty disappointing first impression because I didn't understand some basic aspects of the game like the prevalence of directional command normals that make up most of the chains/gatlings. However, after about an hour of play, the game ended up really clicking and my boyfriend and I played it for like 3 hours straight! The characters are inspired and feel kusoge levels of powerful while keeping a tight, directed design. The juggle system (including DI!) feels more like a platform fighter than a traditional 2D fighter and makes converting hits really engaging and satisfying. I like Yellow so much that I want to go around and ask people if there are any other characters that feel like he does, but I know that none of the answers will be satisfying. Definitely going to play this game some more, especially if some of the 14 players online right now are in matchmaking. The game's free, try it out. Press Green's 2A. It'll click.

So I gave this game shot having gotten a key from the devs.  At first glance the game bears some similarities to Vampire Survivors but realistically thats just the upgrade system.  Overall it feels better to be able to target enemies directly.

The Good:
- Absolutely amazing artwork, the before level screens honestly the vibes of this game are tremendous.
-Storytelling is really good, has gigantic 80's vibes.  Definitely think the openers on levels are very fun.
-Gameplay loop is satisfying, if you like mowing down hordes of people you'll be right at home here.
-Character design is awesome, I love my clown wife,
-Enemy design, is that a murder toaster, hell yeah brother.  Really cool stuff going on here, I don't want to spoil much but you won't be let down in this department.

The Eh:
- Sometimes I felt directionless, the maze level which to the games credit I didn't finish felt repetitive I think some sort of identifier to help feel like you're progressing.  Versus something like the city levels which feel like you're making progress.
-I'd like to have a retry button on the game over screen.  As cool as the story parts are it's definitely time consuming when you're trying to get used to a level even with skipping.

I had a phenomenal time overall, definitely a great game to vibe out to.  Definitely recommend it if you're looking into a game to chill out and play.

Liking it so far... I will say that the combat can be annoying.  The combat moves from most enemies are hard to see the telegraphs and it makes it more frustrating than your average souls game is.  A lot of them will use the same start to an animation and then switch it up at the last second to do a delayed move thus causing a missed parry.  It becomes really frustrating instead of fun.  Take this with a grain of salt because my reflexes are slowing as I age so this could just be me needing to git gud.  One of the first hard enemies killed me like 30 times.  It was "harder" than elden ring or even sekiro.

Beyond some of my frustration with the combat moves I like the game a lot.  The story is good so far, the environments are cool.  Despite my earlier comments on combat I actually still enjoy the fighting, it can just be frustrating sometimes.  The game is performing great, no issues, but I have a really good cpu and gpu.

Really enjoying the game so far.  Definitely worth the $30 price tag.

I am thoroughly enjoying my time with Hope's End so far. The gameplay loop is fun and the amount of challenges/unlocks to achieve is staggering, I am constantly thinking "How many mutators can I enable safely?"
A mutator is a score multiplier that modifies the difficulty in some way. The more mutators, the greater the challenge as well as the score.
Some unlocks are gained by achieving victory with a certain high score so this is definitely a requirement to get those.
Apart from that, the sheer array of differing playstyles is greatly appreciated. I cannot wait to play as the Plague specialization!

I am giving this game a positive review in part due to the price. If it were more expensive I would have expected far better art/UI and just overall polish. I know it is a small team and early access, but those things did immediately stand out. 

Having said that, I am glad I bought the game. The gameplay loop quickly got me hooked on upgrading the Armory and Research and unlocking new things. I am a sucker for progress, unlocks, prestige and all that crap. I was looking for a game where I can just blow off steam after work without being stressed out or PVPing and this is scratching that itch for me. Kinda like VS but I like the power creep and progression this has for me to chase

It is extremely rare I do any reviews, but I've been following the development of this game for quite a bit, and honestly, it is one of my favorite indie horror games i've played. Anyways queue the rambling from your local indie horror fanatic! 

If you've enjoyed things such as Iron Lung, and other games that give you that looming feeling that something is following you, you'll love this one. The atmosphere is great, and along with the early PS1 style graphics, it makes for more second guessing if you actually saw something or if your eyes are playing tricks on you. 
Even without constant in your face scares, this game creates such a tense environment (I found myself stalling a few times because I was afraid to turn the camera or go down a cave passage).

I always admire a really put together story with horror games, as you can get more immersed and feel things closer to home- and this story did just that even coupled with the unnerving out there aspects of the story. Some games leave you on too much of a cliff hanger and don't really provide enough information for you to piece together theories, but this one allows for so much theory-crafting! (Lore nerds, you'll enjoy this one!)

Mechanics and sound made everything so much more eerie, there is something about dated technology that just adds to the horror element all together!

I could go on, but this is seriously a good short solid play! I had such a blast streaming this with my chat, and they got a few good scares too!

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I never played the first desktop dungeons but this is one of my favorite puzzle games in a long time. It's so satisfying beating a run and while it looks like a D&D style roguelike, it really is more of a game of puzzles and resource management. When I lose I feel like a fool and when I win I feel like a genius. Regardless of what happens though, I'm hitting the button to do another run IMMEDIATELY after I finish one. Great game with nearly infinite replayability from what I can see.

Game has a lot of good qualities. I've played through all the game has to offer and there are many parts I do enjoy. It has good music, lore, Some parts of the combat feel pretty fluid and fun(other parts don't). Enemies are just diverse enough to keep the game from becoming monotonous and boring. 

Unfortunately this game has a good number of flaws. I don't blame Digital Sun for the narrative issues, as riot didn't give them the easiest of characters to craft into a hero. But there are several interfaces and interactions that are quite clunky(see below) not to mention a ton of bugs from making enemies un-targetable, to you yourself freezing in place. The only fix I've found for these bugs is quitting and reloading, and when that happens 4+ times in your session it gets pretty frustrating. Combine all this with the fact that some of the game's spells are locked behind paid DLC when $30 is already asking a lot for this product imo, and you get a game I just can't in good faith recommend to everyone

Your character's dash becomes pretty frustrating in combat. If the developers didn't want you to go through terrain with this dash that's their choice(perhaps Hades is just spoiling me) but instead if there is any terrain in your dashing direction it catches you and holds you in place instead of at least nudging you around it. You have to be very careful in combat as often times this dash of yours can hurt you as much as the enemies you are facing

Also the button for dash is the same button as skip dialogue, if you dash into a cut-scene trigger point you will automatically skip dialogue, so change that button config as soon as you can if you care about the story.

There was definitely a lot of care and love put into this game but in its current condition I would say either wait for a patch to rough out the kinks and make your experience more enjoyable, or if you can catch it on sale for at least 15%-20% off. Feels a lot like Riot might have rushed this one out before it was completely ready, which is sad, and I hope this trend doesn't continue with the other indie games riot is funding.

As a guy who grew up playing Starcraft 1 & 2, this isn't the best RTS out there but it's trying... sorta

This game has its issues, like I feel like the campaign could use a little more variety in some things like random events of some sort to spice it up other then, Siege a base and Defend a village.

The unit variety is fine but could use some more stuff like maybe they could bring in the Iron Golem for some sort of Heavy Infantry like unit or add the spiders. Small thing but it can be better.

I wish the player character had more upgrades for them specifically, like your gonna be in the heat of battle most of the time so why not add an unlock-able ranged attack option or the ability to repair buildings with an upgrade. small things to let the player interact with their base and world more ya know? of course I understand that some of those mechanics might get delegated to campaign only but hey, can make campaign more interesting atleast.

Multiplayer has some Desync issues here and there but its not the worst and happens rarely for me.

I do see the problem and dislike for the Cosmetic store and I do agree its not a great thing but in the long term its not the worst thing here, its all optional cosmetics and can be ignored if you wish.

The worse thing with the game imo is the fact the game has too little content for it to be worth 40$. The campaign is not super long and pretty repetitive. I feel like they ride on the fact its a randomly generated world on each new save a bit much, while that adds some replayability, its not a great value with the campaign in its current state.

As for the PvP, I haven't done that yet so I wont leave an opinion here as it wouldn't be right.

But despite its problems, its still pretty damn fun for me as a casual. Its far from perfect but the Campaign being co-op is really fun and I enjoy coordinating sieges with my friends.

Though are if you want to buy it, wait until its on sale imo. 15-20$ I feel is what its proper price should be with its current content. Overtime I'm sure they will add more things but if those are required to make the game feel worth the 40$, the game shoulda been delayed a bit.

P.S. I do recommend reading other reviews, you were probably already gonna do that but I just want to ensure you get informed of any other pros and cons the game has.

An absolute brilliant sequel to the original, that continues directly from it and repeats what the original game did well and thus gives more of it in return.

It's still just as fun as ever and has great dark humour, voice acting (which was a pleasant surprise) and thus plenty new characters to interact with, a LOT of creativity and great scenarios, but also more abuse of "logic" or "suspension of disbelief" but who cares when something is this much fun and such a unique experience?

I just discovered the predecessor to this wonderful sequel is 4 years old at least and honestly, I would love to see more sequels to this series now! Even if it takes another 4 years! I had my eye on the original and finally tried on a whim and really enjoyed it, feeling very satisfied with the whole experience after completing it too and thus shown in my review of it too.

I really like the new scenarios in this one, you get some absolutely devilish setups and "toys" to play with. It's still quite a cerebral experience but not stupidly difficult or so. It's still very meticulous to the final level especially but its so well crafted, so lovingly designed, that it just feels a solid part of the experience and not frustrating or tedious at all.

I enjoyed the levels from this one even more than the original and there were some very fun and funny outcomes too. There's also a lot more achievements to get this time round, a LOT more than I expected and if replaying missions didn't reset your progress in them (you lose your 100% completion for them if you replay them), I would be more keen to try to get the rest of the achievements too.

This series kinda feels like Hitman as a puzzle game (I don't mean Hitman Go but that kinda fits too) and it's such a unique and surprisingly fun experience. It does make you think and you have to be so utterly careful/precise but the game is very forgiving and even if you complete a level and you leave some evidence behind (even just like an open cabinet door), the game will tell you what you missed and let you continue the level from where the issue was and be able to get your 100% clean result, much quicker and more easier too. I believe the original game does this too, which is just a great choice by the developers and makes the game much better for it too.

This is absolutely worth the money anyway, fantastic value for money and I would GLADLY by more of these games and keep supporting these devs, as this is such an all round enjoyable and satisfying game and product, just like the original, that I am truly EAGER to see more of the same by them too!

Also my playtime is much higher than it should be due to going AFK a lot. But there's a solid few hours of gameplay here, give or take depending how easily you solve the puzzles/scenarios of course and if you get a perfect run the first time too or not.

I'm hesitant about recommending this game.  On one hand, it works just fine.  There's no bugs I've found, the content is exactly as described and it's good enough fun.  On the other, it's very light on content.  A couple of hours will let you see everything the game has, and then it's just another 8-10 hours to get the last achievement.  If the dev adds content, then it could be great, but if he leaves it as is, it will only ever be okay.

This is a great wargame! I already enjoyed their previous title, Red Storm, so I was happy to see improvements such as multi-monitor support, colour/contrast adjustments, more tables, detailed intel notes, and everything else I needed to feel like the commander of NATO or Warsaw Pact force. I‚Äôd love it if they could integrate the old title into this version!

Already I‚Äôve played two scenarios, ‚ÄòSteel Rain‚Äô and ‚ÄòCrossing the Waldnaab‚Äô, both of which I managed slight victories. The former was more conventional to what I‚Äôm used to in ‚Äòwhat if‚Äô WW3 battles: Stemming the overwhelming onslaught of fast moving Soviet tanks with just a handful of M1A1s, enough tools to find good cover, concealment, and LOS, then corking their advance. Top it off with M109A2s dropping artillery on their heads.

But the second scenario was quite different! I defended a key road/rail network hub against a quick Czech attack using equally fast moving West German recon troops. Though I was outnumbered, I knew if I could conceal them well, and stall them just long enough, an attack chopper & a few Leopards would arrive from Reserve and turn the tide. And they did! Very satisfying to set it up and execute.

This is an asymmetrical turn-based wargame that relies heavily on how orders are given from an HQ, received by their subunits, and the time it takes for information to pass between them. Once commands are issued, the player watches the gameplay progress without the ability to interrupt those actions (just a pause function) until the turn is over. New turns happen after a changeable amount of minutes based on real world factors (e.g quality of communications, experience, jamming) to give new orders or adjust existing ones.

If you‚Äôve enjoyed games like Steel Panthers, Strategic Command, Combat Mission, and Armored Brigade, then this will feel familiar. But if you‚Äôre more into World in Conflict, Wargame, or anything remotely RTS, know that Southern Storm is deep-dive simulation with a deliberate pace and loads of ‚Äòunder the hood‚Äô details.

So far I love it! It‚Äôs not the kind of game that probably does well on Steam, but I hope a few more cold war nerds give it a try. The only negative I have right now are performance related. Turning on any of the terrain tools, or using them in addition to moving a unit, nearly crashes the client from a system hang. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs a rendering or cpu crunch, but it happens when looking at the %cover, %mobility, elevation kind of layers.

The game didn't really click together until I died the first time, then everything neatly fell into place. You have to really calculate everything out, if you just brute force attack everything it doesn't usually work out. It definitely has that "one more run" feeling until suddenly you're playing it at 3am. I recommend it, if for nothing else than being a pretty good time killer.

I emailed the developer and asked for a game key to showcase the game on my Twitch channel that barely exists. I was going to buy this game anyway, but I got a reply a few minutes later. As such, I gifted this title to a friend who I thought would enjoy it. This in no way effects my review or opinion of the game.

This game is a joy to play.

Fluid, precise movement and tight combat alone sells this game. The dodge mechanic is particularly awesome. First of all, it is an i-frame. Second, the enemy tells are actually good, you can see what's happening. Third, and my personal favorite, if you dodge JUST before getting hit, you do a really cool counter attack. It's a dodge and a riposte of sorts at the same time. It's fantastic.

The story is cute. I think that while some of the translations are a bit off and the voice acting isn't Hollywood quality it somehow fits into the world the game tries to create and a has charm to it. Speaking of, there are many unlocks, and some of these include gifting other characters items found during the run. This unlocks boons to equip at the start of a run. Many other unlocks exist, but because of the tight combat you may not need to max everything before you win a run. I haven't done so yet, by the way.

There is a rhythm mechanic in the game, but it is not a huge one, so don't let this deter you. Basically, every fourth beat, you can do your heavy attack. If you get it right, it does an extension of what it would otherwise do. The beat is consistent enough to time (I'm not superb at rhythm games and I can get it), but there's a small bar next to the attack in the bottom of the screen UI that fills up, indicating the beats and the timing. While this may seem out of place, with the timed parry riposte, the tight platforming, and the good enemy tells, it actually fits in quite well. The game's combat is not souls-like, but it is also not a mash fest. It's a delicate balance that let me relax enough to enjoy myself, but stay alert enough to satisfy the craving of a challenge. 

The rooms themselves don't offer exploration (a big positive for me, I'm tired of huge areas to explore, personally), it's just light platforming and the great combat that I mentioned. This game succeeds in just about everything it tries, in my opinion. If you go in with a mindset of playing a fun game, you'll find that here.

Amazing first impression from the content already there.  Lot of combat systems and roguelike elements to keep each run interesting and playing to unlock more. Indulge me, dear reader, as I regale you with the most unforgettable and breathtaking experience that I recently had with the latest addition to the Steam gaming realm, Hyperhell. This game is not your ordinary shooter rogue-like game, it is a mesmerizing, heart-pumping journey into an otherworldly, neon-hued abyss that left me speechless.

Let us begin with the music, oh the music! The pulsating beats of hyperpop artists Fraxiom and Gupi, have been masterfully woven into the very fabric of this game. The combination of music and gameplay is nothing short of a symphony, for it results in a thrilling adventure that transcends the boundaries of mere mortals.

The gameplay is exceptional. Hyperhell's intensity is not for the faint of heart; it necessitates precision and lightning-fast reactions. The experience, however, is nothing short of heavenly. (once you've mastered the controls). Each level is an artful creation,  with challenging enemies, mind-bending obstacles (cobwebs), and power-ups galore, keeping you on the edge of your seat.

Yet, what truly sets Hyperhell apart from the rest is its unparalleled art direction. The vibrant, neon-infused visuals are a feast for the eyes. The menacing enemies, pulsating backgrounds, and the fine attention to detail in every element of this game are truly a sight to behold

In conclusion, dear reader, I must confess that Hyperhell is a game that defies classification. It is an artful masterpiece, expertly crafted and executed with precision and care. Its electrifying music from the "best artists in the entire world" (~Anthony Fantano), heart-pumping gameplay, and magnificent visuals make it a game deserving of everyone's time and attention. Do not hesitate, for Hyperhell is a rare gem that you cannot afford to miss!

I really want to love this game, but at the moment I can't recommend it, as the balance during mid game just falls apart.  Research points are randomly generated, so if you have bad RNG, you won't get the points you need to upgrade your tech.  Money is directly tied to Science missions in mid-game and without good RNG you can't bring back enough researchables to turn into patents.  Once your economy starts slipping, it's a downward spiral with no recovery.  The "Squarbs?" attack too often and are too powerful.  This could be counteracted by having additional soldiers, but without a better economy to pay for them, they are easily overwhelmed and killed.
unlegendary

The game is fun and quite alright if you turn your brain off. However, for a single player experience, it ends quite quickly, with the endgame empty and bugged out. I'm sure lost legends is there to keep you entertained (till you finish that once).

Regarding the multiplayer experience, pvp seems to be the only draw gameplay loop wise. However, in that aspect players will realise the limited amount of units and structures don't really make the game very diverse. Players will run the bare minimum and still succeed in their siege. (Stone golems just eat through defences if you arent bothered with going with anything else that requires more resources)

Overall, the game's campaign opens up some lore elements which is cool if you're a fan of the series. However, if you are here for the siege and RTS aspects, the game has quite a large shoe to fill on that front. I do hope the game adds much more content, maybe making non-hostile mobs more viable and interesting. I understand that some mobs are likely not going to be implemented due to lore and what's canon. However, the game definitely lacks variety as of now.

The price tag for the state of the current game is not worth. That's a fact, however, if you're willing to invest in a brief experience and pray that the developers push the game to a better state, try it out!

I'm not gonna lie... I played Factory town and quickly became bored so when I saw Factory town IDLE I suspected it would be the same deal but in an everlasting quest to find more stuff to fill my screen with whilst working on coding projects as a form of distraction from finding the ; in a sea of :'s some 5 euro's isn't a big deal...

I found something that truly enraptured me...and have it on my screen ever since I bought it.

Factory Town Idle is a LOT like Kitten's Game and I played that game to death... you start of as any clicker... click a bush to get some wood, use the wood to build a house, assign the worker you get from that house to farm the wood for you, build more houses...

But like Kitten's game the game slowly expands and puts layers upon layers upon more layers of game mechanics. That wood can be made into paper to do research with... or plaks to build more advanced buildings, maybe traded to another village to get them started, sold to the market for money, burned to made coal.... and that's just a snippet for wood (which is maybe 1 of some 30 resources you need to manage)

Factory Town Idle has that distinct honor of turning from an engaging clicker game, into an idler, into a resource management game.... only to have a townspecific upgrade, improvement and even prestige system to be layered on top of that.

If you're a fan of idlers or resource management games then pay this dev some cash... for it's current listing the game is theft with YOU being the thief....
and if you're a fan of Kitten's Game..... I feel sorry for you because you'll be busy "for a bit" ;)

But for the time being, you need to pay [i]at least[/i] $30 (non-refundable, as well) in order to get into the game so you then can deal with the frustrating gacha mechanics so that you can...not unlock things, because practically everything requires shards to unlock, shards which are only acquired through gacha mechanics, so if you find yourself lucky enough to get a really rare item, suffer from the knowledge that you'll need to get the exact same really rare item [i]at least[/i] four more times.

Oh, and let's not forget that characters can be upgraded to give you an advantage in a race. Nothing quite like paywalling stats in a kart racer.

If you're at all interested in this game, wait until it's free-to-play, because I promise that the game itself is very fun, just do not pay to play it.

[h1]Experienced on the Meta Quest 2[/h1]

You can view my initial impressions review & gameplay here: https://youtu.be/JjCIwFCk2Og

[u]This is a neutral recommendation.[/u] I think the puzzle game is fine if you're interested in this game type for VR. However, I don't think VR brings anything special to these types of puzzle games. You're basically playing minesweeper, connect the line, soduku, & other pen & paper puzzle type games in VR. 

The other issue is that there are only 8 puzzle types and 64 puzzles in total. Assuming you're smart, you can probably blow through the content in 1 hour or much longer if you have a lizard brain. Interactions work fine most of the time, but sometimes I had difficulties selecting the items.

It's fine for what it is. You get to manipulate 3D objects in mostly a 2D way. It's like playing hangman in VR though .. you can do it & the game is enjoyable, but what do the simple 3D visuals really bring to the experience that would be better than just pen & paper or a free flash game on a brower? I don't know, but I could see some people enjoying this in VR more than in 2D since you do get to interact with 3D objects.

[b]Rate 5/10. If you ever wanted to play these types of games in VR ... it's only $4 USD. However, I think there may be free versions of these type of games on like VRChat or Rec Room if you look hard enough. [/b]
