Disney Speedstorm and Mario Kart 8 Deluxe are both popular racing games that have captured the hearts of gamers around the world. While both games share similar elements of fun, fast-paced racing and colorful graphics, they have some distinct differences that set them apart.

One of the most significant differences between the two games is their character selection. In Disney Speedstorm, players can choose from a variety of Disney characters, such as Mickey Mouse, Elsa, and Buzz Lightyear, each with their unique abilities. In contrast, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe features a range of characters from the Mario franchise, each with different stats and abilities. This difference makes Disney Speedstorm more appealing to Disney fans and children, while Mario Kart 8 Deluxe is more geared towards gamers who grew up playing the classic Mario games.

Another notable difference is the track design. Disney Speedstorm's tracks are inspired by Disney's theme parks, such as Space Mountain and Pirates of the Caribbean, while Mario Kart 8 Deluxe's tracks are inspired by the Mario universe, featuring familiar locations like Bowser's Castle and Rainbow Road. Disney Speedstorm's tracks are more visually appealing, with more detail and a more significant emphasis on theme park theming, while Mario Kart 8 Deluxe's tracks are more focused on gameplay mechanics, with elements like jumps, boosts, and obstacles.

Both games have a range of power-ups and weapons that players can use to gain an advantage during the race. However, the power-ups in Disney Speedstorm are more diverse and imaginative, such as fireworks that can blind opponents or honey that slows them down. In contrast, Mario Kart 8 Deluxe's power-ups are more traditional and simpler, such as banana peels and green shells.

In conclusion, both Disney Speedstorm and Mario Kart 8 Deluxe are excellent racing games that offer hours of fun and excitement. Disney Speedstorm is more appealing to Disney fans and children, with its unique character selection and visually stunning track designs. Mario Kart 8 Deluxe, on the other hand, is more geared towards gamers who grew up with the classic Mario games, with its familiar characters and traditional power-ups. Ultimately, the choice between the two games depends on personal preference and the audience's age range.

[h1] Intro [/h1]
First of all, some bias towards this game as I have and still play League of Legends, but you do not need to play League to enjoy this one. There are just some minor details/references you'll recognize if you do play it.

I played on Kingslayer difficulty while on default Sylas health and damage.

Overall, I enjoyed playing this game. The story was well written, the main cast were very likable, the combat was pretty satisfying to say the least and the spell system was really fun to use. 

The bosses tho? They're on a WHOLE NOTHER LEVEL. The league champions used in their fights are VERY faithful to their in-game counterpart, and the Mageseeker original bosses were really unique in their own fights.
[h1] Non-positives [/h1]
Although the game is not perfect. There are a bunch of flaws that affect the game. The biggest offender in my opinion is the lack of a fast forward option, ESPECIALLY BEFORE BOSSES. Because when you die at a boss, you have to rewatch the cutscene [b]KH1 style[/b]. And there is an option to "fast forward it" but it only skims through the dialogue and maybe (?) speeds up the cutscene by a tiny bit. Also the element enhancing melee spells are not that good. (except occult shield)
[h1]The combat and spell system[/h1]
Every enemy can be magically categorized into one of 7 types, from Magicless, Fire, Ice, Wind, Nature, Lightning, Mystic and one more exclusive magic exclusive to certain bosses in the game [spoiler] Garen and Wisteria (Morgana's magic cannot be stolen as it gives her a shield when attempted)[/spoiler]. 
Each element has a weakness to it's respected opposite. ex: fire is weak to ice and ice is weak to fire and etc.
To actually use a spell in battle you must steal it from an enemy first in a level. Then after the level you can talk to one of the members to purchase the spell to use mana to cast it. If you stole a spell from an enemy, it is a one use cast and there is a timer for when you can steal it again. 

[h1]Sylas's Combat[/h1]
Sylas has 2 different types of combos. Light attacks and Heavy attacks. In succession, Sylas can do a light attack up to four times, ex: L L L L  | or heavy attack up to three times. ex: H H H. Light attacks are fast and Heavy attacks do more damage, have longer range, are slower and can damage armor. Dash attacks are there too i guess. You can also switch between light and heavy attacks creating combos like H H L H where normally the heavy finisher appears on the third hit but adding a light extends the combo so you can do a heavy attack afterwards.
An important thing to mention is the chain grab. After targeting an enemy and hitting RB/R1 you can pull yourself into an enemy. You are fully invincible while travelling to them, but not after that, and also good for another mechanic i just discovered.

[h1] Finish Cancelling[/h1]
After using either your 4th light attack or 3rd/4th heavy attack (based on example above) you will do a "finisher" where that last hit will deal the most damage but leave you not able to move for a tiny bit. Your moves can be cancelled into a dash but not after using a finisher. This is where the chain grab comes in. if you grab someone after your finisher, it will pull you to them cancelling the time you were left open to do more combos. 

[h1] Bosses [/h1]
The bosses in this game have their own gimmick to them and they test your skills to see if you got what it takes to conquer them and triumph! Though a couple of bosses that spike in difficulty exist, they are so satisfying when you finally beat them. 

[h1] Is this game worth full price? [/h1]
Nah not really, I don't really feel like the game is worth it's full price cause I feel like I spent too much despite the praise i give this game. I recommend you get it on a sale.

[h1] Additional thoughts [/h1]
I've seen a bunch of people complain that since the game was too short (around 10 hours long) which makes me believe people think that longer games should be worth more (?) which I believe is wrong. I believe that there are more to that like how the story depicted the characters or the experience through your journey playing, or maybe it's just my deluded self thinking that because a lot of people around my age range play just the online multiplayer games.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
In all, the game was super enjoyable to play and it was a blast the whole way through, but you should wait for a sale... or dont, your choice.

In sum, Speedstorm is an extremely fun racing Kart game with a Disney theme on top of it that will be really interesting to see further developed and embracing more players when it becomes Free to Play (late 2023/early 2024). 
The game has a really strong foundation in all aspects, so I'm looking forward for the upcoming new content updates, plus hope to see quick action on balance fixes to keep on top of player metas. Also wish to see players and gaming community concerns directly addressed when it pertains to attenuate parts of the monetization; the game can really flourish if this aspect is simplified and the focus is put on more avenues for the player to acquire even more unique visual cosmetics such as unique Karts and Character Skins.


[b]  More intricate details about the game in general:[/b] 
The vehicles handling, speed and the controller feel are great with a myriad of racers present all with different character specific skills plus the power-ups that you can get during the race that make every single race really frenetic and dynamic. Specially considering the good quantity of tracks and variations of them, which contain diverse paths that will be beneficial to each different racer type (Speedster, Trickster, Brawler, Defender).
The game also has a lot of Single-player content and two different Multiplayer Modes (Ranked with levels and Regulated where everyone is at the same level) great graphics that represent well all characters from the different IPs along with the themed tracks from each IP, plus a killer OST containing remixes from the most iconic tunes and movie songs that will definitely stay with you after the game session ends.

The only big caveat of the game as mentioned above, it's the way that you progress and acquire new characters which is tied to a gaccha system akin to other games that contains these type of monetization mechanics (e.g. Genshin Impact), turning into an over complicated experience to acquire characters and over extend the required time for acquisition versus having more ways to get them directly, plus bringing progression levels that not only tie to the Single layer related modes but also one Multiplayer Ranked mode. 
Although to note that all character currently feel competitive (some just requiring a slight change or nerf such as Mike and others a buff such as Beast) so in that sense it's not a major concern to aim for whichever character you like the most in terms of IP or their unique skill along with having a dedicated Multiplayer component (Regulated Multiplayer) in which everyone has the same character level so that players are not forced to worry and dive into the levelling system for online play (which is great fun since it always allows you to invite friends from all levels to join your race).

[b]  The current character roster is the following:[/b] 
‚ñ† The classic Disney Trio: Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck, Goofy plus Steamboat Mickey (next season)
‚ñ† Beauty and the Beast: Belle and Beast
‚ñ† Hercules: Hercules and Meg
‚ñ† The Jungle Book: Mowgli and Baloo
‚ñ† Monsters, Inc: Sulley, Mike Wazowski, Randall, Celia Mae
‚ñ† Mulan: Mulan and Shang
‚ñ† Pirates of the Caribbean: Jack Sparrow and Elizabeth Swann
‚ñ† Walt Disney World: Figment
‚ñ† Possibly coming soon since the tracks were already teased: Toy Story and Lilo & Stitch 
Note: Currently if you didn't get a Founders Pack and this became F2P at this moment, you would pretty much have guaranteed Mickey, Donald and Goofy and get a decent quantity of Shards for others (due to the random nature you could get multiple new ones but it's not guaranteed).

I finished one playthrough of Blood Moon and explored a couple different choices, and I really loved it!

From what I could glimpse of the different choices, things can go in drastically different directions, which is very impressive and offers a unique experience for every player, which is one of the best things about interactive fiction, when done right (and it is done right here).

The plot is really solid, the characters distinct and lovable, and the writing fun and snappy. I was very invested in the story, the pack and the MC, making the stakes high.

The only thing that I wished was a little more developed was the MC's history. It's mentionned briefly a couple of times which left me wanting to know more. [spoiler]Meeting the MC's father also felt a bit bare bones, it felt like there should have been more to it.[/spoiler]

But none of that ruined my enjoyment of the story which I recommend without reservations!

There comes a time in every man's life when he needs to take a look at himself in the mirror and wonder how exactly he reached such a place.
You have to truly ponder what decisions you have made along the way that brought you to the place of your final reckoning.

It is still unclear, even to me, why I purchased Volcano Princess.
There isn't anything wrong with it, with those nudity scenes throughout it's perfectly stellar. But when you look at it as a choice, you realize just how flawed you and the rest of humanity is.

What drove me to purchase such a game? What part of my soul felt so empty that I thought a virtual girl could fill it?
When I look into the boundless depths of my own loneliness I see a pool of reflection. My face isn't there, there is no face. There are only tears in that pool, tears of shame and loss and confusion.

If it were up to me again I know I would purchase it in a heartbeat, I know I would load it up and skip through the countless window prompts so I can have a single morsel of pornographic images which are readily available online.
Yet, despite the abundance of naked virtual women waiting in the digital sphere, I still chose to purchase this game and devote hours of my life to it. That time will never return to me, it is lost just like my soul and just like the time I fear I may never find it again.

There is something broken within me, something that desires sensation beyond my reach, something that whimpers every single night with the knowledge that there is no true Princess, it is a merely an illusion.
In my pursuit to find meaning in this long life, I sought the colorful lights and sounds of a world that only exists in a pop up window on my computer.

I am unsure what the moral of this review is, I am unsure about my place within the universe, all I know is that no amount of virtual girls can cure the vast rot that has overtaken me.

[h1][b][1] Intro [/b][/h1]
The Monstrous Horror Show is a thrilling horror adventure game with RPG elements that will test your courage, puzzle-solving skills, and survival instincts. Above all, what sets this game apart from others in the genre is the inclusion of hentai content, which can be unlocked through a special H-patch provided by the publisher. This content enhances the value of the game, adding some ecchi or hentai elements to the already engaging gameplay.

[h1][b][2] Game Experience[/b][/h1]

The game is a visual treat with its amazing pixel art that immerses you in the eerie atmosphere of the abandoned hospital. The four heroines have unique characteristics and backstories that add depth and complexity to the overarching tale. As you progress through the game, you'll uncover clues, solve puzzles, and confront terrifying monsters that will make your heart race and your palms sweat.

The gameplay is intuitive and engaging, with a variety of challenges that keep you on your toes. You'll have to explore every nook and cranny of the hospital to find useful items and clues. The puzzles are cleverly designed and require both logic and creativity to solve. You'll also have to outrun and hide from monsters, and sometimes even confront them with whatever weapons you can find.

[h1][b][3] Verdict [/b][/h1]
In conclusion, The Monstrous Horror Show is a well-crafted horror adventure game with a unique twist. It is a game that will keep you on edge from start to finish, and leave you with a sense of satisfaction and accomplishment when you finally escape the horrors of the abandoned hospital. The inclusion of adult content adds an extra layer of excitement and sensuality to the gameplay, making it a great choice for players looking for something a bit different.

As someone who enjoys both Fighting Games and Rhythm Games, this game lacks a lot of the QoL options many modern iterations of those games have.

As a fighting game player, this game lacks a lot of quality of life features, especially an inability to change the controls upon character select, but also the tutorial seems broken in that the special button does not work properly in mirrored CPU mode so you can't practice special inputs with characters and especially you can't practice charge characters properly. The health is also so far from the chart that it feels impossible to tell who is in the lead until the chart starts flashing red.

From the rhythm game sides of things, the only note speed options are in training mode for some reason. There is no way to change offset between different controllers to potentially account for different input delays, especially between wired and wireless controllers, which usually wouldn't be an issue for fighting games, but given there is the timing aspect of rhythm games giving you different strengths it feels like a strange oversight. The area that the chart is on is so small for the amount of notes you have that reading can get really hard that it feels like really dumb levels of memorisation. The organisation of charts for each map feels bizarre as it doesn't sort by difficulty for some reason. In fact there aren't really any way to sort charts to begin with.

Also there isn't a mode that lets you play the game like a normal rhythm game which feels like it leads to the charts ending up rather unmemorable. Like, it's ONLY focused on the fighting game 1v1 aspect when it really feels like so much more could have been done with this game.

This game is honestly a massive disappointment to what could have been such a great and novel experience.

I give this a positive review with the extreme hope that this product is nowhere near finished. Too many times have developers pawned out unfinished games that end up being husks of what was promised. I don't know if this game will be any different, but this game really caught my attention.

While the game itself feels like it requires much more work, the framework seems to be really sturdy, as in they have the foundation finished, all they need to do is focus on the smaller (but vital) details. The devs seem to be in touch with the community and it seems like there's actual hope for this to become a fleshed out title.

While many failed attempts have been made to capture this genre, I sincerely believe that these developers have managed to figure it out. As long as they continue to work on the game, I believe this game can revolutionize the RTS/FPS hybrid genre.

In its current state, the game feels nowhere near finished but is still playable and has some fun moments. I only give this positive review to support the devs in their endeavor. If this just ends up being another quick money grab, I'll change my review at some point.

its very complicated at first, but all the systems makes the preparation for war very rewarding. the fps gameplay is surprisingly good, the RTS mode is a bit clunky atm but it works fine for the most part. excited to see where the game goes.

As a lot of other reviews have mentioned, the economy balance is in a poor state at the moment, but it is straight forward to work around it if you are fore-warned:
1) always hire people at the minimum salary.  There is basically no downside to this.
2) always send a three-scientist team to every science planet
3) be aware that you can get blocked later in the game when you start needing exo-suits, so make sure you unlock the suits before getting the other expensive upgrades.

Freeman Guerilla warfare clone. Very linear and 2 dimensional game play. Balancing is awful right now it takes far too long to build and that can only be done one thing at a time regardless of available resources. Same for research, only one thing at a time regardless of resources. No research points or anything like that to make research more interesting. Production takes far too long for ammo and the like. 

FPS game play is limited and not great UI. The strategic gameplay UI is awful. The screen can only move with WSAD and does not work with the mouse pointer at the edge of the display in map mode which is frustrating. Clicking on a unit opens up the unit org window and that covers a large portion of the map. Setting unit equipment is difficult. I can't easily pick and choose. It's either a rifle or a pistol, not both. No grenades for the soldiers no med kits. You can't stack battalions at locations, only one can occupy a town at a time. I would like to be able to stack battalions to make brigades. No mortars, no HMGs. No way of building up defensive positions to defend against attack, troops seem to start outside of town if they are not the garrison when it should be that if a force battalion is garrisoned along with the "local Garrisoned" then they are also in the town. You have no time to prepare a defence of the town when it is attacked either. It's a bit naff really.

It's trying to be Freeman but with much less playability or depth. Bit rubbish at the minute and needs a lot of work to bring it up to an enjoyable playing experience not least because logistics and diplomacy are so 2 dimensional and linear. One thing at a time please... no multi tasking here.

Who knows, in a year or so it might be better but I can't recommend it right now

This game mechanism is overly complicated, especially for food production. 

A limitation for aggregate construction is illogical and stupid as I have 7 cities but the food supply is not sufficient. It took 50 days to make a farm and I have to wait another 50 days again to make another farm to produce a freaking low number of wheat.. while the population eats like a hungry pig.

This game indeed has potential, but now, it is not ready yet, not even for EA. Perhaps in another 10 months of development, this game will be playable.

Despite what I'm going to say here, I enjoyed this game and would recommend it but don't expect a perfect experience.

What I dug: Sidemissions, the Art Design - everything kinda oozes grindhouse/80's horror and we love that.  Music and Core Gameplay loop all give off those Bullet Hell Happy Brain Chemicals.

What I didn't dig: The UI is clunky on a controller or on a keyboard - unskippable cutscenes or the ones that are don't respond to input.  Finished the Maze Level to sit around for 5 minutes thinking the game had froze because the "Start" button didn't function.  Meta Progression - I've played for about 3 hours total and haven't yet acquired enough money to upgrade -anything-

Devs, I know you're reading these; tighten up your UI Responsiveness and make some adjustments to the progression and this could be a 5/7 with Rice kinda game.

Decently written, but underwelmingly short and at many points the story feels disconnected from your character and the choices you've made. I also don't think its traditional three-act structure with a paper-thin epilogue works well for the medium, as it felt like the story ended right when your character was coming into their own - I even missed out entirely on romancing any characters on my first playthrough because I expected to have more than one sole opportunity to romantically connect with a character, but unfortunately that was all I got.

Altogether, a somewhat mediocre but enjoyable and creative piece of interactive fiction, and a let-down for anyone expecting something with some real meat to justify it's base price (and I personally feel it wasn't the greatest value on sale either)

Stray Blade is not a Souls Clone. It has a few elements from souls games but it doesnt feel like a soul game. It feels like a action rpg mixed with some zelda exploration and other things. Its definitley a good game and you can feel the love of the devs. Graphic style is nice. Combat system is rlly satisfying - especily the finisher move and its not too easy - easy to learn but I wouldnt say hard but not so easy to master xD. Voice acting and the characters are a 10/10 too. All in all..its a very good indie game and I dont get why people giving that a negativ review. Its polished and you have to play with a controller but who wanna play games like this one with mouse / keyboard. Stupid negativ reviews....

Weapons are implemented very well, as well as a lot of accessibility options for those who need it. I enjoy the retro-fantasy aesthetic, and the visuals (Textures/Resolution Scaling/Depth), whether it was meant to or not, use the screen-door effect to it's advantage. 

There's some small bugs with the AI (They really have a difficult time seeing me on stairs) as well as the occasional clipping issue. However, for a game in a genre old than I, being translated into a new medium: Absolutely solid. 

I cannot fathom the idea of Ultrakill being ported into VR. On a flat screen that game is able to spike my adrenaline at it's whim. I would consider selling my left leg for such a port.
Great atmosphere of an old school shooter  translated to VR

Never played the flat game, but I'm liking this VR port. I've done Doom 1 & 2, Brutal Doom, Quake, Heretic, Wolfenstein, etc. in VR, and this can stand with those. What I like the most is that it's FAST. The only issues I had so far were not knowing why I start levels with no weapon (had to press grip), some performance issues that will likely be patched, and issues reading the in-game text. My gameplay is below.
https://youtu.be/JY5rf1_GdSk

I like this game. If you play Demo version, you'll see most of all contents this game can provide. There are several other lands(biomes) that has unique statuses like +(or -)100 production of the specific building. Sadly, since this mechanics don't work well now, you just build your town again and again. It's not like "Oh, I create this town as bakery town and import breads for all other towns! :^D". No, it's not like that since the land's buff is too weak to do so. Eventually, you'll be bored while unlocking the other lands. But I enjoyed so much before then. This is EA title, so I hope the dev improves this game more. At the current state, this game for 5$ is steal. I recommend this to anyone who love logistic games.

I'm putting recommend this game tentatively after playing around for a while both with friends and on my own. The atmosphere is fantastic, but as many have noted gets a bit troublesome the further in you go. Whether good or bad that is left up to the player. I feel it adds an extra layer of terror. 

Onto the island size, it is indeed overly large, even with multiple people especially with how slow you move at any given time. Although I have a rough idea of how the island looks in my head as far as landmarks and can probably decently well navigate it now, I am also aware most people aren't good at doing that in their head. Potentially would benefit from having a map system of some type, maybe with a map that fills in as you explore, or some way to set 'markers' of some type.

I can see the devs are hard at work already with updates to try and fix the AI to a satisfactory level so I will only state that it needs some work but as a foundation is pretty good. The tracking system for things like pages and all isn't bad but the intensity of the glow can be difficult to discern especially when you have to physically look down in the game to be able to properly see the book.

Overall I can't wait to see more because the game still is in early access, and as long as things are followed up I believe that this will end up being a pretty great Lovecraftian game. I do hope to see in the future there be more than just the single island for places to explore. I look forward to a lot of great work coming from the game and believe in the hard work that has already been laid out to play.

This is a fun little game with a bunch of potential. combat and movement is silky smooth with enough flashy side effects to keep you engaged. The game itself is a bit on the easy side in comparison to other tough-as-nails rougelikes but that was fine for me. What I will say is that, due to the translation, some of the ability descriptions are inscrutable but combat is forgiving and it is a roguelike so experimentation is rewarded and I never found myself confused for too long. I'm definitely going to keep an eye on this game.

This game changed my life. I now have a beautiful wife, 37 children, 13 cars, 4 villas in the south of France, and trillions in my bank account. All of this thanks to this masterpiece of video game craft. If I could, I would kiss the developers of this gem in their chucko kokos.

I was excited to try out Homestead Arcana, and I was not disappointed! You become a farming witch and explore a mysterious land corrupted by Miasma. I particularly enjoyed creating my own homestead from scratch, growing plants, and developing new spells. I really enjoyed the progression of the game. I encountered creatures with unique and suprising mechanics, and uncovered hidden secrets that kept me on the edge of my seat.
However, it's not without its flaws. The game's graphics are not as impressive as some other titles in the genre, and the controls can be a bit clunky at times.
Despite these minor flaws, Homestead Arcana is a fantastic game that offers a unique and exciting experience for fans of adventure and magic. I highly recommend it. :) And of course I love Huckleberry! :D

Although this is not a full-fledged game, but only a prologue, it is no less interesting to play it. You can create your own mafia empire and engage in various types of crimes, be it bank robbery or intimidation of residents. Highly recommend to pass.
Don Duality: Initiation is a game in which you will experience an exciting 9-day journey to the top. But this is all just a small prologue of a full-fledged game, which will be released soon.

Here is another novelty in the indie genre. While playing it, I plunged into a stolgic mood, as if I was playing the sega and the 8 bit game again. Cool. Feel like a little mafia don and manage it. And also there is the management of your restaurant to move away a little from the affairs of the mafia. 
Of the pluses, one can single out - pixel graphics, and there is also localization in many languages.
Anyway, the game still needs a bit of tweaking.
In general, the game is worthy to play it, especially since it is free.

Don Duality: Initiation is an exciting strategy game that offers players the chance to lead a criminal empire. From the outset, the game pulls you in with its engaging story and interesting mechanics. As the leader of a mafia organization, you will need to manage various criminal activities, including bank robberies, debt collection, and intimidating the police.

The game also features random events that can have a significant impact on gameplay, adding a level of unpredictability that keeps the game fresh and engaging. In addition, players must also navigate the delicate balance of laundering money to avoid police attention, which adds another layer of strategic depth to the game.

Overall, Don Duality: Initiation is an excellent game that is sure to appeal to fans of strategy and simulation games. The combination of engaging mechanics, an intriguing story, and well-designed gameplay make it a must-play for anyone looking for a thrilling gaming experience.

Don Duality: Initiation is a must-play for fans of action-adventure games and crime-themed stories. With its thrilling gameplay, stunning graphics, engaging story, and immersive open world, it offers an unforgettable gaming experience. Get ready to embark on a perilous journey into the criminal underworld and carve your path to the top in this gripping and action-packed adventure!

I didn't play the demo and so came into the game with little in the way of expectations and I'm also new to the genre in general, with the only other rhythm games I've really played being Guitar Hero and (a very long time ago...) Samba de Amigo on Dreamcast. So far, I'm really enjoying things!

The controls are as simple as they come and you can tailor how fast paced you want the gameplay to be with your choice of song, allowing you to go in all guns blazing to smash your previous high score or take a more leisurely stroll and chill out with some good tunes. Speaking of music, the soundtrack is fantastic and really adds to the experience. If you tire of the provided tracks then you can import your own music too.

I usually give games with mixed reviews on release a miss for a while but I'm glad I didn't with this one. It seems that the negative reviews are based on changes between demo and release which is unfortunate and you can't miss something you never had, so if you didn't play the demo you can take those comments with a pinch of salt. The devs also look to be very responsive so I'm sure any of the changes that are missed will be implemented again in the future to build on the fantastic foundation.

And the most important bit - the default FOV is actually usable and doesn't immediately need raising (110). This goes up to 130 if you need it, and is SO refreshing in an age where most devs set a sickeningly low FOV because they are sadists (or catering to console players sat at the other side of the room).

The game is fun, the soundtrack is amazing, and the game plays really smoothly! Play this if you want to feel like John Wick.

Fun action RPG with a different take on leveling, pleasing art style, and relatively decent combat.  

Pros 
- Great looking game
- Combat is good enough
- I like progression and skills being tied to weapons but others may not
- Exploration is rewarded

Cons
- Dodge/Parry system falls apart with multiple enemies
- Some minor bugs
- times where you have a lot of skills points available not able to spend

Running the game on a laptop but have had to drop to 1440p medium settings in order to maintain 60 fps. 
Specs: 6900hx, 32GB RAM, 2TB 4thGen SSD & 3080ti-16GB. 

Developers, please do some optimisation in the EA phase or at least introduce DLSS, DRS or some equivalent technology to increase the frames. There is also a memory leak - as the fps drops the more you play - restarting the game sorts this out. Usually can play for around an hour or so before it becomes noticeable....

Loving the game overall though - like the concept & wave mechanic. There is a lot of potential here to develop a game with  high replay value. Only played a little multiplayer, seems to work fine - not a lot of people online atm - best to play with friends. Maybe a dedicated server option will be offered?

Recommended if you understand EA issues & have a higher spec system - its good fun!

This game is subpar

Just a couple of quick points for skim readers;
Music isn't very good (even though the kinda whole aesthetic is about music?????)
Not very hard, levels felt tedious with the difficulty curve very very gradual 
Abilities/Upgrades aren't big variations to gameplay/low impact
Progression also feels very off
If you're here for the visual novel whatever part the english voice acting is subpar

Long notes 
>The abilities are the weakest part of the game, my taste in rogue likes (synthetik, nuclear throne, binding of isaac, enter the gungeon) all have big focus on weapons and upgrades changing your playstyle run to run, this is not present at all in this game, upgrades are minor changes and the actual combat is very weak consisting of spamming buttons to hit your enemies. I initially was hoping for a rhythm based combat similar to crypt of the necrodancer since the game does have your abilities become strengthed if played on the right beat however the concept is not explored at all. 
Basically COMBAT is very weak, may look stylish to some but i feel isn't very deep complex or has any variation.
>Feeding into above your ability upgrades don't seem to effect gameplay or playstyle at all, just  simple stat changes so again very low variation on combat. 
>MUSIC IS NOT GOOD, this is a game with a hint of focus on rhythm and the entire theme being about a world of weird music corrupting people, and you give me the most bland ost i've ever heard in my life, get the boys who made synthetik to whip something up for you please if the music was a 7/10 i would consider not refunding this game. 

Overall I don't think its an enjoyable experience, feel free to try the game but gameplay isn't that good. Game does seem to have some weird husbando waifu component which i don't think is that deep but if you want to play it for that the world is your oyster. 

Not worth it 2/10 maybe comeback if they update combat.

I bought this game on a whim the day it came out and its just pretty good straight up. 

For the short of it its like a simpler neon anime Dead Cells with extremely light rhythm game elements. 

So basically this game is like if that mobile game Dislyte was a actual game and also good mixed with Dead Cells. Originally I thought the music theme of the game was just for flavour but it bleeds into mechanics like upgrades and the skill attack which surprised me. The art style is cute and dripping in neon. Now this game is Chinese so the audio and text only come in Mandarin and English and beyond some missed translations and occasional subtitle missteps its extremely competent. The voice acting is actually pretty good for English its not like some half trying effort and its admirable, like there are some accents you can hear but its not bad at all so good job on that. 

As for gameplay its pretty simple but inoffensive. You have a attack, a slam from the air, a unique ability per character, a skill, and a ult. Builds havent got too crazy for me yet but i can see potential. Theres a per run upgrade system that is randomized which is unique. Think like a skill grid and you put chips you find in and the grids effects are shuffled so you cant ever really build the same twice, though while this is unique it isnt gonna break a run only elevate it really. 

The only negative things I can think of is that levels are fairly short but thats subjective, and the timing/rhythm skill mechanic which might turn some people off. Personally I think its fine but some people might not like the control over which version of the skill you use.  

If I can be real this game seems like a mobile game that the developer just changed into a full game which isnt a bad thing in the slightest. Ive played a ton of gacha games and this has all the makings of one from how the menus are laid out to currency but since its not tied to micro transactions at all, its well put together.

Ultimately there's nothing particularly wrong with this game and its a fun time for the price.

aside from a bit of broken translation, you can still read it without much issues. Its a pretty fun game! I bought it and played from the start till one ending in a sitting lol...

This has incredible potential and I fully support it, this is an amazing combination of many different types of games and im here for it. However, it does need some improvements, pros and cons are below.

Pros:

The RTS/FPS merge is amazing and i always love when a game does that.

The "mount and blade" like open world and city building is an amazing combination with the RTS IMO.

Graphics are nice, sound is nice too, can use some improvement i think but its nowhere near immediate. 

Moving on to cons:

I think it would be helpful in the resource management bar to have gains and losses so that i can prioritize what settlements  need to produce what resource to get me back in the green. 

Recruiting squads is a bit rough, it would be nice to see unit composition before i recruit them so that i know what kind of unit im building. I do like that the recruited units build up over time, simulates recruitment training and is a nice touch. 

More on squads, when building a custom preset squad, I think it would be more useful if the equipment options were limited to the research that you have completed, otherwise id be building a squad preset that i cannot use at the moment. 

When it comes to research, i think its a bit slow to be limited to researching one time from one tree at a time, it might be better to be able to research one item from each tree at a time. However i have not been playing very long and maybe that's for balance. 

Overall i think this is worth the buy, improvements and refinement is needed but for day 2 early access it is an amazing start.

First want to say yes the gameplay is good however be aware if you buy the standard pack and then decided you wanted to upgrade you're going to have to pay for the full price as if you didn't buy the standard one to begin with.  Now if you want to play only solo you will most likely get stuck from progressing in tracks.  Honestly I don't have issues with paying for cosmetics like character looks or vehicles but to continue with a game it seems a little unfair since it's not a cheap game to begin with.  So my issues are more around progression in gameplay.  If they had just made it where you can play then add dlc for bonus gameplay without the confusion within the game no issue.  With that being said the game itself has good graphics there are some glitches but expected for early access.  The tracks are fun to play.  The music and character sayings are fun to hear.  So the actual gameplay is good which is why I said yes to recommending it.  And if you say well it says dlc for the other editions that's a little misleading cause you can't actually buy what they call dlc without spending the amount for the standard game itself with it.  A dlc is separate and if you can't afford it right away you might buy it later but that's not how this one works.

To everyone claiming this is not refundable, it isn't directly from the menu's itself.

I even used one of the DLC items to unlock a new character and got the 29.99‚Ç¨ pack refunded.

Besides the refund I'll still leave a negative review as this game might have some decent gameplay mechanics which I can't complain about after 36 mins of gametime but the amount of menu's and in game currencies designed to get more money from you on every button press is insane and was my main reason to refund this hot pile of dung until it goes free2play eventually.

Like most analog horror games, it is basically a "find the things, then it's over" deal, so it comes down to how well it's presented, and here it's presented very well.

I got stuck on the first "level", because I am dumb, but if you don't get stuck there, you're off and running to a predictable but still enjoyable end.

We don't get enough cave games, and we don't get enough analog horror games, so, two for the price of one here, and it's less than two bucks.  If you like caves or analog horror, it is silly for you to not buy this immediately.

This game asks the question: what if a cave had something spooky inside it?
7/7

do not go in expectiing a classic dungeon crawler, or even a super traditional roguelike. This is NOT an RPG, it is a puzzle game.

It is however, one of the absolute best puzzle games to date.

DD is a game in the same field and grade as something like Tetris or Minecraft in that, when you stop playing it, it will be something you think about. 

you'll think about strategies, synergies, Kin and Class combinations, items, gods. this is a game with many layers and they are all very worth the time to peel back. Desktop Dungeons has had very clever minds spending countless hours of tinkering and balancing and it displays this beautifully like a finely tuned watch.

This original game holds up well, and works on modern machines but if you want a more modern approach, I would recommend Desktop Dungeons: Rewind as it is virtually the same game.

Don't miss out on this gem.

It's exactly like the old DD. But now 3D. Which means the characters are smaller and harder to see and the UI is worse. 

And otherwise there doesn't seem to be any new addition to the formula or anything? Only the rewind feature, that seems to only put you back 1 Level. Which doesn't help since you can be in an unwinable state at any point during the game, which is how this works. 

And honestly, if this wasn't free for anyone that already owns DD I would not have gotten it. Which is why the did that promotion probably. 

At the end its DD and probably doesn't matter if you buy this one or the old version. I think the old version didn't have widescreen so there is that.

you're allowed to have a preference, and if you prefer the original Desktops Dungeons, by all means, play it.

Desktop Dungeons Rewind has it's quirks, and the worst thing you can say about it is, it is identical to it's predecessor, but it's still Desktop Dungeons and it's still fantastic.

The devs have done a good job bringing this classic to the new age, is it perfect? no, but for newcomers it is exactly as good as it needs to be.

The game was essentially given away for free, so I'm really not sure what anyone could possibly complain about.

if you missed the "give away" please try Desktop Dungeons: Enhanced Edition, see if you like it, and consider supporting the game by buying this one, it's highly worth it and you will definitely get the value of full price.

I was absolutely NOT expecting how fun this game would be. At the beginning it felt like there were too many buttons to use but when you get used to it, it feels so dynamic, so fast. You actually feel like Sylas running and throwing his chains around. The magic stealing mechanic fits like a glove, the story made me like the character (even though I hate him in League), the art is beautiful. I can't wait to see what other game ideas are coming up for other characters and their abilities.

it's a good 15$ game not 40$, if you wan't a good Minecraft spinoff game go buy Minecraft: Dungeons ultimate edition for the same price as this.

if your expecting a hard action game or a hard strategy game, your gonna be disappointed. instead think of this as a guerrilla war simulator where you lead a ragtag army against overwhelming invaders. if that sounds like fun and you can handle some jank, this is for you

Though fun to begin with, the game gets to be very repetitive and overall tedious to play.
The strategy side of the game can be fun, however there is no real point to using various different towers when the most basic of archer towers work fine in almost all occasions.

Best part of the game was attacking Portals, however there are only 3 different types of bases, which leads to again, repetitive gameplay. I enjoyed fighting off the clan of the Bastion the most, as it required actual skill and planning, and this somewhat applies to the clan of the Spore as well, but overall you never *need* to plan, just spam troops with the endless supply of materials from all the villages in the game.

Material collection felt unnecessary due to village chests, and most troop types were also unnecessary due to being able to spam one and win.

Also Creepers were way too powerful lmao

Teslagrad 2 oozes with Norwegian spirit, the environment, the characters, the music.

Sequel features more combat and moving around quickly, with dozens of secret rooms. But it also requires a lot less thinking, the puzzles are more about execution and precision.

The main story is nearly same length as the first game, so don't expect the game to be long (out of my hours 2-3 were the game running on background). If you will only play the main story the game might even feel lacking, so I highly recommend finding the secrets. The optional rooms also have the most challenging rooms in the game while the main story is easier this time (but just like before, the final boss is not a total pushover which I appreciated).

The controls were mostly fine, but they could've still been more refined. Same with the magnetic physics, now and then completely unexpected bounces happen (which might or might not benefit you). And obtaining certain powers can cause problems when you would not want to use them (The ground pound move in general happened accidentally a lot, and the blink axe power against the final boss where enemies are often behind wires made it harder to hit them.)

The magnetic axe is a great idea. a double jump exists in the game, but using the axe to help launch yourself in the air lets you do very high jumps. Without the magnetism it would've been just a God of War's Leviathan Axe ripoff. I also enjoyed how fast you can slide.

I was disappointed that there is still no method to warp between areas, especially now that the map is larger than before. It makes returning to places more cumbersome when you have to claw yourself back out from wherever you go. And think twice before dropping down, I had to repeat entire areas more than once because I fell down and the game autosaved the moment I landed. So my tip is, if you're falling big time without meaning to, quickly exit the game before the autosave makes you swear.

Playing the game on release, there weren't many guides out there, but I was able to fully complete the game thanks to a map you can find that lets you see where the collectables are. It did take me a lot of digging around to find it though.
this game is so ass... take it off the store and put more work into this trash

A relaxing colony sim. Research, unlock, build, and assign colonists to jobs using your main character. Runs very well and I haven't come across any glitches (single player since I don't enjoy this genre with other players). But there are some oddities. For instance, I have a blacksmith's hammer (I think that's what it's called but I could be wrong about the name) in my backpack but when I try to equip it on my colonist that makes steel, it says I have no equipment for colonists. 

My only concern is the game doesn't feel large enough yet considering the price tag. Even so, Havendock is off to a great start. I hope throughout the early access period that all five ideas from the developer in the "about this game" section (cow island, astronomy island, boathouse, the cave, and house building system) are added to the game. All of these additions would add differing play styles and replay value.

So far so great. I love the simple graphics, I also like that its a bear tutorial, they give you enough to figure it out yourself. It's not so difficult that you get stuck and can't progress any farther but it really makes you have to plan things more than you would think by just glancing over the game. 10/10! <3

It's ok. Might pick this up again later but everyone calling this Hotline Miami is on crack. It's a top down shooter with a similar aesthetic but that's about where comparisons end. The random/procedural/whatever levels aren't super fun to play in and I felt more inclined to just bait enemies through doors when possible. The first boss fight was interesting, but the fact that the devs just throw their hands in the air and say "fuck it" by giving you unlimited ammo feels like a cop-out. Otherwise only major issue was I nearly went deaf on the intro logo, and even when reducing volume down to 5% each some sounds seemed to stack, causing ear destruction.
If the idea of a rougelite [strike]Hotline Miami [b]2[/b][/strike] top down shooter with health and bullet time has your interest, you might like this, it's just not for me. Soundtracks bretty gud tho.

There was a situation when a corpse was blocking me to pick up weapon and my character was afraid of corpses. Right until this moment I didn't even know that they have characteristics. It doesn't add nothing than annoyance. Questionable game design.
Also why is the music in the night levels sounds like underwater? It's increadibly unplesant! And while exiting the room it glitches out and boosts the volume for a second.
I hope the devs will polish the game, because it's has potential, and I don't want to leave a negative review.
Looks great and plays great out of the box. Hell yesssssss

This game is great. Good game play, fun enemies, creative and well built levels. I am enjoying my time with this game but it's performance is terrible.

The first chapter ran smoothly the whole way through but every chapter after was a nightmare. Laggy and slow game play which completely broke the flow. Also in the game you can throw your axe like Kratos and teleport it back which is really fun but when the frame rate drops, it completely stops all momentum in your throw and the axe just falls to the ground which is so annoying.

I have an Rtx 3070 and a 12th gen i7 with 16gigs of gram. I put the game graphics to low, steam resolution to 20% and custom res multiplier to 20% and the refresh rate to 72hz but nothing worked. Just to check that is wasn't my P.C's issue, I turned the res to 150% and custom to 100% and went into Half Life Alyx with high settings and everything was fine.

Until this game gets an update, increasing performance, unfortunately I can't recommend this game as it is right now.
okay now give me Dusk VR, and also Ultrakill VR

I have a lot of nostalgia for old school designed shooters over the grey and muddy modern military games and generally New Blood tends to produce what I want. I was more of a Quake/Doom/Duke Nukem fan over Hexen or Heretic, which this game is more heavily inspired by. It probably is why pre the VR port I wasn't as interested in the game overall. 

However, I'm only about 1 1/2 hours into this version but I honestly was having a hard time putting it down when I bought it last night. This is a stark contrast to me playing it pre VR. The port to VR actually adds a lot to the experience of playing this and has made the exploration and general feeling of the game a lot better to me.

At its core I think the way that a lot of the weapons work makes them feel cool and novel in a way that makes them extremely fun to use. I find it extremely fun to just swing your sword and have the projectile go in the direction you look. I like swinging it in time to cancel an enemy projectile attack. It is all extremely fun and intuitive and shows that there was work to make this feel good in VR. The momentum detection feels just right for how much you have to swing. I have a feeling that extended play sessions may give me serious tennis elbow potentially. 

The environmental design is extremely cool and exploring the areas that they've constructed is extremely compelling. The updated lighting model of UE4 contrasting with a Quake 1 style of environmental design feels in a lot of ways like the 2d-3d RPG games that are coming out of Square. The sense of scale you get when you are actually in VR makes the world almost come alive. I find myself spending a lot of time exploring the world to find all the secrets they have.

I do unfortunately have some issues with the AI. They tend to get stuck on simple objects sometimes and their pathfinding could be better. I think that this can make some of the enemy encounters too easy and I am probably going to start over on the harder difficulty to see if that works better for me. I do find myself not dying that often and my health tends to be past its maximum point for almost 90 percent of me playing (thanks to health upgrades and some of the predictable patterns of enemies).

Overall this is solid so far. I am looking forward to any new New Blood VR ports in the future. The Teem Beef ports of classic FPS games to VR does show that putting these types of experiences in VR makes them more interesting. I am glad that an actual studio is doing the work to do this themselves. I look forward to playing more of this (and potentially updating this review to have more of a mechanics deep dive when I do).

I've played this game twice through by myself and i have to say i'm loving this game so far! The atmosphere is amazing and the island is quite eerie, i've seen three of the monsters in total and god they're awesome looking and terrifying. I'm happy when i don't see them and also terrified that i don't know where they are at the same time! Overall really good game for how long it's been out and can't wait to see more added! Only thing i will note as a negative is alot of the relics seem glitched inside items, you'll walk up to a crate and it will have a pick up icon, when you pick it up nothing shows up and then it says you collected a relic, only thing i've remotely noticed, two thumbs up for me!
Really fun game. Great aesthetic, great sound. Looking forward to the fine tuning that comes from the early access process. Would highly recommend.

I've spent over 40 hours in the mobile version of the game. It's easily the best smartphone CoD clone, though it may not be enough on PC, as the development was very slow so far, there's only a bunch of maps, which are small. The greatest advantage is the shooting mechanic as well as the movement, which is far too easily exploitable on mouse and keyboard.
The devs are worth supporting though. There's no pay to win, no lootboxes - all you can get is skins and you get what you pay for - a whole set of skins for weapons and characters for less than $10.

Welcome gamers! Are you ready for a taste sensation? Look no further than Tastemaker, the scrumptious indie restaurant management game that's sure to whet your appetite for gaming greatness.

With its affordable $12 price tag, Tastemaker is a dish that won't break the bank, but don't let its low price fool you. This game has all the ingredients you need for a mouthwatering gaming experience. From designing and building your own restaurant, to managing staff and cooking up delectable dishes, Tastemaker has everything you need to satisfy your hunger for fun.

And let's not forget the graphics, which are as visually delicious as the food you'll be cooking up. Whether you're crafting dishes in the kitchen or interacting with your customers, the game's vibrant visuals will leave you feeling satisfied.

Overall, Tastemaker is a game that's sure to please even the pickiest of gamers. It's affordable, packed with content, and just plain fun. So what are you waiting for? Dive into Tastemaker and let the deliciousness begin!

Ok wow! This game is very different from what i've played and reviewed so this might get kind of long...

The game is fantastic, it has a beautiful aesthetic and pixel art and this could very well turn into an amazing project given the right things are done to it and the developer still plans to expand and work on this piece.

The game as of playing it on April/22/2023 feels incomplete there are a lot of inconsistencies and areas to easily softlock if you exit your mech at the wrong times. (Although you're not supposed to exit the mech at those moments it just feels kind of "unplanned" whenever you want to try something and you end up having to reset the game).

I haven't finished the game yet but this is what I found so far...

The music repeats, there needs to be more soundtracks, I noticed from the dev's previous response that this is a glitch but i'd love to hear what the other soundtracks sound like. 

The very first stage has a place where you can go out of bounds of the map and die its pretty funny.

The Aligator boss almost always drops his core inside the wall making it inaccessible 90% of the time (Maybe replace the core spawn to the center of the stage instead). 

The second "drill boss" doesn't even spawn a core (unsure if it was supposed to). and the boss also spawned with partial health (Again not sure if it was supposed to).

I wish there was omnidirectional shooting, that would make things more immersive, or at least as an upgrade option (didn't see it as one but if there is later in the game feel free to correct me). 

The second stage also relies on a some of "leaps of faith" down holes and crevices where you are unsure if you're actually supposed to go down there or you die trying to find out. Would be nice to have some context clues or indicators showing the path that is needed to follow. (Sloping floors, elevators, breakable blocks, or if you wanna be lazy arrow signs lol etc).

The story itself is very basic, Nothing much is explained or given, I feel like this game could have an amazing storyline, maybe as you're defeating bosses you extract something from them (a vial of stomach acid from the aligator, or a mini cutscene where you rip out the robot's drill arms and take them with you and use those "parts" in the store to upgrade your weaponry and arsenal giving you weapons such as an acid shot or a drill weapon to access hidden areas etc.) 

It would also be cool that as you upgrade your robot his AI is also evolving giving him a more "human" personality. I could see this as being an iconic ending where in the end the robot rips out his own buster to give to the kid in order to save his life while he stays behind and you have to run out of an exploding building or base of sorts. 

All in all, this game has a LOT of potential, I hope the developer continues to work on this and expands it with more ideas and mechanics as it has the potential to be one of the next best sidescrollers out there.

The game has no sex unfortunately so i'll have to dock a point from the overall score :^)

7/10 at its current state.

10/10 if the dev decides to expand the game more.

In the game, players navigate a dungeon filled with monsters before battling a final dungeon boss. The game has qualities of a puzzle as players must find the best methods to use items, spells, and upgrades to reach the final boss without losing too much of their character's health. -Wikipedia

This game looks and feels very simple at first since you only need mouse1 when clearing those dungeons out of those filthy monster scums. But the thing is, you wont get far if you try to kill every enemy that crosses your path just by smacking their goblin faces with your mighty sword. You need to think a few steps ahead and make a gameplan about how to get the best use out of your items and not waste any tiles while trying keep you health and mana high enough to be able to keep pushing forward. 

Extremely addictive, but difficult game and even if you don't like the artstyle, i still recommend to try this out, atleast if its on sale. Even better if you grab it right now since its free! I have not tried the 3D HD version, but it looks very good.

I'm a big League fan and literally have countless hours on it but this game could have been so much better, it like they stopped at good/average game and stopped production and effort.

I have to say, the game looks great and it has its own unique mechanic which is faithful to Sylas from League. The chain system/aiming system for spells is very clunky to begin with and it feels weird. Even after 2hrs and getting used to it on Kingslayer difficulty it doesn't feel fluid at times as some other platformers. 

At the price-point its disappointing because the Level design is kinda linear with a chest here and there, but other-ways you are always on the story path. Also a 35 quid game not having V/O is kinda insane. 

The game is not bad its just average. Without the League IP/Story I cant see the same amount of positive reactions or number of players. I do think it should have been priced way lower.

Don't get me wrong the story is very good, just that I wish there was a way to skip entire dialogs when you're feeling ready to play the game, I feel like I should be allowed to just play the game instead of glossing over 10 mins worth of dialogs and menus.

Gameplay is very fun though

Definetly a fun game however, it is a bit short for its price. I highly recommend if u are a fan of the league of legends lore. But wait for the price to go down if u are just looking for some fun. I would also recommend waiting before buying since there is a couple of annoying bugs at the moment. Don't forget to also try Ruined King to embrace the beauty of Runeterra's lore.

Is this game a masterpiece? It is a very good looking metroidvania, but without the typical combat. Actually, it is a quite unusual metroidvania. We play a little girl named Luminia (who first appeared in the game World to The West), who is hunted by humans and gets eaten alive by most animals or plants she encounters. She runs away as fast as she can from most foes, only sometimes she uses the environment to get a little revenge and kill an enemy. Lumina was flying along in her little zeppelin, when she got attacked and her blimp shot down in an abandoned region. The aim of the game is to return home. She is a Teslamancer, which means she controls electricity. She may not have an attack, but she starts the game with the ability to dash. Very soon she finds a dress with magical properties, which allow her to use magnetic force and polarities. At least I think that it is a magnetic force that allows her to run along walls or fly up in (magnetic?) currents. There is no speech in the game. There is also no text in the game. So some things might be a bit hard to understand - visual storytelling may be an art, but can't easily explain everything.

During the game, Lumina learns new abilities by obtaining new equipment, which allow her to access areas that have been so far unreachable. A typical metroidvania game element - but the abilities are not typical. No walljump or double jump, but fast swimming or a block-breaking slide. Even the fast travel is different than in most metroidvanias. There are no teleporting portals, but there is a central hub and cables that Lumina can move on using her electromagnetic powers. So she can reach the various regions in the game, like the castle, a snowy mountain or the flooded caves.

In the course of the game, you shouldn't expect direct confrontations with the enemies, especially at the beginning of the game. Lumina has no attacks and has to use her dash ability to move quickly and avoid certain death. She is attracted or repelled by certain platforms, and the main gameplay challenge is how to reach the next room while at the same time not getting killed by various deadly things (spikes, electricity fields...) or enemies. She often has to run while being chased by something deadly. While you learn to fight to survive in most metroidvanias, here you need to learn how to move fast, using your various abilities. There are some challenging, frustrating moments due to complex puzzle-platforming elements. Boss fights are also special, you have to think of ways to damage bosses without having an attack. If you die, you reappear at one of the many checkpoints. This is more like Limbo, there is no real punishment for dying, apart from being very annoying and having to go again through some places you already managed to survive.

Gamepad is of course supported. To return home doesn't take too long, but there are 81 cards are hidden in the game for completionists. Also other stuff is hidden and not necessary to finish the main story, like extra abilities. The visuals and animations are amazing, the game is really a little beauty.

[u][b] Conclusion:[/b][/u]
A refreshing but short metroidvania where you don't kill (most of) your enemies, but simply outrun (-swim, -climb, -jump, -fly) them. Actually, it is more of a physics-based puzzle platformer than a classic metroidvania.

A vibe unmatched.

Stealth isn't technically mandatory, but it's highly recommended since straight-forward combat can be very dangerous and wonky at times. The physics and movement feels natural- not too fast, not too slow, not too floaty, not too weighty... 

There's not that much to critique or be upset about, in all honesty. I don't have any nitpicks, at least, not yet. It'd be fun to have something like... oh, I don't know, no rewards mode where you're forced to find recruits and equipment on missions, starting with the market and having to sell your stuff for cash?

[h1]Disclaimer[/h1]
I only played the first level, but this is the same game as base Amid Evil, which I already finished 2 times. Consider this to be just an opinion on the VR port, not a full-game review. Look at my original Amid Evil review for that:
https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197998873734/recommended/673130?snr=1_5_9__402

Played on HTC Vive while standing.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Store page proudly states "This is not some half-baked version of AMID EVIL ported to VR, this is the REAL DEAL"

Eh...

It's ok, but it's also pretty lazy. Amid Evil is good, but I don't know if VR really plays to it's fast-paced action. Frankly I don't recommend Amid Evil VR unless you already played the pancake version, but if you already played it, then this VR version is hard to recommend since it's the same game.

Having a discount if you already own the original is nice, but not enough to warrant this purchase.

[h1]Description[/h1]
It's largely the same as the normal Amid Evil. Maps have small tweaks (I think?), but overall feel and look same.

So the main difference is the controls. You can use the left touchpad on the Vive to move around like using an analog stick on a controller. Pressing on it will jump. Pressing on the right touchpad will turn you (can be set to snap with configurable degrees or set to smooth turn if your stomach can take it like the real VR-slave you are).

You select weapons from a selection wheel by holding the right option button. You attack depending on the weapon. I only played first level and I don't remember many secrets, so I only tried out the Axe, Water Staff and the Sword.

Axe is swung and it automatically hits if your swing has decent arc and momentum. No need to hold attack button.

Water Staff is aimed with your hand and fired with a button.

Sword is interesting - you aim it with your face and have a crosshair that follows your head movement. While swinging sword like the axe, you create projectiles that will aim themselves in the direction of the crosshair, which follows your head movements.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[b]+ It's still the same good game as it was[/b]
I fully recommend pancake Amid Evil.

[b]+ Elegant aiming solution[/b]
I was worried they would just have the sword fire as you press the button, which would make it suck in terms of VR engagement. However making projectiles by swinging is present in the game and you aiming with your face means you can be accurate while swinging. Nice.

I suspect the Morning Star has the same mechanics, while other weapons probably fire normally.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[b]- Lazy[/b]
It is lazy. I did not see anything about new weapons, enemies or levels on the front page, so you effectively just pay for a VR port. It's an ok port, I guess, but when I think VR fps, I think HL Alyx or Boneworks, hell even H3VR. Games that take advantage of the VR controls to the fullest.

Here you play the same game as we did several years ago, but this time you get tired and a little bit VR-sick after playing for a while AND you are not as precise as with normal KB+M controls, so gameplay suffers a bit.

I guess there's room for a classic FPS in VR, but it's just a shame that we already played the version that feels as solid to control as the pancake Amid Evil.

So, in general, it's an underwhelming experience.

[h1]Lowdown[/h1]
Not really worth it. I'm not sure if I will care enough to finish it. I'd probably have more fun replaying the pancake version.

I'd give Amid Evil VR a
[h1]5/10[/h1]
With a not recommended verdict, because pancake is more fun to play.

[h1]This 'Boomer shooter' is an absolute blast in VR! I want more of this![/h1]

People say fast-action shooters don't work in VR. They say that it's "vomit-city" and no one will play it... well here is AMID EVIL in VR. And my god is it a rush! It is fast pace, there is a lot of verticality, jumping, and a lot of things that you "should never do in VR"... this game says fuck that... and I must say, I want more games like this in VR! Here is more proof that Boomer shooters do work in VR. Like I have said before, there are lots of people who get motion sickness from roller coasters, but there are still lots of people who enjoy roller coasters, that's us who love fast-action in VR.

I have got to say 'Thank you' to the devs that translated this game in VR! It plays wonderfully!

Spectacular Virtual Reality Power applied to an already amazing boomer shooter.
You can swing your sword and see the wave flying out of it, you can aim perfectly with your hand while circle strafing that giant monster that you can see in front of you in real life-size scale.

I'm going to finish this game entirely starting it from scratch again from the previous Flat version.

What I can recommend is 
1) buy it immediately
2) Start playing it on HARD : because being able to see with complete freedom,  and have perfect aim with your hands will give you an edge that Non-VR players cannot have on the Flat version of the game. So Hard difficulty will feel a little more balanced.
3) Remove the Aiming Reticle, use your eyes with the true power of VR on your weapons :)

I will upload gameplay video soon from a more advanced part of the game.
The game is blast !!

Kiro II: Wizards Guild, like life is best shared with friends. Deliciously frustrating but intensely satisfying, this game will make you a typing genius, with the low low cost of stress and trauma when you furiously sweat to attack enemies but you made a typo, oops! ur ded sorry.

But all in all Krio II: Wizards Guild makes for a fun game between friends, With its intelligent use of steam inventory you collect power up and items forever. Trade with friends as you explore the procedurally generated dungeons.

If you want delightfully devilish gameplay and want to laugh out loud for reals with friends this is the game for you!

Kiro 2 has it all!

Are you dating an angry Slavic woman who yells at you for no reason? Take out your anger and frustration by killing slugs and bats with butter knives.

Are you almost 40 and balding? Hide that receding hairline with a Wyrmslug silk hat. (it boosts your intelligence too!)

Does your brother and your friend keep beating your ass in Warhammer 40,000? Feel like a bad ass as you defeat giant rock monsters and a red drumming man!

Does your angry Slavic girlfriend take all of your money? Well good news, Kiro 2 is only $5!

All of these benefits and more are waiting for you inside this game.

Text Based? Randomly generated levels? Leveling? Loads of Loot to Collect? Multiplayer AND a Magic system? When I first checked Kiro 2 out I didn't know what to expect, but the simple Command System combined with gorgeous old-school aesthetics won me over in just in the first level. If text-based sounds intimidating think again, it only adds to the tension of attacking and defending from enemy attacks. When played with friends, the fun is upped immensely. Best in person but still amazing over discord, Teamwork and finding your role in the party is just as important as getting as much loot and treasure as you can. The Level generation guarantees a new experience every time, and it can be just as much to fun to race your friends to the end as it is to help the group ;)

Check out Kiro 2 if you haven't, it's a bountiful entry into the old-school genre.

The particular system of non-RTS simultaneous turns that this game employs is very unique as far as strategy gaming is concerned. It plays like a board game given the lack of randomness and pure strategy. Furthermore, the massive amount of maps and units that can be employed allows for countless strategies with subtle nuances among them all. Deciding how you best like to combine different units into formations and to fulfill the correct niche provides ample opportunity to customize your playstyle so that it is unlikely that anyone else has exactly the same strategy. Some battles are won before they start when one side has developed a composition tailored to the map while the other has just mindlessly chosen the big scary units, yet most battles aren't decided until the very end since the system allows for clever or surprising maneuvers to suddenly turn the tide of battle.

My favorite part is the multiplayer as you get to test your mettle against someone else's wit in a timed challenge where every moment counts. Especially when you have many orders to issue, you need to make sure to prioritize your focus on the most important fronts of the battle. The campaign mode is also very interesting to play through as you need to manage the needs of your whole army beyond just the context of the battle. Logistics, money management, and more are all broader challenges that must be considered as well as winning battles and limiting casualties.

The historical accuracy and flavoring is just icing on the cake as well with lovely unit designs and fun voice acting. The graphics are nothing exceptionally revolutionary, but they are still nice graphics that even my toaster of a computer can handle.

There are a couple bugs here or there that are left, but most of the truly problematic or game breaking ones have been squashed by now. Plus, the development team is very responsive to community feedback and are always hard at work ironing things that are pointed out.

All in all it's totally one of my favorite games that I've been able to enjoy recently. Definitely a 10/10

[quote]For more puzzle game reviews, news and everything puzzle-related, follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/25928931-Puzzle-Lovers/]Puzzle Lovers[/url] and check out our [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/puzzlelovers]Steam group[/url].[/quote]

[b]busway islands[/b] is the bus- and railway-based sibling of [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/dohi64/recommended/1547340]puzzle car[/url] and younger cousin of [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/dohi64/recommended/1807930]railway islands[/url], not mature enough for hexagons. not even mature enough to work properly at birth, but it quickly got patched up.

typical tile-switching puzzler with rotatable pieces and [b]35 levels[/b] unlocked one by one. create paths for buses and trains, so the former can visit all the stops before they all leave through their respective tunnels, then start the route. [b]speed settings available[/b] for less waiting. gotta deal with elevation changes too, and since they can cross paths, [b]traffic lights are necessary[/b] to avoid collisions. should one happen, you can make the necessary changes without re-doing the entire level, then try again. what's more, [b]progress is saved when you quit[/b]. mostly unnecessary but a pleasant surprise. [b]a supposedly quick soft-reset results in a loading screen and a camera reset[/b], a lot less pleasant.

[b]I found difficulty uneven[/b], no curve, feels like level order just got randomized. those junction bits that are both straight and a turn were way too frustrating to figure out, there used to be very subtle differences that caused me an unreasonable amount of grief on level 14 and some more later. now they're easier to read with big arrows.

[b]non-rebindable mouse-based controls with some hotkeys.[/b] mouse stuff isn't shown anywhere, left click to pick up and place tiles, rotate with wheel on mouseover or while they're being held. hold right click and the wheel to mess with the camera, wheel zooms if it's not over a piece. the usual stuff, but it'll be somebody's first game and they might not be familiar. hotkeys bring up the menu, soft-reset the level and start and speed up the goings-on.

good enough presentation, relaxing music, colorful little diorama-like towns. can be daytime or night, various seasons, clear weather, rain or snow, but [b]hot air balloons are always in the way[/b]. settings are adequate and available anytime. separate volumes, resolutions, windowed mode, some languages, v-sync, graphics quality, shadows, msaa, ssao, hdr.

the game could've been called [b]traffic puzzle[/b] (or probably something less generic), but I guess [b]railway islands[/b] has become popular enough to name this after (so much so that its price keeps going up for no reason, hopefully won't be the case here). it's okay overall, but plenty of similar games around, so [b]not a must-have unless you have a traffic fetish[/b].
