So first off I want to say that this is early EA. Its very rough but has a good foundation and concept. Has a similar open world mechanic as mount and blade games but is bare bones. This can be compared to games like freeman: guerrilla warfare and mount and blade. I streamed this for about an hour and a half if anyone wanted to see footage. Most of the time I was just trying to figure out controls and mechanics without watching youtube. There is some frustration in the video though.

Pros:
-FPS and RTS, easy to swap between both.
-RTS controls are easy but take some time to learn.
-Good foundation for a game of this style.
-Active devs (I know it just released).

Cons:
-When you die in FPS mode it takes a while for the game to give you another person to control.
-Open world is hard to understand.
-Tutorial is a youtube video series and steam guide.
-Vehicles die too fast to RPGs. Realistic but frustrating.
-Hard to see enemies while they shoot you from ridiculous ranges.
-Only able to build one building at a time in open world.
-Cities starve fast because of a lack of food and unable to make more until you build production for it.
-Creating battalions takes too long because of required reserves and weapons. Only 1 troop replenished a day. (When you have a battalion of 300 soldiers you need to wait 200+ days for them to be full strength again???)
-Hard to assign equipment to units. In 2 hours of playing I still have no idea how to do that. I created custom squad designs but the troops still don't use the equipment assigned even when they are garrisoned at a city that has it.

But remember this is an EA game, its very EA in my opinion. When in battles I would be able to enjoy myself though. So while this needs a lot of work I will give this a recommended. I like to support EA games and as long as they stick to fixing issues and fulfilling this game I will be happy.
P.S. devs please work on issues or concepts one at a time. Don't try to multi-task like others. Give your best to one concept at a time so you can make it as good as you can!

I really wanted to like this game, but the gameplay is very dissapointing. the game has a really nice presentation but everything else is completely lacking. 

the ui is very charming, the SFX feels impactful and the soundtrack includes several indie bands that really give the feeling that a lot of soul was put into the game. 

this game plays like its made by someone who has never played a tony hawk game. every decent skateboarding game ever has a jump on button release, this one jumps on press making the ollie feel less impactful. you can't do multiple tricks off of an ollie. grinding rails have no momentum, they're just rollercoaster tracks and jumping on and off multiple are nearly impossible. this is basically a skateboarding game that doesn't allow for player expression.

the level design is very shoddy, eg: the entire intro section is built of floating parts, you can fall through the level,
the ramps are completely useless except for 1 part where you need to grind some rail. 

the enemies kinda all do the same thing, theres sections where there's an abundance of them in the map and you dont even interact with like 80% of them. all the objectives are the same in each section except the amount you need to kill. it doesn't feel very well thought out.

there's several weapon combinations but they all seem to do the same thing. also the crafting menu says i have weapons when i don't have the rocket launcher. if you're going to have an inventory system give let the player decide what to do with their inventory.
nice game

Fun lil bullet hell/VS game that allows you to live out your Jaeger dreams and smash the pitiful opposition. It has a variety of cool weapons and only 3 mech's but looks like quite a few are planned, hopefully some out of the box designs are in store.

Some aspects of this game really stand out from other similar games, the variety of enemies and their patterns are pretty unique and add a lot of flavor. Not only do you have different enemies that may either try to ram you or stay back and snipe, ive also noticed the spawn patterns allow some to spawn in little bands that you have to play around or come in a little faster. While not crazy, I feel these extra twists will really make this title stand out, especially for a small team like this.

I'm just hoping in the future there are more integrations between the different upgrades, some elements I never really get just because I would always choose straight damage compared to them- similar with the armor upgrades, which you wouldn't really want to get unless you are almost dead. Maybe some feature that allows combinations of upgrades to more incentivize going for certain upgrades that may not as exciting on their own, and add to the replay-ability. 

But overall, would recommend to anyone looking to bap around some people and tanks as a giant mech. I hope this title gets the attention it deserves and the content keeps rolling in.

This was one of my most anticipated games of the year and it didn't disappoint. Reading the other reviews on here, I can see why people would complain about difficulty and lack of variety in upgrades...but part of it is the point of the game, that people don't have the patience to get to and see, and dismiss the game after two hours of gameplay. 

This is a story game, an adventure, disguised as a roguelike. People wanting the Binding of Isaac or Vampire Survivors are going to be disappointed by this. People that love deep lore, mysteries, puzzles, and unraveling a story hidden within the disguise of good ol fashioned roguelike gameplay will love it. 

It IS hard but there's settings to make it a bit easier and it's all about the journey being difficult that makes the game satisfying. I do think there should be a few more unique bullet upgrades to make runs not feel samey, but again, I don't see this as the kind of roguelike you replay over and over. You eventually reach a point in the game where you feel complete and everything makes sense, and that feeling is worth every penny of the game.

Fire and Maneuver is a war game that I personally love, and I guarantee its niche can be enjoyed by players of an entire century of war.
The parts of fire and maneuver that I love the most is the nations and the various units you can bring with you to battle, like for the Italians, you can bring offensive redshirts to lead a charge, but also can bring defensive standard line infantry, it vary much simulates a Victorian battlefield in the sense that you build your army based on your style of fighting, either defensive or offensive, its super fun, especially when going into sandbox mode and screwing around.
the multiplayer aspect is alright for me since as of the moment its not too crowded. but really I enjoy single player mode more than before since the various scenarios and campaigns can keep you entertained for a long while.

All in all a vary enjoyable fun game clearly made with heart and passion, I would totally recommend it for people who play games like total war or EU4, and I can't wait to see other games made by this studio !

In such a saturated market for this type of game, there's really no reason to buy this one. Aesthetically, I love it. Don't get me wrong, the theme is great and the visuals are fine. But you need to really nail the core gameplay if you're only going to offer a fraction of the content and polish that many other, much cheaper games can deliver. The idea of having a base and doing quests in a Survivor-like is really interesting, I wish it was played out better.

I'll list out the things I particularly disliked:

The persistent progression is very, very slow for this type of game
Weapon and item choice is very limited, and leveling them up is just adding damage or sometimes a projectile. Very little noticeable variation between runs
UI is extremely lacking. Can't even change settings during a run, can't check your stats, weapon details, or anything
Quest objectives are often obscure and hard to find, and it doesn't come off as fun exploration, it comes off as frustrating
The dialogue moves incredibly slow, but skipping it doesn't speed it up, it just skips to the next line. You just have to wait for it, and it is very slow.
I've encountered a couple of run-stopping bugs, where a quest line or character interaction becomes stuck
The controls are very weird on Key/Mouse, they're not as bad on controller

I don't hate this game, I've just played so many better ones that it's hard to recommend this one.

Just one note for the normal idle game player (which is also me), this is not your average cookie clicker. It has some typical idle elements, like the option to close the game and it keeps progressing (which is optional), you can click to refill resources, and its super relaxing - but its much more complex. Very unique merge of genres.

This game has amazing potential, and it's honestly everything I wanted from this genre (similar to Mount and Blade). It's a little rough around the edges right now. However, you can see the vision behind this game and it more or less expects you to run an entire country. 

I just dipped my toes in for the first time, and while it was a bit of a shock as there was no tutorial I can say it was a worthwhile time-- just read a guide. 

My only complaint (and I'm sure it's just not a priority right now) is that the resource management is very clunky at the moment. I wish I could hover over a resource (or have a logistics tab) and see how many resources a town was draining/producing etc.

Also, see weekly convoys, what is in them, and be able to cancel them. It's entirely possible that it's in the game, but I wasn't able to find it if it was.

All in all, a promising experience.

So I played the developer previous game and really enjoyed it. As a huge EO/SMT fan, it's always nice to see more dungeon crawlers since there have been kind of a drought with bigger companies this generation. I can safely say that Core Crossing is a very charming and fun experience for people who like these type of games.

First off, I think the art style is very good. I love the character portraits and the dungeon designs are pleasing to look at. I like how the demons reminds me of SMT. It's a very polished art style.

The combat feels pretty good to me. The first floor is not too difficult but allows enough space to learn the mechanics. The second floor is when the game starts to pick up in difficulty. It feels well thought out which I appreciated it. I need to play more of the game to fully comment on this, but it leaves a good first impression for me. 

Overall, I think this is a worthwhile game to check out. If you are a Dungeon crawler fan and need to scratch that itch, this is a great game for it.

Writing here to thank the developer for this game.  It is an absolute triumph!   A roguelike about situational awareness and tactical thinking to use the environment to your advantage.  combined with clever and compelling storytelling.  The love is apparent in every frame.

Also, the soundtrack/sound design is sublime!   Congrats!  Well done!  and Thank you!


PS:  There seems to be a lot of sentiment about how it's too hard, or things are readable.  If you go too fast you'll run into this problem.  Sometimes it's a little subtle, but everything is telegraphed clearly if pause and look around.  

There will be the occasionally moment of mad circle strafing and bullet hell, but usually you can manage enemy aggro and engage on your own terms.  Move slowly, carefully, and methodically and you'll have no trouble using the environment to your advantage and not get caught out by that little pufferfish you didn't spot because you rushed in without taking a second to assess the situation first.

This is a really good detective game in the style of Phoenix Wright. More than Phoenix Wright, it makes great use of a very flavorful setting (Ming China/wuxia). It's generally a more serious set of cases than Phoenix Wright, and none of the characters are annoying comic relief. It's hard but usually fair/logical and you get unlimited retries. 

One thing it doesn't do as well as Phoenix Wright is that you can understand a case fully and still get some of the choices wrong because you're thinking through things in a different order than the writers intended. For example, there are two moments when you can challenge a character who claims he brought "nothing" by presenting conflicting evidence that specifically mentions he brought a cape. This won't work on the first opportunity. However, later on you get ANOTHER chance to call him out and it works then. In both cases there was enough evidence of a contradiction that calling him out feels like the right move. Only having this work the second time feels weird. 

... 

If you haven't already played the game, it's generally really solid and I recommend it. 

If you have already played the game, there are some logical holes on the edges of the plot.[spoiler] I'm around halfway through and supposedly a ~9 month pregnant royal VIP is rescued after a siege is broken and their first instinct is to move her? Their boat comes under HEAVY attack, and she sees this as an opportunity to murder an ally over an unrelated vendetta (revenge for her father's death)? Then she jumps into the water and swims away, and then she *walks* to a friendly keep presumably miles away, and she successfully gives birth to a healthy child that night? [/spoiler] I hope we later find out that most of this is wrong.

Nice short little horror game. Enough to stay interesting while not overstaying its welcome. Jumpscares got me good pretty much every time (even after replaying a few sections). I wanted to like this game. I really did, it's about time we got a Napoleonic Game that's worth a dang (to my mind the last one was Total War Napoleon). The Devs are phenomenal, the community is spectacular, and the units are incredibly well researched. My main issue is just with the battle mechanics themselves. Some people like them, some don't, and I'm one of the latter. I despise the "cohesion" aspect of the game that basically lets 2 lines of line infantry volley fire from 2 hex away, hit, do "cohesion damage" only for said damage to repair itself the net turn, leaving that unit exactly how it was before it got into a 3 turn intense firefight. The fire at will only works every other turn, and cavalry are so hard to predict that even after a nerf, they run rings around anything and everything, because there is no telling where the heck they will wind up. I also firmly believe that this game just wasn't ready for a full release. It's absolutely riddled with potentially game breaking bugs, every game there seems to be a new one. In short, I love everything about the game, except for the game itself.

Fire and Maneuver is my favorite strategy game ever.

Many people expect this game to be polished, and have barely any bugs and glitches, but it is made by a youtuber and his team, not big video game producers. 

The gameplay is refreshing and relaxing, while still being exiting and punishing if you blunder. I found the speed of the game to be perfect, and the troops being generally balanced. The exiting style of gameplay really makes you feel like a military general at the time, commanding your infantry to victory (or death).
What tops it off is just how stunning the graphics are in the game. I absolutely love the art style, and it just makes the game that much more enjoyable to play.

Obviously, there are many bugs in the game, and you will encounter one atleast once, but they are not prominent enough to truly affect your view on the game.

Very interesting strategy game, would recommend, the orders mechanic is very responsive and creates interesting play of predicting enemy movements and punishing them. I got the game for free, but I'd happily pay the current price if I had more interest in the time period.

[h1]Experienced on the Meta Quest 2[/h1]

You can view my single-player gameplay here: https://youtu.be/Ep5kI19_oi4

I honestly can't review this game. I tried playing online pvp multiplayer, but each time I went up against bots. I honestly don't know if there is a playerbase for this game or not. The focus is obviously on PVP and I don't think it would be fair to score the game without having played online multiplayer.

However, I can say that the single-player content is not worth it. There's only one map. There's only one game mode (besides the tutorial). There are no settings of any kind. The AI bots are basically brain-dead if you skate around the edges of the map, which would be the most logical thing for you to do.

However, skating is fun. I could see this game being fun in PVP MP. Skating is easy to pick-up where you basically just move your body side to side to gain speed and face the direction you want to skate. There is no artificial turning, you must turn IRL, so you do need a swivel chair or to stand IRL. You also have power-ups and a disc weapon you can throw towards enemies. You can also jump or brake. You leave a tron-like trail behind you and you can use it defensively or offensively to cut-off other players. Skating is easy to pick-up, but it can be very challenging to pick-up the kitty & keep other plays from bringing you down, assuming they are not brain-dead like the AI in this game.

It's running on the Unity Engine. On my RTX 3080, I was getting a steady 90 fps. I did not experience any issues or bugs.

It's fun.

Decent progression, the concept and story are pretty great. Kind of a Magical Nausicaa vibe, which is fantastic. 

Does it have jank? It's a Unity-engine cutesy-farming game, of course it's got jank. The textures are... questionable, and some of the design choices will drive you mad (The Trader saying "MORNING" in the same voice line every time you open his menu.) But it has soul, and the good parts carry through. Broom riding is actually a joy, and significantly better than walking around. All in all, I'd give this a 7/10 (Actual 7/10, not IGN 7/10).

Good things this game does: No enforced sleep cycle. That's right, you can be the witch-gremlin you are IRL, staying up three days straight in a crafting routine until you need to advance time. The harvesting-minigame is surprisingly interesting, especially once you unlock the ability to start snipping at plants to try and maximize yields. Inventory Tetris exists, but is really easy to work with once you get storage.

Anyone having trouble affording upgrades, let me clue you in on a secret: Salsa. The story says that the people are running low on food, but what they're really running low on is salsa. The SECOND you unlock tomatoes, you'll have a money-making machine that will carry you into the endgame by way of flavortown. Anything else you cook should be for quests, or keeping yourself stockpiled to go into the Miasma. Which is a gentle, yet still somewhat tense series of story-dungeons you'll go through. Not really combat, (That I've seen) more "Follow this path to progress" style.

I love games with a lot of progression that I can sink time into at my own pace. I don‚Äôt care too much about amazing graphics or anything, which this game certainly does not have, as long as the gameplay is fun and I have goals to unlock. There are already a ton of things to unlock here and from the roadmap post it sounds like there will be even more. I don‚Äôt usually care enough to review games but was happy with how cheap this game was for the amount of progression there already is in Early access so what the hell. 

I doubt it is for everyone but certainly will have a good niche audience I think.

Oh and Val gave me some Claptrap vibes which always gives me some great memories. I am sure there are plenty of people that will hate her, but I liked the humor it adds. Might get old after a while, will see.

A lot of fun. For fans of racing games in general and Disney, this game has so much going for it. I'd say if you're on the fence, there are more pros than cons, and the cons are somewhat trivial (in my opinion). 

Pros: 
- Smooth, intuitive controls
- Very cool character-inspired special moves and designs
- Excellent soundtrack that puts driving, energetic twists on old classics
- Gorgeous maps, lots of shortcuts and ways to gain ground 
- Scaling difficulties for those who like a challenge 
- Lots of different pathways to play, for various purposes. Between the ranked/ regulated MP races, the events, the starting circuit, and the seasonal chapters, there is always something to be working toward. 

Cons: 
- Some things cost money to unlock/ attain
- Would be cool if customizations impacted performance
- Characters only have 1 car with various paint jobs, rather than different choices of car
- Very few maps at the moment, though I assume more will be added eventually 

Hope this helps! Happy racing! :D

A fun game!

As a big fan of league lore, it felt amazing to step into that world and forward the story.
The visuals were awesome and the overall gameplay was pretty fun.

Downsides were that the story was very simple and easily predicted but the characters were great.
The combat did get a bit repetitive after a while, but was still fun.
Finally, binding space for cutscene skipping was a really bad idea. Space is the dash that you will be using all the time, so when a cutscene suddenly happens, you may press it at the same time. This lead to me and the streamers i've watched, accidentally skipping several speech bubbles throughout the whole game. Since its a fast forward skip, you don't realize that it's skipping until the characters are talking and its so fast that you miss several speech bubbles before you're able to stop it. Please fix this <3

I would wait to buy this until there are some updates.

I did a couple play through's of this. It's visually appealing and I think I would like the game but not in its current state. There's a downward spiral of income after you run through the easier science and stop getting patentable items. Injuries seem to absolutely cripple your base because they take so long to heal. I find the research progression frustrating as it is all about the random mission hauls and planets can't be revisited. My first playthrough I didn't get one of the primary research components until my base almost collapsed.

If you love stargate, you'll love it! If not, it's probably missing a wow factor. Really keen to see how this evolves through early access.

The game is a solid base builder where you send teams of explorers out on missions. There are surprisingly few bugs considering how early it is, but there are a few issues with the AI. The gameplay loop is very satisfying. However, balancing/progression is still rocky, as it gets extremely hard to make money in the mid-game. The UI is annoying when you have over 10 staff and several teams. Performance also struggles as you get larger.

The game captures the mystery of exploring new worlds reasonably well, with little choose your own adventure events. These combine to form a narrative - however the pacing of this is a bit off. Writing quality is passable. While the gameplay lends itself to re-playability, but I worry the story won't. The game is built to appeal to Stargate fans, but I feel the implementation, story and art style is actually very bland. So if you aren't a fan of Stargate you may find it lacking much personality or a wow factor.

I really dislike the in-game shop, games shouldn't have them. At least give us a way to earn stuff by playing the game.

The next thing is, The campaign is only around 4 hours in a normal play through. Sure, the Main campaign is basically always different since the map changes, but it doesn't change the rather small building selection and pretty... one way using of units.

Basically, once you get creepers you can just... rush to the core and only call creepers, you will be destroying the nether portals within 5 minutes or less. 

The combat is a bit wonky as well. Basically most of the time you will use (A-Move) well known as attack move in the RTS genre. There are ways to select archers and other units individual, but its pretty pointless, Just... send them all in and they even sort them self out.

I haven't Tried the PvP or multiplayer yet, I had no interest in that and it seems rather unbalanced but I can't tell anything about it.

Also, As a last point, from a single player viewpoint its kinda annoying that you gotta be always online, You will lag, fall of cliffs sometimes because you dsync'ed away or somewhere under the map. [b]AND YOU CAN NOT PAUSE THE GAME[/b]. The game will run in the background because its meant to play online or in Co-op.

They also announced some challenges, right now they got some wave mode which is way too easy to finish.

[h1]Final words[/h1]

If you like simple RTS elements and minecraft its a good game, its good for fans and people loving the Lore of MC. But other than that its pretty mediocore at best. If you wan't the game, get it on Xbox Game pass or wait for a good sale.

There's a lot to like here, but there's a few major flaws here that mean I must recommend against purchasing the game.  
The first is a design issue - two actions (slide and ground slam) are mapped to the same button, and sometimes it seems they can activate on positive OR negative edge. So you can start a slide, jump, release slide, and slam yourself into a trap or deadly pit if you're lucky. If you're not lucky, you wind up losing a half an hour of gameplay and have to redo the last zone you're in.   
The second one is that it is bizarrely easy to get softlocked - stuck in an area that the devs clearly didn't seem to think you'd return to at that point. Given the above issues with slamming unexpectedly, and the game's structure, this has happened to me twice in my just under 3 hours with the game. I like the game, but I'm not redoing the opening a third time.

TL;DR: Great take on the idea of turn based strategies, but has some bug issues.

First I'd like to start on the bad, which is the bug issues. To start the UI is a bit buggy, it doesn't work and flow too well, and definitely focuses on looking good while not running too well. For the game itself, it occasionally has a bug that messes with the match or makes the game a lot harder.

However, I personally don't see this as too much of an issue, because of how the development team handles the game. First off, the team is constantly looking for and fixing bugs, with often patches. The development team is also very open about what they're doing (at least on the discord server), often sending announcements about what is going on. And They also put out polls on what to add or change with the game, taking the voice of the community into account, which makes the changes make the most happy. This is also the very first video game this developer has ever made. Armchair historian is a youtube channel, that makes animated history videos on various topics. They had absolutely 0 experience in game making, maybe except for drawing the assets that would be used. They where just a bunch of history guys who wanted to realize an idea, so they made this game. To see a group of animators make a game from nothing with just an idea is impressive, and makes me give them the benefit of the doubt when it comes to these things.

Now, to talk about the gameplay. I could not recommend it more to anyone who likes strategy games. It is a turn based strategy where you give your armies orders to fire and move, to attempt to destroy the other army. These orders are neatly organized in a list that you can use to rearrange the orders or cancel them. Once both of the orders are sent, both armies go down the list completing the orders simultaneously. This makes it where you have to predict your opponents moves, because you both are going at the same time, there is no taking turns. This gives the game the stress of a Real Time Strategy, while still giving you breathing room to asses the situation and figure out what to do next. The game's army building is also fun, allowing for every nation to have different playing styles within, and the playing style and strategy changing based on how many units can be afforded. The two time periods also change what you have available to use, creating even more depth. This game is easy to pick up, but has a high skill ceiling. 

Overall, the game isn't perfect, but its still very fun.
A very fun turn based strategy game set in an underappreciated ear of war

In several places, you walk into or see under the map, and there were also cases where the monsters couldn't kill you, they just followed you through the entire course, which is impossible to complete due to the darkened view while you are being chased. I encountered a total of 3 types of monsters in 2 rounds and if you don't light your lantern, you can avoid almost all of them and the game becomes quite boring.
It's sad that small teams come up with a lot of new ideas and colorful game mechanics, but they can't really implement them well, while big companies produce boring template garbage, where only the graphics stand out. Anyway, good luck to the team and I hope their product will improve in the future. I think its released too early even for an early access game.

I've played the first one and I'm still in the middle of this one. There's just something special with Coffee Talk that's hard to put words on it. Toge Productions really managed to make the comfortable vibes of a coffee bar feel so real. The character writing is phenomenal, to where they just... feel like actual people. People with their own history, emotions, personality, desires, experiences. You can feel the time pass between games from seeing the original characters and their plights (idk, i just feel like Lua is older now than before, which I say complimentary). I just really love the urban fantasy setting, how monster rights are ever evolving in modern times.

I really highly recommend both games. Please do yourself a favor and play the first one before getting this. It really is a direct sequel, and I agree with one of the reviewers here: while the "Episode" part of the title is nice, it does give a lot of people a "dlc" vibe as opposed to sequel vibe, and it can be dropped to just have it be Coffee Talk 2. But I also don't mind it being there as well.

This is one of the best sequels I have ever played to an already amazing game.

To me, the original Coffee Talk felt so far ahead of its visual novel contemporaries in terms of story and character development. It was hard to imagine that I could get as invested, or let alone more invested, in what followed from the first game. And I won't lie, part of that doubt did come from the untimely passing away of the beloved series' creator, Mohammad Fahmi. His design and writing, as far as I'm aware, played an enormous role in why Coffee Talk looked and felt so unique in the first place. So going into this sequel, I was hoping that what he brought to the original game creatively, in both the design and writing departments, would be preserved.

I got more that what I bargained for with this release.

Coffee Talk Episode 2: Hibiscus & Butterfly is an amazing continuation that fluidly builds on stories from the old game while also weaving new ones with novel characters and fantastic designs for them, to boot. The new mechanics introduced for coffee-making AND storytelling are one-of-a-kind, something that I didn't even think of as a possibility yet felt so incredibly seamless and natural upon my first impressions of them.

I can't say much more without spoiling this game for anyone reading. This is a masterpiece, and everyone who worked on this game should feel immensely proud for what they've accomplished. Somehow, despite the odds, Hibiscus & Butterfly not only preserved what made the original Coffee Talk so great, but dare I say, /improved/ on the original product.

Honest Review
What this game is:  2 Hours of Fun + 10 Hours of idle zombie slaughter relaxation.
I recommend for a casual zombie killing farm fest.  It takes a few iterations to your base to see how to kill the most Zombies, but after you settle a layout, its just kill more zombies to get the next upgrade, Go kill survivors for blueprints, come back, modify base, level up turrets, rinse repeat until you don't need any more blue prints and you just grind to 1000000 steal.

Getting the Trophy Table was a bit of a let down.  I wish it would have done some large scale buff or debuff or something.  I feel  with needing 2-3 of the 50,000 steel blueprint tables almost completely upgraded to make it possible to grind to 1000000 steel with the last buff on those tables being 850000, i feel its not worth getting that upgrade until after the trophy table, then  there is no point to grind out 850,000 4 more times just to get everything upgraded because I'm a completionist.   

I recommend if you want a background game to just fill some space in your head while doing other things.  I don't recommend this game if you want a really in depth strategic or very challenging game.

All in all I enjoyed it up until the grind for the Trophy table.  That was just a slog.  I don't currently see much replay value. but for people who like to grind big numbers, it might be something a few people could grind some time into.

Resources during some levels are very limited, level objectives weren't clear enough at the start and the list goes on. I started a new save file instead of the demo one(which i deleted, which is likely the wrong choice) because i want it to be fresh for me, but it just didn't feel the same from when i first played the demo

But if you like it and/or buy it despite what I've said above then i hope you enjoy it, but this game didn't feel right to me, I Don't Recommend It.

Sleeper Games' take on a stealth game and it's as good as I hoped it would be.  Incredibly tense before and after you get spotted, with the innovative (atleast I've never seen it before) catch that enemies are also stealthed, and requiring you to find and tag them, concealing their patrols more than other games and upping the likelihood you'll get found if you play as fast and loose as I do. Passes my main test for a stealth game nowadays, which is "is it still fun when you get spotted?", owing to some excellently tense combat and truly great music that builds as you start taking out enemies and crescendos as you're in battle. Sound design is as always great and the visual style is interesting in an abstract and alien way. Another wonderful game from Sleeper Games, check it out! (and also buy Red Tether and Hyperspace Dogfights!!!)

I'm giving it a thumbs up for the flavor and streamlining of concepts from some other games. I like being able to build a base with defenses, I like that there's more direction than usual, and the flow of neverending zombies feels good.

The movement... is pretty bad. The torso and legs move independently of the body - trying to make your dude run backwards is disconcerting.

Combat, which is a rather key component, is lacking hit response.  When I swing a weapon, I expect the zombie to respond... at all. Or when the zombie actually hits me, same deal. Right now, neither are happening until the zombie falls over dead, or you suddenly have half of your life yanked away.

Once the game has cooked a bit longer, and we see where the creator is going with it, I'll update this review. I'm really looking for the above to be fixed, and to see the game get a bit more sandbox-y.

Game hits a number of high notes that I appreciate in an RPG like this. Companion that isn't an annoyance in combat but still talkative and cheerful to lesson the loneliness for the gameplay. Crafting requires slaying mobs and collecting materials from your surroundings, but otherwise you'll likely get all the blueprints you need on your travel. The map isn't sandbox or super open world, you have a solid direction to go, but still plenty of space to look around and explore areas you've been.

As far as "souls like", it's kind of not. Variable difficulty setting so you can play the game in story mode if you want, or up the challenge when you feel like it. Clearing all the mobs in an area means they won't return if you die and run back, allowing you to freely explore the area without slogging your way through endless hordes of noodles. You gain experience from kills and just keep that experience. There's no penalty (like respawning mobs) for using the shrines to do mundane stuff like level or save the game or whatever.

Really, this is a good RPG. Like, the way RPGs are supposed to be. The closest example I can offer might be Fable or maybe Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning. Really, the only difference is that you're revived when you die rather than loading a previous save or checkpoint.

I really wanted to like this game more. The premise is intriguing and the voice acting is great! The illustrations for items in your inventory are really beautiful. But the actual graphics and game play leave a bit to be desired. I played with a controller and it took me 10 minutes just to figure out how to harvest corn. That's never happened to me when playing a game and I gotta say I felt pretty dumb. I really really wanted to like this game. It has potential and maybe it will improve with time. As it is right now, I'm just not feeling it.

Gameplay:

I've been playing this since the pre-ea demo. It's sort of a mix between Total War, Mount & Blade, and Arma. The world map plays like Total War's, but in real time instead of turn based. The battles themselves are a mix between M&B and Arma's Zeus. When playing in RTS mode the game feels more like Zeus, but with dumber yet more obedient AI troops. You have very limited control over your troops on the field, only really being able to control movement, stance, and fire modes. When playing in FPS mode it feels like M&B, but with guns and armored vehicles instead of swords and horses. 

So if you want something like Call To Arms, but with significantly less focus on the RTS side and more focus on the direct control/FPS side then this is it. It's a very basic RTS and an okay FPS. Not COD or Arma, but better than what you get in Call To Arms or Gates Of Hell.

Quality:

The game has come a long way since the release of the pre-ea demo and I enjoy playing it. However, at the current price of $30, I can't really say it's worth it. It lacks content, some of the mechanics still feel very clunky, and there is still quite a bit of bugs. I know the devs are working to improve the game and they do make an effort to implement features suggested by the community which has helped the game improve a lot. The game has gotten better every update and I'm confident that if the devs see this through then it'll be a great game worth the full $30.

However, looking at this from a consumers stand point I can't recommend you buy this game at its full price of $30. The game is just not there yet. For now it's best to wait until the game either improves a lot or at least until it goes on sale in the future.

So far I've been very addicted to this game since release because it strikes a balance of being a challenge without being overbearing.  Survival elements are always on my mind but not terribly hard to manage just a matter of planning out my trips for resources. As with most survival games progression eases the difficulty for water/food etc. as you get better items. Then added onto their are perks added in as you do things repeatedly aka talents that kick in. Combat takes some skill after repeatedly fighting "honey badger" and the birds I haven't tired of it. 

 I would like to address some users on the forums making complaints that puzzle me. The fov of this game is fine... I have the worst motion sickness that's induced very easily,  so far I've played for hours and not felt ill. Time passes as you craft/harvest etc. which is different but it makes time matter rather than just conjuring things into thin air like a wizard. Hence that's why mp/co-op is not really even possible because if that's added it would do away with the time mechanic altogether. 

 Overall I'm really surprised by this game when I purchased it I was expecting a janky typical survival game for the price but was dead wrong. It has a lot of content at 8hrs ingame so far I don't even have a boat constructed as i'm still exploring the first island. Gotta give credit to the developers for answering questions in the forum nice to see them interact with people rather than hiding like some devs do.  Only con is the "threat nearby" cannot build anything... I would like to see that done away with as its annoying.

If you like fun and challenging survival games, you will enjoy Survival: Fountain of Youth.  After escaping a sinking ship and washing up on a deserted island you will find yourself in a constant battle against hunger, thirst, wild animals, disease, injury, and sickness while searching for the titular "Fountain of Youth".

The game features a large, open world with tons of secrets to uncover.  The game reminds me a lot of Green Hell in terms of difficulty as it's a constant battle just to stay alive.  It's probably not for those who enjoy "casual" survival games, although I believe you can tune the difficulty to your liking.

As of this writing, I'm only about 20 hours into the game and it seems there is plenty of content left for me to discover.  (I believe there are three main islands and I'm still exploring the first one.)  I knew this was going to be a gem when I played the demo many months ago.  The early access release has definitely lived up to that expectation so far.  I highly recommend it!

I've only just begun my adventure, but I'm enjoying the survival aspects of the game so far. Having experienced the demo version of this game a few months ago, I had more of an idea going into this as far as expectations. Although there is a lot of room for growth and additional improvements, the developers have shown a lot of promise with this current build.

The Good:
1. Gorgeous environment 
2. Vast landscape with numerous plant and animal species
3. Diverse blueprint and crafting system
4. Basic in-game tutorial

Needs Work:
1. Mapping system - Drawing the map is as simple as climbing one of the larger trees. This action reveals every resource in a given radius and is available for inspection at any time, which really detracts from the overall immersion of a survival game. I think I'd rather have the ability to draw the map from a high point, but manually contribute my own markers as I discover them. This would also require a more diverse variety of custom markers available to the player. 

2. Crafting/Harvesting - I don't want to spend too much time on this as other reviews have discussed it, but the current crafting/harvesting uses a menu system that displays expected resources, craft/harvest time, and tool processing information. You are not swinging your ax to cut down trees, nor are you performing an action to construct your bed of leaves. As the player finishes the action, the weather often drastically changes or you'll be attacked by a roaming venomous critter or other predator as you exit your craft/harvest menu. 

3. Skills - A few skill perks are great and add considerable damage for thrown weapons. Other perks reduce the chance for injury during cooking by an additional 1%. I'd rather see perks that may increase the chance for a higher quality food item as you level your cooking skill. The Point Perks (PP) task system is a nice implementation, but PP for an acronym? That's literally the best we could do guys? 

4. Flora/Fauna Re-spawn - Every resource operates on a timer, with the average duration being about 30 in-game days. Though I haven't observed a full in-game day, I'd say each day lasts roughly 15 real-time minutes. So, you're playing around 8 hours before coconuts and tree bark grow back. Maybe it hinges on the immersion, or encourages the player to explore other islands. Maybe it's because the short-eared dogs or harpies were on such a short timer in the demo.

There's a few other observations such as locating the majority of stones only in dedicated stone piles, or identifying Liana used for making rope and other tools. I think the description for Liana reads "can be gathered from Banyans and some bushes." Like, hey idiot, go find the Banyan. I had to Google what a Banyan was. I think this is where we should actually have a flora/fauna encyclopedia or journal in the Journal tab, where every plant/tree and animal we interact with creates its own page. 

There are a ton of negative reviews complaining about the badger. I do think it's weird that the block and focus/aim action are the same button on controller, but the short-eared dog has a linear attack pattern. Get really good at throwing weapons by practicing on the crabs and you'll be good to go for those 'badgers.'

if you like to hunt and craft and figure out not to hard things then you'll like this game . it is a fine break from other games when you just wont to take it slow and some what easy . it does have a few pains like weight . but if you craft items right there on the spot it goes away . this is a thinking persons type of game .

About 2 to 3 hours of psychological horror and convoluted navigation through the nightmares, if nothing else the visuals were very beautiful (in a disturbing kind of way), but unfortunately, I felt the game recycled some of its ideas a bit too much. It reminds me of a certain game, but I don't want to make a comparison because of the plot similarities, although I don't think the story is all that unique. I figured it was more of a chill walking game, but it actually takes some ideas from the RE1 remake with the knife counter and a few basic weapons. That said, you can dodge most of the enemies, and the game has a checkpoint every 2 minutes or so. There were a few parts that were slightly difficult, the game has a bit of a problem with stun locking (probably intentional),  so getting grabbed next to 2 enemies is a bite rollercoaster. 

I mean, there is not a lot to say about the narrative here if I am being completely honest, you have 3 characters and the game only covers a few locations (one house and a subway inside a nightmare), and as you might guess there is something that happened to the family in the past. I kinda expected it to make some kind of unique twist or change the formula a bit, but the ending was very much exactly what I expected. 
However, I still like all of the detail in the rooms, the game has a lot of background material and various world-building - I was interested in the story, I just wish it was a bit different.

As already mentioned, the design if the scenery is really the best part here, just the coloring and the gore look very satisfying, plus the enemies feel very uncanny and unpleasant to interact with. As far as I can tell only 2 of the 4 regular enemies can be killed, and I didn't particularly like that design choice, you mostly use bullets to stun or give you a bit of room to dodge. The ammo conservation is not a very big part of the experience, the game resets your inventory between the dreams, so it never really felt like I really had to watch my bullets, aside from the last section, you can more or less just walk past the demon babies. 

There are several optional achievements, and if I am not mistaken it seems there are a few hidden events, I accidentally walked into an enemy that seemingly appeared at random in the same location, not sure what that was about. It has some* optional exploration but not really, mostly illusion of exploration, the game wants you to follow a path, with a few extra rooms that don't have much purpose otherwise. I don't recall any puzzles, for the most part you just have to figure out where to go, and it's not always easy because of the "dream logic".

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

(+) The visuals were great, everything from various death animations to just the coloring of the rooms and the design of the scenery. Very gory, if you like that it has some interesting moments. 

(+) I thought the atmosphere was not great, but decent enough and I was never really out of the experience, it's just that some unintuitive moments made me ignore the narrative a bit. 

(+) I like all of the attempts at world-building, all of the useless trinkets you can look at. I wanted to follow the story, but in the end, it fees like something we have seen before many times.

[h1] Feedback: [/h1]

[u] Gameplay [/u] - for the puddle monsters, sometimes it was not clear where they are located, I know about the body parts, but in a place with the water sometimes I could not tell, so it felt too much like trial and error.
I am not sure if you really wanted the monsters to stunlock you, even 2 enemies can grab you endlessly. Not a big fan of zombies being immortal. 

On a more subjective note, you went with the Resident Evil Remake combat and elements like ammo conservation, but because of the chapter changes and inventory reset, I felt like that part of the game didn't feel justified, I wish it played a bigger part in the game, maybe more conventional bosses you had to kill and not just run away from.

[u] Controls [/u] - for the keyboard, it would be nice if you could also hotkey all weapons to 1,2,3 as well as whatever you have now, I kinda wanted to map fire to mouse 1 too.

[u] Atmosphere [/u] - I liked the jump scares, but I felt like the first 60 minutes did the same thing as the last 60 minutes. I don't know, perhaps the game needed more slow moments with exploration, and fewer jumps.

[b] Overall Thoughts: 7/10 [/b]

My first impression was very good, I think it's a very good-looking horror game and I wish the combat mechanics had more purpose. Sadly, I just don't think the game did anything interesting with the narrative, I didn't mind the characters but for me, I think this is exactly the kind of plot you don't want to do, we have seen something similar so much over the years, I need something a little different. The game was priced a bit lower than I expected, so taking that into consideration, it's not bad, but it won't be a very memorable game for me.

This is a fun and relaxing game that takes me back to games like Kingdoms of Amular. There is plenty to do and see in this world and you are rewarded for not following the the main path. At 17 hrs in, i'm still not halfway through the story as I squirrel a lot, but that's not necessarily a bad thing in my opinion. You are meant to explore in this game. 

I've never felt the "it's a walking game". No matter what I was doing, it felt like I was moving forward. Going back to previous places was refreshing as the world areas change as you progress through the game, sometimes in interesting ways. Eventually you'll unlock quick travel points which will help with the world traversal.

The combat takes a little getting used to, and the camera angles are sometimes a hindrance to the flow of the fight, but it was never a game stopper for me. There is a good selection of weaponry to choose from and I found that some suited me better than others, and it also depended on what I was fighting. 

Crafting is simple, nothing too complicated. Resources are a little hard to come by early on, but if you explore you'll soon have more than enough for whatever you may need.

The story and lore is well told through exploration, dialog, writings, and interactions with the NPC's. I can enjoy the game without having to face walls of text to understand the world. This made the game-play more fluid and allowed me to remain focused on being a part of it.

I recommend this at a discount. Others have said the same things I'm going to say. For reference, I completed all 6 scenarios with 3 stars for each one.

For starters, the game isn't very deep or long. You can only make maybe 10, 15 foods? And the amount of objects to choose from for adding to your restaurant are slim, and sometimes don't match with anything. For example, there's a bit modern rectangular window, but no modern doorways that match it. Some tables and chairs don't match anything, either. There's also only 2 bar options and I think 4 barstool options, but the barstools are all functionally the same in terms of their decor value save for 1. The bars basically seem pointless to have in terms of decor efficiency, honestly.

Simplicity isn't a bad thing, however. But it is reflective of the game's longevity, which isn't much. After you finish the scenarios, which for me took 12 hours but for someone else may take more or less time, there's not much else to do. There's a sandbox mode, but you experienced everything that the game has to offer in the scenarios, and there's not really any amazing building options to want to farm for a super awesome looking restaurant. Decorations are few and far between.

This all sounds negative of me to say, so why would I recommend it? Simply put, I got it on sale, and I had fun with those 12 hours. Despite the flaws, it's still got a good core to it. It's just that it leaves me wanting more.

If the game looks interesting to you, you'll enjoy it. The pictures and videos aren't misleading. But don't go in expecting a AAA masterpiece, because it's a game by one dude, and for being just one dude he did a pretty damn good job.

- LOTS of activities, game modes, etc. to play.
- Multiplayer has crossplay functionality across all platforms. Finding a full grid of people to race against takes me, on average, 10-20 seconds.
- Music, sound effects, and voices are really, really nice.
- The core gameplay is very fast, frantic, and fun. Learning how to maintain your drifts and boosts are essential.
- Track design isn't the best we've seen in a kart racer, but it ranges from average to pretty good.
- Performance is really good! I have everything maxed out on my aging 5-6 year old computer, and the game runs silky smooth. No hiccups at all.
- Powerups aren't super varied, but enough to keep them interesting.

What I DON'T like so far:
- Battle pass feels like it's going to be pretty slow to progress through.
- Character graphics are a step down from everything else in the game. Mickey's ears aren't even fully rounded. I mean, the models ARE decent enough, but they could have been better.
- Gacha/loot box mechanics when opening boxes from the store make it harder to unlock specific characters, crew members, etc.
- It's advertised as free to play, but this is not the case (at least on Steam). You need to purchase a bundle that includes a founder pack, the cheapest is $30. Still relatively cheap if you go for that bundle, but advertising it as free to play feels very misleading.
- Shop is set-up in a way that definitely alludes to spending real money eventually when (not if) they add this to the game.
- The game is very grindy. Unlocking new characters and such will take a good amount of time. Casual players will probably never have the full roster unlocked, especially when we inevitably get additional characters added over time.

Overall, the core gameplay is what definitely keeps this as a thumbs up in my review. The cons aren't deal breakers at all, and it's encouraging that (at this time) there's no way to spend real money in the in-game shop. As long as you're not too bothered by the grind, there's a lot to do in this game so far and I'm sure it'll probably a blast to play with your fellow kart racer loving friends. As a whole, considering this is listed as early access, the game's currently looking and playing very good!

Great skeleton of the game I've always wanted to play.  

Excellent: The UI is smooth and intuitive, with just enough details from visual cues and most things are clickable for full details.  Building rooms, assigning teams is all very natural and easy.

Good: The core game cycle is very good for first contact of each world.  Build up power reserves to connect to more distant worlds, send a team through, return with research samples.

Poor: It feels extremely constricting to have access to a dozen worlds worth of raw resources and new tech but not be able to pay for my 8 employees more than a year before bankruptcy.  Forget about having more than 2 teams.  Forget about having guards and scientists just working at the base.  Forget about patents that last more than 12 months.  The tech tree is extremely basic, but since each world can be visited only once, and research comes only from these visits, you MUST unlock the tech tree in precisely the correct order or you can forget about unlocking next worlds which give access to next research.

Demands: For a game like this I want pages of tech tree for skills, items, weapons, marginal improvements everywhere - both for the gaters and the base's industries.  Similarly I should be able to send teams to worlds repeatedly, even if for diminishing returns, to keep myself from getting hard locked from advancement.  The recurring engineer missions for ore are great, I need this for scientists (remote labs), soldiers, traders, etc.  And most urgently, I need economic balancing.  Money should not be a limiting force once exploitation of dozens of worlds is underway - at least let me hire 1 extra guard for the base without bankruptcy.  And patents need to last longer - 12 months is just not enough time for the amount of work that goes into creating them.  I'm combining novel research from 5 alien worlds into this single tech, dammit and it should pay more than 1 soldier's wages for a year when it takes 6 scientists working around the clock under threat of death for a year to produce it.

Suggestions: not every world needs a story, but every world does need multiple, unique things about it (flora, fauna, physics, whatever).  As such I really want encyclopedias (even if just lists) of creatures and plants, ideally that I can also put on display or collect.  When I assign someone to a team, their shirt should be the color of the team for easy identification.  The thought bubbles should have a legend since they're so critical.  I should be able to research toward different types and sizes of teams, and different equipment to add to the team (robotic pack animals, etc) as ways of "leveling up" the team rather than just more experience for each member (yes I know about training rooms, but everyone has to be working near full-time gathering specimens to have any hope of enough patents for next months payroll).  There should be earth based events and storyline.  There should be more researchable gate defenses.  Gate research should unlock wider areas of planets, not just "more power, argh argh argh."  And maybe, just maybe, I could build bases on the other end of stargates that have been claimed with their own mining and research capabilities and staff.

So unfortunately there isn't much too like about this early access hack n slash title. The combat looked great from the video I saw but actually executing those moves just felt boring. There's no weight behind your attacks, the enemies are silent and offer no audible reactions to being sliced up. The protagonist is completely silent as well, not a single grunt or cry in pain as he takes damage. There is no audible feedback when your hits land, you might as well be fighting with feathers. The music is repetitive, character designs quite ugly and the writing leaves a lot to be desired.
The developer acknowledges that writing and story isn't their strong suit and hopes by releasing it in early access that the community can help improve it via feedback. Apparently the game is in a finished state but it really does not feel like it.

Marries two of my favorite genres of video games. Top down shmup + permadeath/roguelike. My favorite feature has got to be that you can save your progress part way through a run to continue later. Roguelikes should have been doing this forever.

Persistent progress, customizable difficulty, and other [i]secrets[/i] are just icing on the replay value cake.

Many intuitive improvements on a lot of Hotline Miami's core gameplay. Fantastic and satisfying mechanics.

My 2 main complaints:

1. It has the same issue as Hotline Miami 2 where because the maps are bigger, you can get killed by enemies off-screen. But because you have an actual health bar, it's not as frustrating as it was in HM2.

2. There are windows in certain rooms, and because of the color palette, these are very hard to distinguish from regular walls in the heat of a firefight.

Overall, highly recommend, especially on Deck.

p.s. Hey Dev, seriously, apply for the "Deck Verified" checkmark, it's perfect for play on it, and it would do wonders for the game's visibility.

I just started playing Zoeti and I'm really enjoying it so far! The art and character designs are amazing, and the soundtrack fits perfectly with the overall bright atmosphere of the game. I'm not much of a story person, so I tend to skip dialogues, but I can tell that there's a lot of lore and interesting characters in this game.

The mechanics of Zoeti are what really drew me in. At first, I thought it was similar to Slay the Spire, but as I continued playing, I found Zoeti to be more engaging for me. You quickly realize that using your abilities is not entirely reliant on the individual cards you draw, but require you to have poker hands. This adds an extra layer of depth that I was surprised to encounter.

Unfortunately for me, I knew nothing about poker so I had to take some time to get familiar with poker hands. Once I got a grasp on them, that's when the fun really began.

I will admit that I had some trouble trying to understand some of the combat mechanics as it pertains to debuffs, buffs, and trying to understand everything in order to make more informed decisions on what abilities to pick up. It took me some time to understand things like "poison", "gash", and "bite" as they do damage every turn but in different ways. Despite this difficulty, I was able to get a better understanding with every failure and I'm really looking forward to when I'll be able to successfully make it to the end of the run.

For hitting early access a few days ago, Neon Echo is surprisingly fleshed out and some aspects are incredibly polished. There are certainly rough edges to be found, but this could have been sold as is and you'd still easily get 30+ hours of roguelite fun. Keeping in mind that I haven't beat the second boss yet, (I haven't seen the third map/boss and one of the characters,) let's get into my experience with the game:

Positives:
‚Ä¢ Fast and fluid combat that's fun to execute
‚Ä¢ Fantastic visuals full of color and character
‚Ä¢ Memorable character designs and personalities, particularly for the playable characters that are always on-screen
‚Ä¢ The two characters I've played (Lilya and Evelyn) are uniquely strong with fun playstyles
‚Ä¢ Tempo Skills (using your skill on the correct beat to power it up) are a ton of fun to use, both intentionally and on accident
‚Ä¢ A slow but steady pace of permanent upgrades to continually work on
‚Ä¢ A healthy variety of mid-run upgrades spanning 5+ systems that can all synergize
‚Ä¢ Rhapsody deserves a special shoutout for being a really fun way to mix up and direct your build
‚Ä¢ Turbulent stages focused on dodging traps and hitting targets that are a good change of pace
‚Ä¢ Difficulty that encourages personal improvement as you progressively unlock permanent upgrades

Negatives:
‚Ä¢ The English voice acting is awful. A handful characters are unbearable to listen to, occasionally words are mispronounced or differ from the captions, some one-liners don't make sense even in context, (like "Great cooperation!") and while it's good for a laugh here and there it detracts from the experience overall
‚Ä¢ Music variety is almost nonexistent right now; I've already gotten tired of the first map's theme 6 hours in. This is bound to improve as updates come out though
‚Ä¢ While stage layouts barely pass IMO, they're currently weak. Maybe it gets better in the third act, but it's very clear there's a greater map structure that gets cut up for the short stage segments. Sometimes this makes navigation a little confusing with inaccessible areas jutting into your path, other times it serves to enhance the feeling of being a small cog of the massive machine of everything going on in the world. It would be a little better if the barriers to inaccessible zones blended with the walls. At least the short segments and sheer variety don't let you memorize individual layouts, so navigation doesn't feel stale
‚Ä¢ The Rhythm Launchpad system feels cruel at worst and underutilized at best. It definitely plays more into the longer runs I haven't gotten into yet, but it doesn't feel like there's enough music core rewards and needing to get the right colors for your build further limits the value you can get out of it. There's also a limit to how many cores you can use, so even if you're lucky enough to get all the cores you want you'll only be able to slot a few of them in. As if that wasn't enough, the randomization of slot and column/row effects means you will almost never get a cohesive benefit from the launchpad; just a few stat increases that often don't mesh with your build. And some of the effects are literal nerfs (looking at you Omni-Damage -40%)
‚Ä¢ Stage reward options aren't real choices most of the time. Despite having an entire system for picking them, usually there's literally only one option. And when a choice is actually presented it's often between currency for a future permanent upgrade and temporary run upgrade, which once again isn't really a choice; until you've exhausted the permanent upgrades they should be prioritized every time
‚Ä¢ The cooldown indicator for Neonflash, your counter, is tied to your dash. Which makes sense but means you can't see if it's available mid-dash (and the color difference is hard to make out in the heat of combat). A (neon?) visual indicator on the character would be way better but isn't present currently
‚Ä¢ Despite taking place in a world where music empowers humanity to fight, only one mechanic in the entire game revolves around listening to the game's music (and is undercut by a visual indicator). Hopefully more gets tied into the music later on
‚Ä¢ The visual beat indicator for Tempo Skills is at the bottom of the screen, so you have to look away from the action to know if you can use it; which is extra frustrating because the audio indication is almost indistinguishable from normal beats. As a result the coolest part of regular combat is mostly done on accident
‚Ä¢ For how long it takes to charge your ultimate, it doesn't feel impactful to use. Don't get me wrong the visual impact is insane, (please make ult damage show up in neon on healthbars!) but in terms of gameplay you're lucky if it kills something that a couple basic attacks or Tempo Skill wouldn't have. And since there's no way to upgrade your ultimate it will always feel disappointing to use; though I guess it's useful as a panic button for a little bit of invincibility
‚Ä¢ I can't speak for the 3rd boss and this could definitely be a skill issue, but both Lahaire and Rakan are hard to read compared to normal enemies until you've learned their patterns; which combined with significantly larger attack areas makes dodges and Neonflashes against them very difficult. With Rakan being a limbless snake this is especially pronounced, (which must be why it is the only enemy with bright red attack indicators,) but so far I can only attribute my success against the bosses to build choice and luck
‚Ä¢ There's no consistent way to attack above you, which makes airborne combat frustrating. Especially if the enemy is on a ledge slightly above you, I can't tell you how many times I've missed an enemy right in front of me because it's slightly elevated (making my attack get eaten by the ledge)
‚Ä¢ This is the tiniest issue ever, but you can't interact with some things for a brief period after dashing/jumping. I probably lost 2 minutes of my 6 hours waiting for an invisible cooldown so I could grab the stage rewards

TL;DR - The game is already good fun with a lot of polish in the visuals, long-term progression, and moment-to-moment combat. Some mechanics are weak/poorly done right now, and the English dub is absolutely atrocious, but there's plenty of time for things to improve. Definitely worth the money in its current state, especially after an update or two have come out.

Very cute, played through one time at about ~6 hours and absolutely cried at the end. I currently have no intention to play again because the game left me feeling wholly satisfied with how things wrapped up, and I personally believe that to be a big plus. Totally worth the $10.

Translation is rough in some spots but not bad enough to affect my enjoyment, and the only bug I encountered was the (often reported) issue where sometimes when you click on a letter the game softlocks. Luckily exiting the game, reloading the autosave at the start of the day, and simply ignoring the letters let me keep playing, but still an inconvenience that needs to be fixed.

All in all, lovely experience. It's very pretty and the different ways you can choose to progress kept things feeling fairly interesting. There's a lot of stuff and a lot of alternate endings, so if you're the kind of person who wants to grind those out you'll have a good time. I raised my daughter well and she grew up to be an upstanding young lady so I am content to put it  down with no regrets whatsoever. If you like these sorts of management games, especially if you're someone who came from Princess Maker, I think you'll like it a lot.

I'm about 4+ hours into the stock simulation and I've traded 5 mystery stocks. I recommend it if you're looking for an opportunity to build your knowledge of trading, technical analysis, chart, entry & exit skills from scratch. It's also a fun time-filler if you enjoy trading.

What to expect? You trade candlestick charts of historical data of stocks listed on US. stock exchanges. The mystery stocks are revealed to you only after you've traded them for a period of time. You trade with virtual money and if you're good, you should be able to grow your net worth over time. You also grow your capital by learning about various stock market & trading related concepts such as Moving Averages, Margin Loans and so on. The game starts you up with a Margin Loan which you need to invest, safeguard and build, or you run the risk of a Margin Call that ends your campaign run. The deeper you get into the campaign, your capital and technical analysis tool kit expands to include moving averages, MACD, volume and so on. You'll also unlock ETFs and crypto.
 
I've been looking for a simulation like this one for a while now. I found this through another influential day trader who mentioned it on their newsletter. I do think it can help you sharpen your skills, thought-process and trading discipline a bit. This is where the game shines. However, it's training utility drops sharply if you've already passed a day-trader beginner stage. For instance, if you've been relying on an IRL day-trading setup (indicators, trade & risk management), don't expect to be able to extend that setup to this simulation. Here you start from scratch and have limited technical customisation abilities. Ofc this is absolutely fair and I'm only mentioning this because I'd hope this review would help clarify what to expect.  

In a nutshell, the intended target audience for the simulation are beginners. It's still fun to struggle with spotting and profiting from market cycles, huge price breakouts, building your net worth over time only to have to deal with the very real emotions having it disintegrate when markets crash.

Edit: I'm yet to get to a few of the more advanced features, such as trading automation. I hope that at that point the value of the game for me personally will grow. It'd help if a slightly quicker path was available.

The Mageseeker is an action-RPG, with all the waves of enemies and grabbing of loot that you might expect. How does the game feel:

This game is awesome, the most beautiful pixel art I have ever seen. Tremendously consistent, fluid, and impressive to look at.

Powerful magic feels powerful, it breaks the terrain, destroys the scenery...

The story of the game is beautiful, it has plot twists, it has joy, but also has sadness...

The combat is fast, blink and you die. Specially in Kingslayer (hardest difficulty), most hits chunk a good portion of your health, so you have to persevere, try over and over again, just like you would on a Dark Souls game. Wich, this game on the hardest difficulty was most of a challenge than Elden Ring being honest. 

The game is beautiful, please, I encourage you to buy it one weekend (so you have time to enjoy this gem), have a blast, and so support this project so Riot sees we love the game. Much blessings. 


I would have loved to see more of Sylas and Lux tough.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Game length


About game length, I cleared it on the hardest difficulty in 17h according to Steam, 13h according to the game. Sure you could get another game that is longer but... don't you think it's about quality and not quantity?.


Few games can be super long (witcher 3) while still being a blast to play, and not to feel intentionally streetched. Mageseeker lasts for around 13-15h, but you have a lot of fun during that time.


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Replayability


It does not have a NG+ option, after completing the game, you come back to the last safe save point before the last mission.

Next month, maybe, I would start a completly new save just to come back to the challenge that was Mageseeker.

This game has a great idea, and it has promise, but it just makes no sense. You have to use research gained from other planets to... learn how to install treadmills? How to hire soldiers? How to set up a rec room? 90% of the research is just things you should know how to build initially. Sure, it's a game, and it's a game progression system, but it absolutely breaks immersion.

The economy is a mess as well. You simply cannot survive if you hire for more than minimum wage. What is this, late stage capitalism? We live this already, we don't need to play a game revolving around it. What's the point of having higher wage employees if you can't afford them? You only get so much from patents, and [spoiler] the committee drops your funding right when you need it most. [/spoiler] The fact that you can't revisit planets for more research samples is another example of game systems trumping common sense. Planets are BIG. You mean to tell me that if you go to the same planet a second time, you're not going to find anything that might be of commercial value? Instead, you're constantly in a race to expand, with more and more demands on your income, and the constant threat of dwindling income that will doom your run.

All in all, you spend more time trying to nickel and dime your way through the greatest scientific discovery known to man than you do exploring, or having fun. If I wanted to see mankind squander the wonders of science for profit, I'd watch the news. There are a lot of little QoL issues as well, but I expect those will be ironed out (I'm looking at you, guard posts and invasions). Some of the core gameplay loops simply make no sense, and detract from the immersion and the fun. I'm interested to see if this turns around and becomes fun. Time will tell.

Stray Blade comes off to me as a marriage of Kingdom of Amalur's world and design, and a mild version of Souls' combat mechanics.  

Visually, the game looks really good. Despite its more toon like appearance, they did polish it really well. The environment is large, colorful, and sometimes hazardous. Characters/enemies have unique designs, I haven't seen any rinse and repeat so far. Nothing ground breaking, but I'll take a solid design over being the next best thing.  Audio is solid. The ambient sounds is relaxing, decent voice acting, and overall in game chatter is fun.

Combat has a risk & reward setup similar to the Souls games. I don't think its anywhere near as unforgiving, but I do believe you Souls guys would still enjoy. You have your standard light/heavy attacks, dodge, parry/block, and ultimate attacks. You have the ability to lock-on to focus on a desired target. Enemies will glow according to what type of attack is coming next, which you have to decide on a dodge or parry at that moment. There's also a stun meter, which can stagger an enemy, giving you a window to unleash some free attacks. However, you're governed by a meter that's a resource for attacking and defensive maneuvers, so duel with caution. Upon death, you're treated to a revive at the last checkpoint you visited, with a little help from Boji. Weapons feel weighted accordingly, each with their own abilities and properties. You grow your character via skill trees, which you acquire points for as you level.  Equipment is also upgradeable, craftable, and can receive modifications to suit your needs. 

Stray Blade comes off to me as a marriage of Kingdom of Amalur's world and design, and a mild version of Souls' combat mechanics.  Don't come here expecting the next best Souls game or a ground breaking entry. Story seems pretty standard, but I'm OK with that, seeing as the game focuses on it's combat and character management. If you're looking for something that's fun and challenging, give it a shot.
Deep systems and great pacing! Price is very fair. Would like more sound and music.
