***Public Service Announcement***  Always take a few minutes to recommend/review games you enjoy, it helps more than you know!  Also, important and relevant...if you write a negative review and the developer immediately fixes your issue and responds as such, maybe fix your review?  As much as positive reviews are incredibly important, negative reviews (especially silly ones or legit ones that have been addressed/fixed) are horribly damaging.

I've only spent a little bit of time with the game at this point, but from what I've experienced thus far, it has been enjoyable.  The opening of the game with the foundation of the story is laid out fairly quickly and you get right into character creation for up to 5 party members.  There are a surprising amount of classes to choose from to allow you to form a group that fits your play style best.  It also gives you multiple options to try on subsequent playthroughs if you so wish.  

After character creation you are essentially allowed to spend your meager starting funds and then head off to the "Core" or dungeon.  Depending on how long you spend in character creation, you can get to the action within just a few minutes.  There IS a tutorial section you can look at from the menu that gives you A LOT of info and can explain things in much more detail, but it doesn't force this upon you.  I appreciate either way of doing things, but many folks hate forced tutorials and the developer opted to provide the info only if you want it.  So, for the more impatient among us, you can get right into the action!

You have a mini-map that fills in as you explore, you are in a first person view, as you tend to be in most dungeon crawlers, and you have a "danger indicator" in the bottom right.  The more you move and explore, the more you attract baddies.  Combat is what you would expect as well with all very easy to understand mechanics and things working how you would expect.  Again, basing this off the short time I've played, it's just a solid dungeon crawler all around.  

There are a few small things that don't matter and (I assume are easy enough to fix) that I've run into.  Letters being slightly misaligned when inputting a name, not being able to use the keyboard to just type in a name, my controller not being supported/working.  Again, none of these things are a big deal and, short of the controller thing, they can probably be easily fixed if it's worth the effort.  It literally  might be JUST me that has these slight issues and, as I said, they are tiny and don't matter.  The keyboard controls work very well, so the controller thing isn't much of an issue.  Plus, I use a PS5 controller, which tends to be the problem child of controllers.  :)

Steam tends to not count reviews when you have received a product for free, and often times people will also assume we will only say good things.  The developer specifically said they would appreciate any feedback I could give and that I tell them "...what you honestly think."  I do tend to be more positive than most, because I prefer to enjoy things and focus on what works and what is good with a game.  At the end of the day, am I enjoying my time playing Core Crossing?  Yes.  Does it present itself properly and live up to that?  So far, absolutely.  Will I continue to play?  Yes, if time permits.

So, if you're in the market for a dungeon crawler from a developer who is throwing their heart and soul into making dungeon crawlers, for the time being (who knows what the future holds), you definitely should give NANKADA and Core Crossing a chance.  They already have one out, Advent Crossroad (which I was told will be getting a big update soon) and there's a third on the way.  I also recommend you check out some gameplay of the game yourself.  It doesn't have to be my channel, but it does tend to be one of the final steps I myself take before purchasing a game.  

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a team to lead through a core and some trials.

Upon the digital stage of Steam, a grand production doth emerge, christened ArMechGeddon! 'Tis a tale of struggle and prowess, where formidable mechs of iron and steel lock horns upon the battlefield of yore.

Me thinks this creation, a mirror unto the dramatics of life, hath beguiled me beyond measure. Lo! The grand ArMechs, with wondrous intellect most navigational, doth know their position betwixt heaven and earth. 'Tis a sight to behold‚Äîan intricate dance of subtracting where they stand from where they do not.

This beauteous game hath woven a tapestry of action and wits, a perfect union betwixt human intellect and mechanical prowess. The skillful pilot, much like the master playwright, weaves a path of triumph, bringing the ArMech into victorious lands where foes meet their fateful end.

Striking a balance that teeters on the edge of reality and the digital realm, ArMechGeddon prithee bestows upon us a most pleasurable diversion. Be it known, my fellow players, that to engage in this season's tale of glory and strife within the metallic armors of ArMechs is but an honor only matched by treading the boards of the Globe Theatre itself.

Let us, then, with heart and fire, commend this creation to all who seek a taste of adventure and an ode to the Bard himself, for ArMechGeddon is a dream most wondrous, worthy of praise from gamers far and wide!

Fun little game that got more challenging with the first patch.  Very responsive developer whose first Steam release signals a lot of contributions to come.

https://youtu.be/MDA7KyQTUOo

Really wonderful vibes. The music especially is A+, evoking spiritual ecstasy and otherworldly danger both. It has a similar sort of uncanniness to things like Shin Megami Tensei and things like that. The mystery of the nature of the tower, the characters, and Paradise are compelling. There are some nice character moments that dovetail with the metaprogression, and you do get to care for the little children that climb down the tower.

Gameplay-wise, pretty simple, and maybe too simple for dedicated fans of the card-battling genre. Most enemies have varied gimmicks that you have to learn to exploit, and on deeper floors especially you can't just brute force your way through. But I think there are too few random events and enemy types, at least as far as I've gotten, making runs feel a bit too samey. The real variety comes from your team and their loadout, but you'll always want to, for example, keep one fire card on you at all times because you'll probably get an event that needs one. I want this game to be chunkier than it is.

Overall, this is a recommendation for me, with the caveat that you should go in for the whole package, not just the gameplay.

* High Replayability
* Femboy Maids
* Patch available (Ask on Kagura discord)

Although this game is similar to older dungeon crawlers, the implementation is very smooth and modern. The game at 1920 x 1080 resolution.

My only two concerns were stat downgrades when you level up and lack of class-specific item drops. The stat drops are rare when leveling up. It can be hard to find class-specific loot, because the shop only stocks basic stuff. Everything else is very modern and quick. Inventory management is good. Moving through the dungeons and the menus is very fast, especially if you use "short" confirm dialogs. People say that unlocking chests is slow, but it takes about 10 seconds to work through them.

I was able to roll up 6 custom characters with bonuses of 20+ in about an hour. So far, there is minimal grinding. I just got to the third labyrinth after about 4.5 hours of play, and my understanding is that there are about 8 labyrinths total. I expect the later ones to be more lengthy and challenging. I highly recommend the game to fans of party grid-movement turn-based combat first-person dungeon crawlers.  If you like Legends of Amberland, Etrian Odyssey, Grimoire, Might and Magic, Wizardry, etc. then you will like this game. 10/10. Well worth the price I paid.

My only gripe is the voice acting - it's VERY annoying (from the full on scripted bits to the in game vocal sounds when you parry or whatever) & I'd be fine with just text or that sort of muffled gibberish you cant make any words out from. Apart from those issues - it's a very solid little game & well worth the price I paid in Thailand - around 9 USD.

I recently picked up Grand War: Rome, a turn-based strategy game set in the fascinating and rich history of ancient Rome. After spending several hours delving into its immersive world, I'm excited to share my thoughts on this exciting game.

First and foremost, the game's strategic elements are incredibly well-designed. Each turn presents the player with a variety of meaningful choices and decisions that significantly impact the outcome of battles. The balance between managing your military, economy keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging throughout.

One aspect of Grand War: Rome that truly stands out is the smoothness of the gameplay. Transitions between turns and various menus are seamless, and I have yet to experience any performance issues or crashes. 

Another praiseworthy aspect of the game is its attention to historical accuracy. As an enthusiast of Roman history, I was delighted to see that the game's world is rich with accurate representations of figures, events, and locations. This level of detail adds depth to the experience and makes it all the more enjoyable for history buffs like myself.

That being said, there is one area where Grand War: Rome falls a bit short: the user interface (UI). While the UI is functional, it feels somewhat clunky and unintuitive at times. Navigating through menus and accessing certain features can be cumbersome, which detracts from the overall experience. I believe that with some tweaks and refinements, the UI could be vastly improved, elevating the game to new heights.

In conclusion, Grand War: Rome is a highly enjoyable turn-based strategy game that excels in its smooth gameplay, well-designed strategy mechanics, and historical accuracy. However, the game's UI could use some polishing to truly make it shine. Despite this shortcoming, I would still highly recommend Grand War: Rome to fans of the genre and anyone with an interest in Roman history. With some UI improvements, this game has the potential to become a classic in the turn-based strategy world.

As a dedicated fan of VR games like Panoptic, Nemesis, Escape from Mandrillia, and Takelings House Party, I was genuinely excited to try out VR TRIBES. However, I couldn't help but notice that the game is missing some crucial options that I've come to expect from similar titles, particularly when it comes to local multiplayer and accessibility for friends who don't own VR headsets.

I discovered that this issue had been raised in a 2022 discussion thread, but unfortunately, it doesn't seem to be on the developers' official roadmap yet. I sincerely hope they will consider implementing features like Remote Play Together, Parsec, or even a buddy/friend pass system in the future, as it would make it so much easier for me and my friends to enjoy this game together. As of now, it's difficult for me to ask my friends to invest in a game that they can only play with me since they aren't VR owners themselves.

Another aspect that I found disappointing is the lack of a single-player mode and the relatively small player base (the developers' official roadmap does indicate the implementation of a training area and AI in the future though). That said, I was pleasantly surprised to find a thriving Discord community of players eager to join in the fun.

In its current state, I'm considering refunding VR TRIBES and waiting for improvements before giving it another shot. I believe this game has great potential, and I genuinely look forward to seeing it evolve into something more accessible for everyone. Until then, with a heavy heart, I must hold off on recommending this title.

Is this game a masterpiece? Yes. Unless you hate League of Legends, then maybe not. Apart from that, it is a very well produced action-adventure set in the League of Legends universe. I never really enjoyed the original MOBA, but I have to say that the animated series was really good, and the turn-based Ruined King: A League of Legends Story rpg wasn't bad either. The Hextech Mayhem runner wasn't my taste, but this is because I don't enjoy the genre and not because it is a bad game. Back to Mageseeker. Mageseekers? These are people who seek mages to imprison them. Mages are not liked in the city of Demetia. We play Sylus, a guy with magical abilities who once was a mageseeker, but then got imprisoned and tortured by them and now hates mageseekers with all of his heart. After 15 years of prison, you escape and start a rebellion, free other imprisoned mages, torch the city and... get defeated by a knight. Only your old mentor saves you, and you have to flee the city. While the king was killed during the uprising, his son is still alive and the mageseekers, lead by the unscrupulous Lord Eldred, are under his command. After having escaped to the forest, you meet Leilani, who takes you to a well-hidden camp of escaped mages who want to fight the mageseekers. This becomes our new base where we return between the missions, talk with our allies, plan the next mission, select mages to help us on a mission and which grows and improves during the game (with our help). Quite cool.

You walk along (often spreading) paths, and when enemies appear the area becomes enclosed until you kill everyone, then you can continue. Healing potions restore your health, you can dash, and you can attack enemies. Plays like Hades so far. But you also know magical stuff, you are a mage after all. One of your abilities is to copy magical abilities of your enemies. You steal their powers, at least for one-time use. Quite cool. There are six types of elemental magic, and magic users take extra damage from their opposing element. Normal magic spells use mana, which is regenerated by dealing physical damage to enemies. You learn new spells by first copying them from an enemy, and later you can reproduce them in the camp if you have the required ressources. You can also throw a metal chain and pull yourself directly to an enemy, or use the chain to pull you to an object. This is often used to traverse an abyss, when dashing does not reach far enough. Little birds can be freed (collectibles), treasure is often hidden a little away from the main path. You can always use a map. New game mechanics are introduced along the game, the game starts out rather simple but soon does get a bit more complex and diversified.

Fights are soon against hordes composed of various enemy types, so you need to decide whom to attack first, you need to decide how to attack single foes, you need to evade their attacks. It gets rather difficult when mages cast their various projectiles at you, some very fast and well aimed, others with homing capabilities, when crossbows fly at you, soldiers slash at you and heavily armored mage-fighters cast their spells and attack you with their swords. Dashing, switching spells, using healing powers, stealing spells from mages, using chains to catch far away enemies, attacking fast with light attacks or slow with heavy attacks (which is the only way to destroy enemy armor) does keep you occupied. You can always cancel a mission and return to your base if you don't succeed. There are main missions and secondary missions which just provide rewards to improve your character (or the base). At the base, you can soon improve your character and see his stats for attack, defense, attack damage, magic damage, power ups, mana.

The game saves only at checkpoints. When you die, you just continue shortly before you died, there is no harsh punishment for failing. You can choose between three difficulty settings. Controllers are supported. Ultrawidescreen is not really supported, 2560x1440 is the highest resolution. 3440x1440 is displayed not with black borders, but stretched. Cloud saves work fine. While the pixel art looks fantastic, there are no voice-overs.

[u][b] Conclusion:[/b][/u]

Eresys - A horror survival coop Lovecraftian themed game has the potential to be a thrilling and terrifying gaming experience for players who enjoy this genre. Lovecraftian horror often involves eldritch creatures, cosmic horror, and the psychological breakdown of characters, which can create a tense and unsettling atmosphere.

In a cooperative game, players could work together to navigate the dark and foreboding world of Lovecraftian horror. Each player could take on a unique role, such as a detective, scientist, or occultist, and bring their own skills and abilities to the team.

The game could also incorporate elements of survival horror, such as resource management and limited ammunition, to create a sense of vulnerability and tension. The Lovecraftian setting could provide a variety of terrifying creatures and environments for players to encounter and overcome, making teamwork and strategic planning crucial to survival.

Overall, Eresys has the potential to be an exciting and immersive gaming experience for fans of horror and Lovecraftian fiction.

Some random thoughts in random order:

- 7/10 - somewhat entertaining to play through, but feels like it lacks depth. In that sense it's similar to MC Dungeons.
- I think the content in the game is well polished, but the amount of content/variety just isn't much.
- The concept is unique enough and there's not much competition in its genre, so that alone can make it worth trying out.
- Comparing to pricing of many other games, I'd be perfectly happy about my purchase if this was 20‚Ç¨ and I expected a 20‚Ç¨ game, but 40‚Ç¨ is questionable. 
- Many reviews compare the game to "other RTS games", but it's really just not an RTS. Don't expect to play this like Starcraft. At most the description would be like "...with some RTS elements".
- If "action strategy" was a commonly known genre, this would probably belong in it.

TL;DR If you're interested in the concept, it can be worth the time - but my personal suggestion is to wait for a sale.

Dead Unending is more about base-building and fighting off scavengers, which is super satisfying. And when you get the minigun later in the game, it's just awesome. Also, I heard they're adding co-op mode soon, which sounds pretty sweet.

So yeah, if you're into open-world zombie games with some base-building action, you should definitely give Dead Unending a try. I'm really happy with my purchase, and I'd recommend it to others for sure.

Its a topdown, hyper action roguelite. If you like the combat/flow of Hotline Miami but with some RNG abilities aspects, this is a good pick! Of course, like any rougelike, it can be absolutely BUSTED with the right perks and abilities. However, that does not mean the game isn't hard or challenging still. It can be a bit weird getting used to new areas and enemies at first, but after sometime you get into the flow of things. My only real complaint is that the toxic/floor creep enemies attacks are a bit hard to tell sometimes. Especially if you rack up a lot of bodies in an area and the toxic stuff is right below them.

Overall, I recommend if you like these types of games, definitely worth trying out. Also the soundtrack kicks ass! I can only hope more content comes in the future.

Fun concept but it seems to get to a state where RNG is the only way of getting out of some situations. Some cards show up to much and using a discard random event card will pretty much always give you a new random event card back.

The game is very fun, but I do have some things to say. It lacks some variety, for example the buddy upgrade, you could have multiple different buddies with different attack patterns etc. This applies to other things as well, like bullet upgrades, the ones that exist are fun, but there could be so many more.
The variety aside, one of the biggest problems currently in my opinion is the performance - a pixelated game like this should run quite smoothly on low-end setups, however max i ever got was like 30 FPS. Correct me if I'm wrong, but I think this game was made with Unity and my guess is that a lot of the performace problems come from dynamic lighting or the particles. However physics operations are also very resource heavy in Unity, so I would look there for the problem. Anyway I think for a game like this it is important to run smoothly on weaker setupds, otherwise you might lose out on a fairly big player base.
The third thing that's been bothering me, is that unlike in Binding of Isaac for example, you hardly have any indication of when you actually do get items, because it's very random. The thing I would personally suggest is that you use chests for loot that is definitely going to contain items and maybe urns for sth that only contain money or bombs or whatever else. On top of that runs are very unbalanced in that sense, because some runs I got an item in almost every chest and others I didn't get a single item for the whole first floor basically.
One other thing is that the game is kind of too short, I beat it in about 5 hours of playtime I believe and there are only 4 floors and all floors kind of have very similar enemies just slightly modified.
In conclusion I do have high hopes for this game to become even better and the downsides aside, it is a very fun game.
7/10

Stray Blade after learning the mechanics is a good game.
A souls like, metrovania with a twist of its own. The graphical style is pleasant with crafting mechanics and various materials spread across the large map that adapts to the player with a large tree of unique skills to unlock.
The game's problems are basically reduced to small gameplay details for souls like players mainly.
I tried playing on the hardest difficulty and quickly realized that some mechanics needed to be changed.
The game is based on a parry and dodge mechanic. Parry works well but dodging has a very small field which makes it frustrating at times.
Simple mechanics like backstabbing should be immediate death to a single NPC but in this case it relies on a single hit, making stealth mode useless.
The game has a lot of potential and it's a good game once we learn the mechanics, a few simple changes would make the game brilliant.

For now, i cannot recommend this. The early game (2-3 hours) is fun, then it turns into a slog. The big issue is money, and frankly it's not reassuring that such a critical element just a few hours in isn't noticed by the devs. 

There are broadly 3 sources of income: funding (which runs out after just a year, for some reason), mining, and patents. The most common ore is useless except to sell, but sells for so little that it's barely worth it. You cannot sell the other ores either. This leaves patents. With some luck and planning you can get some good patents that can pay quite well. unfortunately, there are too many categories which vastly dilutes how much theories you have, which greatly reduces the potential value of patents.

The biggest drain on your budget is wages. The system is bizarre: initial pay is what the person will cost, forever. Levelling up does not increase pay. Higher wages employees will have higher stats, but this is a noob trap. Money is the limiting factor, not skills. So you have to hire everyone minimum wage or else you are simply shooting yourself in the foot, not just on the short term but forever. 

The end result of all of this is that you simply softlock at some point. You run out of patents, planets to explore, and mining ore simply cannot sustain your program. The aliens don't actually have to do anything to defeat you: your own budget will. Although again, they represent a significant drain in either soldiers (lvl1 soldiers cannot 1v1 a single alien and the first invasion already features 3. this is absurd. But you also cannot compel anyone to defend or focus fire, so a soldier will run to the canteen to grab some food as the aliens are barging through the gate).
cool game, love it but a bit pricey for a 20h gameplay

It's no Warcraft 3 but it's still fun. It being open world through me off at first but I quickly grew to like it. The world is dynamic with constant piglin expansions and invasions that you can choose to deal with or ignore. There isn't a huge amount of units but they all serve a unique role with none feeling useless. Both the defence and attack gameplay is fun. I remember when I was younger I would build walls and redstone turrets around a village then spawn a load of mobs to create a siege, you can do that for real now. The mission structure is the same for the whole game, destroy 3 bases then fight the boss for each faction. Each faction has completely different base architecture with different weaknesses though so it doesn't feel like you're doing the same thing. My major complaint is the lack of factions which is pretty unheard of for an rts game. Another complaint is the player character does literally 0 damage to high tier enemies, bosses and buildings so all you can do is take out the weaklings while your units do everything important, it especially sucks for boss fights. 3/4 boss fights were boring because you can't do anything yourself. I liked one of the bosses because you have to defend a village from it or you lose. The final boss was just more of the same, spawn a load of units next to it and run around, Not being able to hurt bosses with your sword was a really dumb design choice. People have different attention spans so I can't tell when you will get bored but for me the campaign slightly overstayed its welcome. In the last hour I just wanted it to end.

6/10 wait for a sale

Classic survival game with great exploration, a unique mapping system, polished ocean navigating, and detailed yet rewarding food, water, fatigue, and disease/ailment systems. The game world is beautiful and each new biome/area provides a new survival experience. The crafting system is very well established with several tiers of weapons and equipment, specialized crafting stations, complex cooking, as well as fully fledged base building complete with wall trophies, lamps, and rugs. The gameplay does feel a bit grindy until your base is established. Fast travel with your boat to player-built docks makes returning to your base a breeze. For a survival crafting game that has only just entered Early Access, this game feels surprisingly whole.

Very good game. Improves on the first in many ways, but still has the feel of a teslagrad game. Absolutely beautiful art, music, bosses, everything. 100% recommend for fans of the first game. Also, try to find the secret techniques, they make an already fun game even better.

Quite simply, Teslagrad 2 takes all of the elements that made Teslagrad 1 great, and cranks them into overdrive.

The Story: Preserving the same methods of silent storytelling as the original, T2 links T1 and World to the West together to make a seamless cohesive storyline. Seemingly innocuous background art from T1 is given massive significance in T2, and new story elements introduced in T2 are deliberately left a bit vague so they can be expanded in future games. Characters have complex motives which gives them a lot of depth.

The Music: J√∏rn Lavoll outdoes himself. Fire up the game and listen to the title screen music. Just listen, let it develop. It didn't have to be that good since most people will just spam a button to get to the menus, but what an intro. Many more musical styles are explored here, ranging from heavy metal to jungle to whimsical, with plenty of callbacks to music from T1.

The Gameplay: Movement is much more fluid and rewarding. Blinking, a core ability from T1, is given to you from the very start of T2. Sliding was an ability cut from T1 but brought back in T2, and the levels embrace it in plenty of places, with slopes everywhere to launch from. Simple platforming and very mild puzzles lead up to the first boss, but then the puzzle platforming begins to show its true robustness, with new puzzle elements supported by the new item collectibles. Lots more variety in terrain, and some very-appreciated "fast-travel checkpoint" options to get around the much larger map. The boss fights start easy and ramp up to very hard if you're going for all achievements.

This game is a masterpiece. If you liked Teslagrad 1 in any capacity, this is a must-play.

An amazing translation into VR. The weapons feel great to use, movement is smooth. The UI is done well, melee combat feels good, the green sword is done amazingly; very early in, but I can see myself loving this more than the original.

Only slight comment I'd say is it can feel like whenever you land a melee hit, *you* get hit too; the combination of a hitsound and the screen flashing (with the ammo you just got) makes it seem that even if you struck first and killed them, you're getting hit anyway. Takes a few minutes to realise it's not the case, and you get used to it.

The weight system is annoying. I spend more time managing inventory than enjoying the game. 
Combat feels sluggish.

Up front I'll give it a score of 7/10.  Probably should bump it down to a 6/10 for the bait'n'switch they pull in a sidequest, but I'll get to that in the spoiler section.  Combat's fun for the most part, but there is one fatal flaw that absolutely killed it for me.

For starters: a lot of people thought this was going to be a roguelite/rogue-like. It is neither, it's a straight-up linear progression story. In terms of gameplay it's like a cross between the old God of War games and an arcade beat'em up (Streets of Rage, Ninja Turtles, Final Fight, etc). In between levels you wander around camp, talk to people, put points into your upgrades, then start up the next level.

Combat was fun with a fair amount of options in terms of abilities. As those familiar with Sylas from LoL would expect, a key mechanic is stealing spells off of your enemies. Once you've stolen a spell you can unlock it as an equipable spell. While stolen spells are used for free, when you're holding a stolen spell you don't have access to your equipped spells so you have to use the stolen one first. Equipped spells use mana. Your mana bar has up to 4 pips, and each spell costs a different number of pips. Mana is rebuilt by doing regular and strong attacks, strong attacks restoring more.

So you can find your favorite spells and equip them, but you're by no means a spell-spammer. Most of the best spells in the game cost 3 pips, and regaining pips takes a fair amount of physical attacking. With regards to melee combat: as you progress through the game you'll unlock members of a band of "outlaws." These are basically equipable people that increase your damage of a certain type and give you a combo with that type as well. Like the ice guy lets you do a light > light > light > strong combo where the strong leaves a frost AoE puddle that's a DoT.

Also of note is you can use his chains to yank yourself to enemies from a pretty fair distance. Part of my bread'n'butter combo involved this with a wind kick.

So there's plenty to work with in terms of making a build to fit your playstyle. Early-ish in the game you get a spell that gives you a small amount of shield hp for 3 mana pips, and that was pretty much what I spent most of my mana on. Speaking of sustain: you also get a potion with 3 charges that can be upgraded for a 4th, and towards the end of the game you unlock Guardian Angel which gives you one revive per level. I never had it proc so I don't know how much it revives you for, it doesn't say.

As for the one thing that absolutely killed it for me: movement.  It can feel absolutely terrible at times, particularly due to the fact that you can't dash through obstacles.  Not only does this mean it's particularly easy for the enemy to corner you, but it also means that you'll get periodically stuck on random crap like an indestructible stool sitting on the floor.  For a game that's based on rapid-pace action, taking a few hits because Sylas caught his foot on a chair gets pretty frustrating.

~~~Now for some spoilers, stop reading if you don't want to know what champs show up~~~

Champs that appear in the game include...
[spoiler]-Sylas (Obviously)
-Lux
-Garen
-J4
-Shyvana
-Morgana (she fights you as a test of strength before giving you her blessing)
-Kayle kinda-sort but not really
-Nocturne***
***It's just a 3 second cameo.  You're on a sidequest to hunt down something dangerous in the forest that seems to be playing on your fears.  Turns out it's Nocturne who "fights" you, but it's just a repeat of the Morgana fight.  After you win she turns into Nocturne who you see just long enough for him to laugh at you and disappear.  As I mentioned, this bait'n'switch was almost enough to knock the game down to a 6/10 for me because I thought a Nocturne fight would have been awesome.  But no, just reuse an old fight, have Nocturne flip us the bird, then he buggers off.  But I still say the game feels better than a 6/10 so I gave it a 7.[/spoiler]

An absolutely chaotic game that somehow manages to combine the platforming elements of Spelunky with a touch of base management right out of Metal Gear Solid 5 / Peace walker.

How does this actually play then? You go through procedually generated levels with an objective. This could be neutralizing a specific enemy, capturing one, grabbing certain types of loot or getting through the level in a set amount of time etc. You have a fulton balloon system to both grab loot and stunned enemies. Those enemies can then be converted to join your side.

Each unit has their own set of positive and negative quirks and those can change on levelup or later be modified manually. If one of your units dies, they are gone for good. If you are captured however, you can later get missions to rescue those units.

Overall a very fun, chaotic game that I finished just around the 10 hour mark.

Allow me to cut to the chase;  Are you a fan of Dead Cells and Hades? Then you'll find this game both familiar and different. Like a certain fit of a new pair of jeans that are delightfully different because they came from a new company.

Aesthetically, there's more than enough difference that on a visual level it feels wholly different from the aforementioned games. In fact, a ton of detail, care and love has gone into the various special effects, character design and art to give it futuristic neon-rave feel and somehow, without agitating the holly hell out of my astigmatism. (Well done, devs.)

The game-play feels more like Dead Cells, or more recently Have A Nice Death (with a touch of rhythm and timing) - very fast paced, flashy side-scrolling with all the replayability you'd expect from games of this genre. The hub has a plethora of upgrades to pursue, making your path and choices throughout your runs rather difficult, when it feels like you need a bit of everything to make progress.

My gripes about this game at the moment, are minimal. 
-The host of resources you need seems a bit overwhelming in the beginning. I caught myself asking, "wtf do I need this for, again?" more often than I'd like. 
-The musical-battle aspect is very minimal and feels a bit tacked on, as it only affects one skill and it's not easy hit just basing your timing on the music. The audio cue isn't prominent enough and by the time I try to register the timing, the moment has passed and I end up with the weaker variation of the skill every time. I had to use my peripheral vision to have any success with it.
-Finally, the voice acting. Not so much the accents - I applaud anyone from any Asian descent that grew up with their native language, to even attempt to adapt to English. A specific nitpick of mine, the audio doesn't match with the subtitles. Not a huge issue, but it does break immersion.

Although I usually stray from early-access games at a price, I don't regret this one bit. I'm excited to see the future improvements and characters. More than anything, I hope to see more characters, maybe new weapons for each character and whatever else the devs see fit to add. If it's this good already, the finished product with be a hit!!!

Overall, I think you have a lot to do in the game, and I will personally spend lots of hours trying to unlock as many career endings and romance endings as I can.

If Lemmings and Abe's Odyssey humped and had a baby, and Subterrania and Rescue on Fractalus humped and had a baby, those two babies humped and had a baby, Moons of Darsalon would be that baby's baby. This game has everything! Frantic platforming action, state-of-the-art voice synthesis, an amazing SID chip-infused soundtrack, excellent vehicle physics, a full-color palette, 3d pre-rendered ships and scenery, and an overall retro charm that reminds you of a time when the best games were those that had a single developer with a singular vision. One of the best 2D games I've played in years. Well done!

Hello, someone who 100% completed the first game here! I am a huge fan of Coffee Talk, so you bet I got excited to play the sequel the moment it released. I can honestly say this game is a great sequel overall, and expands on the first game when it needs to. Some things are a little different, such as new drink combos, characters, etc. but overall it keeps the formula of the first game and what made it enjoyable, which I say as a massive compliment!

The only other thing I will add is that it's best to come into this game expecting a continuation of the first game (which is to be expected when it says "Episode 2" lol). Because the game is very much the same format, it does feel like we play right where we left off, so you NEED to play the first game in order to understand what's going on in this one. I still have yet to get all of achievements so I do not know all of this games secrets yet, but I can't wait till I do.

I really love what I've played of this game so far, and I think that any Princess Maker game fans will, but unfortunately I just can't recommend it whilst it has so many bugs. 
I can't escape the letters screen so have to play without them, and then when horses were unlocked the game immediately crashed on trying to capture one. 
I'd love to change my review once the game is fixed and I can actually play it to completion.

TLDR;
Great Princess Maker-esque (or Long Live the Queen) game despite some bugs and iffy english texts. 8/10

The good: There is a lot of things you can do, and choices to make that will give varying results without being too punishing. Aside from story related choices most mistakes can be fixed as long as you're not going for a perfect run.
A lot of short mini-games to keep it interesting without it being a chore, since obviously you'll be doing them more than once if you're aiming for a specific stat.
Although I've only reached one ending as of this review, the story and ending was nothing too far from what I would've expected from the choices I made.
The visuals are good, cute, and fitting.

The bad: At the time of the review, mainly the bugs and iffy english translations.
I ran into a few bugs but nothing terribly unavoidable or detrimental to the progression, but there were times where I needed to restart the game. At least the auto save is there in case you forget to manually save.
The text is mostly broken or have grammatical/spelling errors, but most are comprehensible to a point. This may bother some and break the immersion. Nothing was broken to the point of making a wrong choice during my first playthrough.

Some minor QoL functions are missing, such as text skipping but honestly since most texts are short it's not the end of the world.
Both manual and auto saves start at the beginning of the day, so there is no way to save right before choices. But again, the texts aren't long so it's not that difficult to go back to the same spot from the start of the day.

There comes a time in every man's life when he needs to take a look at himself in the mirror and wonder how exactly he reached such a place.
You have to truly ponder what decisions you have made along the way that brought you to the place of your final reckoning.

It is still unclear, even to me, why I purchased The Monstrous Horror Show. 
There isn't anything wrong with it, with those nudity scenes throughout it's perfectly stellar. But when you look at it as a choice, you realize just how flawed you and the rest of humanity is.

What drove me to purchase such a game? What part of my soul felt so empty that I thought a virtual girl could fill it?
When I look into the boundless depths of my own loneliness I see a pool of reflection. My face isn't there, there is no face. There are only tears in that pool, tears of shame and loss and confusion.

If it were up to me again I know I would purchase it in a heartbeat, I know I would load it up and skip through the countless window prompts so I can have a single morsel of pornographic images which are readily available online.
Yet, despite the abundance of naked virtual women waiting in the digital sphere, I still chose to purchase this game and devote hours of my life to it. That time will never return to me, it is lost just like my soul and just like the time I fear I may never find it again.

There is something broken within me, something that desires sensation beyond my reach, something that whimpers every single night with the knowledge that there is no true Princess, it is a merely an illusion.
In my pursuit to find meaning in this long life, I sought the colorful lights and sounds of a world that only exists in a pop up window on my computer.

I am unsure what the moral of this review is, I am unsure about my place within the universe, all I know is that no amount of virtual girls can cure the vast rot that has overtaken me.

Mageseeker is a masterpiece. The story is spectacular and each detail immerses you in the league of legends universe. The fighting felt action packed, quick and not too free. I played through the entire game on the hardest difficulty and did not get to the end of the game without a bit of a struggle. This game does a great job with slowly rolling you out new tools to take on different types of enemies by making different elements have a counter element. Hopefully everything in here is canon and they start dropping characters in league from these Riot forge games. I'd like to see Rukko, Yops and Wisteria ported over in some way. 

I do have some grips with the game, specifically the feeling that they ran out of ideas to make it to the end of the game, but didnt want you to go from cut scene to cut scene. So they made filler by just throwing more enemies at you. about the last 20%-30% of the game, I had unlocked everything and started skipping side quests. Another thing that bothers me is the lack of end game anything. When you are done, yeah you can play through and tune the difficulty but besides that you are maxed out and your moving... game just ended. 

Still worth every penny. If you are a league fan and want to enjoy some of the story like you did with Arcane, grab this one.

It has "Metroidvania" tag, but I haven't seen any ability gating so far (most "gates" are bosses or keys like in dark souls). The map is also a collection of locations between which you teleport, and so far they seemed pretty linear, though you would expect a non-linear interconnected map in most metroidvanias. The fact that the map is absent is also quite annoying and, while common in souls-like games, is pretty frustrating for a game that claims to be metroidvania, and makes tracking your exploration progress much harder than it should be.

Great graphics and sound, just like its predecessor. Once again, bonus points for ultrawide support. No complaints about the presentation, but some of the characters definitely rub me the wrong way. YMMV in that department. 

I had read that the original writer passed away. I see this left the team with a difficult choice. To their credit, I could not tell the difference between the two. It emulates the same style and tone, and I imagine this is intentional to honor the spirit of the original author's intent. Unfortunately, I think the writing was the worst part of the original by far, and I see this as a missed opportunity to move on from that. 

All of the supernatural elements in this story are but the thinnest of veils for what is ultimately a collection of modern day social media discourse. There is rampant virtue signaling, and every character speaks about the world around them as if they live inside Twitter. There are a scant few genuine moments, and I can appreciate the fact that the writer(s?) clearly feel a lot of angst about putting themselves out there and the creative process in general. There is a complete lack of subtlety in the writing regarding this, but I see it and I get it. 

It feels a lot more disappointing than the first one, as we're familiar with much of the cast already, and there's not a lot of progress or poignancy in their respective narratives. I genuinely came away from this game feeling like I spent a few hours reading Twitter threads. It's nothing but surface level social commentary.

Given that the intent here was probably to honor the original writer, I'd still be in for a Coffee Talk 3 in the hopes that they show some growth and try something different. If that one also ends up being the same, I'd definitely call it quits. 

FWIW, this is certainly a worthy tribute for those who do not find fault with the original.

I can't really put into words how much Toge Productions and its games has continously exceed my expectations. And this sequel is totally a deserving and heartwarming sequel to the first game. The characters had all grown and we get to dive deeper on their new emerging problems as they enter a new stage of their life. Meeting them again in this game feels like meeting an old friend whom you haven't talked in so long, and yet you still share the old memories of those years gone by (gosh, I sound like Hyde, don't I...). But yeah it's nice to continue their story while meeting new curious characters as well.

I personally love that in this game and the previous game, Toge doesn't shy away from discussing heavy but important topics, especially for us youngsters looking to find our way to navigate the world. Some of the conversations between the characters do got me thinking and definitely there is a lesson learned there somewhere. But that aside, it's what you would expect the sequel of a chill and heartwarming story would be. And not gonna lie, I almost always have a smile in my face while playing this game, and even if I'm not smiling, there is always something I feel inside, which shows how good the storytelling on this game is as you easily get emotionally and physically (sometimes mentally) invested in the game. It's as if you are following the journey of the characters as if you are really part of the story, which is the appeal of this game from the first sequel as well. So I can't thank you everyone at Toge (including the late Mr. Fahmi) for bringing us such an amazing story and game to experience. Although I can't speak for everyone, so I would recommend everyone to try and see for themselves and hopefully it would leave a lasting mark on everyone too, as it already leave quite a remarkable memories for me personally. So cheers!! And I can't wait to see what story Toge will bring to us next!

A great sequel to the first game! It introduces new interesting characters that you can't help but fall in love with and beautifully intertwines their stories with those of already known characters. The gameplay got improved with two new ingredients and collecting lost items which you can give back to the customers. Overall the second episode of Coffee Talk improved on the already great first game and makes room for more in the future!
game was made by an incel.

The game is aesthetically pleasing, the music choice is excellent, the sound design as a whole is fantastic, overall the game is just insanely satisfying to play. If you think it looks cool, I can assure you it is. I need to play more but I can already tell the game gets better the more you play it. Your skills sharpen, your arsenal expands, the Hotline Miami fan in me is very very happy.

The dialogue is entertaining, but it's quite annoying to play without a guide. There is a definite "correct" or "best" path due to how game-y everything is. Lack of rollback or autosaving can also make things pretty annoying. Hope your "save at every choice" game is strong, or god forbid you fat finger or misclick something. On that note, prepare for soooooo much backtracking, even if you didn't make a choice on accident. Seriously, how do you include random nonsense "comedic" game overs multiple hours in without a rollback function?

Also, the "they" thing is super weird. I assume they did it to not have to record audio (or write dialogue) twice. Still, it's hard to be immersed in a story where you are essentially playing an amorphous blob with no discernible concrete personality traits or identity. It makes for bizarre moments in conversation (and particularly more intimate parts), where the characters (and game) can't actually describe your character because they're completely nondescript. I assume by the themes and more dramatic tone of some parts, they were indeed trying to make you take the story more seriously this time around. If that's the case, I feel it would have been more wise to have picked a gender, picked some at least basic personality traits, and committed to them so it felt like the characters were relating to a person as opposed to an amorphous creature that was just trying to pick the right options to get their pants off. I think it would have really helped the writing.

This isn't a bad game; it has several great parts. But this is not a rating, it's a recommendation, so no I wouldn't recommend it, unless you're really nostalgic for the old stat based dating flash games of yester year and this is exactly what you're looking for.

I am really liking the game not sure what all the mixed reviews are about as it is pretty good. It could be better but honestly it is not bad. The only bad thing imo would be paying 35 euro for this but for 20 it is decent. I am a little lost though even with the compass as it always points to a direction that is closed off by a wall. But the way can still be found without it.

i dont usually write reviews but i feel compelled on this because of the vast mixed reviews/very negative reviews i feel are overblown. This game for sure has some flaws that could have and probably should have been ironed out but they are not game breaking. Most peoples problems with the damage and combat are no where near as bad as said once you start upgrading your armor and your hp/stamina pool. i am playing on the 3rd difficulty (there is 4) and im at a point i feel like i could be on the 4th if i want more of a challenge but could still progress. the actual issues with the game are your weapon "special attacks" feel like they were an oversight. like whoever created them was like "oh lets add a decent strong attack with a cooldown for brownie points" but never actually field tested them. they are like a 2/10 on usefullness. they are god awful slow animations that can just be and WILL BE interupted by an enemy attack and do not do enough poise damage or hp damage to be like "man i NEED to get this move off". yes of course i still always try to use them lol but they are implemented horribly. they parry/dodge system is actually pretty good and cool except if there are multiple enemies attacking. again i think this was an oversight without field testing. you can only parry one attack and HAVE to wait till the parry animation is done to do another meaning if a second enemy is attacking you ARE getting hit no way around it which takes away from skill expression. the fact enemies can constantly interupt/daze you compared to you BARELY ever is just a forced way to add difficulty but take away skill expression/immersion when even the littlest creatures/humans use a light attack and do it yet you used a massive hammer heavy swing and they just swing right through it like yyeeeaahhhh OK not going to happen. its comically bad and frustrating as it breaks your combat groove but again its not gamebreaking and can be worked around. everything else is great. the scenery changes between darker battlegrounds to lush colorful nature. voice acting is fine as long as you dont mind british sounding accents. besides the weird battle flaws i described battles are actually satisfying learning movesets and the finishers are nice looking and quick (most of them). the parry/dodge thing everyone complaining about the game telling you not to look at the color but the movements is i think just a description mistake and the part of the devs. the best way to explain it is you dont HAVE to just react to blue=parry and red=dodge. like you can still dodge backwards on a blue overhead swing. no you cant parry a red attack but you CAN block every attack with a shield wepon. the story isnt too deep from what ive gathered so far but it is unique and interesting so it makes you want to actually uncover the whole thing. if you like adventure/exploration games with action combat this is a very nice and fun game for sure worth picking up.

Yes, its very good, its fun to play with good movement, you don't have to be good at it but you can still manage, speed-running the game was very fun and smooth, the one down side is that once a guy dies you can't get them back, but with the lab you could replace them and make them even better, amazing sound track too, library theme my favorite

The gameplay of Amid Evil is adapted to VR in a great way. This is not just a cheap VR port but a great translation. The weapons feel and look great, so do the levels and the enemies. Being a movement shooter you should have your VR legs before playing this. This demonstrates how well Boomer Shooters can work in VR.

TL;DR: Game is off to a great start and found it enjoyable, are there a few bugs and rough spots? Sure, but as an indie Dev I'll usually give some leeway in that area. Also for the price, its not really breaking the bank to support the developer as they clearly grasp some of the atmosphere, I'd like to see how this game could really grow. But understand this is definitely an early access title and not a complete game in my eyes, if Development stops short this review may change.

Review:
So all in all i've played this game for a couple hours with my gaming group and we plan to play more.

The game is basically a Hide and Seek, Scavenger Hunt, that can feel a bit long winded at first, but once you start collecting and turning in the blood to create the blood orbs, not only does the game get darker (lower brightness) but the monsters become increasingly active. With this mechanic its kind of interesting to see the game change, however I feel this leaves a flaw in gameplay as you could simply ignore blood for a time and gather the pages, then start turning in the blood and making a break for the end portal, thereby making the game easier. My recommendation here would be to create a soft time limit that every "X" minutes or so, the stage treats it as though a blood orb as been gathered (i.e. get darker, more active monsters) without of course awarding the blood orb, to make the game increasingly more difficult as time progresses, similar to how hunts in Phasmophobia work. I would also add a lose condition based on time (a generous amount of time) where the ancient one would awaken. Side note for fun we tried to enter the portal once without a complete book, just for fun to see what would happen and sadly you can't, though we did end up swarmed by numerous enemies. 

I also feel like there is definite room for growth in the tool department, as running with just a lanter, book and blood vials really leaves the gameplay a little waning. Add some more unique lore based one shot items that can help in situations and also add some depth to the gameplay.

The art design is honestly on point. I'm a huge sucker for the Lovecraftian horror genre and feel like the atmosphere is quite accurate. I will say though I would like to see more interesting levels aside from just scavenger hunting through a forest. Perhaps a giant mansion style map with new horrors etc.

There are some visual bugs to be sure. Like walking (floating) on some of the rocks near the perimeter of the map. A couple of rocks that when trying to walk on you would clip through, and one situation where one of our group became stuck on a log, unable to move.

Another thing I would recommend removing is the cutscene when a blood orb is generated, as the game is not paused and the individual that places the last blood into the altar is basically helpless once the cutscene begins. Honestly, its not really needed in my opinion and only adds a small level of frustration when trying to complete the last blood orb, monsters nearby and you're trying to make a clean getaway only to be caught mid cutscene.

Other than that, for $8 USD I feel like I could get my money's worth of entertainment from the game, and its a chance to support an indie dev. This view is of course subjective so I dont fully expect anyone to necessarily agree with me, but all in all its a nice little lovecraftian horror game that is simple to just jump into and enjoy a round or two.

Been looking out for this game since the first ever reveal and DAMN, i loved it. But for the note: This game is in its EARLIEST state right now. With bugs that where you can clip out from the map and get stuck under the rocks or can't even navigate yourself and easily can get lost or go in circles, game itself really has the atmosphere of Lovecraftian place and really gives the vibes of it with its mysterious island. Monsters and their mechanics (how to avoid them, how they find you and etc) are great. Objective of the game is pretty straightforward though. Which for someone who grasped what to do in order to find / collect necessary stuff for plot to move, it can be pretty short. But of course, exploration for the first time was really magical and pulled me in easily.

If this game is gonna receive new maps (perhaps a city map, or something different from just an island like an desert or inside an pyramid) then there should be more different kind of objectives and more focused on story telling and letting the player find out what to do other than just explaining what is the goal of you and your cultist friends right at the start of the game.

A few talkative npc's around the area that's hidden leading to an side-mission or objective where you can unlock more secrets perhaps? Who knows.

With that said, I am looking forward for more content from this game and its developers. I absolutely love the idea of this game and can't play again when its a lot more polished and more filled with cosmic secrets that will drive you to insanity.

Digital Sun did a fantastic job with this game.  I've never played a genre like this before and had a blast.  I'm a big League of Legends fan, and thought the lore and story lines involved were amazing. Would recommend to anyone interested in the League universe or even just a new game to pick up.  8.5/10

The Mageseeker is another great game from Riot Forge that proves one of the biggest strengths of the world of League of Legends; the lore and characters.

A lot of the first reviews I saw for The Mageseeker highlighted that it was a short game, but for the price tag I was very happy with the length of the game - in fact it took longer for me to complete than I thought it would. Though it's worth pointing out there is very little replay value here.

The difficulty is another plus, I played on the highest preset difficulty (you can fine-tune aspects of the difficulty if you wish which is a nice feature) and I found many of the boss battles to be a welcome challenge. They also were always a great spectacle, particularly the fights against [spoiler] Jarvan/Shyvana, Wisteria and Morgana [/spoiler], and were coupled with great music which plays on riffs familiar to people who follow the lore of League.

The combat is really unique and represents Sylas fantastically, though I think it can sometimes be a bit awkward to target the correct enemy in fights and it doesn't completely click in the earlier stages of the game. However, as you advance through the game and acquire better abilities it really comes into its own. The battles in the last few missions are fantastic and you are really tested on your ability to juggle spells.

The Mageseeker features a good number of cameos from League and Legends of Runeterra characters, many of which you would expect based on the premise. It's great to get to know them more and allow their story to develop. In addition it also introduces lots of interesting new characters as both allies and enemies. As for the big picture, the struggle between the rebel mages, the mageseekers and Demacia as a whole makes for a compelling story, especially when you sprinkle in meddling from Noxus and the Black Rose.

Overall, The Mageseeker delivered everything I was looking for when it came to exploring the story of Sylas and Demacia and also has challenging gameplay that rewards your experience in it. so it's a strong recommendation from me.

First things first.
If you enjoying this game, good for you, I'm happy for you, this is just my experience what I'm writing down.

This game made me really mad right at the beginning.
On 1440p, epic settings, this game ran 35-45 FPS. Even FSR on, the max was 55.
Why?! 
I have no clue. I got a RTX2070 and I played Cyberpunk 2077 on all high, dlss on, 1440p with 75-95 FPS, or WD: Legion very high and some ultra settings, dlss on, 1440p with 65-100 FPS. 
There isn't any reason why this game ran so shitty on my rig.

But I was very generous, so I went back to 1080p with FSR on and the game ran with 85 FPS.
I wasn't really happy about this, but ok.

Let me tell you one thing: 
I've finished Elden Ring, Remnant from the Ashes, Code Vein, so I'm not totally unexperienced with these kind of "souls like" games.

But the combat in this game...maaan...
Dodging is somewhat ok, but parry. It's broken AF.
The game warns you to not react to the flashing indicator (that seems pretty stupid to me, but ok), but man... I died 3 times because I coudn't parry at all. Even when I tried to react on the last second of the animation, nothing happened. I just took the hit. So after 3x of dying + the problem with the graphics I asked for a refund. 

So, this is my wonderful experience with this game. :D
UGH!

The general gameplay is good, the driving mechanics, items and maps feel nice, i can see that there's a lot of grind/purchasing needed to unlock what you want, but hey the game goes f2p later and need to finance somehow.

Steam Support may help if you ask nicely by choosing ‚ÄòI have a question about this purchase.‚Äô They say Speedstorm is complimentary with each pack, however, I see no option to play a free version of this on the store page. For now, i cannot recommend this. The early game (2-3 hours) is fun, then it turns into a slog. The big issue is money, and frankly it's not reassuring that such a critical element just a few hours in isn't noticed by the devs. 

There are broadly 3 sources of income: funding (which runs out after just a year, for some reason), mining, and patents. The most common ore is useless except to sell, but sells for so little that it's barely worth it. You cannot sell the other ores either. This leaves patents. With some luck and planning you can get some good patents that can pay quite well. unfortunately, there are too many categories which vastly dilutes how much theories you have, which greatly reduces the potential value of patents.

The biggest drain on your budget is wages. The system is bizarre: initial pay is what the person will cost, forever. Levelling up does not increase pay. Higher wages employees will have higher stats, but this is a noob trap. Money is the limiting factor, not skills. So you have to hire everyone minimum wage or else you are simply shooting yourself in the foot, not just on the short term but forever. 

The end result of all of this is that you simply softlock at some point. You run out of patents, planets to explore, and mining ore simply cannot sustain your program. The aliens don't actually have to do anything to defeat you: your own budget will. Although again, they represent a significant drain in either soldiers (lvl1 soldiers cannot 1v1 a single alien and the first invasion already features 3. this is absurd. But you also cannot compel anyone to defend or focus fire, so a soldier will run to the canteen to grab some food as the aliens are barging through the gate).
cool game, love it but a bit pricey for a 20h gameplay

It's no Warcraft 3 but it's still fun. It being open world through me off at first but I quickly grew to like it. The world is dynamic with constant piglin expansions and invasions that you can choose to deal with or ignore. There isn't a huge amount of units but they all serve a unique role with none feeling useless. Both the defence and attack gameplay is fun. I remember when I was younger I would build walls and redstone turrets around a village then spawn a load of mobs to create a siege, you can do that for real now. The mission structure is the same for the whole game, destroy 3 bases then fight the boss for each faction. Each faction has completely different base architecture with different weaknesses though so it doesn't feel like you're doing the same thing. My major complaint is the lack of factions which is pretty unheard of for an rts game. Another complaint is the player character does literally 0 damage to high tier enemies, bosses and buildings so all you can do is take out the weaklings while your units do everything important, it especially sucks for boss fights. 3/4 boss fights were boring because you can't do anything yourself. I liked one of the bosses because you have to defend a village from it or you lose. The final boss was just more of the same, spawn a load of units next to it and run around, Not being able to hurt bosses with your sword was a really dumb design choice. People have different attention spans so I can't tell when you will get bored but for me the campaign slightly overstayed its welcome. In the last hour I just wanted it to end.

6/10 wait for a sale

Classic survival game with great exploration, a unique mapping system, polished ocean navigating, and detailed yet rewarding food, water, fatigue, and disease/ailment systems. The game world is beautiful and each new biome/area provides a new survival experience. The crafting system is very well established with several tiers of weapons and equipment, specialized crafting stations, complex cooking, as well as fully fledged base building complete with wall trophies, lamps, and rugs. The gameplay does feel a bit grindy until your base is established. Fast travel with your boat to player-built docks makes returning to your base a breeze. For a survival crafting game that has only just entered Early Access, this game feels surprisingly whole.

Very good game. Improves on the first in many ways, but still has the feel of a teslagrad game. Absolutely beautiful art, music, bosses, everything. 100% recommend for fans of the first game. Also, try to find the secret techniques, they make an already fun game even better.

Quite simply, Teslagrad 2 takes all of the elements that made Teslagrad 1 great, and cranks them into overdrive.

The Story: Preserving the same methods of silent storytelling as the original, T2 links T1 and World to the West together to make a seamless cohesive storyline. Seemingly innocuous background art from T1 is given massive significance in T2, and new story elements introduced in T2 are deliberately left a bit vague so they can be expanded in future games. Characters have complex motives which gives them a lot of depth.

The Music: J√∏rn Lavoll outdoes himself. Fire up the game and listen to the title screen music. Just listen, let it develop. It didn't have to be that good since most people will just spam a button to get to the menus, but what an intro. Many more musical styles are explored here, ranging from heavy metal to jungle to whimsical, with plenty of callbacks to music from T1.

The Gameplay: Movement is much more fluid and rewarding. Blinking, a core ability from T1, is given to you from the very start of T2. Sliding was an ability cut from T1 but brought back in T2, and the levels embrace it in plenty of places, with slopes everywhere to launch from. Simple platforming and very mild puzzles lead up to the first boss, but then the puzzle platforming begins to show its true robustness, with new puzzle elements supported by the new item collectibles. Lots more variety in terrain, and some very-appreciated "fast-travel checkpoint" options to get around the much larger map. The boss fights start easy and ramp up to very hard if you're going for all achievements.

This game is a masterpiece. If you liked Teslagrad 1 in any capacity, this is a must-play.

An amazing translation into VR. The weapons feel great to use, movement is smooth. The UI is done well, melee combat feels good, the green sword is done amazingly; very early in, but I can see myself loving this more than the original.

Only slight comment I'd say is it can feel like whenever you land a melee hit, *you* get hit too; the combination of a hitsound and the screen flashing (with the ammo you just got) makes it seem that even if you struck first and killed them, you're getting hit anyway. Takes a few minutes to realise it's not the case, and you get used to it.

Up front I'll give it a score of 7/10.  Probably should bump it down to a 6/10 for the bait'n'switch they pull in a sidequest, but I'll get to that in the spoiler section.  Combat's fun for the most part, but there is one fatal flaw that absolutely killed it for me.

For starters: a lot of people thought this was going to be a roguelite/rogue-like. It is neither, it's a straight-up linear progression story. In terms of gameplay it's like a cross between the old God of War games and an arcade beat'em up (Streets of Rage, Ninja Turtles, Final Fight, etc). In between levels you wander around camp, talk to people, put points into your upgrades, then start up the next level.

Combat was fun with a fair amount of options in terms of abilities. As those familiar with Sylas from LoL would expect, a key mechanic is stealing spells off of your enemies. Once you've stolen a spell you can unlock it as an equipable spell. While stolen spells are used for free, when you're holding a stolen spell you don't have access to your equipped spells so you have to use the stolen one first. Equipped spells use mana. Your mana bar has up to 4 pips, and each spell costs a different number of pips. Mana is rebuilt by doing regular and strong attacks, strong attacks restoring more.

So you can find your favorite spells and equip them, but you're by no means a spell-spammer. Most of the best spells in the game cost 3 pips, and regaining pips takes a fair amount of physical attacking. With regards to melee combat: as you progress through the game you'll unlock members of a band of "outlaws." These are basically equipable people that increase your damage of a certain type and give you a combo with that type as well. Like the ice guy lets you do a light > light > light > strong combo where the strong leaves a frost AoE puddle that's a DoT.

Also of note is you can use his chains to yank yourself to enemies from a pretty fair distance. Part of my bread'n'butter combo involved this with a wind kick.

So there's plenty to work with in terms of making a build to fit your playstyle. Early-ish in the game you get a spell that gives you a small amount of shield hp for 3 mana pips, and that was pretty much what I spent most of my mana on. Speaking of sustain: you also get a potion with 3 charges that can be upgraded for a 4th, and towards the end of the game you unlock Guardian Angel which gives you one revive per level. I never had it proc so I don't know how much it revives you for, it doesn't say.

As for the one thing that absolutely killed it for me: movement.  It can feel absolutely terrible at times, particularly due to the fact that you can't dash through obstacles.  Not only does this mean it's particularly easy for the enemy to corner you, but it also means that you'll get periodically stuck on random crap like an indestructible stool sitting on the floor.  For a game that's based on rapid-pace action, taking a few hits because Sylas caught his foot on a chair gets pretty frustrating.

~~~Now for some spoilers, stop reading if you don't want to know what champs show up~~~

Champs that appear in the game include...
[spoiler]-Sylas (Obviously)
-Lux
-Garen
-J4
-Shyvana
-Morgana (she fights you as a test of strength before giving you her blessing)
-Kayle kinda-sort but not really
-Nocturne***
***It's just a 3 second cameo.  You're on a sidequest to hunt down something dangerous in the forest that seems to be playing on your fears.  Turns out it's Nocturne who "fights" you, but it's just a repeat of the Morgana fight.  After you win she turns into Nocturne who you see just long enough for him to laugh at you and disappear.  As I mentioned, this bait'n'switch was almost enough to knock the game down to a 6/10 for me because I thought a Nocturne fight would have been awesome.  But no, just reuse an old fight, have Nocturne flip us the bird, then he buggers off.  But I still say the game feels better than a 6/10 so I gave it a 7.[/spoiler]

An absolutely chaotic game that somehow manages to combine the platforming elements of Spelunky with a touch of base management right out of Metal Gear Solid 5 / Peace walker.

How does this actually play then? You go through procedually generated levels with an objective. This could be neutralizing a specific enemy, capturing one, grabbing certain types of loot or getting through the level in a set amount of time etc. You have a fulton balloon system to both grab loot and stunned enemies. Those enemies can then be converted to join your side.

Each unit has their own set of positive and negative quirks and those can change on levelup or later be modified manually. If one of your units dies, they are gone for good. If you are captured however, you can later get missions to rescue those units.

Overall a very fun, chaotic game that I finished just around the 10 hour mark.

Allow me to cut to the chase;  Are you a fan of Dead Cells and Hades? Then you'll find this game both familiar and different. Like a certain fit of a new pair of jeans that are delightfully different because they came from a new company.

Aesthetically, there's more than enough difference that on a visual level it feels wholly different from the aforementioned games. In fact, a ton of detail, care and love has gone into the various special effects, character design and art to give it futuristic neon-rave feel and somehow, without agitating the holly hell out of my astigmatism. (Well done, devs.)

The game-play feels more like Dead Cells, or more recently Have A Nice Death (with a touch of rhythm and timing) - very fast paced, flashy side-scrolling with all the replayability you'd expect from games of this genre. The hub has a plethora of upgrades to pursue, making your path and choices throughout your runs rather difficult, when it feels like you need a bit of everything to make progress.

My gripes about this game at the moment, are minimal. 
-The host of resources you need seems a bit overwhelming in the beginning. I caught myself asking, "wtf do I need this for, again?" more often than I'd like. 
-The musical-battle aspect is very minimal and feels a bit tacked on, as it only affects one skill and it's not easy hit just basing your timing on the music. The audio cue isn't prominent enough and by the time I try to register the timing, the moment has passed and I end up with the weaker variation of the skill every time. I had to use my peripheral vision to have any success with it.
-Finally, the voice acting. Not so much the accents - I applaud anyone from any Asian descent that grew up with their native language, to even attempt to adapt to English. A specific nitpick of mine, the audio doesn't match with the subtitles. Not a huge issue, but it does break immersion.

Although I usually stray from early-access games at a price, I don't regret this one bit. I'm excited to see the future improvements and characters. More than anything, I hope to see more characters, maybe new weapons for each character and whatever else the devs see fit to add. If it's this good already, the finished product with be a hit!!!

I really loved playing this game, felt a bit like a more fleshed-out Long Live the Queen, but with a unique flavor. There is some clumsiness in the English translation, but it gets much better later on in the game - the "memory" sequences at the start are the roughest parts.
The voice acting is very cute, and the art is amazing! So many (diverse) romance options, not gender locked at all! Though, for some people it might be a con that you can only play as a father to a little girl, and can't change the gender. (Though it is titled Volcano Princess not Prince but I digress)
Overall, I think you have a lot to do in the game, and I will personally spend lots of hours trying to unlock as many career endings and romance endings as I can.

If Lemmings and Abe's Odyssey humped and had a baby, and Subterrania and Rescue on Fractalus humped and had a baby, those two babies humped and had a baby, Moons of Darsalon would be that baby's baby. This game has everything! Frantic platforming action, state-of-the-art voice synthesis, an amazing SID chip-infused soundtrack, excellent vehicle physics, a full-color palette, 3d pre-rendered ships and scenery, and an overall retro charm that reminds you of a time when the best games were those that had a single developer with a singular vision. One of the best 2D games I've played in years. Well done!

Hello, someone who 100% completed the first game here! I am a huge fan of Coffee Talk, so you bet I got excited to play the sequel the moment it released. I can honestly say this game is a great sequel overall, and expands on the first game when it needs to. Some things are a little different, such as new drink combos, characters, etc. but overall it keeps the formula of the first game and what made it enjoyable, which I say as a massive compliment!

The only other thing I will add is that it's best to come into this game expecting a continuation of the first game (which is to be expected when it says "Episode 2" lol). Because the game is very much the same format, it does feel like we play right where we left off, so you NEED to play the first game in order to understand what's going on in this one. I still have yet to get all of achievements so I do not know all of this games secrets yet, but I can't wait till I do.
