I really love what I've played of this game so far, and I think that any Princess Maker game fans will, but unfortunately I just can't recommend it whilst it has so many bugs. 
I can't escape the letters screen so have to play without them, and then when horses were unlocked the game immediately crashed on trying to capture one. 
I'd love to change my review once the game is fixed and I can actually play it to completion.

TLDR;
Great Princess Maker-esque (or Long Live the Queen) game despite some bugs and iffy english texts. 8/10

The good: There is a lot of things you can do, and choices to make that will give varying results without being too punishing. Aside from story related choices most mistakes can be fixed as long as you're not going for a perfect run.
A lot of short mini-games to keep it interesting without it being a chore, since obviously you'll be doing them more than once if you're aiming for a specific stat.
Although I've only reached one ending as of this review, the story and ending was nothing too far from what I would've expected from the choices I made.
The visuals are good, cute, and fitting.

The bad: At the time of the review, mainly the bugs and iffy english translations.
I ran into a few bugs but nothing terribly unavoidable or detrimental to the progression, but there were times where I needed to restart the game. At least the auto save is there in case you forget to manually save.
The text is mostly broken or have grammatical/spelling errors, but most are comprehensible to a point. This may bother some and break the immersion. Nothing was broken to the point of making a wrong choice during my first playthrough.

Some minor QoL functions are missing, such as text skipping but honestly since most texts are short it's not the end of the world.
Both manual and auto saves start at the beginning of the day, so there is no way to save right before choices. But again, the texts aren't long so it's not that difficult to go back to the same spot from the start of the day.

I bought the game expecting to see strategy and shooter in one game, but I got something strange. As a shooter, the game shows itself at a good level, the management of soldiers and equipment in one battle is an interesting idea, although not the newest, but the management of equipment by bots is not fully worked out. The graphics are good, but the system requirements are also high. As a strategy, the game leaves much to be desired, construction and politics are primitive, logistics is often extremely inconvenient. I leave a positive review due to the fact that this is early access, and the developers still have the potential to fix the shortcomings of the game.

There comes a time in every man's life when he needs to take a look at himself in the mirror and wonder how exactly he reached such a place.
You have to truly ponder what decisions you have made along the way that brought you to the place of your final reckoning.

It is still unclear, even to me, why I purchased The Monstrous Horror Show. 
There isn't anything wrong with it, with those nudity scenes throughout it's perfectly stellar. But when you look at it as a choice, you realize just how flawed you and the rest of humanity is.

What drove me to purchase such a game? What part of my soul felt so empty that I thought a virtual girl could fill it?
When I look into the boundless depths of my own loneliness I see a pool of reflection. My face isn't there, there is no face. There are only tears in that pool, tears of shame and loss and confusion.

If it were up to me again I know I would purchase it in a heartbeat, I know I would load it up and skip through the countless window prompts so I can have a single morsel of pornographic images which are readily available online.
Yet, despite the abundance of naked virtual women waiting in the digital sphere, I still chose to purchase this game and devote hours of my life to it. That time will never return to me, it is lost just like my soul and just like the time I fear I may never find it again.

There is something broken within me, something that desires sensation beyond my reach, something that whimpers every single night with the knowledge that there is no true Princess, it is a merely an illusion.
In my pursuit to find meaning in this long life, I sought the colorful lights and sounds of a world that only exists in a pop up window on my computer.

I am unsure what the moral of this review is, I am unsure about my place within the universe, all I know is that no amount of virtual girls can cure the vast rot that has overtaken me.

Mageseeker is a masterpiece. The story is spectacular and each detail immerses you in the league of legends universe. The fighting felt action packed, quick and not too free. I played through the entire game on the hardest difficulty and did not get to the end of the game without a bit of a struggle. This game does a great job with slowly rolling you out new tools to take on different types of enemies by making different elements have a counter element. Hopefully everything in here is canon and they start dropping characters in league from these Riot forge games. I'd like to see Rukko, Yops and Wisteria ported over in some way. 

I do have some grips with the game, specifically the feeling that they ran out of ideas to make it to the end of the game, but didnt want you to go from cut scene to cut scene. So they made filler by just throwing more enemies at you. about the last 20%-30% of the game, I had unlocked everything and started skipping side quests. Another thing that bothers me is the lack of end game anything. When you are done, yeah you can play through and tune the difficulty but besides that you are maxed out and your moving... game just ended. 

Still worth every penny. If you are a league fan and want to enjoy some of the story like you did with Arcane, grab this one.

It has "Metroidvania" tag, but I haven't seen any ability gating so far (most "gates" are bosses or keys like in dark souls). The map is also a collection of locations between which you teleport, and so far they seemed pretty linear, though you would expect a non-linear interconnected map in most metroidvanias. The fact that the map is absent is also quite annoying and, while common in souls-like games, is pretty frustrating for a game that claims to be metroidvania, and makes tracking your exploration progress much harder than it should be.

Great graphics and sound, just like its predecessor. Once again, bonus points for ultrawide support. No complaints about the presentation, but some of the characters definitely rub me the wrong way. YMMV in that department. 

I had read that the original writer passed away. I see this left the team with a difficult choice. To their credit, I could not tell the difference between the two. It emulates the same style and tone, and I imagine this is intentional to honor the spirit of the original author's intent. Unfortunately, I think the writing was the worst part of the original by far, and I see this as a missed opportunity to move on from that. 

All of the supernatural elements in this story are but the thinnest of veils for what is ultimately a collection of modern day social media discourse. There is rampant virtue signaling, and every character speaks about the world around them as if they live inside Twitter. There are a scant few genuine moments, and I can appreciate the fact that the writer(s?) clearly feel a lot of angst about putting themselves out there and the creative process in general. There is a complete lack of subtlety in the writing regarding this, but I see it and I get it. 

It feels a lot more disappointing than the first one, as we're familiar with much of the cast already, and there's not a lot of progress or poignancy in their respective narratives. I genuinely came away from this game feeling like I spent a few hours reading Twitter threads. It's nothing but surface level social commentary.

Given that the intent here was probably to honor the original writer, I'd still be in for a Coffee Talk 3 in the hopes that they show some growth and try something different. If that one also ends up being the same, I'd definitely call it quits. 

FWIW, this is certainly a worthy tribute for those who do not find fault with the original.

I can't really put into words how much Toge Productions and its games has continously exceed my expectations. And this sequel is totally a deserving and heartwarming sequel to the first game. The characters had all grown and we get to dive deeper on their new emerging problems as they enter a new stage of their life. Meeting them again in this game feels like meeting an old friend whom you haven't talked in so long, and yet you still share the old memories of those years gone by (gosh, I sound like Hyde, don't I...). But yeah it's nice to continue their story while meeting new curious characters as well.

I personally love that in this game and the previous game, Toge doesn't shy away from discussing heavy but important topics, especially for us youngsters looking to find our way to navigate the world. Some of the conversations between the characters do got me thinking and definitely there is a lesson learned there somewhere. But that aside, it's what you would expect the sequel of a chill and heartwarming story would be. And not gonna lie, I almost always have a smile in my face while playing this game, and even if I'm not smiling, there is always something I feel inside, which shows how good the storytelling on this game is as you easily get emotionally and physically (sometimes mentally) invested in the game. It's as if you are following the journey of the characters as if you are really part of the story, which is the appeal of this game from the first sequel as well. So I can't thank you everyone at Toge (including the late Mr. Fahmi) for bringing us such an amazing story and game to experience. Although I can't speak for everyone, so I would recommend everyone to try and see for themselves and hopefully it would leave a lasting mark on everyone too, as it already leave quite a remarkable memories for me personally. So cheers!! And I can't wait to see what story Toge will bring to us next!

A great sequel to the first game! It introduces new interesting characters that you can't help but fall in love with and beautifully intertwines their stories with those of already known characters. The gameplay got improved with two new ingredients and collecting lost items which you can give back to the customers. Overall the second episode of Coffee Talk improved on the already great first game and makes room for more in the future!
game was made by an incel.

The game is aesthetically pleasing, the music choice is excellent, the sound design as a whole is fantastic, overall the game is just insanely satisfying to play. If you think it looks cool, I can assure you it is. I need to play more but I can already tell the game gets better the more you play it. Your skills sharpen, your arsenal expands, the Hotline Miami fan in me is very very happy.

The dialogue is entertaining, but it's quite annoying to play without a guide. There is a definite "correct" or "best" path due to how game-y everything is. Lack of rollback or autosaving can also make things pretty annoying. Hope your "save at every choice" game is strong, or god forbid you fat finger or misclick something. On that note, prepare for soooooo much backtracking, even if you didn't make a choice on accident. Seriously, how do you include random nonsense "comedic" game overs multiple hours in without a rollback function?

Also, the "they" thing is super weird. I assume they did it to not have to record audio (or write dialogue) twice. Still, it's hard to be immersed in a story where you are essentially playing an amorphous blob with no discernible concrete personality traits or identity. It makes for bizarre moments in conversation (and particularly more intimate parts), where the characters (and game) can't actually describe your character because they're completely nondescript. I assume by the themes and more dramatic tone of some parts, they were indeed trying to make you take the story more seriously this time around. If that's the case, I feel it would have been more wise to have picked a gender, picked some at least basic personality traits, and committed to them so it felt like the characters were relating to a person as opposed to an amorphous creature that was just trying to pick the right options to get their pants off. I think it would have really helped the writing.

This isn't a bad game; it has several great parts. But this is not a rating, it's a recommendation, so no I wouldn't recommend it, unless you're really nostalgic for the old stat based dating flash games of yester year and this is exactly what you're looking for.

i dont usually write reviews but i feel compelled on this because of the vast mixed reviews/very negative reviews i feel are overblown. This game for sure has some flaws that could have and probably should have been ironed out but they are not game breaking. Most peoples problems with the damage and combat are no where near as bad as said once you start upgrading your armor and your hp/stamina pool. i am playing on the 3rd difficulty (there is 4) and im at a point i feel like i could be on the 4th if i want more of a challenge but could still progress. the actual issues with the game are your weapon "special attacks" feel like they were an oversight. like whoever created them was like "oh lets add a decent strong attack with a cooldown for brownie points" but never actually field tested them. they are like a 2/10 on usefullness. they are god awful slow animations that can just be and WILL BE interupted by an enemy attack and do not do enough poise damage or hp damage to be like "man i NEED to get this move off". yes of course i still always try to use them lol but they are implemented horribly. they parry/dodge system is actually pretty good and cool except if there are multiple enemies attacking. again i think this was an oversight without field testing. you can only parry one attack and HAVE to wait till the parry animation is done to do another meaning if a second enemy is attacking you ARE getting hit no way around it which takes away from skill expression. the fact enemies can constantly interupt/daze you compared to you BARELY ever is just a forced way to add difficulty but take away skill expression/immersion when even the littlest creatures/humans use a light attack and do it yet you used a massive hammer heavy swing and they just swing right through it like yyeeeaahhhh OK not going to happen. its comically bad and frustrating as it breaks your combat groove but again its not gamebreaking and can be worked around. everything else is great. the scenery changes between darker battlegrounds to lush colorful nature. voice acting is fine as long as you dont mind british sounding accents. besides the weird battle flaws i described battles are actually satisfying learning movesets and the finishers are nice looking and quick (most of them). the parry/dodge thing everyone complaining about the game telling you not to look at the color but the movements is i think just a description mistake and the part of the devs. the best way to explain it is you dont HAVE to just react to blue=parry and red=dodge. like you can still dodge backwards on a blue overhead swing. no you cant parry a red attack but you CAN block every attack with a shield wepon. the story isnt too deep from what ive gathered so far but it is unique and interesting so it makes you want to actually uncover the whole thing. if you like adventure/exploration games with action combat this is a very nice and fun game for sure worth picking up.

Yes, its very good, its fun to play with good movement, you don't have to be good at it but you can still manage, speed-running the game was very fun and smooth, the one down side is that once a guy dies you can't get them back, but with the lab you could replace them and make them even better, amazing sound track too, library theme my favorite

Review:
So all in all i've played this game for a couple hours with my gaming group and we plan to play more.

The game is basically a Hide and Seek, Scavenger Hunt, that can feel a bit long winded at first, but once you start collecting and turning in the blood to create the blood orbs, not only does the game get darker (lower brightness) but the monsters become increasingly active. With this mechanic its kind of interesting to see the game change, however I feel this leaves a flaw in gameplay as you could simply ignore blood for a time and gather the pages, then start turning in the blood and making a break for the end portal, thereby making the game easier. My recommendation here would be to create a soft time limit that every "X" minutes or so, the stage treats it as though a blood orb as been gathered (i.e. get darker, more active monsters) without of course awarding the blood orb, to make the game increasingly more difficult as time progresses, similar to how hunts in Phasmophobia work. I would also add a lose condition based on time (a generous amount of time) where the ancient one would awaken. Side note for fun we tried to enter the portal once without a complete book, just for fun to see what would happen and sadly you can't, though we did end up swarmed by numerous enemies. 

I also feel like there is definite room for growth in the tool department, as running with just a lanter, book and blood vials really leaves the gameplay a little waning. Add some more unique lore based one shot items that can help in situations and also add some depth to the gameplay.

The art design is honestly on point. I'm a huge sucker for the Lovecraftian horror genre and feel like the atmosphere is quite accurate. I will say though I would like to see more interesting levels aside from just scavenger hunting through a forest. Perhaps a giant mansion style map with new horrors etc.

There are some visual bugs to be sure. Like walking (floating) on some of the rocks near the perimeter of the map. A couple of rocks that when trying to walk on you would clip through, and one situation where one of our group became stuck on a log, unable to move.

Another thing I would recommend removing is the cutscene when a blood orb is generated, as the game is not paused and the individual that places the last blood into the altar is basically helpless once the cutscene begins. Honestly, its not really needed in my opinion and only adds a small level of frustration when trying to complete the last blood orb, monsters nearby and you're trying to make a clean getaway only to be caught mid cutscene.

Other than that, for $8 USD I feel like I could get my money's worth of entertainment from the game, and its a chance to support an indie dev. This view is of course subjective so I dont fully expect anyone to necessarily agree with me, but all in all its a nice little lovecraftian horror game that is simple to just jump into and enjoy a round or two.

Been looking out for this game since the first ever reveal and DAMN, i loved it. But for the note: This game is in its EARLIEST state right now. With bugs that where you can clip out from the map and get stuck under the rocks or can't even navigate yourself and easily can get lost or go in circles, game itself really has the atmosphere of Lovecraftian place and really gives the vibes of it with its mysterious island. Monsters and their mechanics (how to avoid them, how they find you and etc) are great. Objective of the game is pretty straightforward though. Which for someone who grasped what to do in order to find / collect necessary stuff for plot to move, it can be pretty short. But of course, exploration for the first time was really magical and pulled me in easily.

If this game is gonna receive new maps (perhaps a city map, or something different from just an island like an desert or inside an pyramid) then there should be more different kind of objectives and more focused on story telling and letting the player find out what to do other than just explaining what is the goal of you and your cultist friends right at the start of the game.

A few talkative npc's around the area that's hidden leading to an side-mission or objective where you can unlock more secrets perhaps? Who knows.

With that said, I am looking forward for more content from this game and its developers. I absolutely love the idea of this game and can't play again when its a lot more polished and more filled with cosmic secrets that will drive you to insanity.

Digital Sun did a fantastic job with this game.  I've never played a genre like this before and had a blast.  I'm a big League of Legends fan, and thought the lore and story lines involved were amazing. Would recommend to anyone interested in the League universe or even just a new game to pick up.  8.5/10

The Mageseeker is another great game from Riot Forge that proves one of the biggest strengths of the world of League of Legends; the lore and characters.

A lot of the first reviews I saw for The Mageseeker highlighted that it was a short game, but for the price tag I was very happy with the length of the game - in fact it took longer for me to complete than I thought it would. Though it's worth pointing out there is very little replay value here.

The difficulty is another plus, I played on the highest preset difficulty (you can fine-tune aspects of the difficulty if you wish which is a nice feature) and I found many of the boss battles to be a welcome challenge. They also were always a great spectacle, particularly the fights against [spoiler] Jarvan/Shyvana, Wisteria and Morgana [/spoiler], and were coupled with great music which plays on riffs familiar to people who follow the lore of League.

The combat is really unique and represents Sylas fantastically, though I think it can sometimes be a bit awkward to target the correct enemy in fights and it doesn't completely click in the earlier stages of the game. However, as you advance through the game and acquire better abilities it really comes into its own. The battles in the last few missions are fantastic and you are really tested on your ability to juggle spells.

The Mageseeker features a good number of cameos from League and Legends of Runeterra characters, many of which you would expect based on the premise. It's great to get to know them more and allow their story to develop. In addition it also introduces lots of interesting new characters as both allies and enemies. As for the big picture, the struggle between the rebel mages, the mageseekers and Demacia as a whole makes for a compelling story, especially when you sprinkle in meddling from Noxus and the Black Rose.

Overall, The Mageseeker delivered everything I was looking for when it came to exploring the story of Sylas and Demacia and also has challenging gameplay that rewards your experience in it. so it's a strong recommendation from me.

First things first.
If you enjoying this game, good for you, I'm happy for you, this is just my experience what I'm writing down.

This game made me really mad right at the beginning.
On 1440p, epic settings, this game ran 35-45 FPS. Even FSR on, the max was 55.
Why?! 
I have no clue. I got a RTX2070 and I played Cyberpunk 2077 on all high, dlss on, 1440p with 75-95 FPS, or WD: Legion very high and some ultra settings, dlss on, 1440p with 65-100 FPS. 
There isn't any reason why this game ran so shitty on my rig.

But I was very generous, so I went back to 1080p with FSR on and the game ran with 85 FPS.
I wasn't really happy about this, but ok.

Let me tell you one thing: 
I've finished Elden Ring, Remnant from the Ashes, Code Vein, so I'm not totally unexperienced with these kind of "souls like" games.

But the combat in this game...maaan...
Dodging is somewhat ok, but parry. It's broken AF.
The game warns you to not react to the flashing indicator (that seems pretty stupid to me, but ok), but man... I died 3 times because I coudn't parry at all. Even when I tried to react on the last second of the animation, nothing happened. I just took the hit. So after 3x of dying + the problem with the graphics I asked for a refund. 

So, this is my wonderful experience with this game. :D
Fun game can't wait for more content.

[h1] Review is split into two parts: first being people who want to know what's new/the difference from the first game, the second being more the actual Review [/h1]

[b] If you have NOT played the first game, then it is highly recommended you do so because of all the references and returning characters, along with a spoiler regarding the first game's ending[/b]

[b] New things/differences from the first game(skip this part if not interested) [/b]

[list]
    [*] Nothing carries over from the first game, and you have to unlock the recipes again. they do reference the first game a bit.
    [*] 2 new drink bases: Blue Pea and Hibiscus. a few more new recipes. for those who are planning on going into Endless mode and unlock them, there are I believe 3 that are locked behind the story, as in even if you have the right mixture it will not give you the drink until you have to make them. most if not all the old recipes are the same, but you will have to unlock them again.
    [*]Characters: there are three New main characters, Riona the banshee, Lucas the Satyr, and [spoiler] Amanada the Alien, "sister" to Neil. [/spoiler] there are a few other minor characters, but aside from a scene or two, aren't as big.
    [*]Returning characters: Everyone makes a reappearance to some degree. Jorgi has been expanded upon and is more than being "just there." Myrtle and Aqua could be considered minor characters given how they have their own storyline but it's a lot smaller comparatively. Freya only makes a single appearance near the end.
    [*] a pretty underutilized item giving mechanic, where when you give the drink you can offer an item to the patron. you can't give the wrong thing to the wrong person, but you if you forget to give someone something it can affect your hidden score and therefore endings. there isn't a whole lot of items, but some of the things may or may not be self explanatory on who you're supposed to give it to(e.g. you might have to give something to someone, but you give it to someone else related to them).
    [*]small changes that I don't feel like they need their own bullet point but should be mentioned: in Endless mode, you can now pick who to serve based on who you met now instead of just Freya. Achievements are somewhat spoiler-ly in that they outright tell you what to do to unlock them, such as serving specific drinks to unlock new songs. not sure if the previous game had these kinds of achievements, but there are a few which involve doing things like doing bad enough to make someone not come back to even getting the worst endings possible(good luck with that).
[/list]

[b] The Actual Review [/b]

The first game has a lot of charm to it. I recently played it again just to see what it was like in anticipation for the sequel.
If you are asking if this game delivers, I would say yes and no. the game is a lot like the first one, built upon it, like a 1.5, which is probably why it is titled Episode 2 instead of a straight up sequel. The story takes place about 3 years after the first one, and you end up catching up with everyone and seeing how things have changed. If you like the first game for the atmosphere and characters, then this game will definitely be something you'll enjoy. If you're looking for expansion on the game-play however, you'll probably be disappointed, as the game does very little to change it up. given it's a "don't fix what's not broke" approach, it makes sense, but still a fair warning. the good of the game is a lot of what the first game had, but it also is the downside of it as you're getting more of the same, just slightly expanded upon.

Story wise, it felt either too fast, or too slow at times. some moments will go by quickly, and you'll be wondering what happened, while other times it feels like they're dragging on a bit, exploring the world but given how you don't have as much direct input, it doesn't feel quite as impactful(stop forgetting your lighter Jorgi). Freya isn't around this time, so when the days are over, you'll be talking to yourself, and most of the time won't really have a moment to reflect on everything that happened. Still, you do get your happy endings, but some of the story weren't explored as much, such as with Aqua and Myrtle, so it isn't as impactful.

gameplay wise, it's the same, just with 2 new ingredients and an item giving mechanic that really is underutilized in my opinion. it does affect what endings you get, but honestly the items you get are a small selection and it's fairly easy to figure out the right item to give, and moreso of knowing who to give it to(hint: you sometimes give an item not to the person directly, but someone related to them). aside from the small changes, they aren't really as big to where the gameplay evolved, but given the kind of game it is, it's not as big of an issue. as for the length, it took me roughly less than 7 hours to beat(beaten within 2 days) not counting the reloading I had to do, so it is a short game if you know what to do or look up a guide.

I'm a fan of the this series, so I am slightly biased when i say I give this game a 8/10, given how long I've been wanting to play this. However, if your'e someone new, and only recently played the first one, this will probably be more of a 6 or 7/10.

There are also NG+ carry over stats that you can do to help make things easier in the next runs. Not to mention, a very flexible save points so you can get a lot of those juicy achievements in 1 go.

Definitely recommended!

I am loving the game so far, voice acting is great and music is comfy! I feel like the character you play could use a little makeover as they look a bit odd for me at least as I was trying to keep them androgynous. The stacks of items I wish could hold more than 5 as well, and money more than 100 :c Also it currently feels a bit difficult trying to wade through so many monsters that you basically are out of mask time by the time you get anywhere useful :c Hopefully these are things that can be considered for a post launch update! Still thoroughly enjoying my time with it though!

The game can be fun, So far has been generally bug free! There is no tutorial, but after a few tries I am getting better. However the Ai is absolutely atrocious as far as both their unit numbers and the ability to seemingly invade me without warning is ridiculous. I did the same thing, half the planet declared war but the ai? Not a single repercussion as my allies are  worthless strategically. This game needs to allow the player to construct more than a single building at a time as well as research which is extremely needed. It's almost impossible to set up a functioning economy without it. Until these things are implemented I can't recommend this.

This game is fun and very cute to look at, but several things about it are clunky and frustrating.

The tech tree is kind of bizarre, without much sense of logic to it. For instance, you research submarines before you can make boats. There also doesn't seem to be any way to put a chick in a hen coop. An arbitrary line pops into existence when you have gone out too far in a given type of boat and it just feels kind of jarring. Space is weirdly limited, and undersea is very plain. You can make steel well before you can make bronze and scuba stations before you can make hay.

The main pain point though is the inability to assign settlers to some of the buildings, such as grills and charcoal burners, and their disinterest in picking up resources from nets or storing them after production. Hopefully these will be addressed soon.

I would say it's worth buying if only because it seems to have a lot of potential and is fun even given some frustrations.

The most fun I had since MW 2019, this game has to survive. love the fast pace in the game I'm always finding enemies everywhere I go. the only problem I have is the spawn points I sometimes spawn behind a enemy that just started to move away from their spawn point with their 2 sec invincibility only to get killed from behind by me
The movement and gun control is so lenient I caught myself trying to wall run thinking it was Titanfall 2.

As of right now, I wouldn't recommend this game, but I will probably update it after new changes come in.

Some things to note:
- There isn't a breakdown of why stability is low. I would prefer if there is a menu where it says something like: "this city has low stability because such and such."
- Political power does nothing at the moment
- You don't get a breakdown of how much resources are being produced. If I build a bakery or a farm, I want to know how much wheat is being produced per day or week.
- Diplomacy is too simple at the moment. There is no option to join an a war an ally is in. You also can't call in an ally to your war.
- This is a personal preference, but there isn't a good way to optimize production of resources. You can select the option to send resources weekly to a city, but you'd have to do it for every single city. Maybe an option where it just sorts resources by itself would be better.

In conclusion, this game can definitely become one of my favorites, but it isn't there yet. Maybe when it gets out of early access. I just hope it doesn't get abandoned like Freeman.

The chuckles from the story dialogue alone are worth the purchase price, but the game-play is an extremely enjoyable take on the dungeon crawl experience. I meant to try it out for about an hour and before I knew it I had been playing for four.  I can tell I am going to get a lot of enjoyment out of this game.  5/5 finger crossbows.

Couldn't be bothered to play more of the campaign and queue times for pvp is usually 20 mins or more. Cosmetics are trash as well.  Wait for a heavy sale if you seriously want to play this.  Mojang, please just work on your actual game so that we can get more than 5 new blocks and a mob per year.

A great successor to a game that I enjoyed playing a while ago. The new movement abilities were fun to play with and works fairly well with other mechanics, mainly the magnetic stuff. The map seems to be larger too, adding more things to do overall in gameplay.

The puzzle part of the platforming is still decent but seems to be less of a focus then the original or is at least easier in that aspect. The focus seems to be more on the platforming side of puzzle platformers, since the new upgrades and changes focus on it more. Only other complaint of something specific would be that the boss before you get your last upgrade was too simple and could easily be beaten in less than 10 seconds, making it pointless to even have gameplay wise. 

overall I would say the game is worth the $20 it's asking for and you should definitely check out the original if you haven't already.

This game is great but there a lot of QOL issues that break immersion, here are my issues.....

#1 Identity

This game is advertised as a rouge-like but it also has the most half-4ssed rhythm aspect that I have ever seen. Basically every 4 beats if you hit on-beat your 2nd attack does a little more damage... and that's the entire rhythm aspect of the game and because of this the game has awful repetitive music to keep you on beat. As a result of this there is also an beat indicator that is very hard to see and makes it hard to play and look at the same time and because every beat sounds the same you have to look at it, it really ruins the experience.

-I feel like they should completely remove this feature add better music and just add a cool-down instead

#2 English dub 

its clearly an AI which is not bad but its done horribly, Its almost like they fed a Language model every anime girl dub to ever exist and then tossed a Chinese and a Australian person in there for good measure and it ruined everything. (it sounds like a Chinese person speaking Engrish-Australian sometimes)

#3 Grammar

I have no clue what I am reading sometimes

#4 video settings

-No anti-aliasing

-If you set the game to windowed mode you cant move the window around and its stuck in 
the center of your monitor 
(whats the point then????) 

-Display mode does not work properly, border-less and windowed get each other mixed up 
sometimes.

-No proper window scaling it is a fixed 16:9 

-Graphics quality appears to do absolutely nothing





Conclusion: I will come back when it is more polished :)

Overall, I really enjoy this game. If you liked My Life as a Teenage Exocolonist or Long Live the Queen you'll probably have a good time with this. It has a lot of content, I'd say I like it more that Long Live the Queen. Not nearly as much as My Life as a Teenage Exocolonist for a few reasons. There are several problems that you may or may not be able to overlook.

Most noticeably, the translations are CRUNCHY. It's not really a problem for most of the game, you can pretty easily get the gist of what was meant. Once you get in to later story stuff for the true ending it gets pretty difficult to understand, to the point that I'm wondering if there are some sequence breaks I found accidentally.

There are also two pretty severe and consistent game breaking bugs. First and foremost are the gift letters you receive. These will lock the game up every single time you try to open one. Fortunately they aren't really a necessary part of the game, they're mostly for flavor. Second is a save data corruption bug that can happen if you have cloud saves enabled. As of the version I'm playing (1.00.00 I think) the devs even have it in the announcements with instructions for how to turn off cloud saves. There are also a number of other bugs that are less consistent, e.g. I once had to force quit when I got stuck in the horse capturing event.

Feels like we have a gem of a game forming. but right now we are in the infancy of this game. I cannot imagine how many hours of this game I would play if they do a throughout job on this game. Think of Mount and Blade but with guns.

There is still a lot to be desired, but just with the bare bones this game has to offer it's already worth putting some hours in to it. It's a challenging game but not over punishing. The mechanics are simple are enough, but enjoyable and have enough depth. I would love to see some quality of life added to logistics, and inventory urgently.

But overall, I happy with the systems they have implemented and excited to see what they add, they are really creating a solid foundation.

I would recommend buying since it's already fun to play, and do get your $30 worth already, and I would love to see what this project could do with more funding.

The game is annoying and not as "deep" as it wants you to believe. Worst thing of all though is how you can just be doomed by a certain class pick and have no realistic way to complete the run because the random boss counters the class you picked.

Also they absolutely ruined the game by tying the puzzle challenges to progression. The old version where you could just progress by doing dungeons was much better. The new kingdom stuff is terrible. The gold management, banking limits, weird overworld dungeon progression, tons of random messages you have to click multiple times to get rid of, kingdom item management... none of it is wanted. Should have just focused on the core game and not all the kingdom nonsense.

More pleasant and pretty than the original but otherwise much the same game. Which is good because the UI gives you much less information the original. It seems they expect you to already know plenty about the game. Gods' preferences are not recorded for seeing later. You can't see what building upgrades will give you before you buy them. At one point I completed a set of puzzles and never got the reward. The game never mentions anything about saving so I assumed it automatically saved as I went as many games do nowadays. Unfortunately dungeon runs are not saved when you close the game so I lost all my progress in the middle of an adventure. I like the game, but I wish it would communicate better with me, and I played a good deal of the original; the experience should be worse for new players.

Honest Reviews

Pros
1) The 2d visual & soundtracks are great.
2) Figuring out what the right card to use on each event/fight is fun (the first time around). 
    For example, Giving away a herb or an upside-down herb will result in a different out come.
    Using water card to interupt enemy fire spell. Using fire card on the Fool when he is drinking to set him on fire.
3) Eventhough it has no major effect on the gameplay I like how each children has their own unique characteristic & 
     interactions.
4) Base Upgrade Feature (in which doesn't last very long...)
    
Cons
Despite having some fun mechanics such as parry & elemental counterplay, the core gameplay end up being just spamming attack & heal cards ez win. I actually don't mind a game being too easy but the lack of new enemy variety & event make later runs kinda dull. For example, the Whale, Oarfish & Jellyfish all share the same attack pattern despite looking completly different.

So, I've played for nearly 4 hours so far last night and I am loving the new stuff. I enjoyed my cup of tea with it and realized I need snackies too. :( also very hangry - don't play at night if you are craving certain drinks and snackies to go with. xDD (also will there be a 3rd one but with snackies?) 10/10 still an awesome game, excellent soundtrack, visuals and it's like we've never left our favourite customers.

Wiped, restarted, finished the game again and this time it was 99/100 achievements. Third time was the charm, 100/100 achievements after VERY CAREFULLY selecting each frog and making sure I got an achievement for the click before I moved to the next frog. As painful as this process was (It took an hour) the game was fun the first playthrough and I've seen that majority of people don't have these issues, and if you're not a completionist / achievement hunter you'll have no issues with the game. Therefore I'm still giving it a positive review. Just be warned, it's not FLAWLESS.

The game feels good and it has potential to grow as a Mario Kart competitor which let's be serious, Nintendo keeps it to themselves. This is a nice opportunity to have a kart experience accross all platform. 

Stop leaving false information on reviews about the game being Pay To Win. Currently there is no Pay to Win mechanic in the game. Buying any of the packs grants you the same gameplay experience. Buying the Ultimate pack will only grant you 2-3 additional racers which you can also buy shards for from the shop when they become available. None of the come fully upgraded or something, everything level 1. 

The additional currency received from the pack? Sure is good to burn it all on the lootboxes like an idiot to get that extra shard you need. But you can also wait for the shards to become available in shops. The additional tokens for the boxes? Is it really pay to win if you open 3 extra boxes? 

Stop with the pay to win crap because this is not the case, the game does not require you any additional payments after you bough the game, you can't buy currency with real money, you just grind it like a normal person. But you open lootboxes for that extra shard because you want to upgrade NOW instead of waiting for an event that gives shards or to become available in the shop. 

Maybe you think there are few racers now, but the roster grows with every season (same with the tracks) The sense of speed is not enough? Come into a multiplayer race with me, I'll bash and stun you so fast, you will pray to the devs to make the game slower xD.

A very complex & difficult game to learn.
Finding people & aligning evidence with actual locations & using said locations where people live or even work can't be used as a way to find potential evidence as in most cases the people that work at these locations don't appear on their own security feeds making it impossible to identify a person or trace down a missing person if more than one person lives in an apartment where someone was killed which was the case for me.

I ran around for 4 hours trying to find a person with no avail. 
Even the tutorial fails to teach you how to play this game properly.
And simple "steal this" tasks don't give you a location to go steal stuff either, just the building but not the location specifically.
So if you walk into an apartment complex that has 1500 apartment within the complex itself; then good luck trying to find which place it is you're looking for.

Interesting premise but fails to deliver.

Honestly, no notes. This is an amazing experience. It does what it says on the tin, procedural murders to solve. It's a tough nut to crack for sure but it's a lot of fun. 

I am worried that the loop will get stale overtime but I've only played the intro case so far for about 2hrs so I haven't really had a chance to discover how the game keeps things fresh over time or what the "end game" is, if there is one.

I will say that sometimes the controls and UI feel a little clunky, would really love to see a mouse wheel scroll for inventory switching. But if thats my biggest complaint, I'd say this is a very solid early access game. Highly recommend you check this out for yourself, if you like 80s cyberpunk bladerunner style, mysteries, or just want to try something new this game is for you.

I wish Steam had a middle option between Recommend and Not Recommend at times like these. 

There's an incredibly strong and fun foundation to this game, but unfortunately for now the systems fall short in providing an interesting or engaging challenge, at least once you've done the first case (the tutorial one). I suspect that once it exits early access it'll definitely be worth picking up, but as is I can't really recommend it.

Performance issues and bugs aside, I think my biggest issue is just that it doesn't really feel like you're a detective, not even a private one that doesn't have to follow the rule of law to get answers. The side missions all have you doing straight up criminal stuff which wouldn't be a big deal if there was anything *other* than criminal things for you to do. You can't even legally enter a murder scene to investigate it since it counts as trespassing, so even if you're trying to do things "by the book", the game just won't let you and you have to break into the apartment anyways. Once you break in though, you basically have free reign to move stuff around, jump, sprint, whatever, no one will come in.

Even something tiny like letting you enter a building if you have a warrant, or chatting up the cops a bit to let you into the scene, small stuff like that would already be a huge improvement, because as it is right all you do is either sneak in through unguarded vents (that no one cares about you entering) or you just lockpick the door and walk in.

The game needs more avenues for gaining access to everything from buildings to information. More fleshed out dialogue options, better info gathering minigames like emails that actually tell you anything useful, recording incriminating conversations from vents, just little details like that, just like the detective media you presumably enjoy considering you're looking at this game in the first place.

Aside from that, the UI/UX is pretty rough as well, I hope a lot of love is put towards that. As is, everything is an information black hole, you can't even find your own address or access your own computer in your own apartment, you just need to memorize/ write it down somewhere.

I'll be keeping a close eye on this one, because I really want it to succeed and genuinely hope that it does.

Considering the bargain price, I recommend this game not only to anyone who enjoys puzzle games, but also first-timers who want to try something new.

I've only just started, so keep that in mind as I review this. If you see my playtime go up, I'm probably enjoying it.

You awake to a world of not-Pokemon, where everything is a Dragon and soaked in a air of Isekai-MC webnovel. Yes, I'm deadly serious. If you read Chinese cultivation novels-without-the-cultivation, you'll know exactly what I mean. If that alone gets your brain tingling, just buy it. Moving on, you figure out that your name is Chang Junwai, protag and Dragon Trainer, that is just another Tamer Student like many others. No, you cannot name your character. Yes, there is a reason for that. 

He's not a silent protagonist either. This matters more than you think.

Straight off, getting it out the way, this is a RPG-Maker game that you wouldn't know was a RPG-Maker game if you didn't pay attention to a few small tilesets and minor music pieces that are quite common in RPG-maker titles. However, that is where that all ends. When I said you wouldn't know unless you knew those things by memory, I meant it. Graphical wise, the artwork and style choice for the whole game is beautiful. Seriously, it's extraordinarily pretty and the looks for the characters alone are so sleek.

Try saving your game. Just do it. Yeah. Doesn't feel like a RPG-Maker game anymore, does it?

Just look at the screenshots. LOOK at those designs. They are everywhere and it's stunning. However, this can also be a fault. This is everywhere in the game and I can't believe I'm saying this, but many of the creatures in the game look so overly well-crafted that you start to get conflicted about just how well designed they are. Think about it in terms of Pokemon. You have have Pidgey, Pikachu and then Lugia. Every creature looks Lugia-level, when they could be a Pikachu, or a mere Pidgey. 

How you feel about that will depend on up to you as a player, but it was something that I got a little annoyed about after awhile. I still like them, but things are less cool when everything is cool. Thankfully, this is just looks and many of the creatures do feel different.

Battle wise? Your monsters have four moves, SP and a charging ATB gauge that tells you when you can use a move. Your opponent will not wait for you, so be ready to pop the move you want and think ahead. Or just hit thing until everything dies because honestly, you all know how creature collector games go. It's only as hard as you make it to be. You'll always have the chance to level up, train or just laugh at foolish NPC's thinking they stand a chance.

I'd spoil more but honestly, the more you progress the deeper the systems start to go. For something that is less expensive than a meal at McDonalds, it's extremely impressive what a brand new creator has done here. I'm both stunned by the effort and the desire to keep playing that I have. 

TLDR#

[b]Cons[/b]
*You cannot be a chick.
*English needs cleaned up. It's not as bad as MTL and very usable, but you'll notice mistakes.
*Some remaining RPG-Maker-style roots may turn some people off.
*Things might be TOO cool.
*I can't pronounce half these names and that's okay. Takes getting used to.

[b]Pros[/b]
*Cheap. Especially right now. 
*Story is a guilty pleasure.
*Artwork is a nonestop pretty-feast for the eyes
*Combat is oddly satisfying and fast.
*Another creature collector for the collection.

I only played a little but I like it already.  Basically ignore the "souls like" tag the marketing suits stick on everything these days and approach it as just an action adventure game.  It actually reminds me the old Soul Reaver series for some reason.  

It's pretty abstract and atmospheric (environments are huge in size), but what stands out the most is the involved combat system with switching colors and parries (of the matching color!) filling out ability bar. It's got the regular jump, dodge, parry, attack, ability etc... The dodge must happen right when the opponent connects so you have to watch them.  It's got a pretty interesting progression system.  If you are into timings and quick reflexes this is your game...  I enjoy this kind of stuff.  If you are into invincible roll dodging everywhere and spamming the fast attack button on everything that moves play dark souls I guess this is not it...  

this game doesn't also seem to have a convoluted tedious "story" associated with it which I also appreciate, I just enjoy the atmosphere but people who need to be led by the nose through some "interesting story" should go back to Elden Ring

And the great thing I appreciate is the HUD is minimal  and actually disappears altogether during adventuring, not many games do that.  Helps immersion.  The few pointless cut-scenes at the beginning are annoying as they take control from you, but that's the modern game design I guess, and this game doesn't overdo it  (like Dark Souls)
A great game so far! I can recommend

This game drives alright once you actually get the car going. It's possible to drive on controller for some people I'm told, but not possible for me, car just spins out completely going into the corner even when I'm up to speed. Reverse on controller is B for xbox, Circle for playstaion. On keyboard it's E and R. I could not find a button/Key for braking which is odd. I could switch it to reverse to brake if needed, but that adds a lot more complication to simply driving the car. I think the physics are pushing too much towards sim style physics, I think it needs to be more towards arcade style. 

All in all, I think there's much to improve on, like how sensitive the car is when trying to go if stopped or slow, it's way too easy to spin out especially on controller in my case. I think there definitely needs to be brakes of some kind. I don't think I'll keep playing this until some improvements are made, I'd like to avoid arthritis in my hand playing on keyboard. I'll recommend it for casual play, but don't expect to have a good time if you're playing to be competitive.

TL;DR - Way too difficult. Spent around 6 hours without any wins after the intro + tutorials.

This game is exactly what I like, dungeon puzzle with a nice UI.

BUT, Past the tutorials and around 4-5 missions since the beginning, I have spend about 6 hours, not able to score ONE win. Very frustrating.  I don't mind challenging puzzle and I'm really wondering what I'm doing wrong as I do everything according to tips and recommendations. 

And I've spend a lot of time on the Web, trying to get some tips, reading Reddit, etc. I really like this game but they need to put some difficulty settings. I was never close to a WIN. You have to level up and fight against a final boss of Level 10. I can barely go around Level 7, no able to kill anything after this (and not enough to level up). The boss does enough damage in ONE strike to wipe me out. I posted couple of messages to have some help, but I can't see what I can do more. And I'm expecting this game to be tougher later so....

When rating a game like this, there's 3 main categories I'd use.

1: Gameplay mechanics/loop - There's one or two things I don't like, particularly the samey-ness of some of the dungeons, but otherwise I'm pretty happy here.
2: Dialogue, Characters and Story: Vapid, boring, static, one dimensional. Nothing interesting or noteworthy here.
3: Graphics: The studio does a good job, but it's still a repetitive, boring set of graphics. 8-bit stylization isn't my thing though.

6/10

[h1] Overview [/h1]

The Mageseeker is a top-down pixel-stylized action-adventure RPG. Set in the League of Legends world of Runeterra, it explores the journey of convict traitor Sylas as he seeks to free mages from tyranny and change Demacia‚Äôs mindset of their second-class citizens. Your primary enemies are the Mageseekers, an oppressive policing force that arrests and prosecutes mages simply for existing regardless of whether they‚Äôre guilty or innocent of any crime. Although the country of Demacia displays itself as righteous and just, the Mageseekers are the corrupted cancerous sore just underneath the skin. 
	Combat consists of beating mageseekers and wild animals to a pulp, stealing their magic and turning it against them. It‚Äôs constantly engaging, pushing you from fight to fight. The puzzles that present themselves in between are pretty basic, but not horribly so. 
The most interesting thing about this game is the story, if you care at all about the League of Legends universe. The struggles of Sylas and his allies are endearing. The strife of Jarvan the 4th suddenly becoming king is on full display, showing that a young man with minimal idea of how to lead anyone probably shouldn‚Äôt be the right guy to head an entire country. I don‚Äôt want to give any spoilers, but League players will get a kick out of the cameos and enjoy the characters interwoven into major roles, especially the revelations of Demacia and the truths it attempts to conceal.

Pros

o	Fun combat that keeps you on your toes
o	The variety of options that the magic and ultimate system gives you
o	The characters, minor and major
o	The story
o	The platforming in certain combat engagements keeps you moving, forcing you to thoroughly think before jumping in head first
o	The graphical stylizations are an enjoyable choice
o	Most of the bosses are pretty awesome, offering interesting and evolving mechanics.
o	You can edit the difficulty to your liking, like increasing enemy HP and damage or reducing Sylas‚Äô HP and damage. You can adjust this difficulty on the fly as well, which is very nice if you feel like the game is too easy or too hard.

Cons

o	Various bugs, both visual and audio are present. Especially in the later game.
o	Its pretty short, only clocking in at about 20-22 hours depending on how well you do at some  boss fights.
o	Enemy AI will sometimes just break, resulting in them just standing their not casting spells or attacking.
o	Some enemies will just be invincible for no reason.
o	Some boss fights feel too full of AoE, causing them to feel unfair.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

	I played the game on hard mode, which increases enemy health and damage. I didn‚Äôt reduce Sylas‚Äô HP or damage, or this game would‚Äôve taken forever. 
At the end of the day, I would give this game about an 8.5/10. Its quite fun, aside from certain frustrating sections. I think it‚Äôs definitely worth a playthrough. The caveat is that I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs worth $30. I‚Äôd recommend waiting for a sale. The Deluxe addition really isn‚Äôt worth it unless you just want to support the devs.

Zoeti is a game that, if you are a fan of roguelite deckbuilders(Slay the Spire, Roguebook, Inscryption, etc) is a must try. But make no mistake, this is game is a strategy game just as much as it is a roguelite deckbuilder. Relying on combinations of cards and keeping track of what you have in your hand as well as your upcoming draws is crucial to the gameplay. 

Gameplay: 

You do not build a deck, but rather you build the array of abilities you can use by having specific combinations of cards from a deck made of traditional playing cards. This feels a bit unfamiliar compared to other games in the genre, but once you figure it out, it works well. Combat encounters feel very hit or miss, you will one shot an elite encounter and then the very next encounter be completely helpless. This is partially the nature of roguelites, but at the same time this feels very extreme and very unforgiving.

Story:
The story, if you are interested, has a lot of depth, however having a story that you repeatedly try to complete and start from scratch after each failed run makes the runs feel a little monotonous. I wanted to skip dialogue, but there are a lot of times where in the middle of 20+ dialogue panels you get to make decisions on gaining specific items so you feel like you can't skip anything.

Pros: 

- The actual gameplay is simple enough to pick up and understand, you don't need to understand poker to understand this
- There is a surprising amount of depth in how you manipulate your hand to succeed, and when you can properly manage your hand turn to turn it feels very satisfying
- The soundtrack is fantastic
- The game is visually very well polished, and accomplishes exactly what it is trying to do

Cons:

- The tutorial is a bit of an information dump, most people will do better just jumping right in if they have prior experience with the genre rather than trying to read everything and understand what it is saying
- This is not a good intro game to roguelike deckbuilders, there is enough complexity that you would be better playing something more straightforward to understand the genre and then coming back to this.


Zoeti can be very unforgiving, especially if you do not understand the values of offence and defense and how to balance them in your abilities. If you are a fan of a challenge and roguelite deckbuilders, this game is for you. If you have never played a roguelite deckbuilder before, then look somewhere else, and if you enjoy it, then come back here. You won't regret it.

Coffee Talk Episode 2: Hibiscus & Butterfly is both a sequel and a final message to Mohammad Fahmi. Toge Productions and Chorus Worldwide have done a good job of delivering Fahmi's final message interestingly and beautifully.

However, as with any new sequel in a franchise, this comes at the expense of the narrative and core gameplay of the original game. Some of the narratives may seem dull and the gameplay offered less varied, but the addition of new characters, drink ingredients, and features make Coffee Talk Episode 2: Hibiscus & Butterfly more varied and interesting to play, especially for those who come as newcomers.

At the end of the day, Coffee Talk is about enjoying the stories and atmosphere of the cafe and listening to the stories and complaints of the customers about their daily lives. Coffee Talk Episode 2: Hibiscus & Butterfly is the perfect game when played after work to enjoy the distinctive stories that Toge Productions has to offer.
Just a great game to chill and make coffee and an intriguing story jut like the first one.

The game is awesome, but in its current state there some severely annoying bugs that ruin some of the experience. I think this game deserves all the positive feedback its getting, but I would wait a month or two to purchase it until they fix some of the more damaging bugs. Some things I experienced included:

1) being stuck the letter opening screen and unable to get out without restarting the whole game (and potentially losing all my game progress for that month)
2) being unable to advance my knight quests at all upon receiving them throughout the duration of the entire game
3) my stats suddenly spiking way up or down after completing an exploration
4) visual bugs where if I skip a cutscene it overlays on top of another cutscene anyways and both voices in the cutscene go at once
5) (not a bug but bad feature) Having enemies "cast a spell" when I'm exploring that doesn't tell me what they are going to do. I lost several runs that way in the last exploration area.

Overall, the bugs don't help the experience, but the game is so much fun that I still played through all of these issues and more. At its current price the game is totally worth it, but if bugs like these turn you off then wait a month until after its released for it to be fixed.

[h1]Not at all like Mount and Blade, more like grand Strategy meets Call to Arms[/h1]

Mount & Blade is first and foremost an RPG, you play as a character, you raise said character stats, and all the game interactions depend on that character and it's standing with the kingdom or other characters, including controlling armies either strategically or tactically, and any diplomacy or settlement management options. [b]Total Conflict: Resistance[/b] doesn't have you controlling a single character, but a whole faction, including it's economy, diplomacy and armies, in a real time grand strategy map, and then you can take control of any soldier or vehicle under your command in real time tactical battles. It's more like a lighter real time Grand Strategy that allows you to control battles in a RTS/FPS hybrid way, think a lighter Realpolitiks meets Call to Arms.

The game is on it's early steps and has a [b]long[/b] way to go. I'd avoid purchasing so early unless you're willing to take the risk, as many promising early access titles get dropped halfway. But I'm confident the good reception will fuel the development of the game to fulfill it's potential. It is, in many ways, a new genre, so it gets extra points for that.

[B]The bad[/b]

The game has a long way to go. The FPS part needs polish, particularly the vehicle control needs a bunch of fine tuning. The RTS part of the game might be the blandest, you need more options in the way you order your units, like advance either seeking cover or assaulting a position, telling your troops to go prone, maybe different formations, etc. The RTS is very bare bones in that aspect.

The production and tech trees are all over the place, and make little sense, they need to be polished and better explained. You can make convoys to build complex production lines (a city makes a raw resource, a second city refines it, a third one makes weapons out of it), but you could do with better production and convoy control (a panel where I can see and tweak what my cities build, what they produce and need, and my programmed convoys).

The story (so far) is funny yet bland, clich√©d, but it allows you to play NATO vs Warsaw Pact equipment and tech trees, which is what I'm here for. There are "anarchist" or "rebel" factions, and you can start as one but I don't recommend it as you'll loose the little tutorial there is and it's a harder start [spoiler]and they are not ideological anarchist, just anarchists in the lax use of the word[/spoiler]. For some reason the character names seem drawn from a bucket, and don't fit the setting, that speaks of European and Slavic populations.

You can manage the equipment your squads have, but that part needs tons of polish. I'd like the devs to take inspiration from Hearts of Iron, where you could design your squads to a standard, and then the logistics in the game will try to match it. At the moment, you can "design" squads in a separate screen with weapons you don't have available, and then you won't be able to build them. "Uniforms" are used as an abstraction for "training", as you'll be able to raise as many soldiers or militias as you have uniforms, and that's Ok, I guess, but could be better explained in game.

Models and graphics also need a lot of work, "standard" troops look more like PMC than like regular army soldiers. Rebels also look more like PMC than like civilians that took up arms. I'd like to see more 1980's NATO or Warsaw Pact uniforms and gear. Also, for some reason, you get desert fatigues but I haven't seen any desert on the map. On the 2D graphics side, the portraits could use a little touch-up, some of the anarchists don't look like rebels at all. The flags could use a lot of work, you have a "communist" flag with a fleu-de-Lis (a French aristocratic symbol), really, use flags that look like the former Yugoslavia or DDR, with red stars or "symbols of work", please. None of the anarchists flags has a circled A.

Music is absolutely bland and forgettable.

You don't have female soldiers, which is [b]an error[/b] I expect the devs to fix, since women have been fighting in wars since antiquity and are fighting at wars today, so it's really just not realistic not to have 10-20% female troops. More so since both "communism" and "democracy" (the opposing ideologies in this game) believe in women rights.

[h1] tldr: Early in development game where you can control a faction in a "West-vs-East" civil war from (light) Grand Strategy down to tactical RTS battles and to a single soldier or vehicle in FPS[/h1]

[table]

        [td]2023[/td]
        [td]$14.99, on sale for $13.49 at the time of this writing, probably on sale now if you're reading this.[/td]

I don't get to play a lot of video games these days. Not really a bad thing, life is better when you're busier, and Sleeper Games titles are experiences I would be loathe to miss out on. This one is coming out of pre-release with a LOT of polish and interface work completed, and prior builds from Itch.io can be reviewed if a body's interested in getting some of that alpha flavor for background. Nice how some games have that going for them: this one is such a game. Good developers, good aesthetic, and an excellent community of players and makers to get in touch with on the ol' Discord there. For a pizza-money price, you're getting what could amount to hundreds of hours of entertainment, wrapped in an aesthetic which has not been matched by any other game creator's titles. It's an [b]experience[/b].

[b][i]If you're checking this game out without having seen any other Sleeper Games titles[/i][/b]: this game is "Genesis/SNES-era Metal Gear with Spaceships in the Atmosphere of a Gas Giant, And You Have Done Drugs". There is a story, and you'll get bits and pieces of it via roguelite-esque missions. The interface for purchasing and equipping gear is fairly unique, and you may enjoy or hate it, depending on how willing you are to try a new experience.

There are parts of this game that will grate, and parts that will be smoother than you'd imagined possible, and there will be exploits from combinations of certain items and weapons. Some of these things will be emergent, some will be built in, I've enjoyed both playing this game without any tutorials *and* playing the tutorials, which are decent, and somewhat challenging to follow and complete. It's a difficult game, you'll quit out of frustration at least once if you're anything like a normal person, and it's still way easier than a lot of games out there. Like a lot of stealth games, there is a puzzle aspect to its action, and combat will have its ups and downs.

[b][i]If you're checking this out after having quickly glanced at the other Sleeper Games titles[/i][/b]: this game is a stealth game rendered in a style similar to ---Red---Tether-->, with a more forgiving twitch-gameplay aspect in its combat, less tether related mechanics, and the aggregated benefit of Sleeper Games's experience from developing their prior titles. Gameplay for this title is very, very distinguished from that in Hyperspace Dogfights, still holds some similarities in certain mechanics though.

[b][i]If you're checking this out after having played and hated the other Sleeper Games titles[/i][/b]: figure it out, lol, what are you doing here?

[b][i]If you're checking this out after having played and enjoyed the other Sleeper Games titles[/i][/b]: also lol, leave a review too, and this game implements some great stuff from each prior game.

From my own steady experience with those titles and this one, and from having witnessed some of the pre-release and alpha build forms for this and ---Red---Tether--->, this is already looking like a final-product, and despite that it almost certainly guaranteed to continue to get updates with more content for at least the next several months, and potentially over the course of the next few years.

Things like the loss of the combat log making it difficult to understand how god punishments work and some other changes mean that aspects of the game are a bit hard to understand. Still, at 20 bucks it's hard to find a better way to scratch the roguelike dungeon crawl itch in half an hour.

I'm thoroughly enjoying Survival: Fountain of Youth! The game offers a compelling story line that keeps me engaged in exploring the world around me. I particularly appreciate the crafting system, which adds a satisfying sense of progress as I gather resources and create new tools. Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for an immersive survival experience with a strong narrative

After my first time playing, I immediately see a huge problem with this game: base management. One of the first things you do in a survival crafting game is survey resources available in an area and decide where to put your base. However, in this game, resources take a long time to regenerate, so you will either have to constantly move your base, or travel further and further for resources (and that doesn't include how much the story quests move you around the map). With the very limited and restrictive movement/carry weight system (you stop completely dead if you are even .1 overweight, which I would suggest a change to maybe 75% movement speed reduction and unable to jump or run, when you are overloaded).

An overlooked possible feature of this game, right at the start, is salvaging the debris from your ship... Like, you see pieces of it all over, but can't do ANYTHING with it.

Short Version: I enjoyed my time with the game for the most part, but regret buying it at full price. The game is around 12 hours long and would be worth buying on a serious discount, but simply does not offer enough for its asking price.

---------------------------------------------------
Long, slightly unstructured version:

The gameplay is enjoyable enough, although you are completely fine for the most part just ignoring the counter element system and the additional moves your allies give you even on the highest difficulty, which is such a shame. Its fun to go through the missions, cool to see your base progress, but nothing too fancy overall.
Sadly, the gameplay is brought down by the low variety in locations and layouts. And while enemy variety is good, the supposed "strongest variant" of most elements feel like less of a threat than their weaker allies, which again is a shame. The variety of spells is nice tho, especially that not all of them are simple damage spells.

Sadly, the story is utterly unremarkable as a mixture of tropes you can see coming from 10 miles away. This would be fine with compelling characters, but I feel that they are also very one-note and cannot carry the story even for its short runtime of around 12 hours (if you complete everything). It also gets vexxing very quickly how the ending to most main story boss fights are handled. And this is such a shame, as the premise has such promise, which is sometimes tapped into ever so slightly, mostly in notes, but wasted for the most part.

The presentation feels a little off. The music is great and the art can look good, especially enemies, but looks silly too many times in dialogue and things like the base walking animation. Which can be ignored during combat so this is a minor issue. What cannot be ignored are the awkward cuts, sometimes not loading cutscenes, etc. Visual clarity is great however. (My complaints might be a product of my general dislike of most pixel art, so take with a grain of salt.)

Overall my issues can be boiled down to too little for too much money. This game is not worth its full price, not to mention the terrible launch-day DLC which locks additional spells behind your wallet. And this tainted my entire experience. Get it on a discount of at least 50% for some light entertainment, don't get it for the story.
Economy needs balancing so you don't run out of money so easily. But the first year of funding is a blast! Super strong Stargate vibes with this game and I love it!

I am a long time Minecraft fan and i was really hyped for this game. Other than being disappointed at launch due to steam deck compatibility (mf microsoy login screen) the game overall has been a great time. 

I think most people used to Minecraft will call this game boring due to it being action strategy but i think it is actually quite nice being a little bit more hands off and leading troops instead of doing everything yourself, it gives you a wider picture to be able to take on larger scale battles more effectively. The beginning of the game hand hold you through the first main battle and after that its pretty much open world, this is basically a redundant second tutorial to teach you how to actually play the game past simple mechanics and even though its a little annoying at the start i think its needed since this is a radical change in genre.

Also given the market of every game being $60 it is refreshing to see a title give a lower price tag dont listen to the overly negative reviews people are just coping bc of the genre change.

Well, I‚Äôll start off by saying I have fears of survival games that have an ocean biome. The Forest, Sons of the Forest, Stranded deep, Raft, Fountain of Youth. And I was scared diving in this at first (example is I approached a wrecked ship out at sea and heard the hunted death music come on and a shark swimming towards the surface near my canoe‚Ä¶ my IRL heart rate increased I started to sweat and I took my canoe and got the hell outta there‚Ä¶ then I turned back after calming down and decided I will no longer let video game sea predators scare me‚Ä¶ I have 2 shark head trophies mounted on my walls of my main camp ü§£ü§£ü§£)  and harpooning a shark and dorados. Diving for sea resources would have all been skipped but fear has been conquered and I dive each time i play. I already have 30 hours in 5 days‚Ä¶ I love everything about this game. The only thing I can comment on is I notice frame drops and stuttering at times usually involving fire and high foliage but it doesn‚Äôt happen often and doesn‚Äôt last for too long. I used to hate survival games but I have recently become addicted and I‚Äôm enjoying the grind so far. Not too challenging in the beginning which is great for getting used to menus, buttons, mechanics etc etc. but by the time you master the basics I mentioned, the game starts throwing the heat exhaustion/stroke, poisonings, cuts,  fevers, fatigue and more. 

I do hope for a roadmap to know what to expect but regardless I will look forward to the devs updating an already S tier game with or without one! I made my wife buy this game too ü§≠
