It's always an absolute pleasure to find a game like this: a truly unique experience that tosses out the typical conventions of indie horror games and tries (AND succeeds) to do its own thing. I can't say I've ever played a game quite like this, and I've played well over 1200 indie horror games over the last 5 years. Superb atmosphere and sound design, an interesting and captivating story, a true mystery that is slowly uncovered as you continue playing, and a disturbing premise. These qualities all came together in a fantastic way, all packed into a bite sized experience that I won't soon forget! You made my skin crawl with this one, fantastic work! Highly recommended!

If you liked the 2D desktop dungeons, this is literally 1:1 but with a new rewind mechanic (edit: and some minor nearly inconsequential edits to certain classes etc.). So, you will like it exactly as much as you did the previous one (I loved the first one, so i'm loving this)

Will say the rewind mechanic is not anything necessary at all though- if you die, it warps you back to a seemingly random point about 40-60% of the way through your run. it's actually something I usually don't even use, because it's too confusing to remember where you are now. So ultimately I would say the game is a super gorgeous version of the already gorgeous 2D version, but with an unneeded (*optional*) new mechanic. 

Plus it comes with the goat as part of the game and not as DLC, so GOTY edition for sure.

They took a fun little game and made it better in every way. Graphics are better and overall charm is enhanced. The balance and difficulty curve are improved. The classes feel more unique. Enemies feel more varied and nuanced. Paid DLC is now part of the game. Everyone should play this game. 

Only con would be the story is light but I feel this is offset by the games overall charm, style and delivery.
good

I wish I could've liked this game more, but there are a few shortcomings that it has that make it really unfun for me. I really enjoyed the pixel art of this game and I think the story is interesting for someone who doesn't really pay attention to that stuff, but when it comes to the gameplay I feel a bit disappointed. 

The dash feels annoying and kinda of works against you alot of the times. Maybe its because I've been graced with other games with different dash mechanics but this one feels sluggish and gets you stuck on objects quite often. I wondered if this was part of the difficulty in the game because this dash SUCKS. 

Another thing that bothers me is the checkpoints. I think the checkpoints are pretty distant to where you last died and it makes it a hassle having to walk over to where you last were instead of just being at the entrance near the place you died. And in my opinion, this especially becomes more evident when you do the side missions of this game, where part of those stages gives you choice of which powerful unique spell you can get. After making your choice and proceeding into the next room, let's say you die. Now I have to go BACK to that last shrine where I made my choice, make my decision AGAIN, and then dash back to that room to start all over. Personally I feel that if you made that chose to begin with, then the player should commit to that spell continuing forward. The argument could be made that maybe a different spell could lead to a better outcome and different ways to tackle those challenges, and in that i would understand. I think I just don't like it.

The cutscenes, the CUTSCENES, can be very tedious and unbearable if they are present before a boss fight or phase. If I lose in a bossfight that has cutscenes before it, you know damn well I am going to have to sit through all that text and animations AGAIN to get straight to the fight. You have the option to "fast forward" these cutscenes instead of a skip button to get to the fight which is just weird. And honestly I don't think this fast forward button makes the animations before a boss fight go faster, I think they just stay the same speed but I'm not too sure. It just makes text go faster which is just okay. It becomes a habit that I've come to see during play that makes it hard to overlook. 

And the last thing I should mention is some of the malpractices other reviewers have come to notice as well. Like disabling spells behind a paywall that you can't get otherwise. I found that out late after I preordered the game and I just find it wrong. 

I really like what they were going here. I enjoy Sylas as a character and I think the game has some wonderful and special charm to it given its story and art, I just wouldn't recommend it right now. I will still continue to play it since I like the champion personally and I guess I just like to suffer, but I'm not sure how long it will last. Hopefully in the future they will update this game with quality of life changes and then I will see myself playing it more.

This is a lovely sequel to the original, with a longer story line and more characters in addition to the regulars you've come to know and love. The music is nice and chill, the variety of arcs has greatly increased, and the drawer system adds to the player's responsibility within the narrative, which is really nice.

There are a few things that sort of make the experience a bit less immersive or polished as it should be. None of the customers finish their drinks, when customers move seats there isn't any sound or animation, and there are a few spelling errors scattered around the dialogue that grab my attention. A nice patch addressing some of these issues could fix these right up, though. Also, for a world based in 2023, the themes of social media are a bit... old? I didn't necessarily feel anything new being addressed with that topic, but that might just be me.

Overall, I enjoyed this game, and would recommend it to anyone who liked the first one or something similar like VA-11 Hall-A. Chill beats, warm drinks, and a bright and lively cast of characters, as always.

a visually stunning game that takes players on a surreal journey through various puzzles. Although the gameplay mechanics can take some time to master, the game's design is simply mesmerizing. Whether you're a puzzle game enthusiast or just looking for a tranquil gaming experience, it is an absolute must-play.

You can check some gameplay on Steam Deck by pressing the link below:
https://youtu.be/f-14jqDwgZg

It's like taking Elden Ring, making it a bit more accessible and giving it a more artistic, colorful art style and you have Stray Blade. While the environmental art up close looks good, the distance terrain could use more detail as it looks backgrounds found in the old PS2 era. 

Combat is what you expect in the souls-like genre with easy-to-understand dodge and parry system. The finishing moves are satisfying as well. 

The skill system rewards experimentation with other weapons but at the same time, it doesn't reward those who just want to stay with a specific weapon. A skill tree refresh in a future DLC could be most welcome here.

Is it work playing? I think if you enjoyed watching Elden Ring through streams and videos but thought it was to difficult to enjoy yourself, you might enjoy this approach. The story is entertaining and the voice talent is quite good. 

Solid 7/10 but easily higher with future content, patching and additions to make the game reach its full potential.

I really wanted to like this game. The concept is cute, the characters are lively, the overall game has so much potential. Unfortunately, this game has game breaking bugs. To the point where it is actually unplayable. There are several people complaining about translation issues, and sure the English translation could be better, but there are two very specific bugs that most people seem to be having problems with. The letters you receive from other characters and when you try to tame a horse.

The letter bug you are able to bypass by not even entertaining the thought of clicking on it. Unfortunately, the horse bug completely crashes your game and breaks it. I can't even play the game anymore. It won't let me get past the opening sequence. There are people who keep saying to unpatch the game, to force it roll back to the old patch, but it does not work if your files are located Program Files (x86). As of right now, my game is actually unplayable.

I recommend saving your money until these bugs are completely fixed. I will change my review until I am able to play the game again.

UNMARKED SPOILERS FOR COFFEE TALK 1
If there was a 'neutral' option I'd pick that. 

I played the first Coffee Talk because I wanted an experience like va11halla. The game ultimately disappointed me quite a bit but I could see the potential in it and I was looking forward to giving this one a try. 

The mechanics and story beats between the two games are largely very similar. This one has a few more drinks and the ability to give items to patrons. Honestly I strongly recommend playing this game with a guide. Replaying days to get drink orders correct is a pain in the ass due to the fast-forward feature not actually fast-forwarding through character animations and the like, and the expanded menu and choices mean little in terms of branching plot content. The good options are objectively more interesting and satisfying than the bad ones (at least from what I experienced).

The story and character selection has somewhat improved as well. I found Freya from the first game to be fairly obnoxious due to her constant meta conversations about stories and narratives. Glad to say that she's pretty much gone. The new characters aren't the best and some of the storylines are utter bores, but at least there's nobody in the cast I hate. 

In my review of coffee talk 1 I expressed my disdain for Lua and Baileys' story and the very forced allegory to racism and inter-cultural marriage. A lot of people mistook this as me hating the game's 'SJW agenda' or something but I have no problem with games tackling contemporary political issues. The reason it was such a bad storyline is because it failed to be interesting within the context of its own world. See, coffee talk has this problem where it gets so caught up in allegories and dialogue that it seems to forget that it is supposed to be a game in its own world. Succubi and elves have no obvious cultural differences. Any historical context simply isn't mentioned. The language they use to talk about their conflict far too strongly resembles the language of our world despite Bailey and Lua literally being different species. I know this isn't Coffee Talk 1 but this tangent applies to the alien storyline in Coffee Talk 2. 

Between the talk about being accepted, changing your appearance and pronouns to better fit with who you are, and coming out to the person you're dating. Silver (previously Neil) is a somewhat obvious allegory for gender identity issues. However when the allegory is this intentional, it starts becoming a little weird that your stand-in for a trans person is literally an alien being pursued by the men-in-black because... well actually they never give us a good reason why. It's like this story was written as an allegory first and a story in the world of coffee talk second. However this story comes across as extra bizarre because Silver and the other alien spend a lot of time teaching you about the nature of their species. If you remember the reveal from the first game, you literally are one of these aliens. Why are they telling you all this? 

Coffee Talk really has a tendency to use most of its dialogue for the benefit of the player while sacrificing more organic conversation. Gala and Hyde remind you explicitly of their long lifespans multiple times. Why? Your player character has talked to them a fuckload of times. This should be common knowledge. It's like if you asked a Chinese bloke what he had for lunch and he told you "I had a delicious bowl of white rice, the staple crop of us Chinese, which I ate with chopsticks, the cutlery of choice for many Chinese folk." It's bizarre and immersion-breaking. 

Even Jorji's storyline about the mysterious spooky vandalism cases has shades of this. Some of the conversations very quickly stop feeling like conversations and start feeling like a Wikipedia page written in casual speech. 

Although I just spent several paragraphs shitting on the game, it's not all bad. The newer sprite work is subtly but noticeably an improvement. The first game's art was fine, but some sprites looked more like low-res paintings than active uses of pixel art. Coffee Talk 2's sprites lean a lot more into the pixel art aesthetics. In some places such as the sprites of the drinks, and pictures on the social media app, the improvements are a lot more obvious. 

A lot of the casual conversations in this game unrelated to the main plot threads have very strong character building. Lua and Hyde specifically get fleshed out a lot in this game, and are much better for it. Rachel was one of the stronger characters from the 1st game and although she only shows up here and there, she's still a lot of fun in this one. The new characters do manage to have their share of interesting moments as well. 

In spite of everything, I do think this is an improvement over Coffee Talk 1. If you liked the first one, I am certain you will like this one. But I still think it is too flawed to earnestly recommend.

I will divide the review in two parts. How i feel the character evolves, and how diverse the biomes are.

[b]Character progression:[/b]
Meta Progression:

There's three main aspect to it. Friendship trinkets, departements and the evolution tree. Yeah it's not the official names but honestly it simpler to name them this way for now.

So the trinkets are basically passives that improves a few stats, specific elements, or could give you more gold during a run. I feel these are fine, killing 20 lords is a bit too much for the last level requirement but overall i feel they do their jobs and are a good way to evolve your character during a run and you get them relatively quickly up to the current cap (outside of elemental ones because you could kill the 20 lords with them all in the current build).

The Departments are also relatively fine in term of progress speed, outside of the ressource you only seem to get from Lord kills but no real complaints. I'm only missing like three upgrades and it's mostly about 20 left to grind. These are mostly upgrade that adds some options during a run. The effects are small but noticeable. I'm a big fan of the one that adds a rhapsody option at the very start of the run but more about this later. Again, no real complaints here.

The evolution tree are basically stat upgrades or buffs that will impact your character directly, such as more damage, some initial goal, an extra life, more health and more. These are the boring kind of upgrades but i will not complain about my distate of this kind of meta progression here. The real issue atm is the speed you aquire the resources. It's slow. Unlike the two previous aspects of the meta progression system, i'm nowhere near done, i don't have all the nodes unlocked, most are at level 1 or 2. It's insanely grindy and i feel needs to be toned down.

Run progression:

Theres 6 aspect to this. The stat potions, the curses, the trinkets, the grid, the rhapsody and the elemental records.

Stat potions are the least interesting but still have an impact on your run of course. They are basically random stat increase and sometime decrease that can help you define a little bit more your character. That's it. Boring but i don't really mind it existing of course.

Curses usually have a temporary negative effect and a big stat upgrade to one aspect of your character. There's not many buffs and debuffs, and ultimately it's kind of boring too. I'd like to see this aspect of the game a little bit more improved with wilder debuffs and buffs cause it feels pretty samey honestly.

Trinkets are just here to refine your character. Get the elemntal ones if you focus on some elements, maybe the starting gold one to get a nice headstart, and choose one more after each chapter clear. Again it's ok, since you know what your options are i feel it's a bit more interesting that the two previous points but i see them more as a way to refine the character.

The grid. Ok so the grid is a weird one. I'd say most of it is boring stat change and will kinda randomly add power to your character but damn some of the nodes are wild. Special mention to the +30% damage per successive smash which is absolutely run defining. Just a single node can completely change how you will end up playing the game. And there's a few like this. Overall i do like the system and i'd like to see more of this kind of nodes rather than the more basic stat change ones. These rare nodes are single handhedly making this system incredible. Be more wild if you expand it with new effects.

Rhapsody is the best thing but i think it's very character dependant. Some of them completely change how the character plays, some of them just add more power of slightly change some attacks. Lilya I think has an awesome mix of skill that will impact almost all possible aspect of the character. Different auto attacks, different variation skill, different main skill, a smash upgrade, the ability to spam your main skill if you play on tempo. Genuinly incredible. Evelyn is also pretty decent but i think not as impressive as Lilya. Maz i feel is kinda boring, maybe i didn't play enough with him but i don't find that the change to his main skills are particularly interesting, and i don't see anything that alter how the variation skill works unlike the two other characters (it's not as wild for Evelyn either but it's still there). So yeah, best part of the game but some character currently have more interesting options i feel. Definitly what i want to see more of in the future, i'd love for the current and new characters to have more of these for sure.

Elemental records are kind of a mixed bag but tbh i think they do the trick just fine. I kinda don't pay attention to them cause it's mostly passive triggers that either work on normals, variation, smash or main. SOmetime there's a bit more of a strategy cause your main skill could be doing more damage if the enemies are frozen, or you can crouch to plant some turrets, but usually i feel it's simply better to just focus on a few main aspect (like variation skills on Evelyn and Maz) and thing will happen on their own without too much brain power. It's ok, i do hope that the effect become wilder and require a bit more thoughts with future additions however. It's the second best aspect i feel but Rhapsody is far more run defining imo.

So overall my opinion is that the meta progression is fine but needs some heavy fine tuning in speed for the evolution tree. And i'd like to see more of a focus on elemental records, the grid and especially rhapsody during the course of the EA. Also i'd argue that adding more to the rhythm element of the combat could be fun. The Lilya main skill reset on tempo press is so damn satisfying for example, we could use more of this kind of stuff. Maybe having normals or variation upgrades that work with the tempo.

[b]Biome Diversity:[/b]

A much shorter topic but also where i feel the game is currently lacking the most.
It need more gimmicks than the gacha, curses and the battle arenas as random events during combat sections.

The amount of different enemies per biome is just ok but i feel 2-3 more biome specific ones could really go a long way.
Do not understimate the joy of fighting 2-3 different bosses at the end of a biome, or more elites in the middle of a biome either. Constantly killing the same boss every runs gets old, at least personally. This is a strength of the genre i feel many roguelite end up dropping the ball with, and it would sadden me to see it being the case here once more. SInce they are story related, i'd say adding alternatives would be more fitting for difficulty level options after a cleared run, but it would still be a nice addition imo.

As for the room variety i feel it's also a bit lacking. Yeah i can believe there's 400 rooms but it still manages to feel a bit repetitive. There's also not enough of the mini game rooms. Like i feel all of them have 2-3 variations at best. I do really like them so i think adding more room like these would be cool to break the monotony, and more types as well.
Also a weird point but i feel that some of the traps you see in these rooms could be made part of a few basic combat arenas, to diversify each biome from one another. It would also justify the trap damage curse more as an actual threat than it currently is. I feel they are wasted in only being used in these rooms for now.

So yeah overall this aspect of the game is kinda meh but serviceable for now. Needs a bit of some polish across all aspects. It's not bad, especially for an EA start, but i hope it gets looked up a bit. As words of encouragement... It's still infinitely better than what game like Skul or even Hades started and even sometimes ended up with. So yes i'm very critical with this aspect, and i'd love to see you come out on top, as i feel the game as a lot of potential.

This game is a lot of fun. Be a good dad and raise an awesome daughter. 

The game is similar to Long Live The Queen or My Life As A Teenage Exocolonist. 

You talk to people, give gifts, take classes, go on expeditions, farm, cook, work at a part time job, do alchemy, etc. You raise statistics through coursework, consuming certain farming outputs, consuming potions, buying outfits, or getting decorations for your house. Some combat specific stats can be raised through going on expeditions. Talking to characters you see on screen also grants a "perception" statistic / currency that is used when responding to letters you see if you have admirers, which can be gained from fame you get from attending balls or working as an actress, or from part time jobes at the bath with more sketchy jobs like card dealer for the mafia granting more admirers. The perception currency you get from talking to each character makes it worth while to talk to everyone and makes it so there are no useless character interactions in the game.

At the end of a playthrough, the person your daughter has the closest relationship with is the trigger for who your daughter marries as an adult. Your daughter may romance female characters if you to. Relationships with characters can be raised by chatting with them, giving them gifts, consulting them which also raises your statistics, challenging them to debates or duels, and taking them on dates. Dates so far seem completely platonic with some romantic undertones as nothing more lewd than handholding or hugging is shown (at least that I have seen in my 2 playthroughs so far).

As you play the game you will inevitably have accomplishments which are worth points at game end to make life the next time around easier. You can boost statistics, base relationship values with folks, boost fame, and get items for the next playthrough.

Like some other games in the genre, some of the "best" or possibly "true" endings are much easier to accomplish in your second playthrough with boosted statistics. There is some explanation on why the starting a new life narratively makes sense, but giving the specifics of why new game + is a thing in this setting would spoil the story. 

Current state, there are some typos, not enough to break the game, as the developer does not speak English natively. There are some bugs, that I ran into which caused me to need to restart the game. The developer has a discord and is actively working on fixing the reported bugs. 

I felt pretty good playing this game, I did not feel stressed out like I did in trying to get a good ending in Long Live the Queen. There are many endings you can get, and it is not the end of the world to get an average ending. Every playthrough can help you get achievements to boost your character in new game +. 

Oh, and the art is nice for the game. The seasonal changes in every single area of the game are nice.

Overall, highly recommend.

This game isn't bad at all.

But there are still a lot of bugs that should be fixed, 

1. If the Robot or the Kid ran out of the map, I can do nothing but restart the act.
2. I don't know what's the difference between the screw and the gear in the map? All these two items offer 1 screw.
3. Only 1 BGM in the whole game.
4. Act 3 and Act 4 are not available, even though I've finished Act 2.
5. The distance of each floating platform is far af.
6. I can not understand the story of this game. Why did the Kid got caught by...alien? Why did the kid know how to control the Robot, and what's the point?
7. The boss fight in Act 2 has an HP bug. I don't know how I triggered it. This bug needs to restart the whole game to fix.

Those are the problems I found so far.
I appreciate Josh giving me this game. 
But unfortunately, I can not recommend it until those problems are fixed.

I first played the original desktop dungeons way back in 2013, around the time it came out. I thought it was pretty neat, but I wasn't any good at it. Got completely stonewalled fairly early into the hard dungeons, then didn't think about it for almost a decade.

I returned to the original a few weeks ago, completely oblivious to the impending release of Rewind. Got much deeper into it this time, but that was more a matter of relying on guides than my own skill improving.

I mention all of this because it's more relevant to Rewind than you might imagine. In case you haven't learned this already, this is *not* a sequel. It's a soft remake, with easily the largest change being the new visual style. The rest of the changes are small enough that you can still use almost all of the same guides from the original to improve at this one.

That might sound disparaging, as if I'm suggesting that the changes are insignificant. But that's not quite right. The changes are small, yes. But in a game this complex, with this many intersecting components, small things can cast long shadows.

I'll admit I've somewhat lost my train of thought here. The end point I'm trying to make is that Rewind is a significant improvement over the original. I recommend it highly as a result.
Great game!

All in all as a person who 100%'d it on hardest... I'd give it two thumbs up. Solid story, Sylas isn't a 2D plank of wood personality wise so that's slick. The team that you a crew feels good. The game feels good. And you get a shitton of I frames on your dash and your Chain dash. The League Champ fights and boss fights were rough but fair, and rather Loyal to the original counterparts. Obviously some moves that are a bit of liberties, but all in all you see each and every ability.

Story: 8/10 Suprisingly felt decently paced but not perfect. A bit of highs and lows. And respect for sylas following through on his word and not being a full on dick as I thought he might be. Actual improvements on some character's lore or at least giving a better taste of them, and general solid progression of the demacian story.

Gameplay: 8/10 Enemies a decent bit varied, but lacking in actual total numbers when you actually look at how many are there. BUT! Each encounter is carefully crafted to not be obnoxious, unfair, or impossible so I'll take that trade off any day of the week instead of having the same enemy but color coded 6 different ways with the same attack but a different flavor. Most if not all casters are rather representative of their element and get bodied by the weakness element except for like... 2 three enemies off the top of my head? But that's primarily Nature Vs Wind being wonky as fuck and both having weird identities and executions for those two. But that's primarily through the spells you steal. Their enemies are rather solid, and none are too obnoxious. And those that are, are designed to have their face caved in easily or even pulled to you to cave their face in. You'll love your chain button by the end of the game mark my words. Though midgame felt a bit rough with how the progression system worked, still learning, and a bit of a pain in the ass that they introduce the ability to replay missions halfway through the game. POST one of the bosses that felt like the biggest wall I've come across. Though I was on the hard difficulty so take that with a grain of salt if you don't want that. Kinda wish they did more with the thing that let you pick up spells for random buffs assigned to random spells so you had to kinda plan a bit on what you took. Though better to want more than to be sick of the mechanic.

Collectibles: 10/10 They aren't ass, the letters/notes are rather nice touches to in world though primarily views of the citizens. Though a healthy few are fun nods to champions. Like how my favorite has a nod to Morg's baker skin where there's just a deadass real recipe for cookies near her hideout. And the silverwing chicks are decently cute as hell, and decorate your base once you get them. Also not obnoxious to find as if you keep an eye out you'll spot them and eventually be able to spot where they are. Though you will definitely have to do some Hall Wuggin' to get them all.

Sound: 9/10 Fuckin' mint. Plenty of VO and Sounds straight from League, but none of it felt out of place, and all characters felt pretty spot on. Music was exceptional, and not a tune felt out of place. Though the only thing not making it perfect is get ready to hear a lot of chain sound effects. Though admitedly, you should see that coming.

Bugs: 7/10 There were a healthy few that were later on in the game that weren't the worst though as of playing 1.0, the Fight with J4 and Shyv's 2nd Phase bugged out and their health bar showed empty for a while up until I just wailed on them to shift phase. The rest were primarily small visual bugs, and none that were absolutely negative.

Visuals: 9/10 Loved 'em. Everything was rather decently crisp. The design team did well by having a few colored pixels be decently expressive, and when zoomed into the portraits, they were decently expressive and spot on. The colors were flashy but not overwhelming. The design to seperate Sylas's projectiles from the enemies' was spot on with the darker colors.

All in all 8.5/10 pretty solid.

For fans of assymetrical games, this is a fun, and relatively simple one. You have a team of worms who try to devour a team of humans who are trying to start a train. They gather resources (fuel), find a train key, and blow up train cars blocking the rail. The unique part of this is that worms are blind. It is only when a human moves on the ground that they can be seen by the worm. This leave sitting still for a while a viable strategy, as is getting to a "safe" point (worms can destroy houses eventually though, so sitting in one while the worm knows you there isn't necessarily the best).

A strong point is that the game is very accessible and easy to learn. My group, which didn't play the tutorial before hopping in blind, figured most things out within a couple of games. Of course, the trade off is that it may not be as "deep" as things like SCP Secret Laboratory, but it isn't trying to be that type of game. This should be thought of more as a casual game you can play with friends at the drop of a hat.

The other strong point, I feel, is that both sides feel genuinely fun to play. I've played many asymmetric games where the only "fun" roll is the small "villain" role and where the "humans" or "good guys" roles are only a disappointment that you put up with. I didn't find that to be the case here. Humans have to regularly make decisions based on the worm, and it never feels like you are "out" unless you die a second time. Even if caught by the worm you can escape via minigame, which avoids the common pitfall of assymetric games where you say "yeah the villain's going to get me so what's the point of trying?"

Some additional details:

Humans do have some means to fight back against the worm in terms of:
1) Dynamite, which will make the worm receive a lot of damage
2) Escaping its clutches through a difficult timing minigame, which will very slightly damage it.

Damage only serves as a way of delaying a worm though. The "slight" damage forces them to find a pink orb underground before they can resurface, while if they take dynamite damage, they need to get several before they can surface.

When you have a group of new players, a single worm will be heavily favored even against 6 or 7, but as players get more experience, the optimal human to worm ratio will decrease. I recommend for a group of friends just starting to begin with only a single worm, and when the humans start winning safely, add more worms.

It is worth noting that 8 friends can play with a single purchase via the "demo" which is actually just for joining your friends for free. This is a great option to try things out with your gaming group and see how you like it.

TLDR: Avoid, you are paying to alpha test, still way off being early access. 

If I received a game in this state to review, normally I just wouldn't bother.

However as part of an agreement before being given a key, I agreed to produce coverage.

Developed by Dragonis Games, Eresys is 4-person Lovecraftian Co-Op game on Steam. 

"With its mysterious and cursed forest, horrifying entities, missions, and mind-bending puzzles, Eresys promises to deliver an immersive and thrilling experience for players who dare to venture into the Lovecraftian Universe."

In reality, it's an unplayable mess that is barely proof of concept and a very far cry from Early Access (which is what it has been released as).

Graphically the game looks okay...  until you try to move, or look in any direction. At  which point you just get graphical anomalies screen tearing unusual artifacts making it impossible to play let alone enjoy.

To be sure it wasn't just poor optimization, I dropped the resolution and settings way down but the issue persists. 

There seems to be a consensus around the quality of this game, as the are very few online players.

During my time playing the game for a review, I was unable to find a game to join or, when I hosted one, unable to find players to join me.

This game is VERY far from finished in it's current state, this is an alpha play test.

In my opinion, this should be a free sign up and not on any store front yet. 

At the moment it'sbin the very early stages of play testing and bug reports.

This this game is not ready for the marketplace yet and it's certainly far from even Early Access.

 I really do not agree with the practice of charging players to bug test alpha test nacent software.

The concept of the game is quite interesting, however, I fear it will never see success as any potential player base will be put off by its current state, never to return.

To me, this game's appeal is that it's charming, quirky, and uncommon. Restaurant-managing games where you can build your own place are so rare for some reason??? I've been playing it since its release two years ago and it's been a weird and fun rollercoaster. At one point, there was a whole casino part of the game with poker tables. At another point, there were cats to catch the rats that showed up when you ordered too many ingredients and the delivery guys put the excess on the floor. All of the waiters used to look identical and I was so confused, and you know what? I loved every weird second of it. It's the epitome of what being an Indie-game-enjoying person is all about. It has jazzy music, gentle/subtle sound effects, and the art style is just so loveable. The game has its flaws, but I can truly see the hard work that's gone into the game from beginning to launch.

In summary: If you're the type of person to giggle and spend time experimenting, this is for you.
If you're the type of person to get irritated and feel like your time has been wasted, this is not for you.

[h1] Review is split into two parts: first being people who want to know what's new/the difference from the first game, the second being more the actual Review [/h1]

[b] If you have NOT played the first game, then it is highly recommended you do so because of all the references and returning characters, along with a spoiler regarding the first game's ending[/b]

[b] New things/differences from the first game(skip this part if not interested) [/b]

[list]
    [*] Nothing carries over from the first game, and you have to unlock the recipes again. they do reference the first game a bit.
    [*] 2 new drink bases: Blue Pea and Hibiscus. a few more new recipes. for those who are planning on going into Endless mode and unlock them, there are I believe 3 that are locked behind the story, as in even if you have the right mixture it will not give you the drink until you have to make them. most if not all the old recipes are the same, but you will have to unlock them again.
    [*]Characters: there are three New main characters, Riona the banshee, Lucas the Satyr, and [spoiler] Amanada the Alien, "sister" to Neil. [/spoiler] there are a few other minor characters, but aside from a scene or two, aren't as big.
    [*]Returning characters: Everyone makes a reappearance to some degree. Jorgi has been expanded upon and is more than being "just there." Myrtle and Aqua could be considered minor characters given how they have their own storyline but it's a lot smaller comparatively. Freya only makes a single appearance near the end.
    [*] a pretty underutilized item giving mechanic, where when you give the drink you can offer an item to the patron. you can't give the wrong thing to the wrong person, but you if you forget to give someone something it can affect your hidden score and therefore endings. there isn't a whole lot of items, but some of the things may or may not be self explanatory on who you're supposed to give it to(e.g. you might have to give something to someone, but you give it to someone else related to them).
    [*]small changes that I don't feel like they need their own bullet point but should be mentioned: in Endless mode, you can now pick who to serve based on who you met now instead of just Freya. Achievements are somewhat spoiler-ly in that they outright tell you what to do to unlock them, such as serving specific drinks to unlock new songs. not sure if the previous game had these kinds of achievements, but there are a few which involve doing things like doing bad enough to make someone not come back to even getting the worst endings possible(good luck with that).
[/list]

[b] The Actual Review [/b]

The first game has a lot of charm to it. I recently played it again just to see what it was like in anticipation for the sequel.
If you are asking if this game delivers, I would say yes and no. the game is a lot like the first one, built upon it, like a 1.5, which is probably why it is titled Episode 2 instead of a straight up sequel. The story takes place about 3 years after the first one, and you end up catching up with everyone and seeing how things have changed. If you like the first game for the atmosphere and characters, then this game will definitely be something you'll enjoy. If you're looking for expansion on the game-play however, you'll probably be disappointed, as the game does very little to change it up. given it's a "don't fix what's not broke" approach, it makes sense, but still a fair warning. the good of the game is a lot of what the first game had, but it also is the downside of it as you're getting more of the same, just slightly expanded upon.

Story wise, it felt either too fast, or too slow at times. some moments will go by quickly, and you'll be wondering what happened, while other times it feels like they're dragging on a bit, exploring the world but given how you don't have as much direct input, it doesn't feel quite as impactful(stop forgetting your lighter Jorgi). Freya isn't around this time, so when the days are over, you'll be talking to yourself, and most of the time won't really have a moment to reflect on everything that happened. Still, you do get your happy endings, but some of the story weren't explored as much, such as with Aqua and Myrtle, so it isn't as impactful.

gameplay wise, it's the same, just with 2 new ingredients and an item giving mechanic that really is underutilized in my opinion. it does affect what endings you get, but honestly the items you get are a small selection and it's fairly easy to figure out the right item to give, and moreso of knowing who to give it to(hint: you sometimes give an item not to the person directly, but someone related to them). aside from the small changes, they aren't really as big to where the gameplay evolved, but given the kind of game it is, it's not as big of an issue. as for the length, it took me roughly less than 7 hours to beat(beaten within 2 days) not counting the reloading I had to do, so it is a short game if you know what to do or look up a guide.

I'm a fan of the this series, so I am slightly biased when i say I give this game a 8/10, given how long I've been wanting to play this. However, if your'e someone new, and only recently played the first one, this will probably be more of a 6 or 7/10.

Definitely recommended!

The most fun I had since MW 2019, this game has to survive. love the fast pace in the game I'm always finding enemies everywhere I go. the only problem I have is the spawn points I sometimes spawn behind a enemy that just started to move away from their spawn point with their 2 sec invincibility only to get killed from behind by me
The movement and gun control is so lenient I caught myself trying to wall run thinking it was Titanfall 2.

As of right now, I wouldn't recommend this game, but I will probably update it after new changes come in.

Some things to note:
- There isn't a breakdown of why stability is low. I would prefer if there is a menu where it says something like: "this city has low stability because such and such."
- Political power does nothing at the moment
- You don't get a breakdown of how much resources are being produced. If I build a bakery or a farm, I want to know how much wheat is being produced per day or week.
- Diplomacy is too simple at the moment. There is no option to join an a war an ally is in. You also can't call in an ally to your war.
- This is a personal preference, but there isn't a good way to optimize production of resources. You can select the option to send resources weekly to a city, but you'd have to do it for every single city. Maybe an option where it just sorts resources by itself would be better.

In conclusion, this game can definitely become one of my favorites, but it isn't there yet. Maybe when it gets out of early access. I just hope it doesn't get abandoned like Freeman.

A great successor to a game that I enjoyed playing a while ago. The new movement abilities were fun to play with and works fairly well with other mechanics, mainly the magnetic stuff. The map seems to be larger too, adding more things to do overall in gameplay.

The puzzle part of the platforming is still decent but seems to be less of a focus then the original or is at least easier in that aspect. The focus seems to be more on the platforming side of puzzle platformers, since the new upgrades and changes focus on it more. Only other complaint of something specific would be that the boss before you get your last upgrade was too simple and could easily be beaten in less than 10 seconds, making it pointless to even have gameplay wise. 

overall I would say the game is worth the $20 it's asking for and you should definitely check out the original if you haven't already.

This game is great but there a lot of QOL issues that break immersion, here are my issues.....

#1 Identity

This game is advertised as a rouge-like but it also has the most half-4ssed rhythm aspect that I have ever seen. Basically every 4 beats if you hit on-beat your 2nd attack does a little more damage... and that's the entire rhythm aspect of the game and because of this the game has awful repetitive music to keep you on beat. As a result of this there is also an beat indicator that is very hard to see and makes it hard to play and look at the same time and because every beat sounds the same you have to look at it, it really ruins the experience.

-I feel like they should completely remove this feature add better music and just add a cool-down instead

#2 English dub 

its clearly an AI which is not bad but its done horribly, Its almost like they fed a Language model every anime girl dub to ever exist and then tossed a Chinese and a Australian person in there for good measure and it ruined everything. (it sounds like a Chinese person speaking Engrish-Australian sometimes)

#3 Grammar

I have no clue what I am reading sometimes

#4 video settings

-No anti-aliasing

-If you set the game to windowed mode you cant move the window around and its stuck in 
the center of your monitor 
(whats the point then????) 

-Display mode does not work properly, border-less and windowed get each other mixed up 
sometimes.

-No proper window scaling it is a fixed 16:9 

-Graphics quality appears to do absolutely nothing





Conclusion: I will come back when it is more polished :)

Overall, I really enjoy this game. If you liked My Life as a Teenage Exocolonist or Long Live the Queen you'll probably have a good time with this. It has a lot of content, I'd say I like it more that Long Live the Queen. Not nearly as much as My Life as a Teenage Exocolonist for a few reasons. There are several problems that you may or may not be able to overlook.

Most noticeably, the translations are CRUNCHY. It's not really a problem for most of the game, you can pretty easily get the gist of what was meant. Once you get in to later story stuff for the true ending it gets pretty difficult to understand, to the point that I'm wondering if there are some sequence breaks I found accidentally.

There are also two pretty severe and consistent game breaking bugs. First and foremost are the gift letters you receive. These will lock the game up every single time you try to open one. Fortunately they aren't really a necessary part of the game, they're mostly for flavor. Second is a save data corruption bug that can happen if you have cloud saves enabled. As of the version I'm playing (1.00.00 I think) the devs even have it in the announcements with instructions for how to turn off cloud saves. There are also a number of other bugs that are less consistent, e.g. I once had to force quit when I got stuck in the horse capturing event.

Feels like we have a gem of a game forming. but right now we are in the infancy of this game. I cannot imagine how many hours of this game I would play if they do a throughout job on this game. Think of Mount and Blade but with guns.

There is still a lot to be desired, but just with the bare bones this game has to offer it's already worth putting some hours in to it. It's a challenging game but not over punishing. The mechanics are simple are enough, but enjoyable and have enough depth. I would love to see some quality of life added to logistics, and inventory urgently.

But overall, I happy with the systems they have implemented and excited to see what they add, they are really creating a solid foundation.

I would recommend buying since it's already fun to play, and do get your $30 worth already, and I would love to see what this project could do with more funding.

The game is annoying and not as "deep" as it wants you to believe. Worst thing of all though is how you can just be doomed by a certain class pick and have no realistic way to complete the run because the random boss counters the class you picked.

Also they absolutely ruined the game by tying the puzzle challenges to progression. The old version where you could just progress by doing dungeons was much better. The new kingdom stuff is terrible. The gold management, banking limits, weird overworld dungeon progression, tons of random messages you have to click multiple times to get rid of, kingdom item management... none of it is wanted. Should have just focused on the core game and not all the kingdom nonsense.

It seems they expect you to already know plenty about the game. Gods' preferences are not recorded for seeing later. You can't see what building upgrades will give you before you buy them. At one point I completed a set of puzzles and never got the reward. The game never mentions anything about saving so I assumed it automatically saved as I went as many games do nowadays. Unfortunately dungeon runs are not saved when you close the game so I lost all my progress in the middle of an adventure. I like the game, but I wish it would communicate better with me, and I played a good deal of the original; the experience should be worse for new players.

Honest Reviews

Pros
1) The 2d visual & soundtracks are great.
2) Figuring out what the right card to use on each event/fight is fun (the first time around). 
    For example, Giving away a herb or an upside-down herb will result in a different out come.
    Using water card to interupt enemy fire spell. Using fire card on the Fool when he is drinking to set him on fire.
3) Eventhough it has no major effect on the gameplay I like how each children has their own unique characteristic & 
     interactions.
4) Base Upgrade Feature (in which doesn't last very long...)
    
Cons
Despite having some fun mechanics such as parry & elemental counterplay, the core gameplay end up being just spamming attack & heal cards ez win. I actually don't mind a game being too easy but the lack of new enemy variety & event make later runs kinda dull. For example, the Whale, Oarfish & Jellyfish all share the same attack pattern despite looking completly different.

So, I've played for nearly 4 hours so far last night and I am loving the new stuff. I enjoyed my cup of tea with it and realized I need snackies too. :( also very hangry - don't play at night if you are craving certain drinks and snackies to go with. xDD (also will there be a 3rd one but with snackies?) 10/10 still an awesome game, excellent soundtrack, visuals and it's like we've never left our favourite customers.

Stop leaving false information on reviews about the game being Pay To Win. Currently there is no Pay to Win mechanic in the game. Buying any of the packs grants you the same gameplay experience. Buying the Ultimate pack will only grant you 2-3 additional racers which you can also buy shards for from the shop when they become available. None of the come fully upgraded or something, everything level 1. 

The additional currency received from the pack? Sure is good to burn it all on the lootboxes like an idiot to get that extra shard you need. But you can also wait for the shards to become available in shops. The additional tokens for the boxes? Is it really pay to win if you open 3 extra boxes? 

Stop with the pay to win crap because this is not the case, the game does not require you any additional payments after you bough the game, you can't buy currency with real money, you just grind it like a normal person. But you open lootboxes for that extra shard because you want to upgrade NOW instead of waiting for an event that gives shards or to become available in the shop. 

Maybe you think there are few racers now, but the roster grows with every season (same with the tracks) The sense of speed is not enough? Come into a multiplayer race with me, I'll bash and stun you so fast, you will pray to the devs to make the game slower xD.

The Call of Duty: Modern Warfare released in 2019 was a huge success, not only is it still regarded by many as the best Call of Duty game in recent years, but it also attracted many game developers to create similar games in order to replicate its success. Combat Master is such a mobile game that has been ported over, With almost the same UI and gameplay as Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019), it has been able to gain a lot of praise from players. In addition to its own uniqueness, the phenomenon behind it is really worth reflecting on.

The stiff and strange movements, the simplistic game interface, the endless bugs and optimization issues, the rough game modeling, the mediocre sound effects of gunfire, and the numerous Bots in the game all make Combat Master a game that is only passable on mobile platforms, but difficult to reach a passing grade on PC. This is also why many players question why this game still has positive reviews.

Understanding the failures of the Call of Duty series in recent years is the key to understanding the success of Combat Master. Since the 2019 release of Call of Duty: Modern Warfare, player reviews for its sequels, Call of Duty: Black Ops - Cold War and Call of Duty: Vanguard, have gradually declined. The poor performance of Call of Duty: Modern Warfare II in 2022 has pushed player dissatisfaction to its peak, as the reduction in mobility and the tactical realism in essence violated what most players crave in Call Of Duty. Combat Master simply relies on its highly flexible mobility similar to that of Titanfall and its exciting gameplay experience, which is enough to win players' hearts.

Of course, there are still many issues with Combat Master today, whether it's the lack of human players in matches or the unfair competition caused by PC players being matched with mobile players. This is somewhat similar to the situation where Ravenfield began to be favored by players after Battlefield 2042 failed, and I personally think this is a sociological problem. As a free game,  many Call of Duty players who have never tried the Call of Duty: Modern Warfare (2019) can find the long-lost happiness in this game - regardless of the level, they are often able to dominate the game. but how long this game can survive is a huge question - whether it's considering future legal disputes or the game's user base.

I am pleasantly surprised by this game, which is unlike anything in particular that I have played, but combines the genre of strategies and shooters. It's similar to Mount & Blade, but in a modern setting. I have to say, this game is being negatively reviewed for little to no reason. This is an incredibly fun and charming action strategy game with only minor issues that prevent it from being a great game. I think this is a very good game regardless of any flaws, and a lot of fun overall.

Let me start by saying this, I played through the campaign in co-op, and had such a blast. The world is sprawling, beautiful and has plenty of things to do. On top of that, the map has some element of procedural generation, meaning no two maps will be exactly the same. The beauty of the large open world and the sprawling epic battles with hundreds of units feel absolutely awesome. The sound design is also particularly good, making you feel evermore present in this epic world. We finished it in 15 hours at our own leisure, something we found out that less than 15% of players have done at the time of reviewing this. I just find it baffling that so many people decided to

When you play this game, you will realize that this game doesn't excel past it's peers in either the action or strategy formats. I think this is the wrong lens to view this game through. It's the way that this game combines elements of both genres that feels great. This type of gameplay might have a niche audience, but for that niche, I think it's going to be absolutely awesome. 

In terms of strategy, this game offers a limited number of buildings and units to the player, however, what it does well, is it makes everything in the sandbox useful. Every unit has it's place and time to be used effectively. Every building is the same. 

When exploring the map, each point of interest is going to be an important factor in slowly stopping the Piglin hordes. You can find special golem units, special towers and extra resources for some crucial upgrades you will need to use back at homebase, the Well of Fate. There are a wealth of resources, and you will need these to slowly expand your arsenal as the piglins get evermore destructive. Some of the epic sieges took an hour to complete. 

Another thing you will notice about this game that I think differentiates it a little, is how much this game emphasises temporary structures. The game is about slowly expanding your battle lines and in the process you will lose plenty of buildings, all while slowly gaining ground. It's quite fast paced. In co-op, this works great as the game offers so many ways for players to work together, even while being on the opposite sides of the world. 

As for negatives, I didn't like the limited number of structures that could be built at the well of fates. While I understand the need to limit the number of units in the game, everything else should have been relatively unlimited in my opinion. On the flipside, with the structures offered, the current gameplay for the campaign felt well balanced. 

Another negative is the potentially stupid AI. Countless times the units miss the bridges you built and fall off. This wasn't too big of an issue, but a minor nuisance nonetheless. 

There were also minor bugs and some minor issues with the controls which can be a bit finicky at times. 

I think the biggest error for this game was the marketing. Frankly, most people had no idea what this game was even after the first 2-3 trailers. I had the benefit of listening to reviews before purchasing this product. I knew exactly what I was getting, and got exactly what the reviewers I listen to said I would get. I feel like the same can't be said for some others. I think people should take the negative reviews with a grain of salt and go and watch actual reviews for the game on Youtube before deciding if this game could be for them. 

Aside from this, had a really positive experience. Look forward to upping the difficulty before another run through the campaign.

A note saying they are dangerous does not make up for them being terrible.

I want to say I recommend this game, but there are so many bugs some of which game breaking. Can't read letters as there's no way to switch from the first letter in the stack or close the top window when you open them. Meaning you have to force quit the game. That's an entire feature of the game that not only doesn't work but literally breaks the game. Its also essentially auto save only. There is a save function, but when you load the game no matter where you saved you restart the entire day so you really can only save at the start of the day, where auto save saves your game already. To be fair the game tells you this when you save but if that was going to be the case the devs could have totally take the player save functionality out had the same result and fixed other bugs. If the player save feature is going to be there it should do something. Not sure if others had the issue, and at least this bug wasn't game breaking, but there is a stables race game bit to the game and it just doesn't function. You hover over the button to "Participate" and you can sit there and click all day but despite the button reacting visually to you hovering over and clicking it the button does nothing. Sometimes other clicks don't respond but if you wait a second and click again it suddenly works, and other times you click to read dialogue and it just skips two or three frames of dialogue or narrative and there's no way to go back so you just flat out miss it.
I feel like this could be a very good game especially for $10, but with all the bugs and some of them flat out game breaking along with sections/features of the game that just don't work at all this feels like a beta version or an early access game that you're paying for to do beta testing for free for the devs. Maybe there will be an update that fixes everything and I'll have to change this review, but until then I just can't recommend the game.

Other than that it seems to me like this game will have a strong position in its subgenre. It's a new and hidden gem that people just don't know about yet.

I LOVE MY DADDY!!!!

(Spoiler warning!)
Opening 
================================================================================================
My daughter was born on 23 April and named Jean. I must admit, this is truly a difficult start since early departure of my wife, but I must press on for the sake of our daughter, our dream. At her early age, we loved to went around town and tried everything we could do at that day. early morning activity was always go-to start for our plan. I knew, this wouldn‚Äôt lead to any further mastery in her future, nevertheless I wished she enjoyed everything that I could offer. 
As she growed up, she started to went around town and be a part of them. She truly one of the heart from the town, everyone is her friend. -heck, even i lost count, how many people has come to our house to see her (my guess is roughly 9, for romantic event). But it put ease on my mind since I got caught an unknown disease. At least, if it‚Äôs the will from the heaven to separate us on earth prematurely, she still had the town to rely on. But thanks to the heaven for he decided not to do so until the time.
My daughter wasn‚Äôt a champion but she was champion in my heart. She might not the best daughter in the world, but she‚Äôs the best for me and I hope the best for her. I‚Äôm proud of her, because she can be who she is and married to whom she loves.
Welp, actually, that‚Äôs my bad. I thought, it was better to had good term with his headmaster- Mr. Claude- so she wouldn‚Äôt have much trouble in school. Both of them took it too seriously, what a mess. At least, my advice, to cook first the ingredients, which come from her adventure, was a good idea. She becomes a good cooker and has her own restaurant.
And here I‚Äôm, on the first spring of this year without her, my wife reach home, which is truly a saving grace.
Also my transformation into a chicken is canceled, I don‚Äôt know why. I‚Äôm disappointed.
================================================================================================


Review
================================================================================================
(Disclaimer) This‚Äôs my first steam review. It‚Äôs worth to take note that my gaming history mostly in fps genre and/or something relate to world war 2 but recently, I want to expend my horizon. So, take my opinion with a grain of salt. No, a lot of them, not just a grain.
Volcano Princess is a rising-‚Äúdaughter‚Äù simulation with visual novel and rpg frame. The players are tasked to raise her daughter whatever they see suit for her. Your aim is her future career and fianc√© (and yes, you can make your daughter marry to other daughter, I tried this to avoid ‚Äúcucked‚Äù feeling but failing due to academic reason: pleasing the headmaster). How to do it? Raise those numbers, baby~. Each turn, the player has a number of action. It can be used to do activity and replenished in certain ways. To end turn, player ‚Äúplan‚Äù study activity for the daughter.
There‚Äôs a lot of arts, ton of them, and there‚Äôre good but due to the variety accessories, I find it‚Äôs insufficient and bothering. But this flaw is ignorable.
The voice is limited to just reaction such as laughing, thinking, etc. There‚Äôs no text reading.
The music is okay at bringing the mood, but I ignored it most of the time.
The rising elements (or the gameplay) is okay. Most of the time, the players raise her daughter through town interaction and planning system. I find this system is boring, due to repetitiveness, since most daughter actions are dictated by player options directly (not through father as mediator) and counted in numbers. I prefer to say it as lack of surprise element because it‚Äôs sureness (the authority of player and the honesty of numbers). % RNG isn‚Äôt the surprise element I mean, but the turning events base on choice like ‚ÄúDisco Elysium‚Äù (unfair comparison, but that‚Äôs the best I have). 
The story is niche, classic fantasy and a little bit of plot. I‚Äôm not sure how the plot turns out since somehow, I managed to avoid by achieve true ending. The good part is the light-warm interaction between char‚Äôs family. Other interactions are sometimes ambiguous due to translation, but still readable by putting few logics. Too bad, I couldn‚Äôt focus the story much (mostly I skimmed) because I feel uncomfortable with the UI. It‚Äôs my problem since I have encounter many similar UI and I couldn‚Äôt do much about my concentration.
The game itself is a little bit buggy. I couldn‚Äôt open the letter from friends (or I stuck with letter in opened position) and few times my games force close by itself, I‚Äôm not sure why.
Final verdict, I with reluctant to pick unrecommended but due to major recommended review, I decide so. I couldn‚Äôt recommend this game to past-self because my gaming history. Nevertheless, it still a good experience although at certain point, I want to bash my head to my keyboard so badly. I highly recommend this game to people that love raising-simulation, romance, and/or ‚Äúvisual novel‚Äù. If you‚Äôre a casual, I recommend you to wait for a while because the bug problem and translation issue.
================================================================================================

Could be a fun little trading game but right now it's got a lot of little annoyances which add up and make me not enjoy spending all that much time in it. 

Right off the start, the most basic thing such as zoom & pan isn't available and you have to unlock it. Fair I suppose, it's a game, it's gotta have challenges. So you unlock the brush which allows you to do that but now after every step/new candle it resets your view, and honestly the controls for it are really not that great. Just make them the same as they are in Trading View. Also after every step the slider on the left which determines your position size gets reset for no reason. There's also no way to change the time frame which is such a basic essential thing. There's no way to set position size based on a % and no way to set a stop loss or a take profit. No way to customize the chart and change candle/background colors. People trade in all kinds of different ways but it seems like the game is only catering to a specific type of trader. It's possible that some of these get resolved further down the line, I just couldn't be bothered to get that far. 

I'd be happy to change this to a positive review if some of these get resolved because I do think the game has lots of potential especially considering the lack of competition but right now it feels really bare bones and frustrating. Using an analogy, it feels more like an arcade racing game than a sim.

The game has the potential to be great.  The visuals are good, most of the gameplay is enjoyable (currently there is a decent amount of lag in certain races, which I assume will be fixed over time).  

[b] However, it is hard to pass the glaring problem that the game functions on a Pay-to-Win model.  I know their previous games work this way, but that's because they are phone games....I have no hope for the longevity of this game unless the Pay-to-Win problems are removed. [/b]

I've been playing this game on hard difficulty and I would not recommend trying it on that difficulty.

I'm gonna be getting into some spoilers so keep that in mind. But basically the dash mechanic and hit boxes for attacks can be infuriating when you're playing on a difficulty where 3 hits essentially equates to death. When I fight Sylas' nightmare it is extremely easy to accidentally dash off the edge, get teleported back to your spot and then get hit anyway. Likewise when you fight Garen again you sometimes just get hit from behind because of the hitbox. 

Another giant issue with this game is the lack of a skip option for cutscenes, you can speed up convos but that doesn't change the fact when characters act out animations. This is extremely obnoxious when you're stuck at a boss and you're forced to just sit through the same cutscene 10 times in a row. The fact that the devs didn't include a skip option is kind of ridiculous as that's pretty customary at this point of modern games.

Let me start out by saying, that I do really love the game.  It has great potential, but as it is now just leaves you very frustrated. It takes to long to get enough samples to write the patents that you need to hire the right amount of staff. Once the invaders start you are quickly overwhelmed, unless you destroy all the generators before they do and rebuild.  You can't revisit planets.  So you end up running out of money very quickly, so so your people quit or are knocked out and die from the invaders.
It just leaves you very frustrated,  I would like to be able to get farther in the game, but at this point you can only do it with a skeleton crew, and by destroy and rebuild every time invaders come, if you have enough money.

What can I say about this product, that is not immediately obvious?
That it is made with love and care? That whoever sees the store page, does not have to wonder, who it was made for? Or that while  experimenting with all the settings available, you are suddenly struck by the amount of work that must have gone into making it as easy to use and as pretty, as possible?
It is a program for artists and lower limb enthusiasts alike. If you need a specific pose from some detailed feet for a project, or just enjoy the sight of perfectly manicured toenails reflecting lights, while toes curl and skin stretches, this is the program for you!
The amount of customization and freedom offered in it, are second to none. Whatever pose, whatever lighting conditions, whatever level of subsurface scattering your heart desires, shall be yours to look at.
And it runs perfectly on steam deck.

The game is OK, but it needs some serious balancing.  Everything is based on research, but it ends up being a big series of gates. For example, someone has a broken bone. They need a need "a [Icon of medicine bottle] in a mattress".  So, do you need to take a bottle of medicine and wrap it in a mattress? No.  If you go and look at the research tree, you see that down the list there is medical treatment that gives you a mattress.  Oh, OK. Let me make the mattress. 

However, before I can research the medical skill, I have to research making bars (places where you drink, not metal rods).  So I guess it makes sense. You make bars and then need medical services after a rough night at the bar. Let's get that out of the way. Oh, I need 8 cooked fish.  ??? To research bars I need 8 cooked fish. OK, so let me make 8 cooked fish.  OK, so waiting on the NPCs to do it takes forever.  Meanwhile I'm not sure if the person in pain is going to die or leave or what.  

Finally, finished with 8 cooked fish I got before anyone could eat them.  Research.  OK, good to go. Let's get medical.  Oh, I need to steel or iron nuggets? I have to build a scuba shed. Oh, I need to research that... 

People aren't happy.  Well, I researched churches so I'll make one of those.  Oh, I need 15 bricks. I can only make one at a time, I can only assign one person to one forge so if I make more forges I need more free people to assign them to. In other words, it's a very long process that requires no skill or planning. It just straight out takes a long time to make 15 bricks.  Maybe the NPCs should just pray for the bricks or something.

The game isn't bad, it just feels like I'm running around all the time trying to make X amount of something to get through the next gate so that I can do it again.  I feel like I'm always trying to play catch up rather than planning my base/town and enjoying it.

There also seems to be only so many areas you can build in. I see that there's things like flying, but I don't have that yet - not sure how I get it. There's a sick bird but it says there's no options to do anything so I guess at some point I'm going to have to do something that allows me to heal him, but no idea what.

A penguin showed up at my dock, but since I have no zoologist and no idea how to get one, he just left. No idea when, or if, he'll come back or why I'd care.  For the love of god, won't somebody think of the penguins?

The idea is good, the game looks good, runs fine, and doesn't crash so there's no problem there. I just think there needs to be a clearer picture of what you need to do rather than bumping into unknowns and then trying to figure out what you need to do and then create 12 pairs of used underwear to upgrade to the laundry skill which lets research the dancing skill after getting 7 rotten fish so you can research the bubbly tea skill with 6 moldy stones so you can make a drink to make some guy happy. (Not really, but you get the idea).

I think it can/will be good and there's a demo so you can check it out yourself. In this case I think early access means that they need to polish up the game play rather than add features and get the bugs out of the engine, so there's a good chance this game will shape up to be something good, but for right now the game play seems a little tedious, random, and pointless.

The gameplay is like a mix of Mount & Blade, Total War & ARMA.  Sounds like a dream game on paper. It kinda reminds me of that game "Freemen: Guerilla Warfare" except better in every way imaginable. The graphics are brilliant. I LOVE the ability to command battles via two different, interchangeable modes (First Person like Mount & Blade, or a birds eye, Tactical Mode like Total War). You can take control of individual units or command them all. As for the campaign, there is a full diplomacy system, the production/trading of goods & research trees. Aesthetically the world map looks and plays similar to Total War's campaign map, however everything's done in real time vs turn based. For your forces, Moving troops, replenishing units and properly equipping them all feels easily manageable. you can also customize the name of your battalions, as well as their appearance, weapons and equipment. 

There are some improvements I'm hoping we see throughout Early Access. When you choose a faction, there isn't any descriptions or stats; you're basically blindly picking one. Once you select a faction & load in, it then gives you a proper backstory of your selected faction; I just don't see why this wasn't added in the selection screen. The tutorial is just a Steam Guide, which leaves out a lot of important details. The game is still too new to find tips online, so without a proper tutorial (or a more detailed guide) you're often left a little lost. The game needs to give the player a little guidance at the start or else you'll sometimes ask yourself "What am I supposed to be doing right now?"

 The campaign could benefit from a mission system. Right now it feels like nothing really has a narrative to it. Long term goals, short term goals, more randomized events and more AI vs AI activity in the world would help this. It says you can create your own faction in the description of the game but I haven't found the ability to do that yet. Unless I'm missing something, they should really take that out until that feature is implemented. 

Overall, as a passionate fan of games like Mount & Blade, Total War & ARMA; I am really enjoying Total Conflict. It is impressive in its current state, and I'm excited to see its progress throughout Early Access. It has all the tools to become a staple in the genre as well as setting a new standard for blending different genres into one cohesive, core experience. Highly recommend it!

holymoly it has been some time since i played a game with the amount of garbage and clunkyness this one here has.

The graphics are quite good so far, but thats it.

The gameplay and movement mechanics are complete garbage.
The way they put a "simulation-layer" behind every basic sort of action like "grab a hanging coconut from a palm taking 40 minutes time + ~40% chance to injure yourself while doing it --> the wound you recieve as a result is not just a simple HP-drain but a status-ailment" lets you limbo in micro-management loops way to often.

For example: - difficulty setting: Hard

Your Character starts with 100 points which slowly drain during a day.
Hunting a whole chicken --> harvesting its meat --> ignite a fire on your campfire --> cook the meat --> eat the meat (all of it with a small to mediocre chance to suffer a wound) takes around 2-3 hourse meanwhile where your hunger depletes by a far greater value then this could balance out.

Even without that you would need 11 chicken or 35 coconuts (whole! and not the "green" ones, as they only quench your thirst!) to eat to go through the day.

What happens when you get injured while crafting/cooking/harvesting or else?? --> you need to mitigate the effect with another loop of "gather leafes to make a bandage (which could take you hours as the tend to appear extremely scarce) --> craft a firestarting tool, ignite a fire (which will fail quite often --> the amount of time (60 minutes!) is still spent!), craft a bandage --> apply the bandage...then notice that the bandage only heals 1-2 stacks of wound --> craft another bandage (takes 30 minutes and you need a burning fire to do so).

Meanwhile you beginn to become exhausted.
You will need to build a sleeping bag for which of course you need other materials.
The crafting takes 45 minutes, with a 14% chance to hurt yourself.
You cannot sleep, when you are hurt, hungry or thursty.
You cannot craft when you are sleepy.
You cannot make food, for which will need "crafting" when you are sleepy.

Everything in this game is so damn boring and pointless beyond the point of stupidity and lack of logic.

Why ffs. can't you take a damn stone and throw it up to a palm to gain a coconut?

I hope steam lets me refund this even with allmost 3 hours spent ingame.
