Great game for an early access game. Very few bugs, most were a pop up of a weapon stats that shows in the inventory, showing after a cutscene. but after opening the inventory it went away. Didn't always happen either.
31 hours of play and exploring and finally beating the story.

Gameplay: Souls like combat, God of War style world where you have to come back after getting skills to get to spots left unexplored. Different degrees of difficulty. Bosses were good and unforgiving at times.

Weapons: Each weapon in the game plays differently, and there are 30 weapons. Some are slow and heavy hitting, some are fast and agile. Each unlocks with finding a blueprint. some after leveling up. Mastering each weapon lets you learn 1-2 passive skills that make you stronger, more HP, etc.

Armor: is the same as weapons. lots of blueprints to find. There are the main armor, shoulder and helms. each with a different look and varying armor and energy effective levels.

World: the world has varying landscapes from green forest to snowy mountains to caves. the enemies in each area have a fun mechanic. when you clear out an area of Beasts for example, the next time you come back, it might have been settled by some soldiers that made camp there, with buildings and such. clear those soldiers and the next time the camp is kind of destroyed and beasts or other wildlife may have moved in again. so the same type of enemies are not always in the same places. Enemies do not automatically respawn when activating a life tree spawn point. they will after leaving the area far enough and coming back.

Overall a great game with lots of fun, 31 hours into it for $27? definitely worth it.

Despite its enchanting setting and captivating storyline, Stray Blade does have a few technical issues that need to be addressed. 


While the game's art and level design are both impressive and beautiful, there are a few bugs and glitches that detract from the overall experience. 


The main issues revolve around the camera. The camera lock on seems to flick randomly between enemies you're currently attacking and others that are patrolling in the distance currently unaware of your presence. You can turn this option off in the settings, but even then frequent and random camera resets take you out of the action and make combat difficult; especially when fighting multiple enemies.


It basically becomes more luck than timed parries and dodges.


The game's dodge, parry, and roll mechanics are a bit sluggish and imprecise, which can make combat feel clunky, floaty and unsatisfying at times. Overall it just doesn't feel as responsive and polished as say a genuine soul's game.


There are some nice execution cinematics but there are also some pretty rubbish ones it can get a little repetitive as can the final narrative of the enemies. A seemingly Greta Thunberg inspired "how dare you!"  seems to play over and over again as you dispatch humanoid enemies. 



Despite these issues, Stray Blade still manages to offer a very immersive gaming experience in the soulslike vein. 



Stray Blade has plenty of loot but not in the traditional sense of these types of games. As enemies are killed they will drop varying levels of materials needed for the games very comprehensive crafting system. 


The different variety of weaponry on offer give you plenty of opportunities to customize your character and create a truly unique gameplay experience. With three Acrean metals to master, you'll have plenty of challenges to keep you engaged and entertained.


Overall, Stray Blade has the potential to be a truly amazing ARPG. With its colorful fantasy setting, engaging storyline, and innovative crafting system, it's an easy recommend . 


While the game may still have a few teething issues that need to be addressed, there's no denying that it's a thrilling and engaging gaming experience that's sure to keep you coming back for more.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

[h1]My First Impressions After 17 Minutes of Gameplay! [/h1]

Hmph, only 17 minutes of playtime for Desktop Dungeons? As a transformer, I know that's plenty of time to form an opinion on this game. After all, I'm far smarter than any puny human.

Let's talk about the gameplay. The concept of randomly generated dungeons is intriguing, and I appreciate the turn-based strategy mechanics. The retro-style graphics may seem outdated to some, but I find them charming in a nostalgic way. The game's soundtrack could use a bit more variety, but it's still enjoyable.

Overall, I give Desktop Dungeons [b]7/10[/b]. It's a solid indie game that's worth checking out, especially for fans of classic dungeon crawlers. But let's be real, it's no Transformers: Devastation. That game was a masterpiece. [h1]DECEPTICONS FOREVER[/h1].

This game is hard. I'll say it again for the people in the back, THIS GAME IS *HARD*.

If you like games that have a hint button, or a little sparkle after 10 seconds to point you in the right direction...

This is NOT that game.

This is FUN but challenging and brutal roguelike/roguelite. This game will give you some cheeky text, some cryptic hints, and a very very quick tutorial. But it does NONE of these things while holding your hand and telling you it will be alright. You will gain things from and between dungeon runs that carry over and make the next run just a teeny (teeny tiny) bit more doable. 

For a game from 2011, it reminds me of some great Popcap games, like the original PvZ, while having much more complex depth and endless puzzles. People saying it's not really a dungeon crawler, it's just a puzzle game hiding... This is a true-blue roguelike, not some quirky spin on the genre. It's turn-based tactics and every dungeon is randomly spawned so you never know what you're going to get to aid you. Or murder you. Not every dungeon can be beat *with what you have right now in this run*, and that's the random nature of it. Not every spell or item spawns in every run. It would have greatly benefited from a combat log, it's absence is very strange for a roguelike, but alas, it doesn't have it, so sometimes you're left staring at an abruptly-ended run wondering how that monster just killed you when you thought you were perfectly healthy, and there's no good way to figure out why except to think real hard before clicking out. 

Actually one of the nicest gifts from the devs is that the monsters don't move around. Everyone would lose a lot more runs if these monsters chased you down, too.

For some perspective, I play a lot of roguelikes, I think I'm decent at puzzles. After 50 hours, I've only unlocked 8 out of 16 classes, 6 out of 7 races, and a fraction of the building upgrades. Every class and race has it's own mechanics, some are familiar and intuitive, others are tricky and it's only after a few runs and the right glyph (spell) on the board that you realize how *good* they are. Sometimes you find random rooms in a dungeon and these are definitely puzzles, and you may not figure it out this time. At least one of your attempts to figure it out might kill you. Puzzles inside puzzles.

There are lots of mechanics at play. There are lots of tricky, clever ways to combine tactics. Over a few losses you will learn them. Over many you might someday master them. Either way, you will die a lot. And it will feel really good when you win. If you really like roguelikes, original genre/style roguelikes, this is one of the best I've played.

Stray Blade was definitely a game I looked forward to getting after seeing an early access review of it. However after playing  it for awhile I realized how hard this game really is. If your expecting a soul-like well it might play out more like Bloodborne, Ashen, or For Honor. (I chose the standard Adventurer Difficulty for this review)

First off with graphics and design. The landscape is quite beautiful, its got a magical fantasyland feel to it. It looks like playing an old PlayStation game like Jack and Daxter or Fable. As Far as I know The map has some backtracking for secrets and unlockable shortcuts, potentially unlockable fast travel later on. They give you some parkour to the level design allowing you to climb various cliffs and find hidden secrets just like how Ashen is. The lore is fairly decent too and has a logbook so you can pick up books or tablets and read them later if you want to focus on adventuring.

The ambient music is pretty decent but the battle theme is the same for about every fight and is a little over-the-top and overused I'd say. The Voice acting however is pretty good With likeable characters and comedic value. It doesn't skimp out on dialogue using voice lines only for cutscenes and then giving you word box to read the rest yourself like so many other games do. This game is fully voiced all the way. Your own character, Male or Female is fully voiced too so your not just another voiceless character with no personality. You sound like a seasoned adventurer who's just a little confused on where you are and whats your purpose in the story.

There's plenty of character customization, armor and a vast array of weapons as you can tell from the skill tree. You can change you pigment color on your armor and weapons as well and find colors in the world. the skill tree is mostly just passive buffs to your overall character and using various weapons offers new unlockable passives that you can use when you try out other weapons. That way your not forced to stick with one weapon type the whole game and incentivises you try new things without feeling your points are invested in just one weapon type. The gear you get is entirely crafted from materials you find and using blueprints dropped from enemies or chests. Unfortunatly no pre-crafted gear for you to just pick up and use on the go. The major flaw I feel with this system is crafting stations are placed thick in enemy camps and you have to fight a bunch of enemies just to use them rather than being near a checkpoint. Enemies will also drop loot bags requiring manual pickup but sometimes they'll drop the bag in a glitched or likely lethal pitfall forfeiting whatever goodies they might have had.

However the biggest reason your here is how good or bad the combat is and oh boy let me tell you. First off the combat is heavily reliant on parrys or dodges with some weapons being able to block. Enemies will telegraph an attack with a blue flash if an attack is parryable or red if it isn't and meant to be dodged and blocking can sometimes affect both. The color flashing usually tells you ahead of time and not exactly when the attack lands. Successfully parry an attack and strike back once or sometimes twice but if you attack first you will most likely be counter-attacked for a chunk of damage and you will stagger.

The problem with the combat is almost every attack requires you to wait for something parryable or dodgeable.  The enemies have a poise bar which if taken damage in quick succession and fully depleted offers an instant kill. However enemies almost never flinch or stagger after being hit once or twice and you'll be punished for spamming trying to get them to, but you will stagger for EVERY hit yourself. The other problem is parryable attacks are often too slow to react and unparryable attacks hit you almost instantly which to me if an attack isn't parryable the attack should be slow so you have the time to dodge and faster attacks swing lighter and should be parryable. An enemy type such as a spearman is an example of this flaw and are generally harder than other enemies. It really feels like a dark souls moment where you couldn't get the timing right and just gave up trying to parry altogether but thats the whole premise of this game. You could also just dodge to counteract this but the game doesn't offer any iframes to dodges (as far as I can tell) and it tries to trick you into perfect dodging closer to an enemy to restore stamina. however enemies attacks will sometimes auto-lock to your position when you dodge and hit you anyway. On top of all that enemies will often gang bang you in groups of two or more giving you little breathing room rather than one on one fights which the combat is entirely designed around. 

I'm not going hit this game too hard with my rating as likely much of these problems will likely be changed over time as this game was released not too long ago. Bugs and Balancing will come with time as I really want to make a full playthrough of this game. Most people didn't like or play Ashen because the combat was really jank but the Landscape, Characters and Atmosphere was well worth the time playing it. And I just know this game will likely have that great feeling too for those that give it a chance.

5.5/10 Love the Design but fix some of the jank.
Here are a list of bugs or problems for the Devs
Remove or add an option to toggle the screen position for the movement button. (it does make me a bit nauseous when i have to fight the camera when moving around)
Perhaps make smoother combat music that doesn't sound like every enemy is a boss fight.
Make loot bags spawn inbounds when an enemy is killed in a weird position ie. backstabs or finishers.
Place more smithies especially for the start of the game so we don't have to fight a whole camp just to find out we're missing one ingredient for a new piece of gear. (it probably keep people feeling a bit better too)
Make enemies attacks a little more telegraphable, mostly the human enemies are too slow or too fast and lower the damage for quicker attacks so its not just an instant punish so we can dodge out of the way.
Add a slight time gap in-between character sentences so it doesn't just jump from one line to the next instantly.

I was a little but hesitant to try this one. On one hand the visual style and combat looks fun, on the other it‚Äôs been released to mixed reviews. After deciding to give it a try, I can recommend this game, it‚Äôs really grown on me.

Visuals:
Love the art style, it‚Äôs got this El Dorado vibe that is really fun. Textures and lighting are on point and they leaned into the art style in a beneficial way.

Non-combat Gameplay:
Outside of combat the zones are what I would call ‚Äúopen area‚Äù; mostly straightforward but with avenues for exploration and collecting. At first glance the skill trees can be confusing because skills are gated behind weapon mastery, what if you don‚Äôt like a particular weapon? However, if you read the tutorial on skills you would find that upgrades apply to all weapons. The system emphasizes exploring other play styles but has enough freedom to let you choose what you like. Oh, and once you clear enemies from an area completely, they don‚Äôt respawn. You also don‚Äôt seem to loose anything on death.

Combat gameplay: 
This is what will make it or break it for some. The combat is very much focused on 1) Recognizing when to block and when to dodge 2) Learning attack patterns and 3) exploiting 1 and 2 to go ham on an enemy until they are staggered and can be executed. I found that once I really leaned into this combat system instead of treating it too much like a souls game, it was very enjoyable.

Performance:
This is where I think some improvements could be made. I‚Äôm running on a Ryzen 5 processor and 3080ti at 4K maxed settings and getting 30-40 fps. I can get a solid 60 if I drop the in game resolution scaling slider, but it feels like my system should be performing better. The AMD superes doesn‚Äôt seem to do anything and I‚Äôd like to see dlss. Other than that, no crashes or performance degradation.

Bugs and other:
I had one bug where I could no longer attack. I was able to resolve this by pausing and resuming play. Other than that, it think that the ui could be scaled a little better for playing on pc with a 4K tv.  Lastly, sometimes movement can be a little ‚Äújanky‚Äù, not sure what to point to other than sometimes it feels a little off

Conclusion: 
I‚Äôm really enjoying this game and the combination of art style, light hearted dialog, combat, and exploration. I like that the skill system encourages exploration, but seems to let you decide which play style you like. I look forward to future updates and content.

Eresys is a curious beast: It brings to the table mechanics taken from Asymmetrical PvP games (Like Evil Dead: The Game) and binds them to a 100% PvE environment. 

It can create moments of tension, but what's on offer here is slim pickings, at least atm. The real selling point - apart from the Eldritch Mythos themes - it's, well, the price itself. For a meager 8 euros you gain access to a title that offers a good amount of immersion and can be played by up to four (4) players - not bad value considering you can invest a couple evenings into getting everything done with your friends. Devs promise to enrich the experience, so by getting the game now you might actually be gaining access to more varied content in the future. 

If supporting small devs with a creative vision is your thing, and you dig some Lovecraftian action, this little Horror-themed trip my be for you. 

My In-Depth Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rqxQ_OZOg9Y

The elephant in the room here is the translation. It's Meh at best and outright gibberish at worst. 

There is a story and what I do understand is interesting. However, I get the feeling that there's a bunch of stuff I'm just missing? Unless you're meant to just piece things together from npc gossip. There's a few major plot points that I'm just not really sure what the relevance was but that might be because in my first playthrough, I didn't do any combat at all. 

Now, I know this review seems negative so far but here's why I still recommend this game: the mechanics. I really enjoy the combat mechanics. They took a hot moment for me to figure out but it was super satisfying when I did. The stat grinding is also something I really liked, and this IS a stat grinding game so if that's not something you're into, you're probably not going to enjoy this experience very much. The pretty graphics don't hurt either.

This might not be a perfect game but it's one that I liked enough to sink about 12 hours straight in a single day. My main complaint (besides the translation) is that I sure wish I knew which subject stats my lessons are leveling up.

I'll start with reasons not to buy first, then jump to reasons to buy afterwards.

The music is stock music taken from a sound library.

The art varies from very professional to quite bad, but you earn that good art. The bulk of your time is spent in really inconsistent play-dough looking characters and randomly one mode is pixel art.

The game was in no way designed for English letters. The translation is so bad, and some modes, like the aforementioned pixel art mode, take quite a lot of work to get to.

I feel kind of weird about some of the outfits you give to her, that provide necessary stat boosts.

The game is mostly menuing without animations. This is especially blatant in the very optional fighting sections of the game, where enemies have very simple silhouettes and pop in and out of existence.

Cutscenes with animation are very ugly. Kind of hard to tell what's actually going on in some cases, especially since they feature the primary conflict of the game very early on.

The good

You're going to need to finish quite a few playthroughs to get all the endings. My first time, my primary love interest turned into an eldrich horror that made my protagonist pass out and forget everything. Kind of an intense ending.

Lots of romance options for the MC, it's like Harvest Moon on fast forward.

Art can be very good when it wants to be, especially the ending, where judgy kid Rose tells you all about your failures.

Load times are very fast.

Lots of options for playthroughs.

It's... a game for people who want to play a game about raising a kid. It's not a game for everyone, and probably not a game that I'll revisit very often, but I played it and I don't necessarily regret it.

This is a good non-WWII wargame that comes close to being excellent, something that's rare outside of tabletop gaming.

Let's start with the negatives. The release feels a bit rushed, and the game would benefit from some polishing. For example, the main menu can be hard to navigate, and feedback on your actions is not always sufficient. You'll need to experiment or look things up online to fully understand the benefits of high ground or damage calculations. While the tutorial videos are well-made, they might not be enough. Additionally, there are some minor bugs, and I've encountered at least one that could be really frustrating in an online match.

However, these issues are not insurmountable, as the game's foundations are solid.

Now, onto the positives. The gameplay is excellent, and that's what matters most in this type of game. Unlike many wargames that rely on randomness, chaos in this game comes from the order system. At the start of each turn, both players prepare a list of orders, without any knowledge of their opponent's orders. This leads to some thrilling decision-making: should you focus on firing at a unit before it moves, or prioritize defense by changing your unit formation? The game is full of such tense moments, as some orders are cancelled if they cannot be carried out anymore.

The game also offers a good amount of content. While the unit variety isn't as extreme as in fantasy wargaming, there's enough to keep things interesting. Cavalry, artillery, and infantry all have unique roles, and there are different subtypes as well. Each nation has its own specialties, which makes playing as a French, Prussian, or Italian army feel unique.

The graphics are also pretty good, considering the non-WWII wargame market.

Something I liked is the voice acting. The developers chose people who actually speak the different languages to read the unit names, and it's a small but cool detail that adds to the immersion. Clicking on a French "L√©gion √âtrang√®re" unit and hearing it pronounced correctly in my language is a nice touch. Even clicking on an "EIN UND ZWANZIG ZENTIMETER KRUPP M√ñRSER" makes me smile every time.

While I'm not an expert on this period of history, the game's historical accuracy seems reasonable. The rules are designed for games to be played within a reasonable amount of time. This simplification, of course, means the game approximates the realities of battles, but the few battles I've played have already given me some memorable moments, like when my Cuirassiers saved the day or when my Bavarian Linen Infantry held a hill for so long, supporting my artillery against the French.

So, despite some issues, I think this game is great for turn-based wargaming enthusiasts looking for a non-WWII setting.

I have yet to finish Between so I may update this review after doing so, but after streaming 3 hours of the game I have a couple criticisms! First and foremost the game is wonderful, it's clear when playing through that it's translated from Russian but the vast majority of the text is well-translated and makes sense. The plot is scattered yet putting the pieces of the story together is half of the fun! 
My primary criticisms:
 - Certain in game interactions require being very close to the interaction in question so it's easy to get confused and miss things.
 - The motion blur is blinding, accompanied by the speed the character moves at it made me motionsick. At the moment I believe the only way to play the game is by turning it off at the very start. 
 - The camera movement is chunky, when walking out to the back of the map where all you can sea is the sea and distant mountains the camera moves smoothly so I'm uncertain if this is a rendering issue or something with my technology or an issue with the game. In tense moments like when trying to play against time in the Sleep Paralysis demon level having the chunky camera and difficulty turning quickly it stacks the odds against the player and can make the puzzle frustrating. 
 - Despite the missions in the journal and the ability to select them, there's a small lack of guidance. It's not necessarily a bad thing but being able to do anything in any order can make certain steps confusing or lead you to hit walls in progress when you need to figure out a different puzzle first to move forward. This is especially true in the hamster wheel puzzle where I didn't realize you could get inside until someone in chat suggested it, even then the chatter said they felt silly saying it and were shocked that was the solution. 
 - Chairs. Of all the items that can be interacted with that can get in the way the chairs are absolutely outrageous, they can clip through walls, block doorways, get underneath the player, and generally cause havoc. The physics on the chairs are reminiscent of something from a ragdoll simulator and in areas like the computer puzzle in the lab having to fight them to reach the computers is tiring. 
 
All of that being said, I still adored the experience! The puzzles are creative, the story is investing, and there's enough various things to do that when you do get stuck it's easy to swap tasks and give your mind a break. Here are the things I love most about the game
- I adore that the game lets you jump off the map. This is a minuscule detail but I was so happy when I realized, teleporting the character back in front of the house is far more interesting and fun than adding invisible walls and barriers!
 - The scenery of the ocean, the pictures, and all the little detailed items are wonderful. The small details like the useless post-it notes and the pretty sights are like little pieces of the developer left behind! They bring some character to the game and show the true level of effort and detail that was put in, after all most indie games are passion projects!
 - The unique design of the subconscious and how the "Dreamworld" of the mind behaves creates a truly investing environment. Some of the glitches or unpolished areas can be written off as the story taking place in one's mind!
 - The option to turn on the bone shine is a really helpful add-on, I have trouble seeing certain things and certain games and having something like that to select helps make the game that much more accessible! 
 - The atmosphere of the game in the lobby is a bit overwhelming, but after entering the game the atmosphere is for the most part an appropriate level and is wonderful! I felt my chest tighten during the night level and I nearly jumped out of my skin the first time I picked up a rabbit and it chattered at me. There are moments that make you feel confused, excited, conflicted, and terrified! This is by far my favorite aspect of the game and it's executed nearly perfectly. 
Overall the game lacks polish, the focus on adding things like telepathy and stuffed rabbit textures is wonderful but I believe more work needs to be done on the foundational features of the game before you're ready for adding things like that. A lot of the issues in the game just need a bit more coding or a couple rules and most of the issues will be solved! I really look forward to a patch release, after the little problems are taken care of I believe that Between will be a shining example of exploration puzzle games! It's really clear to me that this game has the heart and soul of the developers in it, I hope this review helps bring the game to even greater heights! Love, Isaiah.

First, this is an early-access version, and the devs are far from done with it, do not seek a finished product here.
Played over 30 hours over the years, this one is a unique take on what an RPG and life sim could be.
Archmage Rises manages to proceduraly generate a world that makes sense, has history, and people (also monsters) doing their own thing.
You can interact with any NPC, do almost whatever you want if you're willing to get the required equipment/spells/skills.
The sandbox is strong with this one but there are still quests, stories to make you want to push further.
Traveling and dungeon crawling both use a different turn-based systems that would fit right in a TTRPG : intuitive and simple but allowing a lot of things to happen (won't spoil anything).
Combat isn't fully grown yet but the youngling shows promesses :)
To the adventuring ones seeking something new in the video game industry, get it now.
To the picky ones who want "the full sh@$", get it now and wait a few weeks/months.

I like this game, I really do. However, I am forced to give it negative rating. I am more than happy to change it to positive as soon as Microsoft, Mojang or whoever is responsible for multiplayer/crossplay and server communication fixes their problem. Me and many other players experience issue where we see duplicated server of our friends running and we are unable to join them. And when finally after many attempts successfully connected, randomly disconnects. Please, fix this... it's really terrible issue for a game for 40 EUR.

My biggest problem right now is the structure limit. I know I'm not the only one. I don't think the game told me about it until I ran into the "Too many structures" error. The thing is, like some others, I made triple layers walls so that the enemies have a hard time getting through. Apparently each individual wall counts as a structure. So, if you triple layers walls, you'll only be able to do that for a smaller area because you'll eventually run into the "structure limit" and you won't be able to place any towers or other defenses. I found this out 10 hours into the game and now I can't get a refund because I've played for more than 2 hours. Also, this is just one out of multiple other problems I've had with this game but this "Too many structures" error just did it for me. Hopefully, this one little review out of thousands of others will contribute to the devs fixing the problems so many people are running into.

The most authentic and immersive detective sim I've ever played 10/10

I've been waiting for a game like this all my life. Having an entire city to explore, brick by brick, street by street, you can explore every flat in every sky-scraper. Atmosphere is amazing, really cool Blade Runner vibes. Interface is super friendly and the quality over-all is better than most early access versions of other games. Small bugs/glitches here and there, nothing game-breaking/disturbing so far. Collecting clues is awesome, phone numbers, addresses, names, fingerprints, work hours, every piece of information you can find and solve different cases. Thank you, devs, really really well done!

This game is so ambitious and I love it! The developers have given us detective fans an amazing game concept and the execution is definitely here. The random generated cities, graphics, game play mechanics and ambience is brilliant and you really feel like you're a nobody detective in this gigantic new city. 

Issues/Improvements Needed:

- Stability: Stability could be better, with constant frame tears as I re-enter the city from a building and other things that will no doubt be fixed at full launch.
- People difficulty: Investigating is a slight issue as when I was interviewing people I needed to, they gave me nothing and constantly upped the price for the information to where I no longer had the amount they needed. This left me to a dead end and although I somewhat enjoy the no hand-holding approach, it may be frustrating to others who have no idea where to go next.
- More interactions in the environment: for example, I couldn't get into a glass door to an office where a victim worked (it was out of hours) and I thought I could just hammer it's glass pane and crouch through but nope, it was indestructible, despite the window next to it being destructible but blocked by blinds. 
- Even more city variation: Self-explanatory, I would love even more tones and settings with suburban areas instead of just high rises and maybe more action in the cities like police arresting people and other things to make it even more alive.

Overall, an amazing game that will be regarded as the best detective game of the last few years with a few fixes and adjustments as well as some additions in terms of content.

Overall, Shadows of Doubt lays the groundwork for a game that one could get years of gameplay from. At launch, there are a few bugs (side jobs involving waiting on a payphone call don't read with the location, jobs asking that you speak with a staff member don't clarify WHERE the staff members work, and the option itself to ask seems to never be available) and things that mechanically could use a much more thorough explanation (like addiction, as an example). the first few hours of gameplay have been great and the murder investigations have been FANTASTIC.

The perfect game for detective immersion, the silence of the dead walls can give you chills from time to time. The game world is heavily based on personal freedom of choice. Finally i can liveout the expierience of the movie Se7en :)

Wonderful procedural detective game!

Fun detective game, huge potential but needs optimisation and more variety.

The game is entirely procedural and provides you with jobs that you can complete to earn money and social standing. Every now and then, you'll be informed of a murder which you can go ahead and solve, which is arguably the most fun part of the game.

Pros:
- Pretty voxel based game with great lighting.
- Fantastic city aesthetic which is great to look at
- The closest you'll get in a procedural game to feeling like a real detective
- Lots of options on how to tackle your objective via stealth, bashing down doors, hacking and more
- Following a case to completion is very satisfying!!!
- Can buy and decorate your own apartment with your hard-earned cash

Cons:
- Already repetitive after around 3 hours. Seeing the same jobs, notes, emails and clues dotted around.
- Limited NPC and world interaction. You can only ask the same generic questions with the same generic answers. They may all have their own lives but they all feel the same.
- Needs more variety in terms of cases and objectives. Let me figure out the motive, give me more dead ends. Add in some dynamic plot twists to the cases. (Perhaps I'm not far in enough to have seen these)
- Poorly optimised. It can take up to 5 seconds for the search box to register that I've typed something.
- Graphical glitches dotted around

I played the demo two or three times when it was out and it hooked me enough to buy the full game on day one. I've had fun already but I hope we see more variety and better optimisation in the future.

A great addition to the Riot Games roster. If you like fast paced pixel art games you will feel right at home.

The combat is simple but the game forces you to think in what order to kill enemies so you don't have to spam normal attacks when you got no one to steal spells from. Sadly it does not evolve too much during entire play time and does get a little stale and only new spells or stronger enemies liven it up a bit. Every mission/sidequest also plays out the same. While the levels are well done and combat areas are changing I felt that exploration did not yield the satisfaction I was expecting as you are only rewarded with some chests some collectibles and notes.

Spells lets you deck out your build and there are ample of shrines in each level to change them out, however I did not found myself using them too much or as much as I wanted, as gaining mana is a bit hard. Combined with high mana costs you end up hitting the enemy so much that it's not really worth using a spell anymore.
Moreover, some of the spells seem straight up useless, I never found myself using invisibility as it just did not had a use case. You also get way too many ultimates at the same time making so that you don't end up trying them out to the fullest, gaining them a bit more paced out through the game would of felt more rewarding.

Boss fights are incredible however I suggest not playing on hardest mode as the enemies and especially some of the bosses feel sort of spongy.

Great story line, bit of a shame we did not get voice acting that we did in Ruined King but there is not too much reading required and characters never talk about stuff you would not care about. Over all the story is great, and I as a person that kind of hated Sylas from his design to the way he talks in league of legends, or just playing against him (srsly tell me another ap champ that does one shot combos with 200ap), I turned to liking him, I think that the story built him up to be a very likable character. The side characters as well are not some one dimensional NPC's that have their own pasts, character traits and motivations. (If Yops does not get added to league in one way or another I will riot).

Encountered couple of bugs, such as not being able to hit enemies or not being able to target my chains, however this only happened once or twice so it is relatively a bug free experience.

As always like with any other Riot IP the music in this game just slaps. The final boss fight music was just insanely good. 

Over all I give this game 8/10. You can see that lots of work was put in this game from the art to the story. Can't wait to see what else Digital Sun will cook up and what other talented studio will be added to the Riot Forge Roster.

I didn't expect to fight as a T-Rex with a shadow clone against a skeleton king on the moon today, but here we are.

Good solid game, a bit short with 3 levels + 3 mini games at the moment. Really cool day/night mechanic, power ups like 20 Minutes Till Dawn / other similar games, and more of a beatemup rather than a bullethell. 

My main criticism is the game's a bit slow to start until you unlock the 3rd character (at which point you can do more than just roll around waiting for your passives to kill enemies) and rounds are a whole 20 minutes. Not too bad in 20 Minutes Till Dawn, Survivor.io, etc., but the minibosses arent really mini bosses. They're just a high health enemy where you don't need to vary your strategy at all. 

The final boss on the moon is the only one that got me to actually pay attention to it instead of just rolling around gathering health mushrooms until it died. Hopefully more levels and bosses are added like that one, where the orb attack makes you dodge in a specific pattern instead of just rolling away.

The price point is right and you'll get a few hours of fun out of it once you get going with unlocking different characters.

[i]Elena's Journal: To Atlantis[/i] is the second installment of the eponymous series and continues the adventures of Elena and her team of archeologists. While in the first game,  Elena managed not only to uncover the City of the Amazons through a successful expedition but also to find love on the way, the second game will have her embark on a mission to find the legendary city of Atlantis, while also trying to overcome the personal struggles caused by her relationship breaking apart. The games can be played independently of each other, but it's highly advisable to play [i]Unfinished Expedition[/i] before [i]To Atlantis[/i] because the story in the second game reveals many essential aspects of the plot of the first game. 

The gameplay is pretty much the same as in any other GameHouse game. As Elena or one of her friends, you will help their university students or fellow archeologists by fulfilling their requests, combining various ingredients into new items or handing over the objects they need, and then finally billing them at the checkout. As you progress throughout the game, the complexity of available items and combinations increases substantially and the number of people you need to handle simultaneously also grows, while the amount of items you can carry at once also expands.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2966842290
Since Elena travels with her friends all around the world, the locations are now more varied than in other GameHouse games. The first levels take place in some academic environments, followed by her team embarking on a ship towards Atlantis and reaching the dig site in its proximity. We even have some levels taking place in an imaginary world of Atlantis, and an alternate storyline in her mother‚Äôs caf√©. I love the diversity of the levels and the specific minigames that each of them brings (one type per location). Additionally, they were more enjoyable than in other games.

Perhaps the weakest aspect of the game lies in its narrative. While I usually greatly enjoy GameHouse stories, I felt like this one was missing a spark, or rather it didn‚Äôt manage to convey the fuzzy feelings that the other games do. The story jumps between timelines (present and past) and between reality and fantasy, which gives the narrative less coherence than usual. On top of that, the negative transformation of one of the main characters made me enjoy the story less, despite them having a final redemption arc (albeit fairly rushed). But as usual, the ending leaves one wanting more and opens the story to future chapters.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2966841701
In regards to the difficulty, I must admit that I did struggle a bit with the levels of one location, even on easy mode. I was still able to complete them on the first try but it required an increased focus level. The reason for that was the fact that there are dozens of orders for timed items (place the item in a furnace, then click after three seconds to pick it up otherwise it will be destroyed). While this mechanic is normally encountered only a few times per level, this time you have to literally spam-click them and create them back to back to be able to cover all the requests, while also moving around the level to fulfill all other orders and the main objective. It gets chaotic and quite stressful if one wants to satisfy all customers at five hearts, yet still doable with some extra focus. The rest of the locations have levels of average difficulty, with the ones from the second half of the game being much longer than the ones from the first half (there are more customers and more items), thus a tad more difficult.

As usual with Game House games, the majority of the achievements can be unlocked in one playthrough (which can be done on any difficulty mode). A few remaining achievements require you to replay certain levels multiple times to reach the number of orders needed for a specific item. The story takes around six to eight hours, and for 100% completion, you'll need to spend between an hour or two extra.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2966841667
Overall, [i]Elena's Journal: To Atlantis[/i] is a very decent game. The gameplay is as entertaining as always and the graphics are beautiful, with clear and big icons for the items. In some aspects, it has a weaker story than usual and some of the levels are above-averagely challenging.

While I'm still making my way through this title, this ultimately is a well done DRPG title that stays close to it's Wizardry-Inspired origins while also making quite a few Quality of Life improvements to the formula that help reduce the irritation one might feel against it.

Very addictive. It feels like the game balance will be improved eventually since it appears difficult to lose, if at all.

Very good and polish start. Everything made sense. The progression was very clear and figuring out everything took very little effort.

While the progression is polished, except for the end game, it does feel like more gates will be added to limit how quickly someone can research and progress. That might be needed as the game feels less like a game and more chill. Still incredibly fun.

Some complaints:

- buying the power station doesn't make sense. It provides 10 energy at the base but the setup and cost to keep it running is off the charts. It doesn't make sense to build it out.

- the deep appears bugged. The bots don't really manage the deep very well. It appears if you build them and stay in the deep, then they stay but will surface when you do and stay out of the deep and not manage it. It is possible that I need to pay attention to the priorities settings. However the priorities order may as well not exist as it is not per building or I could be misunderstanding. I didn't look at it too closely but it appears to be categories.

- there could be more quality of life improvements but honestly not really needed as it is almost impossible to fail. It would be nice to optimize like you can in other games, this appears like that Evil Genius game and suffers from similar problems. Except the workers don't get stuck like in Evil Genius 2. But they do mostly ignore the deep, so that could be a bug.

- cranes are limited. I get it. My machine is old AF and can't power the high settings. I was hoping to replace all of the workers with bots but that seems like it would not be feasible. This seems like it is balanced in that case because while you could throw a bunch of bots at everything, the game as it is now would be a really bad idea. Cranes also can't optimize much as they as slow and the amount you can have are super limited. I was hoping to fully automate the deep but that doesn't seem possible at the moment.

Conclusion:

- I was impressed. It does seem like they don't have lose conditions as you can't run out of any resource. The traders upgrade to including resources so as long as you have products, you can continue to progress.

- I beat it. I am going to wait a few months before jumping back into it. I did a few expeditions and I am looking forward to this later. I did everything you can do at the moment and loved every minute.
Surreal. Kickass.
Great game, excellent voice acting, incredible story. It did retraumatize me though so now I have to go to counseling again. Other than that, highly recommend it.

The best thing about this game is the combat system, it's so rewarding when you can parry and finish the foe. I love the fact that you can try so many new weapons with tons of personalization. I rarely get into single player games but this is my style! 

Not the best performance wise, I get some frame drops but usually not a big deal, I mean not in the middle of the fight but just when changing areas and I got an high end pc. I hope it will get better in the future.

I hope there will be some kind of arena or atleast NG plus but I doubt it, I would love some kind of replayability because the combat system is what makes me complete the game :)

I love this game; An easy favorite! 

This game offers some advanced combat that requires a great deal of attention. If your not good at that, it also has a very wide range of difficulty level. Anyone can play this, even if you never parry a single attack. I greatly love Farren West and Bojji as characters. The game requires players to spread out their weapon variety to gain more health, energy, or stronger attack damage by gaining 100% mastery over each weapon they forge. This is super cool, because you will love everything from the speedy swords, and heavy axes. I really hope it gets more added to the story.

Even for a Modern Warfare clone this game has no reason to slap as hard as it does. Some negative reviews say you can't play multiplayer online with friends, but you can play together in a custom game with bots (that you can change the difficulty of), and you still earn exp, battle pass progression and gun progression.

This needs to be in your library if you're an FPS fan, I'd happily pay for this, yet it's free.

I want to play as much as I can in case it quickly gets removed from Steam due to it's likeness to Modern Warfare, but if it doesn't, I also can't wait to see what additions it will have.

Give this at *least* another year.

i don't even know why i'm bothering to write such a long and critical review over a less than one dollar game, but i suppose the experience was frustrating enough to motivate me to
i'll talk about the controls and the player character first. there is no tutorial prompts, or even a way to check keybinds in the settings, or in game. while taken for granted, telling the player the have to hold RMB to aim the gun at the cursor, instead of firing in the direction your moving, is a very important thing. also, the player character feels sluggish in ways that do not feel, or play well, for example, trying to switch weapons. i know were not playing a Mr john call of duty, but it still feels excessively slow, especially when the mule is barreling down on me and i would like to pull out my shotgun to use for its intended purpose. this, coupled with the fact that the act of turning around and shooting takes time and does not feel responsive, means that you easily get put into situations of "pop a flare and hope the help comes from the direction your running into in time, because the moment your stamina runs out your dead" and along with that, the weapons feel ineffectual, even beyond the intended purpose. barring the very start, the pistol can't keep up with slowing the mule down, the AR, while effective, requires you to resupply off the dead infantry, and the shotgun feels inconsistent, to say the least, there are times where it will readily reduce the mules speed, but sometimes it just eats the hit with no reduction to their speed, leading to death
second, the collision on the environment is wonky at best, i find myself getting stuck in spots clearly past the branch in the way, or caught on corners i had no idea existed, and not much in terms of visual clues to tell either, unless i had gotten stuck there and most likely, died there before. and some spots you can wiggle through in you move in a particular way, and example being the well with the snack and ammo in the graveyard, once the coffins come up, you can't get in or out from the top way, unless you wiggle and walk in a particular way.
third, the actual mule(?) itself, with which i have issues and gripes. the former problem with map geometry seemingly does not apply to Willickers, i swear I've seen him get through gaps and spots that i myself would easily get stuck on. as for player readability, that is also an issue. while i can figure and assume the the mule's max speed and acceleration go up over time, any other factors are hard to tell. if i shoot it while its stopped and it rears up, did i just "enrage" it and make it gain a chunk of speed? Does shooting it cause it to get faster? it gets skinnier the more you blow it up with barrels and shoot at it, so maybe, who knows? and the magical child grab. i understand the reason for it, its to put pressure on the player and keep them on their twos if the mule is off screen, so they don't think they're safe merely because they have distance, but when it can do this from just off the edge of the screen, and then still come running in full speed, means there are times where you can just insta-lose, especially if approached from the top or bottom
and speaking of the camera, and information given, it is severely lacking in some ways. for example, having no idea the general direction, or speed at which they're approaching, is something that i think is important to tell the player, if your going to limit their visible FoV. along with that, knowing the direction that support is coming from would be a very important to know, especially if they're the only thing standing between you and an all expenses paid trip back to to start of the timer
on that subject, in my frustrated rush to simply "go next" on the next run and mashing space, i discovered a broken and seemingly nonfunctional UI to save, a feature that might've made all the former jank more tolerable, as at least then i could save after doing the initial looting phase, saving me the time and hassle of doing that every single time and letting me focus on routing and figuring out how the mule works
honestly, i still don't quite know why i bothered to write all this up when i could've just refunded this and been on with my day, but i guess i wanted to somewhat advise people on what await them inside

Even in Early Access, this game is a marvel. What it does with procedural generation is something most other games don‚Äôt even attempt. The open ended freedom in detective work is unparalleled. And to top it all off, it‚Äôs actually really fun!

There‚Äôs a few bugs here and there, but nothing that will truly crush you - it‚Äôs certainly already more solid than most AAA releases today. It‚Äôs already complete enough to buy and play all the way through as if it was a full release.

You can check out my full thoughts below, but in short - 100% yes, this game is well worth your time. I will be coming back to this game for years to come.

Great detective game. Still in EA, but very much playable. There are some things that are hard to understand but you won't have a experience like this in any other game,

So far the game has massive promise, easily one of the best detective games I've ever played. 

You really can enter every build and room, with there being hundreds of people populating the city your in.

There are some mild things I would hope are ironed out, the main one gameplay wise thats been bothering me and may just be my fualt is regarding matching fingerprints you find to a person along with other piecies of evidence to a person. I've found numerous items owned by x person with their finger prints on them but it seems unless I directly get their fingerprints off them It will never recognise that those prints are theirs.

There are some other mild gamplay things like that I would image will be addressed at some point. Otherwise  the only other sort of thing I can think of would be the lighting being dodgy at times and some bugs along with general iffy stability. Thats pretty common and expected of an early access title after all and its been out for less than a day so far so fair enough.

I would highly recommend the game its easily worth the price.

performance and gameplay is still rough around the edges but people buying this should already know exactly what they're getting into, and why they're here. so they can finally crawl within those walls, and open every door they come by which pseudo-open world games like GTA so shamelessly tease. but also, solving cases by your own methods without being railroaded through a predetermined detectives logic like those investigative shills Ace Attorney or LA frickin Noire. it's a game that subverses the mostly shallow spectacle of discovery that most games pass off and demands their honesty. i killed three people to solve the murder of one. and justifiably so because i got away with it

This game is an absolute gem and I've been waiting to try it for a few months now! I love the immersiveness and engagement the game provides and the little realistic elements like eating or sleeping aren't so annoying as one might think but are rather tools to move the story forward. It's really fun to explore murder scenes and connect new murders and figure out the culprit. Don't listen to the negative reviews that complain about the game being "too complicated". The game is simply not for them. [i]However, I can see where their complains are coming from if you'd read on...[/i]


Why so negative then? Very simple answer: performance and stability.
In this one game session of six hours so far I've encountered two full blown crashes (and there is no auto-save). The performance is also absolute dogshit in 60% of the time. Basically any time you're outside or inside a large hallway/ hub area you get a nice 15 to 20 frames slideshow (and that's on a 3060). The UI and user experience is also very lackluster in many places. An example would be opening pinned notes on the case board can open them behind the UI elements and makes it difficult to move around. Or how the strings connecting notes can disappear unexpectedly when you show/ hide unrelated strings (this might be intentional but then it's r*tarded by design). Dialogue is also rather buggy with one tenant repeating themselves three times about confirming that the victim is their neighbor. On the topic of dialogue, people are way too negative in the world. Nearly everyone you talk to want you out of the way with dialogue much like "None of your business". Just a little more reasoning behind their answers would be nice to hear.

Not a bug per say but for random jobs you pick up that tell you to find a breifcase for more information the photos can be many times incredibly poorly angled and you have to figure things out yourself. The size of the breifcase is also surprisingly tiny and very randomly placed in the location you're shown so finding it can be very difficult sometimes. Something to keep in mind.

If you're [i]extremely[/i] interested in the game and have been eyeing it for some time and you also have at least something like an RTX card or thereabout then I'd say go for it, the gameplay when it works is really great. However, if you've recently found the game or is on the fence about it, don't get it. Wait 'til stability is improved and so that performance is at least playable in the busy/ large areas. The game is in Early Access after all and it rightfully needs some more time in the oven.

Edit: After lowering from 4k to 1920x1080 the game actually runs completely fine on the 3060 and thanks to the game's voxel style the lower resolution is not noticeable (though I do really think that going to 4k should not make this game into a slideshow. Pretty sure the rendering is flawed and incredibly inefficient). However, these "good" news also come with some bad news. I believe my save file must've been corrupted and any time external footage needs to be taken or rendered, it would seem, the game hard crashes. It happens whenever I try taking any photo (tried multiple times) and it also happened when I attempted to view CCTV footage.

The best way to review this game is to just write down my experience playing

So I started by walking around the streets, before spotting a bar. I walked in and bought some vodka. 
I drunk the entire bottle before throwing it over someones head. The guy gets pissed and knocks me out. 
I wake up in a hospital bed, but they want me to pay the medical bills.
I refuse and get out of the bed and jump out the window, only to discover I am in a 5 story building and get get knocked out again.
I wake up in the same hospital and now they want me to pay even more money.

10/10 game
This game has a lot of potential please give support to the dev and give it a try
Amazing.

The premise is nice, the POTENTIAL is there and I love some mechanics. There's actually coherent procedural generation of the world. The amount of options to solve almost every case is rich and the world is very atmospheric. That's about it on the good parts.

Now, where shall I begin wih the red flags? The game is a buggy mess that lags even on RTX 3080/R7 5800X3D machine, but that's not the main problem, really.

UI/UX and navigation are atrocious, like a Dementor (yeah, read another book!) it sucks any sort of fun and enjoyment out of the game. There are no way to track clues on a map in a remotley predictable way. Clues managenent and reading through information about your victim is a puzzle by itself, more difficult than the most cases at hand. Look, when it's a huge problem to find your own apartment or almost anything relatable on the map, you have an issue. I do hope that the dev will hire someone to actually plan the damn UI, let alone draw one in a workable maner. 

UI scale on a 4K display is tiny, the interactive elements are either too hard to see or stand out too much. Inventory management is kinda ass and feels broken.

There are also tons of game-breakling bugs. Tutorial case can softlock you (like, a lot). 

What else? Well, I really thought that the scale of the city would be much bigger, but that's EA game for you. Right now it's 4 by 4 blocks, feels very cramped tbh. There is also stark lack of sounds, soundtrack (and music direction) and first-person animations.

At this point this game is more like a paid demo for a proof-of-concept. Some things do seem to function, but that's it. It's broken, boring and simply frustrating to navigate around almost every mechanic or concept here.

Wait for more polish, at least in the UI department.

90s fps but melee. The game looks ok, the atmosphere is great, the music is more ambiental and could use some more up beat tracks, at least for boss fights. The fights can get a bit hectic, thankfully the dash refills fast enough, so that you can get out and get your bearings and assess target priority.
At the moment, you can't rebind your keybinds, and there are no end level screens. The game is challenging, especially for people not used to old fps games, but thankfully if you die you respawn near and with full health.

A new indie first-person hack & slash game that (I think) aims to be one of those hard games. That, or I think the game has some balancing problems (or I'm a complete noob). I'm talking about the fact that is so hard to counter ranged enemies projectiles (or, again, I'm too noob). Though even if the game feels hard, every time you die you spawn back in the same place with the enemies that were left when you died, but with a few points deducted from you (every time you kill enemies or pick some coins or crystals you get points). This is another mechanic that I'm confused on. Why would I care if I die or not because it seems that I have enough points to keep coming back to life 100+ times. I also wanted to see more character upgrades or more weapons in the game. I've been playing for almost an hour and I found only some max HP increase. Eventually I've finished the game but I can't say that I had much fun. Either it's too hard for me or this game has problems.

Top notch game/OS feel!

WatanOS GUI is so polished that it feels like it can easily be its own linux distro. The mindbending puzzles can be tricky but are never unfair, the game gives you all the tools you need to solve them without needing the hints but if you get stumped the they do help a lot.

The only thing that I didn't like was that the horror elements are not super strong yet, but as an early access game I'm hoping that Watanoge expands more on it.

The game took me 1.5 hours to finish and I feel satisfied with the experience, definitely I'll keep an eye on this one.

This is not an easy game and it is fantastic!  A careful balance of resources is required while actively pursuing power and influence makes Archmage Rises a very interesting game to tackle.  But this game is brutal, and if you are going to be throwing your toys about permadeath, then move along.

Would I recommend this game?  Yes!!!!  There are still a few bugs to sort out, but I love the open communication and the fact that there is a strong will to make this game into something special.  This is absolutely one of those games that has a lot more depth than the graphics.  I am going to be sinking a lot of hours into this one :)

This new samurai themed bullet hell game is a refreshing and exciting addition to the genre. The unique mechanics that comes with the samurai theme makes it highly enjoyable. This game is clearly a work in progress, with many systems that need fixing. When you're actually racing, gameplay can be surprisingly fun. But everything between races is overly complicated, confusing, and purposefully limiting in ways that make it hard to recommend -- and balancing of character abilities is shaky at best. But with a solid foundation of fun and unique racing mechanics, this game has the potential to be great, and developers have the opportunity to learn from their player base over the early access period and correct their mistakes. If you're interested in supporting a work in progress, I recommend buying the Standard Bundle and sharing your own feedback to help make the game better.

There is a version of this game that i played looooong time ago, probably like 7-8 years ago. It had very simple pixel graphics with little to no colors and textures. Yet, the essence of the game was great and simple at the same time. It feels kind of like sokoban with fantasy RPG elements, upgrade systems, collectables and different classes. 

I've actually played this newer, graphically and gameplay improved version also like few years ago - although i did play only few hours of this newer version. Now that it was given away for free on Steam, it seemed like a great moment to dive back into the game and dive deeper too.

And what better way than by adding a Extreme Edition mod that adds a lot of new stuff, brings in some overhauls and makes the game harder? 

Sometimes a simple but well defined system is enough to capture my heart. It is certainly the case with this game. It has that nice charm and can be quite relaxing as it allows to think things through in it's turn-based gameplay.

Lost Life, developed by Akio Kami, is an outstanding game that brings to mind the classic horror game Silent Hill, but with a modern twist. The game's graphics are simply astonishing, especially considering that it was created by a one-man studio. Lost Life incorporates a range of elements, including horror, survival, exploration, stealth, fighting, and third- and first-person views, all set in a mysterious world that has an outwardly dimension.
After being in development for six years, Akio's hard work has paid off, resulting in a game that is sure to make a mark on the gaming industry. I highly recommend this game, which is available on Itch.io and now on Steam. I played it on the Steam Deck, and it runs exceptionally well. If you're a fan of horror games or just looking for something new and exciting, Lost Life is definitely worth checking out.
The game might say free here, although that was an error. If you want to support the dev, you can find the game on Itch.io here:
https://akiokami.itch.io/lost-life-origins

Full a walkthrough of the game on Steam Deck, just press the link below:
https://youtu.be/6bOR_3vwCJc

This game gave me some interesting memories.

The interface can be confusing and it is understandable since creating a good interface for such thing as managing a whole army down to the details of their clothing and armaments is a quite a challenging thing to do.

This developer has done it. It is clunky and not easy to understand, but it does the thing and You end up with an interesting playground where You have to manage full spectrum of things, from feeding Your population to buying or producing equipment for Your troops and be prepared for war when it comes.

This is essentially a simulator of sorts and I love the way it works.

The game itself is very aesthetically pleasing, there are however many small design choices and oversights that ruin the experience.
Little things like how if you accidentally bump escape when you exit the menu it returns to unpaused even if you were specifically paused before hand.
Or not having any way to remove "fencing" if you accident place it on the edge of the map, as there is no tool to remove fences and the wall removal doesn't work on the edge.
Additionally the choice to put the sell option for objects in the middle of its interface without a second "are you sure?" option has lead to many accidental sales of objects at critical moments with not enough money to repurchase them, and no option to undo.

Over all, many small frustrations that ruin an otherwise good game.
the racing has a very good feel to it. can only get better from here with the addition of more tracks and some nice QoL improvements.  its early, but it's good.

The game is indeed buggy, but other than that its amazing beyond words. I've never felt that much freedom in any other game. The game is like you expect it from the description. You're in an open world with hundreds of people, fully walkable multiple story houses and every person and object could be the way to solve the case. It's a breathing world with an incredible amount of procedural depth.

"The bugs?" you ask? Yeah, I encountered some:

- In a flooded cellar, the water stops without reason at some point (no gameplay consequence)
- Loading a saved game doesn't work sometimes. Make sure you have multiple save games
- Also the save games seem to not contain the whole game state. Sometimes the loaded game is in a very different state, than when I saved it. For example in the tutorial mission I saved in the victims apartment. When I load the game, the police in front of the door ready to break in. Which was absolutely not the case, when I saved it.

If most of the bugs get ironed out, we have a true gem here, ladies and gentlemen.
i feel really uncomfortable breaking into someone's home

I first off want to commend this game's ambition. The stuff it is trying to do and it's attention to detail is incredible for an indie project. However, there are some glaring issues present here. first off is performance and bugs, those will get better with time but I feel the game has soft locked me out on the tutorial case, (the safe I have a passcode for doesn't take the pass code), and while it's cool this game really does just leave you to your own devices, it shouldn't for the tutorial. this is the first time I have had to ask to be handheld in a game but getting information and resources to try and put together what has happened in a case, is difficult to say the least, but more annoying than anything. part of that is the UI is such a mess and navigating the space is as well. idk maybe I have played to many modern video games but the difficulty in investigating here is annoying. Also, can we have the option to be on the side of the police in this game? it's annoying to go back to crime scenes and be harassed by the obligatory sentry at the door. and sure getting creative with breaking into places is cool but it just takes a lot of time.

I guess my biggest complaint rn is that the game just is sooooo slow, and starts to feel like it doesn't respect your time. I can't reccomend it in it's current state because it is frustrating to get anywhere or anything done in this game.

the suggested changes I would make are:
*better map and navigation UI. The arrow compass on the bottom of the screen ain't gonna cut it. Actually give me either a plotted path to the front door of the location or a waypoint to it's front door. it doesn't need to show me every way to break in, just get me to the front door!
*crawling through ducts is slow and tedious. speed it up or just have better and shorter duct layouts. As someone who works in HVAC, duct doesn't snake around as much as this game thinks it does.
*why do cammera breakers slowly creep back up? for as immersive as this game is that just ticked me off that I would have to keep going back to the breakers and just turning them back off.
*everyone in here are hp sponges. I get you don't want people to just punch their way through everything but everyone could do with their hp bars cut down to half or 2/3 of what they are now.
*why so many statuses? they are annoying and again, seek to waste time. could add a feature to turn them off if people don't want to play with them.
*with any puzzle there should be a hint system. again, at least the tutorial should baby you through more than it does, just so it is clear how the process of filling out the case report should go, everything you need to hand in a successful case.
The concept is phenomenal, procedural crimes and worlds. Its the crime game that will keep on giving, cant wait to see what they add with updates

give me options to change the graphics settings and/ or fix performance issues, eg, 5950x and a rtx 3080 running it at 30fps most of the time. 
overall its okay from what ive played so far but too laggy to be considered playable. 
ill check back when its out of early access and re do my review.

Enemies and bosses are all pretty cool. The werewolf brute is so up in your face you can hardly see what's happening though. Worth the price of admission for sure

So, from what I experienced:

The ides of the puzzles is good and entretaining, the way they can engage with people and use and learn different cyphers and puzzles is cool and interesting. Although I feel that hints should be locked by time as right now they can be skipped easily.

UI and UX are really good, it feels as if someone actually created an entirely new, and functional, Operating System. The typing sound and overall sound design is good, I liked it a lot and the klacking of the keys felt satisfying. The songs are not my style, but some of them do fit the game's aesthetic.(and I can't believe someone's beans got burnt:(( )

Me, myself, only saw one typing mistake on the main tour of it, none other later on. I still am surprised that this has Twitch intergrations too, that was an unexpected, but welcome move.

I also feel like the button and signaling to go in the puzzles webpage can be a little bit more on your sight instead of it blending with the other choices, same thing with the cypher's solve or mix page which I discovered after I finished my run, lmao

Sadly the Psychological horror idea felt like it popped in and it doesn't really gives the tension you'd feel it would, although the imagery used was real good to make you feel uncomfortable as I think it's the whole idea of it. The Cyphers and puzzles are interesting, although I feel like some need more of an explanation for people like me who don't really know cyphers (mostly cause I'm stupid.)

Overall, it's a really good base and it can be properly built from there to the final product and I like what's being done, I give it my personal rating of 7.8/10

2. Because what I did get to play was a lot of fun, and the vibes are immaculate. You can really [i] feel [/i] that there's something going on below the surface. I'm excited to dive deeper as soon as I figure out that one puzzle.

Oh boy. 
This is a hard one for my to review given my bias for league, sylas, and how hyped I was for this release. But I'll try to be as objective as I can. Let's start with some pros/cons

[h1]The Good[/h1]

10/10 Art & Animations - I'm not a pixel art fan, but I haven't seen anyone do it better than this game.
8/10 Story - It's a well executed cast of characters and memorable tension.
10/10 Boss fights - I loved fighting iconic champions and seeing their fantasy re-imagined in this game.
8/10 Combat - The basic flow of combat makes you feel like a very powerful version of sylas.

[h1]The Regretable[/h1]

0/10 Environment & Level design - There are 5 maps and they are heavily recycled.
2/10 Enemies - There are <20 enemies in the game. Fighting them becomes very boring very quickly.
3/10 Voice Acting - There is very little of it, which is regrettable for a story focused game.
0/10 Side quests - No opportunity to explore a side story. Just copy paste environment & fights.
STEAM ACHIEVEMENTS ARE INCOMPLETABLE WITHOUT DLC. Not really a huge deal, but ?????

Now I have to ask my self, do I recommend this game? It's still very hard. If I think just about my memory with the boss fights and the important story beats then yes I think so. However, every level quickly felt like just a chore to get through. If this game could have just been me reading a book with the occasional boss fight I think that would have been much better.

I've landed on: At $10 this game delivers an upvote. But only if you also are deeply invested in league of legends lore and really want to see the iconic characters be developed further.

Don't buy this game on Steam. Get it through gamepass. 

Simply wonderful. This game on the hardest difficulty is the best way to enjoy it. Once I turned it down it immediately became a lot less fun. It's not like Dungeons where the hardest difficulty isn't that hard, here; it is actually hard. It forces you to enjoy the quality of life and explore the entire world in order to get more powerful so that you can defeat the piglins. The building in this game is a super fun mechanic and you can get a little creative with it, but I wish there were more options. 

It felt like I had to actually prepare to siege the fortresses on the hardest difficulty and nothing was easy, it made it much more satisfying to take a step forward.

If I had kept it on the hardest difficulty, I easily could've put more hours into my playthrough. 

7/10 would recommend playing this game solo
11/10 would recommend playing this game with friends

SUMMARY: Fixes up the difficulty problem Dungeons had, don't buy it through steam get the gamepass, play the hardest difficulty, loved the game.

If you saw the trailer and your brain started doing cartwheels or kicks or flips or something, you're going to have a good time with this game. Basically you're manipulating colors to match some striped goal state in each level. You're given a few buttons that might shift a color, or expand it, or have it bleed into another color. Holding a button also makes a timer tick down, but as long as you're not moving anything around, you have as much time to think as you'd like.

It's really enjoyable all the way through. The early levels ease you into concepts, and if you ever are stuck on a level too long, you're offered a picture of an intermediate game state you can shoot for that should help you finish it. The mechanics are unique, and there are a lot of great trial-and-error moments sciencing out how each of them works.

29 puzzles for the asking price seems a bit steep though, especially when around 5 of them introduce mechanics. Still recommended.

Tried to post this in the gamepad discussion but couldn't, so here it is:
