Do you like detective games? Do you also like Immersive Sims? Boy oh boy do i have good news for you.

Currently this is one of the best Detective games i have ever played and it all comes down to scale. All the voice acted interrogations and scripted movie moments in the world don't compare to the lake of complexity and depth this game already has and the ocean that it can become.

Playing around with all the evidence and strings as you piece things together is SUBLIME. It gives me the sense of accomplishment that I've missed in a lot of detective games because they feel like a ride at a theme park. They don't allow you to feel like you are a real detective, only dressed like one.

This Game however? There are so many ways to gather evidence and directions that YOU and you alone can take this case to its conclusion. The guide rails are off and its free roam detective time! You want to spend five in game hours on a stakeout for your prime suspect to get home from work? You can! Want to break into an entire floors apartments to narrow down where your target is keeping his corporate files? You Can! Want to dig through emails and rubbish bins to find every scrap of intel on a tough case? YOU CAN!!! The freedom to do anything to progress the case gives you so many ways to make your own fun, fun that will never really drop off because these cases are YOUR cases! No step by step walkthrough spoon feeding the fun of a mystery to you, These randomly generated cases mean you gotta get your hands dirty digging through evidence and red herrings.

This is a fantastic detective game and as more gets added to it i expect my playtime to balloon exponentially.

Its a fun game. Its a bit hard at the beginning and you'll get somewhat lost. Heres some tips:

If you open up your research panel you can invest in skills by spending exp. Each skill is like 100xp. The first skill just increases damage I think.

Weapons give you range. A sword, dagger, and staff hits the front lines while the spear hits the second or something, and the crossbow hits the back. 

If you need money fast you can try to forage for stuff in the wilderness. I found a silver vein in the mountains and all the silver I mined got me about 2k gold.

The game says permadeath but when I end up back at the main menu I always see a continue button. I would have thought the save file gets deleted but I guess that isnt the case. If you want to play a game where you take the role of a wizard, do everything a wizard does, worry about everything a wizard has to worry about... from the mundane to the mystical. This is that game.

Here you have to worry about not pissing people off as much as where your next meal will come from and how to gain power as a mage (through political manipulation, magical pursuits or conquest). My closest analog is adventure mode in Dwarf Fortress, but specifically targeted at capturing the experience of what it would be like to live as a wizard.

The simulation and procedural generation here is pretty impressive. Not only is the world custom made on demand, but quests and even some type of enemies are generated based on what's going on in the world. As an example, bandits are actually drawn from townfolk/peasants if the economy starts becoming hostile.

All that said, it is still pretty early. There will be bugs, and core systems/functionality are still being implemented. But the team is fantastic at giving feedback and incorporating feedback from fans.

This is the easiest recommendation I've ever made. If not for outright purchase, at least wishlist it!

[h1]Disciplining unruly employees, one hypnosis at a time[/h1]
[b]Hypno-Mart[/b] is a short visual novel in which we play a manager who deals with a rude, bratty part-timer he can't fire because no one else is willing to work the night shift. However, he opts to teach her a lesson by hypnotizing her and banging her silly like the ugly bastard he is.

Plot-wise, it's similar to most nukige in the sense that the plot isn't deep and moves from one sex scenario to the other right away. That said, this visual novel has a bit of character development in the latter half when you have to pick choices that lead to any of the three endings available. On the downside, some words slightly go out of bounds or get cut in odd ways, as in moving their last letter to the next line.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2966894010
The visuals are as good as you'd expect from a nukige. I especially like Airi's design because her design is a bit different than the typical anime character. The H-scenes are very well-drawn and focus on the different predicaments the protagonist puts Airi in, ranging from having her pleasure him to putting her in humiliating situations. Unfortunately, the sex scenes are censored and the mosaics can't be removed.

[h1]Verdict: Good for nukige fans[/h1]
[b]Hypno-Mart[/b] is the kind of game fans of the genre and stories where hypnotism is the main focus will enjoy because of the quality of its art. However, those who aren't might want to wait for a sale before purchasing it due to its short duration and mosaic censorship.

UNCE, BOOM, UNCE, BLAM! If you like loud noises, fast past action and proper sick beats then you got the variety all here mixed into one little package. It has all the hall marks of a Quake/Unreal Tournament, "no time to blink" style speed, twitchy gunplay, all with a cel shaded art style. 

If this is your first rodeo into Rhythm shooters then this will take a while to get into, but once you do, it just clicks together!

It's pretty hard too, I'm struggling to get past some arena's on easy/normal mode. So if you're after a challenge then this will give it to you!

This will definitely be one of those easy to learn but hard to master type games. Plus, with all the zipping around, I can see speedrunners taking onto this to see if they can push just that bit harder for a higher score or faster time.

Looking forward to additional content that the developers have already said they would bring!

I hope this game keeps getting updated because I can see a future with a more fleshed out system that lends itself to more depth!

Claustrophobia the game, beating this nightmare gave me a new perspective on life, anything better than being stuck in the tiny tunnels. It feels like the world-building is intentionally empty or lacking the character to create a feeling of uncomfortable space and anxiety. It slightly reminded me of HellNight for PS1, mostly because 90% of this game is moving through tiny tunnels and almost no visibility, it's almost like playing as a food that is moving through an intestine, and I have to say game was extremely immersive, I figured it had no monsters early on, but sometimes I felt like I had to look behind my back because it's just so weird.

That said, I must give a bit of a warning for anyone that wants to try it, the navigation in this game is not exactly friendly, there is a huge exploration area with low visibility, and the layout of the map is not good for orientation. I can't tell you how many times I missed a path because I just could not see it or walked in a complete circle. It got so hard I was considering drawing my personal map, eventually, I managed to memorize the layout, but it took a few hours. On top of that, some of the puzzles and mechanics require a little bit of imagination, the game does not hold your hand, so expect a bit of challenge there as well.

(If I can give a small piece of advice for playing this game, have paper and pencil ready, and hug every wall, all of them, hug every wall that you see because you will miss something).

For me to explain exactly how this game works might be a bit of a spoiler in itself, I think part of the charm of this game is figuring out how the 2 character mechanics interact together. It can be a bit confusing at first, but once you understand the basic idea, the game is not very complicated. Essentially you have a tall character and a small robot that goes into tiny places you can't go, and that is more or less the core of the game. Interestingly the game has some point&click elements combined with a first-person exploration, sometimes it's not intuitive because the robot can press certain things that are out of his range.

So my save file said I beat the game around 90 minutes, but the actual time was closer to 4 hours or so, and even that might be a bit optimistic, there are so many ways to get stuck. I also missed some optional area, hopefully, it has something interesting because the ending was.. well, a little ambiguous. 

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

(+) Now, I can't imagine this game will resonate with many people, but it reminded me of those dreadful games such as HellNight, and unfortunately, I have some nostalgia for games that make you navigate endless tunnels where you can't see much of anything. I am actually not a big fan of games that are too dark, I avoid them if anything, but it feels like that design choice here was not just the lack of effort, but an intentional decision to create an uncomfortable and immersive game, I have never seen someone commit to that feeling of emptiness and just constant claustrophobia so much, outside of games like Isolania or Lost in Vivo.

What I am trying to say, I am not sure if people will appreciate the mood and vibes of this game, I think there is a bit of an acquired taste there, but I personally really enjoyed the atmosphere, very unapologetic **** the player, find the way yourself. 

(+) So for the puzzles, I guess you can look at it 2 ways. Yea, they can be kinda frustrating, but I thought the game was very unique as well, if you can inspect the hints carefully, it's not too hard, and I liked thinking outside the box. You definitely want to pay attention and record anything you find, and memorize the areas as well.

(+) There were some parts of the level design that felt more immersive, moving through constantly small spaces and the overall changing perspective made the game feel very different. I do think you could have done a better job with the overall layout, I think the game is very difficult to navigate for the first few hours. 

[h1] Feedback: [/h1]

[u] Nitpicks [/u] - might want to adjust the elevator controls, you can't interact with it if you are too close, and you have to finish moving in one direction before moving again. Also, if you run out of the elevator, you can softlock yourself. There are a bunch of areas where you can escape the map, mostly any joints between the areas. For one of the harder puzzles, the one with the 3x3, I didn't get the logic for the second hint, solved it with 50%+brute forcing. 

[u] Navigation [/u] - um, so in this case I actually like that how you designed the game around tiny places and crawling all over the place, the only thing that annoyed me is that some paths are just not visible at all if you moving around, you very much have to hug the walls here. Maybe at least a small object to point the player into the hard-to-see areas, use those random neons more.

And a small note for the ending, I mean I like that you left it for the player to interpret, but I don't know, I expected just a bit more context considering the treacherous journey.

[b] Overall Thoughts: 8/10 [/b]

This is the game that will probably make you angry a few times, but also a rewarding game to beat because of how challenging it is to navigate, almost like you escaped from an endless nightmare. I probably enjoyed this game more than a person with objective reasoning would,  it reminds me of certain elements that I don't see very often,  the game feels very unapologetic with navigation and overall experience, and if you give it a chance it can be very moody. The puzzle mechanics were very creative and maybe a bit frustrating, but they are not hard if you can think outside the box. I played many games that were similar, but not this committed to just having so many tiny places to crawl into, so I kinda enjoyed the whole turd-in-tunnel gameplay.

Holy performance issues, batman. Slower than trying to convince your parents to buy you a candy bar before dinner. Fun gameplay from what I've "experienced" but goddamn the lag is real.

I've only played for the first few hours. This may change after 10s of hours.

I tracked down contact of first victim, spoke to them, later broke into their  apartment early in the morning after having been in the sewer. At the same time, the murderer also broke into their apartment and shot them in front of me, all while complaining about the smell. I chased the murderer into the lobby, punched them unconscious, but then I got mobbed by helpful citizens.

I wound up arrested and the murderer has walked free, but I know what they look like and I have a first name only. I don't know how I'll track them down, but I will.

Performance suffers in a few areas, but the experience it gives of being a freelance detective trying to solve crimes is unparalleled. As the game gets more polish and more systems are added it will continue to improve.

Currently there's a few quirks. You can use a computer while someone else is sitting at the desk. Most citizens are really unwilling to give you their name for $50, but will happily take $30 to let you poke around the backroom of their workplace unsupervised. Procedural generation may generate a toilet block with 1 stall and 5 sinks.

Unlike a scripted detective game, you can easily waste time chasing down red herrings. Making your own murder board with bits of evidence, you can flood it with irrelevant crap, or customise it. There's a heap of tools you can use, maps, blueprints air vents.

I hope that future version continue to iterate on the systems.  Different security systems, locks, people perhaps being more willing to share information. Perhaps a grievance system, so people close to the victim adopt different routines temporarily.  But I'm excited to see what the game will become. Even if it doesn't change from what it is now, you will get your value from it
Wow I love video games again. performance needs so work but other then that, it's an absolutely fantastic immersive sim like the original Thief games

Can't get over how good this game is already. When something like this comes out it makes you realise just how much most dev's rely on generic and played out idea of a "game".

Everything about this is absolutely fantastic. The whole city feels alive and the the amount of items and methods to solve your cases and do your jobs is unlike anything I've played before. It feels like it was made by asking "How would you do that in real life?" rather than "How did you do that in a previous successful game"?.

It's immersive, it allows you to play at your own pace, and it offers such a rich procedural generation. It's perhaps the best use of PG I have yet seen in a game.

Early access? If they are to make improvements on the game, I would suggest the obvious improvements in the performance. I don't have serious issues myself, but there is definite slow downs at times. Other than that just make it even more immersive. Add MORE life orientated stuff. Purchasable. Perhaps more individualistic personalities. And of course the steam workshop. This game is almost the definitive example of a game with infinite replayability... all it requires is the steam workshop. I can just imagine the possibilities with mods for this game... Not to downplay the possibilities already realised. A real gem, especially if you like detective noir.

I'm just happy to have purchased it. Already worth every single penny and more. Going to be playing this for a long time.

I'd never heard anything about this game until I saw it pop up on steam on EA release. The concept sounded amazing and so far I'm not disappointed at all. Right out the gate, the attention-to-detail is crazy, especially for a procedurally-generated game. I spent close to an hour in the tutorial just inspecting stuff in my apartment and marveling at how in-depth and intuitive the systems for gathering evidence are. There's also a fair amount of compelling backstory and world-building that it's completely optional for you to interact with, which doesn't really have much mechanical impact on the game (as far as I know so far) but is very refreshing to poke around in and figure out on your own.

This is all stuff that impressed me before even interacting with the world and characters and meat of the gameplay, which I don't really need to go into too much detail on other than to say it's exactly what you're thinking it is from the descriptions, with a high level of polish and really intuitive UI and tutorial. It's not even bad to look at, despite everything being composed of voxels, thanks to really coherent art design and atmospheric lighting. 

Aside from framerate issues which I expect will be fixed, this feels like a full-featured product at launch and one that I'll get much more than my money's worth from. I'm super excited to see how things develop in EA and this is a big fat recommendation from me.

Sid Meiers Covert Action meets Stormworks meets LA Noire.

I rarely like to dip my toes into EA's, but I couldn't help but be intrigued by this game, ticking so many boxes for the "let me do it my way" puzzle/detective thinking game I've always wanted.  And amazingly, here it is.  Presented in a simplistic voxel style, but don't in anyway let that fool you, there's real depth here, real procedural generated cases to solve, everyone different and with their own tasks, to be resolved however you want.

Set in a reinvented dystopian 80's industrial-punknoir, it feels like Shadows of Doubt really does have something to scratch "that" itch, for the unguided off-rail investigator's game you've always wanted.  I know it certainly does for me.  While now in EA, I look forward to seeing how they develop what is already, a very sturdy foundation.
I absolutely love this game. Love the options to customize and tailor it to meet my style of play. Great game. So fun.

TL;DR It's an unpolished gem and actually means Early Access when it says Early Access

DISCLAIMER: THIS GAME ACTUALLY MEANS EARLY ACCESS, THERE ARE BUGS, MANY, MANY BUGS, MANY MISSING GAME SYSTEMS, YOU ARE NOT JUST SIGNING UP FOR A FULL GAME WITH CONTENT PATCHES, YOU ARE SIGNING UP TO HELP TEST AND GIVE FEEDBACK.

Okay that out of the way, do I recommend the game, holy **** yes. It feels like DF adventure mode had a baby with DnD and it scratches an itch I didn't even realize I had. You are an adventurous apprentice cast into the world before you're ready and oh boy do I hope you're ready to realize that a couple of magic missiles is not in fact an adequate response to three skeleton warriors ambushing you out of the dark in the first dungeon you explore.

That being said read the disclaimer. You will encounter bugs, possibly game breaking ones quite often at the moment. The dev is very friendly and fired off a hotfix within a few hours of releasing but I have no idea if that's really a manageable time frame long term (probably not), although given the amount of effort put into getting it this far in the first place, I can't imagine any of the really game breaking ones will survive the week (or month), or at least not until the next big step on the roadmap gets implemented. 

Area for improvement that will immediately stand out but isn't game breaking:
UI/hotkey polish: frankly it could use better tooltips, smoother UI transitions, there's probably a whole host of little QoL improvements that can be made here.
That's actually most of my complaints, well besides the bugs I mean.

This game is great.  Some of the reviews talk about unable to research, and not having enough money.  Yeah, the game is hard if you don't know how to play it.  The tutorial is... well, there's not really one.  That said, if you pay your folks the minimum wage, and send three scientists on every away mission, especially at the beginning, you should have no problems making enough science and (therefore) patents... money.  

I start with two science teams (6 low pay scientists), then soon a 7th to stay at home and just research.  In no time I've unlocked the other occupations and critical base upgrades.   Once you've got mining up and running you can run a full team of engineers to just make cash money by mining ore 24/7. 

Yes, the game is silly making you research a tread mill.  Yes, 3 soldiers isn't enough.  You'll take some casualties.  But they're easily replaced, and they level up quick.  By the time the invasions start to get big, you'll be making enough money to afford 8-10 soldiers guarding your base.  Bolster your med-bay and you're set.

You have to be efficient.  You'll have to restart.  But this game is not that hard, and it's at least as fun as Evil Genius 1.

Some quick thoughts as I'm only an hour in so far. I'm a non-puzzle gamer, so I think the challenges are harder for me that someone invested in this genre. Let's skip over the fact that I'm not the greatest gamer in general haha. The mechanics are dead simple and it's really fun! There are challenges that will rack your brains but it's not too punishing - you can skip, reset, etc. I also appreciate that I wasn't rushed to come up with a solution. I like that as soon as I'm comfortable with the challenges, a new dynamic comes up to make it feel fresh. Fairly straightforward so tutorials are light, which makes the experience smooth.

Also, got to love the style!
Have you ever fantasized about being a detective in a retrofuturistic incredibly stylized world where everyone fucking hates you? This is the game for you!

So far I'm really enjoying myself, the atmosphere sucks you in and sometimes it's fun just to walk around. Feels very Blade Runner at times in the best possible way. There is some issues with optimization and whatnot but that's what you go into Early Access sort of expecting. Game has crashed so far only when I was going to quit to desktop anyways so that's not the end of the world for me. 

I'm very excited to see how far the devs can take it and make the world even more alive.
This is a hell of a noir detective vibe, with some minor cyberpunk stuff going on as well. It's a fun sort of simulation, and the randomization really adds to the re-play value.

Lets Play Walkthrough - https://youtu.be/Vqv1k3Ai3-0

This is a great game if you were a fan of Princess Maker. I played Princess Maker all throughout my childhood and adored it, so it was sad to me when it was difficult to find games like it. Sure, there are handful of games out there that are well enough, but in my opinion none of them ever come close to Princess Maker... until Volcano Princess. Playing this game brings back that sense of nostalgia from my childhood, and unlike other recent games there is a clear true ending to strive for. It brings new mechanics into an old genre and it fits so well together. 

Now, I will say a few things. I really recommend this game, but I feel I do need to point out that out of the few playthroughs I've done now I have come across a few bugs. The most notable one is the fact that letters will come in  and if you click on it the words will not appear and it will break the game. There has been a fix created to help with this. However, another bug I came to was the fact that my game was seemingly skipping over the "Volcano Festival." I'm still trying to figure out if this has something to do with the fact that I changed my birthday month in my second playthrough and it skipped over the month of October because of it. Either way, it is a bug that needs to be fixed. The festival is a big part of the lore and gameplay, and it feels like your missing out when you can't even go. The game still runs fine regardless.

This is an amazing game that is, dare I say, more fun than the original Princes Maker series. The game takes everything you love about PM2, and adds upon it. 

PROS:
Sophisticated stat system
Easy to understand
Areas in the town unlock as you progress through the game
Turn based combat 
Making friends that you take on adventures, each with different skills
Festivals that test your daughter, along with minigames
Wide variety of unique characters that feel like real people
Incredibly adorable father/daughter relationship. Also the option to be a bad dad
Lots of different paths for your daughter to go down, and  balanced with every gameplay
Unique story with its own twist. Choices you make heavily impact your daughter and story
Side quests in the Knights college that help advance your daughter in a certain direction
Lots of things to do in the town map
Romance is very in depth. The game also rewards you with gifts as you advance every relationship
Cooking and Crafting
Lots of straight and lesbian romance routes

CONS:
Dice minigame is hard to understand, even with the guide I'm still confused. I end up avoiding it every playthrough

Horse racing is very hard, even with novice races you have to have an extremely fast horse to win, which is not available until you have at least 40 MND. Also I spent like 2000 gold leveling up my horse and still couldn't win. Hopefully they make this more balanced

You can date practically everyone in the town. The reason I put this in the con section is because there are some weird match ups involving people a lot older than you, and you can start romancing these people once you hit age 12 lol. So yeah there are some huge age gaps and it gets kinda freaky for my taste. The only plus side is that you can't groom your own daughter like in the original PM2

No magic classes in the game. If you want to fight in the forest, you have to build up your STR, which sucks  because INT and CHA have no place in battle

This game is very long. It took me several days to finish one playthrough. I actually kind of like this because the game is very in depth, but I made it a con because some people may not like this when pursuing multiple endings

Battle requires a lot of grinding to progress, although they offset this by spending purple stones to level up characters not in use. The problem is that you have to grind to get the stones, and you can't purchase them

Overall I think this is a great addition to the Daughter Raising Simulator genre, and really scratches that itch I've been craving in a game for a while now. The only thing they could add to make this game perfect (imo) is the ability to decorate your room. I think it would be super cute to acquire different stuff to place in there to personalize it. They kinda do this with the Alchemy station, but you can't see any of the decorations visibly. That's just me though

One of the best CoD Clones and even F2P FPS games out there. I love the map design, weapon ttk, features (near identical to MW2019) and flow of the game. It is essentially MW2019 Multiplayer but with good maps that actually seem to have some thought put into them and cranked mode pacing. The monetization isn't egregious either, with packs only costing 1-5 dollars instead of Activision's insane $20-40 packs. There isn't much to hate about the game, it has a good skill ceiling with its movement mechanics being key to doing well. Even spawns are well thought out and make sense. 

My only complaint would be that with a game of this pacing, you can't have a spawn protection system of this caliber. You can't kill an enemy who just spawned in for about 3 seconds from what I've counted. This is insane when you're on a nuke streak and you die 1 kill off because the game forces you to give your enemy a 3 second head start with god mode on. At most make it 1 second of God Mode, as it kills the flow of the game when an enemy spawns behind you, you turn on them and make every shot, yet lose the gunfight since they had God Mode Spawn protection. Fix that and I genuinely don't have any complaints. It's MW2019 but better in a lot of ways and Free to Play!

I didn't expect to spend 3 hours in some short FREE experience, but I did and I very well enjoyed every second of it! Really really beautiful environments, beautiful music, good positional audio overall - the sounds make the scenes come to life,  very atmospheric, good narration (was reminding me of the old point&&click games where your character react to where he is or when he see something. ) Amazing  day/night experience - I felt soo cool alone on the raft in the middle of night and the ocean ! The Lighting make the scenes come to life as well. Very well animated animals, moving clouds ! - that is for me in any game a MUST ! Cool inovative inventory system, some climbing, Good mushroom effects :D, items felt good, like real objects, some physics to them, like opening the compass - I just couldn't stop playing with it ! 
 Things that I suggest to improve on or I missed very much:  definitely smooth locomotion with jumping and turning because I was struggling with the cable without turning with my joy. My playspace is limited :( Teleport only felt baad! When necessary - yes, but let me walk on the beach with the joystick (combination of both would be nice - like in HLA).  Swimming OK, but would be nice to control also backward/side/down swimming. Paddling on the raft  was kinda basic - I wish they somehow get physics of kayaking like in the game KAYAK VR ! - that would be awesome !!!! Another thing - animate the fingers please and also add if not full inverse kinematics at least arms up to elbows and some chest/body... (Subnautica had it pretty OK) I love to have avatars body in VR ! Maybe add possibility to hang some of the items like weapons to your body for quick access. Plus Save function would be much appreciated.  All and all I think this project has a bright future !  Add some good story to it, like find a treasure, maybe some minor puzzles, pirates who also try to get the treasure. Maybe some other surviver ? I don't know, but I hope you will continue your good work and make nice game out off this and get some real profit !!! All the best to you Snigelsoft!!!

I can only genuinely describe this game as a plant based, family-friendly version of Postal 2.

The breakdown:
I cannot decide on whether they paid the voice actors too much or too little, the delivery of some lines are on par with The Rocky Horror Picture Show or The Room. Exclamations do not receive any specific attention and are delivered in a manner only categorized as "exhaustively bored". "Boss boss, the rabbits have escaped!" is delivered with a tone only rivaled by a tranqed up Text to Speech bot.
The controls on the bike are absolutely mind boggling and it only takes a meandering donkey pedestrian to get it permanently stuck, forcing you to carry your cargo in hand or reset.
The writing is unbelievably silly, the plot is wild, and the human models look like Play-Doh that's been left in the sun too long. The background stuff is funny like store announcer specifically mentioning that they copy security cards, the names of various stores, or the entire city being comprised of streets that were named with the first things someone saw when they broke open their spice cabinet.
This game could be so bad and goofy that's good, but it needs one feature. A punch button. Being able to full on deliver a knuckle sandwich that makes the game models freak out or send their ragdoll bodies across the screen would instantaneously make this game GOTY contender.

What slaughters this game's enjoyment of the hilariously poor voice acting, bewildering storyline and character choices, and the potential to be goofy stupid fun is the actual gameplay. It's mostly walking, getting on the subway and waiting for the game to load, more walking, talk to someone, walk some more, etc... I cannot fathom how this, a game with a dinky 100MB of files, needs to load that often. At heart, it's a chore simulator and doesn't do much to detract from the mind-numbing requirement to walk from point A to point B with nothing but spamming "Ask For Donation" inbetween.

I found a speedrun strat in the event someone finds this worthy:
Drive the bike against the invisible wall closest to the screen and you move faster, wiggle the front wheel as well.

Get plopped into my first city. It's dark and it's cold. I walk around the corner and spot a convenience store. I decide to step in to get warm and talk to the employee working there.

Ahh they have bourbon! Now that will keep me warm on this cold night. I step outside and glug the entire thing, throwing the empty bottle back inside the open door of the store.

I'm very woozy now and can barely stand up. I stumble around occasionally dropping to the ground and then picking myself back up. I throw trash cans, trash bags, and boxes out of my way as I try to get my bearings. I stumble in and out of a bookstore. While the inebriating effects of the booze aren't wearing off, the warmth they provided is, so I stumble over to a burning barrel to get warm.

There's a guy standing nearby. I can sort of make him out amidst the swirling voxels spiraling in front of my face. Then I hear gunshots. I look over, and there is a man in a trench coat standing there with a gun in his hand. He fires a couple more shots and the guy goes down, blood pooling around his body. The man walks away as if nothing happened!

My first case has now started, and boy is it going to be an easy payout since I witnessed the killing first hand. I stumble down the street after the man.  He gets suspicious of me and starts to run away. I stagger behind him as he weaves in and out of buildings. I wait outside a bathroom stall as he relieves himself and then continue the pursuit.

After several minutes of chasing and one bathroom break, I have finally had enough. I decide it is time for my fists to put an end to this, but it's really hard to land a solid blow when you can't stand up straight. I take a few swings and land a punch, but then I realize I had forgotten that this guy was packing, and he pulls out the same gun that offed my barrel buddy and plants some rounds into my chest.

I wake up in the hospital and manage to escape. Looks like I am going to have to track down this guy the old fashioned way. I go back to the crime scene and collect prints  and a wallet from the victim. Guy's name is Carlos Somethingoranother. I investigate his apartment and his place of work, but I am not finding anything linking him to trench coat dude. I find another lead which is the name of his landlord. Maybe she has a thing for guys in trench coats. I get to her apartment and try to pick the lock when no one is looking. An alarm goes off and I am trapped inside a hallway with a turret that shreds me like mozzarella cheese.

I end up back in the hospital. I escape again, and I go back to the convenient store and buy another bottle of bourbon and glug it down. 

I could get used to this detective life...

A very slow classic style open world RPG, the game creates a random world with it's history and everything. A very ambitious game with good ideas.

Things i like:
- Random generated open world.

- Enemy in combat looks nice and feels alive. They are well animated and some can talk during fights.

- Dungeons, you must actually look around the room/location in a dungeon to find loot (Highly miss-able if you did't look through everything).

- Relationship, i'm pleasantly surprised to see 1 of my 3 school mates in one of the town 
  selling stuff at the market (School mates appears only in dialog during character creations). 

Things i feel can improve:
- A lot of QOL things definitely can do better, unless they purposely left it out just so the game 
  can really feel old school. For example to equip, you have to open character and inventory 
  individually and drag whatever you wanted to equip to your doll (no 1 click to snap in place).

- Combat feels slow, every enemy moves have tiny pauses in between. When vs multiple 
  enemy can be annoying.

- Error log keeps popping out, makes you wonder whether to continue the game or just 
  restart or quit for good.

That's about it for now, hard to progress with so many bugs around. I have restarted the games multiple times and keep getting game breaking bugs, quest giver error, and can't even read books (which is super important since you need to read in order to learn new spell) how to progress without this?

I understand this is an Alpha and have to give credits for the dev for coming out 2 hot fixes in the very first day. But still way to many bugs.

For this price tag i will say save your money for now. Unless you wanted to pay $25 bucks and hired yourself to be a bug tester.

I've seen a lot of people comparing this to My Life as a Teenage Exocolonist and Long Live the Queen, and I agree wholeheartedly, but I would also like to raise this statement:

This is the successor to Princess Maker 2 that you have been looking for. 

Not only do you actually feel involved with your daughter's life, but your daughter actually feels like she has autonomy in the things she wants and does, even if you are technically controlling them for her. There's many options in where to take her life, though not enough that it becomes overwhelming and every ending becomes another box to tick; every run feels special. 

Do not let the bad translation scare you off from a lovely, adorable raising sim that captures the old-school Princess Maker formula in a way for modern audiences that makes the whole experience magical from start to finish.
Probably the best game of this genre.

It aight

Pros: 

- Movement + parkour. On KBM you can take full advantage of this and it's very fluid. Changing direction midair is a breeze. The game becomes a spiderman simulator where you are no longer limited by silly things like walls or the tops of the map. 

- Guns are perfectly accurate from the hip for the first few bullets while sliding. Crouch spamming alone is not enough to take full advantage of this. Make sure to jump from side to side for near immortality.

- Full crossplay! With mobile devices. No way to turn this off, no where for mobile to run. Very fun experience on PC. Unknown if it's fun on mobile, I can't communicate with my team in game to ask. 

- No ads! Except for the ones asking you to buy one of the many, many things for sale in this game. You can buy extra weapon xp, level xp, and battle pass xp individually for an extra fun 30 mins.

- No Pay to Win! The one tiny thing that's not mentioned is that you can pay to unlock a weapon early that has attachments perhaps equal to a max level weapon. It's not pay to win, just pay to get to the top of what's achievable much faster and flashier. 

- Near-Instant Matchmaking! You will never struggle to find a match quickly. Maybe I'm getting paranoid but it does seem like some lobbies may have accounts that look real but are bots. Some emblems are unlocked by level and some of these accounts have emblems at a level that is way too early. 

- Customize your weapon! Or rather modify its performance through attachments. There is a massive difference between a Level 1 weapon vs a Level 10 weapon vs Max Level 80 Weapons. For extra distinct equality though you can of course buy a $5.99 USD crate with tons of weapons that have incredible attachments.  

- Insane FPS. Getting 240 on ultra settings. Every frame counts in establishing PC dominance vs PC, Mobile, and perhaps Bots. 

Cons:

- Literally None! What more could you ask for from a free game!

- I have to wait for more battle passes, cases, agents, knives, and other creative ways to spend money on this free game for no advantage whatsoever.

Hope's End is a tower defense game that offers an innovative twist on the genre. The game mechanics are fresh and engaging, making for an enjoyable gameplay experience. The environment is immersive and believable, with some room for improvement. The rounds are just the right length to serve as a fun time-killer, but there's also plenty of skills to master to keep you coming back for more. Fans of tower defense games will definitely want to give Hope's End a try, as it offers a unique take on the genre that is definitely worth checking out. Overall, Hope's End is a great addition to the tower defense genre.

Factory Town Idle is actually Factory Town but without the town building on map. Now, everything you build are numbers, and  you don't have to plan your town on a map.

The game went trough a lot of changes before it was launched on Steam, to purchase. The dev had a lot of ideas and went exploring various ways to evolve your map and interaction with other towns. Current version, at the time of this review, I think it's more balanced, since it will force you to build other towns also since you need to trade specific goods available only on those towns.

I see that there are a lot of negative reviews that the game is not Idle, from my point of view, this game is better than idle, you interact with the game a little bit more, you have more micro management to make sure that when the game is idle you can advance, and at the end, while you are away, you can gain resources that you will use when you return to the game.

I recommend games developed by Erik, if you like the genres that he is developing, because he is a very passionate developer and is doing a hard work, FAST WORK and very good interaction with the community. 
You can see more changes between two versions of a game, released in 1-2 days interval, that have more content than other developers deliver in half a year.

Please note that I was not paid for reviewing this game, I received a key because I owned the Factory Town game, and because I was willing to take part in the testing process before the game was released to public.
If you like this kind of game, you should buy it!

This is so insanely adorable. I haven't played a raising simulator since "Long Live The Queen" because I was so disappointed by how short and limited it was, but it is so adorable raising the daughter in this game, to see how she grows from your actions, to play with her or teach her influences how she'll view life later on, it is very adorable, even just the very little I've played so far.

There are problems with bugs and the english translation isn't perfect ("Daughter, what's up?" to 5 year old daughter xD ) but the developers of the game are active right now, trying to iron out all the problems, and even have proposed bug fixes of their own to avoid certain bugs until they can officially iron them out in an update. I think that's awesome, especially considering usually developers just dip on their games, and only come back when the initial sales dip due to the problems. These guys just released the game, are selling massive numbers, and they are still committed to ensuring the game is perfect for everyone. I really like that dedication to their art :)

Plus, I would like to direct your eyes towards the achievements and oh hell yeah that is 200 and 30 achievemnets. 230 achievements. For a $10 USD game. That's pretty damn impressive IMO. Marking each milestone, and the many, many endings you can get, it's pretty damn impressive :)

10/10 absolutely recommend, especially at the 'introductory price' because that's even below the $10.99 USD. The movement is fun and has a potentially high skill ceiling, and the game is free-to-play. Combat Master has the potential to be cleaned up and turned into a really fun and accessible FPS, but that's kinda the issue with it: there's such a stark lack of polish everywhere, it's hard to feel like the time you'd put into it is worth it.

A non-exhaustive list of some things that feel unpolished:
- the UI: many important buttons are oddly placed or straight up hard to see
- server quality: opponents typically look jittery at best, teleporty at worst
- gun unlocks look ripped right out of modern COD, yet the system as a whole is way less intuitive
- premium (paid) skins adjust gun stats that affect in-game mechanics (did not verify if Pay2Win or paywalling gameplay options, but both scenarios are bad)
- look sensitivity is obscure and clunky: while it's nice that each scope level has its own sens, the simple scale of 0-500 is unhelpful and the scrolls bars are frustrating to try being precise with.
- the game's namesake mode, Combat Master, is horribly unintuitive. I think it's a 6 player BR, but the maps are small to the point where if you don't spawn close to a weapon chest immediately, you're just gonna repeatedly run into the players who did, turning it into "run away and hope you find a weapon before they find you".

I could probably go on but I'll leave it at that. Would love to see this game reach its potential, but the amount of development time it'd take to get it there doesn't seem feasible. Is it worth a download? To feel the movement for yourself, maybe; But it'd be best if you went into it with low overall expectations.

Great voxel neo-noir detective exploration game. It's very fun, when the game works properly. As of release, when this review was made, the game has crashed on me more times than I'd like. I understand it's early access, but that doesn't excuse it from being exempt from criticisms of what should've been polished before even releasing to the public.

I'll leave it a thumbs up regardless, because aside from the bugs, its a genuinely fun game, and you actually have to use your brain to play. The detective work is actually engaging, and the random generation adds so much replayability. I've had fun with the preset quest and city that they set you up with, and I have yet to finish it due to the repeated crashes, but so far Shadows of Doubt hold up as a solid detective sim.

From the first second after opening Re:Fresh, you can immediately tell how special it is. I knew from the jump that the game was going to be good, but I never expected it to be exactly what I needed today. The style and environments were so warm and welcoming, and in combination with the music, each area felt more and more like sinking into your own bed after being away for a few days. The Mushroom Woods really stood out as a beautiful area to explore, but overall the game looks so lovely. The NPCs were very distinct, with each of them featuring their own lovable personalities and ways of interacting with the player through delightfully charming dialogue. You really can‚Äôt help but care for the townspeople of Clover, and I was more than delighted to fix up the town every step of the way. I don‚Äôt feel like I can put into words how much I enjoyed the mechanics and platforming in this game. The controls are tight, the platforming segments are incredibly clever, and the quality of life details like the quest journal and the cosmetic options really just top off the gameplay experience. 

My absolute favorite thing about indie games is the amount of love you can feel from the creators, and it is ten times as present in Re:Fresh. Everywhere you look, you can see the immense care the devs took in making this project what it is. The game comes off as deceptively simple but as soon as the credits roll, it is abundantly clear how much hard work, dedication, and heart went into Re:Fresh. The swell of achievement from bringing back hope to Clover, and the warm wash of unadulterated joy at seeing how this game came to be, culminates into a perfect little bow to put on top of this beautiful experience. I am beyond proud of what everyone involved with Re:Fresh has done to make it as delightful as it is, and I can‚Äôt wait to see what the future has in store for all of these lovely people.

Whether you play Re:Fresh to take your mind off of a bad day, or to keep you company in a particularly bad storm, I hope you too are able to see how special it is. Savor your time with it, and have fun (:

Great concept, the game could use a little work but if you're into the Civil War and enjoy naval strategy give it a try.

At this point, I cannot offer this game a positive rating despite my liking to it. Hopefully, this will change.

Simply put, the naval combat in the game is extremely unrealistic. 

During the Civil War, ironclad vessels were the king of the era because very few naval guns could defeat their armor. Ironclad warships were oftentimes scoring a ten to one kill ratio, while battle between ironclads could drag on for hours while remaining inconclusive.

In the game, however, everything is based on RNG, no realistic consideration of gun penetration or armor whatsoever. A small paddle gunboat could one-shot your ironclad warship through some kind of "catastrophic explosion" just because RNG says so.

During the Civil War, naval guns were also horrendously inaccurate at anything beyond point-blank range. It usually takes several broadsides to score a lucky hit on a faraway opponent, and even close range gunfire requires multiple ranging shots to be zeroed in.

In the game, however, gunfire at extreme range almost possesses 100% accuracy. This preposterous game feature ruined my immersion completely.

More so, the "ramming" attack that tends to sink wooden ships in a single strike does pathetic damage! Making the monstrous ram type ironclad almost ineffective.

Additionally, the game slowly descends into a non-functional state the further one plays into a campaign. On 1862 of the Confederate Campaign, loading a save is almost impossible. One would almost always have to quit out of the game in order to load an old save. What's more? I've been stuck on the screen where my blockade runner reaches Europe for many times now.

As an enthusiastic Civil War naval fan, I've read articles regarding almost every single Civil War maritime engagement and performed in-depth research regarding Civil War naval guns and ironclads. I chose to purchase this game because it is the only large scale Civil War naval game on Steam so far. Yet, the result is wholeheartedly disappointing.

I could forgive the bugs. By all means, I've played so many buggy yet promising games in Early Access state before.

Yet, I cannot recommend Victory at Sea Ironclad because of the horrendously unrealistic, RNG based combat model.

I will continue monitor the development of the game. Hopefully, my review will change in due time.

If you played the demo, you probably mostly know how you'll feel about the game. It's very colorful and you find weapons of different types as you explore. You start with just a sword, but also find great swords, scythes, whips, and at least one other type of sword. There's a ton of space and the level design isn't extremely memorable, but it's memorable enough for you to recognize certain spots. The map also lets you place up to 200 reminders with various icons, which is nice.

Combat feels pretty good to me, as it's similar to a lot of classic games in the subgenre. You can have two weapons equipped at once and most weapon hits will keep the majority of enemies from attacking. You can dash forward or backward, which I think works quite well, but you don't get I-frames, so don't be expect to constantly dash through enemy attacks. A lot of enemy projectile attacks can be knocked back to enemies and you can equip a tome to use elemental magic spells. Weapons can be improved with a consumable you'll find on occasion, but you absolutely won't want to use these all the time, as you consistently find better weapons. 

Afterimage is an action-RPG, of course, and the main character, Renee, levels up upon accruing sufficient experience, which grants you talent points that can be spent on a skill tree. You'll also find talent points whilst exploring. These will give your stats a buff, as well as teach you new abilities for specific weapons. I'm fairly satisfied with all of this. The exploration is similar, as I really feel like the game does a fantastic job of incentivizing you to look in every nook and cranny, as there's a lot of great stuff to find. You'll naturally also be able to backtrack and find new stuff with your movement abilities.

Now for the stuff I'm not crazy about. When you die, you lose all of the experience you have on you since the last time you level up. This obviously isn't a giant deal and you'll get it all back by touching it at the spot you perished. Afterimage also makes use of a bonfire equivalent, so you'll respawn at these, as well as heal. Resting will bring back any defeated enemies and refill your healing charges too. The game isn't all that difficult, though, and there's no stamina management or anything of that sort, although your MP will recover over time. The bonfire equivalents are quite far from one another, though. The map also doesn't fill in automatically, and it only fills in the places you've been upon using a bonfire equivalent, which I don't mind so much.

As for another thing I don't care for, you can only fast travel by using a consumable (at least, so far). This obviously puts a major damper on going back and exploring, but these consumable might be easy to come by later. Early on, I only found a single one of these, so don't expect to find them all the time in your first few hours. Overall, I'm enjoying the game and it offers most of what I like to see in a Metroidvania. It also appears to be fairly lengthy.

This is by far the best Survival Island game i've played.

And I've played alot of survival games on PS5,Xbox, And PC.

Now lets get into the cool stuff that you will love alot right away.

1. Controller support off the getgo... able to be played on Steam Link... on my Phone.
2. Carts... Yes carry all your items with you and don't think your in The Forest... wait wrong game... either way we got 2 of them so far.
3. Ships... yes full on exploration using ships... when you get it... its very fun to just drive around.
4. The game's early hard mode, goes away once you get to know what your doing... the difficulty was hard sure... but it was good... later updates might need to add more difficult enemies on newer islands... but for now its fine.
5. Stone,Flint,Obisidian... plans for Copper,Iron... what? you want cool stuff. go get the resources... the wait is worth it when you finally get a obisidian spear and can kill all those annoying pesky uhh squirrls? waht are they again... to busy murdering these things.
6. Foundation base building similar to ARK,Forest, and alot of other games... at least its windows are interactable.
7. A Dock Piece... yes a Dock Buildable piece... why do games just not have any Prefabs nowadays? this prefab is one of my fav looking.
8. I Love the story.
9. I've never CTD Or Hard Crash, besides Lag Spikes here and there... game is running perfectly fine.
10. Im running out of ideas... i'll edit later and add more stuff.

The Bad.

1. FPS Drops here and there, nothing major... you won't notice it.... mostly when loading alot of stuff in... which you will be fine dealin with.
2. The Lack of more content... now this isn't a major thing... its just i want more. and its coming, so don't let that get you down.
3. The Walking/Movement... now it seems slow sure... but this was probably to slow the early game down... which is fine, but we need a faster movement later game.
4. Doesn't seem to be any Stone Building/Brick/Clay building, could be a future update.
5. Tools break fast... idk if its me... or i'm just using them to much.
6. Figuring out Hides... is a nightmare... and needs improved... abit more... the Jackel hide as far as i can tell does nothing... the only way to get hides is from Boar.
6. It rains to much... idk this just annoys me personally it constantly is rainning... but it is the tropics... i just wish it was less.
7. Custom settings... for resource respawns... world day/night cycle... monster amount counts... stuff like this is missing and should be a feature later on... for Custom Difficulty.
8. 2 Boats... at the time of writing this and playing it... I Was hoping more. then again still early access.
9. Mapping is kindof weird... since i can't auto map while walking? like i've seen this area... just map it already? do it in a more smaller reveal area... if you want it that way... but when the map says NOTHING SEEn... i'm confused.... since i remember the area... explorers would just remember the stuff... not map everything... most of the time... ish.
10. nothing really else... i can pull out of my head... game is fine, it just needs more updates.

Overall worth the money, good devs, needs more content, fun to screw around with.

What a gem.

I'm not big on pixel graphics games, however this holds up very well with some of the most immersive design and good use of lighting that even I can appreciate the art style.

The gameplay is where this really shines, incredibly deep detective simulation where everything can play a role in the crime scene: 
Is there fingerprints on that toothpaste?
What size shoes did the victim wear? Do they match up with those boot prints?
Where does their spouse work? Whats their working hours? Perhaps I should drop by.
Whats the last telephone call they sent/received? Maybe i'll trace it

You get the idea.

This might be one of the most masterfully crafted gameplay loops i've experienced and I can honestly see this game being a huge hit.

while buggy and not perfect (granted its early access), i havent had this much fun in a game in a long time. from the hours of detective work cases can have within them to the random shenanigans you can get into, this game, when the devs iron out the kinks, will 100% be my GOTY.

9.5/10

Rough around the edges (hence the early access) but so damn fun. There's just no other game out there like this that lets you be an investigator in such a dynamic and free way. The game combines so many dynamic systems together to create a detailed playground of hundreds of citizens leaving paper trails for you to follow, every one of which you can dig deeper into by breaking into their home, or work, to learn more about them.

Murders happen dynamically while you play, meaning you can accidentally find yourself at the scene of the crime as it happens. Or not. However, the many ways that you can approach the discovery of the murderer is insane no matter when you arrive. 

I found myself at the scene of a crime yesterday that happened on the streets. After gathering information on the body I was able to instinctively look around the scene for a security camera. After a little breaking in I was able to view the footage during the time frame the murder happened, which lead me to a visual description of about 5 people. To narrow it down, I asked people around that area of the city if they seen anything, and I was on my path to solve the murder, and it worked.

Highly recommend.
Pretty darn atmospheric, but weirdly demanding.
Fun concept, needs some polish, i.e. performance, but otherwise enjoyable

I really like the idea and premise behind the game.

Enjoyed the demo a lot, but the performance here is somehow worse for me than the demo.

Furthermore, a few times objectives didn't properly load and it was hard to get into.

I really appreciate what the guy is doing, and I will probably buy when it's out or at least more polished, but for now, it was unplayable for me.

I love it when puzzle games have very simple mechanics but do a lot with it. Out of the gate this game tells you "think before you move" and it's right! if you go for a trial and error approach it can get frustrating, but if you actually stop and plan your moves, it's a very satisfying game. Music and art are well thought out and executed, there is a coherence between the two which is nice to see from a small indie title like this. Overall this game could be a little bit of a hidden gem, I hope more people find it!

If I could wish for an improvement it would be more easier levels in the beginning to smooth out the learning curve a little bit, to allow players some time to practice how to think in this game. Give a level or two to practice thinking with each mechanic before we have to learn a new one!

i got this game because i saw it circulating on twitter and i thought the art style looked really neat.

what i like:
the game looks great, feels good to play with controller, i enjoy being able to toggle visual effects such as blur and chromatic abberation, the enemies are simple but memorable in their design, weirdly shaped guys. i particularly like how are all the vehicles are rendered; all the shadows when turning and stuff are gorgeous.

now..... onto what's making me unable to finish it.
often times i feel like enemies are too powerful, or there's too many. this isn't that bad with the green guys and their generators, because you can just walk ahead, get rid of those and get the darsanauts to safety - it isn't as easy, and not nearly as fun, to fend off the several spaceship-steering green guys, the bats or the diggers.
next, the decision to limit your jetpack use in level 17, where it's  a bit inconveniencing, and in 27, where i've stopped now. this just isn't fun for me, when being able to fly around for a while is already a thing you were able to do previously, as well as reusing it in level 27, where there is so much verticality you could explore alot faster with the regular jetpack.
one more thing i personally dislike is the way the cursor is bound to the camera and movement of the player when using mouse and keyboard (not the recommended controls, but still). adding to that, the crosshair is REALLY hard to see.

i started out really enjoying this game, it was laid back and pretty alright difficulty wise - even the little remarks the characters make about the game being hard but the player just needing to get better were silly and fun. but as it went on it just made me more and more frustrated. it's really a shame, because i can tell alot of love and effort went into moons of darsalon, and i really wanted to play it all the way through. despite all that, major respect for the solo developer crafting this game througout the years!! i hope other people have more fun with this than me.

[h1][b][1] Intro [/b][/h1]
Coffee Talk Episode 2: Hibiscus & Butterfly is a heartwarming coffee brewing and heart-to-heart talking simulator that takes players on a journey of self-discovery and reconnection with friends, old and new. Developed by Toge Productions, the game is the sequel to the original Coffee Talk and is set in an alternate present-day Seattle where humans, orcs, elves, and other races have been coexisting since the beginning of time.

[h1][b][2] Game Experience[/b][/h1]

As a barista, players get to brew warm drinks using a variety of ingredients such as tea, ginger, mint, chocolate, and coffee, among others. By experimenting with different combinations of ingredients, players can uncover secret recipes that can change people's lives by serving drinks that warm their hearts. Each drink is unique and tailored to the individual customer's needs, and as such, players must listen carefully to the stories their customers share to create the perfect drink.

One of the game's most striking features is its latte-art simulation, which allows players to draw their own latte-art masterpiece to decorate their drinks. With a simple-to-use interface, players can create unique and stunning designs that are sure to impress even the most discerning customer.

The game's chill lo-fi atmosphere is perfect for relaxing and unwinding after a long day. Players can immerse themselves in the relaxing coffee shop atmosphere, listening to the rain outside, and playing chillhop beats while engaging in coffee talk with their customers.

The diverse cast of characters is another highlight of the game. Players get to meet quirky and interesting characters such as Baileys the elf freelance graphic designer, Lua the succubus bisdev executive, Myrtle the orc game developer, and many more. Each character has their own story to tell, and players can influence them with a warm drink or two, helping them overcome their fears and challenges.

[h1][b][3] Verdict [/b][/h1]
Overall, Coffee Talk Episode 2: Hibiscus & Butterfly is an excellent game that delivers a unique and engaging experience. The game's blend of coffee brewing, latte-art simulation, and heart-to-heart conversations makes it a must-play for anyone looking for a relaxing and heartwarming gaming experience. The game's diverse cast of characters, chill lo-fi atmosphere, and immersive storytelling make it a standout title that's sure to be enjoyed by gamers of all ages and backgrounds.

First impression review. The atmosphere is amazing. You get to enter several buildings and its many floors and apartments, snoop around and loot whatever, get in stablishments, talk to people, investigate stuff and pull the threads for as long as you possibly can.

There's so many things I'd do differently IRL, but I'm bound to the game's rules and I don't know how to proceed. Pretty much all AI say the same things like "it's none of your business" and "I'm not gonna tell you that".

All in all, great game, I hope I learn how to get through this and I hope devs fix this lack of tips when stuff like this happens. It's not like I got stuck right away like a noob. I got pretty far. And I spent 54 BRL to play 5.8h. Comparing to a watching a movie at the theater or eating a steak, I'd say it was a good deal. But this is only a positive review because I'm optimistic that I'll eventually break through. Wish me luck.

Definitely recommended, if you liked Return of the Obra Dinn you'll like this too. You have to actually do investigating to solve the cases and it's very immersive and engaging.

For example I took a job to arrest a person and the only information I got was a phone number, age, eye color and height of the person, calling the number the person answered with their first name but refused to answer any further questions so I looked through the phonebook and got all the addresses of people with the same first name initial. 

Then I started going to the addresses and knocking on their doors until in the fourth apartment I found a person who had the matching eye color, I had to bribe him so he let me inside his home where I found his drivers licence which confirmed that the name and age matched so I arrested him and got my reward money.
god damn sync junkies

>Early Access Review as of 04/2023

Compared to other games with procedurally generated elements where pieces of the world fit together like a child's 12 piece jigsaw puzzle, Shadows of Doubt is a technical marvel. 

Despite performance hiccups when moving indoors/outdoors it manages to balance a ton of moving pieces at once like NPC information, their schedules, relationships all while you run across town, through buildings and up and down elevators without a single loading screen.

Gameplay wise it's very satisfying tying together threads and uncovering these randomly generated mysteries. There are commonalities however and while everyone has a unique and fun story to tell right now I think it'll be two months before they all begin to sound alike.

While you can follow many different interesting threads like tracing phone calls, finger print scanning, checking security tapes etc. 
All leads however boil down into breaking into a place which hasn't been balanced because of the random nature of it. And to break into a place it will only ever follow 3 paths: 1. Bribe your way in 2. Go in through the vents 3. Disable security and lockpick in, with your limited items and gadgets only helping to slightly even the odds but it isn't enough. 

The dialogue tree isn't versatile enough to feel natural. Speaking to NPCs feels like talking to Morrowind NPCs who have no quests attached to them. They can tell you who they are, who they knows, where places are but not anything of substance or relevance.

The combat system is incredibly janky and nonfunctional. You can only temporarily stun and render opponents asleep for 2 mins or surprise and cuff them from behind although this approach might bug the game with an unending 'Pursuit' of you.
Guns feature in the game but you cannot use them and supposedly they won't ever be able to be used because killing NPCs would break the procedurally generated elements. 

You will be discovered, you will die, you will save scum, you'll find out the place you spent hours trying to get into wasn't actually related to the case at all. 
Only in the tutorial mission will you ever be handed the closest thing the game has to a smoking gun. These cases are incredibly difficult.

Side missions trick you into thinking that a case to find a missing necklace is an easy beginner's case but instead you'll be handed only a fingerprint and an address book with 14+ people in it to sort through. 
A mission like this can take hours and end up being a total waste of money, effort and time.
Other missions simply say: Arrest this office worker, we don't know where he works, who he is, how old he is, what he looks like, no evidence, just go get him. 
Side missions seem to be a complete afterthought, not as fleshed out as the murder cases yet, not worth the time or effort as of now. 

Hours of progress can easily be lost and doomspiral until you're out of money, lockpick resources and wanted for more crimes than the criminal you're hunting.

The game desperately needs more player options for circumventing annoying stonewalls like uncooperative suspects and triple layered security systems for a janitor's broom closet. 

Alternate sneaking methods of entry like getting through windows, leveraging police warrants to get into suspect's homes, being able to use limited screwdrivers to disable security cameras from below.

Right now it only barely succeeds as a detective sim and you'll note other reviews of people who simply gave up on the snooping and now treat the game as a Hobo Looting Simulator. 
I'm hoping the devs can patch a few more features into this to fully deliver on the premise.

Good game even in its current state. It‚Äôs like a procedurally generated noir/private detective story that plays kinda like Deus Ex or Thief with a decent amount of BladeRunner‚Äòs bleak vibe. The graphics aren‚Äôt amazing but the post processing is used to good effect.

Interacting with the environment is really immersive. Like if you open a drawer you don‚Äôt get a pop up window to show you what‚Äôs in there, the draw itself opens up and whatever‚Äôs in the drawer is actually in the drawer.

Had heaps of fun solving the first ‚Äútutorial‚Äù murder, and one procedural one after that.
There are side jobs you can take, I need to take a photo of someone and all I know about them is they have green eyes, their partner‚Äôs first name (Ying), and their partner‚Äôs profession. So I gotta go visiting all the ‚ÄúY.‚Äùs in the phone book.
It gives you difficult tasks and you have to figure out how to achieve them using what‚Äôs available to you in game. It‚Äôs nice that it doesn‚Äôt help you out too much.

You can buy an apartment and furnish it which is kind of cool, I wasn‚Äôt really expecting that from this game but it‚Äôs a nice distraction from cases. Not sure if you can own multiple apartments at once. Dev please add being a landlord.

Only issue is maybe performance, it runs decently on my laptop at 1080p and mid-high settings but it‚Äôs a decent laptop. 40-60 fps with frames capped at 60. Even at 40 it‚Äôs very playable because it‚Äôs a fairly slow paced game most of the time.
Laptop specs:
RTX 3050 4GB
Ryzen7 6800H 
16GB DDR5 

I‚Äôm impressed it performs as decently as it does because of just how much stuff is being simulated. Like all 300 citizens have jobs and go out for meals and drinks and stuff. And while they‚Äôre doing that, every security camera is actually watching for people and taking photos of them, that you can break into the security computer and look at, and print them out to add to your cork board.

So yeah just be warned that it might not run on your busted-ass hoopty laptop from 2018 but it‚Äôs a fun and unique game

Loved this game. The mechanics are fun and quite intuitive. It has fun and challenging puzzles and I adore the charming art style. In my opinion it is super worth the price. I would easily pay for additional dlc levels for this game!

This is a short point-and-click game with simplistic graphics. The story revolves around Reese who - allegedly - murdered his partner and our task will be to (first) escape the prison we're thrown into then to find out who the real culprit was. The game has some cutscenes with just enough amount of dialogue and do note that because this is a low-budget game voice acting is missing, however, the music is quite good. 

It's one of those games where levels consist of various rooms / scenes and we switch between them. We can click on highlighted objects and use the items in our inventory (or combine them). Puzzles are easy and you get to see a surprising (and very emotional) ending that might just not be everybody's cup of tea. It's a great little game with achievements easy to obtain. If you have 15-20 minutes to spare go for it.

[b]Coffee Talk Episode 2: Hibiscus and Butterfly[/b] is a stand-alone sequel to 2020‚Äôs Coffee Talk, players can jump straight into this new game but those who have played the first instalment will recognise some familiar faces in the caf√©!

It is a wonderful new addition to the series that boasts fantastic casual gameplay, and eclectic and interesting characters in a fantastical yet everyday setting. The retro-style pixel graphics are stunning and make good use of colour to add to the relaxing ambience along with the charming lo-fi soundtrack. Overall, this is a quality experience that I‚Äôd highly recommend to fans of the first game or anyone looking for a laid-back but engaging experience.

[b]WANT TO KNOW MORE?[/b]
My full review of this game where I go into gameplay, narrative and styling is available on [url=https://indie-hive.com/coffee-talk-episode-2/]Indie Hive[/url].

"OXTO" is an intense, adrenaline-fueled, twin-stick-shooter-roguelike with similar graphics and gameplay as "Hotline Miami", but with its own gorgeous style and the addition of bullet-time, dodgeroll and (a much needed) health bar.

The visuals are viscerally noir, the soundtrack slaps you in the face just right, the story and lore of the mysterious entity manifesting as the mansion and the Sisyphus-like task at hand (which is a meta-comment for the genre) is told well and with a grain of existential dread.

Unfortunately, the first area of the game can get old when you already did various runs and then it is very hard to die to the first boss, which seems a bit of a chore. Also some of the drinks (skills) seem superior to others, but these two complaints are just a minor setback.

I still wholeheartedly recommend this for any fan of these genres or stylish games in general!

Overall a lot of fun despite these issues. I play other games like princes maker but this definitely has a lot of content and things that keep it unique. There are over 200 achievements so I will certainly be playing for a while.

I want to put this as meh and not really a no for the recommendation. At its core it is a platformer (Vampire) survivor clone and it isn't bad and I hope it gets polished later on. You level up and build up your character while having some meta progression. 

Many of the flaws from this game comes from the lack of content, from leveling up you can literally pick every skill available in the level up selection. Monster, boss and meta progression are also very limited. When you start progressing towards the higher difficulty, the game is not very optimized and I've had a fair bit of frame drops mainly because my character was firing way too many shots per second and had way too many books shooting on screen as well.

The game isn't bad in any way shape or form but it just isn't quite there yet. Even at 5 bucks, you could find plenty of other survivor clones with much more content and better optimization, such as Brotato or Rogue: Genesia.
